titleStmt.title: The second part of Symboleography, newly corrected and amended, and very much enlarged in all the foure seuerall treatises. 1. Of fines and concordes. 2. Of common recoueries. 3. Of offences and indictments. 4. Of compromises and arbitrements. Wereunto is annexed another treatise of equitie, the iurisdiction, and proceedings of the high Court of Chauncerye: of supplications, bils, and aunsweres, and of certaine writs and commissions issuing thence, and there also retornable: likewise much augmented with diuers presidents, very necessary for the same purpose, beginning at the 144. section, and continuing to the end of bils and aunsweres. Hereunto is also added a table for the more easy and readie finding of the matters herein contayned: the new additions hauing therein this marke * set before them
Symbolaeographia. Part 2

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

1. Of Fines and Concordes.
2. Of Common Recoueries.
3. Of Offences and Indictments.
4. Of Compromi≈øes and Arbitrements. Whereunto is annexed another Treati≈øe of Equitie, the Iuri≈ødiction, and Proceedings of the high Court of Chauncerye: Of Supplications, Bils, and Aun≈øweres, And of certaine Writs and Commi≈ø≈øions i≈ø≈øuing thence, and there al≈øo retornable: Likewi≈øe much augmented with diuers pre≈øidents, very nece≈ø≈øary for the ≈øame purpo≈øe, beginning at the 144. Section, and continuing to the end of Bils and Aun≈øweres. div.head: Viro Iuri≈øprudentiae & pietatis laude illu≈øtri≈øtri≈øsimo EDVVARDO COKE Armigero, ≈øereni≈øsimae Reginae Maiestatis Procuratori ≈øummo, WILL. WEST veram exoptat foelicitatem.
div.p:
OVum ijs fere omnibus, qui lucubrationes ≈øuas de aliquo di≈øciplinae genere in publicum proferunt, in more po≈øitum e≈ø≈øe videtur (vir illustri≈ø≈øime) vt in Epistolis ≈øuis nuncupatorijs duo poti≈ø≈øimum ≈øequantur: vnum vt illum ip≈øum, cuius patrocinio niti ≈øtatnunt, dignis laudibus efferant; alterum, vt operas ip≈øas grato encomio afficiant: erunt forta≈ø≈øe nonnulli, qui idem a me faciendum arbitrabuntur; a quibus tamen ego longe diuer≈øum ≈øentio. Vtrum
que enim vt vellem maxime certe non po≈ø≈øem: Nam ab hoc, ingenioli mei tenuitas: ab illo, pudor quidem ingenitus me remoratur. Et vero, ≈øi in laudes tuas excurrerem longius, vereor, vt & ip≈øe hoc non patereris, Et ego, cum corporis, tum animi dotium, quas natura affatim in te qua≈øieffudi≈ø≈øe videtur, multitudine obrutus, ne
que quid prae ceteris dicendum, ne
que quomodo finis faciendus ≈øit, facile reperire po≈ø≈øem: ≈øiue de eximia iuris nostri ≈øcientia, ≈øiue de ≈øingulari pietate tua dixero, quas in te (vir ornati≈ø≈øime) aetas etiamnum integra, tam mature nobis exhibuit, vt ad qua≈øuis respraeclaras gerendas, non factus, ≈øed natus, e≈ø≈øe videaris. Quarum veluti ≈øuffragijs ad praeclaramunera iamdudum euectus, alij≈ø
que , etiam grandaeuis, praelatus≈øis. Sed quidquid ip≈øe de te dixero, dicturus illud ≈øum tenuius, minu≈ø
que ≈øplendid√®, quam dici debui≈ø≈øet, & rei dignitas postularet. Ita
que malui≈øilere, ac ≈øingulares illas animi, corpori≈øque tui dotes ≈øuspicere, quam nihil dicendo, infantiam meam prodere. De opella autem mea glorio≈øius dicere nihil attinet: Illius enim argumentum eiu≈ømodi e≈øt, vt nullius adeo commendatione magnopere egere videatur, quippe quodde ijs rebus tractat, quae ad pacem & concordiam, cum con≈øtituendam, tum restituendam, ≈øpectant maxime: ≈øiue enim, tractatum primum de finibus: ≈øiue alterum illum de recuperationibus, quae dicuntur: ≈øiue tertium de criminibus & accu≈øationibus inde oriundis: ≈øiue postremum de compromi≈ø≈øis & arbitrijs, contempleris, nihil aliud, quam quietem & tranquillitatem humanae ≈øocietatis, ≈øpirare videntur omnia. Nam arbitria,
lites, ea≈øque ≈øu≈øcitatas, leuiter componunt: fines & recuperationes, dominia & proprietates firmant: accu≈øationes, nocentum peccata detegunt, vt nocentes ip≈øi vel ≈øanentur, vele medio tollantur, ne istorum virus proximos quo≈øque vel conficiat vel inficiat. Et certe haud ≈øcio, an pace quicquam augustius ad veram ≈øingulorum felicitatem excogitari poterit, illa namque nobi≈øcum commorante omnibus bonis ac commodis abundamus, atque ex animi ≈øententia ≈øuccedunt omnia. At ≈øi dulci≈ø≈øima eius con≈øuetudine priuemur, eaque a nobis exulet, ≈øtatim bello, omnibus malis atque aerumnis expo≈øiti, vitam long√® mi≈øerimam ducimus. Modum autem, quo haec tractaui, laudare, meum non e≈øt. Quod ≈øi enim is eiu≈ømodi e≈øt, qui tibi, alij≈øque bonis, & doctis viris placeat, ≈øatis per ≈øe ip≈øum commendatus erit: ≈øin minus, vana rei non probandae commendatio, ip≈øam laudabiliorem non efficiet. De animo autem meo, hoc tua pace liber√® effari libet, volui≈ø≈øe me prode≈ø≈øe quamplurimis, ijs autem praecipue, qui prima iuris nostri tyrocinia exercent. Quod vt melius praestare po≈ø≈øem, ista volui qualicunque methodo: cum profect√≤ nulla mihi videatur dicendi ars alia ni≈øi methodus, quae a prioribus natura, ad proxima: quae a notioribus, ad minus nota: quae a generalibus, ad ≈øpecialia: quae a finitis, ad infinita: quaeque ita demum ab instituto aliquo genere ad media, tum definiendo, tum diuidendo, tran≈øit, donec tandem in exemplorum infinitate con≈øistat, quam quidem disponendi rationem tibi (vir ornati≈ø≈øime) non ingratam fore confido, cum omnes tuae disputationes, atque adeo dicta omnia, illam ip≈øam ≈øuaui≈ø≈øime ≈øemper ≈øpirare videntur. Te igitur horum maecenatem rogo, pro genuina & laudati≈ø≈øima illa tua in rem literariam, literato≈ø
que omnes promouendi, promptitudine, & verae pacis amore ≈øingulari, acerrimo
que tuo in delicta odio, ≈øi alia reipublicae grauiora negotia non impediant, hunc libellum cogno≈øcere, ≈øu≈øcipere, ac tueri velis; quo mihi animos ad haec augenda & perpolienda, & hijs maiora alacriter aggredienda, addas. Te (vir iuri≈øcon≈øulti≈ø≈øime) aeternae pacis author, ad ≈øui nominis gloriam, eccle≈øiae commodum, & reipublicae tranquillitatem, quam diuti≈ø≈øime ≈øeruet incolumem:

closer.dateline: Ex aedibus meis Firbectien≈øibus haud longe a Doncastria burgo, in agro Eboracen≈øi, postridie calendas Maias; Anno ≈øalutis per Christi ≈øolius ≈øanguinem restitutae. 1594.

div.head: SYMBOLEOGRAPHY Of Fines and Concordes.
The definition of Fines.
div.p: FOra≈ømuch as we haue alreadie in our fir≈øt part Sect. 1. of Symboleography ≈øhewed the forme of diuers Conditions and Couenants, a≈øwell for the leuying of Fines of lands and tenementes, as al≈øo to ray≈øe and limit the v≈øes thereof: It now ≈øeemeth nece≈ø≈øarie to ≈øhew how the Notes of writs of Couenants and Concordes for Fines, with other nece≈ø≈øarie circum≈øtances concerning the ≈øame are to be made. Wherefore let vs fir≈øt learne what, and how worthy things Fines be.
Tremayle 21. E. fol. 4. tearmeth Fines, couenants made before Iu≈øtices, and entred of record.
Browne ≈øaith, Fines be fructus, exitus, & finis effectus Legis, Plow. fol. 357.

Glanuil in his eight booke and fir≈øt chapter tearmeth a Fine Amicabilis compo≈øitio & finalis concordia ex con≈øen≈øu & licentia domini Regis vel eius Iu≈øticiariorum. And Bracton tractatu quinto Lib. 5. ca. 28. Sect. 7. de Exceptionibus ≈øaith, finis ideo dicitur finalis concordia, quia imponit finem litibus, & e≈øt exceptio peremptoria.
And Glanuil cap. 3. Lib. 9. ≈øaith, Talis concordia finalis dicitur, eo quod finem imponit negotio, adeo vt neutra pars litigantium ab eo de caetero poterit recedere.

In which bookes may be ≈øeene thauncient forme of leuying Fines & their great antiquitie: for they be as auncient as any Court of Record, Plow. fol. 357. a. 368. b. which without que≈øtion were long before the Conque≈øt.

So that Fines hauing their commencement of Record long before the Conque≈øt, euer ≈øince haue remayned in great e≈øtimation, as appeareth by a Fine leuied before the Conque≈øt touching the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Abbey of Crowland, and diuers other auncient Fines leuied before that time yet extant, Plow. 357. a. 368. b.

But chiefely we are to con≈øider their effects, which be to make certeintie and a≈ø≈øurance to the parties concerning their e≈øtates in lands and tenements, and to end contention, and breed peace and ≈øecuritie to all men.

As appeareth by the Statute‚ñ™ de Finibus 27. Edw. 1. Stat. 1. cap. 1. wherein be the≈øe words, Quia fines in Curia no≈øtra leuati finem litibus imponere debent, & imponunt: Ideo fines vocaÃÑtur maxime cum po≈øt Duellum & magnam A≈ø≈øisam in ≈øuo ca≈øu vltimum locum finalem teneant imperpetuum: with which Statute agreeth Bracton tractatu 5. Lib. 5. cap. 28. Sect. 7. de Exceptionibus.
And therefore by thauncient law, Fine and Nonclaime by the ≈øpace of a yeare and a day was a peremptory barre to all men, which was abrogated by the ≈øtatute made 34. Ed. 3. cap. 16.

And at this day Fines be of great force, pui≈ø≈øance, and worthine≈ø≈øe: for being leuied and ingro≈ø≈øed with proclamatioÃÑs, according to the ≈øtatute of 4. H. 7. cap. 24. 1. R. 3. cap. 7. 32. H. 8. cap. 36. & 31. Eliz. Reg. cap. 2. They are finall endes, and ≈øufficiently conclude, barre, and di≈øcharge for euer a≈øwell parties and priuies as e≈øtrangers to the ≈øame, except women couert (other then beene parties to the fines) and euery other per≈øon at the time of the leuying of the ≈øame fine being within the age of xxi. yeares, or in pri≈øon, or out of the Realme, or of vn≈øound mind, and not parties to ≈øuch fines: Sauing vnto e≈øtrangers to ≈øuch fines ≈øuch right, title, claime, and intere≈øt, as they haue to the tenemeÃÑts therein contained at the time of thingro≈ø≈øing thereof: ≈øo that they pur≈øue the ≈øame by action, or lawful entrie within fiue yeeres next after proclamations thereupon made according to the ≈øaid ≈øtatutes: And ≈øauing to all other per≈øons ≈øuch action, right, title, claime, and intere≈øt, in, or to the tenements in ≈øuch fines mencioned, as fir≈øt ≈øhall grow, remaine, di≈øcend, or come to them after the ≈øaid fine ingro≈ø≈øed and proclamations made, by force of any cau≈øe or matter had or made before the ≈øaid fine leuied: ≈øo that they pur≈øue their action, right, or title within fiue yeeres next after that it is to them accrued.

By which authorities we gather that fines are nothing els, but In≈øtruments 20. A≈ø≈ø. p. 1. 26. A≈ø≈ø. p. 37. Dyer fol. 179. Plow. fol. 146. of record of agreements coÃÑcerning lands, tenements, or hereditaments, duely made by the Queenes con≈øent & licence, & knowledged by the parties to the ≈øame vpoÃÑ a writ of Couenant, a writ of Right, a writ of Cu≈øtomes & Seruices, Warrantia chartae thereof, or ≈øuch like, before the Iu≈øtices of the Common place, or others thereunto authorized, & ingro≈ø≈øed of record in the ≈øame Court, to end all coÃÑtrouer≈øies therof both betweene them≈øelues which be parties and priuies to the ≈øame, and all e≈øtrangers not ≈øuing or clayming in due time.

The≈øe Fines de≈øtroy e≈øtates taile, (other then ≈øuch as be made by the King, the reuer≈øion being in the King, 32. H. 8. ca. 36. And other then fines of lands re≈øtrayned from alienation by act of parliament, 32. H. 8. cap. 36. Or leuied by an Intrudor of lands ≈øei≈øed into the kings hands, as by an heire which holdeth in Capite before Liuery ≈øued 1. H. 7. ca. 5.
for by the Praerogatiue cap. 13. by his entrie he gayneth no freehold.) And in time become perpetuall barres again≈øt all men, end ≈øtrife, make peace, breede ≈øecuritie and tranquillitie, which is the very fruite, effect, and end of all godly Lawes.

div.head: Of the parties to fines.
div.p: IN euery Fine two things are principally to be regarded, the per≈øons, Sect. 2. and the action.
Per≈øons chiefely regarded in fines be the parties to the fines and the Iudges.
Parties to the fines be the Cognizor and the Cognizee, which are thefficient cau≈øes thereof.
The Cognizor is he which doth knowledge the fine.
The Cognizee is he to whom the fine is leuied.
In the parties 3. things are ≈øpecially to be regarded: Their Capacities, Names, and E≈øtates.

Touching the Capacitie of the Cognizor it is to be con≈øidered whether he be a per≈øon able to leuie a fine or no: namely whether he be void of all ≈øuch impediments naturall and ciuill as may hinder him in doing thereof.

div.head: What per≈øons may be Cognizors, and what not?
div.p: ALl per≈øons male & female may be Cognizors, but ≈øuch as are prohibited Sect. 3‚ñ™ that to doe by nature or law.
By nature through defect of the nund, or of the bodie, but no longer then ≈øuch defect endureth.
This defect of the mind is either naturall or ca≈øuall.

div.head: Of Infancie.
div.p: DEfects of the minde by nature is by age which is of Infants, Sect. 4. that is per≈øons vnder thage of xxi. yeeres, as by Ideocy which ought not to be Cognizors, becau≈øe the law intendeth they want vnder≈øtanding and di≈øcretion what to do in this behalfe: Yet if a fine be leuied by an Infant, it cannot be reuer≈øed but by him≈øelfe by writ of Error during his infancy, that the Court may ≈øee him and thereby iudge his age, 50. E. 3. 5. 17. E. 3. 52. and 78.

Impediments of the mind ca≈øuall ≈øuch as affect, are furious madde men, Lunatiques, Ideots, men hauing the Lethargie, whereunto may (as it ≈øeemeth) be added doting old per≈øons wanting di≈øcretion, men drunken, who ought not to be Cognizors, for their fines are not reuer≈øable, becau≈øe the fine it ≈øelfe argueth their habilities, for the law intendeth that Iudges will receiue no cognizances of ≈øuch per≈øons, 17. E. 3. 5. and 78. 17. A≈ø≈ø. 17.

div.head: Defects of the bodie.
div.p: DEfects of the bodie be ≈øuch infirmities thereof by which the principall Sect. 5. ≈øences nece≈ø≈øarie for vnder≈øtanding and to declare their con≈øents are wanting: Of which ≈øort be ≈øuch as are blind, deafe, or dumbe, naturally.
But per≈øons blind, deafe, or dumbe accidentally may make cognizance if they can expre≈ø≈øe their meaning by writing.

div.head: Impediments legall or ciuill.
div.p: LEgall impediments be when ≈øuch per≈øons be prohibited by law as Sect. 6. by nature are able to leuie fines.
And they are either by rea≈øon of ≈øubiection or ioint power.

div.head: Of legall ≈øubiection.
div.p: SUbiection legall is when per≈øons be vnder the rule of others, as a Sect. 7. feme couert to her hu≈øband, 2. H. 5. 9. E. 3. 28. A villein to his Lord 33. E. 3. Per≈øons ciuilly dead, as Friers, Nunnes, Monkes, Channons profe≈ø≈øed, and other like ≈øuper≈øticious votaries, who are in ≈øubiection to their Soueraignes, 14. H. 8. 16. 2. R. 2. 5.

div.head: Of couerture.
div.p: ANd therefore a feme couert within age ought not to leuie a fine, Sect. 8. for that ≈øhe cannot reuer≈øe it during the couerture, nor after if the couerture continue till ≈øhe be of full age, 50. E. 3. 5. 27. A≈ø≈ø. pla. 53.
And a feme couert ought not to leuie a fine but with her right hu≈øband, 7. H. 4. 23. 42. E. 3. 20.

But a fine leuied by a feme couert without her hu≈øband of her owne landes wherein ≈øhe hath fee ≈øimple, is an e≈øtoppell again≈øt her and her heires, if her hu≈øband auoid it not by entrie, or otherwi≈øe, as he may during his wiues life, and after her death during his owne life, as if he be tenant by the Curte≈øie, 17. E. 3. 52. and 78. 17. A≈ø≈ø. 17. 7. H. 4. 23. But if lyuing her fir≈øt hu≈øband ≈øhe take a ≈øecond hu≈øband, and with him and by his name knowledge a fine, this fine ≈øhall not bind her, becau≈øe ≈øhe is mi≈ønamed, 7. H. 4. 22. and 23. Yet if ≈øhe with her right hu≈øband by a wrong chri≈øtian name leuie a fine, ≈øhe is e≈øtopped during her life,
‚Ä¢ . A≈ø≈ø. pla. 11. Brooke Fines 117.
A feme couert mu≈øt beware how ≈øhe with her hu≈øband do leuie a fine of her Iointure, lea≈øt ≈øhe thereby lo≈øe her dower, Trin. 19. Eliz. Dyer fol. 359. pla 49.
Neyther ought the hu≈øband without his wife to leuie any fine of her lands, for ≈øhe and her heires may auoid it after his death, 32. H. 8. cap. 28. 12. E. 4. 12. 42. E. 3. 20.

div.head: Villeines.
div.p: ANd Villeines by knowledging ≈øuch fines ≈øhould preiudice their Sect. 9. Lords, thereby bereauing them of the landes aliened, for ≈øuch fines be good.

div.head: Per≈øons dead in law.
div.p: ANd fines leuied by per≈øons ciuilly dead are vtterly void. Sect. 10.

div.head: Impri≈øonment.
div.p: ANd if men compelled by threatnings or inpri≈øonment ≈øhould be Sect. 11. admitted to leuie fines, they ≈øhould thereby be barred, becau≈øe the law intendeth ≈øuch per≈øons are at libertie when they knowledge fines 17. E. 3. 52. 78. 17. A≈ø≈ø. 17.

div.head: Of per≈øons hauing ioint power.
div.p: PEr≈øons prohibited to be Cognizors by rea≈øon of ioint power, are Sect. 12. they that haue ioint power and aucthoritie with others, as the ≈øingle members of euery Corporation or Society, As a Bi≈øhop without his Deane and Chapter, A Deane without his Chapter, An Abbot or Prior without his Couent, A Par≈øon, Vicar, Prebendary, or Chauntry prie≈øt without their Ordinarie, A Maior without his Cominaltie, Ma≈øters of colledges without their Felowes, And of other Societies incorporate, may not leuie fines, Plow. 375. b. 11. Elizab. fol. 538. a 21. Eliz. 21. E. 4. 13. 11. H. 4. 68. 12. H. 4. 11. & 12. 38. E. 3. 33. Plow. fol. 538. a. 20. Eliz.

div.head: Of the estates of Cognizors.
div.p: ALbeit euery fine be good to bind the parties, yet for the validitie Sect. 13. of the fine it is conuenient that either the Cognizor or the Cognizee be ≈øeazed of the lands aliened, 41. E. 3. 14. 22. H. 6. 13.

For the fine is void if neither of the parties be ≈øeazed at the leuying thereof, 41. E. 3. 14. 33. H. 6. 18. 3. H. 6. 27. 27. H. 8. 4. and 20. 37. H. 6. 34. 13. A≈ø≈ø. p. 8. 3. H. 7. 9. 5. E. 3. 22. H. 6. 57.

Yet the vouchee after he hath entred into the warrantie may leuy a fine vnto the demandant, though in facto neither of them is ≈øeazed: For ≈øuch vouchee is tenant in law and may confe≈ø≈øe the action, becau≈øe of the priuitie betweene him and the demandant. But a fine by him ≈øo leuied to an e≈øtranger is void, 8. H. 4. 5. 5. H. 7. 40.

Per≈øons attained or wayued in per≈øonall actions may alien by fine or otherwi≈øe, for their e≈øtates remayne in them ≈øtill, though they thereby forfeyt the profites of their landes, 9. H. 6. 20. 21. H. 7. 7.

And per≈øons attainted of Felony or Trea≈øon may not be Cognizors, by rea≈øon that by their offences their e≈øtates be forfeyted, But if they do, their fines be good again≈øt all per≈øons but the King and the Lord of whom the lands beholdeÃÑ for their times, 8. A≈ø≈ø. pla. 25. for their e≈øtats
remaine in them during their liues.

Al≈øo tenant for life may leuie a fine ≈øur graunt & releas of the lands which he holdeth for life, to hold to the Cognizee for life of the tenant for life, and it is no forfeiture, 44. E. 3. 36. But if the e≈øtate were larger, or the fine ≈øur cognizance de droit come ceo que &c. it were a forfeiture of his e≈øtate, 4. H. 7. fol.

The ≈øame law is of ≈øuch ≈øins by tenant in tayle after po≈ø≈øibility, tenant in dower, or by the curte≈øie, 39. E. 3. 16. But ≈øuch fine of a reÃÑt ≈øeemeth to be no forfeiture, 2. H. 5. 7. Yet a particuler tenaÃÑt, as in dower, by curte≈øie, or for life, cannot by fine graunt & ≈øurrender their e≈øtates to thowner of the reuer≈øion or remainder, but may by fine graunt and releas the ≈øame, 17. E. 3. 62. 24. E. 3. 26. 20. E. 3. and 14. E. 3.
A tenant in commen or Iointenant may leuie a fyne of his part, 26. H. 8. 9.
So may a Coparcener of his part, Dyer 334. plac. 30. Pa≈øch. 16. Eliz.

A fine leuied by the heyre who is an Intrudor vpon the kings po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion is voyd per le Praerog. cap. 13. 1. H. 7. 5. 24. E. 3. 65. But if ≈øuch fine be leuied without intru≈øion, it bindeth the Cognizor and his heires, 1. H. 7. 5.

If a di≈ø≈øei≈øor leuie a fyne with proclamation, and the di≈ø≈øei≈øee within fiue yeares after do not enter or caime, he and his heires be barred for euer, Plowd. fol. 353. 11. Elizab. inter Stowell & Zouch.
Al≈øo fines may be leuied by the tenant in taile general, or ≈øpecial, And by tenant in fee ≈øimple, And by tenant in remainder or reuer≈øion.

p.hi: ¬∂ Hauing thus pa≈ø≈øed the capacities and e≈øtates of Cognizors, let vs haue con≈øideration how they may be named.

div.head: How Cognizors are to be named.
div.p: TOuching the names whereby parties to fines ought to be named, Sect. 14. for ≈øo much as names be to no other end in≈øerted into fines and other writings, then that it may be certeinly knowen, who be the parties thereunto, it is requi≈øite that they be certeinly named by their right names of bapti≈øme and ≈øurnames, whether the ≈øame be King, Prince, Duke, Marque≈ø≈øe, Earle, Vicont, Baron, Lord, or Knight, which be names of dignitie, (≈øome of which are ≈øometimes named without their Surnames: as Georg. Comes SalopÃÑ without his ≈øurname, IoheÃÑs Dux Lanca≈øtrÃÑ,) or he be an E≈øquire or Gentleman, which be names of wor≈øhip, nobilitie, and honor, 14. H. 6. 15. 21. E. 4. 84.

Who≈øe addicions neuerthele≈ø≈øe of curte≈øie are communly v≈øed in fines: as Io. Byron Miles, H. D. armig. T. L. generÃÑ, Or if he be a ‚Ä¢ eoman, hu≈øbandman, artificer, laborer, or any Eccle≈øia≈øticall per≈øon:
as Archbi≈øhop, Bi≈øhop, Archdeacon, Deane, Par≈øon, Vicar, Clerke, &c. Or any Corporation, or bodie ciuill, politique, or corporate, hauing couent or common ≈øeale: as Baylife and Burge≈ø≈øes, Maior and Comminaltie, or any other fraternitie or brotherhood, 11. H. 4. 44. 12. H. 4. 20. 14. H. 4. 21. 7. H. 6. 27.

And albeit it be not nece≈ø≈øarie alwayes in fines to giue the parties their proper additions of place, dignitie, e≈øtate, degree, mi≈øterie, or occupation: Yet if there be two or more in one pari≈øhe of one name and ≈øurname, it ≈øeemeth requi≈øite for di≈øtinction ≈øake, to giue them ≈øome additions &c. as I. S. ≈øenior or iunior &c. As if a man haue two ≈øonnes of one name, or the father and his ≈øonne be of one name, the father ≈øhall not carie the addition of ≈øenior, but the ≈øonne of iunior, and not the elder brother but the yonger, 37. H. 6. 29. 47. E. 3. 16.

div.head: What per≈øons may be Cognizees in fines, and ≈øecondly by what names they must be named.
div.p: ALl ≈øuch per≈øons as may be grauntees or take contracts, may beeSect. 15. cognizees, as per≈øons of full age, Infants, femes couert, madde men, lunatique, ideots, men impri≈øoned, men without the Realme, And all Corporations and ciuill bodies, men attainted of felonie or trea≈øon, men outlawed in per≈øonall actions, ba≈øtards, clerkes conuict, villeines, aliens, &c.

And if a fine be leuied to a feme couert, ≈øhe needeth not to bee examined, becau≈øe ≈øhe taketh by the fine: And if ≈øhe had any better e≈øtate before the fine, the fine ≈øhall not conclude her to claime it, 3. H. 6. 42. 41. E. 3. 7. 50. E. 3. 9. 24. E. 3. 62.

Neither ≈øhall an Infant being cognizee „Äà‚óä„Äâ
24. E. 3. 62. becau≈øe the fine is for his benefite. Tenant „Äà‚óä„Äâ may be cognizee in a fine, by which the cognizee doth confe≈ø≈øe all his fight, which he hath in the lands, to be the right of the tenant for life, and relea≈øe and quite claime to him and his heires, and not commit any forfeiture, for thereby his former e≈øtate is not changed, and it may inure to him in reuer≈øion or remainder, 1. H. 7. fol. 5.

And an Abbot, Deane and Chapter, Maior and Cominaltie, & ≈øuch like CorporatioÃÑs, may be cognizees in fines: But before the ingro≈ø≈øing of the fine to ≈øuch Corporation, a writ ought to be directed to the Iu≈øtices of the common place, quod permittant finem illum leuari, 5. H. 7. 25. 19. H. 6. 25. A Prior may be cognizee, 22. E. 4. 15. E. 4. 22.
But per≈øons ciuilly dead, as Monkes, Channons, and Friers, can not be cognizees, becau≈øe they be vnder the rule of others, and want ciuill capacitie, 5. H. 7. 25. 19. H. 6. 25. By what names.

2 Cognizees in fines mu≈øt be named by their right proper names &
≈øurnames: for a fine being leuied to A. and Sibell his wife, (where her Chri≈øtian name was I≈øabell) was holden void. 1. A≈ø≈ø. pla. 1. See the Section how the Cognizors are to be named, and that will ≈øatisfie you for the naming of Cognizees.

div.head: Before what per≈øons Fines may be knowledged.
div.p: HAuing thus peru≈øed the capacities, e≈øtates, & names of cognizorsSect. 16. and cognizees, it is time to inquire of the Iudges, before whom this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe may be handled: Touching which it is to be noted, that of the≈øe, ≈øome are Iudges only at the time of the cognizances & certificat thereof.
And others at the time of the Concord.

And Iudges of the cognizances, are ≈øuch per≈øons as haue power to take ≈øuch cognizance, eyther by vertue of their offices, or by ≈øome commi≈ø≈øion generall or ≈øpeciall, graunted vnto them by her Maie≈øtie out of the high court of Chauncery.
All or two of the Iu≈øtices of the Common place may in open court take knowledge of fines, and record them by vertue of their offices, 15. E. 2. cap.

And the chiefe Iu≈øtice of the Common place, by the priuiledge and prerogatiue of his place and office, may take cogni≈øance of fines in any place out of the court and certifie the ≈øame, without writ of Dedimus pote≈øtatem, Dyer fol. 224. pla. 31.

And it ≈øeemeth by the Statute 15. E. 2. that if the parties be not able to trauell, two of the Iu≈øtices of the common Bench, with the con≈øent of the re≈øt, or one of them with a Knight, may go vnto the parties, and receiue and certifie their cognizances into the ≈øaid Court, without any Dedimus pote≈øtatem to enable them thereunto. But this cour≈øe is long ≈øithence di≈øcontinued.

And it ≈øeemeth that ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øtices of A≈ø≈øi≈øes by the generall wordes of their Patents may take and certifie cognizances of fines without any ≈øpeciall Dedimus pote≈øtatem for the wordes be in effect as followeth, that is to ≈øay: Necnon ad recipiend' omnes fines, concordias, & recognitiones in circuitu ≈øuo, coniunctim & diui≈øim recognitÃÑ pro illa vice in circuituillo, non ob ‚Ä¢ lante aliquo actu, ≈øtatuto, ≈øiue ordinatione in contrarium &c.

Yet ≈øuch Iu≈øtices v≈øe not now to certifie them without a ≈øpeciall writ of Dedimus pote≈øtatem, ≈øued forth of the Chauncery, directed vnto them, and giuing them therby power, to take and certifie ≈øuch cognizances as they haue alreadie taken, Dyer fol. 224. plac. 51. 5. Eliz. ‚Ä¢ . H. 7. 9. And fines haue beene leuied before Iu≈øtices Errants, Lib. Intrac' titulo Scire fac' in Ayde 2.

div.head: Of a Dedimus potestatem de Fine leuando.
div.p: A Special commi≈ø≈øion for a fine is a writ of Dedimus pote≈øtatem directedSect‚ñ™ 17. to ≈øome per≈øons to take the cogni≈øances of the cogni≈øours which is graunted out of the Chauncery, when Cogni≈øors of fines by rea≈øon of infirmitie, or other rea≈øonable cau≈øe, cannot come to the Court there to make cogni≈øance thereof. This Dedimus pote≈øtatem mu≈øt containe the ≈øub≈øtance of the writ of Couenant, and recite that it is thereof depending betweene the parties bearing Te≈øte after the writ of Couenant, which writ of Dedimus pote≈øtatem ought to be directed to men of good credite & con≈øcience, and exptert in the lawes, who mu≈øt certifie the ≈øame with the cogni≈øances to the Iu≈øtices of the common Plees, as ≈øhalbe ≈øhewed hereafter. And euery ≈øuch Dedimus pote≈øtatem to a ≈øpecial commi≈ø≈øion mu≈øt be ≈øigned by the Lord Chancelor, or Lord Keeper, and Lord chiefe Iu≈øtice of the common plees, or by ≈øome of the Iu≈øtices of the circuit where the land lyeth.

But now many writs of Dedimus pote≈øtatem to take knowledge of fines bee directed to men of meane degree and ≈ømall knowledge, with whom ≈øometimes for fa≈øhion ≈øake in ≈øuch commi≈ø≈øions be ioined Lords, Knights, and other of good credite: but be ≈øeldome v≈øed in the execution thereof. By meanes wherof oftentimes this bu≈øines is vnduely effected, and Recogni≈øances of femes couert within age, and of other weomen, neuer duely examined, and of Infantes, as al≈øo of madde men, Lunatiques, Ideots, and men impri≈øoned, are ≈øometimes certified which would neuer be ≈øuffered, if ≈øuch Cogni≈øors were for that purpo≈øe either brought into the Court, or before any of the Iu≈øtices thereof, or before any Seriant, or Knight, or man of good con≈øcience and di≈øcretion, who would ≈øoone perceiue their imperfections, and therefore refu ‚Ä¢ e to take their cogni≈øances in ≈øo weightie matters as fines be, which be the mo≈øt binding barres in the law. Great care and heed therfore in my conceipt is to be had, to whom ≈øuch aucthoritie is committed, lea≈øt it be ≈øo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ u≈øed as is aboue≈øaid. And writs of Error haue bin brought, becau≈øe fines haue bin knowledged by Dedimus pote≈øtatem before ≈øuch as were neither Iudge, Abbot, Knight, nor Seriant at the law, And therefore ≈øuch recogni≈øances haue bin refu≈øed, Br. Fines 120.
A Iu≈øtice or other per≈øon being cogni≈øee in a fine, may not take cogni≈øance thereof him≈øelfe: for if he ≈øo doe, the fine thereupon leuied is void, 8. H. 6. 21.

And when any cogni≈øance of fines is taken, it ≈øeemeth conuenient, that the per≈øons, before whom they be knowledge, do ≈øigne the note of the cogni≈øance as it is commonly v≈øed for the credite thereof, Dyer fol. 320. P. 19. H. 15. Eliz.

And now by a late order, all fines taken by Dedimus pote≈øtatem by
him that is not Iu≈øtice of A≈ø≈øi≈øe in that circuit where the laÃÑd lyeth, mu≈øt be ≈øigned by a Iu≈øtice of that circuit, Dyer fol. 220. pla. 15. The forme of the Dedimus pote≈øtateÃÑ appeareth among≈øt the adiuncts of concords.

div.head: Iudges, to whom cogni≈øances are to be certified, and before whom they are to be recorded.
div.p: IVdges for the recording of fines by the Iu≈øtices of the common pleesSect‚ñ™ 18. onely, 15. E. 2. cap. And therefore as is ≈øaid, all cogni≈øances thereof mu≈øt be certified thither, for in that Court onely all fines are to be leuied, Notwith≈øtanding 36. H. 6. 34.
And by ≈øpecial graunt a fine may be leuied in a ba≈øe Court, 44. Ed. 3. 38.
But fines leuied in Auncient deme≈øne by any cu≈øtome ≈øeeme voide, 44. E. 3. 38. And ≈øo in other inferiour Courts, 50. A≈ø≈ø. pl. 9.
Al≈øo by the ≈øtatute of 2. E. 6. ca. 28. fines may beleuied in the county Palantine of Che≈øter.
And by 37. H. 8. cap. 19. fines may be leuied of lands in the Countie Palantine of Lanca≈øter.
And by the ≈øtatute of 5. Eliz. cap. 27. fines may be leuied within the county Palantine of Dure≈øme.

p.hi: ¬∂ Hauing thus r ‚Ä¢ n ouer the di≈øcour≈øe of the per≈øons v≈øed in fines, order requireth that we ≈øhould now ≈øet vpon the verie actions of Fines them≈øelues.

div.head: Of the diui≈øion of fines.
div.p: EVery fine therefore is either witohut proclamations, or with proclamations.Sect‚ñ™ 19. Fines deuided.

At this day a fine without proclamation, which is al≈øo termed a fineA fine without ploclamation. at the common law, is ≈øuch a fine, as is leuied, after ≈øuch maner & forme as they were v≈øually leuied before, 4. H. 7. ca. 24. vpon which no proclamations were made, which fines do ≈øtill remaine of ≈øuch force, as they were at the coÃÑmon law, to di≈øcontinue the e≈øtate of the Cogni≈øor, if theyDi≈øcontinuance. be executed, 7. Ed. 3. fol. 35. 1. R. 3. cap. 7. Dyer fol. 216. p. 54. 4. Elizab. Plow. fol. 265. b. 4. H. 7. cap. 24.

A fine with proclamations (the ≈øame is al≈øo termed a fine accordingA fine with proclamation. to the ≈øtatute) is a fine leuied with proclamation after the forme & maner ordeined by the ≈øtatutes made 4. H. 7. cap. 24. 1. R. 3. cap. 7. Mar. ca. 7. 32. H. 8. cap. 36. 31. Eliz. cap. 2. Plow. fol. 265. b

div.head: Of fines executed, and executory.
div.p: ANd euery fine, a≈øwel with proclamation as without, is either executedSect‚ñ™ 20. A fine executed. or executory.

A fine executed is ≈øuch a fine, as of his owne force giueth a pre≈øent po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion (at the lea≈øt in law) vnto the Cogni≈øee, ≈øo that he needeth no writ of Habere facias ≈øei≈øinam for the execution of the ≈øame fine, but may enter, of which ≈øort is a fine ≈øur cogni≈øance de droit come ceo que il ad de ≈øon done, which is in verie deed the ≈øure≈øt fine of all, 8. H. 4. 8. 41. E. 3. 14. 42. E. 3. 5. 46. E. 3. 15. 50. E. 3. 9. 13. A≈ø≈ø. p. 8.

Fines executory be ≈øuch, as of their owne force do not execute the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øionA fine executorie. in the cogni≈øees, as fines ≈øur cogni≈øance de droit tantum, Fines ≈øur done, graunt, releas, confirmation, or render: for if ≈øuch fines be not leuied, or ≈øuch render made vnto them that be in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion at the time of the fines leuied, the cogni≈øees mu≈øt needs ≈øue writs of Habere facias ≈øei≈øinam, according to their ≈øeueral ca≈øes, for the obtaining of their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions. Neuertheles, if at the leuying of ≈øuch executory fines, the parties, vnto whom the ≈øtate is thereby limited, be in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the lands pa≈ø≈øed, be needeth no writ of execution for the ≈øame, for then ≈øuch fines doe inure by way of extingui≈øhment of right, but alter not the e≈øtate nor po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øionExtingui≈øhment. of the cogni≈øee, but perchance better it, 7. H. 7. 12. and 22. 2. E. 3. 6. 21. E. 3. 44. 8. H. 4. 8. 41. E. 3. 14. 7. H. 4. 23.

div.head: Againe ≈øome fines be ≈øingle, and ≈øome double.
div.p: A Sngle fine is ≈øuch a fine, by which nothing is graunted, or rendredSect‚ñ™ 21. A ≈øingle fine. backe againe by the Cogni≈øees, or any of them, to the cogni≈øors, or any of them, 8. H. 4. 8. 24. E. 3. 26.

A double fine is a fine containing a graunt and render back again eitherA double fine. of ≈øome rent, common, or other thing out of the land, or of the land it ≈øelfe, to all or ≈øome of the Cogni≈øors, for ≈øome e≈øtate, limitting thereby many times remainders to e≈øtraungers, which be not named in the writ of Couenant, 8. H. 4. 8. 24. E. 3. 26. and 35.

div.head: Of the parts of Fines, and of the writ of Couenant.
div.p: IN the forme of euery fine we are to con≈øider the principal parts thereof,Sect‚ñ™ 22. & their Adiuncts, both proper to euery part, and common to all.
The principal parts of fines be the writ or action whereupon the concordParts of fines. is made, and the Concord it lelfe.

div.head: Of writs whereupon fines are leuied.
div.p: THe writ is the verie ba≈øis, ground & foundation of the fine, wherbySect‚ñ™ 23. the parties haue day in court to leuy the ≈øame, & containeth the parties & things to be pa≈ø≈øed certeinely, And it is mo≈øt commonly a writ of Couenant, 35. H. 8. Br. Fines 116. Or a Warrantia chartae, 18. E. 4. 22. Or a writ of Right, Or a writ of Me≈ø ‚Ä¢ e, 26. A≈ø≈ø. pla. 37. Or a writ of Cu≈øtomes and ≈øeruices, 26. A≈ø≈ø. pla. 37. Dyer fol. 179. pl. 46.

div.head: Whereof Fines be grounded.
div.p: IN euery ≈øuch writ the≈ø≈øential parts & the adiuncts are to be con≈øidered: Sect‚ñ™ 24. the principal parts therof be the parties to the ≈øame, whereof we haue ≈øpoken already, And the things whereof a fine is leuied.

div.head: Of what things Fines may be leuied.
div.p:
ANd touching the things whereof fines are leuiable, we are fir≈øt to Sect‚ñ™ 25. con≈øider the nature of the things them≈øelues, whether they will pa≈ø≈øe in fines or no: And then of their names, by which they may pa≈ø≈øe or not. And howe they may bee in order placed in the writs: Fines therefore may be leuied of all things inheritable being in E≈ø≈øe tempore finis, a ‚Ä¢ d certainly expre≈ø≈øed in the writs, 18. E. 4. 22. as de me≈ø≈øuagio, tofto, columbario, gardino, terra. prato, pa≈øtura, bo≈øco, ≈øubbo≈øco, bruera, mora, iuncaria, mari≈øco, alneto, ru≈øcaria, redditu, per Regi≈øtrum fol. 2. a de Rectoria Eccle≈øiae parochialis de M. ac de decimis granorum, garbarum, & foeni, eidem Rectorie ≈øpectantÃÑ &c. or cum omnibus decimis granorum, garbarum, & foeni eidem Rectoriae ≈øpectantÃÑ, Thel Lib. 8. cap. 9. Sect‚ñ™ 2. de Rectoria 2. E. 3. de furlongo terre, 4. H. 6. 14. de pa≈ø≈øagio vltra aquam de T. de pa≈øtura ad certos boues, o ‚Ä¢ es, & alia aueria, ac de communia pro omnibus animalibus, vel pro om ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ modis auerijs, vel de libera pi≈øcaria, libera warrenna, vel de Aduocatione Eccle≈øiae de D. vel de aliquo ≈øeruitio ≈øpeciali, vt de ≈øeruitio vnius fe ‚Ä¢ di Militis, vnius paris Calcarium deauratorum, vel de ≈øeruitio inueniendi hominem, equitem vel peditem ad eundem, vel ad equitandum cum le Cogni≈øee in exercitu Walliae vel Scotiae, &c. de Pi≈øcaria, 13. E. 3. de officio, 27. H. 8. fol. 12. de proficuis officij, 12. E. 3. de Aduocatione, Reg. fol. 165. de Corodio, 18. H. 6. fol. 20. 4. E. 4. 6. de chiminio, 2. E. 3. fol. 49. de proficuo molendini, 18. E. 3. fo. 56. de libero redditu in breui, and in the concord, Quod predictus A. recognÃÑ praedict' redditum cum pertinenÃÑ ≈øimul cum homagio & fidelitate B. C. & haeredum ≈øuorum de totis tenÃÑtis quae &c. 1. E. 3. fo. 1. et 5. de frankfold', 1. E. ‚Ä¢ . fo. 1. de Nundinis & Mercatu, 1. E. 3. fol. 4. de franchi≈øia, 1. E. 3. fol. 4. de Minera plumbi, & cuiu≈øcunque geneis metalli cum pertinenÃÑ, &c. E. 3. 12. 33. H. 6. fol. 11. de Communia, 4. E. 4. 6. de caruca terre, de pa≈øtura ad cen ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ues, de homagio, de feodo Militis, Reg. fol. 166. 167.
And a fine may be of a Rent charge which had no being before, 21. E. 3. 44.
Or, of a chiefe rent or other rent in b ‚Ä¢ ing, 18. E. 4. 22.
Or, of a Seigniory, 48. E. 3. 23.
Or, of an acquitaile, 50. E. 3. 23.
Or, of a Chauntrie, 38. E. 3. 33.
And of many other things may fines be leuied.
And as fines may be leuied of things in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, ≈øo may they be leuied of a Remainder, or Reuer≈øion, 42. E. 3. 7. 44. E. 3. 45.
And a Reuer≈øion or a Remainder wil pa≈ø≈øe by the name of the lands, 43. E. 3. 22.

But where a fine is of a reuer≈øion or a remainder, it behoueth the cogni≈øee Of a reuer≈øion or remainder. to ≈øue a Quid i ‚Ä¢ ris clamat again≈øt the tenant: When it is of rent, a writ Quem redditum reddi ‚Ä¢ : And where of a Seigniorie or ≈øeruices, Per que ≈øeruitia, to compell the tenant to attourne, as ≈øhall be ≈øhewed hereafter.

Fines may be leuied of thinheritance or freehold of par≈øonages, vicarages, Of Eccle≈øia≈øtical lands mad ‚Ä¢ temporal. porcions, pen≈øions, tithes, oblations, or any other Eccle≈øia≈øticall profit made temporall, and admitted to abide in temporall, handes, and lay v≈øes, by the lawes, and ≈øtatutes of this Realme of England, 32. H. 8. cap. 7.
And to conclude, fines be leuyable of all things, whereof a Precipe qd' reddat lyeth, as will appeare by the examples following.

And landes bought of diuers per≈øons may pa≈ø≈øe in one fine, and then Of diuer≈ø ‚Ä¢ purcha≈øe ‚Ä¢
‚ñ™ the writ of Couenant mu≈øt be brought by all the vendees again≈øt all the vendors: And euery vendor mu≈øt warrant again≈øt him and his heires onely: for it is ab≈øurd that one man ≈øhould warrant the ≈øale of an other without con≈øideration.
And ≈øuch ioint fines ≈øeeme rea≈øonable, e≈øpecially where the ≈øeuerall purcha≈øes be of ≈øo ≈ømal value as the charges of a fine would exceed the value of ≈øome of them.
But fines may not be leuied of things incertaine: as de tenemento, Incerteinty. Tenement. 3. E. 4. 19. 11. H. 7. 25. 12. H 7. 6. 47. E. 3.
Nor of lands giuen in taile by the king, for it is void again≈øt the i≈ø≈øue Taile by the King. entaile and the king, 32. H. 8. cap. 36. Br. Fines 121.

Nor of lands re≈øtrained from being ≈øold by act of Parliament, 32. H.
Re≈øtraint. 8. cap. 36.

Nor of lands of the hu≈øband or of his auÃÑce≈øtors a≈ø≈øured for Iointure, Dower. Ioiture. Forfeitur ‚Ä¢ . dower, or in taile, to any woman by meanes of her hu≈øbande or his aunce≈øtors, for ≈øuch fine worketh a pre≈øent forfeiture of her e≈øtate, if ≈øhe graÃÑt a greater e≈øtate then for her life, 11. H. 7. cap. 20. Plow. fol. 459.

Nor of lands ≈øei≈øed into the kings hands before Liuery or Ou≈øter le
Lands ≈øei≈øed‚ñ™

Nor of lands in AuÃÑcient deme≈øne: for if any fine be leuied of ≈øuch laÃÑds, Auncient deme≈øne. it may be reuer≈øed by a writ of Di≈øceit, brought by the Lord of Auncient
deme≈øne, & therby he ≈øhalbe re≈øtored to his ≈øeigniory, and it ≈øeemeth to be void betweene the parties, quia, coram non Iudice, 7. H. 4. 44. 8. H. 4. 23. 21. E. 3. 20. Reg. fol. 13. b. de Fine adnullando &c.
Yet it is holden good to bind the parties, 17. E. 3. 31. and 7. H. 4. Br. Fines 101. which ≈øeemeth not to be law.
But if ≈øuch fines be of lands in Auncient deme≈øne and of lands at the Auncient deme≈øne and lay fee. common law, it ≈øhalbe ≈øtill good for the lands at the common law, 7. H. 4. 44. 21. E. 3. 20.

div.head: By what names things may pa≈ø≈øe in Fines.
div.p: NOw that we haue partly ≈øet downe what may pa≈ø≈øe in fines, let vs Sect‚ñ™ 26. Names. ≈øee by what names the ≈øame may pa≈ø≈øe. An Honor, this may pa≈ø≈øe by the name of a Manor, or by his proper name: as de honore de Tickhill, or, de manerio de Tickhill.

It ≈øuffi≈øeth al≈øo to demaund a Manor by his proper name without naming A Manor. of the Towne wherein it lyeth, For it may be out of any towne, or extend into ≈øeueral townes & counties: as, de manerio de D. cum pertinÃÑ, yet it feemeth be≈øt to expre≈ø≈øe all the ≈øeuerall townes into which it extendeth: as, de manerio de S. cum pertinÃÑ in D. & E. 19. Ed. 4. fol. 9. ‚Ä¢ . 43. E. 3. fol. 9. a. Bracton Lib. 4. cap. 31. Sect‚ñ™ 3. 9. E. 4. fol. 61. 9. a 16. ‚Ä¢ 17. b. 11. H. 7. fo. 22. b 49. For if any of the townes, into which the manor extendeth, be omitted, nothing of the Manor in that towne pa≈ø≈øeth, 5. E. 4. 103.

A Ca≈øtell or a Hundred may be parcel of a Manor, and pa≈ø≈øe by the A Ca≈øtel or Hundred. Manor Ca≈øtell. name of the manor, whereof they be parcel, 26. A≈ø≈ø. 54. And one Manor may be parcel of an other, 2. E. 3. fo. 36. And a Ca≈øtel may be demaunded by his proper name: as, de ca≈øtello de B. cum pertinÃÑ, 1. E. 3. fol. 4.

An Hundred may be demanded by it ≈øelfe: as, de hundredo de S. 27.
Hundred. H. 6. fol. 2.

Me≈øuagiuÃÑ is a dwelling hou≈øe. By the name of a Me≈øuage, may pa≈ø≈øe A Me≈øuage. a Curtelage, a gardein, an orchard, a douehou≈øe, a ≈øhop, a mill, as parcell of an hou≈øe, BractoÃÑ Lib. 5. cap. 28. Sect‚ñ™ 1. Plow. fo. 169. 170. 171. The like of a cottage, a toft, a chamber, a celler, &c. yet may they be demaunded by their ≈øingle names.
A Chappell or an Ho≈øpitall mu≈øt be demaunded by the name of a me≈øuage, A Chahpell. A Ho≈øpitall. 13. A≈ø≈ø. 2.
A Toft is the place wherein a me≈øuage hath ≈øtood.
A Curtelage is a garden, or a yard, or fold, or a peece of void ground, A Toft. A Curtelage. lying neere and belonging to a me≈øuage, Plow.
Molendinum is good without adding ventriticum, or aquaticum: albeit A Mille the latter be more v≈øual. 44. E. 3. fol. 13.

Of a Reuer≈øion, by the name of the land, or otherwi≈øe, 43. E. 3. 22.
A Reuer≈øion.
Land is to be demaunded by the certeine mea≈øure of the ≈øuperficiall Land. quantitie thereof: as hida, carucata, bouata, virgata, acra, roda terrae.
In like maner bo≈øcus, ≈øubbo≈øcus, bruera, mora, iuncaria, mari≈øcus, & alnetum, & ru≈øcaria, may be demaunded by the number of acres thereof, 16. A≈ø≈ø. 9.
Turbarie may be demaunded by the name of More.

Rent by the multitude and number of the things which are to be reÃÑ dred: Rent as, x. librarÃÑ, or ≈øex denarÃÑ, or vno obulatÃÑ, or quin
que ≈øolidatÃÑ redditÃÑ.
Hou≈øebote, Haybote, and Plowbote, may be demanded by the name E≈øtouers of E≈øtouers: thus, de rationabili e≈øtouerio in bo≈øcis, viz. in decem acris bo≈øci ip≈øius A. in D. &c.
Par≈øonages, Rectories, Aduow≈øons, Vicarages, or Tythes impropriate, A Par≈øonage pa≈ø≈øe not by the names de Aduocatione Eccle≈øiae, but de Rectoria Eccle≈øiae de S. cum pertinÃÑ.

But wheÃÑ it is but of a pre≈øentation, it mu≈øt be de Aduocatione eccle≈øiae
A Pre≈øentatioÃÑ
de S. and not, cum pertinÃÑ.

And of all Vicarages endowed, the writ mu≈øt be de Aduocatione
A Vicarage. Vicariae Eccle≈øiae de S. and not cum pertinÃÑ.
And where no Vicarage is endowed, it pa≈ø≈øeth vnder the≈øe words, de Aduocatione eccle≈øiae de S. &c.

If an entier manor, me≈øuage, or other entier thing, be deuided or parted, Parts ≈øeuered. and after a fine is to be leuied of ≈øome of the parts of the thing ≈øo ≈øeuered, theÃÑ mu≈øt not the fine be de medietate, or de quarta parte, or, other part, of the manor, me≈øuage, or other thing, but ≈øuch part mu≈øt be demauÃÑ ded by the name of a whole thing: As if the manor of D. be deuided into 2. parts, the fine of thone part (if the deui≈øion be ≈øo made, that the manor of that part be not extinct) mu≈øt be de manerio de D. So, if a me≈øuage and xx. acres of land be parted into two parts, the fine of thone part mu≈øt be de vno me≈øuagio & decem acris terre &c. and not de medietaie vnius me≈øuagij, & xx. acrarum terre: for the things new diuided from the re≈øt, are now become whole thinges by them≈øelues, though le≈ø≈øe in quantity then the whole was before diui≈øion thereof made. If a thing beTwi≈øe named. twi≈øe named in a writ of Couenant, it hurteth not: as a Manor and an Hundred parcel of the ≈øame manor, 27. H. 8. 2.

If lands in diuers Shires pa≈ø≈øe, there mu≈øt be ≈øeuerall writs of Couenant
Diuers Shires. thereof accordingly, and but one Concord, Dyer 227. pla. 44. 15. E. 4. 33.

div.head: Of the names of the place wherein the lands do lye.
div.p:
ANd the place wherein the lands do lye, is taken to be parcel of the Sect‚ñ™ 27. Place. name thereof: And thefore we mu≈øt regard the places wherein the lands do lye, as the ≈øhire, Towne, Pari≈øh, or Hamlet: for a fine is good
in a Hamlet, 38. E. 3. fol. 19. 8. E. 4. fol. 6. and 7. E. 6. Br. Fines 44. & 91. Hamlet. Towne decaied. or in a Towne decaied, 7. E. 6. Br. Fines 91.
Neuerthele≈ø≈øe, it is al≈øo good to name the Towne wherein the hamlet is, as it ≈øeemeth, and that with addition, for di≈øtinction, if there be diuers Townes of the ≈øame name in the ≈øame Countie.

And if a Manor extend into diuers Townes: as, A. B. C. it is good to A manor in diuers townes expre≈ø al or none: as, de manerio de S. in A. B. C. for if any of the townes be omitted, none of the manor in that towne pa≈ø≈øeth. Yet a fine of a manor cum pertinÃÑ would haue caried the whole manor, 9. E. 4. 6.

But if a maÃÑ haue diuers Manors of one name: as, South S. & North Two manors of one name. S. it is good, in a writ of one of the ≈øame manors, to expre≈ø≈øe certainly which of them is intended to be pa≈ø≈øed, 47. E. 3. 12. H. 7. 6. Albeit it is thought good ynough by the name of the manor of S. without addition: for certeintie is alwaies be≈øt.

div.head: How ≈øeueral things mu≈øt be placed in writs of Couenant.
div.p: NOw that we haue partly learned, of what things fines may be leuied, Sect' 28. Orderly placing. and by what names: yet ≈øeemeth time to ≈øhew in what order and forme they mu≈øt be therein placed one before an other, when diuers thinges pa≈ø≈øe by one writ, for which we may ob≈øerue the≈øe rules. Fir≈øtWorthye≈øt. the more worthy thinges mu≈øt be put before things le≈ø≈øe worthy: as a Me≈øuage is ≈øet before land, a Manor before a me≈øuage, a Ca≈øtle before a Manor, 7. H. 6. 39. Plow. 168. 169.

Secondly, things general before things ≈øpecial: as lande (being the Things general. general, or genus to meadow, pa≈øture, wood, Iuncaria, mari≈øcus, is fir≈øt to be placed: And wood (being the general to wood grounds, as alnetum ≈øalicetum &c. is to be ≈øet before them the writs.
Thirdly, entier or whole things are to be ≈øet before their partes: as, Whole things Parts. de manerio de C. & medietate manerij de B. cum pertinenÃÑ &c.

Fourthly, parts of things excepted mu≈øt ≈øucceede tho≈øe things out of Things excepted. which they be excepted. And if there be diuers parcels in one writ, that parcel, out of which thexception is to be made, ought to be la≈øt placed, Regi≈øtrÃÑ fol. 6. as, de manerio de D. cum pertinÃÑ in C. (excepto vno me≈øuagio, duabus acris terre, & aduocatione Eccle≈øie de C. &c.).
And euery thing excepted ought to be certainly named. It needeth Pertinencie. not to ≈øay cum pertinÃÑ after the thing excepted, 40. E. 3. 25.

And thexception mu≈øt alwaies be of ≈øuch things, wherof the writ wil lie, and be mencioned therein, Plowd. fol. 362. a 362. b 370. a Regi≈øtrÃÑ fol. 228. 229. of which for the pre≈øent, view then≈øample en≈øuing: videlicet.
div.q:
Praecipe A. B. quod teneat C. D. conuenc' &c. de vno me≈øuagio, vno cotagio, & medietate vnius me≈øuagij, & decem acrarum
terrae cum pertinÃÑ, excepta vna acra terrae in N. &c.
div.p: And finally the forme & order of placing the particulers in a writ of Regula. Couenant, is in all things as in a Praecipe quod reddat of lands.
And further, ob≈øerue the rule of the Regi≈øter fol. 2. which partly appeareth in the≈øe Ver≈øes en≈øuing.

q.l: ≈øuagium, tum, lendinum, umbare, dinuÃÑ, ra, tum, tura, cus, ra, Regula.
Me≈ø, tof, mol, col, gar, ter, pra, pa≈ø, bo≈ø, brue, mora.
Iunca, mari≈ø, alne, ru≈ø, red, ≈øectare priora.

div.p:
The writ of Couenant mu≈øt beare Te≈øte before the writ of Dedimus
Writ. pote≈øtatem, 35. H. 8. Br. Fines 116.

div.head: Of Adiuncts proper to the writs whereof Fines be leuied.
div.p: OF Adiuncts proper to writs of Couenant, and other writs vpon Sect. 29. which fines be v≈øually leuied, ≈øome be internall Adiuncts, and ≈øome externall.
AdiuÃÑcts internall be the days of returne, and the date or Te≈øte of the Adiuncts internal. writ, which be al≈øo common to other writs.
In the Returne it is to be ob≈øerued, that there be xv. dayes at the Returne. lea≈øt betweene the Te≈øte, and the day limited for the returne thereof. 12. E. 4. 11.
The Te≈øte or date mu≈øt not be vpon any Sunday, or other fe≈øtiuall Te≈øte. day, which is not dies iuridicus in Court.

External Adiuncts to writs be, the writing, the Latin, the affidauit,
Externall. or compo≈øition, the ≈øigning, and the paiment of the fine, and returning, which be in like maner common to other writs.

Touching the writing thereof, it is meete to be faire written without Writing. ra≈øing or interlining of any principall matter therein, for ≈øuch ra≈øingRa≈øing. Interlining. Fal≈øe Latin. or interlining will ouerthrow the writ in ≈øome ca≈øes, 45. E. 3. 18.
Al≈øo it behoueth that there be no fal≈øe Latin in any ≈øuch writs, 7. H. 6. 34.
And therfore ≈øuch writs ≈øhould heedfully be examined twi≈øe or thri≈øe Examination of Writs. ouer, for feare of errors.

The forme v≈øed in the returning of ≈øuch writs wil appeare among≈øt Returnes. the pre≈øidents, for the returnes are nothing el≈øe but the Shirifes an≈øweres touching that they are commaunded to do by the ≈øame writs.
Vpon what writs fines may be leuied.

For ≈øo much as no fine can be leuied but upon ≈øome originall writ, Originals. Stat. de Finibus, 18. Edw. 1. we are now to con≈øider vpon what original
writs fines are leuiable.
A writ of Couenant is the mo≈øt v≈øuall writ whereu ‚Ä¢ oÃÑ fines are leuied, Couenant. Fitz. Nat. bre. fol. 146. f. 35. H. 8. Br. Fines 116. Carliel St. 15. E. 2.

Yet may fines be leuied vpon a writ Warrantia cartae, 18. E. 4. 22.
Warrantia cartae. Me≈øne. Cu≈øtomes & ≈øeruices. Carliel St. 15. E. 2.
Or vpon a writ of Me≈øne, 18. E. 4. 2.
Or vpon a writ de Con≈øuetudinibus & Seruitijs, 22. A≈ø≈ø. p. 37. Pa≈øc. 14. Eliz. Dyerfol. 179. pla. 46.

Or vpon any writs of Right, 7. E. 3. fo. 335. Plow. fol. 358.
Right. Without original.

Yet Tremayle Iu≈øtice holdeth, that if in a Praecipe quod reddat again≈øt the tenant for life, which maketh default after default, he in the reuer≈øion or remainder be receyued, a fine may be leuied of the land betweene the demaundant and him in the reuer≈øion or remainder, Ideo Quaere, 21. E. 4. 4.

A fine may be vpon a writ Quod permittat habere chiminum vltra
Quod permittat. terram le Cognizor, 2. E. 3. 19. Fitzh. Fines 102.

div.head: The ≈øeuerall formes of Concordes.
div.p: A Concord is the verie agreement betweene the parties how the Sect. 30. lands ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe, in the forme whereof many things are to be regarded: As if it be ≈øingle, whether it be ≈øur cognizance de droit come ceo que il ad de ≈øon done, Or, ≈øur graunt, done, releas, or confirmation. Or if it be a double fine with a render, what e≈øtates are to be created thereby, and of the re≈øeruation of Rents nomine penae, and clau≈øe of di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, and ≈øeruices, with the clau≈øe of warrantie. For which it is to be noted, that when a fine is leuied to diuers Cognizees, the right ≈øhal be limited to one of them onely, and the≈øtate limited to his heires onely who≈øe right it is knowledged to be, 3. H. 6. 42. 21. E. 3. 33. 43. E. 3. 11 24. E. 3, 64. as this:
div.q: Et e≈øt Concordia talis, ≈øcilicet, quod pÃÑdictus A. cognÃÑ tenÃÑtÃÑ praedict' cum pertinÃÑ e≈ø≈øe ius ip≈øius B. vt ill', quae ijdem B. & C. heÃÑnt de dono praed' A. Et ill' remi≈øit & quietÃÑ clamÃÑ de ≈øe & haeredibus ≈øuis praefatis B. & C. & haeredibus ip≈øius B. &c.
div.p: But the kings tenant in Capite may knowledge the right of his lands to be in diuers for the kings benefit, in hauing many ≈øuch tenants in Capite, 7. H. 7. 4.
And likewi≈øe the releas and warrantie mu≈øt be from the heirs of one of the Cognizors, 44. E. 3. 21. for in a fine from diuers, the fee mu≈øt be ≈øuppo≈øed to be in one of them onely, 21. E. 3. 33.

In a fine sur graunt and render, none can take the fir≈øt e≈øtate vpoÃÑ the render, but ≈øome of the Cognizors, but Reuer≈øions or Remainders any e≈øtranger may take: For if A. knowledge a fine to B. and B. render to the ≈øaid A. Habendum ≈øibi & E. vxori eius, and the heires of theri bodies
&c. by this fine E. mu≈øt haue none e≈øtate, becau≈øe ≈øhe is not named in the writ, 24. E. 3. 28. 30. H. 8. Br. Fines 108. 7. E. 3. 64.

And a man cannot by fine by way of remainder re≈øerue a le≈ø≈øe e≈øtate to him≈øelfe then fee: And therefore if A. knowledge a fine to B. in fee, and he rendre to A. in taile, the remainder to him≈øelfe for life, this remainder is void, for A. had fee ≈øimple before, 24. E. 3. 28. 14. H. 4. 31.

And a Concord cannot be of any other thing then is conteyned in the writ of Couenant, and not of a forein thing, if it be not con≈øequent: As in a writ of land, rent, common, &c. may be rendred i≈ø≈øuing out of it, 18. E. 4. 22.
And a Concord may be with an exception of ≈øome part, 44. E. 3. 21.

If a man will, he may make a Iointure by fine thus: If I. leuie a fine to A. in fee ≈øur cognizance de droit come ceo &c. and after A. rendre to I. for life without impeachment of wa≈øt, the remainder to B. his wife for terme of her life, the remainder to I. and his heires, 38. H. 8, Br. Fines 108.

The Manors & tenements conteined in the writ may be diuided: As if a fine be leuied betweene R. and M. of ii. manors, which M. knowledgeth all his right of the ≈øaid ii. manors to be the right of the ≈øaid R. as that which &c. for which R. grauÃÑteth & rendreth thone manor to M. for life, with ii. parts of the other manor, which N. holdeth in dower, To haue thone manor, and two parts of the other manor, to M. for life, the remainder after her death to R. in taile, and that after the death of A, the third part ≈øhall remaine to an other, 43. E. 3. 11. 45. E. 3. 12.

And in like maner a fine is leuied of the manor of G. cum pertinenÃÑ
by A. vnto C: which A. knowledgeth the right in C, as that &c. and C. granteth and rendreth the ≈øame to A. in tayle, The remainder of the 4. part of the manor towards the we≈øt to the ≈øaid A. and her heires, the remainder of an other 4. part towards the Ea≈øt to I. in fee, the remainder of an other 4. part towards the South to one R. in fee, and of the other 4, part towards the North to W. and his heires, it is good, 44. A≈ø≈ø. p. 11. Or incerteinly by 3. third parts to A. B. and C. in remainder ≈øeuerally, 18. H. 7. Br. Fines 111.

A fine leuied to one in tayle vpon condition with remainder is holden to be good, 27. H. 8. 24. Plowd. 34. b. 24. E. 3. 62. Contra per Pri≈øot 33. H. 6. 52. and 44. E. 3. 22. But a fine with a reentrie was reiected, 44. E. 3. 22.

A lea≈øe for yeares may be made by a fine in this forme: The le≈ø≈øe mu≈øt knowledge the tenements to be tthe right of the le≈ø≈øor, as that &c. and then the le≈ø≈øor mu≈øt graunt the lands backe againe to the le≈ø≈øee for ≈øo many yeres as are agreed vpoÃÑ, re≈øeruing a reÃÑt with a clau≈øe of di≈øtre≈ø≈øe: But this fine wil not bind the i≈ø≈øue in taile, becau≈øe he taketh by the fine
but giueth nothing thereby, Br. Fines 106. tempore H. 8. 36. H. 8. Br. Fines 118. Plow. 455. 14. Eliz.

Or, a lea≈øe for yeares may be made by fine to bind the tenant in taile, thus: The tenant in taile and the le≈ø≈øee to knowledge the tenements to be the right of an e≈øtranger as that &c. and the Cognizee to graunt and render the tenements to the le≈ø≈øee for certain yeeres yeelding a reÃÑt with a clau≈øe of di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, and then graunt the reuer≈øion to the tenant in taile, 36. H. 8. Br. Fines 118.

If an e≈øtranger, which hath nothing in the lands, leuie a fine to him in the remainder in taile dependant ≈øur e≈øtate pur vie, ≈øur cognizance de droit come ceo que il ad de ≈øon done &c. and the cognizee by the ≈øame fine render to the cognizor for yeares, de commeÃÑcer al Mich. en≈øuant, and dieth, and al the proclamations are made after his death, The tenant for life after ≈øuch time as the ≈øaid leas is limitted to begin dieth, it is adiudged a good leas to barre the i≈ø≈øue in taile for the terme, 14. Eliz. Plowd. fol. 437. b. inter Smyth & Stapleton, which ≈øeemeth contrarie to the opinion before, Br. Fines 106. 118.
A. by fine graunteth his tenements, which I. holdeth for life, and which after his decea≈øe &c, to W. for life, rendring rent &c. with a di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, ≈øauing the Reuer≈øion, 44. E. 3. 45.

Fine ≈øur cognizance de droit come ceo &c, is leuied to A. in fee rendring rent, this re≈øeruation is void, becau≈øe the fine is executed, for no re≈øeruation can be but of a fine executorie, as ≈øur render, 50. E. 3. 9. 24. E. 3. 26. 39. E. 3. 1.

And if diuers ioine in a fine, the warrantie mu≈øt be by them, and the heires of one of them which is the owner of the land, 44. E. 3. 1. 21. E. 3. 27. 42. E. 3. 13. 24. E. 3. 66. ContrÃÑ ≈øur terres de Gauelkind, ibmÃÑ.
A particuler tenant, as for life &c. cannot ≈øurrender his terme to him in the reuer≈øion or remainder by fine: But he may graunt and releas it to him by fine, 44. E. 3. 36.

One Concord may be of lands in ≈øeuerall Counties, and the fine pro licenc' concord' of all extracted entierly: Yet mu≈øt there be ≈øeuerall writs of Couenant, returnable all at one day, 6. Eliz. Dyer fol. 227. pl. 44. 15. E. 4. 33.

And finally in Concorde, all the ≈øpeciall names of things conteyned in the writ, whereupon the fine is leuied, are not to be rehear≈øed, But onely the generall words therein mentioned: as manor, tenements, rents, aduow≈øon, common, &c.
As where the writ is de vno me≈ø≈øuagio, vno gardino, vno pomario, decem acrÃÑ terrae, v. acrÃÑ prati, x. acrÃÑ pa≈øturae, iiij. acrÃÑ bo≈øci, & communia pa≈øturÃÑ cum pertinÃÑ in C. &c.

The Concord hath, RecognÃÑ tenÃÑta & coiÃÑam praedictam cum pertinentijs
e≈ø≈øe ius &c. But the examples following will more plainely expre≈ø≈øe this, and all the differing formes of Concords here before mencioned.

div.head: ‚Ä¢ Adiuncts of Concords.
div.p:
THe Adiuncts of a CoÃÑcord, be al≈øo of two ≈øorts: Internall, and Externall
Sect. 147. Internall be ≈øuch as be conteyned within the very Concord it ≈øelfe. Of which ≈øort be the clau≈øe of re≈øeruation of ≈øeruice, rent, or other thing, the clau≈øe of nomine penae, the clau≈øe of di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, and theRe≈øeruation. NominÃÑ penae. Di≈øtre≈ø≈øe. clau≈øe of warranties: All which clau≈øes of re≈øeruations, nomine penae, di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, and warrantie, are to be made in ≈øuch words, and in ≈øuch formes, as the like are made in In≈øtruments extraiudiciall: for which ≈øee Lea≈øes and Graunts of rents charge in the fir≈øt part of Symboleography, If the following example do not ≈øufficiently ≈øati≈øfie your de≈øire herein.

And Warranties be ≈øometimes generall, that is to ≈øay, again≈øt all Warrantie. men: Some again≈øt all, except certein per≈øons: ≈øome again≈øt certein per≈øons onely: ≈øome again≈øt euery Cognizor, and his heires ≈øeuerally: and ≈øome again≈øt one of the Cognizors, and his heires onely: ≈øome of all the lands in the fine: ≈øome of all, except part: and ≈øome of part only, certeinly expre≈ø≈øed.

The Externall Adiuncts of Concordes be the licence of alienanation, the Dedimus pote≈øtatem, the examination of the parties, & the
cognizance. The licence of alienation is a power or au ‚Ä¢ thority giuenLicence. Alienation‚ñ™ by her Maie≈øtie to the parties, that lands may be aliened without incurring the danger of contempt.
And euery ≈øuch liceÃÑce is either to alien lands holden in Capite, or to alien lands into Mortmaine.
The licence of alienation of lands holden in Capite may varie from the fine, and be good, 32. H. 8. Br. Alienations 4. 30.

For the obtayning of which licence the Clerke of the licences doth v≈øe to draw a dogket in paper, conteyning the effect of the fine, feoffement,Dogket. or other deeds, whereby the alienation is to be made.

And thereupon affidauit or compo≈øition mu≈øt be made for the value A≈ø≈øida ‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ . of the lands, which are to pa≈ø≈øe thereby, which is to be ≈øigned by the Doctor of the Chauncery that hath power to take oath: Then the Queenes fine is to be paied to the Receiuor of fines, who will ≈øigne the dogket: And afterwards the ≈øame is to be ≈øigned by two of the coÃÑmi≈ø≈øioners of the office of fines & licences, and vpon that dogket, the Clark of the licences is to make the licence, and get it ≈øealed with the great Seale, which licence is to be made in fourme following.

div.head: The writ of Ad quod damnum.
div.p:
BVt before the graunting of any ≈øuch lycence, either to alien lands Sect. 151. holden in chiefe, or, to alien lands in Mortmain, or, relea≈øe right in Mortmain, or exchange, the auncient v≈øe was to haue a writ of Ad quod dampnum, conteyning the ≈øub≈øtance of the Kings licence out of the Chancery, directed to the E≈øcheator in the County wherein the lands lie, to be aliened, to inquire and certifie into the Chancery, what damage or preiudice thalienation thereof will be to the king, or the other chiefe Lord, of whom they are holden, And of what tenure and value the lands be, And whether there remayne ≈øufficient free land be≈øides tho≈øe to the alienor, to ≈øu≈øtaine publique charges, and to be in A≈ø≈øi
‚Ä¢ es and Iuries &c.
And this is a≈øwell where the alienation is made by the king, or by a Corporation, or a feme couert, as by any other.

The like inquirie by writ of Ad quod damnum, hath beene v≈øed before the king made any graunt, or pardon, for alienation, lea≈øe, relea≈øe, confirmation, or licence, and after the Inqui≈øition returned and certified into the Chancery, to effect the ≈øame accordingly, Fitzh. Nat. bre. fol. ‚Ä¢ 21. & inde v≈ø
que fol. 227.

But now experience is to the contrarie, in liew whereof the v≈øe at this day is, to put in the kings patents, the≈øe words: Ab≈ø
que aliquo breui de ad quod damnum, ≈øeu aliquibus alijs breuibus, ≈øeu mandatis, ≈øuperinde habendis, fiendis, aut pro≈øequendis.
And one writ of Ad quod dam ‚Ä¢ um will ≈øerue for diuers purcha≈øes, And a licence to alien in Mortmain of one king, will ≈øerue in the time of an other.
But not ≈øo of lands holden in chiefe, 22. E. 3. Fitzh. Nat. bre. in breui de Ad quod damnum.
div.q: I purpo≈øely omit here the forme of ≈øuch writs de Ad quod damnum, becau≈øe they be ≈øo growen out of v≈øe.

div.head: Of a Pardon for Alienation.
div.p: BVt if perchance any alienation of land holden in Capite, be made Sect. 152. without licence, a pardon mu≈øt be ≈øued, the fine of which is the value of lands by one yeare, and the meane profites betweene the Inqui≈øitionA fine of pardon. and the pardon, 31. H. 8. Br. Alienation 29. vnle≈ø≈øe the Commi≈ø≈øioners will more fauorably compound for the ≈øame, as in ≈øome ca≈øes vpon rea≈øonable cau≈øe ≈øhewed, they v≈øe to do, which pardon being purcha≈øed, the purcha≈øor is to hold his land ≈øtill, 14. H. 6. 26. 50. A≈ø≈ø. p. 2. 1. E. 3. ca. 12. 34. E. 3. ca. 15.
But the fine of a licence, to alien lands holden in Capite, is, the third Fine of a licence. part of the yearely value thereof, 26. H. 8. Br. Alienation 29.

But if alienation of lands into Mortmain be made without licence, Mortmain.
the king may ≈øei≈øe them as forfeited or e≈øcheated, Magna charta cap. 36. We≈øtmÃÑ 2. cap. 32. And for a licence thereof to be graunted, the fine thereupon to be paied, is the value of the land by three yeares, 26. H. 8. Br. Alienation 29.
But variance betweene the licence and the fine is not materiall, if it Variance. be all one alienation, 32. H. 8. Br. Alienation 30.
And it ≈øeemeth that a fine ≈øur releas, or other releas, is none alienation, Releas. & therefore no fine due for the ≈øame, P. 37. H. 8. Br. Alienation 31.
But fines are payable, and licences to be ≈øued vpon common Recoueries, Recoueries. 39. H. 6. 32. H. 8. ca. 1. 4. E. 3.

Deui≈øe by will is an alienation, 3. Ma. 1. Br. Alienation 37.
Will.

div.p: THe Queenes ≈øiluer is the fine, which is paied vnto her Maie≈øty for Sect' 154. her highnes licence of concord, which vpon writs of Couenant, be taxed after the rate following: That is to ≈øay, for landes of the yearely

div.head: Ob≈øeruations nece≈ø≈øarie at the knowledging of Fines.
div.p: VVHen a Fine is to be knowledged, it is meete, that before the Sect' 155. The tytling of the note. parties come before the Iudges, or Commi≈ø≈øioners, the titling of the writ of Couenant and Concord be faire written, according to the parties mindes, and duely examined, and al≈øo ≈øigned, or ≈øub≈øcribed by all the Cogni≈øors.

It is al≈øo requi≈øite that either the Cogni≈øors be knowen to the Ju≈øtices, Knowledge of the Cogni≈øor. or Commi≈ø≈øioners, that mu≈øt take the Cogni≈øance thereof, or that ≈øome other credible per≈øon, knowen to him which taketh the cogni≈øaÃÑce, who knoweth the partie, be pre≈øent: And doe ≈øufficiently informe the Judge, that they be the ≈øelfe ≈øame parties, again≈øt whom the writ is brought: for ≈øome will couenou≈øly knowledge fines in the name of others that be owners of the land, 34. H. 6. fo. 19.

And if a Feme couert be cogni≈øor, ≈øhe mu≈øt be per≈øwaded to yeeld her Examination of wiues. con≈øent and be fully agreed with, before ≈øhe be examined, for in all ca≈øes, where a Feme couert is to depart with any thing by fine, ≈øhe mu≈øt be examined by the Ju≈øtices or Commi≈ø≈øioners that take the cogni≈øance, and confe≈ø≈øe that ≈øhe doth make cogni≈øance freely, and not through feare or compul≈øion of any, before the cogni≈øance will be accepted. But where ≈øhe is to take benefit by a fine, ≈øhe ≈øhall neuer be examined, 42. E. 3. 7. 3. H. 6. 42. 46. Ed. 3. 15. 8. H. 6. 4. 24. Ed. 3. 62. StatutÃÑ de Finibus 18. Ed. 2.

Al≈øo the yerely value of lands ≈øhould be ≈øet downe vnder the Concord, Value. And ≈øome hone≈øt per≈øon, which knoweth the land, brought thether, to make oath for the value thereof: For without ≈øuch oath, or, compo≈øition,Oath. the fine can not pa≈ø≈øe.

And compo≈øition with the Commi≈ø≈øioners will not readily be made Compo≈øition without oath, or ≈øome late fine, licence, or other matter of record, to informe the Commi≈ø≈øioners of the value thereof: Which being done, the writ of Couenant is againe there to be entred, & the fine thereof (if it be fineable) mu≈øt there be paied to the Receiuer, and then the writ mu≈øt be ≈øigned by the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners, & that done, the ≈øaid writ mu≈øt be ≈øealed,
and retorned with the Concord and Dedimus pote≈øtateÃÑ, if the cogni≈øance was taken by Dedimus pote≈øtateÃÑ, and then the ≈øaid writs mu≈øt be taken out & ≈øigned by the Cu≈øtos breuium, & thence they mu≈øt be caried to the Clerke of the Queenes ≈øiluer, who mu≈øt take a note thereof for the entrie of the Q. ≈øiluer, & ≈øigne the ≈øame again, and then mu≈øt they be deliuered to the Chyrographer of fines, to be ingro≈ø≈øed and proclaimed. The examples whereof appeare in their apt places.

div.head: How, and when, cogni≈øances of Fines mu≈øt be certified, and what may hinder the ≈øame.
div.p: IF they, which haue taken cogni≈øance of a fine, wil not certifie the ≈øame Sect' 156. Certificat. in conuenient time, a Cerciorari is to be awarded vnto them, comprehending the matter of the Dedimus pote≈øtateÃÑ, & commaunding them to certifie &c. which, if they doe not, there lieth again≈øt the Commi≈ø≈øioners, an Alias, Pluries, and Attachment &c. Fitz. na br. 147. b.

But they are not bound to certifie ≈øuch recogni≈øances, but within the Time. yere after ≈øuch caption thereof, but if they do, it is good inough, 23. Eli. ca. 3. And with euery ≈øuch certificate they mu≈øt certifie the day and yere wherein the ≈øame was knowledged. Thus, captÃÑ apud R. in comÃÑ EborÃÑ xx. die Octob. A nno regni Eliz. Reginae trice≈øimo nono.

El≈øe no Clerke or officer may receiue the ≈øame, but ≈øhall for fait for euery Forfaiture. writ otherwi≈øe receiued v. li. 23. Eliz. ca. 3. If any of the partics to a fine die after recogni≈øance thereof & before it be certified, it ought not to be certified, 1. H. 7. 9. 33. H. 6. fo. 52. Dier fo. 146. pl. 68. 7. Eliz.
But if ≈øuch cogni≈øance of a fine be certified, and the Queens ≈øiluer entred, Q. ≈øiluer. the fine is good, and may afterwards be ingro≈ø≈øed, though it be in an other terme. Thus.

div.p: In like maner, if a Iu≈øtice hauing taken cogni≈øance of a fine, be di≈øcharged Iu≈øtice di≈øcharged. of his office, before he haue certified the ≈øame, he may not certifie it without a like writ, notwith≈øtaÃÑding that he be re≈øtored to his place againe, 8. H. 4. 5. 1. H. 7. 9.

H. 7. 9. yet learne, for I think the ≈øtatute of 1. E. 6. cap. 7. doth remedy this mi≈øchiefe, for the wordes thereof be the≈øe in effect, viz.

p.hi: E. F. in miÃÑa pro pluribus defaltis &c.

div.p:
PrÃÑfuit vic' E. quod di≈øtringeret praedict' E. F. &c. vt in alijs breuibus
de di≈øtring. ≈øupra. Et modo hic ad hunc diem venit tam praedictus C. D. per W. W. AtturnatÃÑ ≈øuum, quam praedictÃÑ E. F. in propria per≈øona ≈øua. Et praedict' C. D. petÃÑ, quod praedictÃÑ A. B. ≈øe ei de redditu praedict' atturnet &c. Et praedictus E. F. petit auditÃÑ breuis praedict', & ei legitur.
Petit etiam auditÃÑ note finis vnde idem breue emanauit, & ei legitur in hec verba. Inter C. D. querÃÑ &c. reciting the note in Latin &c.

In which ca≈øe, if the tenant atturne, the entrie ≈øhall be, as in a Quid Attornement entred. iuris clamat, and ≈øo ≈øhal the iudgement & execution be al≈øo Mutatis mutandis. But that turnement mu≈øt be in Court, 9. H. 6. 21. 8. H. 6. 15.

If this writ be again≈øt diuers defendants, & ≈øome appeare, and ≈øomeDiuers tenaÃÑts. make default the≈øe, which appeare, ≈øhall not atturne without the re≈øt, vntill they appeare, and after make default, 8. H. 6. 15.

If the tenant once appeare, and after make default, a Di≈øtring' ad atturnand'
Default. ≈øhalbe awarded, 9. H. 6. 8. H. 6. 15.
Cogni≈øee of a rent charge, or rents for yeres, ≈øhall not haue atturnement, Quere, Dyer fol. 140. pl. 37. & 38.

The tenant can not plede by Atturney, but ex con≈øen≈øu querentis, 1.
Atturney. H. 7. 27.

In Quem redd' reddit, the tenant appearing, is to demaunde what the plaintife hath to ≈øhow for the rent, and then he mu≈øt ≈øhow the commencement thereof, and his title thereunto, which the plaintife may an≈øwere, 31. H. 6. 8. 36. H. 6.

In Quem redd' reddit, if the tenant wil di≈øclaime, he may plede that Di≈øclaimer. he was not tenant of the land, the day of the note leuied: for this writ lyeth again≈øt none but him, which is then tenant, 8. H. 6. 15.

p.hi: I write thus briefely of this writ, becau≈øe it ≈øo much re≈øembleth a Quid iuris clamat.

div.head: Per que ≈øeruitia.
div.p: PEr que ≈øeruitia is a Iudiciall writ, i≈ø≈øuing from the note of a fine, & Sect' 167. lyeth for the Cogni≈øee of a manor, ≈øeigniory, chiefe rent, or other ≈øeruices, to compel him that is tenant of the land at the time of the note of the fine leuied, to attorne vnto him, 43. E. 3. 8. H. 6. 17. Plow. 46. b. which is made thus.

Iu≈øticiarijs no≈øtris apud W. in cra≈øtinÃÑ &c. S. F. R. L. &c. ad L. &c. ad cogno≈øcend' per que ≈øeruitia tenent tenÃÑta ≈øua cum pertinÃÑ in B. que ≈øeruitia E. L. in curia no≈øtrÃÑ coram Iu≈øticiarijs nrÃÑis apud W. conce≈ø ‚Ä¢ it W. B. per finem ibi inde inter ‚Ä¢ os factum. Et habeas ibi hoc breue. Te≈øte &c.

div.p: If the Lord grant the ≈øeruices of his tenant by fine, or otherwi≈øe, the Lord before attornemeÃÑt ≈øhal haue ≈øuch things, as lye in prender: as the warde of the bodie of the heire and of the lande, e≈øcheates &c. But not ≈øuch things as lie in render: as, rents, and reliefe, heriots, & other feruiuices, for he cannot auow for them before the atturnement.
If a man graunt the ≈øeruices of his tenant for life, this writ lieth, Br. Sur graunt for life. Per que ≈øeruitia 13.
If ≈øeruices be graunted to I. S. for life, the reuer≈øion to N. N. and I. S. die before atturnement, he in reuer≈øion ≈øhall haue Per que ≈øeruitia, 20. H. 6. 7.
If Per que ≈øeruitia be brought again≈øt diuer≈øe, of which ≈øome onely appeare, they are compellable to atturne, 21. E. 3. 48. T. 32. E. 3.

div.head: Vpon who≈øe alienations the tenant is not compellable to atturne.
div.p: IF tenant in taile of ≈øeruices leuie a fine thereof, the tenant of the land Sect' 168. T ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ taile. is not compellable to atturne, 48. E. 3. 23. If the tenant for life, or any other particuler tenant of ≈øeruices, which To a Íùëticuler tenant. haue them not in fee, leuie a fine thereof, the terre tenant is not compellable to attorne. ltinÃÑ North. 3. E. 3.
If one ioint tenant of a ≈øeiguiory graunt &c. the tenant is not compellable Iointenancy. to attorne, 9. E. 2.

div.head: Again≈øt whom a Per que ≈øeruitia lieth, and whom not.
div.p: IT lieth again≈øt him onely, that is tenant of the land at the time of theSect' 169. Terre tenant. note of the fine leuied, 8. H. 6. 17. 18. E. 4. 10. And therefore mu≈øt not varie from the fine, 18. E. 4. 10. 45. E. 3. 25. E. 3. 50.

Therefore it ≈øeemeth that if he, which is tenant at the leuying of the note do die, or alien before attornemeÃÑt had, that neither his heire nor the alienee is compellable to attorne, H. 26. E. 3. 56. 18. E. 4. 25. E. 3. 50. 10 yet his attornement is good, Ibid' M. 31. E. 3.

Ar Piore≈ø≈øe reclu≈øe is compellable to atturne, 43. E. 3. And an infantA Reclu≈øe.
26. E. 3. 62. And a man only dumbe, by writing or ≈øignes, 26. E. 3. 62.
But a man ≈øurde & mute, is not coÃÑpellable to atturne, 26. E. 3. 62. Mute. Deafe. Madne≈ø≈øe.
Nor a man de non ≈øane memoriae, as a madman, a lunatike, an Ideot, 26. E. 3. 62.
Nor a tenant by curte≈øie for the feeblene≈ø≈øe of his e≈øtate, 9. E. 3. 31. T. by curte≈øy. Late feoffemÃÑt.
He that is infeoffed by the Lord po≈øt StatÃÑ. Quia emptores &c. is not coÃÑpellable to atturne, for he holdeth of the Lord peramouÃÑt, 39. E. 3. 19.

H. 14. E. 3. for it is trauer≈øable T. 20. E. 3. H. 26. H. 6.
