div.head: SYMBOLEOGRAPHY. Of Indictments and Offences.
Of Indictments.
div.p: AN Indictment is a bill or declaration Sect' 1. made in forme of Law (for the benefit of the common wealth) of an accu≈øation for ≈øome offence, either Criminal or Penal, exhibited vnto Iurors, and by their verdict founde and pre≈øented to be true, before an Officer hauing power to puni≈øh the ≈øame offence. And ≈øuch an Indictment is made to the end to compell the partie accu≈øed to aun≈øwere thereunto.

In euery indictment two things ≈øeeme principally to be con≈øidered: Fir≈øt, the verie offence, for reformation wherof thindictment is framed. And then the right forme of the Indictment it ≈øelfe, according to the di≈øtinct qualitie of euery ≈øeueral offence.

Wherefore as in my treati≈øe of Extraiudicial Symbolaeography, I haue fir≈øt di≈øcour≈øed bow Obligations ≈øpring of con≈øent, & theÃÑ di≈øclo≈øed the ≈øeueral formes of In≈øtruments thereof: So in this I haue thought good fir≈øt briefly to vnfold the ≈øundry natures of Offences and defaults, and how they bind thoffendor. And then to lay downe the doctrine and ≈øeueral formes of Indictments concerning the ≈øame.

div.head: Offence.
div.p: AN offence therefore is a fact done vnlawfull and forbidden by nature Sect' 2. or Law, whether the ≈øame be in coÃÑmitting or omitting, wherof thone for learning ≈øake, may fitly be termed an offence, and thother a default, for in Law, thought is free from offence.

div.head: Indeuour.
div.p: BVt ≈øo is not indeuor many times, becau≈øe therein, is guile and purpo≈øe Sect' 3. to offend.

div.head: Offence priuate and publike.
div.p: ANd euery offence is of the≈øtate, publike, or priuate, and is thereof Sect' 4. ≈øo termed.

The de≈øcription of both which offences, is drawen ≈øomtime from the maner of doing: but may perchance more fitly be taken from the obiect which is hurt, vnle≈ø≈øe ≈øome thinke good to conioine them both.

div.head: Symphathie betweene the common wealth and her members.
div.p: FOr certes, when a priuate per≈øon is offeÃÑded, it cannot lightly be deuied, Sect' 5. but that the common wealth is thereby al≈øo offended, and againe, the common wealth being endammaged, howe can it be cho≈øen but euerie Subiect thereof is al≈øo affected, as being a member of the ≈øame.
So great a Sympathie and mutuall ≈øuffering being in them, as betweene the head and members of a naturall bodie.
But in a≈ømuch as ≈øome offences done, more merely re≈øpect priuate wealth, and ≈øome other more meerely the weale publike, tho≈øe be termed priuate, and the≈øe publike.

div.head: Offence publike and priuate.
div.p: A Publike offence, is a greeuous fault committed again≈øt the common Sect' 6. wealth, A priuate offence is an offence again≈øt the wealth of a priuate per≈øon.

div.head: Offences blinde.
div.p: EVery offence of his owne nature maketh the offendor bound to the Sect' 7. common wealth, or to a priuate per≈øon, or to both, and not onely they which actually coÃÑmit offence, but they al≈øo which command, per≈øwade, coun≈øel, procure, abbet, aide or con≈øent that an offence be perpetrated or conceale it being done, are cen≈øured to offend.

div.head: Offences named and vnnamed.
div.p: ANd offences are either named or vnnamed. Sect' 8.
Offences named bee ≈øuch offences as haue certaine names in Lawe.

div.head: Ofences vnnamed.
div.p: VNnamed offences bee tho≈øe which albeit they bin committed, yet Sect. 9. haue they no certeine name ≈øet forth in our law, whereby they may be called.

div.head: Offences named.
div.p: AGaine offences named be either our owne or other mens faults, by Sect' 10. which we are bound, and they haue a certaine name in law, wherby to be termed.

div.head: Offences ≈øimple.
div.p: OVr owne proper offences be either ≈øimple or mixt. Sect' 11.
Our ≈øimple offences be ≈øuch as be committed by our owne ≈øayinges or deedes,

div.head: Offences mixt.
div.p: ANd the mixt be tho≈øe which be committed by words and deeds both Sect' 12. togither.

div.head: Offences by worde.
div.p: OFfences by ≈øayings onely, be they by which the mind, dignitie, or Sect' 13. fame of an other man (which is compared to life) is hurt & not his bodie, & the≈øe are al≈øo done by coun≈øaile or by contumelious words.

div.head: Coun≈øaile.
div.p: BY Coun≈øaile, as through wicked per≈øwa≈øion.

Wicked per≈øwa≈øion is fraudulent coun≈øaile giuen to any, wherebySect' 14. his minde is corrupted and made wor≈øe to doe or attempt any thing noughtly: which yet doth not induce nece≈ø≈øity to do the thing, though it bind him that giueth ≈øuch coun≈øaile.

div.head: Offence by contumelious words.
div.p: ANd offence or crime by words, is when through peruer≈øe wordes, Sect' 15. the good name, credite, or dignitie of a man is impaired.

div.head: Slaunder.
div.p: ANd it is either by voice or writing, and is called Slaunder, which Sect' 16. is either again≈øt God or man.

div.head: Slaunder again≈øt God.
div.p: SLaunder again≈øt God, is whereby the Maie≈øtie diuine is euil ≈øpoken Sect' 17. off. Of this ≈øort be bla≈øphemie, Magicke, Here≈øie, Apo≈øta≈øie, and Periurie.

div.head: Bla≈øphemie.
div.p: BLa≈øphemie is a wicked ≈øaying, or ≈ølauÃÑder pronounced again≈øt God, Sect' 18. touching his e≈ø≈øence or word reuealed.

div.head: Magicke.
div.p: MAgitioÃÑs be tho≈øe which by vttering of certein ≈øuper≈øtitious words Sect' 19. conceiued, aduenture to attempt thinges aboue the cour≈øe of nature, by bringing forth dead mens gho≈øts as they fal≈øly pretended, in ≈øhowing of things either ≈øecret or in places farre off, & in ≈øhowing them in any ≈øhape or likene≈ø≈øe. The≈øe wicked per≈øons by othe or writing written with their owne blood, hauing betaken them≈øelues to the deuil, haue for≈øaken God, & broken their couenant made in bapti≈øme, and dete≈øt the benefits thereof, and wor≈øhip the deuill onely. And ≈øetling their whole hope in him, do execute his commandements, and being dead, commend both their bodies and ≈øoules vnto him.

div.head: South ≈øaying wizards.
div.p: OF this kind of Magicians be al tho≈øe which en≈øue, as South≈øaiers Sect' 20. or Wizards which diuine & foretel things to come & rai≈øe vp euil ≈øpirits by certein ≈øuper≈øtitious & conceiued formes of words. And vnto ≈øuch que≈øtions as be demaunded of them, do an≈øwere by voice, or el≈øe ≈øet before their eies in gla≈ø≈øes, chri≈øtall ≈øtones, or rings, the pictures or images of things ≈øought for.

div.head: Diuination.
div.p:
THe profe≈ø≈øors of ‚Ä¢ hart of Diuination which be puffed vp with prophe≈øing Sect' 21.
≈øpirits. And can manife≈øt who hath ≈øtollen things, and tel where things lo≈øt or ≈øtollen be.

div.head: Iugling.
div.p: IVglers and ≈øleightie Curers of di≈øea≈øes which for the curing of all Sect' 22. ≈øickne≈ø≈øes and ≈øores of man and bea≈øt, v≈øe either certeine ≈øuper≈øtitious words or writings called charmes or ≈øpelles hanged about the necke or ≈øome other part of the body.

div.head: Inchauntings and Charming.
div.p:
INchanters or Charmers through certein words pronounced and charecters Sect. 23. or images, herbes, or other things applied, thinke they can do what they li≈øt, the deuil ≈øo deceiueth them, or in very deed di≈øpatcheth tho≈øe things which the Inchantors would haue done, from the≈øe ≈øomewhat differ witches or hagges, & Augurers or South≈øaiers by birds, di
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ors by ≈øeeing thintrals of bea≈øts ≈øacrificed.

div.head: Witcherie.
div.p: A Witch or hagg is ≈øhe which being eluded by a league made with Sect' 24. the deuill through his per≈øwa≈øion, in≈øpiration and iuggling thinketh ≈øhe can de≈øigne what maner of euil things ≈øoeuer, either by thought or imprication, as to ≈øhake the aire with lightnings & thunder, to cau≈øe haile & tempe≈øts, to remoue greene corne or trees to an other place, to be caried of her familiar which hath taken vpon him the deceiptful ≈øhape of a goate, ≈øwine, or calfe &c. into ≈øome mountaine farre di≈øtant, in a wonderfull ≈øhort ≈øpace of time. And ≈øometimes to flie vpon a ≈øtaffe or forke, or ≈øome other in≈øtrumeÃÑt. And to ≈øpend all the night after with her ≈øweet hart, in playing, ≈øporting, bankqueting, dauncing, daliance, and diuer≈øe other deueli≈øh lu≈øtes, and lewd de≈øports, & to ≈øhew a thou≈øand ≈øuch mon≈øterous mockeries.

div.head: Here≈øie.
div.p: HEre≈øie, is a re≈øolute & ob≈øtinate error in ≈øome article of our chri≈øtian Sect' 25. faith, 1. Timo. 4. 1. 2. Peter 2. 1. 1. Cor. 11. 19. Rom. 16. 17.

div.head: Anabapti≈øme.
div.p: AMong≈øt Heretikes are numbred, Anabapti≈øts, which wickedly iterate Sect' 26. holy bapti≈øme, which hainous offence is very grieuous, as by which the Maie≈øtie of almighty God, and the promi≈øe which in the fir≈øt bapti≈øme was effectual, are violated.

div.head: Apostacie.
div.p: APo≈øtacie followeth, which is a for≈øaking of the Chri≈øtian faith. Sect' 27.

And Apo≈øta≈øie hapneth two waies, either when any man partly reuoulteth from true religion into a wicked ≈øect reteining ≈øtil the name and title of Chri≈øtiani≈øme, or when the contrary ≈øide of the Iewes or Pagans ≈øo plea≈øe him, that he wholy for≈øaketh the profe≈ø≈øioÃÑ of the Chri≈øtian both in name and ≈øub≈øtance.

div.head: Periurie.
div.p: PEriurie, is a lie affirmed by othe. Sect' 1.
So much of ≈ølaunderous ≈øpeeches, again≈øt God.

div.head: Slaunder again≈øt man by word.
div.p: A Slaunder again≈øt man is an iniury done to him by wordes or writinges. Sect' 29. By words when any thing is ≈øaid or done by words to the contempt or reproche of an other.

div.head: By writing.
div.p: I Niurie by writing is done by a ≈ølaunderous libell or picture. Sect' 30.

div.head: By libell.
div.p: A Slanderous libel, is when a libell, epigram, rime or other writing Sect' 31. is produced, written or compo≈øed to the note or contumely of any man, or the ≈øame procured to be bought or ≈øold, that by that meanes the dignitie or fame of an other man may be hurt.

div.head: By Picture.
div.p: AN infamous or ≈ølaunderots picture, is when any man to his infamy Sect' 32. or ignominy is painted in any infamous or di≈øhone≈øt habit or ≈øort, as hanging vpon the gallowes, or in ≈øome euil place or maner.
We haue ≈øhewed thoffences committed by wordes, by which a mans name or dignitie is harmed: let vs now ha≈øten to tho≈øe which are done by deedes.

div.head: Offences by deeds.
div.p: ANnd they be ≈øaid to be done by deed, not becau≈øe they are not al≈øo Sect' 33. done of minde and purpo≈øe: but for that they chiefly con≈øi≈øt in the fact without which it may vnneth be Iudged of their puni≈øhment. And for that ≈øuch offences are not perpetrated again≈øt the minde, but the bodie either of man or his goods, whether it be done mediatly or immediatly. Offences by deeds either altogether di≈øtroy a thing, or at the lea≈øt impaire the ≈øame.

div.head: Destruction.
div.p: DE≈øtruction is the vtter killing or corrupting of things.
And it is either of a fact permanent and apparant: or tran≈øitorie,Sect' 34. and during but a little while.

div.head: Facts Permanent.
div.p: A Permanent fact, is that who≈øe verie ≈øteppes or prints abide, & are Sect' 35. to be ≈øeene after thoffeÃÑce done: of this kind be ≈ølaughter & burning.

div.head: Slaughter.
div.p: SLaughter is a killing done by any meanes, and it is either of man Sect' 36. or bea≈øt.

div.head: Homicide.
div.p:
THe ≈ølaughter of Man is called Homicide, which is euery taking away Sect' 37. of life from any per≈øon bond or free, by man done with violeÃÑce
by which the ≈øole is ≈øeuered from the bodie, by what maner of meanes ≈øo euer it chance, whether by ≈øword, ≈øtaffe, or other weapon, or by venim or poi≈øon, the cau≈øe of death be giuen.

div.head: Voluntarie.
div.p: HOmicide is either voluntarie or ca≈øual. Sect' 38.
Homicide voluntarie is that which is deliberate and committed of a ≈øet minde and purpo≈øe to kill.

div.head: Malicious.
div.p: HOmicide voluntarie is either without precedent malice or with Sect. 39. precedent malice.
Of homicides voluntarie without malice precedent, ≈øome are commaunded, and ≈øome tollerated by law, and others forbidden.

div.head: Commaunded.
div.p: HOmicides voluntarie commanded by law are ≈øuch as are done either Sect' 40. for Iu≈øtice ≈øake, or vpon vrgent nece≈ø≈øity.

div.head: For Iustice.
div.p: HOmicide for Iu≈øtice ≈øake, is thinflicting of ordinary puni≈øhment Sect' 41. vpon heinous offendors by death, which is di≈øpuni≈øhable, yet in this ca≈øe it behoueth the Iudge and other officers to be free from de≈øire of blood and priuate reuenge.

div.head: Nece≈ø≈øarie.
div.p: HOmicide vpon nece≈ø≈øity is either in the due & orderly execution of Sect' 42. Iu≈øtice, as the killing of thoffendors in felonie which re≈øi≈øt or flye officers hauing warrant to arre≈øt, or deteine them, or per≈øons pur≈øuing them with hue and crie, or riotors re≈øi≈øting Iu≈øtices of the peace, which come to arre≈øt them, or pri≈øoners re≈øi≈øting their gailors, if ≈øuch offendors cannot otherwi≈øe be attached or holden. So is it of per≈øons riotou≈øly a≈ø≈øembled re≈øi≈øting per≈øons aucthori≈øed to apprehend them, 1. Mar. ca. 1‚ñ™ 2. And likewi≈øe of offenders in parks, fore≈øts, and warrens, re≈øi≈øting or flying away after hue and crie, 21. Ed. 1. and Burglers and Robbers all which homicides are di≈øpuni≈øhable, 26. A≈ø≈ø. 32. and diuers other in like ca≈øes by ≈øundry ≈øtatutes.

div.head: Se defendendo.
div.p:
HOmicide vpon nece≈ø≈øity in ones owne defence is termed Se defendendo,
Sect' 43. & is where any man being a≈ø≈øaulted by any other, flyeth ≈øo farre as he can without eneuitable danger of death, & then in defending him≈øelfe killeth his aduer≈øarie, yet for this offence he loo≈øeth his goods, & mu≈øt procure pardon for his life, Glouc‚ñ™ cap. 9. 43. A≈ø≈ø. 31.

div.head: Forbidden.
div.p:
HOmicides voluntarie forbidden by Law, without precedent malice Sect' 44. is man≈ølaughter or homicide, or by chance medley, which is where two men void of all former malice and euill will, meeting together
by chance, & vpon ≈øudden falling out, thone of them killeth thother with violence neither for Iu≈øtice, nor in ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øitie, Plow. f. 100. & 101. 21. H. 7. fol. 23.

div.head: Homicide malicious.
div.p: THus much of voluÃÑtarie homicides without malice precedent, now Sect. 45. of homicide voluÃÑtarie of malice proceeding which is termed murder, & is the felonious killing through malice prepen≈øed of any per≈øon liuing in this Realme vnder the Queenes protection.

div.head: Of a mans ≈øelfe.
div.p: ANd it is either of him≈øelfe, or of another.

Homicide of the partie him≈øelfe, is termed felo de ≈øe. And is Sect. 46. where any man of hatred conceiued again≈øt him≈øelfe, doth de≈øperatly, wilfully and feloniou≈øly kil or de≈øtroy him≈øelfe by hanging, drowning, poy≈øoning or otherwi≈øe.

div.head: Murder.
div.p: MVrder of others then the ≈øelfe partie, is the like wilfull and felonious Sect. 47. killing of any other of premeditate malice. And if thoffendor did owe by Lawe vnto the partie ≈ølaine any ciuill obedience, it is in ≈øome ca≈øes termed petie trea≈øon. As if the wife kill her hu≈øband, the ≈øeruant his Ma≈øter or Mi≈øtres, or a Clerke his Ordinary by rea≈øon of the reciprocall tru≈øt, and loyaltie which the law requireth betweene ≈øuch per≈øons, and this offence is therefore farre more heynous then any of thother of homicides.

div.head: Homicide ca≈øuall.
div.p: THus briefly of Homicides willingly done, Homicide ca≈øual which Sect. 48. may al≈øo be termed, Homicide by mi≈øchance, mi≈øfortune, or mi≈øaduenture, is when he that killeth an other, had no will, intent, mind, or purpo≈øe ≈øo to do, or the‚ñ™ man is ≈ølaine by ≈øome other thing then a man. In which ca≈øe th ‚Ä¢ ffender is to haue his pardon of cour≈øe for life & land, but yet mu≈øt loo≈øe his goods. And this homicide is either mearely ca≈øuall or mixt.

div.head: By Chaunce.
div.p:
HOmicide by meare chaunce, is when by meare fortune again≈øt the Sect. 49. minde of the killer, a man is ≈ølaine. As if one hewing, the are flieth of the ≈øhafte and kill one, or if a man lopping a tree warneth the by≈øtanders, that the tree is ready to fall, and yet by the ≈øame ≈øome of them is ≈ølaine, or in throwing tiles from an hou≈øe or ≈øuch other lawfull acts, or the party is killed by ≈øome other thing then man by mi≈øfortune, as by falling from an hor≈øe or cart, by a ≈øtroke of an hor≈øe or any other moueable thing then man, In which ca≈øe the thing which killed him, and all things that moued the ≈øame are forfaited to the Queene, and termed a Deodand, as if a cart wheele go ouer a man and kill him, the
wheele, cart, and al things therein, and the hor≈øes that drew the ≈øame, be all Deodans, 3. E. 3. vndever≈øus.

p.hi: Omnia quae mouent ad mortem, ≈øunt Deodanda. Dyer fo. 78. pl. 37.

div.head: Mixte.
div.p: MIxt is when the killers ignorance, or negligence is ioyned with Sect. 50. the chauÃÑce, as if a man loppe trees by an high way ≈øide, by which many v≈øually t ‚Ä¢ auaile and ca≈øt downe a bough not giuing warning to take heed thereof, by which bough one pa≈ø≈øing by, is ≈ølaine, in whith ca≈øe he offendeth becau≈øe he gaue no warning that the party might haue taken heed to him≈øelfe.

div.head: Thus you ≈øee the diuers kinds of Man≈ølaughter. Slaughter of beasts.
div.p: THe ≈ølaughter of bea≈øts foloweth by what meane ≈øoeuer it coÃÑmeth, Sect. 51. which is a damage done by iniurie and wrong, guile or default again≈øt the Law, which might or ought to haue beene taken heed of. Of this offence ≈øpringeth an action to the owner of the bea≈øt according as the value thereof ≈øhall be e≈øteemed by a Iurie.

div.head: Burning.
div.p: THus farre of ≈ølaughters of man and bea≈øt: burning en≈øueth which Sect. 52. is al≈øo felony, as the wilfull burning of a dwelling hou≈øe, 3. H. 7. 10. And burning of a barne adioyning to a dwelling hou≈øe by night, 11. H. 7. fol. 1. And burning of a barne with corne not adioyning to a dwelling hou≈øe by day.

div.head: Offences tran≈øitorie.
div.p: ANd the≈øe concerning offences of continuing facts, tho≈øe follow Sect. 53. which are of tran≈øitorie or momentarie factes, as vnlawfull copulation, burglarie and theft.

div.head: Adulterie and fornication.
div.p: VNlawfull copulation, is euerie carnall coniunction had out of Sect. 54. lawfull matrimonie, and it is termed fornication or adulterie, which is fir≈øt either naturall or again≈øt nature, and either voluntary or violent. Fornication naturally committed, is betweene man and woman, which if it be perpetrated betweene kin≈øfolks, is ≈øaid to be ince≈øt. Copulation vilent is termed a rape or raui≈øhment of a woman again≈øt her will, which is carnall knowledge had of a woman, who neuer con≈øented thereunto before the fact nor after, and this offence is felony in the principall and his aydors, 11. H. 4. 13. 1. E. 4. 1. We≈øtmÃÑ 2. cap. 13. And carnall abu≈øe of a woman childe, vnder x. yeeres old is felony, 18. Eliz. cap. 6.

div.head: Sodomy or buggery.
div.p:
COpulation again≈øt nature, is by male or female again≈øt nature, or Sect. 55. by female with female, or with bea≈øts which is called‚ñ™ Sodomy or
buggery, 25. H. 8. cap. 5. 5. Eliz. cap. 17. which be felony.

div.head: Burglarie.
div.p: BVrglarie is a felonious entring into an other maÃÑs dwelling hou≈øe Sect. 56. wherein ≈øome per≈øon is, or into a Church, in the night time, to the end to commit ≈øome felony therein, as to kill ≈øome man, or to ≈øteale ≈øomewhat thence, or to do ≈øome other ≈øuch felonious act there, albeit he execute not the ≈øame, if thintent or fact of this offender be to ≈øteale, this is like robberie, If to murder, it differeth not much from murderers, & ≈øo of other felonies.

div.head: Hou≈øe-robbing.
div.p:
THe offence again≈øt the Statutes of 23. H. 8. cap. 1. and 3. Edw. 6.
Sect. 67. cap. 9. ≈øomewhat re≈øemble this, for by them it is ordained, that if any per≈øon do robbe another in any part of his dwelling place, or in his booth, or tent, in any faire or market, and the owner of his wife, children or ≈øeruants being within the ≈øame, he committeth felony.

div.head: Theft.
div.p: THeft en≈øueth, in which not ≈øo much the de≈øtruction of a thing, as Sect. 58. the taking away of the ≈øame chaunceth.

Theft is an vnlawfull felonious taking away of another mans moueable per≈øonall goods, again≈øt the owners wil, with intent to ≈øteale them. And it is from the per≈øon, or in pre≈øence of the owner, or in his ab≈øence.

div.head: From the per≈øon.
div.p: THeft from the owners per≈øon or pre≈øence, is of two ≈øortes, thone Sect. 59. putting thowner in feare, thother not.

div.head: Robberie.
div.p: RObberie is a felonious taking away of another mans goods, from Sect. 60. his per≈øon, or pre≈øence, again≈øt his will, putting him in feare and of purpo≈øe to ≈øteale the ≈øame goods.
And this robbery is ≈øometime termed violent theft, becau≈øe the party is in the law thereby terrified.

div.head: Without feare.
div.p: THeft froÃÑ thowners per≈øon, not putting him in feare, is by cutting Sect. 61 or picking his pur≈øe, and ≈øtealing the money, or pur≈øe, or both: this is done ≈øleightly, without the owners feare and priuity,

But to perfect this offence, an actuall po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the thing taken once ≈øeuered from the per≈øon of the owner, ≈øeemeth nece≈ø≈øarie in the offendor, and that the thing ≈øtollen, exceed the valew of xii. pence.

Theft of goods in the owners ab≈øence, is termed Larc ‚Ä¢ ny, which is nothing el≈øe but a felonious and fraudulent taking away of another maÃÑs moueable per≈øonal goods, not being vpon the per≈øon of the owner, nor in his pre≈øence. And Larciny in re≈øpect of the thinges ≈øtollen,
is either great or ≈ømall: For great Larciny is, when the things ≈øtollen though they be taken at ≈øeuerall times exceede the valew of xii. d . And petie Larcinie is, when the goods ≈øo taken exceede not the valew of xii. d .

div.head: Hurting and violence.
div.p: NOw then crimes comming from the de≈øtruction of things, being Sect. 62. thus ha≈øtely run ouer. Let vs ≈øteppe on to thother which haue their name of the hurting of the thing, and violent hurting de≈øtroyeth not the body, but harmeth and anoyeth it, and maketh either the body, or the ≈øtate and condition thereof wor≈øe.

div.head: Hurts to the bodie of the common wealth, as trea≈øons.
div.p: ANd through certaine offences is hurt to the common wealth immediatly, Sect. 63. and alwaies, or the members thereof. The common wealth is hurt eyther in re≈øpect of the amplitude and maie≈øtie thereof, or of the profite and commoditie thereof, which is hindered or intercepted.
When the Amplitude and maie≈øtie thereof is harmed, the offence is called trea≈øon.

And the≈øe trea≈øons be high trea≈øon, or petie trea≈øon: High trea≈øon is, when thoffence is done again≈øt the ≈øecuritie of the common wealth or of the Queenes mo≈øt excellent Maie≈øtie, who is the true and vndoubted Soueraigne and chiefe head thereof: whether it be by imagination, word, or deed, as to compa≈ø≈øe or imagine Trea≈øon, or the death of the Prince, or of the Queene his wife, or his Sonne and heire apparant, or to deflower the Kinges wife, or his elde≈øt daughter vnmarried, or his elde≈øt ≈øonnes wife, or leuie warre again≈øt the King in his Realme, or to adhere to his enimies, ayding them, or to counterfeit the Kings great ≈øeale, priuy ≈øeale, or money, or wittingly to bring fal≈øe money into this Realme, counterfeited like vnto the money of EnglaÃÑd, and vtter the ≈øame.

Or to kill the Kinges Chauncellor, Trea≈øurer, Iu≈øtice of thone bench or of the other, Iu≈øtices in Eire, Iu≈øtices of A≈ø≈øi≈øe, Iu≈øtices of Oyer and Terminer being in his place and doing of his Office, 25. Ed. 3. cap. 2.
Forging of the kings ≈øigne Manuell, or priuie ≈øignet, priuie ≈øeale, or forraine coyne currant within this Realme, 2. Mar. cap. 6.
Dimini≈øhing or impayring of money currant, 2. Eliz. cap. 11. & 18. Eliz. cap. 1.
The ≈øecond offence in refu≈øing the oath of ≈øupremacie, 5. Eliz. cap. 1.
Or the compa≈ø≈øing to depriue the Q. of her crowne, 1. Eliz. cap. 6.
Or to de≈øtroy the Queene, 1. Eliz. cap. 6.
Or to leuie warre within the realme again≈øt the Queene, 1. El. ca. 6.
Or to affirme that the Queene or the heires of her body, is not or ought not to be Queene of England, or that any other ought, 1. Eliz. cap. 6.
Or intending the bodily harme of the Q. 13. Eliz. cap. 1.
Or to leuie warre again≈øt the Queene. 13. Eliz. cap. 1.
Or to moue forreine inua≈øions of this Realme, 13. Eliz. cap. 1.
Or to declare, that the Queene is not Queene, 13. Eliz. cap. 1.
Or to declare that any other ought, &c. 13. Eliz. cap. 1.
Or to affirme the Q. to he an Heretike, Sci≈ømatike, tyrant, infidel, or v≈øurpor of the crowne, 13. Eliz. cap. 1.
Or to claime the crowne after the Queene, 13. Eliz. cap. 1.
Or to affirme that the common Lawes or ≈øtatutes cannot binde the right of the crowne, 13. Eliz. cap. 1.
Or to maintaine the aucthority of the Bi≈øhop of Rome, 5. Elizab. cap. 1.
Or to obtaine any Bull from Rome, 13. Eliz. cap. 2.
Or to giue, take or promi≈øe ab≈øolution thereby, 13. Eliz. cap. 2.
Or to con≈øpire to enlarge any impri≈øoned by the Queenes commaundement for trea≈øon touching her per≈øon or ≈øu≈øpition thereof, 14. Eliz. cap. 2.
Or to withhold any of the Queenes Ca≈øtels, or holdes, 14. Eliz. cap. 1.
Or any of her ≈øhips or ordinance of warre, 14. Eliz. cap. 1.
Or not to render the ≈øame Ca≈øtels, within ≈øixe daies after proclamation, 14. Eliz. cap. 1.
Or to de≈øtroy any of the Queenes ≈øhips, 14. Eliz. cap. 1.
Or to barre any of the Queenes hauens, 14 Eliz. cap. 1.
Or to per≈øwade any ≈øubiect from naturall obedience, or ReligioÃÑ: or to the obedience of any other, or to be ≈øo per≈øwaded, 23. Eliz. cap. 1.
Or for Ie≈øuits to come into, or be in this Realme, 27. El. ca. 2.
Or to be a Seminarie, and not returne into this Religion, within in ≈øixe moneths after proclamation, and take the oth of allegeance, 27. Eliz. cap. 2.
It is al≈øo to be noted, that al maner of acce≈ø≈øaries to the ≈øeueral treaons aboue mentioned, are guilty of high trea≈øon.

Or of mi≈øpri≈øion of trea≈øon, which is the concealment or not di≈øclo≈øing of knowen trea≈øon: for which thoffendors are to ≈øuffer impri≈øonment during the Queenes plea≈øure, loo≈øe their goods, and the profite of their lands during their liues, 2. R. 3. fol. 9.

div.head: Offences hindering the commoditie of the common wealth.
div.p: NOw ≈øucceed thoffences which hinder the commoditie of the coÃÑ mon Sect. 64. wealth.

The profite of the common wealth is hindered diuers waies, as by fore≈øtalling, engro≈ø≈øing, regrating, by idlene≈ø≈øe of appreÃÑtices, artificers, and ≈øeruants, decaying of the breede of bea≈øtes, de≈øtroying of fi≈øh, by coÃÑ ≈øpiracies of artificers and chapmen, by not de≈øtroying of vermin, as Foxes, Baw≈øons, Crowes, Choughes &c. Or by making or vttering any ≈øtuffe, victuals, or wares deceitfull, corrupt, or in≈øufficient, by not ob≈øeruing due weights, & mea≈øures, or by tran≈øporting of things needfull in England, as rawe hides, tallow, wooll, lead, corne or graine, by erecting of cotages, and breeding of exceeding many poore people, and by ≈øundry other meanes, as plainly appeareth by ≈øundry ≈øtatutes and ordinances made for reformation therof. Of all which particularly to di≈øcour≈øe, would occupie more time then I haue now determined to be≈øtow about the ≈øame.

Fore≈øtalling, is the buying or bargayning for any victuals or wares, comming to be ≈øold towards any faire or market: Or from beyond the ≈øeas towards any citie, port, hauen, creeke, or rode of this Realme, and before the ≈øame be there.
Or the mouing of any per≈øon to enhaunce the price of the ≈øame victuals or wares, or the di≈ø≈øwading to bring it thither to be ≈øold, 5. Ed. 6. cap. 14. 5. Eliz. cap. 12. 13. Eliz. cap. 25.
Regrating, is the buying and ≈øelling of any wares or victuals in the ≈øame market, or faire, or within foure miles thereof. 5. Edw. 6. cap. 14. 5. El. ca. 12. 13. Eliz. cap. 25.

Engro≈ø≈øing, is buying of Corne growing, or dead victuall to ≈øell againe: except barly or malt, Oates for Oatmeale, and victuals to retaile, badging by licence, and buying of Oyles, Spices, and victuals, other then fi≈øh and ≈øalt. 5. Edw. 6. cap. 14. 5. Eliz. cap. 14. 13. Eliz. cap. 25.

div.head: Offences against Subiects.
div.p: IN the≈øe fewe, haue we touched ≈øuch offences as immediatly, and alwaies Sect. 65. are committed again≈øt the common wealth it ≈øelfe: now will we intreat of tho≈øe which alwaies for the mo≈øt part are perpetrated violently again≈øt the inferiour members of the ≈øame (that is to ≈øay) either priuate men them≈øelues, or their goods, which are effected partly by force, and partly without force.
Force is an offence by which violence is v≈øed to thinges or per≈øons.
And force is either ≈øimple or mixt.

Simple force is that which is ≈øo committed, that it hath none other crime adioyned vnto it. As if one by force onely entreth into another mans po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, without doing any other vnlawfull act there.

Mixt force is that violence, which is committed with ≈øuch a fact, as
of it ≈øelfe onely is criminall: as if any by force enter into anothers po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and kill a man, or raui≈øh a woman there &c.
And tho≈øe offences which are atchieued with force, are done by true force, or by force after a certaine ≈øort.
Tho≈øe offences which are fini≈øhed hy true force, are either done by men a≈ø≈øembled, or without men a≈ø≈øembled.
And force with men a≈ø≈øembled is priuate or publike.

Priuate force is when any with weapons by men a≈ø≈øembled, doth inuade the goods or body of another, As tre≈øpas by entring into grouÃÑd, or taking his cattell, or other goods, impri≈øoning of a mans body, or beating of him with ones fi≈øt, or re≈øcues of a tre≈øpas, pound breach, or otherwi≈øe without weapon and ≈øuch like.

Publike force is that violence which is done by any men a≈ø≈øembled with any kinde of weapon what≈øoeuer, as by forcible entree, keeping of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Benefices, Chappels, hou≈øes, or lands, or offices, vnlawfull a≈ø≈øemblees, routs, riots, rebellions again≈øt &c. 1. Mar. cap. 12. 1. Eliz. cap. 17.

A forcible entree is a violent actuall entree into a hou≈øe, or land &c. or taking a di≈øtre≈ø≈øe of any per≈øon weaponed. Whether he offer violence or feare of hurt to any there, or furiou≈øly driue any out of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof, 5. R. 2. cap. 7. 15. R. 2. cap. 2. 8. H. 6. cap. 7.

A forcible deteyning or withholding of a po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, is a violent act of re≈øi≈øtaÃÑce by ≈øtrong hand of men weaponed with harne≈ø≈øe or other action of feare in the ≈øame place or els where, by which the lawfull entree of Iu≈øtices or others is barred or hindered, 29. A≈ø≈ø. 49.

An vnlawfull a≈ø≈øemblie, is the meeting of three, or mo per≈øons together, with force to commit ≈øome vnlawfull act, and abiding ≈øtill, not indeuoring the execution thereof, as to a≈ø≈øault or beate any per≈øon, or enter into his hou≈øe or land &c.
A rout is an a≈ø≈øembly of three per≈øons or mo, going on about forcibly to committe an vnlawfull act, but yet doe it not. Brooke tit. Riot, 4. 5.
A Riot is the forcible doing of an vnlawful act by three, or moe per≈øons a≈ø≈øembled together for that purpo≈øe.

A rebellious a≈ø≈øembly, is an a≈ø≈øembly of twelue per≈øons or moe intending, going about, practi≈øing, or putting in vre vnlawfully of their owne aucthoritie to chaunge any Lawes, or Statutes of this Realme, or to de≈øtroy thinclo≈øure of any Parke, or ground inclo≈øed, or the bankes of any fi≈øhponds, pale, or conduit, to thintent the ≈øame ≈øhall remaine void, or to the intent vnlawfully to haue common or way in any of y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid grouÃÑds, or to de≈øtroy the Deare in any parke, or any warren of CuÃÑnies, or douehou≈øes, or fi≈øh in any pond, or any hou≈øe, barnes, milles,
or baies, or to burne ≈øtackes of corne, or to abaterents, or prices of victuals, 1. Mar. 12. cap. 1. Eliz. cap. 17.
Al≈øo by the ≈øame ≈øtatutes an vnlawfull a≈ø≈øembly may be of per≈øons aboue the number of two: but that offence is neither ≈øo heinous, nor ≈øo ≈øharply to be puni≈øhed.

It followeth how force may be committed without a multitude. This kind of force comprehendeth euery harme, hurt, damage, lo≈ø≈øe, hinderance, and danger be≈øides death, happening to any good, quicke or dead, moueable or vnmoueable, or to men, eyther culpa or dolo, that is negligently or vnwittingly, or guilefully or of ≈øet purpo≈øe, whether it be a≈ø≈øaulting, beating, wounding, maiming, or hurting, bru≈øing, or impairing of the body of man or bea≈øt by any meanes: Or the bru≈øing, breaking or empairing of any other thing what≈øoeuer without a multitude, al≈øo breaking of pri≈øons, to e≈øcape thence, breaking of hou≈øes to ≈øteale ≈øomething thence, or to do ≈øome felony there, which being in the night is termed Burglary, whereof we haue ≈øpoken before entreating of theft. In this ranke al≈øo may be placed the pulling vp or remouing of meares, bouÃÑds, or markes, ≈øet for the deuiding of one mans land from anothers, and many other ≈øuch tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes wherein is none apparant force or terror, as to hawke, hunt, fi≈øh, or fowle, or to cut, eate, tread or foile gra≈ø≈øe in another mans ≈øoile vnlawfully, 11. A≈ø≈ø. 16. 11. H. 8. 4. 16. 21. E. 3. 34.

Hitherto of offences done by true force indeed: now of ≈øuch as are not properly done with force & violence, but by intendment of the law onely: of which ≈øort be bribery, extortion, exaction, priuate impri≈øonment, and certeine other like mi≈ødemeanors.

Tho≈øe offences of briberie, extortion, and exaction, are committed when any for feare of his iudgement, office, or other power, or authoritie, or for any other terror exacteth, extorteth, and wringeth money or other things from another man, as Sherifes, Coroners, or other Officers, Auditors, Receyuers, E≈øcheators, cu≈øtos breuium, Chirografers of fines, Admirals, Mar≈øhals, Criers, Maiors, Baylifes, Clarks, Wardens of felow≈øhips, Iudges, Bi≈øhops, Ordinaries, or other Officers what≈øoeuer for reformation of which, ≈øee the ≈øeueral ≈øtatutes therof, in that behalfe prouided.

To this crew as it ≈øeemeth, may be referred the exaction of vnlawfull v≈øurie: which is taking of any thing of any man for the lone, or giuing day of payment of money, 37. H. 8. cap. 9. 13. Eliz. cap. 10.
And all vnlawfull games, which be all games, but ≈øhooting, 33. H. 8. cap. 9.

And euery other taking of more then is due by colour or pretence of right, as the taking of exce≈ø≈øiue toll by millers, or others, or of exce≈ø≈øiue
pri≈øes for ale, bread, victuals, wares or other things.

div.head: Offences ≈øpringing from words and deeds.
div.p: SO much then of ≈øingle offences, ≈øpringing from only words, or onely Sect' 66. deeds. Now folow tho≈øe which i≈ø≈øue from both together, as tho≈øe which ari≈øe from the crime of fal≈øhood.
The offence of fal≈øhood is a guileful and fraudulent imitation of the truth again≈øt the law, and it is committed either by word or by deede.

Fal≈øhod by word, is by lying, as if any man ≈øhould faine vnto him≈øelfe a fal≈øe name or ≈øurname, or ≈øay, he is another man then he is, to deceiue ≈øome other: or by periurie which is a lie affirmed by oath.

Fal≈øhood by deed is as if a man write or ≈øigne a fal≈øe te≈øtament, or fal≈øly ≈øet downe therein ≈øome legacie or tru≈øt to him≈øelfe, without the mind of the te≈øtator, or if a man make a fal≈øe deed, or accompt, or other in≈øtrument, or if he bribe or corrupt a Iudge, or do raze, change, or corrupt any writing, to the defrauding of another man, or do conuey, remoue, or take away, ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe, conceale, or fal≈øly ≈øigne a te≈øtament or counterfait an other mans hande in writing, or to counterfait or vtter fal≈øe money, or to adulterate, emba≈øe, ≈øhaue, file, clippe, wa≈øh, or empaire the currant coine of England, or counterfait the lands of magi≈øtrates, and certificates te≈øtimonials, or licences in their names, or to v≈øe fal≈øe weights, mea≈øures, or ≈øtandards not agreeable with the ≈øtandard. To corrupt or ≈øuborne fal≈øe witne≈ø≈øes. To make fal≈øe accompts or reckonings.

Hitherto may we referre maintenance, and champerty and ≈øuits, embra≈øing or enueigling of Iurors, forging of fal≈øe and fraudulent writings, making of fraudulent feoffements, lea≈øes, & deeds of gift, or rather fal≈øe graunts, or conueiances of lands or goods, to defraud true creditors, fraudulent con≈øpiring of any mans death, to auow & vndertake vpon one to defend other mens quarrels, to be patron to the cau≈øes of others, by lending of ones name for meed, or fauour, of an offendor, or to vexe, prouoke, or reuenge.
Al≈øo fal≈øly to collude in pleading, or to betray, or to loo≈øe his clients cau≈øe wittingly, or fal≈øly di≈øcontinue & for≈øake his clients ≈øuite.

div.head: Other mens offences, and how farre they bind vs.
div.p: VVE haue intreated of our owne offences: other mens ≈øucceed, Sect' 67. namely, when, and how farre we are bound by them.
And we are bound by other in offences, wheÃÑ we are tied by the faults of our family, or of our bea≈øts.

Our family offendeth by lying, or ca≈øting, or hanging of any thing in
the high way, whereby it is ≈øtopped or hindred: which offence is called a Nu≈øance.
We are bound by many tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes of our wiues, but not to ≈øu≈øtaine corporal puni≈øhment for their offences.

Al≈øo if our bea≈øts or cattel offend in eating other mens corne or gra≈ø≈øe, or in hurting or killing the bea≈øts, or cattels of others, we are bound by it, or if our dogges, beares, or lyons, bores, &c. hurt the goods or cattel of any other, we are bound thereby, for that we ought to gouerne them.

div.head: Offences vnnamed.
div.p: INough of named offences, it remaineth that we view tho≈øe which be Sect' 68. vnnamed.

For when the varietie of offences grew ≈øo manifold, that all could not be di≈øtingui≈øhed by ≈øpeciall names, it was appointed that proper or ≈øpecial names afore≈øaid, failing, the offence of co≈øening, and deceipt, ≈øhould come in place.

Thoffence of co≈øening taketh place, if any thing be done by guile in, or out of contracts, which wil not agree with any of the ≈øaid offences, as if any v≈øe collu≈øion or fraud towards the death, or defrauding of another, ≈øhifting or counterfait ware into the place of others: or to exact a greater ≈øumme then is due, or a debt which is paid, or ≈øel, or pledge any thing to two, ≈øeuerally at one time, or that thing which is another maÃÑs for his owne, knowing it to be another mans: or to pledge copper, or other ba≈øe mettall for gold, or ≈øiluer &c.

Deceit is a ≈øubtil wilie ≈øhift or deui≈øe hauing none other name. Herevnto may be drawen al maner of craft, ≈øubtilty, guile, fraud, wiline≈ø≈øe, ≈øleightne≈ø≈øe, cunning, couin, collu≈øion, deceit, deui≈øe practi≈øe, & offence v≈øed to deceiue an other man by any means which hath none other proper or particuler name but offence.

div.head: Of Indictments as remedies for the former di≈øea≈øes.
div.p: THus haue we rather ≈øleightly ≈øhadowed, then perfectly portraied Sect' 69. the vglie ≈øhape of ≈øuch enormous offences, as with their deformity mo≈øt blemi≈øh the bodie of our beautifull, (otherwi≈øe flori≈øhing) common wealth. Now therefore we are to ≈øhow the waies how to prepare remedies for the ≈øame, which mu≈øt be done by indictmeÃÑts, in which are chiefly to be eyed the matter and forme.

The matter or obiect of indictments in nothing el≈øe but the ≈øeuerall offences and facts vnlawfull, before de≈øcribed, in which the very fact it ≈øelfe and the circum≈øtances thereof are to be waighed.

Touching thoffence or fact it ≈øelfe, we are here fully to regard the verie nature & qualitie of thoffence, as whether it be trea≈øon, felonie, tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe,
deceit, or ≈øome other offence, & of what ≈øeueral ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nd it is, & whether it be puni≈øhable by the common law, or by ≈øome penal ≈øtatut, that the indictment thereupon may be framed accordingly.
The circum≈øtances of the fact are ≈øeuen, that is to ≈øay, cau≈øe, per≈øon, time, place, qualitie, quantitie, and euent.

Touching the cau≈øe of thoffence we are to waigh ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ther thoffence be of cau≈øe iu≈øt or vniu≈øt: whether by chance or of malice & purpo≈øe, or vpon a ≈øudden, or by negligence, or by guile, which maketh ≈øome homicides lawful, ≈øome puni≈øhable, and that in ≈øeueral degrees.

The per≈øon is in two ≈øorts to be regarded, that is, as he is agent or patient. For it is not all one for infants and men of full age, and for men Mad, Lunatickes, and Idiots, to offend. And otherwi≈øe in many ca≈øes are they to be puni≈øhed which offend God, the common wealth, Magi≈øtrates, or their Mai≈øters and ≈øuperiours, then they which offende others.
The time al≈øo in offences maketh difference betweene offences, as in Larceny and burglarie.
The place in like maner maketh the ≈øelfe ≈øame fact either theft, burglarie, or ≈øacriledge.
By the con≈øideration of the qualitie we di≈øcerne whether an offence be hainous or not, & whether it ≈øtand in committing or omitting.
The view of the quantitie of thoffence ≈øhewed vs whether it be puni≈øhable by death or otherwi≈øe, & if by death, what maner of death, and regardeth the cu≈øtome, or iteration thereof.
The euent looketh to the final cau≈øe, purpo≈øe, or i≈ø≈øue, of the fact, whether it be ca≈øuall, or voluntarie.
All which circum≈øtances, are partly ≈øeene before, in the verie handeling of the offences: now let vs looke more ≈øpecially into the forme of the indictment.

div.head: Of the forme of Indictments.
div.p: IN the forme of euery Indictment, be≈øides the ordinarie wordes of Sect' 70. forme, preci≈øe certenty to euery intent is to be as warily looked vnto, as in declarations in ciuil ≈øuites & returne of Sherifes, 3. H. 7. fol. 11. & 12. 3. Ed. 4. 21. otherwi≈øe is the Indictment in≈øufficient, for Indictments and appeals be the very ba≈øe and foundation of euery criminall controuer≈øie.
This certentie con≈øi≈øteth, fir≈øt in the name and ≈øurname of the partie indicted, both principal and acce≈ø≈øorie.
2. In the certain name and ≈øurname of the partie offended.
3. In the certeinty of time, wherein the offence is done, as the certeine day, yere, yea, and many times the very houre is expre≈ø≈øed.
4. In the place where thoffence is perpetrated.
5. In the very matter of the fact, & nature of thoffence committed, as whether it be trea≈øon, felony, tre≈øpas, deceite, penal ≈øtatute &c.
6. In the name & value of the thing, in which thoffence is done.

Vnto the name of the partie indicted mu≈øt be vnited the addition of his e≈øtate, degree, or mi≈øterie, & the ≈øhier, & towne hamlet, or place of his then, or late dwelling or coÃÑmorans: all additioÃÑs which ≈øignify any lawful e≈øtate, degree, or mi≈øter ‚Ä¢ , are good: whether they be of dignity by creation, as Duke, Marques, Earle, Vicont, Archbi≈øhop, Bi≈øhop, knight, ≈øeriant at the law: or without creation, as Baron, E≈øquier, GentlemaÃÑ, which are names of dignity without creation. Al≈øo Alderman, Doctor, Archdeacon, Deane, Par≈øon, Pari≈øh clarke, Widow, ≈øinglewoman, be good additions of e≈øtate or degree: but fermour, ≈øeruant, butler, &c. are not, for that they are common to gentlemen, yeomen &c. & ≈øo incertein, marchant, grocer, tailer, ≈øhoomaker, tanner, currier, broker, hu≈øbandman, o≈øtler, habberda≈øher, miller, draper, gold≈ømith, butcher, chapman, labourer, ≈øpin≈øter, and euery other addition of any lawful occupations, be good additions of mi≈øterie. But neither Chancelor, Trea≈øorer, ChaÃÑ berlein, ≈øherife, coroner, elchetor, bailife, archdeacon, deacon, prebendary, par≈øon, nor ≈øuch other names of dignity by rea≈øon (onely of office) are good, but where ≈øuch per≈øons be charged for offence, by rea≈øon of their offices: nor citizen, for it neither nameth any mi≈øtery, art, nor degree: neither extorcioner, bankrupt, rogue, vagabond, v≈øurer, heretike, ≈øci≈ømatike, dicer, bowler, carder, nor ≈øuch like, being again≈øt the Law. If the place whereof thoffendor is or was, be an hamlet, & there be diuers hamlets in one towne, he may be named either of the towne or hamlet: but if it be only a place knowen a towne, and not an hamlet, he mu≈øt be named of the towne, 13. H. 6. fo. 30. if the towne where the offendor dwelleth beareth one ≈øelfe name with the pari≈øh, he may be named of either: but if there be 2. townes of one name, in one pari≈øh, he ought to be named of the pari≈øh 4. E. 4. fo. 129. 22. E. 4. fo. 22. & 22. H. 6. fo. 41. Alias dictus in Indictments is not nece≈ø≈øary. Thaddition of the degree or mi≈øtery mu≈øt be ≈øuch, as the party hath at the very time of thindictments: but he may be termed nuper of any place wherof he hath bin at any time before, but it is be≈øt to name him of ye place of which he is or la≈øt was thus: Iurato ‚Ä¢ pro dnÃÑa reg' pre≈øentÃÑ
quam I. S. nuper de D. in comÃÑ E≈ø≈øex hu≈øbandmaÃÑ &c. And further, the time of thoffence committed mu≈øt be thus ≈øet downe, as in per≈øonal actions 5. die Feb. anno regni dnÃÑae no≈øtrÃÑ Eliz. dei gratia Angl' &c. And in ≈øome indictments, as of murder, & burglary, the very hower is to be expre≈ø≈øed, as hora 6. ante merid' (if it were before noone) & po≈øt merÃÑ (if it were after) eiu≈ødeÃÑ diei: if thoffence be committed after noone and before midnight, it mu≈øt be laid in the ≈øame day: if after midnight,
and before ≈øunne ri≈øing, then in the day following: and if the time be expre≈ø≈øed by the yere of our Lord God (as it may be) then the yere beginneth with vs euermore vpon the 25. day of March: but in Indictments which pre≈øent that a thing is omitted, or not done, there needeth no time of the not doing or omi≈ø≈øion thereof be ≈øet forth, as that a ditch was not ≈økowred, by meanes whereof meadowes be ouerflowen, and ≈øuch like. If a man be ≈øtricken or poi≈øoned in one countie, & dieth thereof in another countie, thindictment may be in the countie where the death hapned 2. & 3. Eliz. ca. 24. and if one become acce≈ø≈øary in one County to a murder or other fellony done in another, he may well be indicted in the countie where he was acce≈ø≈øary. He which robbeth in the county of D. & is taken with the maner in the county of S. may be indicted of theft where he is ≈øo apprehended, but not of robbery, but in the countie where thoffence was done. The place is thus to be ≈øet downe apud B. in comitÃÑ C. For it is not good to ≈øay in comÃÑ praedict' referring to the name of the countie written in the margent of thindictment: and the place of the offence is ≈øometime more ≈øpecially ≈øet downe thus, apud B. in comÃÑ C. in quodam loco ibideÃÑ vocatÃÑ the northclo≈øe &c. al≈øo it is to be regarded, that if a countie be deuided into ≈øeueral diui≈øions, ≈øo that tho≈øe which be Iu≈øtices in one diui≈øion, be not Iu≈øtices in another diui≈øion thereof, as the countie of Yorke, which is deuided into 3. deui≈øions, called ridings, as the we≈øtriding, ea≈øtriding, & northriding: it is requi≈øite that it be expre≈ø≈øed in thindictment, in which of the diui≈øions or ridings thoffences hapned, as apud R. in We≈øtriding in comÃÑ EborÃÑ in quodam loco ibid' vocatÃÑ the lodge &c. for the Commi≈ø≈øions, whereby the Iu≈øtices of peace in ≈øuch ridings are ordeined, haue in them ≈øuch words, as follow, viz. Sciatis quod a≈ø≈øignamus vos coniuÃÑctim & diui≈øim, & quemlibet ve≈øtruÃÑ Iu≈øtic' n ‚Ä¢ os ad pacem no≈øtram in partibus de We≈øtriding in comÃÑ no≈øtro Eborum con≈øeruandam &c. Mandamus enim tenore pre≈øentium vic' no≈øtro EboruÃÑ quod ad illos dies & loca, que vos vel aliqui hmÃÑodi duo vel plures vrÃÑm, vt praed' e≈øt, ≈øcirÃÑ feceritis venire coram vobis vel hmÃÑdi duobus vel pluribus ve≈øtrum, vt dictum e≈øt, tales probos & legales homines de partibus praedict' tam infra libertates quam extra, per quos rei veritas in premi≈ø≈øis melius ≈øciri poterit & inquiri &c. So that the power of ≈øuch Iu≈øtices extendeth no further then to tho≈øe ridings onely in which they bin ≈øo made Iu≈øtices, and therfore what is by them done otherwi≈øe is coram non Iudice, and void.

Albeit the name of the per≈øon to whom thoffence is committed be in many ca≈øes required, yet an indictment quod defendens bona & catalla cuiu≈ødam ignoti felonice cepit &c. in theft: or quendam ignotum felonice depredauit &c. in robbery, is good for the Queenes aduantage of the forfaiture thereby accrewing, ≈øo is it as it ≈øeemeth quod vi & armis
&c. in≈øultum & affraiam in quendam ignotum fecit &c. Dier fol. 99. pag. 61. & 285. p. 38. But if the goods of a Church be taken away, the Indictment mu≈øt be quod bona parochianorum in cu≈øtodia gardianorum Eccle≈øiae de C. exi≈øtenÃÑ ceperunt, & a≈øportauerunt &c. if the goods of a man be taken, who maketh his executors and dieth, the Indictment mu≈øt be, bona te≈øtatoris &c. but if they be taken after the te≈øtators death, it ≈øhall be bona te≈øtatoris in cu≈øtod' executÃÑ exi≈øtenÃÑ &c. A graue≈øtone is de bonis Eccle≈øiae, coate armour hanged ouer a tombe, be the goods of the dead mans executors: goods taken from one, are the goods of the tre≈øpa≈ø≈øer, vntill the owner haue recontinued his property: goods bailed, are ≈øaid bona, of the owner in cu≈øtodia balliui. The names of things in which the offeÃÑce is committed ought al≈øo to be certeinly mencioned, in Indictments, dead things may be called, bona & catalla, expre≈ø≈øing their names certeinly, as appeareth hereafter: but of liuing things we mu≈øt not ≈øay: bona & cattalla, but vnum equum, or 2. equos & ouem, bouem &c. And the value of tho≈øe things in which offences are committed is v≈øually compri≈øed in Indictments, which ≈øeemeth nece≈ø≈øarie in theft to make a difference from petie Larceny, & in tre≈øpas, to aggrauate the fault & increa≈øe the fine, but no price of things ferae naturÃÑ may be expre≈ø≈øed, as of deere, hares, &c. if they be not in parks or warrens, which is a liberty 8. E. 4. fo. 5. nor of Charters of land. And where the number of the things taken are to be expre≈ø≈øed in the indictment, as of yong doues in a douehou≈øe, yong hawkes in a wood, there mu≈øt be ≈øaid precij, or ad valentiam: but of one liuing thing, or of one dead thing onely, it is precij, and not ad valentiam, but of diuers dead things ad valentiam, & not precij. Of come not currant, it ≈øhalbe praecij but of coine curraÃÑt ≈øhal neither be ≈øaid precij, nor ad valentiam, For the price and value therof is certein, but of counterfait coine, ≈øhalbe ≈øaid ad valentiam, & in counterfaiting of coine ≈øhal not be ≈øaid x. li. libras in denarijs dominae Reginae, nor in pecunia dominae Reginae, but ad in≈øtar pecuniae dominae Reginae.

The verie maner of the fact or deed it ≈øelfe, and nature of the offence mu≈øt al≈øo be mentioned in the indictment, as in e≈øcape, for pri≈øon breaking, mu≈øt be expre≈ø≈øed, for what felony the offendor was apprehended, & impri≈øoned. And for counterfaiting of money mu≈øt be ≈øhewed to what the counterfait is like, as groats, ≈øhillings, &c. And in murder and man≈ølaughter, the ≈øtroke whereof death en≈øued, Dyer fol. 99. pl. 63. And for ≈ølanderous words again≈øt the Queene, the very words mu≈øt be certeinly ≈øet downe. And for entrie, into hou≈øe, land or tenements mu≈øt be expre≈ø≈øed, what maner of hou≈øe, lands or tenements, as a me≈ø≈øuage, a cottage, arable land, medow, pa≈øture, or wood. And where in any Indictment, ≈øeuerall acts be ≈øaid to make vp thoffence which may be done at ≈øeueral
times and places, both the times & places mu≈øt be certeinly expre≈ø≈øed, as in murdar & man≈ølaughter, tha≈ø≈øault and the ≈øtriking, as apud B. in comitatu E. &c. in quendam I. S. in≈øultum fecit, & ip≈øum I. S. cum quodaÃÑ gladio precij &c. adtunc & ibid' felonice, & ex malitia ≈øua praecogitata Íùëcu≈ø≈øit & murdrauit. And in theft, the thing ≈øtollen mu≈øt certenly be laide downe, 22. A≈ø≈ø. pla. 75. & 29. A≈ø≈ø. 45. And an Indictment again≈øt an acce≈ø≈øarie, mu≈øt ≈øhew what felony the principal committed, and that knowing it, receiued the felon feloniou≈øly, 7. H. 6.

Touching the ≈øeueral natures of ≈øeueral offeÃÑces, it is to be noted, that in Indictments of trea≈øons, the fact mu≈øt be nece≈ø≈øarily ≈øai ‚Ä¢ to be done, proditorie: of murder, murdrauit: and of man≈ølaughter, and all other felonies, the deed mu≈øt be ≈øaid to be done felonice, and in burglary, Burglariter, or intentione ad felomam ≈øiue murdrum faciend &c. in rape felonice rapuit, in theft, felonice cepit & a≈øportauit, if it be a dead thing: if liuing, abduxit, or felonice furatus e≈øt, In petie Larceny and maime, mu≈øt al≈øo be ≈øaid, felonice.

And notwith≈øtanding the ≈øtatute of 37. H. 8. ca. 8. it is not ami≈ø≈øe in euery indictment conteining felony or tre≈øpas, to v≈øe the wordes (vi & armis (viz. gladijs, baculis, cultellis &c. And in a Forcible entre vpon the ≈øtatute 8. H. 6. ca. 9. mu≈øt be manuforti &c. or cum multitudine gentiuÃÑ &c. And in an IndictmeÃÑt found vpon ≈øtatuts, it ≈øeemeth not needful to recite the ≈øtatute verbatim, as hath bin heretofore v≈øed, and namely, if the ≈øtatute be general 5. H. 5. 11. 30. a≈ø≈ø. 38. But fully & certeinly to de≈øcribe thoffence again≈øt the tenor of the ≈øame ≈øtatute. And then conclude with the≈øe words. Contra formam ≈øtatuti in humÃÑdi ca≈øu proui≈øi & aediti: If there be onely one ≈øtatute of that offence: but if there be diuer≈øe coÃÑ cerning the ≈øame, then the conclu≈øion mu≈øt be, Contra formam diuer≈øorum ≈øtatutorum in hmÃÑdi ca≈øu aeditÃÑ & proui≈øorum &c.

And it is ≈øpecially to be noted that in Indictments grounded vpon penal ≈øtatuts (other then for tillage) giuing the penaltie to the Queene onely, may be exhibited at any time within two yeres after the offence. But if the benefit be to the Prince & another per≈øoÃÑ, it ought to be ≈øued for ≈øuch per≈øon and the Prince within one yere. And for the Prince alone within three yeres, if ≈øhorter time be not in that behalfe limited in ≈øuch Penal ≈øtatutes, 31. Eliz. cap. 5.
But the formes of Indictments will be≈øt appeare in the following examples, which for the Readers ea≈øe I haue here Alphabetically ≈øet downe as en≈øueth.

div.head: For keeping an Alchou≈øe or Tiplinghou≈øe.
div.p:
IVratores pro Domina Regina pre≈øentant, quod A. B. de C. in dict' comitatu Sect' 67. E. yeoman, vice≈øimo die men≈øis Octobris, Anno regni dominÃÑ
no≈øtrae Elizabethae, Dei gratia Angliae, Franciae, & Hiberniae Reginae, fidei defen≈øoris &c. Trice≈øimo, & continue multis diebus po≈øtea, viz. v≈øque primum diem dicti Octob. AnnÃÑ ≈øupradicto, apud C. praedict' in comitatu praedicto, ob≈øtinate atque ex aucthoritate propria ip≈øius A. B. ≈øine vlla Iu≈øticiariorum pacis dictae dominae Reginae in comitatu praedicto admi≈ø≈øione aut allocatione, a≈ø≈øump≈øit ≈øuper ≈øe cu≈øtodire, & cu≈øtodiuit vnam communem Tabernam (Anglice vocataÃÑ a common Tipling hou≈øe) & ibidem dicto vice≈øimo die, & dictis diebus tum po≈øtea, communiter & publice vendidit cerui≈øiam, & potum (Anglice dictum Ale and Beere) diuer≈øis dictae dominae Reginae ligeis & ≈øubditis. In dictae dominae Reginae contemptum, ac contra formam cuiu≈ødam ≈øtatuti, in parliamento domini Edwardi nuper Regis Angliae ≈øexti, tento apud We≈øtmonÃÑ Anno regni dicti domini Edwardi quinto, in huiu≈ømodi ca≈øu proui≈ø. & editi.

div.head: For ≈øilke in a Cappe.
div.p: IVratores pro Domina Regina prae≈øentant, quod A. B. de C. in dicto Sect' 72. Comitatu Tailor, natus infra hoc regnum Angliae, videlicet, apud C. praedictam, ≈øed filius aut haeres apparens alicuius militis, aut filius hominis altioris gradus non exi≈øtens, nec potens expender per annum viginti libras, in terris, tenementis, feodis, officijs, aut alijs annuis reuentionibus, pro termino vitae ≈øuae: nec valens ducentas libras de bonis ≈øuis proprijs: nec vnquam Maior, Balliuus, Aldermanus, aut capitalis officiarius in aliqua Ciuitate, burgo, aut villa corporata exi≈øtens, nec dictae dominae Reginae ≈øeruiens in ordinario (vtens dictae dominae Regine liberata) exi≈øtens: 20. tamen die Octobris, anno regni dicte dominae no≈øtrae Elizabethae, Dei gratia, Angliae, Franciae, & Hibernie Reginae, fidei defen≈øoris, &c. F. tunc in pace dictae dnÃÑae reginae in dicta domo ≈øua exi≈øtente.) Et ≈øic predictÃÑ A. B. dicto octauo die Iulij, Anno ≈øupradicto, apud C. praedictÃÑ, domum man≈øionalem predicti E. F. predictÃÑ, modo & forma predictÃÑ, voluntarie ex dicta malicia ≈øua praecogitata, et felonice incendit & combu≈ø≈øit: contra pacem dictae dominae Reginae no≈øtrae, ac coronÃÑa, & dignitatem ≈øuas.

G. in eadem domo tunc exi≈øtentÃÑ, tantum timorem corporalem tunc & ibidem inferrebant, ita quod de vitis ≈øuis de≈øperabatÃÑ, as ≈øi dictus W. ≈øimul cum alijs predictis, adtunc & ibidem ex malitia ≈øua praecogitata, eandem domum cum igne tunc & ibidem felonice comburebat, predictÃÑ E. R. C. in P. & E. G. in eadem domo exi≈øtence, contra pacem &c. vt ≈øupra. Ac ≈øi W. R. de B. in comitatu praed' yeoman, & W. I. de S. in comitatu E. predictÃÑ generÃÑ ante felonÃÑ praedictÃÑ per ip≈øos I. C. & alios factam & perpetratam, praed' W. S. praedicto 27. die FebrÃÑ anno ≈øupradicto apud B. predictÃÑ in comitatu predictÃÑ ad felonÃÑ predictÃÑ ≈øic in forma predictÃÑ faciend' & perpetrand' felonice excitauerunt, procurauerunt, & abbettauerunt, contra pacem &c. ac ≈øi praedictÃÑ W. R. & W. S. ≈øcientes predictÃÑ W. S. ≈øimul cum alijs ≈øupradictis felonÃÑ praed' in forma pÃÑdictÃÑ, ≈øic feci≈ø≈øe & perpetra≈ø≈øe, euÃÑdem W. div.p: IVratÃÑ pre≈øentant, quod cum in ≈øtatuto in Parliamento domini E. nuper Sect' 94. Regis Anglie ≈øexti, apud We≈øtmÃÑ, anno regni ≈øui quinto, tentÃÑ, editÃÑ, inter cetera ≈øtabilitÃÑ exi≈øtit &c. Quidam tamen G. B. nuper de S. &c. 2. die Iunij, &c. vi & armis, viz. &c. cum quodam pugionÃÑ in quendam T. C. in pace Dei & dictae dominae Reginae exi≈øtenÃÑ apud C. in comitÃÑ E. praedict' in cemeterio Eccle≈øiae parochialis de C. praed' in≈øultum fecit, & ip≈øum T. ≈øuper caput ≈øuumadtunc & ibideÃÑ malicio≈øe percu≈ø≈øit, & alia enormia ei intulit ad graue damnum ip≈øius T. & contra pacem dictae dominae Reginae &c. ac contra formam ≈øtatuti praedicti &c.

div.p:

dominae Reg' omnis & ≈øingula per≈øona ≈øiue per≈øone inhabitantÃÑ in hoc regno Ang' aut aliquod aliud dominiorÃÑ dict' dominae reg', diligenter & fidelitÃÑ, habentes nullam legalem ≈øeu rationabilem excu≈øationem abe≈ø≈øendi, adnitentur adire ≈øuam parochialem eccle≈øiam vel capellam confuetam, vel ≈øuper rationabile impedimentum, ‚Ä¢ liquam vi≈øitatum locuÃÑ, vbi communes precationes, & diuina ≈øeruitia, in actu illo mencionatÃÑ celebrate fuerint tempore talis impedimenti, quolibet die Dominico, & alijs diebus ordinatÃÑ, & v≈øitatis ob≈øeruari vt fe≈øtiuis diebus, & tunc & ibidem manere ≈øecundum ordineÃÑ & ≈øobrie, durante tempore precum coÃÑ munÃÑ, predicationÃÑ, aut alioruum diuinorum ≈øeruitiorum ibidem vtend' & mini≈øtrand', ≈øub paena punitionis per cen≈øur as eccle≈øiae, & etiam ≈øub paena, quod quelibet per≈øona ≈øic offend', forisfaciat pro qualibet tali offen≈øa 12. denarios leuand' per gardianos Eccle≈øiae parochialis vbi talis offen≈øa foret fact' ad v≈øum pauperÃÑ inhabitÃÑ eiu≈ødem parochiae de bonis, terrÃÑ, & tenementÃÑ, talis offend' per modum di≈øtrictionÃÑ, prout in ≈øtatutÃÑ pÃÑ dict' continetÃÑ, cumque T. R. de D. in comÃÑ praed' armÃÑ & A. vx' eius, vtroque eor exi≈øt' aetatis 16. annÃÑ & amplius, ac exi≈øtant parochianÃÑ, ec ‚Ä¢ l' Íùëochial' de T. praed', in praed' comÃÑ E. infra quam quidem eccl' comÃÑes precationÃÑ, & alia diuina ≈øeruitÃÑ in ≈øtatutÃÑ praed' ≈øpec' po≈øt praed' fe≈øt' natiuitÃÑ S. Io. Ba. anno 1. ≈øupradict', ≈øcz. die dnÃÑca prox. po≈øt fe≈øtum S. Mich. Arch. anno regni Reg' Eliz. Dei gratia &c. 12. diebus dominicis tunc proximÃÑ ≈øequentÃÑ & 8. alijs diebus fe≈øtiualibus ea≈ødem 12. dies dominicas interuenientÃÑ dicebantur & vtebantur, praed' I. & A. non habentes legalem nec rationabilem excu≈øationem, ≈øeu impedimentÃÑ abe≈ø≈øendi ab Eccl' praed', in diebus praedict', tempore praedictÃÑ communÃÑ precum, predicationum, & diuiniorum ≈øeruitiorum ibidem tune dictorum, habitorum, & mini≈øtratorum non ≈øolum non adnitebantur adire Eccle≈ø. parochial' de D. praedictÃÑ exi≈øtenÃÑ eorum Eccle≈øiam con≈øuetam, in praedict' die domi ‚Ä¢ proximÃÑ po≈øt praedict' fe≈øtum ≈øancti Michael' Archang', anno Reg' dictae dnÃÑae reg' nunc 34. ≈øupradict' & praedict' alijs 12. diebus dominicis tun ‚Ä¢ prox' ≈øequenÃÑ, & praedictÃÑ alijs octodiebus fe≈øtiualibus inter ea≈ødem 12. dies dominicas interuenientÃÑ temporÃÑ praedictÃÑ communÃÑ precationÃÑ & diuinorum ≈øeruitiorÃÑ ibidem in diebus illis dictorÃÑ habitorÃÑ & mini≈øtratorum, ≈øed etiam odio habentÃÑ & contenentÃÑ Euang' & ≈øalub' dei verbuÃÑ & dict' dominam reg', & leges ≈øuas, ≈øeip≈øos voluntarÃÑ ab≈øentauerunt, & vterque eoruÃÑ voluntarie ≈øeip≈øum ab≈øentauit ab eccl' praed' die dnÃÑca Íùìx' po≈øt fe≈øt' S. Mich. Arch. anno reg' dictÃÑ dnÃÑae reginÃÑ nunc 34. ≈øuprad' & pÃÑ dictÃÑ alijs 12. diebus donÃÑcis tunc prox' ≈øequentÃÑ, & praed' alijs S. dieb fe≈øtiual' inter ea≈ød' 12. dies dnÃÑcas interuenientÃÑ tempore praed' communiuÃÑ precum, praedicationÃÑ, & diuinÃÑ ≈øeruiciorÃÑ ibid' in diebus illis, dictorÃÑ, habitorÃÑ, & mini≈øtratorÃÑ, contra paceÃÑ & in contemptÃÑ dictÃÑ dnÃÑae reginae nunc & legem ≈øuam & coronam & dignitatem ≈øuam, ac contÃÑ formÃÑ ≈øtatutÃÑ praed',
& in pernitio≈øum exemplum aliorÃÑ malefactorÃÑ &c.

div.head: For taking of Conies in a free warren in the night time.
div.p:

div.head: For con≈øpiring and combining to indicte one for ≈øtealing of a hor≈øe of one of the con≈øpirators, and for procuring of diuers fal≈øe ≈øuites to bee brought and pur≈øued in the names of the con≈øpirators, and of diuers others again≈øt diuers per≈øons.
div.p:
IVratores &c. pre≈øentÃÑ, quod I. P. nuper de I. in praedicto comitÃÑ E. et Sect' 97. R. B. nuper de C. in praed' comitÃÑ E. generÃÑ vna cum alijs quamplurimis per≈øonis adhuc ignotÃÑ, contra legem domini regis ad formam ≈øtatutoruÃÑ in huiu≈ømodi ca≈øu proui≈øorum, con≈øpiratione & couina apud T. praedÃÑ die &c. habitÃÑ, diuer≈øis temporib‚ñ™ po≈øtea ≈øimul vnitÃÑ, confederati, et iurati fal≈øo fraudulentÃÑ & malicro≈øe venerÃÑ ad vindicand', de≈øtruend', perturbaÃÑƒë, placitand', adnihiland', & ≈øimilitÃÑ adnulland' fideles et innocentes ligeos dicti domini regis pro lucro ad eorum proprium v≈øum capiendo, ≈øocietatem inierunt, & adinuicem iurauerunt, ad ≈øimul ≈øtandum contra dictuÃÑ dominum regem, et quo≈øcunque ligeos ≈øuos in omnibus et ≈øingulis materijs placitis et querelis, perip≈øos et eorum quemlibet motis ≈øeu mouendis. Et ≈øi eorum aliquis cum aliquo, placita, materiam, ≈øeu querelaÃÑ moueret, quod ip≈øi & eorum quilibet cum eo, ≈øic materiam, querelam, ≈øeu placitum mouentÃÑ ≈øtare, et per≈øeuerare deberent et deberet. Et ≈øi aliquis eorum aliquam querelam ≈øeu placitum nomine alterius per≈øone cuiu≈øcunque, ver≈øus aliam per≈øonam ≈øuper ≈øe a≈ø≈øump≈øerit manutenend', extunc eorum quilibet querelam, ≈øectam, ≈øeu placitÃÑ praedict', tanquaÃÑ querelam, ≈øectam, ≈øeu placitum, nomine eorum pro≈øecutÃÑ, manuteneret, foueret et teneret, recto, veritate, Iu≈øtic' et iure, omnino po≈øtpo≈øitis et ≈øublatÃÑ: Virtute quorum quidem vnitionis, con≈øpirationis, iuramentÃÑ, confederationis, et manutentionis, praedictorum I. P. R. B. et al' ≈øic in vnum globatÃÑ, et iuratÃÑ, po≈øtea, videlicet die &c. Anno &c. con≈øpiratione inter eos apud C. in comitÃÑ praedict', prehabita, quendam I. H. de eo quod ip≈øe die &c. anno &c. vnum equum pretij &c. de bonis et catallis praedicti I. P. R. B. apud S. inuentÃÑ felonice furatus fuit cepit et abduxit, fal≈øo & malitio≈øe indictari procurauerunt. Et praedict' I. P. et R. B. et alij modo et forma praed' vniti et confederati diuer≈øa fal≈øa placita, ≈øectas, et querelas
innumerabiles, tam nominibus eorum proprijs, quam nominibus aliarum per≈øonarum eis fal≈øo & malicio≈øe congregatÃÑ & vnitÃÑ, pro≈øecuti ≈øuerunt, et manutenerunt & indies pro≈øequntur et manutenent, videlicet praedict' I. P. ad hundredum domini P. militis apud C. praedict' xiij. die, anno &c. tentÃÑ, eodem I. adtunc Ballino eiu≈ødem hundred' exi≈øtenÃÑ, ad ≈øtatum et po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øionem R. S. et A. vxoris ≈øue adnulland': Et pro eo quod ad quamlibet curiam hundred' ibidem ≈øucce≈ø≈øiue tenend', praedict' R. vxorem ≈øuam ibidem producere nequiret, ita quod exce≈ø≈øiua amerciamentÃÑ in ≈øtatus eorum depauperationem fierent & euenirent coÃÑ≈øiderationÃÑ taxatorÃÑ amerciamen ‚Ä¢ curie praedicte, ≈øemper de couina praedict' praed' I. P. extiterunt, tre≈ødecim querelas de placito tran≈øgre≈ø≈øionis, nomine W. Y. et R. B. quatuer querelas tran≈øgre≈ø≈øionis nomine W. E. ab≈øque vera materia ≈øeu iu≈øta cau≈øa, ≈øeperatim ver≈øus praedictum R. F. &c. apud G. &c. in codem comitÃÑ N. pro quinque ≈øolid' in pecunijs numeratis irrationabilitÃÑ & exce≈ø≈øiue di≈øtrinixit, & pro di≈øtriction ‚Ä¢
cepit, vbi tempore di≈øtrictionis & captionis praedict', quarumlibet praedictarum vaccarum precium capitis erat xx. s. contra formam ≈øtatuti praedict' &c.

Quidam tamen A. B. & C. D. de &c. ≈øtatutum praedict' & penam in eodem contentÃÑ minime ponderantes 2. die IunÃÑ, anno &c. 2. vacc' de bonis & catall' E. D. &c. apud F. &c. extra feod ip≈øorÃÑ ≈øiue ip≈øornm alicuius, in coÃÑmunÃÑ ≈øtrato voc' &c. adtunc & ibid' exi≈øtentÃÑ di≈øtrinxerÃÑ, & pro di≈øtrictionÃÑ ceperÃÑ nec tempore di≈øtrictionÃÑ praed' A. B. & C. D. non fuerÃÑ mini≈øtri, nec aliquis eorum fuit mini≈øtrÃÑ, dict' dnÃÑae reginÃÑ, nec habuerunt, nec aliquis eorum habuit ≈øpecialem authoritatem ad illud faciendum, contra pacem &c.

div.head: Again≈øt Egyptians vpon the ≈øtatute of primo and ≈øecundo of king Philip and Queene Marie.
div.p:
IVrÃÑ pre≈øentÃÑ quod cum in ≈øtatuto in Parliamento domini P. & dnÃÑae M. Sect' 101. nuper regis & Reginae Angl' apud W. die x. No. annis Reg' ≈øuorum 1. & 2. tentÃÑ aeditÃÑ inter alia ordinatum exi≈øtit, &c. quod ≈øi aliqua Íùë≈øona, ≈øiue per≈øone ≈øeip≈øos appellantes Egyptianos qui tran≈øportarentur, vel conueiarentur in hoc regnum Angl' ≈øiue Walliae, continuarent, & remanerent, infra idem, per ≈øpacium vnius men≈øis, quod tunc ip≈øe vel ip≈øi ≈øic offendenÃÑ, virtute actus praed', adiudicatÃÑ & e≈øtimati e≈ø≈øent felones, & proinde ≈øu≈øtinerent penas mortis, & forisfact' terrarÃÑ & bonorum, vt in ca≈øu feloniae iuxta ordinem communium legum huius regni, Et ≈øuper examinÃÑ eroum ≈øiue alicuius eoruÃÑ, triarentur in comÃÑ, ac Íùë inhabitantes illius comÃÑ, velloci, vbi ip≈øi vel ip≈øe apprehenderentur, ≈øiue caperentur, & minime Íùë medietatem linguae, & amitterent libertatem & priuilegium Sanctuarij & cleri, prout in eodem ≈øtatuto plenius apparet. Quidam tamen M. P. & P. R. de &c. ≈øeip≈øos appellantes Egyptianos, ≈øtatutÃÑ praedict' minime ponderantes, nec penam &c. qui primo die Aprilis, anno &c. in hoc regnum Angl' tran≈øportatÃÑ & conueiatÃÑ fueruÃÑt, ab eodem primo die Aug' anno &c. ≈øupradicto, v≈øque decimum diem SeptÃÑ extuÃÑc prox' ≈øequenÃÑ apud C. in praed' comÃÑ E. continuauerunt & reman≈øerunt in eodem, otio≈øas vitas ≈øuas noÃÑ relinquentes, nec ≈øeip≈øos in ≈øeruitio alicuius habilis & hone≈øti ≈øub diti huius Angl' collocare qÃÑrentes, ne
que ≈øeip≈øos in aliquo opere
licito ≈øiue occupationÃÑ hone≈øta exercentes, in dnÃÑae Reginae nunc conteÃÑptum, ac contra formam ≈øtatuti praed' &c.

div.p: IVrÃÑ pre≈øentant &c. quod cum in ≈øtatuto in parliamento dominae Reginae Sect. 102. nunc apud We≈øtmona≈øterium in comÃÑ Middel', xiij. die Ianuarij, Anno regni ≈øui quinto tentÃÑ, edita inter alia &c. quod omnes & ≈øingula per≈øona & per≈øone que ab, & po≈øt primum diem Maij, tunc proximÃÑ ≈øequentÃÑ vi≈øe vel inuente forent infra hoc Reg' Angliae ≈øiue Walliae in aliquo commercio vel con≈øortio vacabundorum vulgo vocatÃÑ, ≈øiue ≈øeip≈øos appellanÃÑ Egyptianos vel ≈øeip≈øos ≈øimulantes tran≈ømutantes ≈øiue fucantes Anglic' di≈øgui≈øing per eorum ve≈øtitum, locutionem, aut aliam ge≈øturam con≈øimiles huiu≈ømodi vagabundis communiter appellatÃÑ vel ≈øeip≈øos appellantibus Egyptianos, & ≈øic facerent, continuarent, & remanerent in ei≈ødem, aut ≈øemel, vel ≈øepe, per ≈øpacium vnius men≈øis, quod tunc eadeÃÑ per≈øona ≈øiue per≈øone virtute huius actus e≈øtimate forent & adiudicarentur felo & felones, & proinde ≈øufferent penas mortis, ac ami≈ø≈øionem terrarum & bonorum, vt in ea≈øibus feloniae, ≈øecundum ordinem communium legum huius regni. Et ≈øuper eorum ≈øiue alicuius eorum examinatÃÑ in hac parte triarentur in comitÃÑ ac per inhabitantes comitatus vel loci, vbi ille vel illi apprehenderentÃÑ ≈øiue caperentur, & non per medietatÃÑ lingue, & amitterent priuilegium & beneficium ≈øanctuarij, & cleri, prout in eodem ≈øtatuto plene liquet. Quidem tamen A. B. C. D. &c. ≈øtatutum praedictum minime ponderantes nec penam in eodem contentÃÑ verentes, pro≈øt praed' primum diem Maij ≈øcz. 3. die Aug' anno regni dominae Reginae nunc 35. apud E. in comitatu praedict', vi≈øi & inuenti fuerunt in commertio & con≈øortio vagabundorum vulgo vocatÃÑ & ≈øeip≈øos vocantiuÃÑ Egyptianos, ac ≈øeip≈øos ≈øimulantium, tran≈ømutantÃÑ, & fucantÃÑ, per eorum ve≈øtitum, locutionem, & ge≈øturam, con≈øimiles huiu≈ømodi vagabundis qui vulgo vocantur Egiptiani, & ≈øic fecerunt, continuauerunr, & reman≈øerunt ibidem, & alibi in eodem comitÃÑ, a praedicto tertio die Augu≈øt' anno xxiij. ≈øupradicto v≈øque vice≈øimum diem Iulij tunc proximÃÑ ≈øequenÃÑ in dictae dominae Reginae nunc contemptum, ac contra formam ≈øtatuti praedicti &c.

B. traditus e≈øt & commi≈ø≈øus, ad ≈øaluo & ≈øecure cu≈øtodiendum in Gaola prdicta, donec idem A. B. inde foret legitimo modo deliberatus: prefatus tamen I. F. (tunc vicecomes) po≈øtea, videlicet,

Hu≈øbandman, & Sect. 118. alij machinantes, quomodo populum domini regis nunc ≈øubtili≈ø≈øime poterint decipere vel defraudare, & dominum regem, de his quae ad ip≈øum regem pertinent, & regalia ≈øua, vt de feod' magni ≈øigilli & huiu≈ømodi, exhaeredare, & veram legem Angl', a toto tempore v≈øitatam & approbatam, ≈øubuertere & adnullare, xvj. die FebruarÃÑ &c. apud T. in comitatu M. deceptiue, fal≈øo & proditorie qua≈ødam fal≈øas literas patentes, ad ≈øimilitudinem ≈øcriptÃÑ cancellarÃÑ domini regis, contrafac', qua≈øi e≈ø≈øent literae patentes, de protectionoe ip≈øius reg. ≈øub nomine I.
