div.head: An Indictment of one in London for coo≈øening of Clothiers.
div.p: IVratores pro domina Regina pre≈øentant, Quod S. S. nuper de LondonÃÑ,Sect' 363. mercator ≈øci≈ø≈øor e≈øt per≈øona valde mali nominis fame et conuer≈øationis inhone≈øtae, communis deceptor et defraudator ≈øubditorum dictae dominae Reginae. Et quod ip≈øe 30. die &c. anno &c. trice≈øimo apud LondonÃÑ, videlicet, in parochia ≈øancti laurentij in veteri Iudai≈ømo in warda de Cheape LondonÃÑ, praedictÃÑ in diuer≈øis alijs locis et diebus infra ciuitatem praedictÃÑ tam antea quam po≈øtea, quendam Radulphum Wyat de Ciuitat' WigornÃÑ Clothier, et multos alios fideles ≈øubditos dictae dominae Reginae decipit et defraudauit et per fraudem, a≈øtuciam, et deceptionem Anglice by co≈øenage, diuer≈øos pannos laneos vocatÃÑ Broad clothes, tam de praedictÃÑ Radulpho Wyat quam de diuer≈øis pauperationem ≈øubditorum dictae dominae Reginae nunc, & in contemptum dictae dominae ReginÃÑ, et in pe≈ø≈øimum ac alijs dictae dominae Reginae ≈øubditis perqui≈øiuit habuit et percepit in de pernicio≈øi≈ø≈øimuÃÑ exemplum omnium aliorum ligeorum ≈øubditorum dictÃÑ dominae Reginae in huiu≈ømodi ca≈øu delinquenÃÑ, et contra paceÃÑ dictae dominae Reginae Coronam et dignitatem ≈øuas: Nec non contra formam ≈øtatuti in hmÃÑdi ca≈øu editi & proui≈øi.

div.head: An Indictment again≈øt William Hacket, for trea≈øon and con≈øpiracie, viz. for practi≈øing the depriuation of the Queene, and for traiterous wordes again≈øt her, and for defacing of her armes &c. tran≈ølated into Engli≈øh out of the very Indictment it ≈øelfe.
div.p:
THe Iury do pre≈øent for the Queene, that W. Hacket late of DundelSect' 364. in the County of Northhampton yeoman, as a fal≈øe traitor again≈øt the mo≈øt excellent and chri≈øtian Prince≈ø≈øe, our ≈øoueraigne Ladie Eliz. &c. his natural & ≈øoueraigne liege Lady, hauing not y‚Ä¢ feare of God in his heart, nor weighing his due allegeance, but ≈øeduced by the in≈øtigation of the deuill, malitiou≈øly, and traiterou≈øly, compa≈ø≈øing, imagining, deui≈øing and intending the depriuation and depo≈øing of our ≈øaid Soueraigne Lady Elizabeth, from her honor and royall name of the imperiall Crowne of this Realme of England, on the xxi. day of Iuly in the three and thirteth yere of the Raigne of our Soueraigne Lady Elizabeth, nowe Queene of England, at London, that is to ≈øay, in the pari≈øh of Saint Brides, in the warde of Faringdon extra London, and diuer≈øe other daies and times betwixt the twelfth of Februarie la≈øt pa≈øt, and the the fiue and twenteth day of Iulie in the ≈øaid three and thirteth yeere of her Maie≈øties Raigne, as wel in the Pari≈øh and ward afore≈øaide, as el≈øe where in London afore≈øaid, of his owne peruer≈øe and traiterous minde, and imagination, maliciou≈øely, expre≈ø≈øely,
adui≈øedly, directly, and traiterou≈øly in the pre≈øence and hearing of ≈øundry faithfull Subiects of our ≈øaid Soueraigne Ladie, the≈øe fal≈øe malitious and traiterous Engli≈øh wordes following, concerning our ≈øayd ≈øoueraigne Lady the Queenes Maie≈øtie, fal≈øly, malitiou≈øly, adui≈øedly, expre≈ølly, directly, and traiterou≈øly ≈øaid, rehear≈øed, publi≈øhed, and ≈øpoke viz. That the Queenes Maie≈øtie (meaning thereby our ≈øaid ≈øoueraigne Queene Elizabeth,) did repre≈øent all Hypocri≈øie, and had forfaited her Crowne, and was worthie to be depriued, and that he had bin of that opinion the≈øe 4. yeres, and that he defaced her Armes in Kaies hou≈øe thereby, meaning the hou≈øe of one Ralphe Kaies, ≈øcituate and being in Knight-rider-≈øtreete, in the Pari≈øh of ≈øaint Gregorie neere Paules, in the Ward of Baynards Ca≈øtle L. to take away her whole power of her authoritie, and was mooued thereunto by the Spirit, & that he neither was, nor is ≈øorie therefore to the great ≈øcandall and derogation of the Per≈øon and Royaltie of our ≈øaid Soueraigne Lady the Queene, and to the ≈øubuer≈øion of the ≈øtate of this Realme of England, and contrary to the forme of a Statute in this ca≈øe made and prouided, & al≈øo again≈øt the peace of our ≈øaid ≈øoueraigne Lady, her Crowne and dignities &c.

div.head: An other Indictment again≈øt the ≈øaid W. Hacket, for practi≈øing the depo≈øition and death of the Queene for ≈øtirring ≈øedition in the Realme, for ra≈øing of the Queens Armes, and her picture, and for thru≈øting an Iron in≈øtrument into that part of the picture that repre≈øented the brea≈øt & hart of the Queene: And that he treated with two others for the bringing to pa≈ø≈øe of their purpo≈øes, And for traiterous wordes vttered again≈øt the Queene, tran≈ølated into Engli≈øh out of the very Indictment it ≈øelfe.
div.p:
THe Iurie pre≈øent for the Queene, That W. Hacket late of DundelSect' 365. in the County of Northhampton yeoman, as a fal≈øe traitor again≈øt the mo≈øt excellent and chri≈øtian Prince≈ø≈øe, our ≈øoueraigne Ladie Elizabeth by the grace of God of England &c. hauing not the feare of God in his heart, nor weighing his due allegeance, but ≈øeduced by the in≈øtigation of the deuill, and intending wholy to withdraw, put out, and extingui≈øh the hartie loue, & the true, and due obedieÃÑce, which a true and faithful ≈øubiect of the Queenes ≈øhould beare, and by the Law is bound to beare towards our ≈øaid ≈øoueraigne Ladie the Queene, The fir≈øt day of Iulie in the 33. yere of the raigne of the ≈øaid Queene, at London in the pari≈øh of ≈øaint Gregorie neere Paules, in the Ward of Ca≈øtle Baynard London, fal≈øely, malitiou≈øly, and traiterou≈øly, intended, imagined, went about, and compa≈ø≈øed the ≈øaid Queene his ≈øoueraigne and naturall liege Lady, not onely from her Royall ≈øtate, title, power, and gouernement of this Realme of England, vtterly to depriue, depo≈øe, ca≈øt downe
and di≈øherite, but al≈øo to bring and put the ≈øaid Queenes Maie≈øtie to death and finall de≈øtruction, and ≈øedicion in the ≈øaid Realme of England to ray≈øe vp, leuie and make, and al≈øo wholly to ≈øubuert and de≈øtroy the ≈øtate of this whole common wealth beyng in and throughout euery parte thereof well con≈øtituted and ordered: And to thentent he might fulfill and bring to pa≈ø≈øe tho≈øe his afore≈øaid traiterous purpo≈øes, imaginacions, compa≈ø≈øings and entents: The ≈øaid William Hacket afterward, that is to ≈øay, the fir≈øt day of Iuly, in the 33. yeare of the raigne of the Queenes Maie≈øtie that now is, did come to the man≈øion hou≈øe of one Raph Kaies ≈øcituate and being in Knightrider ≈øtreete in the ≈øaid pari≈øh of S. Gregories in the warde afore≈øaid, and then and there malliciou≈øly, diueli≈øhly, and traiterou≈øly, ra≈øed, and defaced, the Armes of the Queenes Maie≈øtie, then and there in the ≈øaid hou≈øe being, with this entent traiteron≈øly to take away, put downe and ouerthrowe the power of authoritie of the ≈øaid Queene: And that the ≈øaid William Hacket for further accompli≈øhing and effecting of his ≈øaid traiterous purpo≈øes, imaginacions, compa≈ø≈øings, and entents the ≈øaid fir≈øt day of Iuly, in the ≈øaid 33. yeare of her Maie≈øties raigne, in the hou≈øe of the ≈øaid Ralph Kaies, ≈øcituate in the pari≈øh and ward afore≈øaid, did traiterou≈øly raze, a certaine picture of the Queenes Maie≈øties, then and there in the ≈øaid hou≈øe likewi≈øe being: And then and there did malitiou≈øly and traiterou≈øly put in, and thru≈øt an yron in≈øtrument into that part of the ≈øaid picture that did repre≈øent the brea≈øt and heart of the Queenes Maie≈øtie. And afterward, that is to ≈øay, on the xvi. day of Iuly in the 33. yeare of the raigne of the Queenes Maie≈øtie that now is, the ≈øaid William Hacket traiterou≈øly came to the hou≈øe of one Iohn Walker, ≈øcituate and being in the pari≈øh of S. Marie Somer≈øets, in the ward of Queenehith in London afore≈øaid with entent traiterou≈øly to conferre and treat with one Edmond Coppinger gentelman, and Henry Arthington gentleman, coÃÑcerning his traiterous purpo≈øes imaginacions compa≈ø≈øings and entents afore≈øaid: And that the ≈øaid William Hacket afterward, that is to ≈øay on the xvi, day of Iuly, in the 33. yeare of the raigne of the Queenes Maie≈øtie that now is, at London afore≈øaid in the hou≈øe of the ≈øaid Iohn Walker in the afore≈øaid pari≈øh of S. Mary Somer≈øet in the ≈øaid ward of Queenehith in London, of his owne peruer≈øe and trayterous mind and imaginacion, mallitiou≈øly, adui≈øedly, ezpre≈øly and traiterou≈øly, did treate and had coÃÑference with the ≈øaid Edmond Coppinger, & Henry Arthington, by what waies, means, and manner, the ≈øaid traiterous purpo≈øes, imaginations, compa≈ø≈øings, and entents might be accompli≈øhed and brought to pa≈ø≈øe. And thereupon the ≈øaid xvi. day of Iuly, in the ≈øaid 33 yeare in the ≈øaid hou≈øe of Iohn Walker afore≈øaid, ≈øcituate and being in the ≈øaid pari≈øh of S.
Marie Somer≈øets in the ≈øaid ward of Queenehith London, in the pre≈øence and hearing of the ≈øaid Edmond Coppinger, and Henrie Arthington being then and there in the ≈øaid hou≈øe, the ≈øaid Hacket, the≈øe falfe traiterous Engli≈øh words following of our ≈øaid Soueraigne Queene Elizabeth, fal≈øly, malitiou≈øly, adui≈øedly, expre≈øly, directly, and trayterou≈øly ≈øaid, rehear≈øed, publi≈øhed and ≈øpoke, viz. That the Queenes Maie≈øtie (meaning our ≈øaid ≈øoueraigne Lady Queene Elizabeth) had forfaited her crowne and was worthie to be depriued. And that furthermore the ≈øaid William Hacket thereupon the ≈øaid xvi. day of Iulie in the ≈øaid 33. yeare, in the ≈øaid hou≈øe of Iohn Walker, ≈øcituate in the pari≈øh of S. Marie Somer≈øets, in the ≈øaid ward of Queenehith London, malitiou≈øly and traiterou≈øly moued and ≈øtirred vp the ≈øaid Edmond Coppinger, and Henrie Arthington, traiterou≈øly and openly to declare and publi≈øh in London afore≈øaid, that the Queenes Maie≈øtie that now is, had forfaited her Crowne, to the great offence and derrogation of the per≈øon of the Queeues Maie≈øtie, and to the ≈øubuer≈øion of the ≈øtate of this Realme of England, and contrarie to the peace of our ≈øaid ≈øoueraigne Lady, her Crowne and dignities &c.

div.head: An Indictment of Recu≈øancie vpon the Statute of 1. and 23. Elizab.
div.p: I Vratores prae≈øentant, pro domina Regina quod I. S. nuper de parochia Sect. 366. ≈øanctae Margaretae in We≈øtmonÃÑ in comÃÑ Midd' armigerÃÑ, Qui xx. die Septemb. Anno regni Reginae Eliz. &c. quadrage≈øimo primo fuit aetatis ≈øexdecem annorum & vltra non acce≈ø≈øit Anglice did not repaire eccle≈øiae ≈øuae parochiali de parochia ≈øanctae Margaretae in We≈øtmÃÑ pÃÑd' ‚Ä¢ n comÃÑ Midd' praed', nec alicuialiae eccle≈øiae capelli aut v≈øualiloco communis praecacionis nec ibid' fuit tempore communis praecacionis ad aliquod tempus infra ≈øex men≈øes proximÃÑ ≈øequenÃÑ praed' xx. diem Septembris Anno xlj. ≈øupradicto, ≈øed ab≈øtinuit ab ei≈ødeÃÑ Anglice hath for borne the ≈øame, a praed' xx. die Septembris Anno xlj ≈øupradicto per praedict' ≈øpatium praed' ≈øex men≈øium extunc proximÃÑ ≈øequenÃÑ coÃÑtra tenorem cuiu≈ødam StatutÃÑ apud We≈øtmonÃÑ in comÃÑ Midd': Anno regni dictae dominae Reginae nunc primo, pro vniformitate coÃÑmunis praecacionis ac contra formaÃÑ ≈øtatuti AnnÃÑ regni dict' dnÃÑae reginae nunc 23. in hmÃÑi ca≈øu editÃÑ & proui≈ø. in dictae dominae Reginae nunc & legum ≈øuarum contemptnm manife≈øtum, nec non contra pacem dictae dominae Reginae nunc coronÃÑ & dignitatÃÑ fuas &c.
div.q: Memorand, that the cour≈øe is that the partie indicted mu≈øt appeare in proper per≈øon & plead to the Indictment.

div.head: Aplea to the Indictment next before.
div.p:
Et praedict' I. S. in propria per≈øona ≈øua venit & defendit totum & Midd' ≈ø≈ø. quicquid contra pacem & in contemptu Dominae Reginae nunc aut
legum ≈øuarum ≈øuperius fieri ≈øuppo≈øitÃÑ. Et prote≈øtand' quod IndictamentÃÑ praed' ver≈ø. eum exhibitÃÑ minus ≈øufficienÃÑ in lege exi≈øtitad qƒë ip≈øe nece≈ø≈øe non habet nec per legem terrae tenetur re≈øpoÃÑdere: Pro placito tamen idem I. S. vlterius dicit quod de praed' non acce≈ø≈øu alicui Eccle≈øiae capellae aut v≈øuali loco communis precacionis aut de ab≈øtencione inde contra formam StatutÃÑ praed' in indictamentÃÑ pred' ≈øpecificatÃÑ vel de aliqua alia tran≈øgre≈ø≈øione offen≈ø. aut contemptÃÑ in IndictamentÃÑ praedict‚ñ™ ≈øuperius ≈øupponitÃÑ, quod ip≈øe in nullo e≈øt inde culpabilis. Et de hoc ponit ≈øe ≈øuper patriam &c. Et Henricus Fermor genÃÑ qui pro domina Regina in hac parte ≈øequitur ≈øimiliter. Ideo venÃÑ inde IuratÃÑ &c.

M. maiore ciuitatÃÑ no≈øtrae London, & ≈øocijs ≈øuis Iu≈øticiarÃÑ no≈øtris ad gaolam no≈øtram de Newgate de pri≈øonarijs in eadem exi≈øtenÃÑ deliuerand' a≈ø≈øignÃÑ apud Iu≈øtice hall in le old Baylie, die veneris ≈øcilicet xiij. die Iunij proximÃÑ futurÃÑ ad horam primam po≈øt meridiem eiu≈ødem diei viginti, & quatuor liberos & legales homines de vi≈ønetÃÑ ≈øanctae Margaretae in We≈øtmona≈øterÃÑ in comitatu no≈øtro Middel≈øexiae: ad recognÃÑ ≈øuper Sacramentum ≈øuum. Si I. S. de parochia ≈øanctae Margaretae in We≈øtmona≈øterÃÑ in comitatu Middle≈øexiae genÃÑ culpabilis ≈øit de quadam tran≈øgre≈ø≈øione & contemptu vnde idem I. S. indictatus exi≈øtit, necne &c. Et habeas ibi tunc nomina IuratÃÑ praedictÃÑ & hoc breue.

div.head: An Indictment of Burglarie, and for hanging vp the good man of the hou≈øe by the thumbs vpon a beame with pothookes, & for binding with coards the good man of the hou≈øe and his wife, and for taking out of a chest 5. li. in money.
div.p:
I VratÃÑ prae≈øentaÃÑt, qƒë G. C. nuper de M. in comÃÑ Ce≈øtriae & alij ignoti Sect. 367. xvj. die Martij Anno Regni Edwardi ≈øexti dei gratia Angliae &c.
quinto circa horam vndecimam in nocte eiu≈ødem diei apud A. in comÃÑ C. domum cu ‚Ä¢ u≈ødam R. W. vi & armis, viz. baculis gladijs & dagarijs burglariter ac felonice fregerunt et intrauerunt. Ea intencione ad ≈øpoliand' & depredendum praed' R. W. et in praed' R. W. ac R. W. filium ≈øuum et lo. vxorÃÑ eius adtunc & ibidem in≈øultuÃÑ fecerunt, et ip≈øum R. W. cum quodam in≈øtrumento vocatÃÑ Pothookes, polices ip≈øius R. W. ≈øuper trabem vocatÃÑ a beame, domus praedict' ip≈øum adtunc & ibidem ≈øu≈øpenditur & praed' R. W. et Ioh. vxorÃÑ eius cum cordis ligauerunt et C. s‚ñ™ in pecunijs numeratÃÑ in quodam ci≈øto contentÃÑ de bonis et catallis praed' R. W. adtunc et ibidem inuentÃÑ felonice ceperunt a≈øportauerunt et ≈øpoliauerunt vi & armis, ac contra pacem dicti dnÃÑi Regis, ac contra formam ≈øtatuti in huiu≈ømodi ca≈øu editÃÑ et proui≈ø.

div.head: An order to be ob≈øerued in the right framing of Indictments.
div.q: Quis, quando, vbi, quid, cuius, quomodo, quare.
div.p: QVis, The per≈øon with his name, ≈øurname, addicioÃÑ of the Towne,Quis.
Countie, Arte, and degree.
Quando, The day and yeare.Quando‚ñ™ Vbi. Quid. Cuius. Quomodo. Quare.
Vbi, The place, Towne, and Countie.
Quid, The thing taken, the coulour, the marke, the price and value.
Cuius, The owner of the thing and who≈øe it was.
Quomodo, The manner of the doing and how.
Quare, The entent which is compri≈øed in this word (Felonice.)

div.head: SYMBOLEOGRAPHY. Of Compromi≈øe and Arbitrements.
A Compromi≈øe defined.
div.p:
A Compromi≈øe or Submi≈ø≈øion, Arbitrium, Compromi≈ø≈øum,
Sect. 1. Submi≈ø≈øio, is the facultie or power of pronouncing Sentence betweene per≈øons at controuer≈øie, giuen to Arbitrators by the parties mutuall priuate con≈øent, without publike authoritie, 8. E. 4. 2.

div.head: Compromi≈øe deuided.
div.p:
EVery Compromi≈øe is generall or ≈øpeciall, Dyer 217. plac. 6.
Sect. 2. 4. Eliz.

div.head: Compromi≈øe generall.
div.p: A Generall Compromi≈øe is of all quarrels, actions, executions, and Sect. 3. demandes &c.

div.head: Compromi≈øe ≈øpeciall.
div.p: A Speciall Compromi≈øe is euery ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to order which is not Sect. 4. ≈øo generall, as when it is of certaine matters, facts, or things onely, as of a Tre≈øpas, or of all actions of Tre≈øpas, or of a plaint or Debt, or Detinue, &c.

div.head: Parts of Iudgements.
div.p: AS of euery other iudgement, ≈øo of iudgements which grow by coÃÑ promi≈øe, Sect. 5. there are two parts, the per≈øons, and the que≈øtion.

div.head: Per≈øons in Iudgements.
div.p: PEr≈øons chiefly regarded in Compromi≈øe, are the ≈øtriuing parties, Sect. 6. and the Arbitrators.

div.head: Per≈øons ≈øtriuing.
div.p: THe parties ≈øtriuing be they, betweene whom the controuer≈øie dependeth, Sect. 7. and which compromit the ≈øame, Dyer 217. 4. Eliz.

div.head: Per≈øons ≈øtriuing 2.
div.p: ANd they mu≈øt be two at the lea≈øt, namely the plaintife, and the defendant Sect. 8. of which ≈øometime there be two, or more of a ≈øide.

div.head: The Plaintife.
div.p: The Plaintife is he which moueth the que≈øtion.

div.head: The Defendant.
div.p: The Defendant is he again≈øt whom the que≈øtion is moued.

div.head: What per≈øons may compromit, and what not.
div.p: AL per≈øons both male and female may make compromi≈øe, but ≈øuch Sect. 9. as are prohibited by nature or by law.

div.head: Impediments to compromit.
div.p: BY nature ≈øome are prohibited to compromit through defect of the Sect. 10. mind, and ≈øome through defect of the bodie.

div.head: Impediments in mind naturall.
div.p: THrough the defect of the mind, is when either age is ≈øuch that by Sect. 11. nature they want di≈øcretion, or being at age they want it, eyther naturally, or ca≈øually: as Infants vnder one and twenty yeares old, 10. H. 6. 14. 18. E. 4. 2. 7. E. 4. 5.

div.head: Impediments in mind ca≈øuall.
div.p: ANd furious mad Lunatikes, during their lunacy, 12. E. 4. 8. and Sect. 12. Ideots.

div.head: Impediments in bodie.
div.p: DEfect of the body is ≈øuch infirmity as hindreth the principall ≈øen≈øes Sect. 13. nece≈ø≈øary for the atteyning of knowledge: as dumbnes, deafnes, and blindnes.

div.head: Dumbnes and deafnes naturall and ca≈øuall.
div.p: ANd therefore per≈øons by nature, dumb & deaf, cannot compromit, Sect. 14. as it ≈øeemeth, for they cannot haue vnder≈øtanding, neither can they graunt, Perkins Sectio 25. But per≈øons blind, dumb, & deafe by chance, which can write and read, may well by writing compromit.

div.head: Impediments legall, ≈øubiection, ioynt power.
div.p: SVch per≈øons ≈øeeme prohibited by law to compromit, as be ≈øubiect to Sect. 15. others power, or haue onely ioint powers with others: as boÃÑd≈ølaues or villeins, lea≈øt the award ≈øhould become void on their part, 35. E. 3.

div.head: Couerture.
div.p:
IN like maner, women couert without their hu≈øbandes, 2. H. 5.
Sect. 16. 9. E. 3. 28.

div.head: Death ciuill.
div.p: ANd per≈øons ciuilly dead: as Monkes, Friers, Canons, profe≈ø≈øed Sect. 17. Nunnes, and ≈øuch other votaries, which be in ≈øubiection to their Soueraignes, 14. H. 8. 16. 2. R. 2. 5.

div.head: Compromi≈øe.
div.p: HEreunto may be added, men compelled to ≈øubmit by threats, or Sect. 18. impri≈øonment, 8. A≈ø≈ø. 25. 7. E. 4. 21. for in ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion the con≈øent ought to be free.

div.head: Attainder and Outlawrie.
div.p: OF this ≈øort al≈øo are per≈øons attainted of felony or trea≈øon, and Sect. 19. per≈øons outlawed or wayued in per≈øonall actions, for they haue no goods, 36. H. 6. 26. 16. H. 6. 47. 21. H. 7. 7. 8. E. 4. 4. 5. H. 7. 16.

div.head: Ioint power.
div.p:
PEr≈øons prohibited to compromit, for that they haue onely ioynt Sect. 20. power with others, are the ≈øingle members of euery corporation
without their fellow members, as a Deane without a Chapter, an Abbot without his Couent, a Maior without his Comminaltie, The ma≈øter of a Colledge or Ho≈øpitall without his fellowes, and ≈øo of other ≈øocieties or guilds, 21. E. 4. 13. And in awarde it ≈øeemeth that ≈øuch per≈øons onely may of them≈øelues compromit, as may of them≈øelues make good graunts.

div.head: Arbitrators defined.
div.p:
AN Arbitrator is an extraordinarie Iudge which is cho≈øen & hath Sect. 21. power to iudge, giuen to him by thonely mutuall con≈øent, will, coÃÑ promi≈øe, & election of priuate per≈øons ≈øtriuing, to thend they may decide their controuer≈øies, 19. H. 6. 36. who becau≈øe the controuer≈øie is coÃÑmitted to his plea≈øure, & arbitremeÃÑt, is termed an arbitrator, & for that it is done by the mutuall promi≈øe or compromi≈øe of the parties, he is called compromi≈ø≈øarius iudex. Dyer 536. 19. Eliz. 39. Or a Iudge hauing cognizance by the compromi≈øe of the parties, his power is larger then the power of any ordinarie or other extraordinary Iudge appointed by a magi≈øtrate, for an arbitrator hath power to iudge according to the coÃÑ promi≈øe after his owne mind a≈øwel of the fact as of the Law, not ob≈øeruing the forme of law, but thother Iudges are tied to a pre≈øcript forme limitted to them by the Law or Magi≈øtrate, of which they be onely executors, For which cau≈øe Tully ≈øaieth well. Aliud e≈øt iudicium, aliud arbitrium: nam iudicium e≈øt pecuniae certae, arbitrium incertae: ad iudiciuÃÑ hoc modo venimus, vt totam litem aut obtineamus aut a mittamus, At arbitrium hoc modo adimus, vt ne
que nihil ne
que tantum quantum po≈øtulamus con≈øequamur, whence ≈øpringeth this old ≈øaying, he that putteth his coate to daying, is like to loo≈øe a quarter.

div.head: The choy≈øe of Arbitrators.
div.p: SEing then the power of arbitrators is ≈øuch and ≈øo great and vncontrolable, Sect. 22. warine≈ø≈øe mu≈øt be v≈øed in the choi≈øe of them. In which two things ≈øeeme nece≈ø≈øarie to be regarded, namely that the arbitrators be ≈øufficient, and indifferent.

div.head: Sufficiency of Arbitrators con≈øidered.
div.p: TOuching their ≈øufficiency, ≈øuch per≈øons are to be elected, as haue Sect. 23. ≈øufficient ≈økill of the matter coÃÑpromitted, & haue neither legal nor natural impedimeÃÑts to giue an vpright ≈øentence. Natural impedimeÃÑts, be through defect of mind or body, naturall impediments through defect of mind be infancie (for infants by rea≈øon of their tendernes of yeares, want di≈øcretion to manage them≈øelues, & their owne affaires) madnes, and Ideocy, for they who are maymed with the≈øe blemi≈øhes are vtterly void of vnder≈øtanding. And although I haue red ≈øome examples of ≈øage ≈øentences giuen by fooles, yet dare I not adui≈øe my friends to expect alwaies the like at their hands. As this‚ñ™

div.head: A fooles Arbitrement.
div.p: THat an huÃÑgry begger e≈øpying daintie cheere in a cookes ≈øhop ha≈øted Sect. 24. thither, & beyng ≈øet downe, did eate a ≈ømall peece of his owne bread, and incontinently, receiued ≈øuch wonderful comfort, by the ≈øweet ≈ømell, of the cookes cates and ≈øauces, whereof he ta≈øted no bitt, that he confe≈ø≈øed, that his eager ≈øtomacke, was a≈øwell ≈øati≈øfied therewith, and had as good a repa≈øt, as if he had indeed ≈øtuffed his paunch, with the be≈øt cheere there: which the cooke hearing, ≈øtraight waies with a ≈øterne countenance, bids the poore caytife pay for his breakfa≈øt, whereat the ≈øimple gue≈øt was mightely amazed, and the craftie cooke ≈øomuch the more earne≈øt, in≈øomuch that this poore man, & the cooke were content therein, to abide the award of him that ≈øhould next pa≈ø≈øe by, no ≈øooner was the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion made, but thither cometh a mo≈øt notorious naturall foole, to whom as their iudge, they rehear≈øed the matter, which beyng heard, the Ideot cau≈øed the poore man to put ≈øo much money betweene two ‚Ä¢ a≈øons as the couetou≈øe cooke exacted, and to ≈øhake them in the cookes hearing, which done this arbitrator awarded, that as the cooke had fedd the poore man with the onely ≈ømell of his cates, ≈øo the poore man ≈øhould pay him therefore, with the onely ≈øound of his coine, which ≈øentence was highly approued of all the hearers.

div.head: A ≈øimple magistrates Arbitrement.
div.p: NOt much vnlike to this, is that, which is reported of a couetous Sect. 25. churle, who ≈øorrowed extremely, for that he had lo≈øt a pur≈øe, with one & twentie angels in it. But an hone≈øt man hauing found the ≈øame, of meere con≈øcience deliuered it to the ≈øame ‚Ä¢ hurle, who not once thanking him that was the bringer, fals to accompt his coine, & finding only xx. angels in the purce, with great rigour exacted the odde angell, and becau≈øe the hone≈øt man denied the finding thereof, he conuented him before a Magi≈øtrate of a corporation, who≈øe wealth and authoritie, farre exceeded his wit (as in ≈øuch places commoÃÑly hapneth, for that affectioÃÑ and ≈øimplicity, be their ordinary Electors.) The plaintife ≈øweareth they were one and twenty angels in the pur≈øe which he lo≈øt, the defendant, that there were onely twenty in that which he found: WhereupoÃÑ the Magi≈øtrate pronouÃÑced that the pur≈øe found was not the plaintifes, and therefore adiudged him to re≈øtore vnto the defendant the pur≈øe with twenty angels, leauing the plaintife to good fortune for the finding againe of his pur≈øe with one and twentie angels. I thinke a man may trie a thou≈øand fooles in the like ca≈øes, before he receiue the like ≈øentence.

div.head: Defects of the body in Arbitrators.
div.p:
THe defects of the bodie hindering iudgement are infirmities, by Sect. 26. which the principal ≈øen≈øes nece≈ø≈øary for the apprehen≈øion of knowledge,
are impaired, as by deafenes, dombnes, and blindnes.

div.head: Arbitrators indifferent, who?
div.p: ANd for indifferency, it is good that the Arbitrators be void of malice Sect' 27. & fauor, to either of the parties, that they be not notorious by outlarie, excommunication, or ≈øu≈øpected of any other notorious crime, that they be neither irreligious nor couetous: For albeit as it is ≈øaid, an Arbitrator hath herein ab≈øolute power, yet ought his iudgement or ≈øentence to be ≈øincere and incorrupt, according to right and equitie, without malice, flatterie, and euery other vicious affection or perturbation, which may in any ≈øort lead him awrie from the right pathe of Iu≈øtice and equitie.

p.hi: Hitherto of per≈øons regarded in ≈øubmi≈ø≈øions.

div.head: The Question.
div.p: THe Que≈øtion which conteineth the matter of tharbitrement, followeth. Sect' 82.
The que≈øtion is a thing in controuer≈øie declared to the Iudge or Arbitraitor, to the ende it may by him be decided, Dyer fol. 216. 4. Elizab. pla. 6.

div.head: The question double.
div.p: ANd euery que≈øtion is either about the fact, or about right. Sect' 29.

div.head: The question of the fact.
div.p: A Que≈øtion of the fact, is when ≈øuch a fact is enquired of, as is Sect' 30. doubtfull.

div.head: The question of right.
div.p: THe Que≈øtion of right, is when the fact being knowen, it is yet Sect' 31. doubtfull how much is thereby growen, right and due to ech partie by Law.

div.head: What is to be con≈øidered in each question.
div.p: ANd in euery que≈øtion hereupon ari≈øing, it is to be con≈øidered whether Sect' 32. the thing in que≈øtion be arbitrable or no: for in vaine it is to compromit things not arbitrable. Let vs therefore ≈øee what things be arbitrable, and what not.

div.head: What things are arbitrable, and what not.
div.p: THings and actions per≈øonall incertain are arbitrable: as tre≈øpas, Sect' 33. a warde taken away &c. 22. H. 6. 39. 14. H. 4. 2. 4. H. 6. 17. But things certain are not arbitrable but when the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion is by ≈øpecialty, if they be not ioyned with others incertain: as debt with tre≈øpas, 4. H. 6. 17. 2. H. 5. 2. 12. R. 2. Dyer 33. H. 8. fol. 51. pla. 14.
But Chattels real or mixt, are not arbitrable by theÃÑ≈øelues: as Charters of lands, 9. H. 6. 60. 14. H. 4. 24. if the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion be not by ≈øpecialty, 19. H. 6. 3. H. 6.
Al≈øo an Annuitie is not arbitrable, if the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion be not by ≈øpecialty, 9. H. 6. 60. 14. H. 4. 18. 3. H. 4. 6.
Nor debt vpon arrerages of Accompt before auditors, 4. H. 6. 17. becau≈øe ≈øuch debt is due by record, 3. H. 4. 5. 6. H. 4. 9.

Al≈øo it ≈øeemeth that neither ≈øuch things as were not in rerum natura at the time of the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, though they happeÃÑ to be before the award made be arbitrable: as if the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion be of Ewes with lambe, which after the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion and before the award made haue lambes, it ≈øeemeth they haue no power to make any award touching the lambes.

Matters concerning the common wealth ≈øeeme not arbitrable, as all criminall offences, as trea≈øons, felo ‚Ä¢ es, &c. touching the crime, for it is for the benefite of the common wealth, that ≈øuch offendors be made knowen and puni≈øhed.
Al≈øo cau≈øes matrimoniall ≈øeeme not arbitrable, lea≈øt men ≈øhould ≈øeperate tho≈øe whom God hath ioined together.

div.head: Circumstances regarded in ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion: First that it be in writing.
div.p: NOw that we haue ≈øet foorth the per≈øons and things nece≈ø≈øarie in Sect‚ñ™ 34. euery compromi≈øe, it is good to con≈øider ≈øuch other circum≈øtances as be requi≈øite in the ≈øame.
Three things therefore be≈øide the per≈øons and things are meete to be ob≈øerued in euery compromi≈øe.

Fir≈øt that euery compromi≈øe be made by writing with the parties couenants or bonds ≈øufficient to bind their heires & executors to performe the award which ≈øhal thereupon be made, that both the arbitrators may know their power, and the parties how farre they are ≈øubiect to their ≈øentence. And al≈øo lea≈øt their labour and iudgement therein ≈øhould bee fru≈øtrate for want of means to compel the ≈øame to be executed.

div.head: Of the power giuen to Arbitrators.
div.p: SEcondly, it is behouefull that the very Compromi≈øe arme the arbitrators Sect‚ñ™ 35. with ≈øufficient authoritie to do all things nece≈ø≈øary for the ending of the controuer≈øies: as to appoint times & places for their meeting, to examin & decide the matter compromitted, & to bring the parties with their proues, euidences, & witne≈ø≈øes thither together before them. And to puni≈øh the per≈øons defectiue, & to expound & correct ≈øuch doubtfull ≈øentences & que≈øtions, as may ari≈øe vpon their award, inconuenient to either parties, contrarie to equity, and the arbitrators good meaning, which inconueniences could not by them be fore≈øeene, at the making of the award, as it oftentimes hapneth: for temporis filia veritas, trueth is the daughter of time.

div.head: Of time and place.
div.p: THirdly, that by the compromi≈øe, conuenient time and place be limited Sect' 36. for the yeelding vp of their award to the parties or their atturneies, deputies, or a≈ø≈øignes, lea≈øt the parties ≈øhould otherwi≈øe be long lingered with vaine hope of an endle≈ø≈øe end, and that the arbitrators may before the ≈øet time, fini≈øh their award: for what≈øoeuer they do arbitrate after the time appointed, is void. 8. H. 6. f. 18.

And it is all void that is not conteined in the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, or nece≈ø≈øarily depending thereupon 7. H. 6. fo. 40. 8. H. 6. fo. 18. 36. H. 6. fo. 11. as ≈øhal more largely appeare, wheÃÑ we come to the doctrine of arbitremeÃÑts.
The in≈øtrument of compromi≈øe or ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, may be made in forme following.

div.head: A Compromi≈øe or ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion with couenants to performe the ≈øame.
div.p:
THis Indenture made &c. betweene A. B. on the one partie and C. Sect' 37. D. on the other partie. Witne≈ø≈øeth, that the ≈øaid A. B. and C. D. do by the≈øe pre≈øents, willingly compromit and ≈øubmit them≈øelues, and either of them, to the awarde, arbitrement, order, rule, dome, and iudgement of E. F. and G. H. arbitrators indifferently named, elected, & cho≈øen by the ≈øaid parties to co arbitrate, award order, decree, and iudge, of and vpon all and all maner of actions, ≈øuites, quarels, debts, accompts, tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes, controuer≈øies, debates, and demaunds what≈øoeuer, had, made, moued, depending, or accrewed, or which might haue bin had, or moued, betweene the ≈øaid parties, at any time or times before the date hereof, except one action of debt &c. depending betweene the ≈øaid parties in the Queenes Maie≈øties Court of common Plees, or before &c. and except one debt of x. li. due to the ≈øaid A. B. by the ≈øaid C. D. for the price of certeine Corne &c. and except all landes and tenements of the ≈øaid A. B. and ≈øuch like exceptions &c. So alwaies that the ≈øame arbitrators doe make their award, order, and iudgement of, and concerning the premi≈ø≈øes to be made, by writing indented, vnder all their hands and Seales, on this ≈øide, and before the x. day of Iune now next en≈øuing, and one part of the ≈øame deliuer or cau≈øe to be deliuered by the ≈øaid Arbitrators to the ≈øaid A. B. or his certeine atturney or atturnetes in that behalfe, requiring the ≈øame, the ≈øaid x. day of Iune now next comming, at or in the Pari≈øh Church of R. in the ≈øaid Countie of Yorke. And the other part of the ≈øaid award to the ≈øaid C. D. his atturney or atturneies, deputie, or a≈ø≈øigne, requiring the ≈øame at the ≈øaid day and place: and ≈øo alwaies, that the ≈øaid arbitrators do not by the ≈øaid awarde, order, or appoint any act, or acts, thing or things, to be done or performed, by, or to any per≈øon, or per≈øons, other theÃÑ to or by the ≈øaid parties to the≈øe pre≈øents, their heires, executors, admini≈øtrators, or a≈ø≈øignes, or ≈øome of them, & not to or by any e≈øtranger or e≈øtrangers to this pre≈øent ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion. And the ≈øaid A. B.
and C. D. and either of them for them≈øelues, their heires, executors, and admini≈øtrators, and the heires, executors, & admini≈øtrators of either of them, do by the≈øe pre≈øents mutually couenant, conclude, promi≈øe, and agree to and with the other his executors, and admini≈øtrators, and euery of them, that neither they nor either of them, wil at any time hereafter reuoke the authority hereby giuen to the ≈øaid Arbitrators, nor di≈øcharge them nor either of them of the ≈øaid facultie or power of Arbitration. And that they & either of them, & the heires executors, admini≈øtrators, & a≈ø≈øignes, of either of them on their ≈øeuerall parts ≈øhall, & will well & truly ob≈øerue, performe, fulfil, and keepe al and euery clau≈øe, ≈øentence, article, ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, and agreement i ‚Ä¢ the≈øe pre≈øents mentioned on his or their part to be performed and kept according to the tenor, true intent, and meaning of the ≈øame. In witne≈ø≈øe whereof the ≈øaid parties to the≈øe pre≈øents haue interchangeably ≈øet to their handes and Seales, the day and yere aboue written.

div.head: Of binding the parties to performe the award.
div.p: OR the parties may ≈øubmit them≈øelues to awarde by obligation, Sect‚ñ™ 38. with condition according to the effect of the ≈øaid In≈øtrument of ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, but that ≈øeemeth perilous, for that that ≈øo they may for a trifle, hazard the whole penalty of the bond, which were too too mi≈øchieuous. Neue ‚Ä¢ thele≈ø≈øe if any be willing to aduenture, the parties may be bound either to other, and the condition may bee made in forme following.

div.head: The condition of an Obligation to performe an awarde.Sect‚ñ™ 39.
div.p:
THe condition of this Obligation is ≈øuch, that if the aboue bounden A. B. his heires, executors, admini≈øtrators, and a≈ø≈øignes, and euery of them doe on his and on their part and behalfe, well and truely ≈øtand to, obay, performe, fulfill and keepe the award, arbitrement, order rule, dome, and iudgement of S. T. and W. R. arbitrators, indifferently elected and cho≈øen, a≈øwel on the part of the ≈øaid A. B. on the one partie, as on the part of the aboue named C. D. on the other partie, to arbitrate, awarde, order, and iudge, of, and vpon all and all maner of actions, ≈øuites, quarrels, debts, accompts, tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes, controuer≈øies, debates, and demaundes what≈øoeuer had, moued, depending, or accrewed, or which might haue bin had or moued, betweene the ≈øaid parties at any time or times before the date hereof, except one action of Eiectione firmae, depending betweene the ≈øaid parties in the Queenes Maie≈øties Court commonly called the Kings bench as by the Records thereof in the ≈øame Court remayning it doth and may appeare, and except out of this ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, all lands and tenements of the ≈øaid A. B. (or any like exception.) So alwaies that the ≈øame award, arbitrement, order, and
iudgement, of, and concerning the premi≈ø≈øes be made by writing Indented vnder all their hands and ≈øeales before the fir≈øt day of December now next en≈øuing, and one part of the ≈øame deliuered or cau≈øed to be deliuered by the ≈øaid Arbitrators, to the ≈øaid A. B. or his certain Atturney or Atturne ‚Ä¢ s, deputie or deputies, in that behalfe requiring the ≈øame the ≈øaid fir≈øt day of December, now next en≈øuing, at or in the pari≈øh Church of R. in the ≈øaid Countie of Yorke: And the other part of the ≈øaid award be likewi≈øe deliuered by the ≈øaid Arbitrators, to the ≈øaid C. D. or his certaine atturney or atturneis, deputie, or deputies, in that behalfe requiring the ≈øame, at the ≈øaid day and place. And ≈øo that by vertue or occa≈øion of the ≈øaid award neither of the ≈øaid parties, nor the ≈øeuerall heires, executors, or admini≈øtrators, of them or any of them be to do any act or thing, to or by any ≈øtraunger to the ≈øame award, and to the≈øe pre≈øents. And ≈øo as the ≈øaid A. B. doe not di≈øcharge the ≈øaid arbitrators before the ≈øaid time. That then this pre≈øent obligation to be vtterly voide and of none effect, or els to ≈øtande, remaine, continue, and be, in full ≈øtrength and vertue.

div.head: Of the condition to performe an award of lands.
div.p: ANd if the award be coÃÑcerning a title to land, the words in the condition may be thus.

A≈øwell, of, for, and concerning the right, title, intere≈øt, v≈øe, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øionSect‚ñ™ 40. and demaund, of, and in the manor of S. with the appurtenances in S. in the ≈øaid countie of Y. and all landes, tenements, and hereditaments, with the appurtenances in S. afore≈øaid, in the occupation of the ≈øaid A. B. and his a≈ø≈øignes, as, of, and vpon all actions, tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes, ≈øuites, quarrels, debts, duties, debates, griefes, inconueniences, and demaunds, had, moued, ≈øtirred, or depending, betweene the ≈øaid parties, concerning the ≈øaid Manor, tenements and premi≈ø≈øes, or any part thereof. And al≈øo, if the ≈øaid A. B. before the fea≈øt of P. now next comming, doe ≈øhew vnto the ≈øaid Arbitrators, all ≈øuch writings as he hath concerning the ≈øaid Manor and premi≈ø≈øes, at ≈øuch time and place, as the ≈øaid Arbitrators ≈øhall appoint for the ≈øight thereof. So alwaies that, &c. vt ≈øupra. That then &c. vt ≈øupra.

div.head: Whether power to arbitrate may be a≈ø≈øigned.
div.p: AN Arbitraitor cho≈øen cannot graunt, or a≈ø≈øigne ouer his aucthoritie Sect‚ñ™ 4 ‚Ä¢ . of arbitation to any other, 8. Ed. 4. fol. 1. and 9. becau≈øe it is but a nude power, which is not to be graunted ouer: notwith≈øtanding the opinion in 47. E. 3. 20. to the contrary. Neither doth the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion extend to giue the Arbitraitors power to elect others.

div.head: Whether the Compromittors may di≈øcharge the Arbitrators or no.
div.p: ANd it ≈øeemeth, that albeit the parties haue agreed vpon daie≈ømen, Sect‚ñ™ 42. or Arbitraitors, yet before the arbitrement made, either of the parties may reuoke the authoritie giuen to the arbitrators, and di≈øcharge them thereof, for power may be countermaunded, but if the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion be made by bond, then the bond ≈øeemeth to be forfaited, 5. E. 4. 1. 21. H. 6. 30. 28. H. 6. 6. 49. E. 3. 9.

But by A≈øhton Iu≈øtice, if 2. plaintifes, & one defendant, or 2. defendants and one plaintife put them≈øelues to the award of others, neither the one plaintife without the other, nor the one defendant without the other, may di≈øcharge the arbitrators, 28. H. 6. 6. And by Finch. 49. E. 3. 9. If the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion be by deede, the di≈øcharge mu≈øt likewi≈øe be by deede. So much of ≈øubmi≈ø≈øions, arming the arbitrators with power: Now of Arbitrements i≈ø≈øuing from the ≈øame.

div.head: What an Arbitrement is.
div.p:
AN Arbitrement, or award therefore, arbitramentum, laudum, arbitratus.
Sect‚ñ™ 43. Libro intrationÃÑ, debt in arbitrÃÑ 2. & 3. is nothing el≈øe but the very dome, order, and decree pronouÃÑced by arbitrators vpon the controuer≈øie, for the ending whereof they were cho≈øen by the ≈øtriuing parties. Dier 356. 10. Eliz. pla. 39.

div.head: Of things regarded in Arbitrement.
div.p: IN the forme of euery Arbitrement, fiue thinges are ≈øpecially to be Sect‚ñ™ 44. regarded.
Fir≈øt, that it be made according to the very ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion or compromi≈øe touching the things compromitted, and euery other circum≈øtance as is ≈øaid, 9. E. 4. 44. Plow. 396. a
Secondly that it be a finall ende of the controuer≈øies compromitted, 19. H. 6. 36. 21. Ed. 4. 38.

Thirdly that it appoint either party to giue or do vnto the other ≈øome thing bene≈ø ‚Ä¢ ciall in apparance at the lea≈øt, 43. E. 3. 28. Dier 356. 19. Eliz. pla. 39. 12. H. 7. 39. H. 6. 9. 22. E. 4. 25. 7. H. 6. 40. 19. H. 6. 36. 10. Hen. 6. 19.
Fourthly, that the performance thereof be po≈ø≈øible, 22. H. 6. 46. 8. Ed. 4. 1. & 9. 17. Ed. 4. 5. H. 7.
Fifthly, that there be a meanes how either party may by law attaine vnto that which is thereby awarded vnto him, 5. Ed. 4. & 24. 17. Ed. 4. 5. 18. Ed. 4. 22. & 23. 5. H. 7. 23.
For if it faile in any of the≈øe points, then is the whole Arbitrement void and of none effect, as it doth manife≈øtly appeare by the≈øe ≈øpecial ca≈øes following. As.
An award that the parties ≈øhall obey the arbitrement of A. B. is void, for power cannot be a≈ø≈øigned, 8. E. 4. 19.

An award that any of the parties ≈øhalbe bound, or doe any other act by the adui≈øe of the arbitraitors is not good, becau≈øe they cannot make ≈øeuerall awardes, 18. Ed. 4. 22. 23. but that the parties ≈øhall be bound, or make a≈ø≈øurance by the adui≈øe of Coun≈øaile is good, 18. Edw. 4. 22. & 23.

Arbitrement that the parties ≈øhall be non≈øuit in actions is not good, for euery award ought to be a ≈øati≈øfaction to the parties, and a determination of things compromitted, ≈øo as one party haue amends, but when one hath bin non≈øuit, he may begin againe, 19. H. 6. 36. 21. E. 4. 38.
But an award that the parties ≈øhal make di≈øcontinuance and retraxits of their ≈øuits is good, 21. E. 4. 38. 5. H. 7. 22.

If the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion be of diuers things, & the award onely of ≈øome part of them, yet it is the award good, for that part notwith≈øtanding, as if the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion be of all actions real and per≈øonal, and the award of actions per≈øonall onely: and if it be de iure & po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øione, and the award is only de po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øione, 19. H. 6. 6. per curÃÑ, notwith≈øtanding the contrary opinion of Pri≈øot, 39. H. 6. 9.

An award that an action ≈øhalbe ≈øued betweene the parties, by the adui≈øe of A. and B. is good, for that A. and B. in this ca≈øe are not Arbitrators, but executors of the award, yet quere for it is vncerteine whether they will giue adui≈øe or no. 8. E. 4. 1. & 4.
Arbitrement that the plaintife ≈øhall pay to the defendant x. li. and relea≈øe to him all actions. And that the defendant ≈øhall relea≈øe to the plaintife all actions, is good, 20. H. 6. 18. & 19.
Arbitrement that either partie ≈øhal relea≈øe to other all actions, & that becau≈øe the one hath tre≈øpa≈ø≈øed more then the other, he ≈øhall pay to the other, ‚Ä¢ . s. is good, 20. H. 6. 18. & 19.

Arbitrement that either party ≈øhall go quite again≈øt other, is good, 20. H. 6. 18. & 19. 10. H. 6. 14. 19. H. 6. 36. 22. H. 6. 39. Dyer 356. 16, Eliz. pla. 39. 21. H. 6. that it is not good, if the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion were by parol, 9. Ed. 4. 8.
An arbitrement in tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe is not good, if it award not ≈øomething to the plaintife for amends, 43. E. 3. 28.
In tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe of goods taken, it is no good award, that the defendant ≈øhall reteine part of the goods, and the plaintife haue the re≈øt, 17. Edw. 3. 16.
In debt of x. li. it is no good Arbitrement, that the plaintife ≈øhall retaine the one moity, & the defendant haue the other, 45. E. 3. 16.

In tre≈øpas, award that if the defendant wil wage his Law, that he is not guiltie, that then he ≈øhall go quite, and that the plaintife ≈øhal relea≈øe
vnto him, ≈øeemeth good, 46. E. 3. 17.

Award, that for ≈øo much as the one hath done more tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe then the other, therefore he ≈øhall giue him a peny for amends, And that the other ≈øhall go quite again≈øt him, is good, 19. H. 6. 3. 6.

By Pri≈øot, if two ≈øubmit them≈øelues to Arbitrement of all tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes &c. and it is awarded that the one ≈øhall make amendes to the other, and nothing is awarded for the others benefit, this award is void, 7. H. 6. 40 39. H. 6. 9. 22. E. 4. 25. So if it were that the one only ≈øhall go quite again≈øt the other, for an award mu≈øt be final, obligatory and ≈øati≈øfactory, to both parties, 7. H. 6. 40. 19. H. 6. 36. 20. H. 6. 18.
Award in tre≈øpas of goods taken that the defendant ≈øhal cary and redeliuer the goods taken to the plaintife, is good, 12. H. 7. 14. & 15.
Award that the one partie ≈øhall pay xx. sÃÑ. or enfeoffe &c. is good, and the performance of either ≈øuffi≈øeth, 21. H. 6. 22. H. 6. 52.
An award that one of the parties ≈øhall do an act to an e≈øtraunger, is void, if the parties be not bound, 22. H. 6. 46.
Or if an award be to pay x. li. to an e≈øtraunger, it is void, for how can he pay the ≈øame, if he will not accept it, 22. H. 6. 46. 8. E. 4. 1. & 9.

Or if the award be that hee ≈øhall cau≈øe an e≈øtraunger to enfeoffe the other partie, for he hath no meane to compell the ≈øtraunger, 17. E. 4. 5. So if it be awarded that he ≈øhalbe bound with ≈øuerties, 18. E. 4. 22. 23. 5. H. 7. 23.

Arbitrement that money ≈øhalbe payd at a day to come is good, for the partie may thereof haue an action of debt after the day, if it be not paied accordingly, 20. H. 6. 12. 5. E. 4. 7. But award to do any other thing at a day to come, is void, if the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion be not by ≈øpecialtie, becau≈øe the partie hath no meanes to compell his aduer≈øarie to performe it, 5. E. 4. 7. and 24.

An award is void (as is ≈øaid) if it neither be executed, nor any meanes by law for the execuiton thereof: As if it be awarded, that thone ≈øhal pay to thother x. pound, this is good, for hee may recouer the ≈øame by action of Debt. But if it were awarded that thone ≈øhould deliuer to thother an acre of land, or do ≈øuch like act executory, it were void, if it be not deliuered ≈øtraight way, or proui≈øion made by bond, or otherwi≈øe to compel the performance thereof according to the award, 19. H. 6. 36. 20. H. 6. 12. 5. E. 4. 7, 19. E. 4. 8.
Thus much of the doctrine of Arbitrementes, now of their ≈øeuerall formes.

div.head: An Arbitrement, or award of lands, by which the partie couenanteth to performe it.
div.p:
THis Indenture made &c. betweene T. R. of &c. of the one partie,Sect‚ñ™ 45. and L. M. of &c. of the other partie, Witne≈ø≈øeth, that whereas there
hath beene, and yet is contention, variance and ≈øuite betwixt the ≈øaid parties, not onely for, and concerning the right, title and intere≈øt, of, and in a certaine quantity of ground, by e≈øtimation two acres or thereabout lying in K. and adioyning to the Mill of the ≈øaid T. R. in T. afore≈øaid, claymed by eyther of the ≈øaid parties to be his owne land and inheritance, But al≈øo, for, and concerning certayne wayes to the Mill of the ≈øayd T. through the ground of the ≈øaid L. from al the Townes, Villages, Hamlets, and other places in the North ≈øide of the riuer of D. bordering, lying, and being within the ≈øpace of ten miles of the ≈øaid Mill, and all other matters and controuer≈øies, betwixt the ≈øaid parties. For the friendly ending and appea≈øing of which ≈øaid variances, and controuer≈øies, the ≈øaid parties haue compromitted and ≈øubmitted, and by the≈øe pre≈øents do compromit and ≈øubmit them≈øelues, and all matters in variance afore≈øaid to the order, arbitrement, award, doome and iudgement of F. W. and T. W. Whereupon the ≈øaid arbitrators hauing viewed the ≈øaid grouÃÑd in variance, and peru≈øed diuers writings and euidences concerning the ≈øame, and heard the te≈øtimony and witnes of diuers auncient men & neighbors dwelling nigh the ≈øaid ground, a≈øwell touching the occupation and v≈øage of the ≈øaid ground by the ≈øaid T. R. and his aunce≈øtors, as al≈øo the ≈øaid waies v≈øed vnto the ≈øaid Mill by thinhabitants afore≈øaid time out of mind, do make and declare their award, order, doome, and Iudgement touching the premi≈ø≈øes, and euery part of them. ‚úø And the ≈øaid T. R. and L. M. do couenant and grannt ≈øeuerally either of them, to and with the other, for them≈øelues, their heires, executors and admini≈øtrators, in maner and forme following. And fir≈øt the ≈øaid Arbitrators do order, award, and iudge, And the ≈øaid L. M. is ≈øo contented and agreed, and accordingly doth couenant and graunt, for him, and his heires, to and with the ≈øaid T. R. his heires &c. that he the ≈øaid T. R. ≈øhal and may from hence forth, haue hold, occupie, and quietly inioy to him and his heires for euer, the ≈øaid parcel or quantitie of ground containing by e≈øtimation two acres, lying and being on the North ≈øide of the riuer of D. directly ouer again≈øt the ≈øaid Mill, and deme≈øne lands of the ≈øaid T. R. in T. afore≈øaid, as it is now bounded and meared foorth with ≈øtones by the ≈øaid Arbitrators, And ≈øhall al≈øo haue and may take to his and their owne proper v≈øe, all the trees now ≈øtanding or beyng, or that hereafter ≈øhall growe in and vpon the ≈øaide grounde, and all other profites and commodities comming off, and vpon the ≈øaide ground (onely the thornes, briars and herbage, excepted and forepri≈øed) with free libertie, entrie and pa≈ø≈øage, for the felling, hewing, leading, carrying away, and taking of the ≈øame trees, and all other the ≈øaid profits and commodities (except before excepted) at all and euery time and times hereafter at his and their plea≈øure. And
that the ≈øaid T. R. his heires and a≈ø≈øignes, and all and euery other per≈øon and per≈øons, that ≈øhall come and bring any corne to the Mill of the ≈øaid T. R. called T. Mill, from the ≈øaid townes, villages, hamlets, or any other place inhabited, ≈øhall haue free libertie, waies and pa≈ø≈øage for the carrying, fetching and bringing of their corne to the ≈øaid Mill, a≈øwell ouer and through the ≈øaid parcell of ground ≈øet foorth and meared as is afore≈øaid, as al≈øo through and ouer other the grounds of the ≈øaid L. M. in K. afore≈øaid, in as ample and large manner and forme, as the inhabitants of the ≈øaid townes, villages and hamlets or other places haue beene accu≈øtomed and v≈øed to do at any time heretofore, and as it is now mo≈øt commonly v≈øed. ‚úø And ≈øhall and may tie and fa≈øten any their hor≈øes, mares or other bea≈øts wherewith they carrie any corne to the ≈øaid Mill, to any tree growing, or other thing, beyng in, and vpon the ≈øaid ground, ≈øo that the ≈øtring, corde or rope, exceed not the length of foure whole yards at the mo≈øt. ‚úø And that the ≈øaid T. R. his heires and a≈ø≈øignes ≈øhall and may lawfully at all and euery time and times ≈øo oft as need ≈øhall require, amend and repaire all and ≈øinguler the waies, and euery part thereof, for the ea≈øe, ≈øauegard, and pa≈ø≈øage, of the inhabitants of the ≈øaid townes, villages, hamlets, and places inhabited, coÃÑ ming, and going, to, and from the ≈øaid Mill, without any let, trouble, vexation or contradiction of the ≈øaid L. M. his heires or a≈ø≈øignes, or any of them. And that the ≈øaid L. M. his heires and a≈ø≈øignes, ≈øhall at all times within ‚Ä¢ he ≈øpace of two yeares next en≈øuing the date hereof, doe, make, knowledge and ≈øuffer, or cau≈øe to be made, knowledged and ≈øuffered, all and euery act and actes, thing and things, as ≈øhalbe rea≈øonably deui≈øed, or adui≈øed, by the ≈øaid T. R. his heirs or a≈ø≈øignes, or his or their learned coun≈øell, at the onely proper co≈øtes and charges in all things, of the ≈øaid T. R. his heires or a≈ø≈øignes, for the further and better a≈ø≈øurance and ≈øure making, a≈øwell of the ≈øaid parcell or quantity of ground, containing about two acres, as al≈øo of the ≈øaid waies, in maner & forme before expre≈ø≈øed, vnto the ≈øaid T. R. his heires and a≈ø≈øignes for euer, according to the true effect, meaning and purport of the≈øe pre≈øents: In con≈øideration whereof it is further ordained, awarded, deemed and iudged, by the ≈øaid Arbitrators. ‚úø And the ≈øaid T. R. doth ≈øo couenant &c. that he the ≈øaid L. M. his heirs and a≈ø≈øignes, ≈øhall and may haue, take and enioy, onely the gra≈ø≈øe & herbage, with the thornes and briers yearly growing, or being in, or vpon the ≈øaid parcell or quantity of ground ≈øo bounded or ≈øet foorth, as is afore≈øaid. And in further con≈øideration of the premi≈ø≈øes, the ≈øaid T. R. hath paied to the ≈øaid L. M. at the in≈øealing hereof, at the reque≈øt of the ≈øaid Arbitrators, the ≈øumme of xx. pounds &c. ‚úø In witne≈ø≈øe whereof not onely the ≈øaid parties to the≈øe pre≈øent Indentures of award interchangeable haue put their ≈øeales, and ≈øub≈øcribed
their names: But al≈øo the ≈øaid Arbitrators to both the parts of the≈øe Indentures haue put their ≈øeales and ≈øub≈øcribed their names the day and the yeare &c.

div.head: An other Arbitrement of debte, where the parties are bound to performe it.
div.p:
TO all true Chri≈øtian people to whome this pre≈øent writing of award Sect. 46. indented ≈øhall come, G. W. G. N. S. S. and T. N. of &c. ≈øend greeting in our Lord God euerla≈øting. Whereas diuers ≈øuites &c. betweene T. W. and I. S. of &c. For pacifying, ordering and ending whereof, the ≈øaid T. W. and I. S. haue bound them≈øelues either to other in the ≈øumme of a M. l . of lawfull Engli≈øh money, by their ≈øeuerall obligations bearing date &c. with conditions there vnder written, to ≈øtand to &c. vt ≈øupra of the ≈øaid G. J. S. and T. Arbitrators indifferently elected and cho≈øen, a≈øwell vpon the part and behalfe of the ≈øaid I. S. as of the ≈øaid T. W. to award, arbitrate, order, rule, iudge, end & determine, al, and al maner of ≈øuites, debts, actions, controuer≈øies, debates and demaundes what≈øoeuer, depending betweene the ≈øaid I. S. and the ≈øaid T. W. and W. W. his ≈øonne and heire: So that the ≈øaid award were made and giuen vp in writing vnder the hands and ≈øeales of all the ≈øaid Arbitrators, at or before the &c. at &c. as by the ≈øaide obligations and conditions among≈øt other thinges doeth and may appeare. ‚úø Know you now that the ≈øaid G. I. S. & T. taking vpon them the charge and burden of the ≈øaid award, & hauing deliberately heard the griefes, allegations, & proofes of both the ≈øaid parties, do by the≈øe pre≈øents arbitrate, award, order, deeme, & iudge, of, and concer ‚Ä¢ ing the premi≈ø≈øes in maner & forme following: that is to ≈øay. ‚úø Fir≈øt, they do award, order, deeme, & iudge by the≈øe pre≈øents, that the ≈øaid I. S. his executors or admini≈øtrators, or ≈øome of theÃÑ, ≈øhal wel and truly pay, or cau≈øe to be paid vnto the ≈øaid T. W. or his certain Atturney, exec. or admini≈øtr. or ≈øome of them, at, or before the &c. at, or in the &c. 200. li. of &c. and at, or before the &c. other 200. li. of &c. in full ≈øati≈øfaction of 400. li. For paiment whereof the ≈øaid I. S. ≈øtood bound to the ≈øaid T. W. in, and by fower ≈øeuerall Obligations, whereof two are already forfaited, as thereby may appeare. ‚úø Al≈øo the ≈øaid Arbitrators do award, order, &c. that the ≈øaid I. S. his exec. & admini≈øtr. or ≈øome of them, at their, or ≈øome of their co≈øts and charges, ≈øhall before the &c. cau≈øe & procure, that all ≈øuits, bils, plaints, and informations heretofore commenced again≈øt the ≈øaid T. W. in any court, or courts what≈øoeuer, either by, or in the name of the ≈øaid I. S. or by, or in the name of H. S. his ≈øonne, or by, or in the name of our Soueraigne Lady the Q. Maie≈øtie that now is, and of euery, or any of them, or by, or in the name of any other per≈øon or per≈øons, by the con≈øents, meanes, & procurements of them, or any of them,
≈øhall thenceforth ≈øurcea≈øe, and be no further proceeded in by them, nor any of them, or by the means, con≈øent, or procuremeÃÑt of them, or any of them. And before the &c. be vtterly di≈øcontinued, and made void. ‚úø And the ≈øaid Arbitrators do further award, order, deeme, and iudge by the≈øe pre≈øents, that for the ≈øure payment of the ≈øaid ≈øumme of 400. pounds, the ≈øaid I. S. and G. S. within two daies next after tender or deliuery of the one part of this pre≈øent award to the ≈øaid I. S. ≈øhall well, and ≈øufficiently make, ≈øeale, and deliuer as their deeds to the ≈øaid T. W. in &c. one Obligation or writing obligatorie ≈øufficient in the lawe, wherein, and wherby the ≈øaid I. S. and G. S. ≈øhal acknowledge them≈øelues, and either of them to be ioyntly, and ≈øeuerally bounden to the ≈øaid T. W. in the ≈øumme of 800. pounds of &c. with condition thereupon in due forme of law indorced for the ≈øure paiment of the ≈øaid ≈øumme of 200. li. parcell of 400. li. at, or in the &c. before &c. And the other 200. li. re≈øidue of the ≈øaid ≈øumme of 400. li. at, or before the &c. and at &c. ‚úø Al≈øo the ≈øaid Arbitrators do further award, &c. that the ≈øaid I. S. his executors, or admini≈øtrators, or ≈øome of them, ≈øhall, and will before the &c. at his, and their owne proper co≈øtes and charges, cau≈øe, and procure to be cancelled, and made void one recogni≈øance of 200. li. bearing date the &c. knowledged, and inrolled in the Q. maie≈øties high court of Chancerie, wherein, and whereby the ≈øaid T. W. ≈øtandeth bounden to the ≈øaid I. S. in the ≈øaid ≈øumme, with condition thereunto annexed: That if the ≈øaid T. W. his heires, executors, and admini≈øtrators, & euery of them, ≈øhould well, & truely ob≈øerue, performe, fulfil, & keepe, all, & euery the couenants, grants, articles, & agreements, which on his and their parts were to be ob≈øerued, performed, fulfilled, & kept, coÃÑtained and ≈øpecified in one Indenture bearing date the &c. had, and made betweene the ≈øaid T. W. on the one partie and the ≈øaid I. S. on the other partie, concerning the marriage of W. W ≈øonne & heire apparant of the ≈øaid T. W. and A. S. daughter of the ≈øaid I. S. according to the true intent, purport, & effect of the ≈øaid Indenture: That then the ≈øaid Recognizance to be void, and of no effect, or el≈øe to ≈øtand &c. as by the ≈øaid Recognizance & Indenture more plainly, and at large appeareth. ‚úø And al≈øo that the ≈øaid I. S. his executors, or admini≈øtrators, or ≈øome of them, ≈øhall, and will before the fea≈øt of &c. deliuer, or cau≈øe to be deliuered vnto the ≈øaid T. W. his executors, or admini≈øtrators, or ≈øome of them, in the ≈øaid now dwelling hou≈øe of the ≈øaid T. W. afore≈øaid, the ≈øaid Indenture of couenants concerning the fore≈øaid marriage, cancelled, or to be cancelled. In witne≈ø≈øe whereof the ≈øaid Arbitrators to both partes of this pre≈øent award indented, haue ≈øet their hands and ≈øeales. Dated, &c.

div.head: An Arbitrement or award of debt made by an Earle vpon ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion by bond.
div.p:
TO all true Chri≈øtian people, to whom this pre≈øent writing of award Sect. 47. indented ≈øhal come: The right Ho. G. Earle Mar≈øhal of England, &c. ≈øendeth greeting, &c. Whereas diuer≈øe ≈øuits, variances, coÃÑtrouer≈øies, & debates, heretofore haue bin had, moued, & depending, between T. G. of T. in the couÃÑtie of Y. yeomaÃÑ on the one partie, & F. M. of D. in y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid couÃÑtie gentlemaÃÑ, on the other partie: For pacifying, ordering, & ending wherof, the ≈øaid T. G. & F. M. haue bound them≈øelues either to other in the ≈øumÃÑ of 400. l . of, &c. by their ≈øeueral oblig. bearing date, &c. now la≈øt pa≈øt, with coÃÑdition there vnder writteÃÑ, to ≈øtaÃÑd to, abide, performe, fulfil, & keepe the award, order, rule, doome, iudgemeÃÑt, & determination of the ≈øaid Earle indifferently elected, & cho≈øen, by the mutual coÃÑ≈øent, & at the earne≈øt, & huÃÑble reque≈øt, & petition, of both the ≈øaid parties, to arbitrate, award, order, iudge, & determine, of, for, & coÃÑcerning al, & al maner of actions, ≈øuites, quarrels, debts, duties, & demaunds what≈øoeuer, had, moued, or depeÃÑding or which hereafter might be had, moued, or depend between the ≈øaid parties, by rea≈øon of any matter, thing, or things what≈øoeuer, accrued, or groweÃÑ froÃÑ the beginning of the world, vntill the day of the date of the ≈øame oblig. So that the ≈øame award were made in writing indented, vnder the hand & ≈øeale of the ≈øaid Earle before the xix. day of, &c. & thone part of the ≈øame writing indented, deliuered, or cau≈øed to be deliuered by the ≈øaid Earle, to the ≈øaid T. G. his executors, &c. or any of them, or to their, or any of their v≈øe, vpon, or before the ≈øaid xix. day of &c. at, or in the now maÃÑ≈øion, or Manor hou≈øe of the ≈øaid Earle, called S. in &c. & the other part thereof, to the ≈øaid F. M. &c. vt ≈øupÃÑ, as by the ≈øaid oblig. & conditions thereof doth & may more at large appeare. ‚úø Know you now, that the ≈øaid Earle of his meere good will & fauour, which he beareth to both the ≈øaid parties, & of y‚Ä¢ great & honorable re≈øpect, which he hath of their future quietnes, taking vpon him the charge & burden of the ≈øaid award, & hauing deliberatly at ≈øundry times at large, heard & con≈øidered the griefs, allegations, & proofes of both the ≈øaid parties, doth by the≈øe pre≈øents, arbitrate, award, order, deeme, & iudge, of & concerning the premi≈ø≈øes in maner & forme following, viz. ‚úø That the ≈øaid F. M his &c. or ≈øome of them, ≈øhall well, & truely pay, or cau≈øe to be paid vnto the ≈øaid T. G. his &c. or ≈øome of them, the ≈øum of 160. l . of &c. in the &c. in maner & forme following. viz. vpon &c. 80. l . therof, and vpon &c. other 80. l . therof re≈øidue, & in full paiment & ≈øati≈øfaction of the ≈øaid ≈øum of 160. l . ‚úø And that in con≈øideration thereof the ≈øaid T. G. ≈øhall permit, & ≈øuffer all ≈øuits, actions, quarrels, debts, duties, and demands, growen before the date of the ≈øaid oblig. to cea≈øe, & be di≈øcontinued, and no further pro≈øecuted by him, or any other by his procurement. ‚úø And
furthermore, for as much as the ≈øaid F. M. is charged as is afore≈øaid, for the paimeÃÑt of the ≈øaid ≈øum of 160. l . partly by rea≈øon of a iudgment heretofore giueÃÑ for the ≈øaid T. G. again≈øt one L. S. in the Q. Maie≈øties court, coÃÑmonly called the K. bench‚ñ™ in an actioÃÑ of debt, in which the ≈øaid T. G. hath recouered again≈øt the ≈øaid L. S. 285. l . and 4. d. as by the record thereof remaining in the ≈øaid court appeareth. His honor doth further award by the≈øe pre≈øents, in reliefe & ea≈øe of the ≈øaid F. M. that if the ≈øaid F. M. his &c. or any of them do well and truely pay, or cau≈øe to be paied the ≈øaid ≈øum of 160. l . according to the true meaning of this pre≈øent award, And if the ≈øaid L. S. his heirs, &c. or ≈øome of them, ≈øhall not well, & truely ≈øati≈øfie, content, & pay vnto the ≈øaid T. G. his &c. the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall ≈øums aboue in this awarde appointed to be payed by the ≈øaid F. M. before the ≈øeuerall daies herein aboue mentioned: That then, & at all times after any ≈øuch default of paiment ≈øo to be made by the ≈øaid L. S. his &c. the ≈øaid T. G. his &c. ≈øhall permit and ≈øuffer the ≈øaid F. M. his executors, and admini≈øtrators, & euery of them, at the co≈øts & charges of the ≈øaid F. M. his exec. and admini≈øt. effectually to pro≈øecute, or cau≈øe to be pro≈øecuted, all, and euery ≈øuch execution, and executions vpon the ≈øaid iudgement ≈øo had for the ≈øaid T. G. again≈øt the ≈øaid L. S. as to them, or any of them, or the learned coun≈øell of them, or any of them, ≈øhall ≈øeeme good. And all, and euery ≈øumme, and ≈øums of money thereby to be obtained, to take, and conuert to the only proper v≈øe, and behalfe of the ≈øaid F. M. his exec. & admini≈øtr. without any accompt, recompence, or payment thereof, or therefore to be yeelded, or made to the ≈øaid T. G. his &c. or any of them: any thing in this pre≈øent award contained &c. notwith≈øtanding. ‚úø In witnes whereof, the ≈øaid Earle to both the partes of this pre≈øent award hath ≈øet his hand and ≈øeale. Dated &c.

p.hi: All ≈øuch couenants, & conditions as be v≈øually made for the a≈ø≈øuraÃÑce or enioying of lands, or tenements, goods‚ñ™ and chattels, may be in≈øerted into awards, as ≈øhall ≈øeeme good vnto the arbitrators or parties.

div.head: Of notice of the arbitrement.
div.p: AND when the arbitrators haue made their award, according to Sect. 48. the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, albeit, perchance they be not bound to giue notice thereof to the parties, yet it ≈øeemeth very requi≈øite, that they ≈øhould in due time, before that eyther party be to performe any part thereof, notifie the ≈øame vnto them, lea≈øt otherwi≈øe they might breake their boÃÑds, or couenants, in that behalfe (if any ≈øuch be) before they know the ≈øame. Notwith≈øtanding, that the booke in 8. Edw. 4. 1. & 9. be doubtfull in that point.

div.head: The finall cau≈øe, and effects of Arbitrements.
div.p:
ANd thus, by that which hath bin di≈øcour≈øed, it ≈øufficiently appeareth Sect. 49. (as we thinke) that the ≈øcope, and end of arbitrements, and
other iudgments is all one. And chiefly the finall determination of ≈øtrif ‚Ä¢ , ≈øuit, and controuer≈øie 19. H. 6. 36. And ≈øo con≈øequently, their effects be almo≈øt equall. But the lawes ≈øeeme more fauourable to arbitrements then other iudgments, in ≈øo much, as by arbitrators the ≈øtrict cour≈øe, and tedious ceremonies of law ≈øuits (which are mo≈øt commonly wont to wearie ≈øuters, and picke their pur≈øes) are cut off, and ≈øhorter deci≈øions by them made, with little or no co≈øt at all.
Wee differ to ≈øhew how arbitrements may be pleaded in barre of other actions, vntill we come to their fit place among≈øt our pre≈øidents of pleadings, and ≈øo end this treati≈øe.

div.head: An Award made by an Arbitrator touching copyhold land, betweene an Alderman of London, and an other.
div.p:
TO all Chri≈øten people to whom this pre≈øent writing of award indented Sect. 50. ≈øhall come H. T. of Lincolns Inne in the countie of Middle≈øex E≈øquier ≈øendeth greeting in our Lord God euerla≈øting. Whereas ≈øuite, variance and debate heretofore hath beene and yet is had, moued and depending, as well in the Queenes Maie≈øties Court of Reque≈øts, as in diuers other Courts, betweene R. H. Citizen and Alderman of London of the one partie, and R. E. of K. in the countie of M. Yeoman of the other partie, of for and concerning the right, title, v≈øe, intere≈øt, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of diuers lands, tenements & hereditameÃÑts, with the appurtenances lying and being in K. within the manor or Lord≈øhip of T. within the ≈øaid Countie of M. and containing by e≈øtimation about 200. acres of land, meadow, pa≈øture, and wood, commonly called or knowne by the name of Hebines land for the appea≈øing, final end and determina ‚Ä¢ ion of all which ≈øaid ≈øuites, variances and debates the parties afore≈øaid haue ≈øubmitted, & compromitted them≈øelues to ≈øtand, to obay and performe the arbitrament, ordinaunce, dome, and iudgemeÃÑt of me the ≈øaid H. T. Arbitrator indifferently elected, named and cho≈øen by both the ≈øaid parties, indifferently to arbitrate, order, deeme, awarde, and Iudge as well of, for and concerning the e≈øtate, right, title, intere≈øt, v≈øe and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of all and ≈øinguler the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes, and euery parte and parcell thereof, as al≈øo of for and vpon all maner of ac
‚Ä¢ ions, ≈øuites, quarels, debts, debates, tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes, and demaunds, what≈øoeuer heretofore had moued, ≈øtirred or depending betweene the ≈øaid parties from the beginning of the worlde vntill the twentie day of Nouember la≈øt pa≈øt, as by their ≈øeuerall writings obligatorie wherein eyther of the ≈øaid parties ≈øtand bounden to the other of the ≈øame parties, in the ≈øumme of two hundred pounds, bearing date the ≈øaid 20. daie of Nouember, and made for the true performaunce of the ≈øaid award more at large it doth and may appeare. Wherupon the ≈øaid H. T.
hauing taken vpon him the charge, and burden of the ≈øaid Arbitramen ‚Ä¢ And hauing pre≈øent before him both the ≈øaid parties, & hauing al≈øo very adui≈øedly and deliberatly weighed and con≈øidered the titles, claimes, allega ‚Ä¢ ions, and proofes, of either of the ≈øaid parties to the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes. And vpon ≈øight and due con≈øideration of all the euidences, writings and proofes ≈øhewed and made before me the ≈øaid H. T. by both the ≈øaid parties do award, arbitrate, order, deeme & iudge of the premi≈ø≈øes in maner and forme following. That is to ≈øay: Fir≈øt I the ≈øaid Arbitrator do award, deeme, order & Iudge, that the ≈øaid R. E. or his heires at al times within 3. yeares next en≈øuing the date of the≈øe pre≈øents, vpon lawfull & rea≈øonable warning by the Steward, Bailife, or Reeue of the ≈øaid manor of T. for the time being ≈øhall at the next Court ≈øo to be holden, then next after ≈øuch warning had ≈øurrender and giue vp into the hands of the ≈øaid R. H. his heires or a≈ø≈øignes in open Court, according to the cu≈øtome of the ≈øaid Manor, to the v≈øe of the ≈øaid R. H. and his heires for euer all & ≈øinguler the afore≈øaid lands, tenements and hereditaments, hereafter in the≈øe pre≈øents mencioned expre≈ø≈øed and declared: That is to wit, one man≈øion or dwelling hou≈øe, wherin the ≈øaid R. E. now dwelleth, with all edifices & buildings &c. And furthermore I the ≈øaid H. T. do award, ordaine, deeme and Iudge by the≈øe pre≈øents, that the ≈øaid R. H. his heires or a≈ø≈øignes at the ≈øaid Court, where, and when the ≈øaid ≈øurrender ≈øhalbe ≈øo made, ≈øhall a≈ø≈øure and conuay vnto the ≈øaid R. E. or to his heires that ≈øhall ≈øo ≈øurrender the premi≈ø≈øes as afore≈øaid by copie of Court Rolle, according to the cu≈øtome of the ≈øaid Manor, or otherwi≈øe as by the ≈øaid ‚Ä¢ . E. his heires and a≈ø≈øignes or any of them, or by his or their learned coun≈øell ≈øhalbe rea≈øonably deui≈øed, or adui≈øed, & at the proper co≈øtes and charges of the ≈øaid R. E. his heires & a≈ø≈øignes not altering by the ≈øaid a≈ø≈øuraunce, or a≈ø≈øuraunces ≈øo to be deui≈øed, or adui≈øed as is afore≈øaid any cu≈øtome, libertie or iuri≈ødiction of the ≈øaid Lord≈øhip, manor or other the premi≈ø≈øes with all and ≈øinguler the ≈øaid lands, tenements and hereditaments, and al other the premi≈ø≈øes, with their appurtenances what≈øoeuer before by the≈øe pre≈øents ordered, and iudged to be ≈øurrendred as is afore≈øaid (foure acres of land now in the occupacion of &c. parcell of the premi≈ø≈øes to be cho≈øen by the ≈øaid R. H. &c. only excepted & forepri≈øed.) To haue & to hold the ≈øame lands, tenemeÃÑts & all other the premi≈ø≈øes with the app ‚Ä¢ rtenances (except before excepted) vnto the ≈øaid R. E. & to his heires males incorrupt within the 4. degree of con≈øanguinitie, according to the ancient cu≈øtome of the ≈øaid manors. And if it happen‚ñ™ that the ≈øaid R. E. do dece ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ before the ≈øaid ≈øurrender made as is afore≈øaid, Then to haue & to hold the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes with the appurtenances to the heires of the ≈øaid R. E. which ≈øo ≈øhall ≈øurrender the ≈øame & to his heires males incorrupt‚ñ™ within the 4. degree of con≈øanguinitie &c.

div.head: An Awarde reciting that either of‚ñ™ the parties ≈øtand bound to other to performe the award. And that the award is made before the prefixed time in the Obligations, and with the full con≈øent of both the parties.
div.p: TO all chri≈øtian people, to whom this pre≈øent writing indented of award Sect‚ñ™ 51. ≈øhal come R. W. and R. C. ≈øend greeting in our Lord God euerla≈øting. Know ye that whereas variance, ≈øtrife, debate, and controuer≈øie hath heretofore bin had, moued and ≈øtirred betweene A. B. of C. and D. E. of E. of, for and concerning the right, title, intere≈øt, v≈øe, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and occupation of &c. for the appea≈øing & ending whereof, either of the ≈øaid parties by their mutual a≈ø≈øents, con≈øents, & agreements, haue ≈øubmitted, compromitted, and bound them≈øelues either to other by their ≈øeueral writings obligatory, bearing date &c. in the ≈øuume of &c. to ≈øtand too, abide‚ñ™ obey, ob≈øerue, performe, fulfill and keepe the award, arbitrement, ordinance, dome and iudgment of vs &c. Arbitrators indifferently elect and cho≈øen, betweene the ≈øaid parties of, and for the premi≈ø≈øes as by the ≈øaid ≈øeueral obligations with condition for the performance therof more at large appeareth. Whereupon we the ≈øaid Arbitrators taking vpon vs the labour, bu≈øines, and charge of the ≈øame award, and willing to ≈øet the ≈øaid parties at a final peace, vnitie, and concord, for and concerning the premi≈ø≈øes, haue by good adui≈øe, & deliberation ≈øeene, heard, and throughly examined both their titles, allegations, euidences and proues in, and to the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes, and thereupon before the day and time appointed vnto vs by the ≈øaid obligations for the making, giuing vp and fini≈øhing. And fini≈øhing of the ≈øaid award, wee the ≈øaid Arbitrators by and with the full a≈ø≈øent, con≈øent, and agrement of both the ≈øaid parties do make, publi≈øh, declare, and giue vp this our pre≈øent award betweene the ≈øaid parties of, for, and concerning the premi≈ø≈øes, in manor & forme following. Fir≈øt we award, ordaine, deeme, and iudge, that &c. Al≈øo we awarde &c. And finally we award, ordeine, deeme and iudge &c. In witne≈ø≈øe whereof we the ≈øaid Atbitrators, and al≈øo both the ≈øaid parties to to the award haue interchangeably put our hands and ≈øeales the x. day of M. in the xx. yere of the raigne of our Soueraigne Lady Elizabeth, by the grace of God of England, France and Ireland, Queene defendor of the faith &c.

div.head: SYMBOLEOGRAPHY. Of the Chauncerie, Proceedings in the ≈øame, and Supplications, Billes, and Aun≈øweres.
The Chauncerie.
div.p: SEing by Gods fauor, we intend ≈øomewhat to Sect‚ñ™ 1. di≈øcour≈øe of the maner of proceeding in Chancerie ≈øuits, and to ≈øet downe ≈øome Pre≈øidents thereof, to the performing whereof, it ≈øeemeth requi≈øite fir≈øt to vnfold the nature of Equitie, Con≈øcience, & the rigor of the common Lawes of this Realme, as the proper obiect or matter whereabout ≈øuch ≈øuites are for the mo≈øt part occupied, to the end it may with the more facilitie be vnder≈øtood, how, and when ≈øuch ≈øuits are fitly to be taken in hand. Therefore we wil fir≈øt ≈øpeak of Summum ius, (which oftentimes preci≈øely regardeth the verie letter and words of the common Lawes: for remedie whereof, parties grieued, pray aide of this honorable Court of Chauncerie, to bridle extremitie, and reduce ≈øuch rigor to Equitie and Con≈øcience.

div.head: Of ≈øtrict or preci≈øe Law, which is called Ius ≈øummum.
div.p: ARi≈øtotle calleth it Eract or preci≈øe Law, becau≈øe that, if it haue Sect‚ñ™ 2. no allay in it to qualifie the har≈øhnes & ≈øeuerity of it, it is vnplea≈øant and ≈øower in ta≈øt, and repugnant to Equitie.

And Budaeus ≈øaith, that this word (≈øtrict and preci≈øe Law) is a word, which among≈øt the Ciuilians, ≈øignifieth verie hard law, exact, and ful of rigor, and almo≈øt vniu≈øt: For they that writ of the Law, make the≈øe words, ≈øtrict Law, and Equitie, oppo≈øite, the one to the other, thus farre Budaeus. The Lawiers do al≈øo tearme it, Ius ≈øubtile, ≈øubtil Law. Other Lawiers do tearme it, Summum Ius, Law in the highe≈øt degree‚ñ™ or mo≈øt exact, and it is ≈øo taken of them, when men ≈øtand more vpon the letter of the Law, then vpon the meaning of the writer, or maker of the Law. In which behalfe, it ≈øo falleth out oft times, that vnder a colour of knowledge
of the Lawes, many gro≈ø≈øe and dangerous errors be committed, Cora≈øius Mi≈ø≈øel. li. 2. ca. 8. Nu. 12.
Oldendorpius deuideth this Ius ≈øummum, or Law in the highe≈øt degree, into two branches: the one proper, the other improper.

Law in the highe≈øt degree, ≈øo properly termed or taken, is an vndoubted & infallible rule of hone≈øtie, which may generally without exception be put in executioÃÑ in any coÃÑmon weale, whether it be originally grouÃÑded vpon the Law of Nature, or vpon the Law of Nations: For examples whereof you may take all the rules and principles of the Law, for the≈øe rules and principles of the Law, do in their kind, mo≈øt ≈øtrictly and exactly define and bound out the matter which th ‚Ä¢ y handle, barely and nakedly, without any regard of circum≈øtances of the fact that may fal out, of which ≈øort of rules are the≈øe. Keepe thy word, hurt no man: the≈øe are general rules of Law in the highe≈øt degree, ≈øo righteous and full of Iu≈øtice in their kind, that by the Law of Nature it ≈øelfe, better and more rightfull cannot be giuen, Li. 1. F. de pactis.

But here you ≈øee no re≈øpect had to any circum≈øtance, of your worde or hurting, for this point belongeth to Equity, or the Court of Con≈øcience, which with vs is called the Chauncery, as the ca≈øe may fall out. And the law in the highe≈øt degree, being thus properly taken, is wrongfully termed by the common ≈øort of men, wrong in the highe≈øt degree, for to ≈øpeake generally and at a word, it is the iu≈øte≈øt rea≈øon that may be, whether Naturall, or Rationall, ≈øo farre is it, from being, to be rightfully taken wrong, vntill it be ≈øtretched, and as it were ≈øet vpon tenture bookes, to be drawen to ≈øome inconuenient circum≈øtance of the fact: as when a man doth couenant or giue his word to do ≈øome di≈øhone≈øt fact, or hurtfull and dangerous to the common wealth, In which ca≈øe, if a man ≈øhould wre≈øt this rule of Law, Keepe thy word, in ≈øteede of doing right in the highe≈øt degree, he ≈øhould commit iniu≈øtice in the highe≈øt degree: Not becau≈øe the Law hath any fault in it ≈øelfe, but becau≈øe through his error, and cauelling with the Law, he worketh wickednes, not iudging a right the circum≈øtances of the fact, wherein Law and right ≈øtandeth, Li. Si. F. de pactis.

Law in the highe≈øt degree improperly taken, is ≈øo termed when by an ouer rigorous and hard interpretation, it is drawen to inconuenient kinds of facts, or by colourable arguments, is drawen to fru≈øtrate the good meaning of the Law, L. Inciuile cum L. ≈øeq. F. de Legibus. Many examples hereof we haue in the Law: As, it is a Law, that no man ≈øhall be forced again≈øt his will to commence or maintaine any ≈øuit or action: Now put the ca≈øe, that I. S. is wrongfully impleaded by I. N. who hath framed a cunning action, full of glorious ≈øhewe again≈øt him the ≈øaid I. S. But I. N. finding in conclu≈øion that he is not able to proue,
and make good his action, becommeth non≈øuit, I. S. praieth remedy of the Iudges again≈øt this wrongfull vexation of I. N. and he the ≈øaid I. N. in defence of his wrongful vexation, vrgeth this rule of Law, that no man is compellable to maintain an action: Shall he be heard in this ca≈øe: No ≈øaith Iu≈øtinian, this fal≈øe glo≈øe of I. N. is not to be ≈øuffered or borne withal. This tearme or word of Law in the highe≈øt degree, being thus taken, we may wel ≈øay, that Law in the highe≈øt degree is wrong in the highe≈øt degree. For the more ≈øubtilly that a man doth argue, & the more authorities he heapeth togither, to inforce ≈øuch a law, ≈øo much the more and greater wrong, and iniu≈øtice ≈øhall he doe.

div.head: Of Equitie.
div.p: EQuitie is that which is commonly called equall and good, & ≈øometimes Sect‚ñ™ 3. equall and iu≈øt, and ≈øometime equall, iu≈øt, Lib. 1. & Pen. F. de Iu≈øticia & iure, I. ≈øi & ius F. ≈øi certum petatur, Ari≈øt. termeth it Epieices, and other terme it Epieician, which is as much to ≈øay, a mittigation, or moderation of the Lawe written, in ≈øome circum≈øtance, either of the things them≈øelues, of the per≈øons, or of the times. Law (≈øaith Donatus) is that, that maketh all things ≈øtraight, and not pliable to thone, nor other. Equitie is that, that di≈øpen≈øeth with many points of the Law. Oldendorpius ≈øaieth, that Equitie is nothing el≈øe, but a ≈øound or vpright will or iudgement of an hone≈øt man, nothing craftie or ≈øubtill, ≈øo mea≈øuring out to euery man that, that is his, that in the meane while noe man is wronged, as appeareth mo≈øt elegantly in I. bona fides I. Incurrit F. depo≈ø.
