Equitie as ≈øome other ≈øay, is a rea≈øonable mea≈øure, conteining in it ≈øelfe a fit proportion & rigor, ≈øo that it differeth from Law in this, that Law is a determinate ≈øentence ≈øet downe according to the rules of the law: But Equitie is a certaine proportion and allay, vpon good occa≈øions, ≈øetting on ≈øide the common rules of the Law, and ≈øo they cal it a ruled kind of Iu≈øtice, allayed with the ≈øweetnes of mercie.

Equitie is diuer≈øly termed in the Law, ≈ø ‚Ä¢ metime it is very ≈øignificantly called a Conueniency, becau≈øe it mini≈øtreth amonge≈øt men, a fit proportion, aun≈øwerable to the per≈øons, the matters, the places, and the times. Sometimes, plain dealing, is called Equitie, which is oppo≈øite to the dealing of man by nice points of the Law. Sometime it is taken for naturall Iu≈øtice, or the Law of Nature. Sometime it is taken for Law that is oppo≈øite to forged and deui≈øed Law. Sometime it is taken for Religion &c. And to be ≈øhort, Equitie, is the correction or amendement of a good Law, which is defectiue in ≈øome part, by rea≈øon of the generalitie of it.

div.head: Of the diui≈øion of Equitie.
div.p: EQuitie is twofold, written, and not written, for Equitie may be v≈øed Sect‚ñ™ 4. both in Schooles, and places of Iudgement, two waies: The one, by taking good heed, how, and in what ≈øort, Princes and Lawiers haue ob≈øerued Equitie, in making and ≈øetting downe of lawes, appointed to be rules and ≈øquares of mens actions: So that if at any time any ca≈øe falleth out, which is in all points aun≈øwerable to the Law, void of any different circum≈øtances, which might require ≈øome change, or alteration of the Law, they may accordingly frame their iudgements, being ≈øure and out of doubt, that the Law of Equitie is alreadie chalked out to them.

An other way Equitie is to bee pratti≈øed in the≈øe particuler facts, which daily fall out, and haue no certain line and ≈øquare ≈øet out for them in the Lawes alreadie made, ≈øo that we mu≈øt bee forced to deliuer our Iudgements in them, according to certain circum≈øtances, applyed as neerely as we can, to the principles of our Law. And herein ≈øtandeth the greate≈øt v≈øe of Equitie, mo≈øt fit for common weales: And therefore we may well call it an vnwritten Equitie, not becau≈øe we are at our liberties to define and determine of it, without due regard had to the Lawe written, but becau≈øe it taketh ≈øome libertie not to bind it ≈øelfe, to the generall Rules of the Law.

div.head: Of the efficient cau≈øe of Equitie.
div.p: GOD is the efficient cau≈øe of Equitie, who hath ≈øo di≈øpo≈øed of the Sect‚ñ™ 5. nature of mankind, that we are not in any wi≈øe able, to ≈øet downe a certaine rule for fu ‚Ä¢ ure things, and yet hath be≈øtowed vpon vs ≈øo much knowledge, as whereby we may frame certain generall rules of hone≈øt life‚ñ™ which may ≈øerue for directions in all particuler actions and facts, daily and hourely falling out among≈øt men, if they be duly and carefully examined by the rule of Equitie, which hath hereye ca≈øt vpon all ordinarie circum≈øtances.

div.head: Of the material cau≈øe of Equitie.
div.p: THe Law of Nature, the Law of Nations, and good maners, are Sect‚ñ™ 6. the materiall cau≈øe of Equitie, for a well minded man, and of ≈øound Iudgement, will make of the≈øe three an hol≈øome and verie medicinable mixture, for any ≈øtate and common wealth. But the matter where about this Equitie mu≈øt occupie and bu≈øie her ≈øelfe, are the affaires of men, infinite, as they fall out. For right or Law will bee rightly mini≈øtred, if as matters fall out, the circum≈øtances thereof duely con≈øidered, the mini≈øters of the Law do frame their Iudgements accordingly.

div.head: Of the formal cau≈øe of Equitie.
div.p: THe formal cau≈øe of Equitie is the matching and leueling of facts Sect' 7. falling out, and the circum≈øtances thereof, with the rules of the Law, as buildings are framed to Carpenters lines and ≈øquares.

div.head: Of the final cau≈øe of Equitie.
div.p: THe final cau≈øe of Equity, or effect, is, to keepe an equalitie amoÃÑg≈øt Sect' 8. the ≈øtate of men, who are at much odds & ≈øquares amonge≈øt them≈øelues, to the end, the common wealth may be pre≈øerued in ≈øafety, which ≈øtandeth for the mo≈øt part in righteous iudgements.

div.head: Why Equitie is ≈øometimes compared to a ruler.
div.p: NOt vnfitly is Equitie tearmed, the rule of maners: for as by a Sect' 9. rule the faults of a building are di≈øcouered, ≈øo doth Equitie Iudge a right, both of the written Law, and al≈øo of all mens actions and behauiours: And therefore ≈øuch as are mini≈øters of Iu≈øtice, applie and frame their Iudgements, after the ≈øquare and rule of good and egall, that is to ≈øay: of Gods Law, and the Lawes of Nature. Again≈øt which Lawes, what Iudgements ≈øoeuer be giuen, cannot be but vniu≈øt and vnrighteous.

div.head: How Equitie and Clemencie differ.
div.p: THere is a difference betweene Equitie, and Clemencie: for Equitie Sect' 10. is alwaies mo≈øt firmely knit to the wil of the Law, which way ≈øoeuer it bends, whether to clemencie, or to ≈øeueritie. But clemencie is onely proper to the Prince, or tho≈øe Magi≈øtrates, that haue like power of admini≈øtration of Iu≈øtice, as Princes haue.

div.head: Of the difference‚ñ™ betweene Equitie, and ≈øtrict Law.
div.p:
STrict Law & Equitie differ herein, that ≈øtrict Law doth ≈øet downe Sect' 11. in a generall ≈øort what it enacteth, & is ≈øeuere, and not to be moued, one way or other: it taketh order for things, once for all: the grounds & principles which it bringeth forth are vniuer≈øall, & full of ≈øeuerity and ≈øharpnes, from which rules it will not ≈øtart a≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e, no not the breadth of an heire. But Equity is fitly compared to a Shoomakers ≈øhop that is well furni≈øhed with all ≈øorts and maner of la≈øtes for mens feete, where each man may be ≈øure to finde one la≈øt or other that ≈øhall fit him, be he great or ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ all. It is not al≈øo vnfitly compared to an Apothecaries ≈øhop, ≈øtored with al kind of drugges, fit for all the maledies & di≈øea≈øes of men. Which drugs notwith≈øtanding, in ca≈øe they ≈øhould be vn≈økilfull compounded togither, would in ≈øtead of healing, worke pre≈øent death to the patient that ≈øhould receiue them: For it requireth the indu≈øtrie and exqui≈øite
art of a good Phi≈øition, to make a right compo≈øition, di≈øcerning, and tempering by iu≈øt proportions good venims from euill. In like ≈øort in affaires both publike and priuate, equity doth particularly, & carefully examine the cau≈øes, the times, the circum≈øtances, the ≈øorts and differences of per≈øons, and matters, and by former iudgement giuen in like ca≈øes, gathereth and frameth an ab≈øolute and perfect deciding and determining the matter pre≈øently in que≈øtion and ≈øute.
And S. German to the like effect ≈øaith, Equitie is a righteou≈ønes tempered with mercie, which con≈øidereth all the particuler circum≈øtances of the deed, Doct. & Stu. Lib. 1. cap. 16.

This Equitie, ≈øaieth he, mu≈øt alwaies be ob≈øerued in euery Law of man, and in euery Maxime or generall rule thereof, for that mens acts are ≈øo diuers and infinite, that it is impo≈ø≈øible to make any general Law which may aptly meete with euery particuler act, and not faile in ≈øome ≈øpecial ca≈øe. Therefore Law-makers do fore≈øee things which may oft happen: in ≈øo much as ≈øtrictly to ob≈øerue the word and tenor of the law, were in ≈øome ca≈øes both again≈øt Iu≈øtice and the comon wealth. Wherefore in ≈øuch ca≈øes we mu≈øt ≈øtick fa≈øt to that which rea≈øon and Iu≈øtice require, which is, that Equitie may mittigate Rigorem iuris, which equitie is no other thing, theÃÑ an exception of the Law of God, or of the Law of Rea≈øon, from the general principles of mans po≈øitiue law, not agreeing with them in ≈øome particularitie, which exception is inwardly implyed in euery general ground or Maxime of the Law. And yet taketh not away the very right, but ≈øub≈øtituteth right in ≈øteed of that which by the onely letter of the Law ≈øeemeth to be right and is not. Neither may we therefore accu≈øe the Law of crueltie (which as is ≈øaid) generally taken is good of it ≈øelfe, and not cruel, though it reach not fully to euery particuler circum≈øtance of mens actions. And therefore if a Law were made, that no man vnder the paine of death, ≈øhould open the gates of a Citie before the Sun ri≈øing, yet he who for ≈øauing the Citizens flying from their Enemies to the ≈øame gates, openeth them before that time, offendeth not thintent and equitie of that Law, D. S. Lib. 1. cap. 6. Or if a Statute were made, that who≈øoeuer doth ≈øuch an Act ≈øhould be put to death: yet if one of Non ≈øanae memoriae, or an infant of tender yeres, which wanteth di≈øcretion do ≈øuch an act, they ≈øhall not therefore ≈øuffer death. Or if a Statute were made, that who≈øoeuer receiueth or aydeth with meate drinke, or otherwi≈øe I. S. an offendor knowing his offence ≈øhalbe acce≈ø≈øary thereunto as a felon, yet if his wife knowing his offence receyue and ayde him, ≈øhe ≈øhall not thereby be a Felon: for in the generalitie of ≈øuch Statutes, Madmen, Infants, and his owne wife are not inteÃÑded to be included, but excepted by implication. By l ‚Ä¢ which we may gather, that the outward words of the Law onely, are not the law,
but the inward ≈øence and meaning thereof: For our Lawes (as all other Lawes) haue two parts, that is to ≈øay: the fle≈øh and ≈øoule, The letter re≈øembleth the fle≈øh, the intent, and rea≈øon, the ≈øoule: Nam ratio legis, e≈øt anima legis. The Law may be compared to a Nut, whereof the letter re≈øembleth the ≈øhell, the ≈øence the kernell: And as the profit of the nut is not in the ≈øhell, but in the kernell, ≈øo the fruit of the Law is not in the letter, but in the ≈øence: And as he which re≈øteth vpon the ≈øhel lee≈øeth the fruit of the nut: ≈øo he which ≈øtaieth vpon the letter wanteth the profit of the law, for the letter is ≈øometimes larger, and ≈øometimes narrower then the intent which Equitie regardeth, Plow. 9. b 465. a

And Bracton of Equitie writeth thus: aequitas e≈øt rerum conuenientia quae in paribus cau≈øis paria con≈øiderat iura, & omnia bene coequiparat. Et dicitur aequitas qua≈øi aequalitas, & vertitur in rebus, id e≈øt, in dictis & factis hominum, lib. 1. cap. 4. SectÃÑ 35.

div.head: How the Chauncerie is termed the Court of Con≈øcience.
div.p: ANd for ≈øo much as this Court bridleth the rigor of the Common Sect' 12. Law, by giuing actions and exceptions for remedies whereby law none were, according to equitie and con≈øcience, to maintaine aequum & bonum, the common people terme the Chauncery the Court of Con≈øcience: Yet herein con≈øcience is ≈øo regarded, that Lawes be not neglected, for they mu≈øt ioine hands in the moderation of extremitie, Diuer≈ø. CurÃÑ 105. Nam ip≈øe etiam leges cupiunt vt iure regantur, id e≈øt, vt leui, facili, ac benigna interpretatione temperentur, vereque dicitur, Nullus recedat a Cancellaria ≈øine remedio, 4. H. 7. 4.

div.head: Of Con≈øcience.
div.p:
THis Con≈øcience is defined, Reliqua in hominerationis ≈øcintilla, bonorum,
Sect' 13. malorumque facinorum, index & Iudex: igitur & bipertita ea approbatio ≈øcilicet & opprobatio, illa in bene, hec in ≈øecus factis. Iu≈øtus Lip≈øus lib. ciuilis doctrina cap. 5. or thus.

p.hi: Con≈øcientia e≈øt ta ‚Ä¢ itum animi infallibileque facti no≈øtri iudicium, a communi Iu≈øtitiae formula, quam Deus in≈øculp≈øit omnibus hominibus productum, per quod aut accu≈øatur res mala aut defendi ‚Ä¢ bona, Oldendorpius, Cora≈øius in Mi≈øcel. lib. 4. cap. 20.

div.p:
Con≈øcience is an actuall applying of knowledge to ≈øome particuler act of man, as Saint Germain ≈øaith, Doct. and Stu. cap. 15. And Syndere≈øis which is termed a natural power of the Soule, per≈øwading good, and di≈ø≈øwading euil, D. S. lib. 1. cap. 13. & is nothing els but attenta ob≈øeruationis occa≈øio cuÃÑ o ‚Ä¢ bus circum≈øtantijs eius, Theucid. lib. 7. and mini≈øtreth the general principles of that knowledge. Vere igitur di ‚Ä¢ itur, con≈øcientiam veraÃÑ ni≈øi adhibeat, Iudex non pote≈øt cau≈øam ≈øecundum equitatem,
definire, ≈øimille te≈øtes, totidem
que videat ob oculos in≈øtrumenta, Con≈øcientia enim (cum mille te≈øtium vim obtineat) certa e≈øt, non fallitur. At in probationibus ≈øaepe vel error, vel dolus ver≈øatur, ≈øicut experientia heu nimis frequens nos docet, Oldend.

div.head: Of Iudgements in Chauncerie.
div.p: SO great is the power, iuri≈ødiction, and maie≈øtie of this court, that Sect. 14. Iudgements therein giuen are not to be controlled or reuer≈øed in any other Court, then the high Court of Parliament, which is the chiefe≈øt of all other Courts in this Realme, Diuer≈ø. Cur. 105. 37. H. 6. 14.

div.head: Of the power ordinarie of the Chauncerie.
div.p: ANd this Court is armed with twofold power, that is to ≈øay: with Sect. 15. power ordinarie and ab≈øolute, 9. E. 4. 15.

By ordinary power the Lord Chauncelor proceedeth as at the common Law, as in proceeding vpon Recognizances there knowledged, and trauer≈øes of offices, in which parties are to plead and ioyne i≈ø≈øue as at common Law. And ≈øo in ≈øuit again≈øt, or for Clerkes of the Chauncerie, and other per≈øons priuiledged by Attachment there for matter of action remediable by the common Law &c. But when they be at i≈ø≈øue, the Record mu≈øt be tran≈ømitted into the K. Bench to be tried by Iurie. And when it is ≈øo tried, it mu≈øt be remaunded into the Chauncerie, that iudgement may be there giuen, and execution had vpon the ≈øame, 24. E. 3. 45. 14. E. 4. 7. 8. E. 4. 6.

div.head: Of the power ab≈øolute of the Chauncerie.
div.p: THe ab≈øolute power is not tied to the rules of the common Law, Sect. 16. but by that, matters may be examined omnibus vijs & modis quibus rei veritas melius ≈øciri poterit, & iudged ≈øecundum allegata & probata, and not by Iurie of twelue men, as at the common Law: But by examination of witne≈ø≈øes, as in the courtes of the Ciuill Law, Smithus de Rep. Angl. lib. 2. cap. 12. Diuer≈ø. Cur. 106. 9. E. 4. 15. Neither is ≈øuch preci≈øe forme of pleading v≈øed in the ChauÃÑcerie, as at the common Law, nor any aduaÃÑtage to be taken for mi≈øpleading, or want of forme, ≈øo as the ≈øub≈øtance of the matter be ≈øufficiently di≈øclo≈øed in con≈øcience, Diuer≈ø. Cur. 106. 9. E. 4. 15. 24. E. 3. 45. 14. E. 4. 7.

Diuers other ≈øpeciall aucthorities and priuiledges hath the Lord Chauncelor by ≈øundrie Statutes, as thereby appeareth. And partition made in the Chauncery rendring rent is good, and may well be ≈øent into the Kings Bench, and execution thereupon made by Scire facias, ‚Ä¢ 7. H. 6. 43. li. A≈ø≈ø. 32. And if lands be recouered from a woman whereof ≈øhe was endowed in the ChauÃÑcerie, ≈øhe may haue a Scire facias there to be newly endowed, 29. A≈ø≈ø. 23.

div.head: Of a Subpena.
div.p: ANd ≈øeeing the ordinarie meanes to call and bring in the parties to Sect. 17. aun≈øwere in this Court is eyther by the Serieant of the Mace, as before, or by Subpena which onely is thoriginall proce≈ø≈øe of this court, and mu≈øt be directed to the parties, D. St. lib. 1. cap. 17. Smith de Rep. Ang. lib. 2. cap. 12.

div.head: Ca≈øes remediable in Chauncerie.
div.p: HAuing thus peru≈øed Equitie and ≈øummum Ius with their differences, Sect. 18. and al≈øo what con≈øcience is, whereupon ≈øuits in this court do chiefly lie: It ≈øeemeth good now ≈øpecially to con≈øider ≈øuch ≈øpeciall ca≈øes as be remediable in Chauncerie, and for which a writ of Subpena lieth there, as in ca≈øes following.

A Subpena lyeth in no ca≈øe but where the common Law fayleth, ≈øo as the partie who in Equitie hath wrong, can haue none ordinarie remedie by the cour≈øe and rules of the common Law, 39. H. 6. 26. 7. H. 7. 11. as in the≈øe ca≈øes following, and ≈øuch like.
As if the Queene by her letters Patents giue vnto A. goods forfeited to her highnes by Trea≈øon, A. may ≈øue for the ≈øame in Chauncerie, 39. H. 6. 26.

And it ≈øeemeth if one Coexecutor alone releas debt due to the te≈øtator, his companion may thereof haue remedie in Chauncery again≈øt his Coexecutor onely, if no couin be in the debtor: but if there be, then again≈øt them both, 4. H. 7. 4. Diuer≈ø. Cur. 106.

And by Moyle, if in a Quare impedit by two Coparceners, thone make a fal≈øe plea of couin betweene him & the defendant, then his companioÃÑ by ≈øuit in the Court may enforce him to ioine with him in a true count, 6. E. 4. 10.
If lands in Auncient deme≈øne extended by ≈øtatute Marchant be recouered by common recouerie, the cognizee hath no remedie but in con≈øcience, 7. H. 7. 11.
If feoffees in tru≈øt commaunded by ce≈øtuy qÃÑ v≈øe to enfeoffe his vendee, refu≈øe to do it, a Subpena lyeth for the vendee again≈øt them, 37. H. 6. 36.

If ce≈øtuy qÃÑ v≈øe deui≈øe by his will that his feoffees make an e≈øtate to I. S. for life, the remainder to H. in fee, and I. refu≈øe to take his e≈øtate, H. after the death of I. may by Subpena compell the feoffees to make e≈øtate to him accordingly, per Ienny & Finch. 37. H. 6. 36.

Tenant in Borough engli≈øh enfeoffe A. to the v≈øe of the feoffor and his heires and die, his yonge≈øt ≈øonne ≈øhall haue a Subpena, and not the elde≈øt, for the v≈øe is of the nature of the land, 5. E. 4. 7.

If a man make a feoffement in tru≈øt of lands di≈øcended to him ex parte matris, and die without i≈ø≈øue, his heire ex parte matris may haue
a Subpena, 5. E. 4. 7.

If a man make a feoffement to performe his will, and after to infeoffe his heires, and declare his will for yeares, and die, hauing i≈ø≈øue a ≈øonne and a daughter by one venter, and a daughter by another ventre, the ≈øonne dieth without i≈ø≈øue before the will be performed, his ≈øi≈øter of the whole bloud is to haue execution of the ≈øtate by the feoffees, for po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øio fratris de feodo (of an v≈øe) facit ≈øororem e≈ø≈øe haeredem, & the will for yeares is no impediment of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion: But otherwi≈øe if it had bin of franktenement by the Reporter, 5. E. 4. 7.

If A. ≈øei≈øed in fee to the v≈øe of a woman, who taketh an hu≈øband, & he ≈øelleth the land to S. for money which y‚Ä¢ wife receiueth, & A. at their reque≈øt infeffe the vendee, the hu≈øbaÃÑd dieth, the wife may haue a Subpena again≈øt the vendee, hauing notice hereof, or el≈øe again≈øt the feoffee for recompence: for this is the ≈øale of the hu≈øband onely, 7. E. 4. 14.

If M. know that W. is infeoffed to mine v≈øe, or of my will, or hath goods giuen to him to mine v≈øe, and buy the lands or goods for money, a Subpena lieth again≈øt the vendor and vendee to performe the will or v≈øe, 5. E. 4. 7. 11. E. 4. 8. Diuer≈ø. Cu ‚Ä¢ 106. But again≈øt the vendor only if the vendee haue no ≈øuch notice, Diuer≈ø. Cu ‚Ä¢ 106.

A man by Subpena may enforce his feoffee of tru≈øt to bring actions in their names, 7. E. 4. 29. as tre≈øpas again≈øt tre≈øpa≈ø≈øors, 11. E. 4. 8. yet if the feoffee had relea≈øed to the tre≈øpa≈ø≈øor, Ce≈øtuy que v≈øe had bin remediles, 11. E. 4. 8. or A≈ø≈øi≈øe, 2. E. 4. 2. or tre≈øpas for goods giuen to his v≈øe taken away, 7. E. 4. 29. But not an appeale of Robberie, becau≈øe they be not compelable to ioyne battaile, 7. E. 4. 29.
If a feoffement be made to the chiefe Lord, or others, to v≈øes, he may refu≈øe to execute the e≈øtate for extingui≈øhing of his Seigniorie, and no Subpena lieth again≈øt him, 16. E. 4. 4.
The heire of the feoffee in tru≈øt being in by di≈øcent is compellable by Subpena to execute an e≈øtate according to the tru≈øt, 22. E. 4. 6.
If a wife will that her feoffees ≈øhall infeoffe her hu≈øband, he may not compell them thereunto, for the will of a wife in this ca≈øe is void, 18. E. 4. 11.
If A. be bound to F. to the v≈øe of C. C. in Chauncerie may compell F. to ≈øue A. for the ≈øame, 2. E. 4. 2.

If R. deliuer money to A. to deliuer to his executors or admini≈øtrators to di≈øpo≈øe &c. and deliuer A. the ≈øame vpon bond to B. to keepe and redeliuer to him, R. dieth, his executors, or admini≈øtrators may in ChaÃÑ cery compell A. to ≈øue the obligors for the money, 4. E. 4. 37.

If P. be bound in a ≈øtatute ≈øtaple to I. and H, to the v≈øe of I, & H. releas P, no Subpena lieth again≈øt P. notwith≈øtanding that he had notice of thu≈øe, for euery man may lawfully aide him≈øelfe, 11. E. 4. 8. Diuer≈ø.
Cur. 106. The like of an Obligation to two, to thu≈øe of one, the remedie is again≈øt him that did ≈øo releas, Diuer≈ø. Cur. 106. 11. E. 4. 8.
If A. be bound to B. to thu≈øe of C. and B. relea≈øe, C. may haue remedie therefore in Chauncerie, 7. H. 7. 11.

If a man pay debt due by ≈øpecialtie without an acquitance, or haue an acquitance, and loo≈øe it, he ≈øhall haue remedy in Chauncery, 22. E. 4. 6. 7. H. 7. 11. But it ≈øeemeth to be otherwi≈øe, if the debt be by matter of record, for el≈øe might all Records be auoided by witne≈ø≈øes which would di≈øtroy the common Law, 22. E. 4. 6. Diuer≈ø. Cur. 106. D. and S. lib. 1. cap. 12.
A Subpena lyeth on a promi≈øe or agreement by word: as to build a hou≈øe, or do any other lawfull act, 8. E, 4. 4. Diuer≈ø. Cur. 105.
An action lieth again≈øt Executors in ChauÃÑcerie vpon a ≈øimple contract without ≈øpecialty, 7. H. 7. 11.
If there be 2. obligors, and the obligee giue longer day of payment to thone of them, & ≈øue thother, he may haue a Subpena, 6. E. 4. 41.
If goods be giuen to defraud creditors, they may haue remedie in ChauÃÑcerie again≈øt the donees, or ≈øuch as haue the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øioÃÑ of the goods, 16. E. 4. 9.

If a man be ≈øuerti ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ or an others debt, and the debtor, and others be bound to ≈øaue the ≈øuertie harmeles, & the ≈øuretie haue‚ñ™ al≈øo goods deliuered by the debtor to ≈øaue him harmeles: Notwith≈øtaÃÑding the ≈øuerty pay the debt, yet if he ≈øue his Obligation, the debtor may haue a Subpena for re≈øtitution of his goods ≈øo pawned for the ≈øame, lea≈øt he ≈øhould be twice charged therefore, 16. E. 4. 9.

If a man buy a debt due by obligation, and be bound to pay a ≈øumme of money to the vendor for it: yet for ≈øo much as the thing ≈øold is cho≈øe in action in the vendee he can haue no propertie, and therefore hath not quid pro quo, the vendee may be relieued in Equitie for his owne obligation, 37. H. 6. 13.
And for euidence whereof the plaintife knoweth, neither the certain contents nor contentment, he may haue remedy in Chauncery, Diuer≈ø. Cur. 105.
Learne whether if a tran≈øitorie per≈øonall action be ≈øued in a forein Countie, the defendant may ≈øtay the plaintife in Chauncerie by Iniunction, Diuer≈ø. Cur. 106.

So nece≈ø≈øarie be the remedies in Chaunceri e vpon equities allowed by law, that it ≈øeemeth to ≈øome not inconuenient to haue a≈ø≈øigned ≈øuch remedies for the 7. ground of the Lawes of this Realme, which are ≈øaid to con≈øi≈øt of 6. grounds onely: Fir≈øt the Law of Rea≈øon, 2. The Law of God, 3. Generall Cu≈øtomes of the Realme, 4. Principles or Maxims of Law, 5. Particuler Cu≈øtomes v≈øed onely in certein places
of this Realme, 6. Acts of Parliament, Doct. & Stu. Lib. 1. cap. 3. 4. 5. 6. 7. 8. 9. 10. 11. and 17.

If a man bound in a ≈øingle Obligation or bill of debt, pay the money according to the bond, neither taking an acquitance thereof, nor cancelling the ≈øpecialtie of the ≈øame, he is by the common Law chargeable to pay the ≈øame debt againe, by vertue of the ≈øaid ≈øpecialtie: But may haue remedy thereof in the Chauncerie, Doct. Stu. Lib. 2. cap. 6. 1. H. 7. fol. 14.

div.head: ¬∂ A view of certeine ca≈øes wherein the partie grieued ≈øeemeth wronged Sect. 19. in Con≈øcience, and yet is remedile≈ø≈øe in Chauncery.
div.p: OF an vniu≈øt wager of Law in an action of debt vpon a ≈øimple coÃÑ tract, Doct. Stu. Lib. 1. cap. 18.
Of a fal≈øe verdict by a graund Iurie in Attaint, Doct. Stu. Lib. 1. cap. 18.

For damages where a man hath right or title to land in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of another, and may by action recouer, onely the land but no dammages, for the meane occupation there is no remedie for the ≈øame damages in Chauncerie: As if the tenant in taile be di≈ø≈øei≈øed, and the di≈ø≈øei≈øor die ≈øei≈øed, and his heire is in by di≈øcent, a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øt whom the i≈ø≈øue in taile bringeth a Formedon, he may recouer the land, but no damages, D. S. lib. 1. cap. 19.

A man may not deny that which he hath once affirmed of record, in a Court of Record, nor affirme that which he hath once denied of record in a Court of Record, nor that whereof he wilfully e≈øtopped or excluded him≈øelfe by deed indented, or otherwi≈øe: As if a daughter which is ≈øole heire to her father ≈øue liuerie with her ba≈øtard ≈øi≈øter, ≈øhe is remedile≈ø≈øe by law, D. S. lib. 1. cap. 19.
If a thing be found by verdict again≈øt trueth before iudgement, D. S. lib. 1. cap. 19.

Where the cau≈øe of the law cea≈øeth, the law al≈øo cea≈øeth in con≈øcience: As le≈ø≈øee for yeares recouereth by iudgement treble damages for a tre≈øpas of wa≈øt done by an e≈øtranger, And he in the reuer≈øion dieth before his action of wa≈øt be ended, yet in con≈øcience he ought to ≈øue execution for his ≈øingle damages, for he had no more hurt thereby, D. S. lib. 1. cap. 19.
A Law grouÃÑded vpon a fal≈øe pre≈øumption is not to be holden in con≈øcience, D. S. lib. 1. cap. 19.

Con≈øcience may not preuaile again≈øt a lawfull Cu≈øtome, either generall or particuler: As in di≈øcents of lands to the elde≈øt ≈øonne by the common Law, to the yonge≈øt by Borough Engli≈øh, and to al by Gauelkind, D. S. lib. 1. cap. 19.

So if a man without con≈øideration make a deede of feoffement of two acres of land, lying each in a ≈øeuerall Shire, and make liuery of ≈øei≈øin in thone acre onely in the name of both, that wherein liuerie of ≈øei≈øin was made, onely pa≈ø≈øeth in law and con≈øcience. Doct. St. lib. 1. cap. 20.

If one Iointenant of a wood ≈øell the wood, and keepe all the money receiued for it wholly to him≈øelf, his fellow may haue remedy in Chancerie, lib. 1. cap. 19. And ≈øo it ≈øeemeth, if they were Iointenants in common, or Coparceners of other things.

If a common per≈øon of his mere motion without other con≈øideratioÃÑ make a feoffement of a manor, without the≈øe words, (with the appurtenances) he hath right onely to the demeanes and coÃÑmons, and rents, of the attournement: but neither to Aduow≈øon appendant, nor villein regardant. But in the Kings ca≈øe, notwith≈øtanding the words (with thappurtenances) were in the graunt: yet neither Aduow≈øons, nor Villeines do pa≈ø≈øe, either by Law or con≈øcience, vnle≈ø≈øe they be e≈øpecially named, D. S. Lib. 1. cap. 19. 6. E. 3. 286. Regi≈øt. fol. 228. Fundamenta Legum fol. 70. 43. E. 3. 22.

If a lea≈øe for yeares be re≈øeruing rent, with a clau≈øe of reentrie, the rent is behind, the le≈ø≈øor dieth before demaund, the heire can neither enter by law nor con≈øci ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e: Otherwi≈øe if he made a lawfull demaund thereof, D. S. lib. 1. cap. 20.
If tenant in Dower ≈øow the land and die before the Corne be reaped, hir executors ≈øhall haue the Corne: but not the gra≈ø≈øe, nor other fruits, D. S. Lib. 1. cap. 20.

If tenant for life, or tenant in taile after po≈ø≈øibilitie of i≈ø≈øue, alien in fee, he in the reuer≈øion or remainder may enter, and haue the land by the forfeiture, in law and con≈øcience, D. S. Lib. 1. cap. 20. 45. E. 3. 3.
Euery Law ordeined for the di≈øpo≈øition of lands or goods, contrarie neither to the Law of God, nor to the Law of Rea≈øon, bindeth in the Court of Con≈øcience, D. S. Lib. 1. cap. 20.

Whether one of the age of xx. yeares, who hauing rea≈øon and wi≈ødome to gouerne him≈øelfe, ≈øelleth his land for money, and therewith buy other lands of better value, and taketh the profits thereof, may haue his fir≈øt land againe in con≈øcience, as he may in law, repaying the money which he receiued: Yet ≈øeemeth he may, becau≈øe the contract is in≈øufficient by rea≈øon of the infancy. D. S. lib. 1. cap. 21.

If a man ≈øell his land by a ≈øufficient and lawfull contract, though he want liuerie or attournement, or ≈øuch other ≈øolempnities of the Law, yet the ≈øellor is compelable‚ñ™ in the Chauncerie to performe the contract, D. S. lib. 1. cap. 21.

If the tenant for life impanelled on an Inque≈øt loo≈øe i≈ø≈øues & die, they are leuiable by law on him in the reuer≈øioÃÑ. And ≈øo be the hu≈øbands i≈ø≈øues
after his death vpon the wiues land, and as it ≈øeemeth in Con≈øcience, for the nece≈ø≈øitie of the execution of Iu≈øtice. D. S. lib. 2. cap. 21.
No man is bound in Con≈øcience to pay the penaltie of a penall ≈øtatute, nor other penaltie vntill it be lawfully recouered again≈øt him. D. S. lib. 1. cap. 23.

If A. infeoffe B. in fee of land vpon condition, that if he infeoffe any other, that A. and his heires may enter: this condition ≈øeemeth void in Law and Con≈øcience, becau≈øe it is contrary to the Maximes of the law, notwith≈øtaÃÑding thintent of the parties, for thintent mu≈øt be ordered by law, & if it be not, it is void, as by a feoffement of lands without recompence to A. for euer, he hath e≈øtate for life onely, for want of the woord (heires) And a Lea≈øe to A. & his heires for xx. yeares, ≈øhall go to his executors, becau≈øe it is a chattel, & ≈øo by feoffement without recoÃÑpence to a man & his wife & a third per≈øon, the hu≈øband & wife take only the moitie, becau≈øe they are but one per≈øon in law. D. S. lib. 1. cap. 24.
A fine with proclamation & no claime within v. yeres extingui≈øheth the right of all e≈øtrangers, a≈øwell of the parties by law.
And by Con≈øcience al≈øo as it ≈øeemeth, becau≈øe thereby the right and title is made certaine, and thereby the common wealth more quiet, and it is not contrarie to Gods law. Doct. & St. 25.

Common recouery with vouchers vpon writs of Entre orderly pur≈øued, and no recouery in value to be had in deed barre thi≈ø≈øue in taile in law, 23. H. 8. Br. Taile 23. 14. E. 4. 14. & 19. 13. E. 4. 1.

And in con≈øcience as it ≈øeemeth, for as the intailes are made by law, We≈øt. 2. ca. 1. euen ≈øo by law may they be adnulled. And ≈øuch Lawes as concerne right or propertie to things, and be not contrarie to the lawes of God, or of rea≈øon, are good in con≈øcience. D. S. lib. 1. cap. 6.

If a di≈ø≈øei≈øor giue the lands to I. S. in taile, & he graunteth vnto the di≈ø≈øei≈øee rent out of the ≈øame lands, in con≈øideration wherof the di≈ø≈øei≈øee relea≈øeth his right, this graunt bindeth the i≈ø≈øue in taile for euer in law and con≈øcience, becau≈øe this relea≈øe doth confirme his e≈øtate which the di≈ø≈øei≈øee might el≈øe haue defeated. D. S. Lib. 1. cap. 27. 44. E. 3. 22.
If the bodie of a debtor that hath nothing, be by iudgement impri≈øoned vntill he pay his debt, hee ≈øeemeth remedyle≈ø≈øe in Con≈øcience. D. S. lib. 1. cap. 29.

A recouerie with vouchers of an annuitie intailed, bindeth thi≈ø≈øue in taile neither in law nor con≈øcience, becau≈øe a writ of Entre doth not lie for an Annuity, nor any other writ then only a writ of Annuity again≈øt the per≈øon of the grantor or his heire, hauing a≈ø≈øets by di≈øcent: Or again≈øt a Corporation, if it be graunted to be perceiued out of their cofers, for that an Annuitie is no freehold in law. D. S. lib. 1. cap. 30. 44. E. 3. 5. 2. H. 4. 13. Fitz. Na. br. fol. 152.

If tenant in taile be di≈ø≈øei≈øed and die, and a collaterall aunce ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ er to the heire in taile relea≈øe to the di≈ø≈øei≈øor with warrantie and die, and the ≈øame warrantie di≈øcend vpon the ≈øaid heire, he is barred in law and con≈øcience. D. S. cap. 31. 35. H. 6. 63. 41. E. 3. 7. 45. E. 3. 23. 19. H. 6. 59. 15. H. 7. 9. & 10. 21. H. 7. 39. 3. H. 7. 9.

Tenant in taile after po≈ø≈øibilitie of i≈ø≈øue is di≈øpuni≈øhable for wa≈øt by law and con≈øcience, becau≈øe he had once inheritance, 45. E. 3. 3. 39. E. 3. 16. and thereby power to wa≈øt without puni≈øhment, which power endureth ≈øo long as his e≈øtate, D. S. lib. 2. cap. 1.

If a man be outlawed before he haue knowledge of the ≈øuit, albeit the ≈øurmi≈øed cau≈øe of action be vntrue, yet the Queene may haue his goods by Law and con≈øcience, by rea≈øon of his di≈øobedience in not appearing, to the hindrance of the effect of law, for he is bound to take notice of the ≈øuit being of record at his perill. And the forfeiture groweth by a generall Maxime made for the nece≈ø≈øarie execution of Iu≈øtice: But it ≈øeemeth the defendant may haue remedie in con≈øcience again≈øt him which cau≈øed him to be outlawed without iu≈øt cau≈øe. D. St. lib. 2. cap. 3. 21. H. 7. 7. 9. H. 6. 20.

If an e≈øtranger do wa≈øt lands which another holdeth for yeares, life, in dower, or by the curte≈øie, without the tenants a≈ø≈øent, the owner of the reuer≈øion may recouer the place wa≈øted, and treble dammages again≈øt the tenant in law.

And in con≈øcience notwith≈øtanding that the ≈øtranger be in≈øufficient to recompence him for the ≈øame, for it is his owne act and follie to take ≈øuch e≈øtate ≈øubiect to the chance. D. S. lib. 2. cap. 4.

If a real action be brought by a very lawfull heire, and yet ba≈øtardie being pleaded in him, he is vntruely certified by the Ordinarie to be a ba≈øtard, and ≈øo barred, the tenant knowing this certificate to be vntrue, ought not in con≈øcience to reteyne the land, yet is there no remedie for him in law, nor in Chauncerie, as it ≈øeemeth for that the Bi≈øhops certificat is the highe≈øt triall that the law affordeth in this behalfe. And euery ≈øtranger may take aduantage of this certificate, and no moe writs may be awarded for further trialll of the trueth thereof, for the auoyding of the incoÃÑuenience which might happen, if another Bi≈øhop ≈øhould certifie ≈øuch ba≈øtard to be legitimate. D. S. lib. 2. cap. 5.

If a feoffement in fee be made without deed, or a gift in taile, or a lea≈øe for life, the remainder ouer in fee: Or if tenant for ‚Ä¢ fe graunt his whole e≈øtate by deed Poll, re≈øeruing rent, in the≈øe ca≈øes the re≈øeruation is void in law, and there is no remedie therefore but in con≈øcience. D. S. lib. 2. cap. 9.

Learne whether Executors or Admini≈øtrators hauing a≈ø≈øets, be compellable in Chauncerie to make amends for tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe done by their
te≈øtator, or to pay debt due by him vpon a ≈øimple contract, Do. St. lib. 2. cap. 10.

If tenant in fee haue two ≈øonnes and die, and I. S. abate and thelder ≈øonne make his executors and dieth, and the yonger recouereth again≈øt the abator in A≈ø≈øi≈øe of Mortdaunce≈øter the lands and damages from the death of his Father, the executors of the elder brother haue no remedie for the damages accrued in his life time, as it ≈øeemeth. Do. & Stu. lib. 2. cap. 13.
Tenant in dower hath no remedie in Equitie again≈øt the alienee of her hu≈øband for damages growing betweene his death and her demauÃÑd, D. S. lib. 2. cap. 13.

Tenant for life di≈ø≈øei≈øed dieth, his di≈ø≈øei≈øor dieth, his heire entreth, again≈øt whom the owner of the reuer≈øion recouereth the landes, but no damages by law nor Equitie, D. S. lib. 2. cap. 13.

If a man ≈øei≈øed of lands knowing that an other hath good right thervnto, leuieth a fine with proclamation to extingui≈øh ≈øuch right, And maketh no claime within v. yeres, he is remedile≈ø≈øe in law and Equitie, D. S. lib. 2. cap. 14.

A man ≈øei≈øed of lands in fee hath a daughter, ≈øhe marieth and hath i≈ø≈øue, & her father dieth, the hu≈øband ≈øo ≈øoone as he knoweth of his fathers death, ha≈øteth to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the land, but before he come to it, his wife dieth, he ≈øhal not be tenant by the Curte≈øie of England, by law nor con≈øcience, becau≈øe he had not actual po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof in the life time of his wife. D. S. lib. 2. cap. 15.
If without con≈øideration a new rent be graunted without deede, or a reuer≈øion without attornement, the grauntee is remedile≈ø≈øe, Do. St. lib. 2. cap. 15.

A man ≈øei≈øed in fee of lands holden by Knights ≈øeruice, deui≈øeth the whole to A. B. the deui≈øee thereof is remedile≈ø≈øe for a third part thereof, for that there is no Maxime in law for him, D. S. li. 2. ca. 15.

If the tenant make a feoffement of the land which he holdeth by prioritie, & taketh e≈øtate thereof backe againe and dieth, the Lord of whom he held by priority is remedile≈ø≈øe, D. S. lib. 2. cap. 15.

If the grauntee of a rent charge take a feoffement from the grauntor of parcel of the lands charged to his owne v≈øe, the whole rent is extinct by the vnitie of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, becau≈øe ≈øuch rent is again≈øt common right: And the law deemeth it his owne folie to accept the feoffement, and neither his ignorance of the deede, nor of the law can helpe him. D. S. lib. 2. cap. 16. & 17. Yet Quaere in Equitie, becau≈øe the grauntor him≈øelfe is priuie to the ≈øaid feoffement. D. S. lib. 2. cap. 17.

A. graunteth a rent charge out of two acres of land vnto B. and then infeoffeth H. of the one acre in fee to his v≈øe, and after H. intending to
extingui≈øh the whole right, cau≈øeth the ≈øame acre to be recouered again≈øt him, by common recouerie in a writ of Entre ≈øur di≈ø≈øei≈øin in le Po≈øt, in the name of the ≈øaid grauntee (not knowing thereof) and of an other man, who by force thereof entreth and dieth, ≈øo that the grauntee is ≈øole ≈øei≈øed of all the ≈øame acre by ≈øuruiuor, to thu≈øe of the ≈øaid H. The whole rent is hereby extinct by law through the vnitie of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, though the v≈øe be to H. & it is al≈øo extinct in con≈øcience as to the grauntor, becau≈øe he is neither party nor priuie to that by which thextingui≈øhment groweth. But Quere whether in con≈øcience the grauntee ought to haue the whole rent of H. who cau≈øed the ≈øaid recouerie to be ≈øo had. Do. S. Lib. 2. cap. 17.

If a Villein graunted for life, purcha≈øeth lands in fee, and the grauntee entreth before the villein alieneth the ≈øame, the grauntee ≈øhall haue the land for euer as a perqui≈øite, by rea≈øon of the villein. And this both by Law 5. E. 4. 61. and by con≈øcience, D. S. lib. 2. cap. 18. Perkins Sect' 94. 95. 96. & 97.

If one haue a villein for yeres, as executor, who purcha≈øeth lands in fee, thexecutor by law and con≈øcience ≈øhal haue the ≈øame lands in fee to the behoofe of his te≈øtator, and they ≈øhall be deemed a≈ø≈øets in his hands, D. S. lib. 2. cap. 18. becau≈øe he hath them by rea≈øon of his villein.

If a Lawier ignorantly or affectionately giue wrong coun≈øel to his client, who followeth it to his trouble and lo≈ø≈øe, yet is he remedile≈ø≈øe as it ≈øeemeth, D. S. lib. 2. cap. 19. Therefore it is good to a≈øke adui≈øe of none but ≈øuch as be learned in the Lawes, and of good con≈øcience.

If a man without con≈øideration giue landes by Indenture to H. and his heires, vpon condition, that if he pay not vnto I. S. ‚Ä¢ . li. rent yerely, that then the ≈øaid I. S. may enter &c. which rent is not paid, yet the ≈øaid I. S. may neither enter by law nor con≈øcience, becau≈øe he is neither party nor priuie to the ≈øaid condition, notwith≈øtanding the intent of the giuer, for ≈øuch intent being not grounded vpon the law is void. D. S. lib. 2. cap. 20. Plo. 25. B. But the feoffor as it ≈øeemeth may lawfully reenter, becau≈øe the words of the Indenture implie a condition in law to that effect, D. S. lib. 2. cap. 23.

If a man without con≈øideration confirme the≈øtate of his le≈ø≈øee for life, the remainder to another in fee, this remainder is void in law and equitie, becau≈øe a Remainder cannot commence, but at the ≈øame in≈øtant that the particuler e≈øtate, whereupon it dependeth began D. S. lib. 2. cap. 20. Plow. 25. b. yet the feoffor and his heires in this ca≈øe may enter for the breach of the ≈øaid condition.

If by a feoffement indented it be agreed that the feoffee ≈øhall yerely pay to A. B. and his heires a certein rent, and that if he pay it not, that A. B. and his heire may enter &c. albeit the feoffee pay not the money, yet
may neither the ≈øaid A. B. nor the feffor enter, for that there is no clau≈øe of reentre in the ≈øaid deede. Howbeit it ≈øeemeth he may haue remedy in Chancerie for the ≈øaid yerely payment. D. S. h. 2. ca. 21.

If A. promi≈øe to giue vnto B. a ≈øumme of money, or other thing of meere motion without any con≈øideration, the partie is not bound to performe this promi≈øe either by law or in ChauÃÑcerie, becau≈øe it is Nudum pactum, D. S. lib. 2. cap. 24.

If A. promi≈øe to giue B. x. s. in con≈øideration of a tre≈øpas by him done vnto B. yet A. is not thereby bound in law nor con≈øcience, becau≈øe this is an accord, for which none action lieth. And notwith≈øtanding this accord, B. may haue his action for the ≈øaid tre≈øpas, becau≈øe the concord is executorie, D. S. lib. 2. 24.

If a man haue one ≈øonne before mariage, and an other after, and bequeathed all his goods to his ≈øonne and heire, it ≈øeemeth both in law and con≈øcience, that the ≈øonne borne after mariage ≈øhall haue the goods, for he is heire by the common Lawes of the Realme, of which the Spiritual Iudges are bound to take notice, and to giue ≈øentence accordingly of temporal things: Notwith≈øtanding that by the common Lawes the other≈øonne is legitimate and the te≈øtators heire, for the auoiding of the inconuenience which might happen by the contrary iudgements in ≈øeuerall Courts. In like maner temporall Iudges ≈øeeme bound in con≈øcience to take notice of the common Law, when they are to Iudge ≈øpirituall things, and to order their Iudgements according to the ≈øame, D. S. lib. 2. ca. 25.

Iointenants and tenants in common of an Aduow≈øon, mu≈øt within vi. Monethes after auoidance agree and ioine in pre≈øentment of their Cierke. And the elde≈øt ≈øi≈øter of Coparceners mu≈øt pre≈øent fir≈øt, and then the ≈øecond, by turne, or by ≈øuch compo≈øition as they make thereof, except the yonge≈øt coparcener be the kings ward, in which ca≈øe the pre≈øentmeÃÑt belongeth to the king. And if they keepe not this cour≈øe of pre≈øentment within the ≈øixe Monethes, they loo≈øe their pre≈øentment for that time. And the Ordinary may pre≈øent by Laps both in law and con≈øcience, D. S. lib. 2. cap. 33.

And if the auoidance be by death, ce≈ø≈øion, or creation, the 6. Monethes commenc ‚Ä¢ at the death, creation, or ce≈ø≈øion, & the patron is bound to take notice thereof. And if by re≈øignation or depriuation, then from notice thereof giuen by the Ordinary to the Patron. If by vnion, from the agreement how they ≈øhall pre≈øent, D. S. lib. 2. cap. 31.

The wife ≈øuruiuing her hu≈øband which tooke a lea≈øe for yeres, or life, in both their names, may lawfully and with good con≈øcience waiue and relinqui≈øh it: So may an Executor refu≈øe a terme made to his te≈øtator, if he haue not a≈ø≈øets, Do. St. lib. 2. 33.

If A. infeoffe an Abbot by deede indented vpon condition, and the Abbot onely performeth not the condition, the feoffor both in law and con≈øcience may reenter and haue his land againe as in his former right. D. S. lib. 2. 34.

div.head: Warrantie collaterall.
div.p: A Man ≈øei≈øed of lands in fee hath i≈ø≈øue two ≈øonnes, the elder brother goeth beyon ‚Ä¢ the Sea & remaineth there vntil it be commonly reported that he is dead, the father dieth, the yonger brother entreth into his lands as his heire, and alieneth with warrantie, and dieth without i≈ø≈øue of his body, leauing no land to di≈øcend to his next heire, and afterwards the elder brother returneth and claimeth the landes in his owne right, yet is he barred by Law and con≈øcience, for that it is the act of his aunce≈øter who≈øe heire he is, by whom as he might haue had aduantage to haue had his lands by di≈øcent, from his as his heire, if he had had any, ≈øo it ≈øeemeth rea≈øonable, that for the priuitie of bloud he ≈øu≈øtaine di≈øaduantage by him, becau≈øe both the ≈øeller and the buyer were ignorant of the elder brothers life and right, by rea≈øon of his owne ab≈øence. D. S. lib. 2. cap. 49. LittÃÑ ≈øectÃÑ 704. 705. 707. But if ≈øuch heire were vouched by force of ≈øuch warranty, he might enter into the warrantie, as one that hath nothing by di≈øcent from that aunce≈øter, and ≈øo auoid the warranty.

div.head: Debtagainst one as heire.
div.p: If the father bind him and his heires for the payment of a debt, & die, leauing a≈ø≈øets by di≈øcent to his ≈øonne & heire, he is bound to pay the debt by law and con≈øcience, becau≈øe he hath ≈øuch benefit by him, Do. St. lib. 2. cap. 49. 26. H. 8. fo. I. 40. E. 3. f. 38. 12. E. 3. f. 9. 13. E. 3. fo.

It is agreable both with law and con≈øcience, that a man outlawed either in felouie or in actions per≈øonals, ≈øhall forfait & loo≈øe all his goods, becau≈øe it is ≈øo ordeined for the nece≈ø≈øitie of the admmi≈øtratioÃÑ of Iu≈øtice, D. S. lib. 2. ca. 49. 43. E. 3. fo. 18. 21. A≈ø≈ø. 21. 39. H. 6. fo. 26. 21. H. 7. f. 7. 49. E. 3. f. 5. 16. E. 4. fo. 6.
The like is of forfaiture of goods attached by default of apparance, a≈øwel in Court Baron as in Courts of Record, 28. H. 6. fo. 34. H. 6. fo. 29. and 40. 21. E. 4. fo. 78.

A man is di≈ø≈øei≈øed of landes, the di≈ø≈øei≈øor ≈øelleth the land, the alienee knowing of the di≈ø≈øei≈øin, obtaineth a relea≈øe with warrantie from a collateral aunce≈øter of the di≈ø≈øei≈øee, who al≈øo knoweth that the di≈ø≈øei≈øee hath good right and title to haue the ≈øame landes, that collaterall aunce≈øter dieth, the warrantie di≈øcendeth vpon the di≈ø≈øei≈øee as his heire without a≈ø≈øets, yet the di≈ø≈øei≈øee is barred by law and con≈øcience, for it were inconuenieÃÑt that ≈øuch relea≈øes & other writings ≈øhould be auoided by ≈øuch allegations of con≈øcience. D. S. lib. 2. ca. 50. L ‚Ä¢ tÃÑ ≈øect' 707.

If a feme couert being of full age leuie a fine by her hu≈øbandes compul≈øion, yet after his death ≈øhe ≈øhall neuer for that cau≈øe by law nor con≈øcience, be admitted to auoid ≈øuch fine, for the incoÃÑuenience which might thereof en≈øue, if by ≈øuch nude auerments, matters of record ≈øhould be auoided. D. S. lib. 2. cap. 50. 7. H. 4. fo. 23.

If goods be wrecked vpon the Sea, that is, where goods be ca≈øt or come into the Sea by ≈øhip wracke, ≈øo that no man, dogg, or catt, come aliue to the land out of the ≈øhip or barge wherein they were caried (which is deemed a Wrecke, We≈øt. 1. cap. 4.) and the owner thereof prooueth them not to be his within a yere & a day after ≈øuch wrecke, then the Q. ought to haue them both in law & con≈øcience, becau≈øe ≈øhe is ≈øoueraigne head of the people, and owner of the narrow Seas, and is to ≈øcower theÃÑ (as it ≈øeemeth) from pyrats, & becau≈øe the property of goods mu≈øt needs be in ≈øome per≈øon, otherwi≈øe they would peri≈øh, which were again≈øt the weale publique, & in this ca≈øe the fir≈øt owner of the goods is vnknowen. And the like is it, of an E≈øtray, or Deodand: But not of goods voluntarily weyued, or ca≈øually lo≈øt and found by others, for in the≈øe two la≈øt ca≈øes, the propertie remaineth ≈øtill in the fir≈øt owners, D. S. lib. 2. cap. 51. 35. H. 6. fol. 27.
The like ≈øeemeth to be where a ≈øubiect hath wreckes by pre≈øcription, 11. H. 4. fo. 16.

div.head: Of a Commi≈øsion to examine witne≈ø≈øes in perpetual memory.
div.p: FIr≈øt the plaintife mu≈øt exhibite his bill, and thereby ≈øhew his title to Sect' 48. the land, lea≈øe, or ≈øuch like matter that he hath right vnto. And that the witne≈ø≈øes which can prooue his title are aged, and not like long to liue, whereby he may be in daunger of the lo≈ø≈øe of the thing in que≈øtion. And al≈øo to pray proces of Subpena again≈øt him, her, or them, to ≈øhew cau≈øe, if he or they can, why the plaintife ≈øhould not examine his witne≈ø≈øes, as afore≈øaid, The forme of which Proce≈ø≈øe en≈øueth, in haec verba.

div.p: Concerning the matters of the≈øe Chauncerie, Note what en≈øueth.

And if the partie defendant doe appeare, either by him≈øelfe, or his Coun≈øaile, and ≈øhew ≈øuch ≈øufficient cau≈øe, as the Court will allow off, why the plaintife ≈øhould not examine his witne≈ø≈øes, as is afore≈øaid, then the plaintife may not proceed therein, vnle≈ø≈øe he can better ‚Ä¢ ati≈øfie the Court to the contrary. But if the defendant be contented, and wil ioine with the plaintife in examination, then after examination ≈øo had, there can be no publication thereof ‚Ä¢ uring the liues of the witne≈ø≈øes: vnle≈ø≈øe the defendant do a≈ø≈øent, or vnle≈ø≈øe the plaintife, or ≈øome other in his behalfe do make oath, that the matter whereupon the witne≈ø≈øes were examined, is to take triall at the common Law, either at the A≈ø≈øi≈øes, or at the Barre. And that A. B. or more of the witne≈ø≈øes before examined, are nece≈ø≈øarie witne≈ø≈øes, and not able to trauaile to the ≈øaid trial: And vpon ≈øuch oath taken, his, or their depo≈øitions t ‚Ä¢ be publi≈øhed of cour≈øe. And to be exemplified if the partie ≈øo require.

But if the partie defendant do not appeare vpon the ≈øaid writ, neither
by him≈øelfe, nor his Atturney, by the end of the ≈øaid fourteene daies, nor ≈øhew no cau≈øe of ≈øtay thereof, whether it be in Terme or out of Terme time, then vpon oath made of the ≈øeruing of the ≈øame writ, the Lorde Chauncelor, Lord Keeper, or Mai≈øter of the Rolles for the time being, at the reque≈øt of the plaintife, will appoint Commi≈ø≈øioners for the examination of the plaintifes witne≈ø≈øes, according to certaine orders pre≈øcribed in that behalfe.

div.p:

C. nuper exhibuit, quodque eidem R. per breue no≈øtrÃÑ praeceperimus, quod e≈ø≈øet coram nobis in dicta CancellarÃÑ no≈øtrÃÑ ad certum diemiam praeteritum ≈øub certa pena in dict' breui no≈øtro contenta petition praed' re≈øpon≈øurÃÑ: Sciatis quod a≈ø≈øignauimus vos, ac tenore pre≈øentium damus vobis vel vni ve≈øtrum pote≈øtatem & aucthoritatem re≈øpon≈øionÃÑ prefati
R. ad petitionem praedict' recipiend', & in ≈øcriptis redigend', & quo≈øcunque te≈øtes, de, & ≈øuper materia in petitione & re≈øpon≈øionÃÑ praedictÃÑ contentÃÑ, examinand', ac eandem materiam iuxta ≈øanas di≈øcretiones ve≈øtras vel vnius ve≈øtrum audiend', & finaliter determinand'. Et ideo vobis maÃÑdamus, quod vi≈øo tenore petitionis praed', quam vobis mittimus pre≈øentibus interclu≈øam, prefatÃÑ R. coram vobis, vel vno ve≈øtrum venire faciatis, ac re≈øpon≈ø. ≈øuam petitionÃÑ praedict' informa praedictÃÑ, fiendam ≈øuper ≈øacramentum ≈øuum recipiatis, & in ≈øcriptis redigatis, nec ‚Ä¢ onte≈øtes praedictÃÑ, coram vobis vel vno ve≈øtruni ad certos dies & loca, quos ad hoc prouideritis coram vobis venire faciatis, & euocetis, ac ip≈øos, & eorum quemlibet, de & ≈øuper veritate petitionis, & re≈øpon≈øionÃÑ praed', ac de & ≈øuper articulis omnibus & ≈øingulis premi≈ø≈øa qualitercun
que concernenÃÑ ≈øuper eorum ≈øacramÃÑ corporaliter pre≈øtand', diligenter examinetÃÑ, examinatione≈ø
que ≈øuas recipÃÑ, & in ≈øcriptÃÑ redig'. Et cum eas ≈øic ceperitis candem materiam partibus ad id vocatÃÑ, vi≈øi≈øque eorum ≈øcriptis & auditis hinc inde earum rationibus, & allegationibus, omnibus vijs, modis & med ‚Ä¢ js quibus melius ≈øciueritis, aut poteritis, vel vnus ve≈øtrum ≈øciuerÃÑ, aut poterÃÑ, iuxta ≈øanas di≈øcretiones ve≈øtras vel vnius ve≈øtrÃÑ finaliter determinetis, vel vnus ve≈øtrum determinet: Sin autem nos de omni eo quod inde feceritis vel vnus ve≈øtrum fecerit, in CancellarÃÑ no≈øtra ≈øub ≈øigillis ve≈øtris, vel vnius ve≈øtrum in Quindena Sancti Mich. prox' futurÃÑ, vbicunque tunc fuerit, di≈øtincte & aperte reddat certiores, hoc breue, vna cum petitione re≈øpon≈øione & te≈øtium examinationibus pred' nobis remittentes.

div.p:
Quia de & ≈øuper veritate quaerimoniaeSect‚ñ™ 58. in quadam petitione coram nobis in Cancellaria no≈øtra per T. C. ver≈øus I. R. & alios nuper exhibita contentÃÑ, ac de & ≈øuper veritate in quadam re≈øpon≈øione per partes predictas in hac parte facta, & in eadem Cancellaria ≈øimiliter exhibitÃÑ, necnoÃÑ de & ≈øuper omnibus articulis & circum≈øtantijs queremoniam & re≈øpon≈øionem illas concernentÃÑ, vt tutius & confultius pro iu≈øticia in ei≈ødem exhibend' procedere valeamus vobis de quorum fidelitatibus, & prouidis circum≈øpectionibus plene confidimus: Dedimus vobis, vel duobus ve≈øtrum pote≈øtatem & aucthoritatem audiendi & examinandi materiam in petitione, ac re≈øpon≈øione, ac in omnibus articulis & circum≈øtantijs praedictis querimoniaÃÑ, & re≈øpon≈øionem illas concernenÃÑ hijs pre≈øentibus annex' contentam, & ≈øpecificatÃÑ, et eandem materiam iuxta ≈øanas di≈øcretiones ve≈øtras finaliter ≈øi poteritis determinand'. Et ideo vobis, vel duobus ve≈øtrum mandamus, quod ad certos dies & loca, quos ad hoc prouideritis, te≈øtes quo≈øcuÃÑque inter partes
praed', quos maxime prote≈øtificatione veritatis premi≈ø≈øorum fore videritis euocandos, coram vobis vel duobus ve≈øtrum euocetis, Ac ip≈øos te≈øtes et eorum quemlibet de & ≈øuper querimonia, re≈øpon≈øione articulis et circum≈øtantijs praed' ≈øuÍùë ≈øacrameÃÑta ≈øua diligenter iuretis, & examinetis. Et ≈øuper hoc auditis hincinde earum rationibus, et allegationibus, ac alijs vijs ac modis, quibus melius ≈øciueritis aut poteritis eandem materiam vt praed' e≈øt finaliter ≈øi poteritis determinetis. Sin auteÃÑ nos in Cancellaria no≈øtra de omni eo quod inde feceritis in quindena ≈øancti Hillarij prox' futurÃÑ, vbicunque tuncfuerit, ≈øub ≈øigillis ve≈øtris, vel duorum ve≈øtruÃÑ di≈øtincte & aperte eddatis certiores, remittentes nobistuÃÑc tenores praedictos, vna cum hoc breue.

div.head: Comm≈ø≈øio ad examinadum Testes adlocum & diem certum, de valore bonorum & catallorum.

div.p:
Sciatis quod nos de fidelitatibis & prouidis circum≈øpectionibus ve≈øtris plurimum confidentes, a≈ø≈øignauimus vos, ac tenore prae≈øentiuÃÑ, damus vobis, vel duobus ve≈øtrum plenam pote≈øtatem & aucthoritatem inquirendi, tam per depo≈øitiones quorumcunque te≈øtium, coram vobis producend', & examinand', quam alio quocunque modo ad libitum ve≈øtrum, quae bona et catalla fuerunt. I. M. genero≈øi, ≈øiue alterius cuiu≈øcun que remanentÃÑ infra domum man≈øionalem, ≈øiue fitmam de C. in E. in comitatu OxonÃÑ quo tempore Ro. Bi. po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øionem eiu≈ødem domus ≈øiue firmae natus ≈øit, et cuius valoris ≈øiue precij eadeÃÑ bona et catalla ≈øic infra eandem domuÃÑ, et firmam praed' exi≈øtentia ad tunc fuerunt, et extiterunt. Damus etiam vobis, vel duobus ve≈øtrum pote≈øtateÃÑ & auchoritatem te≈øtes quo≈ødam quorum ≈øeperalia nomina in quibu≈ødam Interrogatorijs prae≈øentibus interclu≈ø. ac ei≈ødem te≈øtibus ≈øeperaliter proponend', in≈øerta apparebunt de et ≈øuper ei≈ødem InterrogatÃÑ diligenter examinand'. Et ideo vobis mandamus, quod ad certos dies et loca, quos adhoc prouideritis, te≈øtes praedictos ac alios quo≈øcuÃÑque quos maxime pro te≈øtificatione veritatis fore videritis nece≈ø≈øarios et opportunos coram vobisvel duobus ve≈øtrum venire faciatis, et euocetis, ac ip≈øos te≈øtes, et eoruÃÑ quemlibet tunc et ibidem, tam de et ≈øuper pleno et iu≈øto valore omnium et ≈øingulorum bonorum, et catallorum praedictorum quam et ≈øuper Interrogatorijs praedictis, ≈øuper ≈øacramenta ≈øua per ≈øancta Dei Euangel ‚Ä¢ a coram vobis, vel duobus ve≈øtrum corporaliter prae≈øtanduÃÑ diligenter examinetis: Examinatione≈øque ≈øuas recipiatis, et in ≈øcriptis in pergameno redigatis. Et cum ‚Ä¢ as ≈øic ceperitis nos inde, ac de omni eo quicquid pro meliore cognitione praemi≈ø≈øorum feceritis, vel duo ve≈øtrum fecerint in Cancellaria no≈øtra in Octabis Sancti Mich, proxmÃÑ futurÃÑ, vbicunque tunc fuerit, ≈øub ≈øigillis ve≈øtris, vel duorum ve≈øtrum cla ‚Ä¢ ≈ø.
di≈øtincte, & aperte, reddatis certiores, remittentes nobis Interrogatoria praedict', vna cum hoc breue.

div.p: Sciatis quod nos de fidelitatibus, & prouidis circum≈øpectionibus ve≈øtrÃÑ plenius confidentes a≈ø≈øignauimus vos, ac tenore pre≈øentium damus vobis plenam pote≈øtatem & aucthoritatem audiendi & examinand' quandam materiam in quibu≈ødam articulis his praefatibus annex' contentam, & ≈øpecificatÃÑ, & eandem materiam iuxta ≈øanas di≈øcretionÃÑ ve≈øtrÃÑ finaliter ≈øi poteritis determinand'. Et ideo vobis mandamus, quod ad certos dies & loca, quos ad hoc prouideritis ad quoddam va≈øtum vocatÃÑ Blackdowne ≈øuper M. in comÃÑ S. in articulis praedict' ≈øpecificatÃÑ, per≈øonaliter accedatis, va≈øtum que illud ≈øuperuideatis, ac tam per depo≈øitiones te≈øtium quam alijs vijs, modis, & medijs quibus melius ≈øciueritis aut poteritis diligenter inquiratÃÑ quantum inde ad manerium de H. & quantum inde ad manerium de W. in ComitÃÑ praedict', pertinere debeat, & ≈øuperinde, limites, bundas, metas & diui≈øas, inter vnum & alterum, & quantum ad vnum, & quantum ad alium maneriorum praedictorum pertinere vobis con≈øtare poterit, poni faciatÃÑ & limites examinatione≈øque te≈øtium predictorum recipiatis, & in ≈øcriptis redigatis, omne≈øque alias depo≈øitiones te≈øtium ante hac examinatÃÑ minumenta, ≈øcripta, recorda, tran≈øcripta, territoria, chartas, ac alias euidentias qua≈øcunque per partes in articulis praedict' ≈øpecificatÃÑ, coram vobis exhibend' acceptetis & in≈øpiciatis. Et ≈øuper hoc, materiam in articulis praedictis ≈øpecificatÃÑ iuxta ≈øanas di≈øcretiones ve≈øtras finaliter ≈øi poteritis determinetÃÑ: Sin autem nos in CancellarÃÑ no≈øtra de omni eo quod inde feceritis in quindena Sancti Michaelis prox' futurÃÑ vbicunque tuncfuerit ≈øub ≈øigillis ve≈øtris di≈øtincte & aperte reddatis certiores, remittentes nobis articulos praedictos vna cum prae≈øentibus.

P. knight, chiefe Iu≈øtice of the Pleas there, I. B. E≈øq: chiefe Barou of our E≈øchequer there, F. A. E≈øquire, one of our priuie Coun≈øell there, I. D. E≈øquire, ≈øecond Iu≈øtice of our chiefe Bench there, R. F. E≈øquire our Serieant at the Law there, and L. D. E≈øquire our Solicitor there.

body.p:
Know ye, that for certeine con≈øiderations vs thereunto mouing, and of
our meere motion, and for the great confidence and tru≈øt we haue in your fidelities, circum≈øpections, prouidences and wi≈øedomes, we haue deputed, ordeined, aucthorized, appointed, con≈øtituted, giuen & graunted, and by the≈øe pre≈øents do depute, ordeine, aucthorize, con≈øtitute, appoint, giue, and graunt vnto you, or any viii. vii. vi. v. iiii. or iii. of you, (of which we will that &c. be alwaies one) full power, iuri≈ødiction, and aucthoritie, to hold plea, heare, determine, di≈øcu≈ø≈øe, decree, and finally to iudge of all and ≈øinguler actions, debates, ≈øtrifes, quarrels, rights, titles, and demaunds what≈øoeuer they be, a≈øwell reall as per≈øonall, which by plaint, ≈øupplication, or bill to be exhibited, or otherwi≈øe by any maner of meanes el≈øe, ≈øhall, or may appeare, or come before you, or any viii. vii. vi. v. iiii. or iii. of you, (of which we will that &c. be alwaies one) of, for, and concerning the intere≈øt, right, title, demaund, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of two parts or moities, of all tho≈øe landes &c. with the appurtenances in the Countie of D. within the ≈øaid Realme of Ireland to be by O. D. late of &c. I. D. widow, F. D. M. D. D. D. gentl', and ≈øonnes to R. D. late decea≈øed, and R. D. Nephew to the ≈øaid F. M. and D. or by any of them ≈øeuerally, or iointly, or any two, iii. iiii. v. or vi. of them again≈øt C. S. alias H. Lord of H. within our ≈øaid Realme of Ireland, and all and euery other per≈øon or per≈øons, which ≈øhall claime from, by, or in the right of the ≈øaid Lord, or in his, or their owne right or rights, or by any meanes el≈øe what≈øoeuer it be, which he or they claime to haue to the ≈øaid moities of the two parts of the ≈øaid lands &c. with the appurtenances afore≈øaid: geuing and graunting, and by the≈øe our Letters patents, we do giue and graunt vnto you, or to any viii. vii. vi. v. iiii. or iii. of you, (of which number we will that &c. be alwaies one) full power, iuri≈ødiction, and aucthoritie, to call before you, or any viii. vii. vi. v. iiii. or iii. of you, (of which we will that &c. be alwaies one) at ≈øuch times and places according to your good di≈øcretions, which vnto you, or any viii. vii. vi. v. iiii. or iii. of you, (of which we will &c. be alwaies one) and to cau≈øe the ≈øaid Lord H. or any which claimeth in his or their owne right or rights, or by any waies or meanes els what≈øoeuer, any intere≈øt, right, title, or po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion in the two parts or moities of the ≈øaid lands &c. with their appurtenances afore≈øayd, or any parcell thereof, to an≈øwere, reioine, and ioine i≈ø≈øue, or otherwi≈øe pleade, as the cau≈øe & matter ≈øhall require, and vpon any plaint, ≈øupplication, action, or ≈øuit what≈øoeuer, which ≈øhall be exhibited or come before you, by the afore≈øaid D. D. P. P. I. D. F. D. M. D. and R. or by any of theÃÑ iointly or ≈øeuerally, or any ii. iii. iiii. v. or vi. of them, of, and concerning the ≈øaid two parts or moities of the ≈øayd lands &c. with their appurtenances afore≈øaid: Giuing and graunting, and by the≈øe pre≈øents, we do giue and grant vnto you, or any viii. vii. vi. v. iiii. or iii. of you, (of which we
will that &c. be alwaies one) full power, iuri≈ødiction, and aucthoritie, according to your wi≈øedomes, di≈øcretions, and prouidences, to call before you, all maner of witne≈ø≈øes, and to examine all charters, euidences, muniments, writings, & euery other thing els, which may be a meane to proue, fortifie, di≈øclo≈øe, or make euident the intere≈øt, right, titles, demand, or po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of any of the aforenamed parties, to the ≈øaid two parts or moities of the ≈øaid lands &c. with their appurtenances afore≈øaid, and vpon the ≈øame throughly, and with mature deliberation and iudgement con≈øidered and waighed, we do giue and grant vnto you, or any viii. vii. vi. v. iiii. or iii. of you, (of which number we will that &c. be alwaies one) full power, iuri≈ødiction, and aucthoritie to proceede to the full order, decree, definition, ≈øentence and finall iudgement, according to your di≈øcretions, of the intere≈øt, right, title, demand, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid two parts or moities of the ≈øaid lands &c. with their appurtenances afore≈øaid, and to decree the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the premi≈ø≈øes to him or them, to whom of right it ought to appertain, and his or their ≈øaid po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions to maintaine: And if any of the parties afore named, or any other per≈øon or per≈øons which ≈øhall haue to do in the ≈øame matter or cau≈øe, do wilfully, or ob≈øtinately with≈øtand or di≈øobey any proce≈ø≈øe, order, decree, ≈øentence, or iudgement which ≈øhall he directed or giuen in the premi≈ø≈øes by you, or any viii. vii. vi. v. iiii. or iii. of you, (of which number we will that &c. vt ≈øupra, be alwaies one:) Then we will and commaund you, and by vertue of the≈øe our Letters patents giue full power, warrant, and aucthoritie vnto you, or to any viii. vii. vi. v. iiii. or iii. of you, (of which number we will that you &c. be alwaies one) to commit him or them to pri≈øon, there to remaine till his, her, or their conformities ≈øhall be therein had, willing & commaunding you, or any viii. vii. vi. v. iiii. or iii. of you (of which we will &c. be alwaies one) that at ≈øuch times & places, as to your di≈øcretions, or to the di≈øcretion of any viii. vii. vi. v. iiii. or iii. of you (of which number &c. be alwaies one) ≈øhall ≈øeeme fit and conuenient, diligently to attend, applie, and with ≈øpeede put in execution the effect of this our Commi≈ø≈øion, ≈øo as the complainants before named, or any of them which ≈øhall haue to do therein, may not haue iu≈øt cau≈øe to make further complaint for delay or want of Iu≈øtice, willing and commaunding you, or any viii. vii. vi. v. iiii. or iii. of you, (of which we will &c. be one) to admit no dilatorie exception to any ≈øupplication or ≈øupplications, bill or bils of complaint exhibited, or to be exhibited before you, or any viii. vii. vi. v. iiii. or iii. of you, (of which number we will that &c. he alwaies one) or otherwi≈øe to the ouerthrowing of this our Commi≈ø≈øion: But according to our meaning herein to proceed, and to go to the full hearing, ordering, decreeing, iudging, and determining of the right, title, and demaund of the
parties afore≈øaid, of, for, and concerning the premi≈ø≈øes, and euery part and parcell thereof, and accordingly to decree, and iudge, as to equitie and right ≈øhall appertaine: any act, ≈øtatute, law, proui≈øion, or ordinance to the contrarie thereof notwith≈øtanding. And therefore fayle you not, as you tender our fauor: for if our ≈øayd Subiects O. D. P. P. I. F. M. D. and R. D. ≈øhould be put from ≈øuch triall of their right to the premi≈ø≈øes, as by this our Commi≈ø≈øion we haue prouided for them. Their di≈øabilitie and want of riches, wealth, friend≈øhip, and alyance con≈øidered, and of the other part, the ≈øaid Lord of H. their aduer≈øarie being throughly furni≈øhed of all tho≈øe things, and withall being a Lord by byrth, and of great calling and aucthoritie, and inhabiting within the ≈øaid Countie, where the ≈øaid lands &c. do lye, our ≈øaid ≈øubiect ≈øhould be in perill and danger to be without remedie at our common Lawes there, which were no ≈ømall mi≈øchiefe to them. The premi≈ø≈øes con≈øidered, we haue graunted this our Commi≈ø≈øion according to the tenor afore≈øaid. And further we will and commaund you, and by vertue hereof giue full power and aucthoritie vnto you, or any viii. vii. vi. v. iiii. or iii. of you (of which we will that &c. be one) that after the right, intere≈øt, title, and demaund decreed, adiudged, and determined, as is afore≈øaid: that you haue con≈øideration vnto the hinderance, lo≈ø≈øes, and damages which the Complaynants, or any of them, as is afore≈øaid, haue had, and ≈øu≈øteyned, by rea≈øon of the wrongfull deteyning of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the premi≈ø≈øes, and the ≈øaid damages by you, as is afore≈øaid, taxed, and extracted, thereof to cau≈øe a full execution and ≈øati≈øfaction to be had and made vnto the ≈øaid complainants, and euery of them, as is afore≈øaid. And for the better putting in execution of this our Commi≈ø≈øion, we will and commaund the Shirife of that our ≈øaid County of D. and all other our Officers for the time being, to whom in this ca≈øe it ≈øhall apperteine, that they and euery of them be attendant vpon you, or any viii. vii. vi. v. iiii. or iii. of you, (of which we will that &c. be one) for thexecuting, fulfilling, and doing of all, and euery act & acts, thing or things, as ≈øhall be by you, or any viii. vii. vi. v. iiii. or iii. of you, (of which be alwaies one) commaunded, limited, or appointed. In witne≈ø≈øe whereof &c.

div.p: Hauing hitherto in ≈øome ≈øort ≈øhewed the writs of Commi≈øsions and cour≈øe of proceeding in Chancerie ≈øuits: It ≈øeemeth needefull now to expre≈ø≈øe what Bills of complaint, An≈øweres, Replications, Reioinders, and Surreioinders be, with diuers formes thereof, according to the cau≈øes of ≈øuit.

div.head: ¬∂ What a Bill of Complaint is.
div.p:
A Bill of Complaint is a declaration in writing, ≈øhewing theSect. 62. plaintifes griefe, and the wrong which he ≈øuppo≈øeth to be done
vnto him by the defendant, and what damages he „Äà‚óä„Äâ by „Äà‚óä„Äâ
≈øion thereof, praying proce≈ø≈øe again≈øt him for ‚Ä¢ edre≈ø≈øe of the ≈øame, as may appeare by many examples hereafter following, whereupon Ho≈øtien≈øis hath the≈øe ver≈øes.

q.l: Quis quid coram quo‚ñ™ quo iure petatur & a quo,

div.p: And fir≈øt the matter of euery bill ought to be true. Secondarily, the ≈øame matter ought to be layd downe therein plainely and certeinly in euery circum≈øtance of the thing, per≈øon, time, place, maner of doing, & other accidents. And thirdly, the ≈øame ought to be ≈øufficient in Law, both for the forme thereof, and for the matter, that it be ≈øuch as is examinable in this Court, which being otherwi≈øe may be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed thence.
THe direction of all Bills in the Chancerie mu≈øt be at the toppe Sect' 63. thereof. And when there is neither Lord Chancelor, nor Lord Keeper, it is thus:
div.q: To the Queenes mo≈øt excellent Maie≈øtie, in her highne≈ø≈øe Court of Chancerie.

p.hi: In mo≈øt humble maner complayning, ≈øheweth vnto your mo≈øt excellent Maie≈øtie your mo≈øt humble and obedient ≈øubiect H. C. &c.

div.p: And when there is a Lord Keeper, as at this time, thus:
div.q: To the Right honorable Sir Iohn Puckering Knight, Lord Keeper of the great Seale of England.
div.p: And when there is a Lord Chancelor, then thus:
div.q: To the Right honorable Sir C. H. knight, Lord Chancelor of England.
div.p: Their other titles of honor may be al≈øo added in the ≈øaid direction, but they are not much nece≈ø≈øarie.

div.head: What an Aun≈øwere is.
div.p: AN aun≈øwere is that which the defendant pleadeth or ≈øayth in Sect' 64. barre to auoid the plaintifes bill, or action, either by confe≈ø≈øion and auoiding, or by denying and trauer≈øing the material parts thereof. And the title of ≈øuch aun≈øwere is thus:
div.q: The Aun≈øwere of A. B. defendant to the Bill of complaint of C. D. complainant.
div.p: But if there be many defendants, then thus:
div.q: The ioint and ≈øeuerall aun≈øweres of A. B. and C. D. defendants, to the bill of complaint of E. F. complainant.
div.p: An aun≈øwere is called in Latin Exceptio, quae dicta e≈øt qua≈øi quaedam exclu≈øio quae interponi actioni cuiu≈øcunque rei ≈øolet, ad excludendum id quod in intentionem condemnationem iure deductum e≈øt. Vlpianus.

div.head: What a Replication is.
div.p: A Replication is the plaintifes ≈øpeech or an≈øwere to the defendants Sect. 65. an≈øwere, which mu≈øt affirme and pur≈øue his bill, and confe≈ø≈øe and auoide, denie or trauer≈øe the defendants aun≈øwere. And note, that the plaintife ought to replie the next Terme after that the defendant hath aun≈øwered, el≈øe may he giue him day to replie: By which day if he do not replie, the defendant may procure a di≈ømi≈ø≈øion and get co≈øtes.

p.hi: Et dicta videtur Replicatio quod vel implicatam & qua≈øi tectam exceptionis iniquitatem replicet & patefaciat: vel potius quod equitatem actionisab excipiente rei tectam & qua≈øi complicatam explicet atque aperiat. Hottamanus.

div.p: And a title of a Replication is thus: The Replication of W. P. Complainant, to the an≈øwere of R. C. defendant.

div.head: What a Reioinder is.
div.p: A Reioinder is than≈øwere which the defendant maketh to the plaintifes Sect. 66. replication, which mu≈øt pur≈øue and confirme his aun≈øwere, and not ≈øwarue from the ≈øame, and ≈øufficiently confe≈ø≈øe and auoide, denie or trauer≈øe, each materiall part of the plaintifes replication, E≈øt autem reiunctio ≈øeu duplicatio vel allegatio quae datur reo ad infirmandum replicationem actoris & confirmandum exceptionem rei. Spieg.

If the parties be not at i≈ø≈øue, by rea≈øon of ≈øome new matter di≈øclo≈øed in the defendants reioinder, that requireth aun≈øwere: Then may the plaintife Surreioine to the ≈øaid reioinder, and the defendant in like maner to the Surreioinder, if there be cau≈øe, which happeneth verie ≈øeldome.
And the title of a Reioinder is thus: The reioinder of C. A. defendant, to the Replication of E. W complainant.

div.head: What a Surreioinder is.
div.p: A Surreioinder is a ≈øecond defence of the plaintifes action, oppo≈øite Sect' 67. to the defendants reioinder. And therefore Hottamanus calleth it, Triplicatio, quae e≈øt ≈øecunda actionis defen≈øio contra rei duplicationem oppo≈øita.
And thus is the title of a Surreioinder: The Surreioinder of E. W. complainant to the Reioinder of C. A. defendant.

div.head: A Bill of complaint for entring into and making ≈øecret e≈øtates of Copyhold lands, wa≈øting part therof, & mingling part therof with the lands of others to di≈øinherite the Plaintife by hauing the Copies therof.
div.p:
HVmbly complayning ≈øheweth vnto your Honorable L. H. E. of Sect', 68. B. in the Countie of Yorke E≈øqu. That whereas H. E. late of
S. E≈øquier decea≈øed, father to your Orator, was in his life time by good and lawfull conueyance and a≈ø≈øurance in the law, lawfully ≈øei≈øed to him and to his heires in fee ≈øimple, according to the Cu≈øtome of the manor of W. in the ≈øaid Countie of Y. of one Copyhold or Cu≈øtomarie me≈øuage or tenement, and of certaine Cu≈øtomarie lands, meadowes, and pa≈øture, to the quantitie of one hundred acres or thereabouts. And the ≈øaid H. E. your Orators father ≈øo being thereof ≈øei≈øed as afore≈øaid, and being vi≈øited with ≈øicknes during the minoritie of your ≈øaid Orator, by good and lawfull conueyance and a≈ø≈øurance in the law, and according to the cu≈øtome of the ≈øaid manor of W. did conuey, a≈ø≈øure, and ≈øurrender the ≈øaid Copyhold or cu≈øtomarie me≈øuage or tenements, and other the premi≈ø≈øes with the appurtenances into the hands of A. B. the Lord of the ≈øaid manor, for the better maintenance, and to the v≈øe of your ≈øaid Orator: To haue and to hold to your ≈øaid Orator, and to his heires and a≈ø≈øignes, at the will of the Lord, according to the cu≈øtome of the ≈øaid manor: By force whereof your honors ≈øayd Orator in the Court of the ≈øaid manor paied his fine, and was of the ≈øaid Copyhold & Cu≈øtomary tenements with the appurtenances, by the then Steward of the ≈øaid manor of W. admitted tenant. But ≈øo it is, if it may plea≈øe your honor, that all the Euidences and Copies, of, and concerning the ≈øaid me≈øuage, lands, tenements, and premi≈ø≈øes, being left in the hands, cu≈øtodie, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of your Orators ≈øaid father while≈øt he liued, in right belonging vnto your Lord≈øhips ≈øaid Orator, are now by ca≈øuall and ≈øini≈øter meanes comen to the hands and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of one H. H. of O. in the ≈øaid Countie of Y. who by colour of the hauing thereof, hath wrongfully entred into the ≈øaid me≈øuage, lands, and premi≈ø≈øes afore≈øaid, and hath made and conueyed vnto him≈øelfe, and to others to his v≈øe, diuers and ≈øundry ≈øecret e≈øtates thereof, and doth pretend wholie to di≈øinherite your Lord≈øhips ≈øaid Orator of the ≈øame, notwith≈øtanding your ≈øaid Orator hath by diuers and ≈øundry meanes in friendly maner, oftentimes ≈øought to haue the ≈øaid Euidences and Copyes, and reque≈øted the ≈øame at the hands of the ≈øaid H. H. and al≈øo that he would yeld vnto your ≈øaid Orator the quiet po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid me≈øuage, lands, and premi≈ø≈øes, to whom he doth well know the ≈øame in right to belong and appertaine, yet that to do, he hath not onely denyed and refu≈øed, and ≈øtill doth denie and refu≈øe to do the ≈øame: But of his further malice again≈øt your ≈øaid Orator, he doth threaten your Orator in ≈øuch ≈øort, that your Orator for want of the ≈øaid Euidences and Copyes, dareth not make his iu≈øt and lawfull entrie, in, and to the ≈øame: And al≈øo the ≈øaid H. hath committed, and doth continue daily great and outragious wa≈øtes and ≈øpoyles, in decaying of the hou≈øes, felling downe of the wood and tymber trees of the premi≈ø≈øes, to your Orators great lo≈ø≈øe
and di≈øinheri≈øon, and contrarie to all right, equitie, and good con≈øcience. In tender con≈øideration whereof, and fora≈ømuch as by the ≈øtrict cour≈øe of the common Lawes of this Realme, your Lord≈øhips ≈øaid Orator hath not any ordinarie remedie for the obteyning and recouering of the ≈øaid Euidences and Copyes, for want of the certeine knowledge of the contents and dates thereof, and what in them be conteyned, neyther can your Orator learne again≈øt whom to commence any ≈øuit for the ≈øaid me≈øuage, lands, and premi≈ø≈øes, for that the ≈øaid H. H. and others to your Orator altogether vnknowen, haue confederated them ≈øelues together again≈øt your ≈øaid Orator, and haue contriued and made among≈øt them ≈øelues, diuers ≈øecreat e≈øtates & conueyances, and haue ≈øo intermingled the ≈øame, to, and with other lands, tenements, and hereditaments, to, and with certeine of their owne freehold and inheritance, that your Orator knoweth not which the ≈øame be, nor how much thereof the ≈øaid H. H. & other his confederates do ≈øeuerally hold, whereby to commence any action or ≈øuit, or make any lawfull entrie, into, or for the ≈øame, without your Orators great daunger: And yet your Orator hopeth, that vpon the corporall Oath of the ≈øaid H. H. he will manife≈øt ≈øuch matter, whereby your Orator may the more better, ea≈øily, and readily proceede and attaine to the recouering of his iu≈øt & lawfull right and inheritance of the premi≈ø≈øes: For the furtherance whereof, it may plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, to graunt vnto your ≈øaid Orator, her Maie≈øties mo≈øt gratious writ of Subpena, to be directed to the ≈øaid H. H. commaunding him there by, at a certaine day, and vnder a certaine paine therein to be limitted, per≈øonally to be and appeare in her Maie≈øties high Court of Chauncerie, then and there, to aun≈øwere to the premi≈ø≈øes &c.

div.head: The An≈øwere of H. H. defendant, to the Bill of complaint of H. E. complainant.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid defendant ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid bill of complaint again≈øt him Sect' 69. exhibited into this honorable Court, is very incertaine, vntrue, and in≈øufficient in the Law to be an≈øwered vnto, by the ≈øaid defendant, for diuers and ≈øundry apparant faults & imperfections therein contained: And deui≈øed and exhibited into this honourable Court, partly of malice and euill will, without any iu≈øt cau≈øe conceiued again≈øt the ≈øaid defendant, to the intent thereby vniu≈øtly to vexe & mole≈øt him with tedious trauell, being an aged man, and to put him vnto great expences, being very poore: But chiefely to thintent and purpo≈øe to wearie, impoueri≈øh, and terrifie him this defendant: Neuerthele≈ø≈øe, if by the order of this honorable Court, this defendant ≈øhalbe compelled to make any further or other aun≈øwere vnto the ≈øaid vntrue, incertaine, & in≈øufficient bil of complaint, then and not otherwi≈øe the aduantage of exception
thereof to this defendant, at all and euerie time and times hereafter ≈øaued, for further an≈øwere thereunto, and for a full and plaine declaration of the trueth, touching ≈øo much of the materiall contents of the ≈øaid bill, as in any ≈øort concerneth this defendant, He for him≈øelfe ≈øaith, that whereas the ≈øaid complainant in his ≈øaid bill alleageth, that one H. E. his father decea≈øed, was in his life time by good and lawfull conueyance and a≈ø≈øurance in the Law, lawfully ≈øei≈øed to him and his heires in fee ≈øimple, according to the cu≈øtome of the ≈øaid manor of W. in the ≈øaide bill mentioned, of one copyhold or cu≈øtomarie me≈øuage or tenement, and of certaine cu≈øtomarie lands, meadowes, and pa≈øture, to the quantitie of an hundred acres, or thereabouts: and that he being thereof ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, and vi≈øited with ≈øicknes, during the minoritie of the ≈øaid Complainant, by good and lawfull conueiance and a≈ø≈øurancein the Lawe, and according to the Cu≈øtome of the ≈øaid manor of W. did conuey, a≈ø≈øure, and ≈øurrender the ≈øame Copyhold or Cu≈øtomarie me≈øuage or tenement, and other the premi≈ø≈øes with the appurtenances thereunto belonging for his better maintenance, to the v≈øe of the ≈øaid coÃÑplainant, To haue and to hold to the ≈øaid complainant, and to his heires and a≈ø≈øignes, at the will of the ≈øaid Lord, according to the cu≈øtome of the ≈øaid manor: And that by force thereof the ≈øaid complainant in the Court of the ≈øaide manor, paid his fine and was of the ≈øaid copyhold or cu≈øtomarie tenements with thappurtenances, by the then ≈øteward of the ≈øaid manor of W. admitted tenant. He this defendant ≈øaith, that to his knowledge, the ≈øaid H. E. late father of the ≈øaid complainant was neuer either lawfully ≈øei≈øed to him and to his heires, according to the cu≈øtome of the ≈øaid manor of W. of the ≈øaid tenements and premi≈ø≈øes in the ≈øaid bill mentioned, by any good and lawfull conueyance and a≈ø≈øurance in the law, according to the cu≈øtome of the ≈øaid manor: Nor did euer conuey, a≈ø≈øure, and ≈øurrender the ≈øaid cu≈øtomarie tenements, and other the premi≈ø≈øes, to the v≈øe of the ≈øaid complainant his heires and a≈ø≈øignes: Neither did the ≈øaid complainant euer pay his fine for the ≈øame in the ≈øaide court, neither was he euer lawfully admitted tenant thereof, as he the ≈øaid complainant in his ≈øaid bill vntruely pretendeth.
