And whereas the ≈øaid complainant in his ≈øaid bill al≈øo pretendeth, that the euidences and copies, of, and concerning the ≈øaid me≈øuage, lands, tenements, and premi≈ø≈øes, being left in the hands, cu≈øtody, & po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid complainants father while≈øt he liued, in right belonging vnto this complainant are now by ca≈øuall meanes comen to the hands and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of this defendant, and that he by colour of the hauing thereof, hath wrongfully entred into the ≈øaid me≈øuage, lands, and premi≈ø≈øes afore≈øaid, and hath made & conueyed to him≈øelfe and to others to his v≈øe, diuers and ≈øundry ≈øecret e≈øtates therein, and doth pretend thereof wholly to di≈øinherite the
≈øaid complainant, This defendant ≈øaith, that none euidences or copies, of, or concerning the ≈øaid me≈øuage, tenements, and premi≈ø≈øes, are by ca≈øuall meanes, or otherwi≈øe come to the hands or po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of this defendant, and that by colour of hauing thereof, he this defendant, neither wrongfully entred into the ≈øaid me≈øuage, tenements, and premi≈ø≈øes, nor any part thereof, neither hath he this defendant conueyed‚ñ™ to him≈øelfe, or to any other per≈øon to his v≈øe, diuers and ≈øundrie, or anie ≈øecrete e≈øtates thereof, neither doth he pretend thereof wholly to di≈øtinherite the ≈øaid complaint, as in the ≈øaid bill it is vntruely alleaged: without that, that the ≈øaid complainant by diuers and ≈øundrie meanes in friendly manner hath oftentimes ≈øought to haue the ≈øaideuidences and copies, and reque≈øted the ≈øame at the handes of this defendant, And al≈øo that he would yeeld vnto your ≈øaid Orator the quiet po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid me≈øuage, tenements, and premi≈ø≈øes, or that he this defendant doth well know the ≈øame, in right to belong vnto him the ≈øaid complainant, as in the ≈øaid bill it is vntruely alleaged: And without that y‚Ä¢ he this defendant of malice again≈øt the ≈øaid complainant doth threaten him the ≈øaid cooÃÑplainant, in ≈øuch ≈øort, that he for want of the ≈øaid euidences, dareth not make his iu≈øt & lawfull entrie or claime, to, & in the ≈øame premi≈ø≈øes, or that he the ≈øaid defendant hath or could commit, or doth, or can continue daily committing great & outragious wa≈øtes and ≈øpoiles, in decaying of the hou≈øes, and felling downe of the woods and timber trees of the premi≈ø≈øes, to the great lo≈ø≈øe and di≈øheri≈øon of the ≈øaid complainant, and contrarie to all right, equitie, and good con≈øcience, as in, and by his ≈øaid bill of complaint he hath mo≈øt vainely and vntruely alleaged. For touching the ≈øaid ≈øuppo≈øed threats, this defendant ≈øaith, that he is a verie feeble poore olde quiet man, verie de≈øirous of the fauour and good will of all men, and therfore neither willing, nor able by his threats to terrifie or feare the ≈øaid complainant, being a gentleman of wor≈øhip, power, and liuing, hauing many kin≈øfolkes, alies, friendes, and ≈øeruants, ≈øo that he this defendaÃÑt hath rather iu≈øt cau≈øe to be affraid of the ≈øaid complainant then the ≈øaid complainant to feare him. And further touching the ≈øaid wa≈øtes and ≈øpoyles, this defendant ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid cu≈øtomarie or Copihold in W. afore≈øaid, are holden of the manor of W. afore≈øaid. And without that, that the ≈øaid complainant hath, or euer had anie lawfull title to commence anie action or ≈øuite, or to make anie entrie, again≈øt or vpon this defendant, for anie landes, tenements, or hereditaments, in the ≈øaid bill of complaint mentioned, as it is therein vntruely alleaged: And without that, that this defendant can vpon his corporall Oath manife≈øt ≈øuch matter, whereby the ≈øaide complainant may the more better, ea≈øily and readily proceed and attain to the recouering of anie iu≈øt or lawfull right or inheritance, or in anie
other maner then in this an≈øwere is ≈øet downe, as the ≈øaid complainant vnwi≈øely ge≈ø≈øeth, and mo≈øt bainely hopeth, as he in his ≈øaid bill alleageth: And without that, that any other matter, thing or things, clau≈øe, ≈øentence, article, or allegation in the ≈øaid bill of complaint conteined, materiall or effectuall in the law to be an≈øwered vnto by this defendant, and not herein confe≈ø≈øed and auoided, denied or trauer≈øed, is true. All which matters this defendant is ready to auerre and proue, as this honorable Court ≈øhall award: And therefore prayeth to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed out of the ≈øame, with his rea≈øonable co≈øtes and charges in this behalfe wrongfully and without cau≈øe ≈øu≈øtained.

div.head: The Replication of H. E. E≈øquier complainant, to the An≈øwere of H. H. defendant.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid Complaynant for Replication ≈øaith, that he will auerre, Sect. 70. maintaine, and iu≈øtifie his ≈øaid bill of coÃÑplaint, into this honorable Court exhibited, and euery matter and thing therein conteined, to be certeine, true, and ≈øufficient in the Law to be an≈øwered vnto by the ≈øaid defendant, And not deui≈øed and exhibited into this honorable Court of any malice or euill will, but vpon iu≈øt cau≈øe conceiued again≈øt the ≈øaid defendant, as the ≈øaid defendant in his an≈øwere vntruely hath alleaged. And for further replication ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid H. E. late father of this Repliant, was lawfully ≈øei≈øed to him & to his heires, according to the cu≈øtome of the ≈øaid manor of W. of the ≈øaid tenements and other things in the ≈øaid bill mencioned, by good & lawfull conueyance and a≈ø≈øurance in the law, according to the cu≈øtome of the ≈øaid manor: And did conuay, a≈ø≈øure, and ≈øurrender the ≈øaid cu≈øtomarie tenements & premi≈ø≈øes to the v≈øe of the ≈øaid Repliant and of his heires, and the ≈øaid complainant did pay his fine therefore, and was lawfully admitted tenant thereof, as he the ≈øaid complainant in his ≈øaid bill very truely pretendeth. And al≈øo he ≈øaith, that the euidences and copies, of, and concerning the ≈øaid tenements and premi≈ø≈øes, are comen to the hands of the ≈øaid defendant, and that by colour thereof the ≈øaid defendant hath wrongfully entred into the ≈øaid me≈øuage, tenements & premi≈ø≈øes, & hath conuayed to him≈øelfe and to others to his v≈øe, diuers & ≈øundry ≈øecret e≈øtates therein, as in his ≈øaid bill of complaint is al≈øo mo≈øt truely declared: And that the ≈øaid complainaut hath oftentimes ≈øought & reque≈øted to haue the ≈øaid writings, copies, & euidences at the hands of the ≈øaid defendant: And al≈øo that he would yeld vnto him the quiet po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid me≈øuage & premi≈ø≈øes, And al≈øo that the ≈øaid defendant hath and ≈øtill doth commit, and continue daily committing great and outragious wa≈øtes & ≈øpoiles, in decaying of the hou≈øes, and felling downe of the woods and timber trees of the premi≈ø≈øes, to the lo≈ø≈øe and di≈øheri≈øon of him this complaynant,
as in the ≈øaid bill of complaint is truely alleaged: And without that, that any other matter or thing contained in the ≈øaid an≈øwere material or effectual to be replied vnto, and not herein ≈øufficiently confe≈ø≈øed or auoided, trauer≈øed or denied, is true. All which this complainant is ready to auerre and proue, as this honorable Court ≈øhall award. And praieth as he before in his ≈øaid bill of complaint hath praied.

div.head: A Bill to ≈øtay ≈øuite at the common law vpon an obligation, becau≈øe the money is ≈øatisfied in diuers payments and reckonings.
div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe complayning, ≈øheweth to your good Lord≈øhip Sect. 71. Fr. M. That whereas one H. B. of D. in the Countie of D. E≈øquier, now decea≈øed, hauing many daughters to aduaunce, which were then but of tender yeares, did about one and twentie yeares now la≈øt pa≈øt, make his la≈øt will and te≈øtament in writing, and by the ≈øame did giue and deui≈øe among≈øt diuers and ≈øundrie other legacies amounting to a verie great value, the ≈øumme of one hundred pounds to A. one of his daughters, and of his ≈øaid la≈øt will & te≈øtament did nominate, coÃÑ≈øtitute, and appoint your ≈øaid Orator, and one G. R. E≈øquier, being his neere kin≈øeman, & a≈ø≈øured good friend his executors: but al≈øo did commit the gouernment & education of his ≈øaid children vnto them, and after died. By and after who≈øe decea≈øe, and before the probate of the ≈øaid la≈øt will, & te≈øtament, the ≈øaid R. died: by rea≈øon whereof your ≈øaid Orator alone proued the ≈øaid will, and tooke vpon him the execution of the ≈øame, and afterward, one I. W. being a maÃÑ very ba≈øely borne, & of very little credit, did without the priuity, con≈øent, or good liking of your ≈øaid Orator, or of any other to whom the ≈øaid H. B. had committed the gouernment and education of his ≈øaid children, coÃÑtract him≈øelfe with the ≈øaid Anne, and with her did marie: After which mariage, albeit your ≈øaid Orator greatly mi≈øliked therewith, and that the ≈øaid H. B. had bequeathed vnto the ≈øaid Anne, but the ≈øumme of one hundred pounds, yet your ≈øaid Orator in re≈øpect of the neere aliance betweene him & the ≈øaid children, and to the end they ≈øhould liue in the better credite & accompt, was among≈øt y‚Ä¢ re≈øt contented to be≈øtow on the ≈øaid Anne one hundred pounds more then hir ≈øaid father bequeathed vnto hir: & thereupon at the ≈øpeciall reque≈øt & earne≈øt ≈øuit of the ≈øaid I. W. & the ≈øaid Anne then being his wife, and for their better credit, aduancement & preferment, did not only pre≈øently pay and deliuer to the ≈øaid I. W. in ready money, the ≈øumme of 50. pounds, parcell of the ≈øaid ≈øumme of one hundred pounds ≈øo bequeathed to the ≈øaid A. his wife, as is afore≈øaid, but al≈øo became bound vnto the ≈øaid I. W. in the ≈øumme of an hundred poundes for the paiment of fiftie pounds more at certaine times in the condition of the ≈øaid Obligation mencioned, which amounted to the full ≈øumme of one hundred pounds, ≈øo bequeathed as is afore≈øaid to the ≈øaid Anne,
And then al≈øo became bound vnto the ≈øaid I. W. in one other bond, in the ≈øumme of 200. pounds, for the payment of one hundred pounds, at certaine times in the condition of the ≈øaid obligation limited, which your ≈øaid Orator of his owne liberalitie, and for the aduancement of the afore≈øaid Anne, gaue vnto her ≈øithence: which bondes ≈øo made, the ≈øaid I. W. hauing had manie occa≈øioÃÑs to v≈øe money, hath often made means to your ≈øaid Orator to relieue his nece≈ø≈øitie therein, before ≈øuch time as the ≈øame ≈øummes or anie of them grew due vnto him, to be paide by the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall Obligations, by rea≈øon whereof your ≈øaid Orator about the ≈øixt daie of Iuly, in the two and thirtieth yeere of the Queenes Maie≈øties raigne that now is, paid and deliuered vnto the ≈øaid I. W. the ≈øumme of fiftie pounds more in part of paiment and ≈øati≈øfaction of the ≈øaid ≈øumme of one hundred and fiftie pounds growing by the ≈øaid two ≈øeuerall obligations, wherin your ≈øaid Orator ≈øtandeth ≈øo bound, as is afore≈øaid: and your ≈øaid Orotor likewi≈øe paid and deliuered vnto the ≈øaid I. W. at ≈øuch times as the ≈øaid I. W. hath demaunded the ≈øame diuers ≈øeuerall ≈øummes of money, amounting in the whole to the ≈øumme of 21. l' 8. sÃÑ. which the ≈øaid I. W. hath accepted in part of paiment of the ≈øaid ≈øumme of 150. pounds, and which the ≈øaid I. W. knoweth to be true, and al≈øo your ≈øaid Orator hath paid by the handes of F. B. to the ≈øaid I. W. and in di≈øcharge of ≈øome debts due by the ≈øaid I. W. and by his appointment at ≈øeuerall times the ≈øumme of lxx. l' vi. sÃÑ. viii. d. which the ≈øaid I. W. hath al≈øo accepted in part of payment of the ≈øaid ≈øumme of one hundred and fiftie pounds, which ≈øaid ≈øeuerall ≈øummes the ≈øaid I. W. hath from time to time accepted, as in part of paiment, & di≈øcharge of the ≈øaid ≈øumme of 150. l'. And your ≈øaid Orator al≈øo ≈øtandeth bound for the onely debt and duetie of the ≈øaid I. W. for the payment of 20. l' more vnto I. P. E≈øquire, which your ≈øaid Orator alwaies hath beene, and yet is readie to pay for the ≈øaid I. W. when he ≈øhall be thereunto required, ≈øo that your ≈øaid Orator, hath in the whole paid and ≈øati≈øfied vnto the ≈øaid I. W. and in di≈øcharge of the debtes of the ≈øaide I. W. the full ≈øumme of one hundreth, foure≈øcore and eight poundes and more, which is more then your ≈øaid Orator needed to haue paide vnto him as anie money due vnto the ≈øaid Anne, wife of the ≈øaid I. W. for the ≈øaide I. W. doth very well knowe, that the ≈øaid H. B. did not deui≈øe or bequeath any more vnto the ≈øaid Anne, then the ≈øumme of one hundred pounds. And doth al≈øo very well know, that he hath diuers and ≈øundrie times, vpon the receipt and payment of the ≈øaide ≈øeuerall ≈øummes, not onely confe≈ø≈øed the receipt of the ≈øame, but al≈øo faithfully promi≈øed vnto your ≈øaid Orator, that he would cancell and deface the ≈øaid obligations, yet notwith≈øtanding, ≈øo it is, if it may plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, that albeit the ≈øaid I. W. doth very well know, that your
≈øaid Orator hath fully ≈øati≈øfied and paide vnto him the ≈øaid ≈øumme of one hundreth pounds, bequeached by the ≈øaid H. B. vnto the ≈øaid Anne, and hath al≈øo fullie ≈øati≈øfied and payed vnto him, foure≈øcore and eight poundes, and more, parcell of the ≈øaid hundreth pounds, which your ≈øaid Orator gaue vnto the ≈øaid Anne, of his owne free liberalitie, and for the aduancement of the ≈øaid A. and that the ≈øaid Obligations, viz. one of one hundreth poundes, for the payment of fiftie pounds, and one other Obligation of two hundred pounds, for the payment of one hundred pounds, which your ≈øaid Orator became bound in, vnto the ≈øaid I. W. were for the ≈øelfe≈øame debts, which your ≈øaid Orator hath at ≈øeuerall payments, as is afore≈øaid, paid vnto him in di≈øcharge, and in part of ≈øati≈øfaction of the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall Obligations, ought in all right, equitie, and good con≈øcience, to be cancelled and defaced, vpon the payment of the re≈øidue of the ≈øaid ≈øummes which is behind, and which your ≈øaid Orator is readie to pay, yet he the ≈øaid I. W. hauing a very greedy, and couetous di≈øpo≈øition to enrich him≈øelfe, albeit he doth very well know the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall Obligations, to be in effect fully ≈øati≈øfied and di≈øcharged, as is afore≈øaid, and that he hath not at any time beene, any thing dampnified by the for bearing of the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall ≈øummes, yet hath he now lately commenced ≈øuite vpon one of the ≈øaid Obligations, in her Maie≈øties Court of Kings Bench, and vpon the other Obligation in her Maie≈øties Court of common Plees, meaning to take the whole forfaiture of the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall Obligations again≈øt your ≈øaid Orator, in that your ≈øaid Orator did not in trueth alwaies pay vnto him the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall ≈øummes, according to the condition of the ≈øaid Obligations, but did alwaies pay the ≈øame at ≈øuch times as the ≈øaid I. W. had occa≈øion to v≈øe it, and as he did at any time demaund it, and doth with all the expedition he can, and with the mo≈øt hardne≈ø≈øe that he may v≈øe, ≈øeeke to recouer the penalties of the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall Obligations again≈øt your ≈øaid Orator, contrarie to all right, equitie, and good con≈øcience, and to the great hurt and hinderance of your ≈øayd Orator. And albeit your ≈øayd Orator hath diuers and ≈øundry times earne≈øtly required of the ≈øayd I. W. not only to cancel and deface the ≈øayd Obligations, vpon the paiment of the re≈øidue, and ≈øurcea≈øe his ≈øeuerall ≈øuites commenced vpon the ≈øame, yet that, or any of them to do he hath denied and refu≈øed, and ≈øtill doth denie and refu≈øe, contrary to all right, equitie, and good con≈øcience: In con≈øideration whereof, and for a≈ømuch as your ≈øaid Orator hath no good matter to pleade in barre of the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall Actions by cour≈øe of the common Lawes, in that, albeit he hath in truth paied and ≈øati≈øfied the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall ≈øummes, in ≈øuch ≈øort as the ≈øayd I. W. held him≈øelfe contented therewith, yet can he not make any proofe of the paiment of the ≈øame, according to the conditions of the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall
Obligations: And for that al≈øo the ≈øaid I. W. hath not in any ≈øort bin dampnified by the forbearing of the ≈øaid ≈øummes of money, or any part thereof, and yet if he had, for≈øomuch as your ≈øaid orator hath fully paied vnto him fower≈øcore & eight pounds more then he neede to haue paied, and that of his owne liberalitie, there is now no rea≈øon why he ≈øhould ≈øeeke by rigor of law to take the forfeiture of the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall Obligations, albeit it were true that the ≈øame were not fully ≈øati≈øfied and di≈øcharged, in ≈øuch ≈øort as they ought to be: May it therefore plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, to grant vnto your ≈øaid Orator the Queenes Maie≈øties mo≈øt gracious ≈øeuerall writs of Subpena and Iniunction to be directed to the ≈øaid I. W. not only ≈øtraightly charging and commaunding him by the ≈øame at a certaine day, and vnder a certaine paine therein to be contained & limitted, per≈øonally to appeare before your good Lord≈øhip, in the Queenes Maie≈øties mo≈øt high Court of Chancerie, then & there to an≈øwere to the premi≈ø≈øes, but al≈øo inioyning him by the ≈øame, his Coun≈øellors, Attorneys, and Solicitors, to ≈øtay and ≈øurcea≈øe the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall ≈øuits, and no further to proceede in the ≈øame, vntill other order ≈øhall be therein taken by your good Lord≈øhip. And your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhall pray for your good Lord≈øhip in honor long to indure.

div.head: A Bill for the detaining of a lea≈øe for yeares, and taking the profites of the lands lea≈øed, and ≈øecret taking of a Cow distreined and impounded by the plaintife out of the pound, and charging him with thee e≈øloyning of the ≈øame Cow.
div.p:
HVmblie complaining, ≈øheweth to your good Lord≈øhip your daily Sect' 72. orator N. C. of H. in the countie of D. Gentleman. That whereas one T. E. of H. afore≈øaid gentleman, was lawfully ≈øeazed in his deme≈øne, as of fee, of, and in diuers and ≈øundry lands, tenements, hereditaments, with the appurtenances, ≈øet, lying, and being in H. afore≈øaid, And he ≈øo being thereof ≈øei≈øed about the 20. day of May, in the 27. yeare of the raigne of our ≈øoueraigne Ladie the Queenes Maie≈øtie that now is, at H. afore≈øaid, for and in con≈øideration of a certaine ≈øumme of money to him by the ≈øaid N. C. well and truely contented and paid, and by Indenture of lea≈øe, the certeine date whereof your ≈øaid orator knoweth not, for that he hath not the ≈øaid Indenture, did demi≈øe, grant, ≈øet, and to farme let the ≈øame vnto the ≈øaid N. and his a≈ø≈øignes, for and during the full ende and terme of two yeeres then next following. By force whereof, your ≈øaid orator was thereof lawfully po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, vntill about the xvii. yere of the raigne of the Queenes Maie≈øtie that now is, R. B. W. G. N. T. R. W. W. F. W. E. & K. his wife by ca≈øuall meanes hauing obteyned and gotten into their hands, or into the hands of ≈øome of them, the ≈øaid Indentures, confederating them≈øelues together of
purpo≈øe, to wrong your ≈øaid orator, & to expell & put him from his lawfull & quiet po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the premi≈ø≈øes, or the greate≈øt part thereof, entred into one parcell of the premi≈ø≈øes called B. fields, being then ≈øowed with Dates by your ≈øaid Orator. and at the ≈øame time put in one Cow and Heyfer, very maliciou≈øly to depa≈øture and eate the graine & corne of your ≈øaid Orator therein then growing, which ≈øaid Cow & Heyfer, was, and remained there depa≈øturing, eating, and treading downe the ≈øaid graine and cor ‚Ä¢ e, vntill your ≈øaid Orator came and di≈øtraiued the ≈øaid Cowe and Heyfer for dammage there doing, and impounded the ≈øaid Cow and Heyfer in a pound ‚Ä¢ uert, at H. afore≈øaid, as lawfull was for him to do, ≈øhortly after which impounding of the ≈øaid Cow and heifer, that is to ≈øay: vpon the twelfe day of Sept. the ≈øaid R. W. W. F. W. E. and K. his wife repaired vnto the dwelling hou≈øe of your ≈øaid Orator at H. afore≈øaid, and then and there required your ≈øaid Orator to deliuer the ≈øaid Cow and Heyfer forth of the ≈øaid pound, affirming that they were ≈øent thither to that intent and purpo≈øe by the ≈øaid R. B. W. G. and N. T. which to do, your ≈øaid Orator refu≈øed, as lawfull was for him to doe, becau≈øe the ≈øaid W. F. E. and K. his wife, nor any of them, did then and there tender vnto your ≈øaid Orator, any amends or ≈øati≈øfaction, for, or towards the ≈øaid tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe: But ≈øo it is if it may plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, that about a leuen or twelue of the clocke in the night of the ≈øaid twelfe day of Sept. the ≈øaid Cow and Heyfer was conueyed foorth of the ≈øaid Pound, (the dore or gate of the ≈øaid pound being fa≈øt locked) by the ≈øaid R. B. W. G. N. T. R. W. W. F. W. E. and K. his wife, or ≈øome of them, as your ≈øaid Orator verily thinketh, and is per≈øwaded in con≈øcience, ≈øithence which time, the ≈øaid B. G. and T. haue mo≈øt fal≈øely and vncon≈øcionably charged, and ≈øtill charge your ≈øaid Orator for the e≈ø ‚Ä¢ oyning and conueying away of the ≈øaid Cow and Heyfer, and haue thereupon not onely commenced ≈øuit again≈øt your ≈øaid Orator at the common Lawe, but al≈øo by colour of hauing the ≈øaid Iudenture, haue made and contriued vnto them≈øelues, or ≈øome of them, or to ≈øome other per≈øons to their, or ≈øome of their v≈øes, ≈øundry ≈øecret e≈øtates of the premi≈ø≈øes, and do yet mo≈øt wrongfully deteine, and withholde the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of a great part of the premi≈ø≈øes from your ≈øaid Orator, to his great hurt and impoueri≈øhment: And for as much as your ≈øaid Orator hath not any ordinarie remedie by the due cour≈øe of the common lawes of this realme, for the recouery of the ≈øaid Indenture, for that he knoweth not the certaine date or contents thereof, nor wherein the ≈øame is conteined: And ≈øo there by not only very like to l ‚Ä¢ ≈øe his lawfull and rightfull po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, of, in, and to the premi≈ø≈øes, but al≈øo ≈øtandeth in great daunger to lo≈øe great dammages for the ≈øuppo≈øed e≈ø≈øoyning of the ≈øaide Come
and Heyfer, vnle≈ø≈øe it plea≈øe God, as your ≈øayd Orator hopeth it will, to moue the hearts of the ≈øaid ‚Ä¢ . G. E. W. F. ‚Ä¢ . and K. his wife, vpon their an≈øweres and othes in this honorable court, to di≈øcouer and di≈øclo≈øe the trueth of their euill dealing, and di≈øorder in breaking of the ≈øaid pound, and taking foorth if the ≈øaid Cowe and Heyfer, conueying them ‚Ä¢ o vnknowen places, of purpo≈øe to charge your ≈øayd Orator therewith. And fora≈ømuch, as they haue denied, and refu≈øed, and yet do refu≈øe and denie, either to permit or ≈øuffer your ≈øaid Orator quietly to haue and take the i≈ø≈øues and pro ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tes of the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes, or to deliuer vnto him the ≈øaid Indenture of lea≈øe, although he hath oftentimes mo≈øt gently and friendly required and de≈øired them ≈øo to do: It may therefore plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip &c. As before is ≈øaid in Sectio 61.

div.head: The An≈øwere of the ≈øame Bill.
div.p:
THE ≈øaid defendants ≈øay, and either of them for him≈øelfe ≈øeuerally Sect. 73. ≈øayeth, that the ≈øaid bill of complaint is very vncertaine, vntrue, and in≈øufficient in the Lawe to be aun≈øwered vnto by the≈øe defendants, or any of them for diuers apparant faults and imperfections therein contained, and the ≈øame very friuelous, as the≈øe defendants thinke for ≈øundry cau≈øes, and namely, for that, that it is thereby ≈øuppo≈øed, that they and others by rea≈øon of hauing the cu≈øtody of the ≈øaid ≈øuppo≈øed indenture, or lea≈øe pretended to be made by the ≈øaid T. E. in the ≈øaid bill named to the ≈øaid complainant of the ≈øaid Deme≈øne lands of the Highlow afore≈øaid, for two yeares now ended, if any ≈øuch were, haue made, or contriued vnto them≈øelues, or to ≈øome other per≈øons, and to their v≈øes, ≈øundry ≈øecret e≈øtates of the premi≈ø≈øes, where if any ≈øuch e≈øtates had bin made, they be already determined. And the ≈øaid def. further ≈øay, that as they verily thinke by the ≈øcope of the ≈øaid bill containing in it ≈øelfe much like matter ≈øet out with many words, and in effect no matter worthy to be examined in this honourable Court, the ≈øame bill is deui≈øed and exhibited into this honourable Court, of meere malice, and euil will, to the intent to mole≈øt and trouble the≈øe defendants, and others in the ≈øame bill named, being quiet poore men, dwelling almo≈øt ≈øeauen≈øcore miles from the citie of W. with long and tedious iournies to make their per≈øonall apparance in this honorable Court, to an≈øwere the ≈øaid friuolous and vntrue bill without any good or iu≈øt cau≈øe ≈øo to do. Thaduantage of exception to the manife≈øt incerteintie, and in≈øufficiencie of which vntrue bill of complaint to the≈øe defendants, and eyther of them ≈øaued, for an≈øwere thereunto, they and either of them for him≈øelfe ≈øeuerally ≈øayeth, that they thinke it to be true, that the ≈øaid T. E. of H. in the ≈øaid bill named, was lawfully ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈ø ‚Ä¢ e, as of ‚Ä¢ ee, or fee taile, of, and in diuers lands, ‚Ä¢ enements, and
heredit ‚Ä¢ ments, with thappurtenances, ≈øet, lying, and being in H. afore≈øaid, and that he being thereof ≈øo ≈øei≈øed about two yeares now la≈øt pa≈øt, did demi≈øe, graunt, ≈øet and to farme let, the ≈øame vnto the complainant for two yeares, as it is in the ≈øaid bil alleaged, without that, that the≈øe defendants of purpo≈øe to expell the ≈øaid complaynant from his lawfull po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the premi≈ø≈øes, or the greate≈øt part thereof, entred into the ≈øaid parcell of the premi≈ø≈øes, being ≈øowen with oates by the ≈øaid complainant, or at the ≈øame time put in one Cow, and one heifer, verie malitiou≈øly to depa≈øture and eate the graine and corne of the ≈øaid complainant growing therein. Or that the ≈øaid cow and heifer to the≈øe defendants knowledge, remained there depa≈øturing, eating, or treading downe the ≈øaid graine and corne, vntill the ≈øaid complainant came and di≈øtrained the ≈øaid Cow and Heifer, for damage their doing, and impounded the ≈øaid cow and heifer in a pound ouert, at H. afore≈øaid to their knowledge, as in the ≈øaid bill is very vntruely alleaged. And without that, that ≈øhortly after the ≈øaid impounding of the ≈øaid cowe and heifer, that is to ≈øay, the eleuenth day of S. the ≈øaid R. W. W. F. W. E. and K. his wife, by the knowledge of the ≈øaid defendants or either of them repaired vnto the ≈øaid dwelling hou≈øe of the ≈øaid complainant, at H. afore≈øaid, and then and there required the ≈øaide complainant to deliuer the ≈øaid cow and heifer forth of the ≈øaid pound, affirming that they were ≈øent thither to that intent and purpo≈øe by the≈øe defendants, and the ≈øaid N. T. in the ≈øaid bill named, as in the ≈øaide bill is vntruely alleaged. And without that, that to the≈øe defendants knowledge, there was any ≈øuch cau≈øe, that any amends ≈øo ≈øhould haue bin tendered vnto the ≈øaide complainant, for or towards the ≈øaid ≈øuppo≈øed tre≈øpas. Or that about eleuen or twelue of the Clocke in the night of the ≈øaide eleuenth day of S. the ≈øaid cow and heifer were conueied forth of the ≈øaide pounde by the≈øe defendants, or either of them, or that the≈øe defendants or eyther of them, haue vncon≈øcionably charged the ≈øaid complainant for the e≈øtoining and conueying away of the ≈øaid cow and heifer, or thereupon commenced any ≈øuite again≈øt the ≈øaid complainant at the common law, as in the ≈øaid Bill is very vntruely alleadged, for they the≈øe defendants verily thinke that there was neuer any ≈øuch Cow and Heyfer, ≈øo as is afore≈øaid, di≈øtreyned, and without that, that the≈øe defendants by colour of hauing of the ≈øaid Indenture in the ≈øaid bill mentioned, haue made and conueied vnto them≈øelues, or to any other per≈øon or per≈øons to their v≈øes, any ≈øecrete e≈øtate of the premi≈ø≈øes, or any part thereof, or do wrongfully deteine and withhold the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of a great or any part of the premi≈ø≈øes, from the ≈øaid complainant as in the ≈øaid Bill of complaint it is likewi≈øe vntruely alleadged. And without that, that the≈øe defendants or either of them, haue denied & refu≈øed,
or yet do deny or refu≈øe, either to permit or ≈øuffer the ≈øaid complainant, quietly to haue and take the i≈ø≈øues and profits of the premi≈ø≈øes, or deliuer vnto him the ≈øaid ≈øuppo≈øed Indenture or lea≈øe, as in the ≈øaid Bill is vntruely ≈øurmi≈øed, for the≈øe defendants ≈øay, that to their knowledge, they neuer ≈øaw, nor heard read any ≈øuch Indenture or lea≈øe. And without that, that any other matter, thing or things &c.

div.head: A Bill to be releeued for Obligations made for Simonie.
div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe complaining ≈øheweth vnto your Honorable Sect' 74. Lord≈øhip, your daily Orator W. C. par≈øon of T. in the county of Y. That whereas about fiue yeares now la≈øt pa≈øt, W. by the permi≈ø≈øion of God, now Bi≈øhop of L. and C. was lawfully ≈øei≈øed of thaduow≈øon of the vicarage of D. in the Countie of D. as of one in gro≈ø≈øe, by it ≈øelfe, as of ≈øee in right of his B. afore≈øaid, and vnto the ≈øame vicarage being vacant, did pre≈øent your ≈øaid Orator his Clerke, who was afterwards admitted, in≈øtituted and inducted into the ≈øame accordingly, which vicarage afterwards by re≈øignation into the hands of the ≈øaid B. to pre≈øent againe to the ≈øame, as the very true patron thereof became voide. And afterwards your ≈øaid Orator became an humble ≈øutor vnto the ≈øaid B. in the behalfe of one R. W. Clerke, that it ≈øhould plea≈øe him to pre≈øent the ≈øame R. W. to the ≈øaid vicarage, which after long ≈øuit, it being fir≈øt agreed betweene your ≈øaide Orator, and one C. Q. with the knowledge and con≈øent of the ≈øaid B. that your ≈øaid Orator in re≈øpect of the ≈øaid pre≈øentation and admi≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid R. W. that there ≈øhould a certaine ≈øumme of money, amounting as your ≈øaid Orator thinketh to the ≈øumme of thirtie pounds, to be paid at certaine daies then betweene them agreed vpon, for the paiment thereof, and that for true paiment of the ≈øaid ≈øumme at the ≈øaid daies, your Orator ≈øhould become bounden vnto the ≈øaid C. D. by ≈øeuerall Obligations, whereupon afterwards, that is to ≈øay, the twentith day of I. which was in the eight and twentith yeare of the raigne of the Queenes mo≈øt excellent Maie≈øtie, that now is, your ≈øaid Orator for the onely con≈øideration afore≈øaide, and for the onely benefite of the ≈øaide R. W. afore≈øaide became bounden vnto the ≈øaide C. D. in foure or fiue ≈øeuerall obligations, videlicet, by ≈øome obligations in the ≈øumme of 20. pounds, or there abouts, for the paiment of ten pounds, and in ≈øome other, in other ≈øummes for paiment of fiue pounds, or there abouts, at the ≈øaide daies, and times, betweene them ≈øo as is afore≈øaid agreed vpon, and thereupon the ≈øaide R. W. for the ≈øaide con≈øiderations was in≈øtituted, and inducted into the ≈øaid Vicarage accordingly, which bonds were ≈øo made by your ≈øaide Orator in hope, and vpon the faithfull
promi≈øe of the ≈øaid R. W. would haue paid and di≈øcharged the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall ≈øummes of money at the ≈øaid daies, according to the ≈øeuerall conditions of the ≈øaid obligatioÃÑs, but now, ≈øo it is, that if it may plea≈øe your Honorable Lord≈øhip, that the ≈øaid R. W. though oftentimes by your ≈øaid Orator required, hath not paid the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall ≈øummes of money, nor any of them vnto the ≈øaid C. D. according to the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall obligations, & according to the ≈øaid agreement, and his ≈øaid promi≈øe in that behalfe made, as is afore≈øaid, by meanes whereof, the ≈øaid obligations, or the mo≈øt part of them bin forfeited, and your Orator alreadie thereupon impleaded in her Maie≈øties Court, called the Kings Bench, and by rea≈øon of the ≈øaid Obligations or ≈øome of them, very like ≈øpeedily to be condemned thereupon, if by your L. gratious meanes, he be not ≈øpeedily relieued, the which ≈øaid practi≈øes are much again≈øt all right, equity, & good con≈øcience, and to the great damage, lo≈ø≈øe, and hinderance of your ≈øaid Orator. In tender con≈øideration whereof, and for ≈øo much as the ≈øaid promi≈øe of R. W. and the ≈øaid agreement for the paiment of the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall ≈øummes of money, being matters of corruption, and vnlawful ≈øimony, were ≈øo clo≈øely and ≈øecretly wrought & contriued among≈øt them, that your ≈øaid Orator is not able to make any ≈øuch due proofe thereof, as the ≈øtrict cour≈øe of the common lawes of the Realme, in this behalfe requireth, and ≈øo your L. ≈øaid Orator is vtterly without remedy by the common lawes to auoid the ≈øaid bond, or to make proofe of the ≈øaid a≈ø≈øumption, and promi≈øe of the ≈øaid R. W. though the ≈øame be ≈øo well knowne vnto the ≈øaid Bi≈øhop, & the ≈øaid C. O. his factor, procurator, for ≈øuch contracts of ≈øimony, and al≈øo to the ≈øaid R. W. that your Orator verely thinketh they will vpon their an≈øweres hereunto in this honorable court, vpon their corporall oathes, if they be not altogether blinded with extreame couetou≈ønes, confe≈ø≈øe the truth to be, as is aboue≈øaid, It may therefore plea≈øe your honorable Lord≈øhip to grant vnto your ≈øaid Orator, her Maie≈øties mo≈øt gratious writ of Subpena, to be directed vnto the ≈øaid W. B. and vnto the ≈øaid C. O. and R. W. thereby commanding them and euery of them, at a certaine day, and vnder a certaine paine therein to be limited by your Lord≈øhip, to be, and per≈øonally to appeare before your honorable Lord≈øhip, in her Maie≈øties mo≈øt high court of Chancery, then & there to an≈øwer vnto the premi≈ø≈øes, & to abide ≈øuch further order and direction therein, as to your honorable Lord≈øhip ≈øhall ≈øeeme to ≈øtand with right, equity, and good con≈øcience, and al≈øo to grant vnto your ≈øaid Orator, her Maie≈øties mo≈øt gratious writ of Iniunction, to be directed vnto the ≈øaid C. O. thereby commaunding and inioyning him, and all his Coun≈øailers, Soliciters, and Atturneies, to ≈øtay his ≈øaid ≈øuites and proceedings, again≈øt your ≈øaid Orator, at, and by the common lawes, vntill the premi≈ø≈øes ≈øhall be heard and determined, or otherwi≈øe
ordered in this honourable Court, and your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhall daily pray vnto Almightie God for the pre≈øeruation of your honourable Lord≈øhip in good health long to continue.

div.head: A Bill for Boording.
div.p: HVmbly complaining, ≈øheweth vnto your Lord≈øhippe, your daily Se‚ñ™ 75. Orator F. W. of K. in the Countie of L. Gentleman, That whereas about foure or fiue yeeres ≈øince, one E. C. then the widdowe of B. C. and nowe wife to R. H. of N. in the Countie of L. Yeoman, verie earne≈øtly and in≈øtantly required of your ≈øaide Orator not onely for her ≈øelfe and her ≈øonne to be tabled or boorded at the hou≈øe of the ≈øaid complainant, but al≈øo haue hou≈øe roome for continuall abode and lodging with him likewi≈øe, promi≈øing liberally and fully to recompence both the co≈øt and trouble which your ≈øaide Orator, or his hou≈øeholde ≈øhould ≈øu≈øtaine therein, vppon hope of which promi≈øe and agreement, your ≈øaide Orator did to the full reque≈øt and ≈øati≈øfaction of the ≈øaide E. table and lodge the ≈øaide E. and her ≈øonne being of the age of ≈øeuen yeeres, or thereabouts, during her widowhoode, by the ≈øpace of two yeeres at the lea≈øt, ended about the Annunciation of the Virgine Marie, in the twentith yeere of the Queenes Maie≈øties Raigne, about which time the ≈øaid E. tooke to hu≈øband the ≈øaid R. H. after which mariage, vpon like promi≈øe and agreement which the ≈øaide R. your ≈øaide Orator did likewi≈øe boorde or table, and lodge in his hou≈øe the ≈øaid R. and E. her ≈øonne, and a ≈øeruant by the ≈øpace of one whole yeere and a halfe ended about May day la≈øt pa≈øt, during which time al≈øo the ≈øaid R. put your ≈øaid Orator to great charge and trouble, with diuers hor≈øe as well kept in the hou≈øes of your ≈øaid Orator, and at his co≈øt, as al≈øo abroade in his clo≈øes and pa≈øtures, notwith≈øtanding all which co≈øts, troubles, and charges of your ≈øaid Orator, Now ≈øo it is, if it may plea≈øe your Lord≈øhip, that the ≈øaid R. and E. being departed from the hou≈øe of your ≈øaid Orator, craftely, deceiptfully, & vnconcionably, refu≈øe vtterly and denie to giue any recompence or con≈øideration to your ≈øaid Orator for their meate, drinke, lodging, or other charges, contrarie to all humanitie, equitie, and right. In tender con≈øideration thereof, and for that your ≈øaid Orator, is without all helpe, by the ≈øtrict order and cour≈øe at the common law, for that for the ≈øaid tabling, lodging & charges, there was no certaine time, nor no certaine ≈øumme of money agreed vpon, amonge≈øt the ≈øaid parties, nor promi≈øed by the ≈øaid R. and E. and that al≈øo the ≈øaid agreement was betweene them≈øelues only, without any witne≈ø≈øe, May it plea≈øe your Lord≈øhip to grant vnto your ≈øaid Orator the Queenes Maie≈øties writ of Subpena to be directed to the ≈øaid R. and E. and your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhall daily may for your good Lord≈øhippe &c.

div.head: A demurrer for double vexation.
div.q: The demurrer of R. and W. defendants to the Bill of G. W. complainant.
div.p:
THE ≈øaid defendant by prote≈øtation, not confe≈ø≈øing or acknowledging Sect' 76. any thing in the ≈øaid bill alleaged, materiall again≈øt this defendant to charge him to be true, but rather deui≈øed and ≈øet foorth, onely of purpo≈øe to put this defendant to wrongfull vexation, co≈øtes, charges, and expences in the lawe, for that before this time, that is to ≈øay, about the terme of Ea≈øter, in the fiue and twentith yere of the raigne of our ≈øoueraigne Lady the Q. maie≈øtie, that now is, the ≈øaid complainant vnto this honorable Court of Chauncery, exhibited again≈øt this defend. a Bill contayning in effect, the ≈øame matter which is alleaged in the bill now exhibited, differing onely in forme, but nothing in ≈øub≈øtance, ≈øauing by adding ≈øome fiue acres, as the number of foure or fiue, as e≈øtimating one clo≈øe in this bill at foure acres in the former e≈øtimated but at two, or there abouts, and an other clo≈øe in this bill now exhibited, at three acres, in the former e≈øtimated at two or thereabouts, and putting ≈øome acres to ≈øome other clo≈øes, the which before were ≈øet downe without limitation or naming of any acres at all, being the ≈øelfe≈øame clo≈øes and me≈ø≈øuage in the former bill expre≈ø≈øed, v≈øed and occupied by the ≈øame title and name, and the ≈øame number of acres, now put in more of purpo≈øe, to giue the ≈øame complainant ≈øome colour to exhibit this bill, as though it were a new matter although in deede it be nothing ≈øo. To which former bill this defendant an≈øwered, and thereto the ≈øaid complainant replied, and this defendant reioined and ≈øo di≈øcended to Commi≈ø≈øion, wherein this defendant ioined with the ≈øaid complainant, and named Commi≈ø≈øioners for him≈øelfe, as the ≈øaid complainant named others for him≈øelfe, and this defendant then bare halfe the charges of the ≈øame Commi≈ø≈øion, as in ≈øuch ca≈øes is v≈øed. And when the time came, that the ≈øame commi≈ø≈øion was to be ≈øitten on, the ≈øaid complainant fore≈ølowed the ≈øame, neither gaue any warning to this defendant, nor laboured his owne commi≈ø≈øioners, that this defendant euer heard of, to meete for the execution of the ≈øame, but ≈øuffered the ≈øame to ≈øtay by the ≈øpace of fiue or ≈øixe termes, or thereabouts, as this defendant remembreth: whereupon this defendaunt for his owne expedition at his owne co≈øtes and charges, procured a commi≈ø≈øion for examination of witne≈ø≈øes in that matter directed to the ≈øelfe ≈øame commi≈ø≈øioners, that the former commi≈ø≈øion was, and gaue notice thereof to the ≈øaid complainants, and to one of his commi≈ø≈øioners, who agreed to meete at the day and place appointed, where this defendant was pre≈øent with his commi≈ø≈øioners and witne≈ø≈øes, and one of the ≈øaid complainants
commi≈ø≈øioners was in the towne where the place was appointed the ≈øame day and time readie to haue executed the ≈øaid commi≈ø≈øion, if the ≈øaid complainant would haue ≈øpoken to him therefore, as this defendant was credibly informed, and the ≈øaid complainant was there pre≈øent at the ≈øame time and place, and did, or might haue ≈øpoken with him that was named commi≈ø≈øioner, for him who had a dwelling hou≈øe in the ≈øame towne, being the towne of M. in the ≈øame Countie: and then and there the deponents, vpon this defendantes behalfe were ≈øworne and examined by and before the≈øe defendants then commi≈ø≈øioners, and ≈øome of them ≈øworne in the pre≈øence of the ≈øaid complainant, And thereupon the depo≈øitions and examinations of the witne≈ø≈øes ≈øo ≈øworne, were by the≈øe defendants, then commi≈ø≈øioners, cau≈øed to be ingro≈ø≈øed in parchment, and certified into this honorable court, and afterwards publi≈øhed, and after publication this defendant ≈øtaied without doing any thing therein by the ≈øpace of two termes or thereabouts, during which time the ≈øaid complainant, did or ≈øaid nothing at all in the ≈øaid court touching the ≈øaid ≈øuit, that this defendant euer heard of. And then this def. cau≈øed the ≈øaid depo≈øitions to be exemplefied vnder the great ≈øeale of Eng. to his great charges which he hath readie to ≈øhew to this H. Court. And the ≈øaid complainant being not contented with the≈øe cau≈øels vexations of this defendant: Anone after that this complainant had obtained the ≈øaid commi≈ø≈øion, the ≈øaid coÃÑplainant for this defendants further vexation, commenced ≈øuit again≈øt this defendant in the eccle≈øia≈øticall court of the Archb. of Yorke, within who≈øe dioces the ≈øame lands and tenements in N. in the bill mentioned be, & where the ≈øaid father of this complainant and defendant died, vpon ≈øurmi≈øed matters, touching the ≈øuppo≈øed will mentioned in the ≈øaid bill, whereupon this defendant to his great charges appeared & an≈øwered as behoued for the time, by him≈øelfe & his procter as is there v≈øual, whith ≈øuit the ≈øaid complainant relinqui≈øhed al≈øo as this defendant thinketh, for he hath heard nothing therof the≈øe xii. moneths and more. And now the ≈øaid complainant meaning nothing el≈øe but this defendants trouble & mole≈øtation, hath renued the ≈øaid ≈øuit in this H. Court againe, which before he had in the ≈øame court by the ≈øaid fir≈øt bill, conteining the ≈øame matters in effect & almo≈øt word for word as in the ≈øame bill is mentioned, whereunto this defendant hath alreadie an≈øwered, as appeareth by the ≈øame an≈øwere remaining of record here in this court, and the ≈øame proceeded vpon both as afore is ≈øaid: wherefore this defendant for the cau≈øes afore≈øaid, and for the ≈øaid double vexation in this honorable court by two bils conteining in effect but one matter in ≈øub≈øtance, demurreth in law and praieth that he this defendant may be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed out of this honorable court, with his rea≈øonable co≈øtes and charges in this ≈øuit wrongfully ≈øu≈øtained.

div.head: A Bill for not ≈øurrendring a lea≈øe made by the Plaintife to the defendant in tru≈øt, to trie a title, and for occupying, and wasting the tenth dem ‚Ä¢ ≈øed and for deteining of writings of copyhold lands, contrarie to their agreement.
div.p:
HVmbly complaining, ≈øheweth vnto your H. Lord≈øhip your daily Sect' 77. Orator I. K. of W. in the Countie of Y. yeoman, that whereas about 40. yeeres now la≈øt pa≈øt, one W. M. yeoman, was lawfully ≈øea≈øed in his deme≈øne, as of fee, of & in one me≈øuage, with thappurtenances in E. in the County of M. and of, & in diuers lands, tenements, meadowes, pa≈øtures, & hereditaments therunto belonging, being freehold land in E afore≈øaid, & H. in the ≈øaid con ‚Ä¢ ty of N. and he being there of ≈øuch e≈øtate ≈øo ≈øeazed about the fir≈øt yeere of the raigne of the Q. Maie≈øty that now is, by his la≈øt will and te≈øtament in writing made, & written in the life time of the ≈øaid W. M. did giue & bequeath the ≈øame to one E. then his wife, & now wife vnto your ≈øaid Orator, for the time of her natural life, the remainder thereof after her decea≈øe to one R. M. as by the ≈øaid will appeareth, and afterward the ≈øaid W. M. died of ≈øuch his e≈øtate thereof, ≈øo as is fore≈øaid ≈øei≈øed, by force of which wil and deuice, the ≈øaid E. by and after his death, entred into the ≈øaid me≈øuage or tenements, & was thereof lawfully ≈øea≈øed in her deme≈øne as of freehold, for the terme of her life, the remainder thereof after her decea≈øe to the ≈øaid R. M. in forme afore≈øaid belonging: & al≈øo whereas the ≈øaid W. M. was in his li ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ al≈øo ≈øea≈øed of or in certain copihold, or cu≈øtomary lands, lying & being within the manor of S. in the ≈øaid county of N. and holden of the ≈øaid manor by copy of the court rolles of the ≈øame manor in his deme≈øne, as of fee, according to the cu≈øtome of the ≈øaidmanor, and he being thereof ≈øo ≈øeazed died therof ≈øo ≈øeazed, by & after who≈øe death, the ≈øaid E. his wife was endoments, of the third part of the ≈øaid copihold or cu≈øtomary lands and tenements, and according to the cu≈øtome of the ≈øaid manor, admitted therof tenant by the Steward of the Court of the ≈øaid manor accordingly, by force wherof ≈øhe likewi≈øe entred into the third part of the ≈øaid cu≈øtomary tenements and premi≈ø≈øes, and was therof likewi≈øe ≈øeazed in her deme≈øne as of freehold as tenant in dower therof for the terme of her life naturall, according to the ≈øaid ou≈øtome, and quietly and peacably occupied and enioyed the ≈øame vntil about ten yeares now la≈øt pa≈øt. Now that your ≈øaid Orator through importunancy and earne≈øt per≈øwa≈øions of ≈øome friends of the ≈øaid I. T. and A. L. was contented in ≈øome maner to yeeld vnto their ≈øuit, and therupon, for the furtherance and triall of the title and intere≈øt of the ≈øaid I. T. about the fourteenth day of I. in the 26. yeare of the Queens Maie≈øties raign that now is, without any fine, income, or other coÃÑ≈øideration to him paid, but giuing credit vnto
the ≈øpeaches of the ≈øaid I. T. and A. L. that they would ≈øeeke nothing at the hands of him your ≈øaid Orator, but onely v≈øe the benefit of his pre≈øent e≈øtate, for the re≈øi≈øting of certaine vnlawfull ≈øuits, & attempts which were then offered (as they then affirmed) by the ≈øaid R. and others, did by this your ≈øaid Orators Indenture of lea≈øe, bearing date about the ≈øaid time demi≈øe, graunt, and to farme let, to the ≈øaid I. T. and A. L. all the ≈øaid freehold lands, tenements, and hereditaments, with the appurtenances in E. and H. afore≈øaid, to haue and to hold the ≈øaid tenements and premi≈ø≈øes, with the appurtenances to the ≈øaid I. T. and A. L. their executors and a≈ø≈øignes, from the fea≈øt of S. M. the Bi≈øhop in winter la≈øt pa≈øt, before the date of the ≈øaid Indenture vnto the full end and terme of 21. yeeres thence next following, and fully to be complete and ended, if the ≈øaid E. did ≈øo long liue, yeelding and paying therefore yearely during the ≈øaid terme of 21. yeeres vnto your ≈øaid Orator, his executors, admini≈øtrators, and a≈ø≈øignes, twenty ≈øhillings of lawfull Engli≈øh money, at the fea≈øtes of Penteco≈øt, and Saint Martin the Bi≈øhop in Winter by euen portions, as by the ≈øame Indenture more at large appeareth: by vertue and pretence of which demi≈øe, the ≈øaid I. T. and A. L. into all the ≈øaid tenements and premi≈ø≈øes with the appurtenances about the ≈øame time entred, and were thereof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, and euer ≈øince their entrie haue quietly and peaceably occupied and enioyed the ≈øaid demi≈øed tenements, and premi≈ø≈øes, and the rents, i≈ø≈øues, and profits thereof ari≈øing and comming haue quietly, and peaceably taken and conuerted to their owne only v≈øe, which rents, i≈ø≈øues, and profits of the premi≈ø≈øes, euer ≈øince the making of the ≈øaid lea≈øes, which is by the ≈øpace of ten yeeres now la≈øt pa≈øt, haue bin yearely woorth four pounds at the lea≈øt, ouer and aboue all charges and repri≈øes. And in truth at the time of the making of the ≈øame lea≈øe, it was fully concluded, and agreed, by and betweene your ≈øaid Orator the ≈øaid I. T. and the ≈øaid A. L. and the ≈øaid I. T. and A. L. in con≈øideration of the making of the ≈øaid lea≈øe to them by your ≈øaid Orator in maner and forme afore≈øaid, and for the cau≈øes afore≈øaid, promi≈øed, that the ≈øaid lea≈øe, and their ≈øaid e≈øtate thereby made, ≈øhould be ≈øurrendred and yeelded vp vnto your ≈øaid Orator, when eyther the ≈øaid ≈øuits were ended betweene the ≈øaid R. and them, or either of them, or when they by vertue of the ≈øaid lea≈øe had enioyed the ≈øame demi≈øed tenements and premi≈ø≈øes by the ≈øpace of one whole yeare, for then the ≈øame lea≈øe was ≈øo as is afore≈øaid, made onely for the defence and trial of the ≈øaid e≈øtate, right and title of the ≈øaid I. T. and A. L. of, and in the ≈øame tenements and premi≈ø≈øes, and not to thintent that they, or either of them ≈øhould by rea≈øon of the ≈øame Indenture according to the purport and tenor thereof, for the terme of one and twentie yeares haue and enioy the ≈øame, for ≈øo ≈ømall a rent,
which neuerthele≈ø≈øe they haue done, and yet do ≈øo occupie and enioy the ≈øame, contrarie to their ≈øaid faithfull promi≈øe & agreement, as is afore≈øaid thereof made: and yet not contenting them≈øelues with the ≈øaid occupation of the ≈øaid tenements, &c. do not onely denie and refu≈øe to yeeld vnto your ≈øaid Orator either the ≈øaid yearely rent re≈øerued vpon the ≈øaid lea≈øe, or any other con≈øideration for the occupying of the ≈øame, and vtterly denie to yeeld vnto your ≈øaid Orator any rent or con≈øideration for the ≈øame, being ≈øo as afore≈øaid, behinde by the ≈øpace of ten yeares: but al≈øo do vtterly denie to yeeld vp vnto your ≈øaid Orator their ≈øaid e≈øtate and terme of yeares, yet to come, of, and in the ≈øaid demi≈øed tenements and premi≈ø≈øes according to their faithfull promi≈øes and agreement, ≈øo as is afore≈øaid made, and further ≈øince their ≈øaid entrie into the ≈øaid tenements and premi≈ø≈øes, they the ≈øaid I. T. and A. L. or the one of them haue razed or defaced all or part of the hou≈øes, edifices, and buildings, which at the time of the making of the ≈øame lea≈øe were ≈øtanding and being vpon the ≈øaid demi≈øed tenements and premi≈ø≈øes, and the thacke, ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ate, timber, and ≈øtone thereof, haue either giuen away or conuerted the ≈øame to their owne v≈øes, without the con≈øent of your ≈øaid Orator, to the intent that the ≈øame tenements might ≈øo be made vnmeete for the habitation of your ≈øaid Orator, and his ≈øaid wife, whereby they might the rather enforce your ≈øaid Orator for want of the ≈øaid buildings to yeeld the ≈øame vnto them, for little or nothing, by rea≈øon of the want of the ≈øaid Indenture there being only one part thereof made together, which with ≈øuch copies as concerne the ≈øaid copyhold lands, are in the hands and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid I. T. and A. L. or of one of them, or of ≈øome other per≈øons by the deliuery of them, or of the one of them, the certaine number, dates, contents, and other certainties whereof your ≈øaid Orator knoweth not: and albeit that your ≈øaid Orator hath diuers times in gentle maner required them the ≈øaid I. T. and A. L. to deliuer vnto your ≈øaid Orator the ≈øaid Indenture and copies, and to yeeld vp and ≈øurrender vnto your ≈øaid Orator the ≈øaid intere≈øt, of, and in the ≈øaid demi≈øed tenements and premi≈ø≈øes, according to the ≈øaid agreement and tru≈øt, yet they ≈øo to do, haue euer hetherto refu≈øed and denied, and yet do denie and refu≈øe to do the ≈øame, and to yeeld vp and ≈øurrender the ≈øaid e≈øtate of, and in the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes, according to the tru≈øt in them repo≈øed, and to repaire and reedifie the ≈øaid tenements and premi≈ø≈øes ≈øo by them razed, and pulled downe, as is afore≈øaid, again≈øt all right, equity and good con≈øcience, and again≈øt all good and hone≈øt dealing, and to the impoueri≈øhing, and vtter vndoing of your ≈øaid Orator, and his ≈øaid wife, if ≈øpeedy remedy be not in due time by your Honorable Lord≈øhip prouided for the repre≈ø≈øing of their ≈øaid vncon≈øcionable purpo≈øes and attempts in the premi≈ø≈øes. In tender con≈øideration whereof, and for ≈øo
much as the ≈øaid Indenture, conclu≈øion, promi≈øes, and agreements, ≈øo is afore≈øaid, had and made, by, and betweene your ≈øaid Orator & the ≈øaid I. T. and A. L. concerning the premi≈ø≈øes, were ≈øecretly made and agreed vpon, by and betweene them≈øelues, and few mitne≈ø≈øes being priuy therunto or pre≈øent with them at the time of the making thereof, which might te≈øtifie the ≈øame, and tho≈øe witne≈ø≈øes, (≈øuch as they were) be now either dead, or vnto your ≈øaid Orator vtterly vnknowen, being at the ≈øame time meere ≈øtrangers vnto your ≈øaid Orator, & then brought thither by them the ≈øaid I. T. and A. L. as it ≈øeemed, of ≈øet purpo≈øe to circumuent & deceiue your ≈øaid Orator, and his wife in the premi≈øes, your ≈øaid Orator then referring e≈øpeciall tru≈øt and confidence to the ≈øaid I. T. and A. L. as per≈øons whom he tooke, and accompted to haue bin his very e≈øpeciall goods friends, and al≈øo very ≈øub≈øtantiall hone≈øt men, is vtterly without all remedy by the ≈øtrict cour≈øe of the coÃÑmon lawes of this realme of England, to recouer either the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øame tenemeÃÑts and premi≈ø≈øes of the ≈øaid rents, they hauing his ≈øaid Indenture of lea≈øe as is afore≈øaid, or to recouer the ≈øaid copies, It may therfore plea≈øe your honorable Lord≈øhip the premi≈ø≈øes gratiou≈øly con≈øidered to grant vnto your ≈øaid Orator, the Q. Maie≈øties mo≈øt gratious writ of Subpena out of her highne≈ø≈øe court of Chancery, to be directed to the ≈øaid I. T. and A. L. and either of them therby commaunding them, and either of them at a certaine day, and vnder a certaine paine therein to be limitted, to be and per≈øonally to appeare before your honorable Lord≈øhip, in the ≈øaide court of C. Then and there to an≈øwere vnto the premi≈ø≈øes, and to ≈øtand to, and abide to ≈øuch further order & direction therein, as to your honorable Lord≈øhip ≈øhall be thought to ≈øtand with right, equity, and good con≈øcience. And your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhall daily pray vnto God for the pre≈øeruation of your Honors pro≈øperity and good health long to continue.

div.head: A Bill by an Administator vpon a promi≈øe made vnto the inte≈øtate by the defendant, to pay vnto him certaine money in mariage of the d ‚Ä¢ fendants daughter with one of the inte≈øtates Sonnes.
div.p:
COmplaining, ≈øheweth vnto your Honorable Lord≈øhip, G. Earle of Sect'. 78. S. admini≈øtrator of the goods and chattels of the right honorable G. Earle of S. decea≈øed his late father, that wheras about ≈øeuen yeares now la≈øt pa≈øt, there was certaine communication betweene the ≈øaid G. Earle of S. in his life time, and one W. R. of K. in the County hf N. E≈øquier, of, for, and concerning a marriage then intended to be made betweene H. T. E≈øquier, one of the ≈øonnes of the ≈øaid late Earle, and E. the onely daughter, and heire apparant of the ≈øaid W. R. And thereupon it was fully concluded and agreed betweene the ≈øaid late Earle, and the ≈øaid W. R. and either party did mutually promi≈øe, and agree to
and with the other, that the ≈øaid H. T. and the ≈øaid E. daughter of the ≈øaid W. R. ≈øhould marry together, according to the Eccle≈øta≈øticall lawes of this realme of England, at a certain day by the ≈øaid parties for that purpo≈øe agreed vpon & appointed. And for, and in con≈øideration of the ≈øaid marriage to be made, as is afore≈øaid, the ≈øaid W. R, about the ≈øame time did a≈ø≈øume, & to the ≈øaid late Earle faithfully promi≈øe to pay and giue vnto the ≈øaid late Earle 4000. l . of lawfull Engli≈øh money, or there abouts, at certain daies likewi≈øe in that behalfe between them agreed vpon, & now long ≈øithence pa≈øt, by rea≈øon of which agreement, promi≈øe, & a≈ø≈øumption ≈øo made, as is afore≈øaid, the ≈øaid H. T. did ≈øhortly after the ≈øaid agreement, marry and take to his wife the ≈øaid daughter of the ≈øaid W. R. And thereupon the ≈øaid W. R. did well & truly content and pay to the ≈øaid late Earle the ≈øumme of 3000. l . parcell of the ≈øaid ≈øumme of 4000. l . or there abouts. And ≈øhortly after & before he the ≈øaid late Earle had receiued the re≈øidue of the ≈øaid ≈øumme of 4000. l . he the ≈øaid Earle died. Now ≈øo it is, if it may plea≈øe your honorable Lord≈øhip, that the ≈øaid W. R. not ignorant of the premi≈ø≈øes, and nothing regarding his ≈øaid agreement & faithfull promi≈øe and a≈ø≈øumption, ≈øo as is afore≈øaid by him made, to, and with the ≈øaid late Earle, but imagining and fraudulently intending, a≈øwell the ≈øaid late Earle in his life time, as your ≈øaid orator, being admini≈øtrator of the goods & chattels of the ≈øaid late Earle, ≈øince his death in this behalf fal≈øly & deceiptfully to defraud and decei ‚Ä¢ e him of the ≈øum of a 1000. l . at the le≈øt, parcel of the ≈øaid ≈øum of 4000. l . or there abouts by him agreed & promi≈øed to be paid to the ≈øaid late E. as is afore≈øaid in con≈øideration of the ≈øaid mariage, although he the ≈øaid W. R. hath oftentimes, a≈øwell by the ≈øaid late E. in his life time, as by the now E. ≈øince his death bin curteu≈øly required to haue paid the ≈øaid ≈øumme of 1000. l . according to his ≈øaid agreement, promi≈øe, and a≈ø≈øumption, yet that to do, hath he euer hitherto denied and refu≈øed, and yet doth denie & refu≈øe to do the ≈øame, contrary to his ≈øaid faithfull promi≈øe & a≈ø≈øumption, to the great lo≈ø≈øe & damage of the now E. and altogether again≈øt all right, equity, & good con≈øcience: Notwith≈øtanding that the ≈øaid late Earle, in re≈øpect of the ≈øaid mariage, hath conueyed and a≈ø≈øured vnto the ≈øaid H. T. a good e≈øtate of inheritance, of diuers manors, lands, tenements, and hereditaments worth 3000. l . by the yeare, or there abouts, wherof the ≈øaid R. his daughter is intituled to haue dower by law: In con≈øideration whereof, and for≈øomuch as by rea≈øon of the great tru≈øt & confidence which the ≈øaid late Earl did repo≈øe & put in him the ≈øaid W. R. the ≈øaid agreement, promi≈øe, & a≈ø≈øumption, ≈øo as afore≈øaid betweene them made, was ≈øo made ≈øecretely & priuatly betweene theÃÑ≈øelues only, without calling any other per≈øon or per≈øons vnto theÃÑ to be witne≈ø≈øes therof, which might te≈øtify the ≈øame agreemeÃÑt, promi≈øe, &
other an≈øwere to the ≈øaid vntrue and in≈øufficient bill of complaint: then they and either of them for the ≈øati≈øfaction of this honorable Court, in the truth of all the matters in the ≈øaid bill mo≈øt vntruly obiected by the ≈øaid complainant again≈øt the ≈øaid def. for further and ful an≈øwere thereunto, and for plaine declaration of the truth therein: They the ≈øaid defendants and either of them ≈øay, that true it is indeed, that there was a certaine ≈øpeech or communication had betweene the ≈øaide complainant and the≈øe ≈øaid def. for ≈øuch a bargaine to be had and made between them in ≈øuch ≈øort, for the lea≈øe and paiments, as they ‚Ä¢ re by the ≈øaid bill alleaged, the which ≈øaid communication was then ≈øet downe in certaine articles bearing date, in the ≈øaid complainants bill alleaged. And it was then al≈øo mo≈øt materiall, for the≈øe ≈øaid defendants further couenanted and agreed on the part of the ≈øaid complainant, that that ≈øaid communication ≈øhould be by him the ≈øaid complainant put in writing by deed indented, and according to law be executed by ≈øealing & deliuering thereof, as the≈øe ≈øaid defendants then did, and yet do take it, & moreouer that the ≈øaid complainant and G. B. of E. in the Countie of D. E≈øq. ≈øhoulde become bound iointly and ≈øeuerally vnto the ≈øaid def. for the true performance of all and euery the ≈øaid agreements, in the ≈øumme of 110. li. before the paiment of the ≈øaid ≈øumme of 40. li. in the ≈øaid bill mentioned, being the fir≈øt paiment which they ≈øhould haue made, the which ≈øaide communication as the ≈øaid defendantes did accompt it, was then ≈øet down in writing vnder the terme of Articles of agreemeÃÑt, but yet neuer meant to conclude or bind the ≈øaid bargaine, vntill the ≈øame ≈øhould haue bin ingro≈ø≈øed, ≈øealed, & deliuered, & the ≈øaid obligatioÃÑ entered at the ≈øaid complainaÃÑts co≈øts and trauel, as the ≈øaid def. haue euer taken it, & think the ≈øame wil proue ≈øo in law becau≈øe it was referred to further writings more effectuall in the law to be accompli≈øhed by the ≈øaid complainant, the which to do, he neither yet hath, neither as it ≈øeemeth meant to performe, but rather to gaine the ≈øaid defendants money, without anie a≈ø≈øurance thereof to be made vnto theÃÑ, for that he hath not cau≈øed the ≈øaid articles to be ingro≈ø≈øed, neither hath he & the ≈øaid G. B. entred into bond to the ≈øaid defendants, or either of them according to the ≈øaid agreement, but wholly ≈øought, if by any meanes he could, cunningly to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe him≈øelfe of the ≈øaid ≈øumme of 55. li. or of ≈øo much thereof, as he could without any a≈ø≈øurance making, or entring into bond to the ≈øaide defendants, as afore≈øaid, to the great impoueri≈øhment of the ≈øaid defendants, if the ≈øaid complainants entent had taken effect, for which cau≈øes they the ≈øaid defendantes thinke that the ≈øaide complainant hath no iu≈øt cau≈øe of complaint, neither are they the ≈øaid defendants or either of them bound, as they take it, to performe the ≈øaid paiments in the ≈øaide bill expre≈ø≈øed, without that, that the ≈øaid agreement was priuately and
≈øecrettly made betweene the ≈øaid complainant, and the ≈øaid defendants as in the ≈øaid bill is mo≈øt vntruly alleaged, or that the ≈øaid defendantes euer meant any fraud, or guile, as likewi≈øe in the ≈øaid bill is very ≈ølaunderou≈øly pretended. And without that, that any other matter or thing in the ≈øaid bill of complaint contained, materiall or effectuall in the law to be aun≈øwered vnto, and in this their aun≈øwere not ≈øufficiently aun≈øwered vnto confe≈ø≈øed and auoided, trauer≈øed or denied, is true, all which matters the≈øe defendants, and either of them are readie to auerre and proue as this honorable Court ≈øhall awarde, and pray, that they may be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed out of the ≈øaid Court, with their rea≈øonable co≈øts and charges in that behalfe wrongfully, and without cau≈øe ≈øu≈øtained.

div.head: The Replication of Io. S. complainant vnto the ioynt and ≈øeuerall an≈øweres and demurrers of I. M. and P. M. defendants.
div.p:
THE ≈øaid complainant for replication ≈øaith, in all and euerie thing Sect'. 82. and things, as he in his ≈øaid bill of complaint hath ≈øaid, and doth, and will auerre, iu≈øtifie and maintaine his ≈øaid bill of complaint, and all and euery thing and things, clau≈øe, ≈øentence, article, and allegation therein contained, to be good, iu≈øt, and true, certaine and ≈øufficient in the law to be an≈øwered vnto by the ≈øaid defendant, and deui≈øed & exhibited into this honorable court, vpon good and iu≈øt cau≈øe of ≈øuite, as in, and by the ≈øaid bill is mo≈øt truely ≈øet downe and di≈øclo≈øed. And not deui≈øed, imagined & ≈øet forth by this coÃÑplainant again≈øt the ≈øaid defendants vpon malice or ≈øet purpo≈øe, to put the≈øe defendaÃÑts to wrongfull and verie vniu≈øt vexation, co≈øtes, charges and ≈øuit in law, without any good ground or cau≈øe ≈øo to doe, as in the ≈øaid an≈øwere it is vntruly alleaged. But the ≈øaid complainant ≈øaith, that the an≈øweres of the ≈øaid defendants are verie vncertaine, vntrue, and in≈øufficient in the law to be replied vnto for diuers and manife≈øt imperfections therin contained. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe, if by the order of this honorable Court, this complainant ≈øhall be compelled to make any further replication vnto the ≈øaid vntrue, incertaine, and in≈øufficient an≈øweres of the ≈øaid defendants, then, and not otherwi≈øe, the aduantage of exception, to the manife≈øt incertainty and in≈øufficiency thereof to this complainant, at all and euery time and times hereafter ≈øaued, for further replication thereunto ≈øaith, as in the ≈øaid bill of complaint he hath ≈øaid, without that, that at the ≈øaid time of the making of the ≈øaid agreement in the ≈øaid bill and an≈øwere mentioned, it was further couenanted and agreed on the part of the ≈øaid complainant, that the ≈øaid communication ≈øhould by the ≈øaid complainant be put in writing by deed indented, and according to the law be executed by ≈øealing and deliuerie thereof. Or that
this complainant, and the ≈øaid G. B. E≈øquire in the ≈øaid an≈øwere named, ≈øhould become bound ioyntly, and ≈øeuerally vnto the ≈øaid defendant for the true performance of all and euery the ≈øaid agreements in the ≈øumme of one hundred and fortie pounds in the ≈øaid bill mentioned, being the fir≈øt payment which they ≈øhould haue made, as in the ≈øaide aun≈øwere it is very vntruely alleaged, with this, that this complainant doth & wil auerre, and proue that the ≈øaid communication in the ≈øaid bill and an≈øwere mentioned, ≈øet downe vnder the terme of articles of agreement was euer ment to conclude and binde the ≈øaid bargaine, the ≈øame not referred to any further ceremony of engro≈ø≈øing, ≈øealing and deliuerie, or entring into the ≈øaid obligation by the ≈øaid complainant, or G. B. at the co≈øtes and trauell of the fore≈øaid complainant, & the ≈øaid G. & this complainant al≈øo ≈øaith, that the ≈øame agreement was then fully and ab≈øolutely made, & not referred to any ≈øuch further writing more effectuall in the law, to be fully accompli≈øhed by the ≈øaid comploinant, as in the ≈øaid an≈øwere, it is coniecturally and vntruely ≈øugge≈øted, and without that, that this complainant, and the ≈øaid G. B. or either of them haue ment to gaine the ≈øaid defendants money, without any a≈ø≈øurance made of the tenements in the ≈øaid bill mentioned to the ≈øaide defendants, or wholly ≈øought by any meanes he could, cunningly to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe him≈øelfe of the ≈øaid ≈øumme of 50. l . or of ≈øo much thereof as he could, without any a≈ø≈øurance making, or entring into bond to the ≈øaid defendants, as afore≈øaid, to the great impoueri≈øhment of the≈øe defendants, if the complainants intent had taken effect, as in the ≈øaid an≈øwere is vntruely ≈øurmi≈øed. For this complaint ≈øaith, that euer ≈øince the making of the ≈øaid bargaine and agreement, he and the ≈øaid G. B. haue, and yet are readie to performe and do, what≈øoeuer they did then bargaine and agree to doe, by the ≈øame articles, as vnto this honorable Court‚ñ™ ≈øhalbe truely and ≈øufficiently proued, and this complainant al≈øo ≈øaith, that he hath iu≈øt cau≈øe of complaint, and that the ≈øaid defendants are bound to performe the ≈øaid paiments in the ≈øaid bill of complaint mentioned, which he hopeth, they ≈øhall be compelled to doe, by the order of this honorable Court. And without that, that any other matter, thing or things, clau≈øe ≈øentence, article or allegation, in the ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ an≈øwere contained, material, or effectuall in the law, to be replied vnto, by this complainant, and not herein in this his replication by this complainant ≈øufficienlty replied vnto, confe≈ø≈øed and auoided, denied or trauer≈øed is true. All which matters, this complainant is readie to auerre add proue as this honorable Court ≈øhall awarde, and prayeth as he in his ≈øaide Bill of complaint hath praied.

div.head: A Bill for money lent without ≈øpecialty and witne≈ø≈øes.

opener.salute: To the Right Honorable Sir T. B. &c.

div.p: IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe complaining, ≈øheweth vnto your Honorable Sect. 83. Lord≈øhip, your daily Orator T. G. of A≈øhebourne, in the countie of Darby Gentleman, that whereas your ≈øaid Orator by way of pre≈øt, at the fea≈øt of P. in the xviii. yeare of the raigne of our Soueraigne Ladie Glizabeth by the grace of God, of England, France, and Ireland, Queene defendre≈ø≈øe of the faith, &c. did deliuer vnto E. C. of A. in the Countie of Y. yeoman, the ≈øumme of xx. pound of currant Engli≈øh money, to be paid vnto him your ≈øaid Orator, at or before fea≈øt of S. Bart. the Apo≈øtle then next en≈øuing: Now ≈øo it is, that although your ≈øaide Orator hath many and ≈øundrie times required payment of the ≈øaid xx. pound, yet notwith≈øtanding, he the ≈øaid E. the ≈øame xx. pound to your ≈øaid orator hath not yet paid, to the great lo≈ø≈øe & hinderance of him your ≈øaid Orator, And for becau≈øe your ≈øaid Orator hath not any ≈øpecialtie or witne≈ø≈øe to proue the deliuery of the ≈øaide xx. pound, he is therefore thereof without remedie by order and cour≈øe of the common lawes of this Realme, and is vtterly like to loo≈øe the ≈øaid ≈øumme, contrarie to all equitie, good con≈øcience and true dealing, vnle≈ø≈øe your honorable Lo. fauor and lawfull aide be herein ≈øhewed. In tender con≈øideration whereof, may it plea≈øe your honorable Lo. the premi≈ø≈øes con≈øidered, &c.

div.head: The An≈øwere of the ≈øaid Bill.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid defendant ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid Bill of complaint is very vntrue, Sect' 84. and in≈øufficient in the law to be an≈øwered vnto, for diuers apparant matters therein conteined, and that the ≈øame is deui≈øed by the ≈øaid complainant, and exhibited into this honorable court of meere malice and euill wil, to thintent to put this defendant to great charges and expences, without any good matter, or iu≈øt cau≈øe, or colour of cau≈øe ≈øo to doe: And that if the ≈øaid ≈øuppo≈øed matter were true, as indeede it is not, yet were the ≈øame determinable, at, and by the common lawes of this Realme, and not in this honorable crurt, whereunto this defendant prayeth to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, with his rea≈øonable co≈øtes and charges in this behalfe wrongfully ≈øu≈øtained, without that, that the ≈øaid complainant by way of pre≈øt at the fea≈øt of Pentico≈øt, in the ≈øaide three and twentith yeare of the Queenes Maie≈øties Raigne, or at any other time did deliuer vnto this defendant the ≈øaid ≈øumme of twentie pounds to be paid vnto him, at, or before the ≈øaid fea≈øt of S. Bart. the Apo≈øtle as in the ≈øaid Bill is ≈øuppo≈øed. And without that, that the ≈øaid complainant manie and ≈øundrie times required payment of the ≈øaid twenty pound, as in the ≈øaide Bill is likewi≈øe vntruely ≈øuppo≈øed. And without that,
that any other matter, thing, or things, clau≈øe, ≈øentence, article, or allegation in the ≈øaid bill contained materiall or effectuall in the law to be an≈øwered vnto and not herein in this his an≈øwere ≈øufficiently confe≈ø≈øed, and auoided, denied, or trauer≈øed is true. All which matters, &c.

div.head: A Bill of deteining bonds and bils paid, praying an Iniunction to ≈øtay ≈øuite thereupon.

opener.salute: To the Right Honorable Sir C. H. Knight of the noble order of the garter, and Lord Chaunctllor of England.

div.p:
HVmbly ≈øheweth vnto your good Lo. F. L. of S. in Ie dale, in the Sect' 85. Countie of D. E≈øquier. That whereas your ≈øaid ≈øupplyant did long ≈øithence in his fathers life time, at diuers ≈øeuerall times (the certainty whereof your Lord≈øhips ≈øaid Orator doth not now remember) vpon ≈øome occa≈øion, that he then had to v≈øe more money then he had then in ≈øtore, did borrow and take to Ioane of one R. S. of S. in the ≈øaid Countie of D. yeoman, diuers ≈øummes of money, vpon receipt whereof, your Lord≈øhips ≈øaid ≈øuppliant did alwaies deliuer vnto the ≈øaid R. S. either ≈øufficient Obligations of double the ≈øumme borrowed, or el≈øe his the ≈øaid F. L. your Lo. ≈øaid ≈øuppliants ≈øingle bill obligatorie, for repaiment of all ≈øuch ≈øummes of money as he then borrowed at ≈øuch times as were then agreed vpon betweene them. And among≈øt the re≈øt, your Lo. ≈øaid Orator did about twentie yeares ≈øince, as he now remembreth, borrow of the ≈øaid R. S. the ≈øumme of xx. l . for the repaiment wherof at a certaine day therefore, then agreed vpon betweene them, your Lo. ≈øaid ≈øuppliant did then deliuer vnto the ≈øaid R. S. his bill obligatorie for his ≈øufficient a≈ø≈øurance thereof, the which ≈øaid xx. l . like as al≈øo al the other ≈øums of money ≈øo borrowed by your L. ≈øaid ≈øuppliant, as is afore≈øaid, he the ≈øaid. F. L. your L. ≈øaid ≈øuppliant, hath mo≈øt certainly now long ≈øithence repaied vnto the ≈øaid R. S. at ≈øuch time as hethe ≈øaid R. was wel therewith coÃÑtented, as wel in ful di≈øcharge of the ≈øaid bill obligatorie of xx. l . as of all the other bonds and writings ≈øo entred by your Lo. ≈øaid ≈øuppliant, as is afore≈øaid: And in re≈øpect, that he the ≈øaid R. S. had not the ≈øaid bill obligatorie for the ≈øaid xx. l . readie to be cancelled and redeliuered at the ≈øaide repayment of the ≈øaide xx. pound, he the ≈øaid R. S. did then verie faithfully promi≈øe vnto him that made the ≈øaide repayment, that he the ≈øaide R. S. woulde a≈ø≈øuredly cancell the ≈øaid bill obligatorie, when≈øoeuer the ≈øame ≈øhould next come into his handes: But ≈øo it is, if it may plea≈øe your good L. that the ≈øaide R. S. hath lately put the ≈øaid Bill for the ≈øaide xx. pound in ≈øuite, as your Lord≈øhippes ≈øaide ≈øuppliant is credibly informed,
meaning to be double paid for the ≈øaid xx. pound, in the ≈øaid bill mentioned, again≈øt all equity and good con≈øcience: In con≈øideration wherof, and for a≈ømuch as your Lord≈øhips ≈øaid Orator hath no remedie at the common law, either to recouer the ≈øaid bill obligatory for the ≈øaid ≈øumme of xx. pound from the ≈øaid R. S. or otherwi≈øe to pleade in di≈øcharge thereof. And fora≈ømuch as the ≈øaid R. S. hath diuers other the ≈øaid obligations and writings yet remaining in his hands, which are likewi≈øe ≈øati≈øfied, and which he hath promi≈øed to deliuer ynto your L. ≈øaid ≈øuppliant at diuers times now long ≈øithence pa≈ø≈øed, the which to do he hath hitherto not fulfilled, and in verie good ≈øort by your Lord≈øhips ≈øaid Orator, and his ≈øeruants oftentimes required, for like recouery or di≈øcharge whereof your Lord≈øhips ≈øaid ≈øuppliant ≈øtandeth likewi≈øe de≈øtitute by the ≈øtrict cour≈øe of the common lawes. It may therefore plea≈øe your good L. to award a≈øwell the Queene Maie≈øties mo≈øt gratious writ of Iniunction to be directed vnto the ≈øaid R. S. and all and euery of his Coun≈øellers, Attorneis, Sollicitors and Factors comcommaunding them, and euerie of them thereby at a certaine day, and vnder a certaine paine therein to be ≈øet downe by your good Lord≈øhip no further to proceede in the ≈øuite vpon the ≈øaide xx. pound bill, vntill your Lord≈øhippe ≈øhall haue taken further direction therein, as al≈øo the Queenes Maie≈øties writ of Subpena to be directed to the ≈øaid R. S. commaunding him thereby, &c.

div.head: A Bill to examine witne≈ø≈øes in perpetuam rei memoriam, touching a lea≈øe made in trust by the plaintife to the defendants.

opener.salute: To the right honorable Sir C. H. Knight, Lord Chancellor of England.

div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe complaining ≈øheweth vnto your honorable Sect' 86. Lord≈øhip, your ≈øuppliant and daily Orotor T. B. of B. in the countie of Y. E≈øquier. That whereas your ≈øaid Orator about ≈øixe yeares now la≈øt pa≈øt, was, and yet is lawfully ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne as of fee, of, and vpon one me≈øuage or tenement called B. and of diuers landes and grounds thereunto belonging, or with the ≈øame commonly v≈øed or occupied, lying and being within the Lord≈øhip of M. in the county of Y. and he being therof ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, vpon ≈øpecial tru≈øt and confidence which he then repo≈øed in one W. G. of B. in the countie of Y. and M. his wife, by his deed ≈øufficient in the law, did demi≈øe, grant, and to ferme let vnto the ≈øaid W. G. and M. his wife, when ≈øhe the ≈øaide M. was ≈øole and vnmaried, the ≈øaid me≈øuage, tenements, and premi≈ø≈øes, To haue and to hold the ≈øame vnto the ≈øaid W. and M. from the ende and expiration of one lea≈øe then enduring, and now ended, which the ≈øaid
W. G. then had in the premi≈ø≈øes for the terme of 21. yeares, thence next following, fully to be complete and ended: which ≈øaide lea≈øe was not onely meant and entended to be to the v≈øe of your ≈øaid Orator, but al≈øo at the time of the making hereof it was ≈øo declared and expre≈ø≈øed, a≈øwel by your ≈øaid Orator, as by the ≈øaid W. and M. in the pre≈øence of diuers witne≈ø≈øes, and not to the v≈øe of the ≈øaid W. and M. as your Orator ≈øhall be able plainely to proue in this H. court, which notwith≈øtanding by the ≈øini≈øter per≈øwa≈øion confederacie and procurement of one W. L. of E in the countie of D. yeoman, they the ≈øaid W. and M. do chalenge, and claim the ≈øaid lea≈øe to be to their own v≈øe & behoofe, coÃÑtrarie to the fore≈øaid tru≈øt ≈øo repo≈øed by your ≈øaid Orator in them the ≈øaid W. G. and M. and contrarie to the fore≈øaid v≈øe thereupon expre≈ø≈øed, at the time of the ≈øealing and deliuery of the fore≈øaid lea≈øe by your ≈øaid Orator vnto them as is afore≈øaid. And for as much as the fore≈øaid lea≈øe in writing is ab≈øolute without any v≈øe expre≈ø≈øed, or declared, in the deede of the ≈øame, And al≈øo ≈øeeing ≈øuch witne≈ø≈øes as your ≈øaid Orator hath for the proofe of the fore≈øaid v≈øe declared (at the time of the ≈øealing and deliuerie of the fore≈øaid lea≈øe) are now very aged, and impotent, and not likely to liue long, and doe inhabite and dwell within the countie of Y. and are not able to trauell to the Citie of London, and if they ≈øhould chance to die before they be examined concerning the prem ‚Ä¢ i≈ø≈øes, then were your ≈øaid Orator without all remedie, for proofe of the fore≈øaid v≈øe and tru≈øt ≈øo by him repo≈øed in the ≈øaide W. G. and M. his wife, (except by your good Lord≈øhip, it be granted vnto him, that he may haue a commi≈ø≈øion directed vnto ≈øuch per≈øons, as to your Lord≈øhip ≈øhall be thought meete, inhabiting in the ≈øaid countie of Y. for the examining of the fore≈øaide witne≈ø≈øes, in perpetuam rei memoriam, for the proofe of the fore≈øaid v≈øe and tru≈øt ≈øo repo≈øed by your ≈øaid Orator in the ≈øaid W. G. and M.) May it therefore plea≈øe your mo≈øt honorable Lord≈øhippe, the premi≈ø≈øes gratiou≈øly con≈øidered, to grant to your ≈øaid Orator &c.

MemorÃÑ. This direction is when there is neither Lord Chauncellor, nor Lord Keeper.
div.p:
HVmbly complaining, ≈øheweth vnto your Maie≈øtie, your faithfull Sect. 87. ≈øubiect W. P. of H. in the countie of L. gentlemam, that whereas
about the moneth of April which was in the yeare of our L. God 1590. one H. S. was lawfully po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of 62. ≈øcore Ewes, and 6. ≈øcore lambs, as of his own proper goods, & he being of theÃÑ ≈øo po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed about the ≈øame time did fell the ≈øame vnto your Maie≈øties ≈øaid ≈øubiect, for the ≈øumme of fiftie pounds of lawfull Engli≈øh money, or thereabouts to him paid by your ≈øaid ≈øubiect: By force of which bargaine your ≈øaid ≈øubiect was of the ≈øaid ≈øheepe lawfully po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, as of his owne proper goods, and he being thereof ≈øo po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, it was then agreed betweene your ≈øaide ≈øubiect, and the ≈øaid H. S. and one G. C. of A. in the countie of Y. hu≈øbandman, that the ≈øaid H. S. ≈øhould deliuer the ≈øame ≈øheepe to the ≈øaid G. C. to be ≈øafely kept by him to the v≈øe of your ≈øaide ≈øubiect, to be brought and deliuered to your ≈øaid ≈øubiect, at your ≈øaid ≈øubiect his dwelling hou≈øe in H. afore≈øaid in the ≈øaid county of Lincolne. And thereupon the ≈øaid G. C. in con≈øideration thereof, and in con≈øideration of forty ≈øhillings to him by the ≈øaide ≈øubiect to be paide at the deli ‚Ä¢ ery of the ≈øaid ≈øheepe, in forme afore≈øaid, did then a≈ø≈øume vpon him≈øelfe, and to your ≈øaid ≈øubiect did faithfully promi≈øe, that if the ≈øaid ≈øheepe were deliuered vnto him, according to the ≈øaid agreement, that then be the ≈øaid G. C. would well and ≈øafely keepe the ≈øame, and bring & deliuer them or cau≈øe the ≈øame to be brought and deliuered vnto your ≈øaide ≈øubiect, at his ≈øaid hou≈øe in H. afore≈øaid, within certaine time after that he ≈øhould ≈øo receiue the ≈øame: which time is long ≈øithence pa≈øt. And your highnes ≈øaid ≈øubiect further ≈øaith, that about the fir≈øt day of May next en≈øuing the ≈øaid agreement, and promi≈øe, all the ≈øaid ≈øheepe were deliuered vnto the ≈øaid G.
