C. at A. afore≈øaid, according to the ≈øaid agreement. But ≈øo it is, if it may plea≈øe your excellent Maie≈øtie, that the ≈øaid G. C. in his life time, imagining, & fraudulently intending, your ≈øaid ≈øubiect in this behalfe craftily & ≈øubtilly to defraud and deceiue, did not onely, not deliuer vnto your ≈øaid ≈øubiect the ≈øaid ≈øheepe, nor any of them, according to his ≈øaide faithfull promi≈øe, and a≈ø≈øumption: but contrariwi≈øe did take and conuert a great part of them to his owne proper v≈øe, ≈øelling ≈øome of them to diuers per≈øons to your ≈øaid ≈øubiect vnknowen for diuers ≈øummes of money conuerting the ≈øame to his owne v≈øe, and killing ≈øundrie other of them in his hou≈øe. And ≈øhortly after made his la≈øt Will and Te≈øtament in writing, and thereof con≈øtituted one R. C. his brother his Executor, and died po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the ≈øaid re≈øidue of the ≈øheepe. After who≈øe death the ≈øaid R. C. proued the fore≈øaid Te≈øtament, and al≈øo tooke vpon him the burthen and charge of the execution thereof, and by pretence of the ≈øaid re≈øidue of the ≈øaid ≈øixe ≈øcore & one Ewes, and ≈øixe≈øcore & one lambes being about foure≈øcore Ewes, and thre≈øcore Lambes, worth thirtie pound and aboue, came to the hands and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid R. C. who imagining, and fraudulently intending your ≈øaide ≈øubiect in this behalfe,
and ≈øubtilty of the ≈øaid ≈øheepe to defraud and deceiue, hath in like manner ≈øold the mo≈øt part of the ≈øaid Ewes, and Lambes, ≈øo comen to his hands and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, to diuers per≈øons to your ≈øaid ≈øubiect vnknowen, for diuers ≈øummes of money betweene them agreed vpon, and the money thereof ari≈øing hath conuerted to his onely v≈øe and behoofe: and albeit your ≈øaid ≈øubiect hath diuers times comen vnto him the ≈øaid R. C ≈øince the death of the ≈øaid G. C. gently requiring him either to deliuer vnto him your ≈øaid ≈øubiect ≈øuch & ≈øo many of the ≈øaid ≈øheep, ≈øo as is afore≈øaid, comen into his hands and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, or the very value thereof, which very value of ≈øuch other ≈øheepe as the ≈øaid G. C. had in his life time, ≈øo as is afore≈øaid ‚Ä¢ onuerted to his owne v≈øe, yet the ≈øaid R. C. notwith≈øtanding that after the death of the ≈øaid G. C. the goods, and chattels, which were the ≈øaid G. C. at the time of his death, ≈øufficient both to di≈øcharge, pay, and performe, all the debts, and legacies of the ≈øaid G. C. and to ≈øati≈øfie your Maie≈øties ≈øaid ≈øubiect, of and for ≈øuch, and ≈øo many of the ≈øaid ≈øheepe as came to the hands of the ≈øaid G. C. and neuer came to the hands, cu≈øtodie or po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of him the ≈øaid R. C. hath euer hitherto denied and refu≈øed, and yet doth deny and refu≈øe to yeeld vnto your ≈øaid ≈øubiect any ≈øati≈øfaction, or any recompence at all, either for the ≈øaid ≈øheepe, ≈øo as is afore≈øaid, conuerted to the onely v≈øe of the ≈øaid G. C. in his life time, ≈øo as is ≈øaid, either conuerted to the v≈øe of the afore≈øaid R. C. after the death of the ≈øaid G. or by him the ≈øaid R. ≈øtill vniu≈øtly detained and holden from your ≈øaid ≈øubiect, which vniu≈øt dealing of him the ≈øaid R. C. is to the greeuous lo≈ø≈øe and damages of your ≈øaid ≈øubiect, and altogether again≈øt all right, equity, and good con≈øcience. In tender con≈øideration whereof, and for ≈øo much as the ≈øaid promi≈øe of the ≈øaid G. C. ≈øo as is afore≈øaid made for the deliuery of the ≈øaid ≈øheepe as is afore≈øaid, was ≈øo made in the pre≈øence and hearing of the ≈øaid R. C. and of certaine other witne≈ø≈øes, which be now all dead, but the ≈øaid R. C. in ≈øo much as for want of ≈øuch proofe as is requi≈øite in that behalfe, he your ≈øaid ≈øubiect is without all remedie either to recouer the ≈øaid ≈øheepe, or any recompence for the ≈øame, either by the ≈øtrict cour≈øe of the common lawes of this Realme, or in this honorable court, otherwi≈øe then by the parties owne confe≈ø≈øion vpon his oath in this honorable court, which your ≈øaid ≈øubiect verely doth imagine and thinke, that he will confe≈ø≈øe to be in ≈øuch ≈øort, as is here afore≈øaid. It may therefore plea≈øe, &c.

div.head: The an≈øwere of R. C. to the Bill next before.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid defendant by prote≈øtation not acknowledging or confe≈ø≈øingSect. 88. the matters in the ≈øaid bill of complaint, containe ‚Ä¢ to betrue, in ≈øuch manner and forme, as in the ≈øame they be ≈øet forth and alleaged,
≈øaith, that the ≈øaid bill of complaint is verie vntrue, incertaine, and in≈øufficient in the law to be an≈øwered vnto, and the matters therein ≈øurmi≈øed are enuiou≈øly deui≈øed, and vnconcionably contriued, imagined and ≈øet forth, onely of purpo≈øe to vexe and mole≈øt this defendant vniu≈øtly, and to put him to great, trauell, expences and charges of ≈øuit and that without any iu≈øt cau≈øe, or good matter, as this defendant hopeth he ≈øhall proue vnto this honorable court, neuerthele≈ø≈øe, the aduantage of exception to the in≈øufficiency, and vncertaintie of the ≈øat ‚Ä¢ bill of complaint, and all other aduantages to this defendant, at all times hereafter ≈øaued, the ≈øaid defendant for an≈øwere vnto the ≈øaid bill of complaint ≈øaith, that he doth not certainly know, neither is he as he thinketh, compelable to take notice, whether one H. S. in the bill named, being about the moneth of Aprill, in the yeare of our Lord God 1590. lawfully po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of ≈øixe ≈øcore and one Ewes, and ≈øixe ≈øcore and one Lambes, as of his owne proper goods, did ≈øell the ≈øame vnto the ≈øaid complainant for the ≈øumme of fiftie pounds, as in the ≈øaid bill is ≈øuppo≈øed, or whether the ≈øaid complainant being lawfully po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the ≈øaid ≈øheepe, as of his owne proper goods by force of ≈øuch bargaine, there were anie ≈øuch agreement betweene the ≈øaid complainant, and the ≈øaid S. and one G. C. of A. in the Countie of Y. for the deliuerie of the ≈øaid ≈øheepe to the ≈øaid G. to be ≈øafely kept to the complainants v≈øe, and to be deliuered to the complainant at his dwelling hou≈øe in H. in the Countie of L. as in the ≈øaid bill is ≈øugge≈øted, this defendant as he thinketh is not bound now to take notice, being then a ≈øtranger thereunto, or whether the ≈øaid G. C. vpon the former part of the in≈øufficient con≈øideration grounded vpon the premi≈ø≈øes, or for, in, or vpon the latter, being a lame blanke and imperfect, or rather no con≈øideration, there naming nihil omnino to be by the ≈øaid complainant paied vnto the ≈øaid G. C. did a≈ø≈øume and faithfully promi≈øe vnto the complainant ≈øafely to keepe and deliuer the ≈øaid ≈øheepe, as in in the ≈øaid bill is alleaged, but this defendant ≈øaith, that if the a≈ø≈øumption be grounded vpon any good con≈øideration, then the complainant might haue his remedie at the common law, if he had any iu≈øt cau≈øe. And therefore this defendant, as he thinketh, might verie well demurre in lawe vpon the ≈øaid bill, and demaund iudgement, if he ≈øhall be by this honorable court compellable to an≈øwere the complainant any further. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe, for as much as this defendant hopeth that the ≈øaid complainant ≈øhall neuer be able to proue his ≈øubtill ≈øuppo≈øed ≈øugge≈øtions in the ≈øaid bill ≈øet forth, and alleaged, For further an≈øwere vnto the ≈øaid bill, ≈øaith, that true it is, that the ≈øaid G. C. in the ≈øaid bill mentioned, made his la≈øt Will and Te≈øtament in writing, and thereof con≈øtituted this defendant his executor, and died, without that, that the ≈øaid G. C. in his life time, imagining, and fra ‚Ä¢
dulently
intending the ≈øaid complainant in that behalfe craftily and ≈øubtilly to defraud and deceiue, did not onely, not deliuer vnto the ≈øaid complainant the ≈øaid ≈øheepe, nor any of them according to his ≈øaid faithful promi≈øe and a≈ø≈øumption, but contrariwi≈øe did take & conuert a great part of them to his owne proper v≈øe, ≈øelling ≈øome of them to diuers per≈øons to the ≈øaid complainant vnknowen, for diuers ≈øummes of money, conuerting the ≈øame to his v≈øe, and killing ≈øundrie others of them in his hou≈øe, and died po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the re≈øidue of the ≈øaid ≈øheepe, as in the ≈øaid Bill is vntruely and vncharitably alleaged again≈øt the ≈øaid G. C. being now dead. For this defendant verely doth thinke, and imagine in his con≈øcience, if ≈øuch ≈ø ‚Ä¢ eepe were deliuered to the ≈øaide G. C. to be kept and deliuered as is afore≈øaid, that then the ≈øaid G. did in his life time well and truely deliuer the afore≈øaide ≈øheepe accordingly: without that that after the death and departure of the fore≈øaid G. C. the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid re≈øidue of the ≈øaide ≈øixe ≈øcore and one Ewes, and ≈øixe ≈øcore and one Lambes, being about the full number of foure ≈øcore Ewes, and three ≈øcore Lambes worth thirtie pound and aboue, came to the handes and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaide R. C. now defendant, who imagining, and fraudulently intending the ≈øaid complainant in that behalfe craftily and ≈øubtilly of the ≈øaid ≈øheepe to defraud, and deceiue, hath in like manner ≈øolde mo≈øt part of the ≈øaid Ewes and Lambs ≈øo come to his hands and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, to ≈øundrie per≈øons to the ≈øaid complainant vnknowen, for diuers ≈øummes of money betweene them therefore agreed vpon, and the money thereof ari≈øing, hath conuerted to his onely v≈øe and behoofe, as in the ≈øaid bill of complaint is very fal≈øly ≈øurmi≈øed, ≈øet forth, and alleaged. And without that, that any other matter or thing in the ≈øaid bill materiall, to be an≈øwered vnto, and in this an≈øwere not ≈øufficiently an≈øwered, confe≈ø≈øed, and auoided, trauer≈øed, or denied, is true. All which matters, &c. and praieth, &c.

div.head: The Replication of W. P. Complainant to the aun≈øwere of R. C. Defendant.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid complainant for replication ≈øaith in all and euery thingSec' 89. and things, as he in the ≈øaid bill of complaint hath ≈øaid, and doth and will auerre, iu≈øtifie, maintaine, and proue his ≈øaid bill of complaint, in all and euery matter, thing and things therein contained to be good, iu≈øt and true, certaine, and ≈øufficient in the law to be an≈øwered vnto by the ≈øaid defendant in ≈øuch manner and forme as they be in the ≈øame mo≈øt truely ≈øet forth and declared, and not enuiou≈øly deui≈øed, nor vncon≈øcionably contriued, imagined, and ≈øet forth, onely of purpo≈øe to vexe and mole≈øt this defendant vniu≈øtly. And to put him to great trauell, expences and charges of ≈øuit, and that without any iu≈øt cau≈øe, or good matter
as in the ≈øaid an≈øwere, it is by the ≈øaid defendant vntruely ≈øurmi≈øed. And this complainant further ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid an≈øwere of the ≈øaid defendant is verie incertaine, vntrue and in≈øufficient in the law to be replied vnto by this complainant, for diuers apparant faults and imperfections therein contained. And namely in this, that the ≈øaid complainant, being in, and by the ≈øaid bil of complaint, charged to haue had in his hands and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, diuers of the ≈øaid ≈øheepe, in the ≈øaid bill mentioned, doth in in his ≈øaid an≈øwere neither confe≈ø≈øe nor denie the hauing thereof, as by the ≈øaid an≈øwere it appeareth, ≈øo that in rea≈øon he ought to be compelled by the order of this honorable Court, to make a better and more certaine and perfect an≈øwere vnto the ≈øaid bill of complaint, Neuerthele≈ø≈øe this defendant ≈øauing vnto him≈øelfe, at all times hereafter, all aduantage of exceptions to the manife≈øt incertainty and in≈øufficiency of the ≈øaid an≈øwere for further replication therunto, Al≈øo further ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid con≈øideration in the ≈øaid bill of complaint contained, is very ≈øufficient to maintaine the ≈øaid ≈øuit in this honorable Court, Albeit that no other thing had been departed with, on the part of this complainant, but onely the credite and deliuery of the ≈øaid ≈øheepe, vnto the handes of the ≈øaid G. C. and yet this complainant hopeth to proue, that there was giuen vnto the ≈øaide G. C. for and on the behalfe of the ≈øaide complainant, very good matter of con≈øideration for keeping and conueying of the ≈øaid ≈øheepe, as in the ≈øaid bill is alleaged. And further this repliant doth, & wil al≈øo auerre and proue, that diuers of the ≈øaide ≈øheepe ≈øince the death of the ≈øaid G. C. haue come to the hands and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid complainant, which haue bin vnlawfully conuerted to his owne v≈øe, again≈øt all right, equity, and good con≈øcience, without that, that any other matter, thing or things, clau≈øe, ≈øentence, article, or allegation in the ≈øaid an≈øwere contained materiall or effectuall in the law, to be replied vnto by this complainant, and not herein before in this his replication ≈øufficiently replied vnto, confe≈ø≈øed and auoided, denied or trauer≈øed is true. All which matters this complainant is ready to auerre and proue as this honorable Court ≈øhall award. And praieth as he in his ≈øaid bill hath praied.

div.head: A Bill for a debt vpon a contract without witne≈ø≈øes.
div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe complaining ≈øheweth vnto your honor, yourSect. 90. poore and daily Orator T. B. of C. in the countie of Darby Mercer, That were about two yeares now pa≈øt, one T. G. of B. in the Countie of Y. gentleman, bought of your ≈øaid Orator, xii. yeardes of li ‚Ä¢ nen cloth, price, xxii. sÃÑ. and diuers other wares and marchandices, amounting in the whole to the value of xx. markes or thereabout, for paiment whereof the ≈øaid T. G. earne≈øtly required your ≈øaid Orator to forbeare him the ≈øaid T. G. for the ≈øpace of a moneth or there abouts, then
next following, And for that the ≈øaid T. G. did then faithfully a≈ø≈øume and promi≈øe to pay the ≈øaid debt, vnto your ≈øaid Orator at the ≈øaid monethes ende, your ≈øaid Orator tru≈øting to his bare promi≈øe, deliuered vnto the ≈øaid T. G. the ≈øaid cloth, wares and marchandi≈øes, without taking any ≈øpecialty or other ≈øecurity for paiment of the afore≈øaid money, Now ≈øo it is, if it may plea≈øe your honorable L. that the ≈øaid G. T. perceiuing that your ≈øaid Orator can by no order of the common lawes of this Realme recouer the ≈øaid money for want of ≈øpecialtie or witne≈ø≈øes to proue the ≈øaid a≈ø≈øumption and contract, being very lately by your ≈øaid Orator, reque≈øted to pay the ≈øaid money according to his ≈øaid promi≈øe, yet neuertheles the ≈øaid T. G. hath plainely affirmed and an≈øwered, that your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhall not haue anie peny thereof, which if it ≈øhould ≈øo pa≈ø≈øe without reliefe to your Orator herein, would turne to the great impoueri≈øhment and damage of your ≈øaid Orator, who hath ouer many ≈øuch debtors. In con≈øideration whereof the premi≈ø≈øes tenderly con≈øidered, and fora≈ømuch as your ≈øaid Orator is without all remedie for the recouerie of the ≈øame by the ≈øtrict order of the common lawes of this Realme, for want of ≈øpecialtie or witne≈ø≈øe, as afore≈øaid. May it therefore plea≈øe &c.

div.head: The An≈øwere, and demurrer of the ≈øame.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid defendant ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid bill of complaint is very vncertaine,Sect. 91. vntrue and in≈øufficient in the law to be an≈øwered vnto by this defendant, for diuers apparant matters and cau≈øes therein contained, deui≈øed and exhibited into this honorable Court, as this def. verely thinketh by the ≈øini≈øter adui≈øe and per≈øwa≈øion of N. C. Atturney at the common law, of malice and euill will, to thintent to put this defendant to vniu≈øt trouble and vexation, That he the ≈øaid N. C. may thereby gaine, by ≈øolliciting of this ≈øaid matter in this honorable court, and not vpon anie iu≈øt cau≈øe ≈øo to doe. And further ≈øaith the ≈øaid def. That if the ≈øaid matters mentioned in the ≈øaid bill of complaint were true, as they be not indeed, yet were the ≈øame determinable and to be determined, at, and by the common lawes of this Realme, and not by this honorable Court, whereunto this defendant praieth to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed with his rea≈øonable co≈øtes and charges wrongfully ≈øu≈øtained hereabouts. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe if he this defendant be compelled by this honorable court to make any further an≈øwere vnto the ≈øaid incertainty, vntrue and in≈øufficient bill of complaint, Then (and not otherwaies) thaduantage of exception, to the manife≈øt incertainty and in≈øufficiency of the ≈øaid bill of complaint to this defendant alwaies ≈øaued. For further aun≈øwere thereunto, and for a full and plaine declaration of the truth touching the materiall contents of the ≈øaid bill
of complaint (if any ≈øuch be) he this defendant ≈øaith. That true it is indeed, that about three yeares now la≈øt pa≈øt, This ≈øaid defendant or ≈øome of his ≈øeruants to his v≈øe, did receiue of this complainant xii. yards of linnen cloth, halfe an ell of cloth, one quarter and a halfe of cloth, and two ≈øcaines of threed which he thinketh to be parcell of the ≈øaid wares in the ≈øaid bill mentioned, and ≈øuppo≈øed to be bought by this defendant of the ≈øaid complainant, which ≈øaid wares were ≈øo receiued by this defendant or to his v≈øe, as is afore≈øaid, to thintent that this defendant ≈øhould pay to the ≈øaid complainant, ≈øo much money for the ≈øame as ≈øhould be rea≈øonably agreed vpon by this defendant, and the ≈øaide complainant, which ≈øaid bargaine and agreement, this defendant is, and euer hitherto hath beene readie to haue performed, without that, that the ≈øaid defendant about two yeares now la≈øt pa≈øt, did buy of the ≈øaid complainant, the ≈øaid twelue yardes of linnen cloth, at, and for the ≈øaid price of xxii. sÃÑ. or the ≈øaid halfe elle of other cloth for the ≈øaid price of ii. sÃÑ. viii. d . or the ≈øaid quarter and a halfe of other cloth, and two ≈øcaines of threed for the ≈øaid price of xviii. d . for he this defendant ≈øaith, that he and this complainant did neuer to his remembrance agree to anie certaine price for the ≈øaid wares, as in the ≈øaid bill of complaint is vntruly alleaged. And without that, that he this defendant did euer buy of this complainant, the ≈øaid ten yards of beluet, or any part therof, or any other wares or marchandices amounting in the whole to twentie markes, or for the paiment thereof, euer required the ≈øaid complainant to for be are him the ≈øaid defendant, for the ≈øpace of one moneth then next following, as in the ≈øaide bill is wrongfully alleaged. And without that, that he this defendant did faithfully a≈ø≈øent and promi≈øe to pay the ≈øaid debt vnto the ≈øaid complainant at the ≈øaid monethes ende, Or that the ≈øaid complainant, tru≈øting the bare promi≈øe of this defendant, deliuered vnto him this defendant, the ≈øaid cloth, wares, veluet, and marchandi≈øe, as in the ≈øaid bill is vntruly alleaged. And without that, that he this defendant perceiuing that this complainant can by no order of the common lawes of this Realme, recouer any part of the ≈øaid money, for want of ≈øpecialtie or witne≈ø≈øe to prone the ≈øaid ≈øuppo≈øed a≈ø≈øumption and contract, hath plainely affirmed, that he the ≈øaid complainant ≈øhall not haue one penny thereof in ≈øuch manner and forme, as in the ≈øaie bill of complaint is mo≈øt vntruely and ≈ølaunderou≈øly alleaged, without that, that any other matter &c. thing, things, clau≈øe, ≈øentence, article, or allegation, in the ≈øaid bill of complaint contayned, materiall or effectuall in the law to be an≈øwered vnto by this defendant and not &c.

div.head: A Bill to be di≈øcharged of ≈øundrie bondes made by the Plaintife to diuers by the Defendants meanes vpon promi≈øe that they ≈øhould not preiudice them, laying open diuers cunning and lewde practi≈øes to circumuent the Plaintife.
div.p:
HVmbly complaining ≈øheweth vnto your honorable L. your daily Sect. 92. Orator I. M. of M. in the Countie of Y. yeoman, that whereas about ≈øixteene yeares now la≈øt pa≈øt, certaine debts, controuer≈øies, ≈øuits, and variances did ari≈øe betweene one T. L. of E. in the Countie of Y. yeoman, and your ≈øaid Orator, and certaine other freeholders of the Lord≈øhip of Eccle≈øall afore≈øaid, concerning the inclo≈øing, v≈øe, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and occupation of certaine parcels of wa≈øt or common ground called R. in E. afore≈øaid, wherein your ≈øaide Orator and other freeholders, and all tho≈øe who≈øe e≈øtate they then had, and yet haue in certaine lands in the ≈øaid Lo. by all the time, whereof there is no memory of man to the contrary, haue v≈øed to haue common of pa≈øture for their bea≈øts and cattel, vpon the ≈øaid lands leuant and couchantat all times of the yeare, at their wils and plea≈øures, as vnto their tenements belonging, which parcels of wa≈øte ground one N. S. E≈øquier before that time, had demi≈øed vnto the ≈øaid T. L. for certaine yeares then induring, for pacifying and ending of which ≈øaid ≈øuites and controuer≈øies, and of ≈øuch ≈øuits and controuer≈øies, as were then betweene the ≈øaid L. and S. touching the ≈øame and other things, your ≈øaid Orator and T. D. and other of the freeholders afore≈øaid, and the ≈øaid L. by the meanes and intreatie of the ≈øaid N. S. about the ≈øaid time did ≈øubmit them≈øelues to the order, arbitrement, and award of I. F. R. M. C. W. and E. H. touching the ≈øaid controuer≈øies, & to the end that the ≈øaid L. would be contented that the ≈øaid ≈øuites betweene him & the ≈øaid S. might rather by that means receiue a quiet ende, then by ertremitie of law, there being then great ≈øuits betweene the ≈øaid N. S. and L. which the ≈øaid L. would not otherwi≈øe compromit, your ≈øaid orator & the ≈øaid D. was bound vnto the ≈øaid L. in one obligation of C. l . & vnto the ≈øaid N. S. in one other obligation of C. l . for performance of the ≈øaid award, the ≈øaid N. S. then promi≈øing to your ≈øaid Orator, that within ≈øhort time after the making of the ≈øaid bond vnto him, he would haue cancelled or made voide the ≈øaide bond of C. pound, made by them vnto the ≈øaid N. S. the meaning of which bonde your ≈øaide Orator (being a ≈øimple vnlearned man) thought to haue reached no further, but to actes to haue bin done by him≈øelfe again≈øt the ≈øaid awarde, which he the rather ≈øo thought, becau≈øe the ≈øaid N. S. tolde him ≈øo, or to the effect, and they were onely ≈øo agreed to haue the condition thereof made before the making thereof. And the ≈øaid L. was al≈øo bound in an C. l . vnto your ≈øaid Orator, and the ≈øaid D
for the performance of this part of the ≈øaid awarde, And afterwardes, viz. about the xi. yeare of the raigne of the Queenes Maie≈øtie, that now is, the ≈øaid arbitrators made an awarde of the premi≈ø≈øes, that the ≈øaid L. ≈øhould haue inclo≈øed the ≈øaid grounds, during ≈øuch terme as he then had therein by the demi≈øe of the ≈øaid N. S. by Indenture without veration of your ≈øaid Orator the ≈øaid T. D. and other freeholders of the ≈øaid Lo. of E. by meanes of which awarde the ≈øaid L. enioyed the premi≈ø≈øes euer ≈øince the making thereof accordingly, without any vexation of the ≈øaid D. or your ≈øaid Orator, or any other the freeholders of E. afore≈øaid, vntill ≈øuch time as the ≈øaid L. cau≈øed the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes to be purcha≈øed or taken by lea≈øe, as lands concealed, and vniu≈øtly withholden from her Maie≈øtie, and thereupon cau≈øed ≈øuites to be commenced again≈øt diuers of the ≈øaid freeholders by information in the Ex. of intru≈øion ≈øuppo≈øed to be done by them into the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes, which ≈øuite ≈øo long continued, that a verdict and iudgement therein were had for the ≈øaid freeholders, whereby their title to the ≈øaid common being then in i≈ø≈øue, was ≈øpecially found as by the recordes thereof remayning in the ≈øaid court it plainly appeareth, wherupoÃÑ ≈øome of the ≈øaid freeholders (as this complainant thinketh) entred into the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes being vnfenced. And thereupon the ≈øaid L. commenced ≈øuite vpon the ≈øaid bond of an C. l . again≈øt your ≈øaid Orator and the ≈øaid D. albeit they neuer interrupted his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion in the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes, and the ≈øaid D. and your ≈øaid orator for their indempnity likewi≈øe pro≈øecuted ≈øuit vpoÃÑ their bond of an C. l . becau≈øe the ≈øaid L. in his part had not performed the ≈øaid award, by meanes whereof your ≈øaid Orator, and the ≈øaid D. obtained a verdict and iudgement again≈øt the ≈øaid L. for the ≈øaid C. l . L. his ≈øaid ≈øuit again≈øt them depending vntried, whereupon the ≈øaid L. ≈øeeing how vniu≈øtly he had dealt with the ≈øaid D. and your ≈øaid Orator about the premi≈ø≈øes perceiuing in what ieopardie he ≈øtood, and how in equity he ought not to haue recouered any thing again≈øt your ≈øaid Orator and the ≈øaid D. by his ≈øaid bond, nor haue had any reliefe for the ≈øaid C. l . ≈øo by them recouered again≈øt him, he the ≈øaid L. moued your ≈øaid Orator and the ≈øaid D. by ≈øundrie meanes to come to agreement with him for the ≈øaid C. l . ≈øo recouered again≈øt him, whereupon the ≈øaid D. and your ≈øaid Orator, intending a generall quietne≈ø≈øe for all bonds and matters concerning the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes, at the great and importunate ≈øuit of the ≈øaid L. and by the meditation of certaine hone≈øt men their friends, vpon the faithfull promi≈øe of the ≈øaid L. that he the ≈øaid L. woulde warrant him your ≈øaide Orator again≈øt the ≈øaid N. S. for his ≈øaid bond of an C. l . alleaging that N. S. had no cau≈øe to ≈øue the ≈øame, and that if he had, yet becau≈øe the matter of the ≈øaid bond principally concerned him the ≈øaid L. (as it did indeed) that if your ≈øaid Orator agreed with
him for the premi≈ø≈øes, that then the ≈øaid N. S. neither could nor would hurt him by rea≈øon of his ≈øaid bond, the ≈øaid iudgement for the ≈øaid C. l . was relea≈øed vnto the ≈øaid L. by your ≈øaid Orator hauing none other con≈øideration therefore, then his ≈øaid promi≈øe of quietnes and di≈øcharge of the ≈øaid N. S. his ≈øaid bond. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe not long after the ≈øaide agreement, the ≈øaid L. perceiuing him≈øelfe to be di≈øcharged of the ≈øaid iudgement, and entending the vtter vndoing of your ≈øaid Orator, contrary to his ≈øaid promi≈øe, practi≈øed with the ≈øaid N. S. touhing the ≈øaid bond by him and the ≈øaid D. made vnto the ≈øaid S. and procured the ≈øame to be put in ≈øuite again≈øt them in the Queenes Maie≈øties Bench. Albeit the ≈øaid N. S. had neuer any lo≈ø≈øe by rea≈øon of any act done again≈øt the ≈øaid bond to the valew of one penny, ≈øince which ≈øuit the ≈øaid N. S. and D. haue ≈øecretly growen to agreement betwene them≈øelues, to thintent to lay the whole penalty of the ≈øaid bond vpon your ≈øaid Orator, Notwith≈øtanding the ≈øaid faithfull promi≈øe of the ≈øaid N. S. to deliuer in the ≈øaid bond to be cancelled, and the ≈øaid L. his promi≈øe was to ≈øaue your ≈øaid Orator harmele≈ø≈øe again≈øt the ≈øaid N. S. for the ≈øame. Albeit the ≈øaid N. S. neuer had any lo≈ø≈øe or hinderance by rea≈øon of the premi≈ø≈øes, by means of your ≈øaid Orator, neither was any thing attempted or done by the ≈øaid freeholders again≈øt the ≈øaide L. contrary to the ≈øaid award, Otherwi≈øe then by the con≈øent of the ≈øaid N. S. who moued or procured the ≈øaid freeholders to enter into bond one to another, to heare the charges of ≈øuites for the defence of their ≈øaid title of common in the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall parcels of ground, called R. and T. promi≈øing them his aide and furtherance therein, vnto ≈øome of which bonds the ≈øaid N. S. hath ≈øub≈øcribed his owne name as a witne≈ø≈øe of the deliuery thereof, which their hard dealings again≈øt your ≈øaid Orator in the premi≈ø≈øes, are much again≈øt all right, equity, and con≈øcience, and to the vtter impoueri≈øhment and vndoing of your ≈øaid Orator, his poore wife and children, wherefore the premi≈ø≈øes graciou≈øly con≈øidered, and for as much a≈øwell the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes and agreements of the ≈øaid N. S. with your ≈øaid Orator, and the ≈øaid D. and the ≈øaid practi≈øe had betweene the ≈øaid N. S. and the ≈øaid L. to put the ≈øaid bonde in ≈øuite, as al≈øo the ≈øaide agreement made by the ≈øaid N. S. and the ≈øaid D. for ≈øtaying of his ≈øaide ≈øuite again≈øt the ≈øaid D. and al≈øo the ≈øaid promi≈øe or agreement of the ≈øaid L. to ≈øaue your ≈øaid Orator harmele≈ø≈øe again≈øt the ≈øaid N. S. for the ≈øaide bonde was ≈øecretly made among≈øt them≈øelues, & for that your ≈øaid Orator tru≈øted that they would faithfully haue performed the ≈øame to your ≈øaid Orator, called no witnes to be pre≈øent to heare the ≈øame promi≈øe made, and therefore is not able to produce any witnes to te≈øtifie the premi≈ø≈øes, nor hath any meanes to proue the ≈øame, other then by the aun≈øweres of the ≈øaid N. S. and T. L. who he verely thinketh will in their
an≈øweres to the premi≈ø≈øes confe≈ø≈øe the ≈øame: May it therefore plea≈øe your Lord≈øhip, of your accu≈øtomed goodne≈ø≈øe, to grant vnto your ≈øaid Orator the Queenes Maie≈øties mo≈øt gratious writ of Subpena, to be directed to the ≈øaid N. S. and T. L. and to either of them, thereby commaunding them, &c.

div.head: A Bill for practi≈øing with the plaintifes wife, to receiue of her the plaintifes goods, and for receipt and detaining thereof.
div.p:
HVmbly complaining ≈øheweth vnto your good Lord≈øhip, your daily Sect. 93. Orator L. I. of S, in the Countie of N. Gentleman, That whereas about foure or fiue yeares pa≈øt, your Orator being po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of diuers goods, and diuers ≈øummes of money, to a great valew, to the ende that C. C. of W. in the ≈øaid Countie of N. M. his wife, and A their daughter, now the wife of I. P. of H. in the ≈øaide Countie yeoman. might the better bring to pa≈ø≈øe, indirectly to gaine and get into their, or ≈øome of their cu≈øtodies and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, all, or the mo≈øt pact of the ≈øaid money and goods, and by that meanes defraude or defeat your Orator thereof, by continuall and ≈øini≈øter practi≈øe, in≈øtigation, and per≈øwa≈øion, then allured, prouoked, and inti≈øed A. I. decea≈øed, being then your Orators wife, to grow to ≈øome di≈øcord and variance with him, and to e≈øloine and conuey into their, or ≈øome of their keeping, all or the mo≈øt part of the ≈øaid money or goods, promi≈øing that the ≈øame ≈øhould be readie, and v≈øed for her v≈øe and behoofe: Now ≈øo it is, if it may plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, that by the ≈øaid lewde and ‚Ä¢ ad practi≈øes of the ≈øaid C. M. and A. P. and of diuers other per≈øons by their meanes, who≈øe names your Orator knoweth not, your Orators ≈øaid wife about foure or fiue yeares ≈øince, and at ≈øundrie times before, did with violence breake open ≈øome part of your Orators hou≈øe at S. afore≈øaid, his chi≈øts therebeing locked and did e≈ø≈øoine, ≈øteale, imbea≈øill, or conuey away from your Orator, ≈øeueral ≈øummes of money, and diuers parcels of his goods and hou≈øehold ≈øtuffe, a≈øwell in the night ≈øea≈øon as in the day time, to a very great value, the certainty whereof your Orator knoweth not, but is induced by good rea≈øon to beleeue, that it doth amount vnto the ≈øumÃÑ of one hundred pound at the lea≈øt, and deliuered, or cau≈øed the ≈øame to be deliuered vnto the cu≈øtodie and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid C. C. and M. his wife, or A. their daughter, or of ≈øome other per≈øon or per≈øons, by their or ≈øome of their meanes or con≈øents, whereof your Orator by ≈øome good meanes hauing had intelligence, hath ≈øundry times v≈øed ≈øpeech and communication with the ≈øaid C. M. and A. P. touching the ≈øame, and in mo≈øt gentle and friendly manner required to haue the ≈øaide money and goods ≈øo e≈ø≈øoined and imbea≈øiled, as afore≈øaid, to be to him re≈øtored, or el≈øe to haue ≈øome recompence for the ≈øame, but they haue vtterly refu≈øed
to doe eyther the one or the other, and doe ≈øtill refu≈øe to doe the ≈øame, and do conuert and di≈øpo≈øe the ≈øaid money and goods to their own v≈øes, whereby your Orator ≈øhal be vtterly thereof defeated, to his great hinderance and impoueri≈øhment, contrarie to all equitie, & good con≈øcience, vnle≈ø≈øe by your Lord≈øhips fauor he may be relieued in this mo≈øt honorable Court. Fora≈ømuch therefore as your Orator knoweth not the names or number of the ≈øaid confederates, nor the ≈øeueral & certaine times wherein the ≈øaid money and goods were conueyed away from him as afore≈øaid, nor the quantitie, nature, or valew of them, whereby to make any lawfull demaun ‚Ä¢ , or to v≈øe any action by the ≈øtrict cour≈øe of the common lawes of this Realme, again≈øt them the ≈øaid C. M. and A. P. or any other their confederates, for the≈øe great iniuries & wrongs, as afore≈øaid, but that the trueth and certainty of all the≈øe matters doe re≈øt in the priuate and proper notice of the ≈øaid C. C. and M. his wife, and A. their daughter, or of ≈øome one of them, who no doubt, vppon their corporall Oathes will di≈øclo≈øe and ≈øet downe the trueth and certaintie of all the≈øe matters: May it therefore plea≈øe your honorable Lord≈øhip, to grant vnto your Orator, the Queenes Maie≈øties gratious writ of Subpena, to be directed, &c.

div.head: The An≈øwere to the ≈øame.
div.p:
HHe ≈øaid defendants ≈øay, that the ≈øaid bill of complaint again≈øtSec' 94. them exhibited into this honorable Court is very incertaine, vntrue, and in≈øufficient in the law, to be an≈øwered vnto by the ≈øaid defendants, or any of them, for diuers and ≈øundrie apparant faultes and imperfections therein contained and deui≈øed, and exhibited into this honorable Court, partly of malice and euill will, without iu≈øt cau≈øe conceiued again≈øt the ≈øaid C. C. one of the≈øe defendants, to the intent thereby to vexe and mole≈øt him, and his ≈øaid wife and daughter, with vniu≈øt trauell and expences, but chiefly to the intent and purpo≈øe to wearie, impoueri≈øh, and terrifie him this defendant with ≈øuch ≈øuites, ≈øo that he ≈øhal neither be able nor willing to pro≈øecute the law again≈øt him the ≈øaid complainant, for diuers great ≈øummes of money which he oweth vnto him the ≈øaid C. C. this defendant, and vniu≈øtly detaineth from him, and not for anie good or iu≈øt cau≈øe of ≈øuite: Neuerthele≈ø≈øe, if by the order of this honorable Court, the≈øe defendants ≈øhall be inforced to make any further or other an≈øwere, to the ≈øaid incertaine, vntrue, and in≈øufficient Bill of complaint, then, and not otherwi≈øe, all aduantage of exception, to the manife≈øt incertaintie and in≈øufficiencie of the ≈øaid Bill of complaint, to the≈øe defendants, and euerie of them, at all and euery time and times hereafter ≈øaued. For further an≈øwere thereunto and for a full and plaine declaration of the truth of the premi≈ø≈øes, The≈øe defendants
≈øay, and euery one of them ≈øaith, thst neither they, nor any of thens by continuall & ≈øini≈øter practi≈øe, in≈øtigation, and per≈øwa≈øion, did not at any time allure, prouoke, & intice A. I. decea≈øed, then wife of the ≈øaid coÃÑ plainant, to grow to ≈øome di≈øcord with the ≈øaid complainant, & to e≈ø≈øoine and conuey into their, or any of their keeping, all or any of the ≈øaid money and goods, in the ≈øaid bill of complaint mentioned, promi≈øing that the ≈øame ≈øhould be readie and v≈øed for her v≈øe & behoofe, to the ende that they the≈øe def. or any of theÃÑ, might the better bring to pa≈ø≈øe indirectly to gaine or get into their cu≈øtody & po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, all, or the mo≈øt part of the ≈øaid money & goods, and by that meanes, to defeat and defraud the ≈øaid complainants thereof, as in the ≈øaid bill of complaint is very ≈ølaunderou≈øly, & mo≈øt vntruly alleaged: And the≈øe defendants further ≈øay, & euery of them ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid late wife of the ≈øaid complainant did neuer with violence breake open ≈øome part of the ≈øaid complainants ≈øaid hou≈øe at S. in the ≈øaid bill mentioned, nor his ≈øaid chi≈øts there being locked, nor did e≈ø≈øoine, imbea≈øill, or conuey away from the ≈øaid complainant, ≈øeuerall, or any ≈øumme or ≈øummes of money, & diuers, or any parcell of his goods, or hou≈øehold ≈øtuffe, either in the night ≈øea≈øon, or in the day time, by the practi≈øe of the≈øe def. or of any of theÃÑ, or of any other per≈øon or per≈øons, by their or any of their means, as in the ≈øaid bil of complaint is likewi≈øe very malitiou≈øly and vntruly ≈øurmi≈øed, without that, that the ≈øaid wife of the ≈øaid complainant euer deliuered, or cau≈øe to be deliuered the ≈øaid money and goods in the ≈øaid bill of complaint mentioned, or anie part thereof, vnto the cu≈øtodie, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the≈øe defendants, or of ≈øome of them, or of any other per≈øon or per≈øons, by their, or ≈øome of their meanes or con≈øents, as in the ≈øaid bill of complaint is al≈øo vntruely alleaged: And without that, that euer there was anie cau≈øe why the ≈øaid complainant did, or ≈øhould v≈øe any ≈øuch ≈øpeach and communication with the≈øe defendants, or anie of them touching the premi≈ø≈øes, or require to haue the ≈øaid money and goods ≈øuppo≈øed to be e≈ø≈øoined or imbezeled, to be to him re≈øtored, or to haue ≈øome recompence for the ≈øame, or that the≈øe defendants, or anie of them doe conuert and di≈øpo≈øe the ≈øaid money and goods or any part thereof, to their or any of their owne v≈øes, whereby the ≈øaid complainant ≈øhall be vtterly thereof defeated, to his great hinderance and impoueri≈øhment, contrarie to all right, equitie, and good con≈øcience, as in the ≈øa≈ød bill of complaint is likewi≈øe vntruely ≈øugge≈øted: And without that, that any other matter, thing, or things, clau≈øe, ≈øentence, article, or allegation, in the ≈øaid bill of complaint contained, materiall or effectuall in the lawe to be an≈øwered vnto, by the≈øe defendants, or anie of them, and not here in this their an≈øwers ≈øufficiently an≈øwered vnto, confe≈ø≈øed and auoided, denied or trauer≈øed, is true. All which matters, &c.

div.head: The Replication to the An≈øwere next before.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid complainant, for, and by way of replication ≈øaith, that hisSect' 95. ≈øaid bill of complaint, exhibited again≈øt the≈øe defendants into this mo≈øt honorable Court, is very certaine, true, and ≈øufficient in the law to be an≈øwered vnto, and not deui≈øed and exhibited into his mo≈øt honorable Court of malice and euill will, without cau≈øe conceiued again≈øt the ≈øaid C. C. one of the ≈øaid defendants, to thintent thereby to vexe and mole≈øt him his ≈øaid wife and daughter with vniu≈øt trauell and expences, as in the ≈øaid an≈øweres is vntruly alleaged, Nor chiefly to thintent and purpo≈øe ≈øo to wearie and impoueri≈øh and terrifie the ≈øaide C. C. with ≈øuch ≈øuites, that he ≈øhould neither be able nor willing to pro≈øecute the law again≈øt the ≈øaid complainant, for di ‚Ä¢ ers great ≈øummes of money, which he doth owe vnto him the ≈øaid C. C. and vniu≈øtly detained from him, but is exhibited vpon iu≈øt cau≈øe of ≈øuit, as the ≈øaid complainant doubteth not to make manife≈øt and proue vnto this honorable court, with that, that the ≈øaid def. or ≈øome one of them, by ≈øini≈øter, practi≈øe, in≈øtigation, and per≈øwa≈øion, did allure, prouoke, & intice the ≈øaid complainants wife to grow to ≈øome di≈øcord with the ≈øaid complainant, & to e≈ø≈øoine and conuey into their, or ≈øome, or one of their keepings the ≈øaid money & goods, in the ≈øaid bill of complaint mentioned, promi≈øing that the ≈øame ≈øhould be readie, & v≈øed for her v≈øe and behoofe, to the end that they might the better bring to pa≈ø≈øe, indirectly to gaine or get into their, or ≈øome, or one of their cu≈øtody & po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion the ≈øaid money & goods, & by that means to defeat & defraud the ≈øaid complainants thereof, as in the ≈øaid bill of coÃÑ plaint is very truly alleaged. And al≈øo with that, that the ≈øaid complainaÃÑts wife, did with violeÃÑce break open ≈øome part of the ≈øaid coÃÑplainants hou≈øe at S. in the ≈øaid bill mentioned, & his ≈øaid chi≈øt there being locked did e≈ø≈øoine, ≈øteale, imbea≈øil, & conuey away from the ≈øaid coÃÑplainant, ≈øeuerall ≈øums of money, & diuers parcels of his goods & hou≈øhold ≈øtuffe in the night ≈øea≈øon, & in the day time, by the practi≈øe of the ≈øaid def. or ≈øome, or one of them, or of ≈øome other per≈øon or per≈øons, by their, or ≈øome, or one of their means, as in the ≈øaid bil of complaint is likewi≈øe very truly declared: And with that, that the ≈øaid complainants wife did deliuer, or cau≈øe to be deliuered the ≈øaid money & goods, in the ≈øaid bill of coÃÑplaint mentioned, vnto the cu≈øtody and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid def. or of ≈øome, or one of them, or of ≈øome other per≈øon or per≈øons, by their, or ≈øome, or one of their meanes or con≈øent, as likewi≈øe in the ≈øaid bil of complaint is mo≈øt truly alleaged: And without that, that there was cau≈øe why the ≈øaid coÃÑplainant ≈øhould v≈øe ≈øpeech & communication with the ≈øaid defendants, or ≈øome, or one of them touching the premi≈ø≈øes, & require to haue the ≈øaid mony & goods e≈ø≈øoined & imbea≈øiled to be to him re≈øtored, or to haue ≈øome
recompence for the ≈øame: And that the ≈øaid defendants, or ≈øome, or one of them do conuert and di≈øpo≈øe the ≈øaid money and goods, to their, or ≈øome, or one of their v≈øes, whereby the ≈øaid complainant ≈øhall be vtterly defeated thereof, to his great hinderance, as in the ≈øaide Bill of complaint is likewi≈øe mo≈øt truly alleaged: without that, that any other matter, cau≈øe, or thing, materiall or effectuall in the ≈øaid an≈øweres contained, to be by the ≈øaid complainant replied vnto, and herein not ≈øufficiently replied vnto, confe≈ø≈øed and auoided, &c.

div.head: A Bill far that the Defendant hath got the Plaintifes bill for payment of money by them into their hands, and thereby meane to defraude him of the ≈øame.
div.p: HVmbly complaining ≈øheweth vnto your good Lord≈øhip, your dailySect' 96. Orator N. T. of T. in the Countie of D. yeoman. That whereas about two yeares now la≈øt pa≈øt, your ≈øaid Orator did ≈øell vnto one I. M. G. W. P. T. alias S. and R. H. foure oxen, and three kine, for 14. pound of lawfull Engli≈øh money, And at the ≈øame time made vnto your ≈øaid Orator a Bill of their hands for the payment thereof, at the fea≈øt of S. Michaell tharchangell la≈øt pa≈øt: But now ≈øo it is, if it may plea≈øe your L. that the ≈øaid bill of 14. pound is by ca≈øuall meanes come vnto the hands and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid I. M. G. W. P. T. alias S. and R. H. or of ≈øome of them, who haue cancelled and defaced the ≈øame bill, And therefore, albeit they haue beene diuers times gently required by your ≈øaid Orator, to pay vnto him the ≈øaid 14. pound ≈øo to him due, yet that to doe, they and euery of them haue hitherto denied and refu≈øed, and yet doe denie and refu≈øe to doe the ≈øame, again≈øt all right, equitie, and good con≈øcience. In due con≈øideration whereof, and for that your ≈øaid Orator hath no remedie to recouer the ≈øaid 14. pound without the ≈øaid bill, by the common lawes of this Realme: May it therefore plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, &c.

div.head: A Bill for wrongfull entering into Copyhold lands intailed, detayning of them, and of the writings of the ≈øame, for wasting the ≈øame, and concontriuing ≈øecret e≈øtates thereof.
div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe ≈øheweth vnto your good L. your daily OratorSect. 97. A. G. of D. in the Countie of D. That whereas one T. G. father vnto your ≈øaid Orator, was in his life time lawfully ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne as of fee taile, to him and to his heires males of his body lawfully begotten, of, and in one me≈øuage or tenement with thappurtenances, ≈øcituate, lying, and being in W. in the ≈øaid Countie of D. And was likewi≈øe ≈øei≈øed to him, and the heires males of his body lawfully begotten, of, and in foure cottages, three clo≈øes or pa≈øtures, and eight acres of
arrable land with their appurtenacces, lying and being in W. afore≈øaid, being cu≈øtomarie lands, and holden of the Q. Mate≈øtie, as of her highne≈ø≈øe manor of W. afore≈øaid, at the will of the Lord, according to the cu≈øtome of the ≈øaid manor: And the ≈øaid T. G. being of all and ≈øinguler the premi≈ø≈øes, with their and euery of their appurtenances ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, as afore≈øaid, of ≈øuch e≈øtate, died thereof ≈øei≈øed, By and after who≈øe death, all and ≈øinguler the premi≈ø≈øes with their appurtenances, did di≈øcend vnto H. G. as ≈øonne and next heire male of the bodie of the ≈øaide T. by force and vertue whereof, the ≈øaid H. entred into all and ≈øinguler the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes with their appurtenances, and was thereof lawfully ≈øei≈øed to him, & the heires males of his body lawfully begotten. And he ≈øo being therof ≈øei≈øed, of ≈øuch an e≈øtate died ≈øei≈øed: By & after who≈øe death, all and ≈øinguler the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes with their appurtenances, did di≈øcend and come to T. G. as ≈øonne & next heire male of the bodie of the ≈øaid H. by force wherof, he the ≈øaid T. entred into al & ≈øinguler the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes, & was thereof lawfully ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne, as of fee taile, to him and the heires males of his body lawfully begotten. And he the ≈øaid C. ≈øo being therof ≈øei≈øed, of ≈øuch an e≈øtate died ≈øei≈øed, without any i≈ø≈øue male of his bodie, By & after who≈øe death, all and ≈øinguler the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes with their appurtenances, did di≈øcend and come vnto your ≈øaid Orator, as brother & next heire male of the ≈øaid T. G. But now, ≈øo it is, if it may plea≈øe your good L. that a≈øwel the ≈øaid deed of intail, & al other the deeds euidences, e≈øcripts, writings, & muniments, manife≈øting, for feiting, defending, & prouing the e≈øtate, right, intere≈øt, & title of your ≈øaid orator, of in, & to the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes, are by ≈øome ca≈øuall or ≈øini≈øter meanes comen into the hands, cu≈øtody or po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of one R. W. & E. his wife T. C. & A. his wife I. D. & I. W. or ≈øome of them, who by colour thereof haue entred into the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes, & receiued, perceiued, & taken the i≈ø≈øues, profits, & commodities thereof, & conuerted the ≈øame to their owne proper v≈øes & behoofes, without yeelding any con≈øideration or recompence to your ≈øaid orator for the ≈øame. And yet not ≈øo coÃÑtented, but they the ≈øaid R. E. T. A. I. & I. by colour of hauing the ≈øaid deeds, euideÃÑces, e≈øcripts, writings, & myniments haue not only made great ≈øtreppe, & wa≈øt of the premi≈ø≈øes, but al≈øo contriued & made to them≈øelues, & to other per≈øons vnknowen to your ≈øaid orator, diuers & ≈øundry ≈øecret e≈øtates & conueiances of the premi≈ø≈øes to the plaine di≈øinheri≈øon of your ≈øaid orator, contrary to all right, equity, & good con≈øcience. And although your ≈øaid Orator hath diuers & ≈øundry times by him≈øelfe & his friends, reque≈øted the ≈øaid R. W. & E. his wife. T. C. & A. his wife, I. D. & I. W. and euery of them to yeeld vp the quiet po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the premi≈ø≈øes, & to deliuer vnto your ≈øaid Orator the ≈øaid deeds, euidences, e≈øcripts, writings, & muniments, yet they & euery of them, ≈øo to do, haue vtterly refu≈øed & denied,
and ≈øtill do denie and refu≈øe, contrary to all right, equity, & good con≈øcience. In tender con≈øideration whereof, and for a≈ømuch as your ≈øaid Oratr knoweth not the contents nor certaine dates of the ≈øaid deeds, euidences, e≈øcripts, writings, and myniments, nor weather they be contained in bagge or boxe ≈øealed, in che≈øt, or cubbord locked. And therefore is at, and by the ≈øtrict cour≈øe of the common law of this Realme remedile≈ø≈øe for the recouery of the ≈øame. May it therefore, &c.

div.head: A Bill for deteining of an Indenture of lea≈øe for yeares.
div.p:
HVmbly complaining ≈øheweth vnto your honorable L. your dailySect. 98. Orator I. B. of N. in the pari≈øh of A. in the Countie of Y. E≈øquier. And T. B. ≈øonne and heire apparant of the ≈øaid I. That whereas your ≈øaid Orator the ≈øecond day of Iuly, in the eight yeare of the raigne of our ≈øoueraigne Ladie the Queenes Maie≈øtie that now is, did demi≈øe and to ferme let vnto one R. M. of B. in the ≈øaid Countie ye ‚Ä¢
man, all his moitie, or one halfe of his me≈ø≈øuage or tenement called D. with all the lands, meadows, clo≈øes, pa≈øtures, & commons vnto the ≈øame belonging or in any wi≈øe appertayning, from the fea≈øt of Saint M. the Bi≈øhop la≈øt pa≈øt, before the date aboue≈øaid, vnto the full end and terme of 18. yeares then next en≈øuing, fully to be complete & ended. By vertue of which demi≈øe afore≈øaid, R. M. into the me≈øuage or tenemeÃÑt afore≈øaid, did enter as was lawful for him to do. And now ≈øitheÃÑce the making of the lea≈øe afore≈øaid, the ≈øaid R. M. did often repaire & come to the hou≈øe of the ≈øaid I. B. & by that meanes in ≈øhort time became very familiar with the ≈øaid I. in≈øomuch that he the ≈øaid I. being aged, & by rea≈øon therof al≈øo lieth bedriden, & hath done for the ≈øpace of many yeares, And finding the ≈øaid M. to be very diligent and carefull about him the ≈øaid I. for the recouery of his health, did ≈øo affect the ≈øaid M. as y‚Ä¢ he did wholly commit the cu≈øtody & keeping of all his euidences, lea≈øes, bonds, & bils, among≈øt which the counterpaine of the ≈øaid M. his lea≈øe was. And vnle≈ø≈øe the ≈øaid M. together with ≈øome of your ≈øaid Orators ≈øeruants haue ≈øecretly conuaied & taken it away, as your ≈øaid Orator doth vehemently ≈øu≈øpect, in that he wanteth the ≈øame lea≈øe: by rea≈øon whereof he neither knoweth what conditions are contained in the ≈øame, neither what penaltie, if the rent be behind, or whether there be any di≈øtre≈ø≈øe for not paiment of the rent, or el≈øe whether the lea≈øe be vtterly void, if the rent be not paid at a day certaine & what other couenants it containeth for prohibiting of wa≈øt to be done, as al≈øo for the repairing of the me≈ø≈øuage or tenement afore≈øaid with needfull reparations, with diuers other couenaÃÑts to many good purpo≈øes ≈øpecified in ye ≈øame lea≈øe. Add for that al≈øo y‚Ä¢ the ≈øaid couÃÑterpain is by ≈øome ≈øuch indirect means as before is aleaged come vnto ye hands of the ≈øaid M. as al≈øo for that your orator through
want thereof by the ≈øtrict cour≈øe of the common lawes of this land cannot duely puni≈øh the breach of all, or any the couenants therein expre≈ø≈øed, which on the ≈øaid M. his part ought to haue beene performed and kept, for want of the ≈øaid counterpaine. May it therefore plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, &c.

div.head: A Bill for money for bording with one, who≈øe Executor the Plaintife is.
div.p:
HVmbly complaining, ≈øheweth vnto your honorable Lord≈øhip yourSect'. 99. daily Orator D. C. of B. in the Countie of D. yeoman, executor of the la≈øt Will and Te≈øtament of D. C. his father. That whereas about the fir≈øt day of Iune, which was in the 18. yeare of the raigne of our mo≈øt gratious ≈øoueraigne Lady the Queenes mo≈øt excellent Maie≈øtie that now is, one W. S. of M. in the ≈øaid Countie yeoman, at B. afore≈øaid, did put him≈øelfe and A. then his wife to borde with the ≈øaide D. C. the Te≈øtator, and there to remaine ≈øo long with the ≈øaid Te≈øator as it ≈øhould plea≈øe both the ≈øaid parties, and the ≈øaid W. S. in con≈øideration there of, there faithfully agreed to pay, and ≈øati≈øfie for the ≈øame, vnto the ≈øaid D. C. the Te≈øtator or his executors, during ≈øuch time as he and his ≈øaid wife ≈øhould remaine at borde with the ≈øaid Te≈øtator, ≈øo much lawfull Engli≈øh money, as the ≈øaid bording ≈øhould be rea≈øonably worth, and at ≈øuch time as he ≈øhould be thereunto required. By vertue of which putting to borde, agreement, and faithfull promi≈øe, the ≈øaide W. and A. his wife, were at borde with the ≈øaid Te≈øtator by the ≈øpace of three whole yeares, or thereabouts, during all which time the ≈øaid Te≈øtator at his owne co≈øtes and charges did finde vnto the ≈øaid W. and A. conuenient, and nece≈ø≈øacie meate, drinke, and lodging, and at ≈øundrie times Hay, and Gra≈ø≈øe for the Hor≈øes of the ≈øaid W. which bording, Hay, and Gra≈ø≈øe, by the ≈øaid ≈øpace of three yeares afore≈øaid, was rea≈øonably worth fortie pounds at lea≈øt. Yet the ≈øaid W. not ignorant of the premi≈ø≈øes, nor regarding his ≈øaid faithfull agreement and promi≈øe, but imagining, and fraudulently intending the ≈øaid D. C. the Te≈øtator, and your ≈øaid Orator his executor in this behalfe, craftily and deceiptfully to deceiue and defraud: albeit he hath beene oftentimes thereunto gently required by the ≈øaid Te≈øtator in his life time, and by your ≈øaide Orator, his executor, after his death, hath not paid or ≈øati≈øfied any thing vnto the ≈øaid Te≈øtator in his life time, nor vnto your fore≈øaid Orator after his decea≈øe for the ≈øame bording, meate, drinke, & lodging during the fore≈øaid time, that he and his ≈øaid wife ≈øo remained at borde with the ≈øaid Te≈øtator, according to his ≈øaid faithfull promi≈øe, and agreement, but hath euer hitherto, denied and refu≈øed therefore to ≈øati≈øfie and pay the ≈øaid Te≈øtator in his life time, and your ≈øaid Orator after his death,
and yet doth denie and refu≈øe to pay and ≈øati≈øfie your ≈øaid Orator for the ≈øame, again≈øt all right, equitie, and good con≈øcience, and to the hinderance of the execution of the ≈øaid la≈øt Will and Te≈øtament of the ≈øaid Te≈øtator. In tender con≈øideration whereof, and for ≈øo much as your ≈øaid Orator hath none ordinarie remedie to recouer any thing for the ≈øaid bording, and premi≈ø≈øes by the ≈øtrict cour≈øe of the common lawes of this our Realme of England, as well for that it was not certainely agreed vpon betweene the ≈øaid W. and the ≈øaide Te≈øtator, howe much the ≈øaid W. ≈øhould yeeld for the ≈øame: as al≈øo for that the ≈øaide Te≈øtator did ≈øo much credite the ≈øaid W. that the ≈øaid promi≈øe and agreement was priuately made betweene them≈øelues, no per≈øon being thereunto called that might witne≈ø≈øe the ≈øame, ≈øo that if happily the ≈øaid W. will not vpon his oath in his an≈øwere hereunto in this honorable Court, confe≈ø≈øe the ≈øaid promi≈øe and agreement, as your ≈øaide Orator is verely thinketh he will, your ≈øaid Orator is vtterly de≈øtitute of witne≈ø≈øes to make proofe thereof. Albeit that it be mo≈øt true, that the ≈øaide agreement and promi≈øe, was made and agreed vpon, as is afore≈øaid, which your ≈øaid Orator hath ≈øundrie times heard the ≈øaid Te≈øtator ≈øay and declare: May it plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhippe, to grant vnto your ≈øaid Orator, &c.

div.head: A Bill for not entering into bonde to ≈øaue a ≈øuretie harmele≈ø≈øe according to promi≈øe.
div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe complaining ≈øheweth vnto your Honor, your daily Orator R. P. of W. in the Countie of S. yeoman, That whereasSect. 100. as one F. L. of S. in the ≈øaid Countie of S. yeoman, did borow of one A. B. of S. in the ≈øaid Countie of S. Gentleman, the ≈øumme of ≈øeuenteeue pounds and twelue ≈øhillings, of good and lawfull money of England, to, and for the onely v≈øe of him the ≈øaid F. L. and of one R. L. of B. in the ≈øaid Countie of S. yeoman, kin≈øman to the fore≈øaid F. L. and for the true di≈øcharging and paiment of the fore≈øaide ≈øumme of ≈øeuenteene pounds, and twelue ≈øhillings, becau≈øe the ≈øaid R. L. was a man e≈øteemed to be of verie ≈ømall credit, and altogether vnknowen vnto the ≈øaid A. B. therefore the fore≈øaid R. L. earne≈øtly reque≈øted, and de≈øired of your ≈øaid Orator, being his neere neighbour, and of verie long acquaintance & familiaritie with him to enter into bond with him the ≈øaid F. L. to the ≈øaid A. B. for the true payment, and ≈øati≈øfaction of the fore≈øaid ≈øum of ≈øeauenteene pounds, and 12. SÃÑ. and if in ca≈øe your ≈øaid Orator would enter into bonde for him, then he the ≈øaid R. L. did faithfully promi≈øe, and affirme vnto your ≈øaid Orator to enter into a counter bond of double value to his bo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ vnto your ≈øaid Orator, to di≈øcharge, and faue him harmele≈ø≈øe again≈øt the ≈øaid A. B. his executors and admini≈øtrators, of, and from all manner of actions, ≈øuites, arre≈øtes,
quarrels, troubles, mole≈øtations, and incumbrances what≈øoeuer, which ≈øhould or might ari≈øe by rea≈øon or meanes of the ≈øaid obligation: wherupon your fore≈øaid Orator (con≈øidering the great want and need that the fore≈øaide R. L. did at that time ≈øtand in) tru≈øting to his fayre ≈øpeeches and promi≈ø≈øes, after long entreatie and reque≈øt to him made your ≈øaid Orator did con≈øent and agree to become bounden with the ≈øaid F. L. to the fore≈øaid A. B. for the paiment of the ≈øaid ≈øumme of ≈øeuentie pounds twelue ≈øhillings, ≈øo that your ≈øaide Orator might haue ≈øuch a counterbond from the ≈øaid R. L. to di≈øcharge & ≈øaue him harmele≈ø≈øe again≈øt the ≈øaid A. B. for and concerning the ≈øaid bond, after which time, that is to ≈øay, the 25. day of March, in the xxix. yeare of the raigne of our ≈øoueraigne Lady the Queenes Maie≈øtie that now is, The ≈øaide F. L. and your ≈øaid Orator by their writing obligatory, did bind the ≈øaid A. B. in the ≈øummr of xl. pound, of good and lawfull money of England, vpon this condition indorced vpon the ≈øaide writing obligatorie, viz. that if the ≈øaid F. L. and the ≈øaid R. P. your ≈øaid Orator, or eyther of them, their heires, executors, admini≈øtrators, of them, or any of them did well and truely content and pay vnto the ≈øaid A. B. his executors and admini≈øtrators, the ≈øaid ≈øumme of xvii. l . xii. sÃÑ. of good and lawfull money of England, at, or vpon the xxv. day of March, in the yeare of our Lord God, one thou≈øand fiue hundred eightie and eight, in the Church porch of S. betweene the howers of one and three of the clocke in the after noone of the ≈øame day, that then the ≈øaid writing obligatorie to be void and of no effect, or el≈øe to ≈øtand in full force and vertue: But ≈øo it is right honorable, that the ≈øaid ≈øumme of xvii. l . xii. sÃÑ. was not paide vnto the ≈øaid. A. B. at the time and place mentioned in the ≈øaid condition, whereby the ≈øaid bond of xl. pound, wherein the ≈øaid F. L. and your ≈øaid Orator were bounden to the ≈øaid A. B. was, and yet continueth forfaited, the ≈øaid A. B. being not paide nor agreed withall, by rea≈øon whereof, your H. ≈øaid orator is like to grow to great trouble and ≈øuite of law for the ≈øaid bond: And albeit your honors ≈øaid Orator hath diuers and ≈øundry times ≈øithence the making of the ≈øaid bond, promi≈øe, and a≈ø≈øumption, mo≈øt earne≈øtly reque≈øted the ≈øaide R. L. to make vnto your honors ≈øaid Orator a counterbond, for the di≈øcharging and ≈øauing harmele≈ø≈øe of your ≈øaid Orator, again≈øt the ≈øaid A. B. for, and concerning the ≈øaid bond, according to his ≈øaid a≈ø≈øumption and promi≈øe, yet that ≈øo to doe, the ≈øaid R. L. hath denied and refu≈øed euer hitherto, and yet doth denie and refu≈øe to do the ≈øame, contrary to al right, equitie, and good con≈øcience: In tender con≈øideration whereof, and for a≈ømuch as your ≈øaid Orator hath no ≈øufficient witne≈ø≈øe and wordes of a≈ø≈øumption to maintaine an action vpon this ca≈øe at the common lawe, meaning nothing but plainely, whereby he is void of all remedy at the
common law: May it therefore plea≈øe your honour, the premi≈ø≈øes con≈øidered, to grant vnto your ≈øaid Orator, the Queenes Maie≈øties mo≈øt gratious writ of Subpena, to be directed to the ≈øaid R. L. &c.

div.head: A Bill for making fal≈øe Affidauit for apparance.
div.p: IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe ≈øheweth vnto your good Lord≈øhip, your Lo. Orator Sect' 101. M. F. of L. Gentleman. That whereas vpon ≈øuite heretofore and yet depending in this honorable Court, betweene your Lo. ≈øaide Orator then plaintife, and one R. A. defendant in the ≈øaid ≈øuit, her Maie≈øties writ of Subpena was out of this ≈øaid Court vnto the ≈øaid R. A. directed, commaunding him thereby at a certaine day therein limitted, to appeare before your Lo. in the ≈øaid Court, and to an≈øwere to your L. ≈øaid Orator, in, and touching the ≈øaid ≈øuite: Now ≈øo it is, and it may plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, that the ≈øaid R. A. not hauing any regard of her Maie≈øties ≈øaid proce≈ø≈øe of Subpena, ≈øo to him directed, but ≈øeeking deceiptfully and fraudulently to neglect and di≈øobey the ≈øame, procured one E. B. his ≈øeruant, a very lewde per≈øon and fit mini≈øter for ≈øuch a purpo≈øe, to come vnto this honorable Court of Chancery, and there mo≈øt corruptly, fal≈øely, and periuriou≈øly, to ≈øwere and depo≈øe vpon the holy Euangeli≈øt, that the ≈øaid R. A. at that time was lame and not able to trauell to this Court, without great danger a ‚Ä¢ his health, for that the paines of his lamene≈ø≈øe was ≈øuch, that he was per≈øwaded by his friends to goe to the Bath, being thirtie miles di≈øtant from his dwelling hou≈øe, or thereabouts, and that he was gone to the ≈øaid place with much a doe, and there remained at the taking of his ≈øaide Oath, wherein the ≈øaid E. B. by the meanes, ≈øubornation, and procurement of the ≈øaid R. A. hath mo≈øt wickedly committed mo≈øt willfull and corrupt periurie, Fora≈ømuch as the ≈øaid R. A. was at that time in very good and perfect health, ability, and ≈øoundne≈ø≈øe of bodie, without any manner of lamene≈ø≈øe or debilitie, ≈øo as he might haue verie well trauelled without hurt or daunger of his health, and was at that time at C. in the County of L. and not at Bath, as the ≈øaid E. B. in his ≈øaid depo≈øition mo≈øt vntruely depo≈øed. May it therefore plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, &c.

div.head: A Bill to be relieued of an Obligation with condition for that the money was paide accordingly.
div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe complaining ≈øheweth vnto your good Lord≈øhippe,Sect. 102. your daily Orator N. K. of F. in the Councie of D. hu≈øbandman, and I. B of A. in the ≈øame Countie hu≈øbandman. That where one N. B. of F. in the Countie of S. Gentleman, hauing neede to v≈øe and borrowe money for his nece≈ø≈øarie v≈øe, entreated your ≈øaide
Orator to borrow of one M. E. of A. in the ≈øaid Countie of D. widow, the ≈øumme of xx. l . which your ≈øaid Orator did according to the reque≈øt of the ≈øaid N. And for the repayment therof to the ≈øaid M. your ≈øaid Orator became bound to her the ≈øaid M. by obligation, in the ≈øumme of fortie pounds with condition, for the payment of the ≈øaid twentie pound at a day now pa≈øt, which twentie pounds he the ≈øaid N. hath well and truely contented, ≈øati≈øfied, and paid to the ≈øaid M. according to the condition afore≈øaid: Which notwith≈øtanding, ≈øo it is if it may plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, yet doth the ≈øaid M. again≈øt all good dealing detaine the ≈øaid obligation in her hands, notwith≈øtanding ≈øundrie reque≈øtes made vnto her by your ≈øaid Orator, for the deliuerie thereof, again≈øt all right, equitie, and good con≈øcience, minding as it ≈øhould ≈øeeme to put the ≈øame in ≈øuite, eyther again≈øt your Orator or his executors when opportunity ≈øerueth. In tender con≈øideration whereof, and fora≈ømuch as your ≈øaid Orator hath not any ordinarie remedie by the cour≈øe of the common law, to compell the ≈øaid M. to deliuer the ≈øaid bond, or to cancell the ≈øame according as in right ≈øhe ought to doe. May it plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip to grant, &c.

div.head: A Bill for that the Plainiife hath not according to promi≈øe, procured an acquittance for rents by him paide to the Defendant by the appointment of his le≈ø≈øor.
div.p:
HVmbly complaining ≈øheweth vnto your honorable Lord≈øhip, your Sec' 103. daily Orator I. M. of M. in the Countie of Yorke yeoman. That whereas about the fir≈øt yeare of the Raigne of the late King Edward the ≈øixt, one I. M. late father of your ≈øaid Orator was lawfully ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne, as of fee, of, and in certaine lands and tenements with the appurtenances in S. and within the pari≈øh of S. in the ≈øaid Countie, and being thereof ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, died thereof ≈øo ≈øei≈øed. By and after who≈øe death the ≈øaid tenements and premi≈ø≈øes with the appurtenances di≈øcended and came as of right they ought to di≈øcend and come to your ≈øaid Orator as ≈øonne and next heire of him the ≈øaid I. M. after who≈øe death your ≈øan ‚Ä¢ Orator entered into the ≈øaid tenements and premi≈ø≈øes with the appurtenances, and was thereof ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne as of fee, and being thereof ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, one me≈øuage or tenement, one garden, one orchard, one clo≈øe or croft, therunto adioining, diuers, lands, meadowes and pa≈øtures, parcell of the premi≈ø≈øes, were a≈ø≈øigned to A. M. late wife of the ≈øaid I. M. decea≈øed for her dower of the ≈øaid lands of her ≈øaid hu≈øband, by force whereof ≈øhe was thereof ≈øei≈øed in her deme≈øne, as of freehold, and ≈øhe being thereof ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, afterwards, that is to ≈øay, about the ≈øixt day of Iune, in the fourth and fifth yeare of the Raigne of King Phillip and Queene Marie, by Indenture dated the day and
yeare aboue≈øaid, granted and to ferme did let vnto your ≈øaid Orator the ≈øaid lands, tenements, and premi≈ø≈øes, to hold from the date of the ≈øaid Indenture, vnto the ende and terme of three ≈øcore yeares, if ≈øhe ≈øhould ≈øo long liue, re≈øeruing thereupon to her yearely during the ≈øaid terme of three ≈øcore yeares, if ≈øhe ≈øo long liue, three pounds of lawfull Engli≈øh money, which yearely rent of three pounds your ≈øaid Orator did well and faithfully pay vnto the ≈øaid A. and her a≈ø≈øignes vntill about the tenth yeare of the raigne of our Soueraigne Ladie the Queenes Maie≈øtie that now is, at which time the ≈øaide A. did grant and a≈ø≈øigne thirtie ≈øhillings, yearely, parcell of the ≈øaid yearely rent of three pounds during her life, to one R. M. of E. in the countie of D. Cutler. And afterwards, that is to ≈øay, about the twentith yeare of her Maie≈øties ≈øaid Raigne, the ≈øaid A. for ≈øundrie con≈øidrations did appoint the ≈øaide R. to receiue the other thirtie ≈øhillings yearely, re≈øidue of the ≈øaid yearly rent of three pounds to his own v≈øe. And your ≈øaide Orator euer ≈øince the ≈øaid grant and appointment hath yearely paide vnto the ≈øaide R. as well the ≈øaid thirtie ≈øhillings rent, ≈øo to him granted by the ≈øaid A. as the ≈øaid other thirtie ≈øhillings rent, re≈øidue of the ≈øaid three pound rent. In tender con≈øideration whereof the ≈øaid R. M. about the fir≈øt day of Iune la≈øt pa≈øt faithfully promi≈øed your ≈øaid Orator to procure and deliuer vnto him ≈øufficient acquitances of the ≈øaid A. for all the ≈øaid rents which the ≈øaid R. had ≈øo, as is afore≈øaid, receiued of your ≈øaid Orator by the appointment of the ≈øaid A. And whereas further (if it may plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip) about the eightenth day of April, in the xxvii yeare of the raigne of the Queenes Maie≈øtie that now is, the ≈øaid R. M. being indebted to one W. S. of S. in the ≈øaid Countie Smith, in the ≈øumme of fiftie and three ≈øhillings and foure pence, of Engli≈øh money, did entreat your ≈øaid Orator to be ≈øuertie for him to the ≈øaid W. S. for the payment of the ≈øaid ≈øumme of fiftie three ≈øhillings foure pence to the ≈øaid W. S. at the fea≈øt of Saint Bart. the Apo≈øtle then next en≈øuing, which your ≈øaid Orator did accordingly, in con≈øideration thereof, the ≈øaid R. M. did then a≈ø≈øume vpon him≈øelfe, and vnto your ≈øaid Orator faithfully promi≈øe that if he the ≈øaid R. M. did not well and truely pay vnto the ≈øaid W. S. the ≈øaid fiftie three ≈øhillings foure pence at the ≈øaid fea≈øt of Saint Bart. That then he the ≈øaid R. M. woulde ≈øufficien ‚Ä¢ ly conuey and a≈ø≈øure to your ≈øaid Orator, the ≈øaid yearely rent of thirtie ≈øhillings, to him as afore≈øaid, granted by the ≈øaid A. together with the ≈øaid deed thereof, & afterwards the ≈øaid R. M. did neither pay to the ≈øaid W. S. the ≈øaid ≈øumme of fiftie three ≈øhillings foure pence, nor any part thereof, at the ≈øaid fea≈øt of Saint Barth. nor at any time ≈øince, nor did conuey the ≈øaid yearely rent of thirtie ≈øhillings, or deede thereof to your ≈øaid Orator according to his ≈øaid promi≈øe. But altogether contrarie
to his owne promi≈øe hath procured the ≈øaid A. to ≈øue your Orator before the Queenes Maie≈øtie, and her honorable Coun≈øaile, e≈øtabli≈øhed in the North parts, for xxv. l . x. sÃÑ. as arrerages of the ≈øaid yearely rent of three pounds, ≈øuppo≈øing the ≈øame to be behinde and vnpaid by the ≈øpace of eight yeares and a halfe, now la≈øt pa≈øt, notwith≈øtanding that you ≈øaid Orator hath well and truely paid the ≈øame to the ≈øaid R. M. afore≈øaid. And the ≈øaid R. M. although he hath beene often times gently required by your ≈øaid Orator a≈øwell to procure him the ≈øaid acquittance of the ≈øaid A. for the ≈øaid rent of three pounds, as to make a≈ø≈øurance of the ≈øaid yearely rent of xxx. ≈øhillings, to him by the ≈øaid A. granted, yet that to doe, he hath euer hither to denied, and refu≈øed, and yet doth deny to doe the ≈øame, again≈øt all right, equitie, and good con≈øcience, and to the great hinderance and lo≈ø≈øe of your ≈øaide Orator. In tender con≈øideration whereof, and for ≈øo much as the ≈øaid agreements, promi≈øes, and paiments of the ≈øaid rents were priuately made betweene your ≈øaid Orator, and the ≈øaid R. M. without any witne≈ø≈øes thereof, for that your ≈øaid Orator repo≈øed ≈øo great tru≈øt in the ≈øaid R. M. being his naturall brother, that he called no man to beare witne≈ø≈øe thereof, ≈øo that he can haue none ordinarie meanes by the due cour≈øe of the common lawes of this Realm, but is altogether remedile≈ø≈øe to obtaine or recouer any recompence or damages thereof, vnle≈ø≈øe the ≈øame R. M. will confe≈ø≈øe the ≈øame to be true in his an≈øwere hereunto, as your ≈øaide Orator verely thinketh that he will. It may therefore, &c.

div.head: A Bill for that the defendant, for whom the plaintife was ≈øuretie to pay certaine money, did neither pay the ≈øaid money, nor ≈øaue the plaintife harmle≈ø≈øe.
div.p:
HVmbly complaining ≈øheweth vnto your honorable L. your daily Sect'. 104. Orator H. H. of E. in the Countie of D. yeoman. That whereas about the viii. day of October, in the xxii. yeare of the Raigne of our Soueraigne Ladie the Queenes mo≈øt excellent Maie≈øtie that now is, your ≈øaid Orator, at the earne≈øt reque≈øt of one H. C. of C. in the ≈øaid Countie yeoman, and R. C. his ≈øonne, for and with the ≈øaid H. did enter and become bounden vnto H. S. of E. afore≈øaid yeoman, in one Obligation or bond of xl. l , of lawfull Engli≈øh money thereupon indorced with Condition, that if the ≈øaid H. H. and H. C. or either of them, their executors, admini≈øtrators, or a≈ø≈øignes, or any of them, did well and truely pay or cau≈øe to be paide, vnto the ≈øaid H. S. his executors or a≈ø≈øignes, the ≈øumme of twentie pounds of lawfull Engli≈øh money vpon the ninth day of October, which then ≈øhould be in the yeare of our Lord God 1581. at the now dwelling hou≈øe of the ≈øaide H. S. in E. afore≈øaid, that then the ≈øaid Obligation ≈øhould be voide and of none
effect. And the ≈øaid H. C. and R. C. in con≈øideration thereof, did then and there a≈ø≈øume vpon them≈øelues, and vnto your ≈øaid Orator faithfully promi≈øe, that the ≈øaid H. C. the ≈øumme of twentie pound vnto the ≈øaid H. S. vpon the ≈øaid ninth day of October in the yeare of our Lord God 1581. would well and truely pay, or cau≈øe to e paid, according to the ≈øaid condition of the ≈øaid obligation. And that the ≈øaid H. C. and R. C. would from time to time, and at all times hereafter, ≈øaue & keep harmele≈ø≈øe, and indempnified your ≈øaid Orator again≈øt the ≈øaid H. S. of, for and concerning the ≈øaid bond of fortie pounds, and of, for and concerning all actions, ≈øuites, and troubles to be had or commenced again≈øt your ≈øaid Orator, for, or by rea≈øon of the ≈øaide bond of fortie pounds. And al≈øo that they the ≈øaid H. C. and R. C. would forthwith haue beene bound vnto your ≈øaid orator by their ≈øufficient obligation in the ≈øumme of foure ≈øcore pounds, for the ≈øo ≈øauing harmele≈ø≈øe of your ≈øaid Orator again≈øt the ≈øaid H. S. as is afore≈øaid. But now ≈øo it is, if it may plea≈øe your honorable Lord≈øhip, that the ≈øaid H. C. intending your ≈øaid Orator in this behalfe, craftily and ≈øubtilly, to defraud and deceiue, hath neyther paide vnto the ≈øaid H. S. the ≈øaid twentie pound the ≈øaid ninth day of October in the ≈øaid yeare of our Lord God 1581. according to the effect and meaning of the ≈øaid condition, nor at any time ≈øithence, nor the ≈øaid H. C. and R. C. haue become bounden vnto your ≈øaid Orator in the ≈øaid Obligation of foure≈øcore pounds, to ≈øaue your ≈øaid Orator harmle≈ø≈øe again≈øt the ≈øaid H. S. as is afore≈øaid, albeit that your ≈øaide Orator hath ≈øundrie times gently required them, and either of them ≈øo to doe, the ≈øame to doe, haue euer hitherto refu≈øed, and yet doe refu≈øe and denie to doe the ≈øame again≈øt all right, equitie, and good con≈øcience, contrarie to their faithfull promi≈øe and a≈ø≈øuumption afore≈øaid, ≈øo that your ≈øaid Orator is likelye verie ≈øhortly to be enforced to pay vnto the ≈øaid H. S. the ≈øaid twentie pounds, which would be to the great damages and hinderance of your ≈øaid Orator, if ≈øpeedie remedie be not in this behalfe by your good Lord≈øhip in due time prouided to preuent the ≈øame, wherefore and fora≈ømuch as your ≈øaid Orator giuing faith and credite to the ≈øaid promi≈øe & a≈ø≈øumption of the ≈øaid H. C. did take their ≈øaid promi≈øe and a≈ø≈øumption of them, without calling anie witne≈ø≈øe to them to heare the ≈øame, ≈øo that your ≈øaid Orator for want of ≈øuch witne≈ø≈øes hath no remedie by the common lawes of thsi Realme, nor otherwi≈øe to make them performe the ≈øame promi≈øe and a≈ø≈øumption, vnle≈ø≈øe the ≈øaid H. C. and R. C. doe confe≈ø≈øe the ≈øame in their an≈øwere in this Honorable Court, as your ≈øaide Orator verely thinketh they will. May it, &c.

div.head: A Bill for entitling him≈øelfe to the ≈øoyle of a common, and for, ≈øelling of woods therein growing.
div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe complaining ≈øheweth and complaineth to your Sect. 105. Honor, your daily Orator R. G. Clerke, Prebendarie of the Prebend, commonly called the Prebend of the Ouerhall in Norwell, in the Collegiate Church of Southwell in the Countie of NottÃÑ. That wheras your ≈øaid Orator was, and is ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne as of fee, in the right of the ≈øaid Prebend, of, and in one Manor in Norwell, in the ≈øaid Countie, whereof certaine wooddy grounds and ≈øpringes, being mo≈øt commonly open, and the herbage thereof, taken and v≈øed as common by the tenants and other inhabitants of the ≈øame Manor and Towne of N. afore≈øaid is parcel. And the tenants and inhabitants of the ≈øame Manor and Towne of N. afore≈øaid, as tenants of the ≈øame Manor, And other tenants and inhabitants within the townes and villages of C. and K. that is to ≈øay, by them as Commoners, becau≈øe of Vicinage, by rea≈øon of which ≈øaid wooddy and ≈øpring of grounds, v≈øed as common, as is afore≈øaid, part whereof is parcell of the ≈øame Manor of N. contayning by e≈øtimation twentie acres, extending in length from a certaine Oke tree, being a boundarie Oke betwixt the ≈øame and ≈øuch other like grounds, being parcell of an other Prebend in the Collegiate Church of S. afore≈øaid, commonly called the Prebend of the Neatherhall or Palacehall in N. afore≈øaid, and from thence extendeth along, by a place where three trees lately there did grow, commonly called the three brethren, and ≈øo from thence along by a Meare, which is as it hath beene an ancient drie ditch ca≈øt vp as it were, or had beene a Meare Southward betwixt the ≈øeuerall Lords and owners of the lands in that place, that is to ≈øay, fir≈øt Ea≈øtwardes, betweene the Lord and owners of the ≈øame lands, and the Manors and lands of Caunton & Be≈øtthrop, and We≈øtwarde vnto the manor of Kirk≈øall, and from thence downeward We≈øt vnto the parke pale of K. and by the ≈øame parke pale Northward by a certaine little riuer of water, vnto certaine of the like landes and tenements of the ≈øaid other manor of P. afore≈øaid, and ≈øo Ea≈øtward vpward vnto the fore≈øaid ancient Oke, which ≈øaid parcell of ground, one R. W. and F. B. Gentlemen, and one R. T. yeoman, pretending to haue ≈øeuerall manors in C. afore≈øaid, And hauing diuers deeds, Charters, euidences, bonndaries, terrars and muniments, concerning the premi≈ø≈øes of right belonging to your ≈øaid Orator, ca≈øually or by ≈øome ≈øini≈øter meanes come to their hands, doe not onely claime the ≈øame to be parcell of their ≈øaid ≈øeueral manors, But al≈øo vnder pretence of their ≈øaid pretended and vncertaine claime, not onely ≈øome of them, but al≈øo diuers other vnder the colour or permi≈ø≈øion of ≈øome of them hath not,
and cau≈øed to be cut downe the mo≈øt part of the be≈øt trees growing vppon the ≈øaid parcell of wood ground, as in trueth, all that was felled, did grow there in a corner thereof towards the Ea≈øt part containing like 12. acres, and that in ab≈øence of your ≈øaid Orator, then being, and yet remaining a ≈øtudent in the Vniuer≈øity of Cambridge, that is to ≈øay, a fellow of Gunuill and Caius Colledge, and not ≈øoe contented, but con≈øidering your ≈øaide Orators ab≈øence, daily and continually, both continue their former claime to the ≈øaid ground within the meeres and boundes afore≈øaid, and ≈øo doe cut downe, and cau≈øe to be cut downe the re≈øidue of the wood there growing, and ≈øo will very ≈øhortly leaue none there. And al≈øo by colour and rea≈øon of the ≈øaid permi≈ø≈øion, they will ≈øhortly by ≈øuch indirect meanes and practi≈øe, winne, and get the freehold, and inheritance thereof to them, as they haue in other the wa≈øts, common, & like grounds, within the Manor, of, or in C. or at the lea≈øt, haue none able to te≈øtifie the contrarie, whereas now in trueth there are diuers and ≈øundry ≈øufficient and ancient witne≈ø≈øes, being very aged, and ≈øome of them very impotent, that can and will trauell ≈øo farre as they are able to trauell, to te≈øtifie vpon their oathes the trueth of the premi≈ø≈øes in manner and forme as before in effect is alleaged, and more for the better proofe of your ≈øaid Orators right, in, and to the ≈øaid la≈øt recited premi≈ø≈øes, if cau≈øe and neede ≈øhall ≈øo require, and that the ≈øaid R. W. F. B. and R. T. vpon their an≈øwere vnto the matters in this bill of complaint, will not confe≈ø≈øe the trueth therein, as it is mo≈øt credibly to be pre≈øumed they will, and the rather, for that, if they will denie the ≈øame, they know in proceeding vpon their an≈øweres to this bill, all the whole trueth concerning the premi≈ø≈øes mu≈øt be examined by depo≈øitions of witne≈ø≈øes, and their depo≈øitions, if order pre≈øently be not taken of the ≈øame, ≈øhall and may remaine of record in perpetuam rei memoriam, to doe further therein, as by this honorable Court ≈øhall be awarded, wherefore the premi≈ø≈øes tenderly con≈øidered, and al≈øo the incertaintie, whether the ≈øaid R. W. F. B. and R. T. or any of them will confe≈ø≈øe the whole trueth, concerning the right and title of your fore≈øaid Orator to the ≈øame, And the wrong and damage by them, and other by their meanes and con≈øent to him done. And if they ≈øhould not, the vncertainty whether that the fore≈øaid ancient, aged and impotent per≈øons, or any of them that now be liuing, and can te≈øtifie the trueth concerning the ≈øame ≈øhall be liuing when the ≈øame ≈øhal come in triall, at, or by the cour≈øe of the common lawes, to whom the right of the freehold, and inheritance thereof doth of right belong, ouer and be≈øides the impotency, that they or mo≈øt of them may haue at ≈øuch time and times, to trauel to witne≈ø≈øe & te≈øtifie che trueth concerning the premi≈ø≈øes, with this, that your ≈øaid Orator doth not know the certaine date
or dates of the ≈øaid deeds, charters, euidences, boundaries, terrers, miniments, or wherein the ≈øame be contained, whether in bagge, or boxe, ≈øealed, or locked, or otherwi≈øe, and ≈øo without remedy for the recouery of the ≈øame, and redre≈ø≈øe for the wrong aboue ≈øaid, at, or by order of the common lawes of this Realme. It may therefore &c.

div.head: A Bill again≈øt the executors ‚ñ™or that the Testator did not deliuer ≈øpecialties paid, whereupon they threaten to ≈øue the Plaintife.
div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe complaining, ≈øheweth to your good Lord≈øhip Sect. 106. your poore and daily Orator G.
