N. of T. in the Countie of D. yeoman, that whereas your ≈øaid Orator about the moneth of Ianuary, in the xxx. yeare of the Raigne of our Soneraigne Lady Elizabeth, the Queenes Maie≈øtie that now is, by his ≈øeuerall bodds, or writings obligatory became bonnd to one N. D. now decea≈øed, for the paiment of ≈øeuerall ≈øummes of money vnto the ≈øaid N. All which ≈øaid ≈øummes of money, and euery parcell thereof your ≈øaid Orator hath truely ≈øati≈øfied and paid to the ≈øaid N. D. in his life time, according to the purport and effect of the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall bondes and writings obligatorie, not taking any of the ≈øpecialties, or any acquittance or di≈øcharge from the ≈øaid N. D. for the ≈øame, but onely tru≈øted the wordes of the ≈øaid N. D. who faithfully promi≈øed your ≈øaid Orator to ≈øende the ≈øame ≈øpecialties to your ≈øaid Orators hou≈øe, at Totley afore≈øaid, or ≈øufficient acquittance for the ≈øame. But now ≈øo it is, if it may plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhippe, that ≈øince the death of the ≈øaid N. D. the ≈øaide obligations and writings obligatory are come to the handes and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of N. C. of S. in the Countie of Yorke. yeoman, and T. C. of S. afore≈øaid yeoman, who by colour of hauing thereof, haue nowe of late in their owne names as executors to A. D. late wife of the ≈øaid N. D. and cxecutrix of the la≈øt Will and Te≈øtament of the ≈øame N. commenced ≈øuit in her Maie≈øties Court of common Plees at We≈øtmin≈øter, again≈øt your Lord≈øhips ≈øaid poore Orator, vpon one of the ≈øaid obligatious or writings obligatory of the ≈øumme of xii. pounds or thereabouts, indorced with condition for the payment of ≈øixe pounds, at a day mentioned in the ≈øame condition, and doe threaten to put the re≈øidue of the ≈øaid ≈øpecialties in ≈øuite again≈øt your ≈øaid Orator, meaning, and intending thereby to recouer again≈øt your ≈øaid Orator the penalties of the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall obligations, and writings, who hath already paide the principall and due debts of the ≈øaid N. D. in his life time as afore≈øaid, which is contrarie to all right, equity, and good con≈øcience: in cod≈øideration whereof, and for as much your Lord≈øhips ≈øaid Orator hath not any witne≈ø≈øes now liuing, that can te≈øtifie the paiment of any of the ≈øaide ≈øummes of money, or any part or parcell thereof, and therefore can not plead any
matter in barre at the common law to the ≈øaid actions alreadie commenced by the ≈øaid C. and C. whereby your ≈øaid Orator, by the ≈øtrict cour≈øe of the common lawes of this Realme is altogether remedile≈ø≈øe, vnle≈ø≈øe your Lord≈øhips accu≈øtomed goodne≈ø≈øe be to your ≈øaid poore Orator extended. May it therefore plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, &c.

div.head: A Bill again≈øt executors vpon a priuate promi≈øe made by their testator, retayning an Atturney to pro≈øecute and defend ≈øuits, for him≈øelfe, and others, alleaging that the executors haue wasted the Testators goods &c.
div.p:
HVmbly complaining, ≈øheweth vnto your honorable Lord≈øhip your Sect. 103. daily Orator W. W. of F. in the County of Y. gentleman, one of the Atturneies of the Queenes Maie≈øties Court of common Plees, before her Highne≈ø≈øe Iu≈øtices, to be holden of the ≈øame Court, that whereas one I. M. of T. neere N. in the County of Nottingham E≈øquier decea≈øed, in his life time, that is to ≈øay, about y‚Ä¢ terme of the holy Trinity, which was in the yeare of o ‚Ä¢ r Lord God 1586. did retaine the ≈øaid W. W. to be of councell with him the ≈øaid F. M. to pro≈øecute and defend duers and ≈øundry ≈øuites, plees, and bu≈øine≈ø≈øes to be done, and had in the ≈øaid Court of common plees, as well for the ≈øaid F. M. as for diuers others, his then ≈øeruants, and bailifes, and tenants, and namely for the ≈øaid I. M. again≈øt R. E. in a writ of Repleuin for three Kine of the ≈øaid R. ≈øuppo≈øed to be vniu≈øtly taken and detained by the ≈øaid I. M. And for the ≈øaid I. M. again≈øt H. T. in a Repleuin of the ≈øaid H. for ≈øixe Oxen ≈øuppo≈øed to be taken, & vniu≈øtly detained by the ≈øaid I. M. And for the ≈øaid I. M. again≈øt I. H. in a Repleuin for two Kine of the ≈øaid I. H. ≈øuppo≈øed to be taken & vniu≈øtly detained by the ≈øaid I. M. And for the ≈øaid I. M. again≈øt E. S. in a Repleuin of certaine cattell of the ≈øaid E. ≈øuppo≈øed to be taken, & vniu≈øtly detained by the ≈øaid I. M. And for R. R. and W. S. again≈øt R. L. for three Oxen of the ≈øaid R. H. ≈øuppo≈øed to be taken and vniu≈øtly detained by the ≈øaid R. R. and W. S. And for I. S. and R. S. again≈øt H. T. alias W. in a Repeuin, for certaine bea≈øts of the ≈øaid H. S. ≈øuppo≈øed to be taken & vniu≈øtly detained by the ≈øaid I. S. and R. S. And for R. R. and W. S. again≈øt R. H. in a Repleuin of diuers bea≈øts of the ≈øaid R. H. ≈øuppo≈øed to be taken & vniu≈øtly detained by the ≈øaid R. R. & W. S. And for I. S. & T. W. again≈øt T. E. in a Repleuin of certaine bea≈øts of the ≈øaid T. E. ≈øuppo≈øed to be taken & vniu≈øtly detained by the ≈øaid I. & T. W. And for the ≈øaid I. S. and T. W. again≈øt the ≈øaid R. E. in an other repleuin of certaine bea≈øts of the ≈øaid R. E. ≈øuppo≈øed to be taken & vniu≈øtly detained by the ≈øaid I. S. & T. W. taking for his fee & labour for euery one of the ≈øaid plees & bu≈øines ≈øo as is ≈øaid in the ≈øame court by him to be pro≈øecuted and defended for euery terme
in which your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhould ≈øo be Atturney for him or them or any of them, 3. sÃÑ. 4. d . And be≈øides that fee, all rea≈øonable co≈øtes, and expences about the pro≈øecution of the ≈øame ≈øuites, plees, and bu≈øine≈ø≈øes, as for the writing of writs, ≈øealing of them, and drawing and entring of plees and warrants of atturney, and al≈øo for all other things in that behalfe, by him your ≈øaid Orator be laid forth and expended, and in con≈øideration thereof, he the ≈øaid F. M. did about the ≈øame time, a≈ø≈øume vpon him≈øelfe, and vnto your ≈øaid Orator faithfully promi≈øe, well and truely to content, ≈øati≈øfie, and pay vnto the ≈øaid orator when≈øoeuer he ≈øhould be thereunto required by your ≈øaid orator a≈øwel the ≈øaid fee of 3. sÃÑ. 4. d . for euery of the ≈øaid ≈øuits, plees, & bu≈øine≈ø≈øes ≈øo to be pro≈øecuted, as al≈øo all the ≈øaid co≈øts, and expences, ≈øo as is afore≈øaid, to be laid forth in that behal≈øe: by rea≈øon of which reteiner & promi≈øe, ≈øo as is afore≈øaid made, your ≈øaid Orator was of coun≈øaile with the ≈øaid I. M. and the ≈øaid other per≈øons in the ≈øaid ≈øuits, & plees in the ≈øaid court, by the ≈øpace of 8 ≈øeueral termes next en≈øuing the ≈øaid retainer, & during the ≈øaid time, did pro≈øecute and ≈øue for & defend diuers ≈øuits & writs, a≈øwell iudiciall as originall as by the records thereof remaining in the ≈øaid court appeareth, by rea≈øon wherof your Orator fees for the pro≈øecution, and defending of the ≈øaide ≈øuits, or plees by the ≈øaid time did amount vnto 10. l . or there abouts, be≈øides the co≈øts & expences laid out by him in the ≈øame, which co≈øts & expences laid out by your Lord≈øhips ≈øaid orator, did amouÃÑt vnto 8. l . 19. sÃÑ. 9. d . which were behind, & vnpaid vnto your ≈øaid orator by means wherof action accrued vnto your ≈øaid Orator to demaund and haue of the ≈øaid I. M. in his life time the ≈øaid ≈øumme of 18. l . 19. sÃÑ. & 9. d . and of the ≈øaid A. M. vnto whom the admini≈øtration of all the goods & chattels which the fore≈øaid I. M. had at the the time of his death were after his death lawfully committed, yet therfore the ≈øaid I. M. in his life time the ≈øaid ≈øumme of 18. l . 19. sÃÑ. & 9. d . nor any peny therof though often times in his life time therunto by your ≈øaid Orator required, or the ≈øaid A. M. his admini≈øtrator after his death, notwith≈øtanding that the goods & chattels which were the ≈øaid I. M. be ≈øufficient for the paiment of the ≈øaid 18. l . 19. sÃÑ. 9. d . vnto your ≈øaid Orator, and of all other debtes which the ≈øaide I. M. ought to haue paid, did come to the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid A. M. and ≈øtill remaine in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of her the ≈øaid A. M. or of ≈øuch per≈øon and per≈øons, vnto whom ≈øhe hath yeelded, left, or deliuered the ≈øame, notwith≈øtanding that ≈øhe hath ≈øundry times ≈øince the death of the ≈øaid I. M. bin gently required by your ≈øaid Orator to pay to him the ≈øame 18. l . 19. sÃÑ. 9. d . or any part thereof, hath not yet paid and contented, but the ≈øame to content and pay hath euer hitherto denied and refu≈øed, and the ≈øaid A. doth yet denie and refu≈øe to pay the ≈øame, thereof intending vtterly to defraud and deceiue your ≈øaid Orator again≈øt all right, equity,
and good con≈øcience, notwith≈øtanding al≈øo that ≈øhe the ≈øaid A. M. hath her ≈øelfe at ≈øundrie times heard the ≈øaid I. M. in his life time promi≈øe that he would pay vnto your ≈øaid Orator all ≈øuch ≈øummes of money, as were behinde vnto your ≈øaid Orator, and notwith≈øtanding al≈øo, that ≈øhe well knoweth, that the fore≈øaid ≈øumme of 18. l . 19. sÃÑ. 9. d . due vnto your ≈øaid Orator by the afore≈øaid I. M. in his life, by rea≈øon that ≈øhe hath ≈øeene, and hath a perticular bill thereof, which was ≈øent and deliuered to him in his life time by your ≈øaid Orator, and notwith≈øtanding al≈øo, that ≈øhe her ≈øelfe ≈øince the death of the ≈øaid I. M. did a≈ø≈øume, & faithfully promi≈øe to pay vnto your fore≈øaid orator, all ≈øuch mony as was due vnto him at the ≈øaid time of his death, if ≈øhe the ≈øaid A. M. did take vppon her the admini≈øtration of his goods, and chattels, which ≈øhe hath done as is ≈øaid. All which things ≈øhe the ≈øaid A. hath done partly by her owne iniurious minde, but chiefly by the wicked and ≈øinfull per≈øwa≈øion of R. M. gentleman her ≈øonne, by who≈øe coun≈øaile and per≈øwa≈øion ≈øhe hath clo≈øely and ≈øecretly conueyed away a great part of the ≈øaide goods being of verie great value, to diuers places and per≈øons, to your ≈øaid Orator vtterly vnknowen, and left the ≈øame out of the Inuentorie of the ≈øaid I. M. his ≈øaid goods which ≈øhe hath exhibited: and al≈øo hath cau≈øed ≈øuch goods and chattels, as be mentioned in the ≈øaid Inuentorie, to be prai≈øed much vnder the value thereof, and a great part thereof to be ≈øet downe therein ≈øo confu≈øedly, and inconueniently, that it cannot well be knowen, either what they be, or of what value. And furthermore ≈øhe the ≈øaid A. by the like ≈øini≈øter coun≈øaile, and per≈øwa≈øion hath con≈øented and cau≈øed one H. B. and T. C. and diuers other per≈øons being her e≈øpeciall friends couenou≈øly to commence diuers and ≈øundrie fraudulent actions of debts, and executions, again≈øt her as admini≈øtratrix of, and to the ≈øame I. M. ≈øuffering her ≈øelfe therein to be conuicted and condemned, though in verie trueth either nothing or verie little was due vnto them, and in a manner nothing at all taken of her by them, by vertue of the ≈øaid actions, and executions, to the intent thereby to da≈ø ‚Ä¢ e the eies of your Orator, and of other the creditors of the ≈øaid I. M. not knowing the trueth of the ≈øame vngodly deui≈øes, intending by ≈øuch meanes to defraud and defeat, your ≈øaid Orator, and the re≈øt of his ≈øaid creditors, of the mo≈øt part of their ≈øeuerall debts, which their vnlawfull practi≈øes, are like to be to the great lo≈ø≈øe and hinderance of your ≈øaid Orator, if ≈øpeedie remedie be not by your good Lord≈øhips meanes prouided, to meete with and preuent the ≈øaide vnconcionable and vniu≈øt dealing in the premi≈ø≈øes, for that the promi≈øes and a≈ø≈øumptions of the ≈øaid I. M. and A. M. were made ≈øecretly and priuately vnto your ≈øaid orator, nor per≈øons being pre≈øent with theÃÑ at the making of the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall promi≈øes, nor anie man liuing which can te≈øtifie the ≈øame, ≈øo
that your ≈øaid Orator for want of ≈øuch proofe thereof, as is requi≈øite by the ≈øtrict cour≈øe of the common lawes of this Realme, is altogether remediles, if it be not by thorder of this honorable court, wherein your L. ≈øaid Orator hopeth, & verily thinketh, that ≈øhe the ≈øaid A. M. in her aun≈øwere to the premi≈ø≈øes, vpon her corporall oath will confe≈ø≈øe the ≈øame, to be in effect, as it is herin ≈øet forth & di≈øclo≈øed: May it therfore plea≈øe &c.

div.head: A Bill for diuers Euidences.
div.p: HVmbly complaining ≈øheweth vnto your Lord≈øhip, G. Earle of. S Sect. 108. That whereas the ≈øaid Earle is lawfully ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne as of fee, of, and in the manor of S. in the County of Y. and in the hundred of S. with thappurtenances in the County of D. and of and in the ca≈øtle and manor of S. with thappurtenances in the Connty of Y. and of the ca≈øtle & manor of B. in the County of D. and of, and in the ca≈øtle & manor, and hundred of B. in the County of D. with thappurtenances, and of, and in diuers me≈øuages, lands, tenements, hereditaments, franchi≈øes and liberties, to the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall manors & hundreds belonging: Now ≈øo it is, if it may plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, that diuers and ≈øundry courtroles, charters, euidences, exemplifications of records, extracts, terrers, pleadings, writings, and muniments, concerning the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall manors, hundreds, and premi≈ø≈øes with thappurtenances, & of right belonging vnto the ≈øaid Earle, and whereby the ≈øaid Earle ≈øhould make his title vnto the ≈øaid manors, hundreds, liberties, and premi≈ø≈øes with thappurtenances, or to the mo≈øt part thereof, are by ca≈øual meanes come vnto the hands, cu≈øtodie, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of one N. C. of S. in the County of D. And albeit that the ≈øaid Earle hath ≈øundry times ≈øent vnto the ≈øaid N. C. gently requiring him to deliuer vnto the ≈øaid Earle the ≈øaid court rolles, charters, euidences, exemplifications of recordes, extractes, pleadings, writings, and muniments, yet that to do, the ≈øaid N. hath euer hitherto vtterly denied, & yet doth deny to do the ≈øame, again≈øt all right, equity, and good con≈øcience: In tender con≈øideration whereof, and for ≈øo much as the ≈øaid Earle knoweth not the certaine dates, and other the certainties of the ≈øaid deeds, charters, euidences, exemplifications &c. neither wherein they, or any of them be contained, & therefore haue not any ordinary remedy by the common lawes of this Realme, to recouer the ≈øame deeds, euidences &c. or any of them, and wanting the ≈øame deeds, &c. is in daunger to loo≈øe many franchi≈øes, liberties, and commodities belonging to the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall manors, hundreds, and premi≈ø≈øes: May it therefore plea≈øe your honorable Lord≈øhip, to graunt vnto the ≈øaid Earle, the Queenes Maie≈øties mo≈øt gratious writ of Subpena, to be vnto him directed, commaunding him to appeare before your honorable Lord≈øhip in her Maie≈øties high Court of Chancery, &c.

div.head: A Bill for not making of an a≈ø≈øurance of landes according to a couenant alleaging the Indenture thereof, to be come to the defendants handes, and that ≈øome of the defendants were within age at the making of the ≈øame Indenture.
div.p:
COmplaining ≈øheweth vnto your honorable Lord≈øhip, Gilb. Earle Sect' 109. of S. ≈øonne and heire of the right honorable George late Earle of S. decea≈øed, and admini≈øtrator of the goods and chattels which were the late Earles at the time of his death, That whereas about the moneth of September, which was in the two & thirtieth yere of the raigne of the Queenes mo≈øt excellent Maie≈øtie that now is, one R. E. of H. in the County of D. gentleman, was ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne as of fee, of, and in one Annuitie or yearely rent charge of twentie pounds by the yeare, i≈ø≈øuing and going forth of certaine landes in B. in the ≈øaid Countie of D. and of, and in one other Annuitie or yearely rent charge of fortie markers by the yeare, i≈ø≈øuing and going forth of certaine landes and tenements in B. afore≈øaid. And where al≈øo he then had to him and his heires, to thu≈øe of him and his heires for euer, by conneiance from one P. B. E≈øquier, one melting hou≈øe and certaine ground then lately v≈øed to the ≈øame. And where further the ≈øaid R. E. by conueyance from the ≈øaid P. B. then had to him and his heires for euer, the Tyeth of the Corne and Hey renewing, comming, or growing within B. afore≈øaid, or el≈øe where within the ≈øeuerall pari≈øhes of D. or S. or eyther of them, in the ≈øaid County of D. And where al≈øo one T. E. ≈øonne & heire apparant of the ≈øaid R. E. then al≈øo had by conueiaÃÑce from the ≈øaid P. B. to chu≈øe of the ≈øaid T. E. and his heires for euer, diuers and ≈øundry lands, tenements, & hereditaments with thappurten ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ces in B. afore≈øaid. And where al≈øo one G. E. ≈øecond ≈øonne of the ≈øaid R. E. then had by conueyance from the ≈øaid P. B. vnto the v≈øe of the ≈øaid G. E. his heires and a≈ø≈øignes for euer, the manor of B. with thappurtenances, & diuers lands, tenements, & hereditaments with thappurtenances, as by ≈øeuerall conueyances of the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall tenements, things, & premi≈ø≈øes, to the ≈øaid R. T. and G. before that time ≈øeuerally made appeareth: by force wherof they were thereof lawfully ≈øei≈øed ≈øeuerally in their ≈øeueral deme≈ønes, as of fee, And being thereof ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, they the ≈øaid R. E. T. E. & G. E. for a certaine ≈øumme of money to them well & truly paid by the ≈øaid late E. and for other con≈øideratioÃÑs them then e≈øpecially mouing, by Indenture hearing date, in or about the ≈øaid moneth of Sept. in the xxxii. yeare aboue ≈øaid, made betweene them on the one party, and the ≈øaid G. late Earle of S. on the other party, did fully, freely, and ab≈øolutely alien, grant, borgaine, & ≈øell vnto the ≈øaid G. late Earle of S. his heires & a≈ø≈øignes for euer, the ≈øaid manor of B. with al his rights, meÃÑbers & appurtenances
in the ≈øaid Countie of D. And all & ≈øinguler me≈øuages, tofts, cotages, hou≈øes, &c. to the ≈øaid Manor of B. belonging, or in any wi≈øe appertaining, And all other the me≈øuages, lands, tenements, rents, reuer≈øions, ≈øeruices, and hereditaments of the ≈øaid R. T. and G. E. and of euerie of them, what≈øoeuer, ≈øcituate, lying &c. Together withall the reuer≈øion and reuer≈øions, remainder and remainders, of all and ≈øinguler the premi≈ø≈øes, and euerie part thereof with thappurtenances, and all e≈øtate, right, title, intere≈øt, claime, v≈øe, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and demaund, of them the ≈øaid R. E. T. E. and G. E. and of euerie of them what≈øoeuer, of, in, and to the ≈øaid Manor, me≈øuages, landes, tenements, hereditaments, and other the premi≈ø≈øes before mentioned, and of, in, and to euery part thereof: Excepting and for pri≈øing one grant made by the ≈øaid P. B. to the ≈øaid R. his heires and a≈ø≈øignes for euer, of common of pa≈øture for all &c. To haue and to hold the ≈øaid Manor, lands, tenements, and premi≈ø≈øes with thappurtenances, (except before excepted) vnto the ≈øaid G. late Earle of S. his heires and a≈ø≈øignes for euer, to the onely v≈øe of him the ≈øaid late Earle, his heires and a≈ø≈øignes for euer: And in con≈øideration of the premi≈ø≈øes the ≈øaid late Earle by the ≈øaid Indenture of bargaine and ≈øale, did grant vnto the ≈øaid R. E. his heires and a≈ø≈øignes for euer, to the onely v≈øe of the ≈øaid R. his heires and a≈ø≈øignes for euer, one Annuitie or yeareiy rent charge of one hundred pounds, of lawfull Engli≈øh money, to be i≈ø≈øuing and going out of all and ≈øinguler the ≈øaid manor, lands, tenenmets, and premi≈ø≈øes, (except before excepted) and except ≈øuch lands, tenemeÃÑts, & hereditaments as were then a≈ø≈øured or conueyed for the Iointure of the right Honorable Elizabeth then, and yet Counte≈ø≈øe of S. to be paide at the fea≈øt of S. Michaell the archangell, and the Annunciation of the virgin Marie, by euen portions, or to this or the like effect and meaning, as in, and by the ≈øaid Indenture of bargaine and ≈øale among≈øt other things plainely appeareth, the preci≈øe contents whereof, this complainant cannot more certainely ≈øet downe, for want of the ≈øaid Indenture. And whereas al≈øo (as this complainant hath heard) it was in, and by the ≈øaid Indenture of bargaine and ≈øale couenanted and granted on the part of the ≈øaid R. E. T. E. and G. E. to and with the ≈øaid G. late Earle of S. this complainants ≈øaid late Father, his heires and a≈ø≈øignes, and euery of them, that they the ≈øaid R. E. T. E. and G. E. their heires and a≈ø≈øignes, and euery of them, other then ≈øuch per≈øon and per≈øons for the time being, who≈øe e≈øtates and intere≈øts are in the ≈øame indenture excepted, their executors, admini≈øtrators, and a≈ø≈øignes, and euerie of them, in re≈øpect onely of the ≈øame e≈øtates and intere≈øtes ≈øo excepted, and euerie of them, ≈øhould and would at all times hereafter, for, and during the ≈øpace of certaine yeares, next en≈øuing the date of the ≈øaid Indenture of bargaine and ≈øale, now almo≈øt ended and
expired, at, and vpon the lawfull and rea≈øonable reque≈øt, and at the co≈øts and charges in the law of the ≈øaid late Earle, his heires or a≈ø≈øignes, or ≈øome of them do make and knowledge, and ≈øuffer, cau≈øe, and procure to be done, made, and knowledged, all and euerie ≈øuch further, lawfull, and rea≈øonable act and actes, thing and things, deui≈øe and deui≈øes in the law what≈øoeuer, for the further and more better a≈ø≈øurance, ≈øuretie, and ≈øure making and conueying of the ≈øaid Manor of B. and the me≈øuages, lands, tenements, and premi≈ø≈øes with thappurtenances, in the ≈øaid Indenture mencioned to be bargained and ≈øold, (except before therein excepted vnto the ≈øaid late Earle, his heires and a≈ø≈øignes, to the onely v≈øe and behoofe of the ≈øaid Earle, his heires and a≈ø≈øignes for euer, according to the true intent and meaning of the ≈øaid Indenture, were it by fine, feoffement, recouerie, deed, or deeds inrolled, the inrolement of the ≈øaid Indentures, relea≈øe, confirmation with ioynt or ≈øenerall warranty of the ≈øaid R. E. T. E. and G. E. their, and euerie of their heires again≈øt them the ≈øaid R. E. T. E. & G. E. their, and euery of their heires and a≈ø≈øignes, & euerie of theÃÑ ‚ñ™ & again≈øt all and euerie other per≈øon and per≈øons what≈øoeuer claiming, in, by froÃÑ, or vnder them, or any of theÃÑ or otherwi≈øe with like warranty, or without warranty as by the ≈øaid Earle, his heires or a≈ø≈øignes, or his or their coun≈øell learned in the lawes, ≈øhould be deui≈øed, adui≈øed, and required, ≈øo as none of the ≈øaid actes or things concerning the ≈øaid further a≈ø≈øurance ≈øhould ≈øtretch or extend to any other or further warranty or warranties o ‚Ä¢ the premi≈ø≈øes, or any part thereof, then as is before expre≈ø≈øed, or to that effect and meaning, as in the ≈øame Indenture of bargaine and ≈øale appeareth: But now ≈øo it is if it may plea≈øe your honorable Lord≈øhip, that at the time of the making of the ≈øaid Indenture of bargaine and ≈øale vnto the ≈øaid late Earle, the ≈øaid T. E. and G. E. were within and vnder the age of one and twentie years: And ≈øhortly after the making of the ≈øaid Indenture, and before the ≈øame was either knowledged or inrolled, or any e≈øtate executed thereupon, by Atturnement, Liuerie of ≈øei≈øin, or otherwi≈øe, that is to ≈øay: vpon, or about the ≈øeuenteenth day of Nouember, next en≈øuing the making of the ≈øaid Indenture, the ≈øaid G. late Earle of S. died, by, and after who≈øe death, the right to haue and inherite the ≈øaid Manors, lands, tenements, and premi≈ø≈øes with the appurtenances, di≈øcended and came, as of right the ≈øame ought to di≈øcend and come vnto this complainant, as his elde≈øt ≈øonne & next heire, ≈øhortly after who≈øe death, the admini≈øtration of all the goods and chattels of the ≈øaid G. late Earle of S. was by the right Reuerend father in God, I. by the prouidence of God, Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, Primate & Metropolitaine of all England, committed to this complainant now Earle of S. who admini≈øtred the ≈øaid goods & chattels accordingly. And further ≈øo it is, if it may plea≈øe
your good Lord≈øhip, that the part or counterpaine of the ≈øaid Indenture of bargaine and ≈øale belonging to the ≈øaid late Earle, is ≈øince the death of the ≈øaid late Earle by ca≈øuall meanes comen to the handes, cu≈øtodie, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid R. E. T. E. and G. E. or of ≈øome of them, or of ≈øome other per≈øon by their priuity and con≈øent, the full contents whereof are vtterly vnknowen to this complainant, by colour whereof and for that the ≈øaid T. E. and G. E. were ≈øo, as is afore≈øaid, within age at the making of the ≈øaid Indenture, they the ≈øaid R. E. T. E. and G. E. hauing a great de≈øire to haue the ≈øaid manors, lands, tenements, and bargained premi≈ø≈øes, and thereof to di≈øinherite and defeat this complainant, contrary to the true intent and meaning of the ≈øaid Indenture: Notwith≈øtanding that this complainant hath yearely ≈øithence the making of the ≈øaid Indenture, well & truely ≈øati≈øfied and paid vnto the ≈øaid R. E. the ≈øaid Annuity or yearly rent charge of 100. pounds, by the yeare, in the ≈øaid Indenture mentioned, according to the tenor, forme, and effect of the ≈øame Indenture, (as this complainant verely thinketh.) And notwith≈øtanding that this complainant hath ≈øundrie times, a≈øwell by him≈øelfe, as by diuers others of his ≈øeruantes and friends in his behalfe, ≈øent and come vnto the ≈øaid R. E. T. E. and G. E. gently requiring them, and euery of them, to redeliuer vnto your ≈øaid Orator, the ≈øaid part or Counterpaine of the ≈øaid Indenture of bargaine and ≈øale of the premi≈ø≈øes, And al≈øo to make vnto him this complainant and his heires, further conueyance and a≈ø≈øurance of the ≈øaid manor, tenements, and premi≈ø≈øes, by fine to be leuied before the Iu≈øtices of the common Plees at We≈øtmin≈øter, and for that purpo≈øe in the terme of Saint Hillarie, which was in the foure and thirtieth yeare of the Queenes Maie≈øties Raigne that now is, at We≈øtmin≈øter in the Countie of Middle≈øex, this complainant required the ≈øaid R. and T. according to the tenour, true intent, and meaning of the ≈øaid Indenture of bargaine and ≈øale thereof, to come before Sir E. A. knight, then, and yet chiefe Iu≈øtice of her Maie≈øties Court of common Plees at We≈øtmin≈øter, to make cogni≈øance before the ≈øame E. A. Knight, of the ≈øaid manor, tenements, and premi≈ø≈øes with thappurtenances, in forme of Lawe, that a fine thereupon might haue beene leuied, to the v≈øe of this complainant, and his heires for euer, yet that to doe, they and euery of them haue euer hitherto refu≈øed and denied, and yet doe denie and refu≈øe to doe the ≈øame, contrarie to the forme and true meaning of the couenants and agreements in the ≈øaid Indenture of bargaine and ≈øaile thereof conteyned, and again≈øt all right, equity, and good con≈øcience, and to the manife≈øt defeating and di≈øinheriting of him this complainant, of, and in the ≈øaid manor, landes, tenenements, and premi≈ø≈øes, and contrary to the true intent and meaning
of the ≈øame Indenture of bargaine and ≈øale thereof, except ≈øpeedie remedie be in due time prouided to preuent the ≈øame. Wherefore the premi≈ø≈øes con≈øidered, and for ≈øo much as the ≈øaid complainant not knowing the certaine deate and contents, and other certainties of the ≈øaid part or Counterpaine of the ≈øaid Indenture of bargaine and ≈øale, nor wherein the ≈øame is contained, whether in bagge, boxe, or che≈øt locked, ≈øealed, or otherwi≈øe, and ≈øo hath none ordinary remedy by the due cour≈øe of the common lawes of this Realme, for the recouery thereof. And without the ≈øame Indenture hath no direct action by the common lawes of this Realme to compell the ≈øaid R. E. T. E. and G. E. or any of them to a≈ø≈øure vnto him this complainant, the ≈øaid manor, lands, tenements, and premi≈ø≈øes, according to the ≈øaid bargaine thereof, for lacke of the ≈øaid Indenture, both partes thereof being come to the hands of the ≈øaid defendants. Neither if this complainant had the ≈øaid part or Counterpaine of the ≈øaid Indenture (as he hath not) yet had he not thereby any meanes by the common lawes of this Realme, to compell the ≈øaid T. E. and G. E. or either of them to performe the bargaine and couenants therein contained, they the ≈øaid T. and G. being as is afore≈øaid, vnder the age of one and twenty yeares, at the time of the making thereof, It may plea≈øe your honorable Lord≈øhip, the premi≈ø≈øes, con≈øidered, to grant vnto him this complainant, the Queenes Maie≈øties mo≈øt gratious writ of Subpena to be directed to the ≈øaid R. E. T. E. and G. E. and euery of them, thereby commaunding them and euery of them at a certaine day, and vnder a certaine paine therein by your good Lord≈øhip to be limitted, to be and per≈øonally to appeare before your honorable Lord≈øhip in the Queenes Maie≈øties high Court of Chancery, then and there to an≈øwere vnto the premi≈ø≈øes, and further to ≈øtand to, and abide ≈øuch order and direction therin, as to your good L. vpon the hearing of the ≈øaid cau≈øe ≈øhal ≈øeeme to be agreeable with right, equity, and good con≈øcience &c.

div.head: A Bill again≈øt the heire for entring into lands deui≈øed to the plaintife, praying a Commi≈ø≈øion to examine witne≈ø≈øes in perpetuam rei memoriam.
div.p:
HVmbly complaining ≈øheweth vnto your good Lord≈øhippe your Sect. 110. poore and di≈øtre≈ø≈øed orator G. W. of N. in the County of N. yeoman. That whereas W. W. decea≈øed father vnto your ≈øaid Orator was in his life time lawfully ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne as of fee, of, and in the manor and Capitall me≈ø≈øuage of N. in the County of N. and of, and in one farme ≈øet lying and being within the pari≈øh of W. in the ≈øaid County of N. & of diuers other lands, tenements, & hereditaments in N. afore≈øaid. And al≈øo whereas the ≈øaid W. W. decea≈øed
was likewi≈øe in his life time lawfully ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne as of fee of, & in certaine ground, and one tenement with the appurtenances, ≈øet lying and being within the pari≈øh of C. in the Countie of D. and al≈øo of, and in the rectorie and per≈øonage of C. alias C. within the ≈øaid County of D. and of diuers other landes, and tenements, ≈øet lying and being in the countie of N. and D. and he ≈øo being of the ≈øaid landes and tenements ≈øei≈øed, did by his la≈øt Will and Te≈øtament in writing, deui≈øe and bequeath vnto your ≈øaid humble Orator, and to the heires males of his bodie lawfully begotten, certaine parcels of land, of, and in the ≈øaide Manor of N. that is to ≈øay, one man≈øion hou≈øe wherein your ≈øaid poore Orator now inhabiteth and dwelleth, one clo≈øe commonly called B. containing by e≈øtimation, two acres or thereaboutes, one other clo≈øe commonly called C. containing by e≈øtimatioÃÑ two acres or therabouts, one other clo≈øe commonly called the vpper S. all which ≈øeuerall parcels of land are ≈øcituate, lying, and being in N. as is afore≈øaid, in the fore≈øaid Countie of N. one me≈ø≈øuage or tenement commonly called by the name of an oxgang, ≈øcituate and being in W. in the ≈øaid County of N. and al≈øo one tenement called the N. ≈øcituate, lying, and being in the Countie of D. and al≈øo one lea≈øe of the rectorie, and per≈øonage of C. in the County of D. by vertue & force of which ≈øaid deui≈øe, and bequeath, your ≈øaid humble Orator entered into the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes, and the ≈øaide i≈ø≈øues and profits of the ≈øame hath perceiued, receiued, and taken to his owne profit, v≈øe and behoofe, as lawfull was for him≈øelfe to doe, as he verely beleeueth. But now ≈øo it is, if it may plea≈øe your honorable good Lord≈øhip, hhat one R. W. brother to your ≈øaid humble Orator, as ≈øonne and heire apparant to the ≈øaid W. W. his father decea≈øed, hath taken away, concealed and cancelled, as it is thought, the ≈øaid la≈øt Will and Te≈øtament of your ≈øaid Orators father, and hath taken vpon him the admini≈øtration of all the goods and chattels, of your ≈øaid Orators father reiecting and di≈øanulling the ≈øaid la≈øt Will and Te≈øtament made by your ≈øaid Orators father as afore≈øaid, to thintent only & therby of ≈øet purpo≈øe, malice, and vnbrotherlike dealing, to defraud, expell, depriue, and di≈øinherit your ≈øaid Orator of his right, title, and intere≈øt of, and in the ≈øaid lands deui≈øed to him as afore≈øaid, and al≈øo doth threaten your fore≈øaid Orator, that he may at his plea≈øure relinqui≈øh and di≈øanul the before≈øaid la≈øt Will and Te≈øtament made by your fore≈øaid Orators father as is afore≈øaid, and did take the admini≈øtration of all your ≈øaid Orators fathers goods, and chattels, and entred into all his ≈øaid landes, as is afore≈øaid, contrarie vnto all right, equity, and good con≈øcience, and not chri≈øtianlike but vnbrotherlike dealing, and contrarie to the true intent and good meaning of your fore≈øaid Orators Fathers Will, made as is afore≈øaid, vnle≈ø≈øe your good Lord≈øhip doe according vnto your accu≈øtomed
goodne≈ø≈øe, extend your clemency, and pitty in that behalfe to your poore Orator. In con≈øideration whereof the premi≈ø≈øes con≈øidered, and for as much as the title of your ≈øaid Orator, by rea≈øon of the vndirect practi≈øe v≈øed as afore≈øaid, in concealing, cancelling, and relinqui≈øhing the ≈øaid la≈øt Will, as afore≈øaid, doth greatly depend vpon the witne≈ø≈øe and te≈øtimony of certaine per≈øons dwelling within the County of N‚ñ™ to prooue the true meaning of your ≈øaid orators fathers Wil, which are of great yeares, and al≈øo very impotent, not like long to liue, nor yet able to trauell to this honorable Court to be examined for the te≈øtifying of the trueth, touching the premi≈ø≈øes, as by common order appertaineth. And al≈øo for that in time the ≈øaid witne≈ø≈øes may die, and by meanes thereof your ≈øaid Orator may be in danger to ≈øu≈øtaine di≈øinheri≈øon of the premi≈ø≈øes. May it therefore plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip to grant the Queens, &c.

div.head: A Bill for refu≈øing to receiue the Plaintifes rent according to an order, and taking of forfeiture of a bonde made for payment of the rent.
div.p:
HVmbly complaining, ≈øheweth to your good Lo. your daily Orator Sect' 111. I. T. of G. in the County of N. yeoman, that whereas one I. K. of W. in the County of Yorke Miller, pretended as in the right of his wife to be owner of a certaine me≈ø≈øuage in E. in the County of N. afore≈øaid, and of certaine land, meadow, and pa≈øture thereuuto belonging, and lying within the fields of E. afore≈øaid, and the ≈øaid I. R. ≈øo preteÃÑding him≈øelfe in the right of his ≈øaid wife to be ≈øei≈øed as is afore≈øaid about the 19. or 20. yeare of the Queenes Maie≈øties mo≈øt gratious Kaigne, that now is, did demi≈øe the ≈øaid me≈ø≈øuage and land in E. afore≈øaid vnto your ≈øaid Orator, and one A. L. Gentleman to haue and to hold to them for the terme of 21. yeares from the time of the making thereof, rendering therefore yeerely the rent of xx. sÃÑ. payable at Whit≈øontide and Martimnas by euen portions, for the payment of which ≈øaid rent of xx. sÃÑ. he the ≈øaid K. knowing him≈øelfe the title thereof to be que≈øtionable, and likely to grow to ≈øome charges in law to your ≈øaid Orator to defend, did therefore cunningly get your ≈øaide Orator to become bound in an obligation of xx. l . for the yearely paiment of the ≈øaid rent accordingly vnto him the ≈øaid K. after which lea≈øe and bond ≈øo made, as afore≈øaid, and al≈øo immediatly after your ≈øaid Orators entrie into the ≈øame, the title thereof was ≈øo defended again≈øt your ≈øaid Orator, by ≈øuch as claimed the ≈øame again≈øt him the ≈øaide K. as that the charges thereof ≈øpent about the recouering thereof, did ≈øtand your ≈øaid Orator in aboue twenty nobles, be≈øides the great trauaile and lo≈ø≈øe of time that your ≈øaid Orator ≈øu≈øtained thereby, being yet altogether vnrecompenced at the ≈øaid K. hands, although he often promi≈øed to haue ≈øome con≈øideration
thereof towards your ≈øaid Orator. And whereas al≈øo ≈øince and immediatly after that time, he the ≈øaid I. K. likewi≈øe in the right of his ≈øaid wife pretended to haue right vnto certaine copihold lands lying in the pari≈øh of E. afore≈øaid, then being in the occupation of your ≈øaid Orator and other per≈øons, for the triall whereof, there being certaine actions depending in the copihold Court at Southwell, it was notwith≈øtanding before the triall thereof, a≈øwell by the con≈øent of the ≈øaid K. of the one party, as al≈øo by the a≈ø≈øent of your ≈øaid Orator, & the defendant on the other party, referred to the order and arbitrement of one P. K. and I. B. E≈øquires, that they ≈øhould order and determine, a≈øwell the right, as the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid copiholde landes ≈øo then in que≈øtion, which ≈øaid P. K. and I. B. E≈øquires, being willing the controuer≈øies, might haue a good and finall end, and yet them≈øelues hauing then no good opportunity to attend the ≈øame, did therefore entreate a≈øwell the ≈øaid I. K. as al≈øo your ≈øaid Orator and the other, that it might ≈øtande with their likings, that one M. C. and H. W. of M. for that they were beter acquainted with the intere≈øt of both the parties, might therefore order and make an ende thereof in all points, as ≈øhould ≈øeeme good vnto them, whereunto a≈øwell the ≈øaid K. as al≈øo your ≈øaid Orator, with the re≈øt agreed, promi≈øing to performe any ≈øuch order as they the ≈øaid C. and W. ≈øhould in that behalfe make and agree vpon: Whereupon the ≈øaid M. C. and the ≈øaid H. W. taking vpon them the ≈øaid arbitrement, did thus, or to rhe like effect, order, agree, and publi≈øh their order and award, that your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhould ≈øtil enioy and continue his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid copihold lands, for, and during ≈øo long time as the wife of the ≈øaid K. ≈øhould liue, paying yearely for the ≈øaid copihold land vnto the ≈øaid K. foure ≈øhillings rent, and for that he the ≈øaid K. receiued al≈øo an other rent of xx. ≈øhillings by the yeare, at two ≈øeuerall times of your ≈øaid Orator, for the freehold land afore≈øaid, they the ≈øaid arbitrators, for the more ea≈øe and certainty of him the ≈øaid K. did further order and appoint, that your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhould al≈øo pay the ≈øaid foure ≈øhillings rent for the copihold land, at the ≈øame time that the other rent for the freehold was v≈øed to be paid, which was at Whit≈øontide and Martinmas, ≈øo that from thenceforth, he your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhould yearly pay at the daies afore≈øaid, the whole and intire ≈øumme of xii. ≈øhillings at euery of the ≈øaid fea≈øts. And al≈øo for that the ≈øaid arbitrators did well fore≈øee, that the ≈øaid intire payment of xii. ≈øhillings at one day and in≈øtant, could not conueniently be paide on the ≈øeuerall landes, out of the which they in trueth and law were ≈øeuerally i≈ø≈øuing, for that the ≈øaide freehold and copihold land be di≈øtant in ≈øeuerall places, therefore the ≈øaid Arbitrators, for the more ea≈øe and certainetie of him the ≈øaid K. did order and appoint, that your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhould yearely at the daies
afore≈øaid, or within xiiii. daies after euery of them, pay the ≈øaid rent of xii. ≈øhillings at the hou≈øe of one W. W. of M. being a friends hou≈øe of him the ≈øaid K. and al≈øo farre neerer vnto the ≈øaid K. his dwellings, then the land it ≈øelfe is, vnto which ≈øaid order and Arbitrement, he the ≈øaid K. together with your ≈øaid Orator did willingly agree and condi≈øcend: And ≈øo for the ≈øpace of ≈øeuen or eight yeares la≈øt pa≈øt, the ≈øaid K. hath alwaies receiued his rent, accordingly, at the hou≈øe of the ≈øaid W. W. of M. afore≈øaid: Notwith≈øtanding ≈øo it is if it may plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, that the ≈øaid I. K. meaning as it ≈øeemeth, not onely contrary to the ≈øaid order and award, but al≈øo contrary to all right, equitie, and good con≈øcience, ≈øubtilly and extreamely to take aduantage of your ≈øaid Orators bond of xx. pound, hath refu≈øed to receiue your ≈øaid Orators la≈øt Whit≈øontides rent, readie for him at the ≈øaid W. hou≈øe in M. afore≈øaid, according to the ≈øaid order and award therein made, as afore≈øaid: May it therefore plea≈øe your good &c.

div.head: A Bill for payment for cattell ≈øold, without pre≈øent money, or e≈øpecialities, by rea≈øon of tru≈øt repo≈øed in the vendee.
div.p: HVmbly complaining ≈øheweth vnto your good L. your daily Orator Sect' 112. W. B. of B. in the county of N. Butcher, That where as your ≈øaid Orator about ≈øixe or ≈øeuen yeares now la≈øt, ≈øold and deliuered vnto one R. W. of the ≈øame Towne and Countie Butcher, ≈øixe Steares, and fiue Oren, being all fat cattell, for the price of xl. l . and x. sÃÑ. which ≈øaid ≈øumme of xl. l . and x. sÃÑ. the ≈øaid R. W. then faithfully promi≈øed to pay vnto your ≈øaid Orator within a ≈øhort ≈øpace then after, and now long ≈øithence pa≈øt, or el≈øe when your ≈øaid Orator would require & demaunde the ≈øame of him the ≈øaid R. W. of which ≈øaid bargaine and ≈øecurity for the ≈øaid money, your ≈øaid Orator was then the le≈ø≈øe carefull, for that your ≈øaid Orator not long before, had been ≈øeruant vnto the ≈øaid R. W. and for that the ≈øaid W. had been ma≈øter vnto your ≈øaid Orator, therefore your ≈øaid Orator did tru≈øt him the ≈øaid W. ≈øo well, as that he neither tooke any ≈øpecialty or ≈øecurity of him the ≈øaid W. for the ≈øaid ≈øum of xl. l . & x. sÃÑ. nor prouided any witne≈ø≈øes to be pre≈øeÃÑt & to te≈øtify the ≈øame bargaine & coÃÑtract betwixt them, but only priuatly betwixt them≈øelues contracted the ≈øame. And like wi≈øe your ≈øaid Orator priuatly deliuered the ≈øaid ≈øixe Steares & fiue Oren, vnto him the ≈øaid R. W. vpon tru≈øt, and performance of his priuate ≈øpeech, & promi≈øe of paiment thereof as afore≈øaid, whereupon the ≈øaid R. W. then pre≈øently receiued the ≈øaid ≈øix Steares and fiue Oren, at your ≈øaid Orators hands, & did pre≈øently afterwards conuert the ≈øame to his owne proper v≈øe and benefit: before the money paid by him the ≈øaid W. vnto your ≈øaid Orator for the ≈øame, &c. May it therefore plea≈øe your honorable Lord≈øhip, &c.

div.head: A Reioinder.
div.p: THe ≈øaid defendant reioyneth and ≈øaith in all and euery thing and Sec' 113. things, as he in his ≈øaid an≈øwere hath made, and doth and will auerre, iu≈øtifie, maintaine, and proue the ≈øame an≈øwere, and all and euery thing and things, clau≈øe, ≈øentence, article, and allegation therein contained, to be good, iu≈øt, and true, certaine, and ≈øufficient in the law to be replied vnto, in ≈øuch ≈øort, manner, and forme, as the ≈øame beene therein mo≈øt truly ≈øet forth and declared. And this defendant further ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid Replication of the ≈øaid complainant is very incertain, vntrue, & in≈øufficient in the law to be reioyned vnto by this defendant, for diuers apparant faults & imperfections, therin contained. And y‚Ä¢ the ≈øame is ≈øo contriued & made, by the ≈øaid coÃÑplainant for the cau≈øes in the ≈øaid an≈øwere expre≈ø≈øed, and to the end to giue ≈øome further colour, or rather ≈øhadow for the maintenance of the ≈øaid bill without cau≈øe in this hnorable court, to the vniu≈øt vexation of this defendaÃÑt, as may appeare, for that, ≈øhe the ≈øaid complainant, by the ≈øini≈øter meanes of one T. Y. who as it is ≈øaid, procureth and ≈øoliciteth the ≈øame ≈øuit for the ≈øaid complainant again≈øt this defendant, hath without all order, as he is informed, cau≈øed him being a plaine ≈øimple vnlearned man, to become bounden by obligation, for the proceeding in the ≈øaid ≈øuit of this defendant and with ≈øuch condition whereof this defendant is vtterly ignorant, of all which this defendant hopeth this honorable Court will haue due con≈øideration for the puni≈øhing of ≈øuch lewde and indirect cour≈øes and actions therein v≈øed. And without that, that any other matter, thing or things, clau≈øe, ≈øentence, article, or allegation in the ≈øaid replication contained materiall or effectuall in the lawe to be reioyned vnto by this defendant, & not here in this his reioinder ≈øufficiently reioined vnto, confe≈ø≈øed, and auoided, denied, or trauer≈øed, is true. All which matters this defendant is readie to auerre, and proue as this honorable Court ≈øhall award, and therefore praieth as he before in his ≈øaid an≈øwere hath praied.

div.head: A Bill vpon putting one to ≈øeruice with promi≈øe that the ≈øeruant ≈øhall ≈øerue truely, and that the defendant will ≈øatisfie all damages, which ≈øhall happen to the Maister by the ≈øame ≈øeruant, &c.
div.p:
HVmbly complaining ≈øheweth vnto your honorable Lord≈øhip C. T Sect. 114. of the town of M. in the County of N. gentleman, That whereas S. N. daughter of A. S. of the Towne of A. in the Countie of Yorke, about two yeares now la≈øt pa≈øt, being de≈øirous to ≈øerue your ≈øaid Orator, and his wife then dwelling at Rotheram, at an Inne there, called the ≈øigne of the Angell in the ≈øaid Countie of Yorke, was entertained into their ≈øeruice at, and vpon the further entreatie of the ≈øaid S. A. and
vpon her faithfull promi≈øe vnto the ≈øaid Orator then ginen, and made, that the ≈øaid M. her daughter ≈øhould during the time of ther ≈øeruice and abode with your ≈øaid Orator, houe≈øtly, faithfully, and truely behaeu her ≈øelfe and ≈øerue your ≈øaid Orator and his wife, in all lawfull bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and that if any lo≈ø≈øe or preiudice ≈øhould befall vnto your ≈øaid Orator through either negligence, default, or abu≈øe of the fore≈øaid M. in any re≈øpect, that then the ≈øaid A. would vpon notice to her giuen in that behalfe by your ≈øaid Orator of ≈øuch lo≈ø≈øe and detriment in that behalfe ≈øu≈øtained, ≈øati≈øfie and recompence your ≈øaid Orator for the ≈øame to the vttermo≈øt value thereof. By rea≈øon whereof your fore≈øaid Orator entertained and receiued the fore≈øaid M. into his ≈øeruice, as is afore≈øaid. And thereupon the wife of your ≈øaid Orator deliuered vnto the ≈øaid M. to her onely charge and cu≈øtodie, many and ≈øundry parcels of plate, linnen, and al≈øo other nece≈ø≈øarie things, for your fore≈øaid Orators behalfe. In which ≈øaid ≈øeruice the ≈øaid M. remained with your ≈øaid Orator by the ≈øpace of one whole yeare then next following. Now ≈øo it is, if it may plea≈øe your ≈øaid honorable Lord≈øhip, during the time of the abode of the fore≈øaid M. in ≈øeruice with your ≈øaid Orator as is afore≈øaid, The fore≈øaid M. did not onely ≈øecretly and priuily deliuer vnto the fore≈øaid A. S. her mother, diuers of the ≈øaid parcels of plate, linnen, and other vten≈øils of your ≈øaid Orators, to the full value of twentie markes, or thereabouts, to, and for the v≈øe and behalfe of the ≈øaid A. But al≈øo during the ≈øaid time, conuerted ≈øundrie other parcels of goods, and ≈øums of money receiued of gue≈øtes that re≈øorted to the ≈øaid hou≈øe, appertaining to your ≈øaid Orator, vnto the onely v≈øe and benefit of the ≈øaid M. her ≈øelfe. By meanes whereof your ≈øaid Orator was greatly preiudiced, and hindred to his lo≈ø≈øe of 30. or 40. pounds, or thereabouts, vpon which occa≈øions your ≈øaid Orator was enforced to put the ≈øaid M. forth of his ≈øeruice. And although your ≈øaid Orator hath diuer≈øe and ≈øundrie times heretofore notified, & made knowen vnto the ≈øaid ‚Ä¢ . the lo≈ø≈øe and hinderance, by her ≈øu≈øtained, as is afore≈øaid, by & through the negligence default, and abu≈øe of the ≈øaid M. as is afore≈øaid, and hath required recompence and ≈øati≈øfaction for the ≈øaid goods ≈øo deliuered and conuerted to the v≈øe of the ≈øaid A. and M. as is afore≈øaid, according to the promi≈øe of the ≈øaid A. made to your ≈øaid Orator vpon the entertaining of the ≈øaid M. into his ≈øeruice as is afore≈øaid, yet the ≈øaid A. the ≈øame to doe hath heretofore refu≈øed and denied, and ≈øtill doth refu≈øe & denie to do, contrarie to her promi≈øe & a≈ø≈øumption afore≈øaid, & again≈øt all right, equity and con≈øcience. In con≈øideration whereof, and fora≈ømuch as your ≈øaid Orator is not able to make any due proofe, neither of the certainty or quantity of the plate, linnen, and other goods ≈øo ≈øecretly deliuered to the ≈øaid A. by M. during the time of her ≈øeruice, as is afore≈øaide, or of the ≈øaide
other goods, conuerted by the ≈øaid M. to her own v≈øe, as if afore≈øaid, nor of the promi≈øe made by the ≈øaid A. vnto your ≈øaid Orator vpon the retaining of y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid M. into his ≈øeruice as is afore≈øaid, by rea≈øon the ≈øame was in ≈øecret betwene th√®≈øelues without calling any other to witnes y‚Ä¢ ≈øame, whereby your ≈øaidorator, by the ≈øtrict rule and cour≈øe of the common lawes of this Realme, hath no ordinarie meanes for recouery of the ≈øame, but onely by ≈øuite before your honorable Lord≈øhip in the Queens Maie≈øties high Court of Chancery, by the oathes of the ≈øaid A. and M. in who≈øe priuities all the premi≈ø≈øes principally lie and whom your Orator thinketh vpon their ≈øaid oathes, wil reueile and manife≈øt the truth, and circum≈øtance of the ≈øame, the premi≈ø≈øes con≈øidered, May it therefore plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip to grant vnto your ≈øaid Orator the Queenes Maie≈øties mo≈øt gratious writ of Subpena to be directed to the ≈øaid A. and M. and either of them, commaunding them thereby, not onely to appeare before your honor in the Queenes Maie≈øties high Court of Chancerie, at a certaine day, and vnder a certaine paine therein to be limitted and a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, then and there to an≈øwere to the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes, But al≈øo to ≈øtand to, and abide ≈øuch further order and direction therein, as to your H. wi≈øedome ≈øhall be thought fit and conuenient, and your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhall daily pray vnto God for the long continuance of your H. in health and pro≈øperitie.

div.head: The ioint and ≈øeuerall an≈øweres, of A. S. and M. S. defendants to the bill of complaint of C. T. complainant.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid defendants ≈øay, and either of them, for him≈øelfe ≈øeuerally Sect. 116. ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid bil of complaint again≈øt them exhibited into this honorable court, is very vncertaine, vntrue, and in≈øufficient in the lawe to be an≈øwered vnto by the ≈øaid defendants, or either of them, for diuers manife≈øt and apparant faults and imperfections therein contained, and deui≈øed, and exhibited into this honorable court of meere mallice and enuie, onely to the intent, not onely to vere and trouble the defendants, being verie vnable and vnmete vpon the ≈øudden with long and tedious iorneis to make their per≈øonall appara ‚Ä¢ ces in this H. court, being aboue one hundred and twenty miles di≈øtant from the to „Äà‚óä„Äâ of a. in the countrie of Y. where the≈øe defendants now dwell, but al≈øo to wearie the defendants in ≈øuch ≈øort, that they might extort & wring from the≈øe defendants ≈øome con≈øideration for the ≈øtay of the fore≈øaid ≈øuit, be it neuer ≈øo vntrue, & without any iu≈øt cau≈øe or colour of cau≈øe ≈øo to do, neuertheles if the≈øe defendants ≈øhal by y‚Ä¢ order of this honorable court he compelled to make any further, or other an≈øwer to the ≈øaid vncertain, & in≈øufficient bil of complaint, then the aduantage of exception to the manife≈øt incertaintie and in ‚Ä¢ ≈øufficiencie of the ≈øame bill of complaint to the≈øe defendants,
and either of them at all times hereafter ≈øaued, for an≈øwere thereunto, and for a manife≈øt declaration of the trueth, touching the contents of the ≈øame bill, the≈øe defendants ≈øay, and either of them, for him≈øelfe ≈øeuerally ≈øaith, that about the time mentioned in the ≈øaid bill of complaint, the ≈øaid M. St. the other of the≈øe defendants was entertained to ≈øerue the ≈øaid complainant & his wife for the terme of one yeare next en≈øuing the time of ≈øuch her reteiner, for xvi. sÃÑ. wages for the ≈øame yeare, without the knowledge of the ≈øaid A. St. the other of the≈øe defendants, vntil that ≈øhe the ≈øaid M. was ≈øo with them retained. And the≈øe defendants further ≈øay, that by vertue of the ≈øame retainer, the ≈øaid M. did hone≈øtly, faithfully, and truely behaue her ≈øelfe, & did ≈øerue the ≈øaid complainant and his ≈øaid wife in all lawfull bu≈øines accordingly, during all the ≈øaid yeare, and that to her knowledge no lo≈ø≈øe nor preiudice did be fall vnto the ≈øaid complainant through the negligence, default or abu≈øe of the ≈øaid M. in any re≈øpect during the ≈øame yeare. And that in the ende thereof ≈øhe departed from them with their fauour & goodwill, at her owne reque≈øt, without that, that ≈øhe the ≈øaid M. was entertained in their ≈øaid ≈øeruice, at & vpon the entreatie of the ≈øaid A. S. and vpon her faithfull promi≈øe vnto the ≈øaid complainant then giuen & made, that the ≈øaid M. her ≈øaid daughter ≈øhould during the time of her ≈øeruice & abode with the ≈øaid complainant hone≈øtly, faithfully, & truely behaue her ≈øelfe, ≈øeruing him and his ≈øaid wife in all lawfull bu≈øine≈ø≈øes, and that if any lo≈ø≈øe or preiudice ≈øhould befall vnto the ≈øaid complainant through the negligeÃÑce or abu≈øe of her the ≈øaid M. in any re≈øpect, that then ≈øhe the ≈øaid A. St. vpon notice to her giuen by the ≈øaid complainant of ≈øuch lo≈ø≈øe and detriment in that behalfe ≈øu≈øtained, would ≈øati≈øfie and recompence the ≈øaid complainant, for the ≈øame to the vttermo≈øt value thereof, or that by rea≈øon thereof the ≈øame complainant entertained and receiued M. in his ≈øaide ≈øeruice, as in the ≈øaide bill it is vntruely alleaged. And the ≈øaid defenda ‚Ä¢ ts further ≈øay, that albeit ≈øhe the ≈øaid A. S. had made vnto t ‚Ä¢ e ≈øaid complainant any ≈øuch promi≈øe as he in his bill of complaint ≈øuppo≈øeth (as in very trueth ≈øhe did not) yet were the ≈øame promi≈øe voide in law, and of n ‚Ä¢ validitie or force to bind her thereby, for that the ≈øaid a. at the time of the ≈øaid ≈øurmi≈øed promi≈øe was couert with I. S. her hu≈øband. And without that, that vpon ≈øuch promi≈øe the ≈øaid wife of the ≈øaide coÃÑplainant deliuered vnto y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid M. to her charge and cu≈øtodie many parcels of linnen, and other nece≈ø≈øarie things, and furniture for the ≈øaid complainant his behalfe in any other maner then, as to euery other ordinarie ≈øeruant in the ≈øame hou≈øe in the like ca≈øe, without taking vpon her any ≈øpeciall charge for the keeping thereof, as in the ≈øaid bill of complaint it is verie vntruely alleaged, and without that, that during the ≈øame time of the ≈øaide abode of her the
≈øaid M. in ≈øeruice with the ≈øaid complainant, as afore≈øaid, the ≈øaid M. did either ≈øecretly deliuer vnto the ≈øaid A. S. her ≈øaid mother diuers or any of the ≈øaid parcels of plate, linnen, and other goods, for the v≈øe and behoofe of the ≈øaid A. S. or during the ≈øaid terme conuerted ≈øundrie or anie other parcels of goods and ≈øummes of money receiued of gue≈øtes that re≈øorted to the ≈øaid hou≈øe, appertaining to the ≈øaid complainant, vnto the v≈øe and benefit of the ≈øaid M. her ≈øelfe, by meanes whereof the ≈øaid complainant was greatly preiudiced and hindered, to the lo≈ø≈øe of 30. or 40. l . or thereabouts, or that vpon ≈øuch occa≈øions the ≈øaid complainant was enforced to put the ≈øaid M. from his ≈øeruice, for that the ≈øaid complamant hath diuer≈øe and ≈øundrie times heretofore notified and made known vnto the ≈øaid A. the lo≈ø≈øe & hurt he ≈øu≈øtained, as is afore≈øaid by, & through the negligence, default, & abu≈øe of the ≈øaid M. as is afore≈øaid, and required recompence and ≈øati≈øfaction for the ≈øaid goods ≈øo ≈øuppo≈øed to the deliuered, and conuerted to the v≈øe of the ≈øaid A. and M. as is afore≈øaid, as in the ≈øaid bill of complaint is mo≈øt vntruly alleaged. And without that, that any other matter, thing, or things, clau≈øe, ≈øentence, article, or allegation in the ≈øaid bill of complaint contained materiall, or effectual, in the law to be an≈øwered vnto by the≈øe defendaÃÑts, or either of them, and not herein in their an≈øwere ≈øufficiently an≈øwered vnto, confe≈ø≈øed, and auoided, denied, or trauec≈øed, is true, all which matters the≈øe defendants and either of them, are readie to auerre and proue as this honorable Court ≈øhal award, and therefore they pray to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed out of the ≈øame court, with their rea≈øonable co≈øts and charges in this behalf wrongfully and without cau≈øe ≈øu≈øtained.

div.head: The Replication to the ≈øame An≈øwere.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid complainant ≈øauing to him≈øelfe all aduantages of exception Sect. 116. to the incertainties and in≈øufficiency of the ≈øaid defendants an≈øweres, for replication ≈øaith as he before by his ≈øaid bil hath ≈øaid, and doth, and‚ñ™ wil auerre, iu≈øtifie, and maintaine his ≈øaid bill, & all and euerie thing and things therein contained to be good, iu≈øt, and true in ≈øuch ≈øort manner and forme, as in and by the ≈øame is mo≈øt truely ≈øet forth and declared. And that the an≈øweres of the ≈øaid defendants are vncertaine, vntrue, and in≈øufficieÃÑt in the law to be replied vnto for diuers vntruths and imperfections therein conteined, without that, that the ≈øaid M. one of the ≈øaid defendants did hone≈øtly, faithfully, and truely behaue her ≈øelfe in the ≈øeruice of the ≈øaid complainant as by the ≈øame defendants in their ≈øaid aun≈øweres is vntruely alleaged, for this ≈øaide complainant ≈øaith, as he before by his ≈øaide Bill hath ≈øaid, that the ≈øaid M. one of the ≈øaide defendantes did ≈øecretly deliuer to the ≈øaide A. the other defendant diuers parcels of the goods of the ≈øaide complainant, that
the ≈øaid defendants mo≈øt wrongfully detaine and withhold from him the ≈øaid complainant again≈øt right and equitie, and further the ≈øaid complainant ≈øaith, and will auerre and proue, that the ≈øaid A. one of the ≈øaid defendants, did giue her faithfull promi≈øe to ≈øati≈øfie and pay vnto the ≈øaid complainant the vttermo≈øt value of euery lo≈ø≈øe, or hinderance the ≈øaid complainant ≈øhould ≈øu≈øtaine by the ≈øaid M. as by his bill is mo≈øt truly ≈øet forth & declared, without that, that any other matter, or thing in the ≈øaid defendants an≈øwere contained materiall or effectuall, to be replied vnto, in, and hereby not ≈øufficiently replied vnto is true. All which matters the ≈øaid complainant is readie to auerre and proue, as this honorable court ≈øhall award. And praieth as he before by his ≈øaid bill hath praied.

div.head: A Bill for entring into and detaining copihold lands ≈øold by the defendant to the plaintifes grandfather, which de≈øcended to the plaintife being an infant, the ≈øaid entrie being made by rea≈øon that the copy and court rolle of the ≈øaid bargaine came to the defendants hands.
div.p:
HVmbly complaining‚ñ™ ≈øheweth vnto your Lord≈øhip, your daily Orator Sect. 117. F. H. of W. in the countie of Yorke gentleman, that whereas about the xxiiii. day of September in the third yeare of the raigne of the late King of famous memory Edward the ≈øixt, one Chri≈øtopher Baxter late of F. in the ≈øaid Countie hu≈øbandman, was lawfully and rightfully ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne as of fee, as a copiholder, according to the cu≈øtome of the Manor of the prebend of Laghton, it the ≈øaid Countie, of and in one cu≈øtomarie me≈ø≈øuage or tenement, and one oxgange of land, with thappurtenances in F. afore≈øaid: and in another me≈ø≈øuage or tenement, and thirtie acres and a halfe of land with thappurtenances in F. afore≈øaid, and he being thereof ≈øo ≈øei≈øed about the time afore≈øaid, for a certaine great ≈øumme of money to him paid by F. H. of W. afore≈øaid, grandfather of your ≈øaid Orator did ≈øurrender according to the cu≈øtome of the ≈øaid Manor, the ≈øaid cu≈øtomarie tenements and premi≈ø≈øes with thappurtenances into the hands of the then Lords of the ≈øaid Manor, to the v≈øe of the ≈øaid F. H. the grandfather & his heires for euer, by force whereof the ≈øaid F. H. the grandfather was thereof admitted tenant accordingly, and was of the ≈øame, as a copiholder lawfully ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne as of fee, by, and according to the cu≈øtome of the ≈øaid Manor, and the rents, i≈ø≈øues and profits thereof ari≈øing and growing, did likewi≈øe lawfully take & conuert to his owne v≈øe, vy the ≈øpace of diuers yeares, and afterwards the ≈øaid F. H. the grandfather being thereof ≈øo ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid tenements and premi≈ø≈øes, died thereof ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, about the ≈øecond yeare of the raigne of the Queenes mo≈øt excellent Maie≈øtie that now is. By and after who≈øe death the ≈øaid tenements
and premi≈ø≈øes di≈øcended and came, and of right ought to di≈øcend and come vnto your ≈øaid Orator being then of very young and tender yeares, viz. about the age of ≈øixe yeares, as next co≈øin & next heire vnto the ≈øaid F. H. the grandfather, that is to ≈øay, ≈øonn of T. H. ≈øonne & heire of the ≈øaid F. H. the grandfather, but now ≈øo it is, if it may plea≈øe your good L. that after the death of the ≈øaid F. H. the grandfather, all the copies of Court rols of the ≈øaid manor, and the very Court rols them≈øel ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ concerning the premi≈ø≈øes, did by ca≈øuall meanes come vnto the handes, cu≈øtody, & po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid C. B. & one T. G. of T. in the ≈øaid county hu≈øbandman, or to the hands of one of them, which they or the one of them haue cancelled & defaced, intending thereby vtterly to di≈øinherite your ≈øaid Orator of the ≈øame tenements & premi≈ø≈øes, & by colour therof ≈øhortly after the death of the ≈øaid F. H. the grandfather, y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid C. B. old wrongfully abate and enter into the ≈øaid tenements and premi≈ø≈øes. And euer ≈øince his ≈øaid wrongfull entre, that is to ≈øay, by the ≈øpace of xxiiii. yeares or thereabouts, hath wrongfully occupied the premi≈ø≈øes or the mo≈øt part therof, and receiued and taken, and conuerted to his owne v≈øe, the rents, i≈ø≈øues, and profits of the ≈øaid tenements & premi≈ø≈øes, and will not by any meanes permit or ≈øuffer your ≈øaid Orator to enter, meddle, or haue to do therewith. And notwhith≈øtanding that your ≈øaid Orator not onely by him≈øelfe, but al≈øo by his friends, hath in gentle and quiet manner, diuer≈øe times come vnto the ≈øaid C. & T. gently requiring theÃÑ to deliuer vnto him your ≈øaid orator, y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid copies of court rols, & to make rea≈øonable recompence & ≈øati≈øfaction vnto him your ≈øaid Orator for the rents, i≈ø≈øues, & profits of the ≈øaid tenements & premi≈ø≈øes, ≈øo as is afore≈øaid by the ≈øaid C. wrongfully receiued according to your ≈øaid Orator his good right & title therunto, yet that to do, they & either of them haue euer hitherto refu≈øed & denied, & yet do refu≈øe and denie to doe the ≈øame again≈øt all right, equity, and good con≈øcience, and to the di≈øinheri≈øon of your ≈øaid orator, of, & in the premi≈ø≈øes, & to his great lo≈ø≈øe & hinderance, if ≈øpeedy remedy be not by your good Lord≈øhip in this honorable court ≈øpeedily prouided to preuent the ≈øame. In tender con≈øideration wherof, and for ≈øo much as your ≈øaid Orator, not knowing the certain number, dates, or contents of the ≈øaid copies and Court rols, nor wherein they or any of them be conteined, in bagge, bore, or che≈øt, locked, ≈øealed or open, is therefore without all remedy by the due cour≈øe of the common lawes of this Realme to recouer the ≈øame, and for lacke thereof your ≈øaid Orator is very like to lo≈øe the ≈øaid tenements and premi≈ø≈øes, and for that al≈øo, that the contents of the ≈øaid bargaine and ≈øurrender of the ≈øaid tenements and premi≈ø≈øes, ≈øo as is afore≈øaid, made betweene the ≈øaid F. H. grandfather, and the ≈øaid C. B. cannot now otherwi≈øe be proued then by an≈øwere of the ≈øaid C. B. and T. B. made vpon their Dathes in this
honorable Court, all ≈øuch per≈øons as were witne≈ø≈øes of the ≈øame bargaine, being now either dead, or el≈øe vtterly vnknowen vnto your ≈øaid Orator being ≈øo young, as it is afore≈øaid, at the time of the making of the ≈øame. May it plea≈øe your honorable Lord≈øhip to grant vnto your ≈øaid Orator the Queenes Maie≈øties mo≈øt gratious writ of Subpena, to be directed vnto the ≈øaid C. and T. ≈øtraightly commaunding them and either of them, at a certaine day and vnder a certaine paine therein to be limited, to appeare before your Lord≈øhip in her Maie≈øties high court of Chancery, then and there to an≈øwere to the premi≈ø≈øes, and to abide ≈øuch order and direction therein, as to your Lord≈øhip ≈øhal ≈øeeme to ≈øtand with right, equitie, and good con≈øcience, and your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhall daily pray to Almightie God for your honour in good health long to continue, &c.

div.head: A Bill by the husband and wife, as Gardeins to her childe for euidences.
div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe complaining ≈øheweth vnto your good Lord≈øhip. Sect. 118. your poore and daily Orator I. W. of B. in the Countie of D. yeoman, and I. his wife late the wife of I. S. the elder of B. afore≈øaid yeoman now decea≈øed. That where the ≈øaid I. S. in his life time was lawfully ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne, as of fee, of, and in one me≈ø≈øuage or tenement, commonly called H. & of and, in certaine lands, meadow and pa≈øture, and other hereditaments with thappurtenances to the ≈øaid tenement belonging, and with the ≈øame v≈øually occupied, ≈øcituate, lying and being in B. afore≈øaid. And he the ≈øaid I. S. being of the premi≈ø≈øes ≈øo ≈øei≈øed did in his life time conuey and a≈ø≈øure the ≈øame vnto certaine per≈øons, and their heires, to the v≈øe of the ≈øaid I. and of the ≈øaid I. then his wife, and of the longer liuer of them, without impeachment of wa≈øte. And after their di≈øea≈øes, to the v≈øe of the heires of their two bodies lawfully begotten, with diuers remainders ouer, by force whereof the ≈øaid I. S. and the ≈øaid I. then his wife, were thereof ≈øei≈øed accordingly, And ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, the ≈øaid I. S. about three yeares now la≈øt pa≈øt, died ≈øei≈øed of ≈øuch e≈øtate, as afore≈øaid, hauing i≈ø≈øue betweene him and the ≈øaid I. one I. S. an infant of the age of two yeares or therabouts. After who≈øe death the ≈øaid I held her ≈øelfe in the ≈øaid me≈ø≈øuages and lands, and was thereof ≈øei≈øed accordingly. And ≈øo ≈øei≈øed tooke to hu≈øband the ≈øaid I. W. the other of your ≈øaid Orators, by force of which entermariage the ≈øaid I. W. and the ≈øaid I. were lawfully ≈øei≈øed of the premi≈ø≈øes, as in the right of the ≈øaid I. And your ≈øaid Orators haue al≈øo the cu≈øtody of the ≈øaid I. S. the infant, rightly belonging to the ≈øaid I. his mother as gardeine in Socage. Now ≈øo it is, if it may plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhippe, that certaine deedes, euidences, and writings, touching
and concerning the premi≈ø≈øes, and of right belonging to your ≈øaid Orators, and the ≈øaid infant, or to the one of them, are ca≈øually come to to the hands and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of T. C. of B. afore≈øaid, and I. S. of H. being kin≈øman vnto the ≈øaid I. S. of B. the elder decea≈øed, who by colour of hauing the ≈øaid deeds, euidences, and writings, haue wrongfully entred into the premi≈ø≈øes with thappurtenances, and thereupon haue contriued certain ≈øecret e≈øtates vnto diuers per≈øons vnknowen to your ≈øaid Orators, and by colour thereof, they the ≈øaid T. C. and I. S. of H. or the one of them of late time hath wrongfully entred into the premi≈ø≈øes, and hath receiued and taken the i≈ø≈øues and profits of the premi≈ø≈øes, or ≈øome part thereof, from your ≈øaid Orators, and although your ≈øaid Orators haue diuers and ≈øundrie times gently reque≈øted the ≈øaide T. C. and I. S. of H. to permit and ≈øuffer your ≈øaid Orators quietly to haue and enioy the ≈øame premi≈ø≈øes, and to deliuer vnto your ≈øaid Orators the ≈øaid deeds, euidences, and writings, touching and concerning the premi≈ø≈øes, and which of right doe belong and appertaine vnto your ≈øaid Orators, and to the ≈øaid I. S. the infant, yet they the ≈øame to doe haue hitherto refu≈øed, and yet doe refu≈øe contrarie to all right, equity, and good con≈øcience, which is likely to turne, not only to the lo≈ø≈øe and hinderance of your ≈øaid Orators, But al≈øo to the preiudice and di≈øinheritance of the ≈øaid infant, if ≈øpeedie redre≈ø≈øe herein be not had by your good Lord≈øhip, in con≈øideration whereof, and fora≈ømuch as your ≈øaid Orators doe not know the certaintie, nor certaine number of the ≈øaid deedes, euidences, writings, nor whether the ≈øame be contained in bagge or boxe, ≈øealed, or in che≈øt locked, and ≈øo your ≈øaid Orators, and the ≈øaid infant are without any ordinary remedie for the recouerie of the ≈øame by the common lawes of this Realme, And for that your ≈øaid Orators do hope that the ≈øame C. and S. will vpon their Oathes in this honorable Court, confe≈ø≈øe the certainty and truety therein, where the ≈øaid euidences are to be had, or to whom they haue deliuered the ≈øame. May it therefore plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, the premi≈ø≈øes con≈øidered, to grant vnto your ≈øaid Orators the Queenes Maie≈øties, &c.

div.head: The An≈øwere of the ≈øame.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid defendants ≈øay, and euery of them ≈øeuerally ≈øaith, that the Sect. 119. ≈øaid bill of complaint is verie vncertaine, vntrue and in≈øufficient in the law, to be an≈øwered vnto for diuers manife≈øt defaults and imperfections therein contained, and framed, and exhibited into this honorable Court, as the≈øe defendants verely thinke of malice and euill will, to the intent to put the≈øe defendants to great trauaile, charges and expences to make their per≈øonall appearance in this honorable Court, the ≈øaid defendants dwelling in B. afore≈øaid, in the ≈øaide countie of D. which is ≈øix≈øcore miles di≈øtant from the Citie of We≈øtmin≈øter, and
without any iu≈øt cau≈øe ≈øo to doe, and the≈øe defendants further ≈øay, that if the ≈øurmi≈øed matters contained in the ≈øaid bil of complaint were true as in very trueth they are not, yet were the ≈øame determinable, and to be determined by the common lawes of this Realme, and not in this honorable Court, whereunto the≈øe defendants pray to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed with their rea≈øonable co≈øtes, charges, and damages in this behalfe wrongfully and without iu≈øt cau≈øe ≈øu≈øtained, yet neuerthele≈ø≈øe, if the≈øe defendants ≈øhall be compelled by the order of this Court, to make any further or other an≈øwere vnto the ≈øaid vncertaine and in≈øufficient bill of complaint, then the aduantage of exception to the incertaintie and in≈øufficiencie thereof to the≈øe defendants, and either of them at all times here after ≈øaued, for further an≈øwere thereunto, and for a full and plaine declaration of the trueth, ≈øay that they thinke it is true, that the ≈øaid I. S. was in his life time lawfully ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne as of fee, of, and in the ≈øaid me≈ø≈øuage or teuements commonly called the H. and of, and in certaine lands, meadow, and pa≈øture, and other hereditaments with the appurtenances to the ≈øaid tenements belonging, and with the ≈øame v≈øually occupied, ≈øcituate, lying, and being in B. afore≈øaid, as in the ≈øaid bil of complaint is alleaged, but the ≈øaid defendaÃÑts further ≈øay, that the ≈øaid tenements in the ≈øaid bill of complaint contained, as they verely beleeue, are holden of the right honorable G. Earle of S. of his manor of C. in the ≈øaid Countie of D. by knightes ≈øeruice, and by the yearely rents of two ≈øhillings. And that he being thereof ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, and the ≈øaid Earle being al≈øo ≈øei≈øed in fee, of the ≈øaid manor, as the≈øe defendants thinke, died thereof ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, by, and after who≈øe death the ≈øaid tenements and premi≈ø≈øes in the ≈øaid bill mentioned, de≈øcended and came to the ≈øaid I. S. the ≈øonne, as ≈øonne and heire of the ≈øaid I. S. decea≈øed, who is yet within the age of one and twentie yeares, by meanes wherof the ≈øaid Earle after the death of the ≈øaid I. S. the father, as garden of the ≈øaid I. S. infant, during his minority, by rea≈øon of the tenute afore≈øaid, ≈øei≈øed the bodie of the ≈øaid I. S. the infant, without that, that to the ≈øaid defendants knowledge, the ≈øaid I. S. the father being of the premi≈ø≈øes ≈øei≈øed in fee, did in his life time conuey and a≈ø≈øure the ≈øame premi≈ø≈øes vnto certaine per≈øons, and their heires to the v≈øe of the ≈øaid I. S. & of the ≈øaid I. then his wife, & of the longer liuer of either of them, without impeachment of wa≈øt, and after their decea≈øe to the v≈øe of the heires of their two bodies lawfully begotten, with diuers remainders ouer, as in the ≈øaid bill of complaint is vntruely alleaged, or that to the≈øe defendants knowledge, by force thereof the ≈øaid I. S. and the ≈øaid I. S. then his wife being thereof ≈øo ≈øei≈øed died thereof ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, or that to the≈øe defendants knowledge, after his death the ≈øaid I. held her ≈øelfe in the ≈øaid me≈ø≈øuages, landes and premi≈ø≈øes, and was
thereof ≈øo ≈øei≈øed accordingly, by force of any ≈øuch conueiance, or that ≈øhe being thereof ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, tooke to hu≈øband the ≈øaid I. W. or that by force of the ≈øaide entermariage the ≈øaide I. W. and the ≈øaide I. to the knowledge of the≈øe defendants, were ≈øo lawfully ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes, in the right of the ≈øaid I. as in the ≈øaid bill is alleaged. And without that, that to the≈øe defendants knowledge the ≈øaid I. W. and I. haue the cu≈øtodie of the ≈øaid I. S. the infant rightfully belonging to the ≈øaid I. as Gardein in Socage, as in the ≈øaid bill is likewi≈øe alleaged. And without that, that any deeds, euidences, and writings, touching and concerning the premi≈ø≈øes, and of right belonging to the ≈øaid infant, or to one of them, are ca≈øually come to the hands, cu≈øtody, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid defendants other then ≈øuch deedes, euidences, and writings, as the ≈øaid I. did deliuer vnto the ≈øaid T. S. the one of the≈øe defendants, which he the ≈øaid T. about one yeare now la≈øt pa≈øt, or more, vpon the receipt of the Queenes Maie≈øties writ of Subpena deliuered to I. L. late of H. Haull in the County of D. Gentleman, to the v≈øe of the ≈øaid infant which as he remembreth was done by appointment or agreement of the ≈øaid I. And then an other old deede or writing without date conteyning the≈øe words following, or the very like in effect and meaning, viz.

Sciant prae≈øentes & futurÃÑ quod ego Io. filius Tho. de B. dedi conce≈ø≈ø. & hac prae≈øenti charta mea confirmaui Duranto de Toxdwood pro homag', & ≈øeruitio ≈øuo, & pro quadam pecuniae ≈øumma mihi prae manibus ≈øoluta, totam terram meam quae vocatur le Haule cliffe in territorijs de B. cum bo≈øcis, pratis, pa≈øcuis, pa≈øturis & omnibus ≈øuis pertinÃÑ. ≈øine aliquo retento, quae iacet integre in latitud' intÃÑ viam quae ducit ver≈øus B. terram quam L. de L. quondam tenuit, & extendit ≈øe in longitudinÃÑ de meta de B. v≈øque ad terram AbbatÃÑ de R. & terram quae fuit A. F. & terram R. de le Scagh, vna cum tota illa terra cum domibus & edificijs in ea ≈øitis, cum omnibus ≈øuis pertinÃÑ, quam R. de T. quondam tenuit, quae iacet integre inter terra, &c. And without that any other matters, &c.

div.head: A Bill to be di≈øcharged of a Recogni≈øance for the ≈øauing of landes ≈øolde harmele≈ø≈øe, for that a lea≈øe made thereof by which he ≈øeemeth to be dampnified, was either made in tru≈øt or by ≈øurrender, before the ≈øaid bargaine, with an an≈øwere, replication, and reioinder to the ≈øame bill.
div.p:
COmplaining ≈øheweth vnto your honorable Lord≈øhip Geor. Earle Sect. 120. of Shrow≈øbury, that whereas Sir W. S. knight Lord M. deceaced, in his life time, about nine yeares now pa≈øt, was lawfully ≈øei≈øed of an e≈øtate of inheritance among≈øt other lands and tenements, of the third
part of the ≈øcite & man≈øion hou≈øe of the late di≈ø≈øolued Abbey, Mona≈øtery, or Priory of B. in the county of L. and of all and ≈øinguler me≈ø≈øuages, hou≈øes, edifices, buildings, orchards, gardens, fi≈øhings, ponds, lands, tenements, meadowes, pa≈øtures, commons, & hereditaments with the appurtenances to the ≈øaid ≈øcite belonging, then late in the occupation of F. S. & afterwards in thoccupation of one M. and the ≈øaid Lord M. being thereof ≈øo ≈øei≈øed about the xvi. day of December in the vii yeare of the Raigne of our Soueraigne Lady the Queenes Maie≈øty that now is, of ≈øpeciall and ≈øecret tru≈øt & confidence by him the ≈øaid Lord M. repo≈øed in one W. S. of M. in the county of S. gentleman, & M. his wife or of one of them, did make an Indenture bearing date the xvi. day of September, in the ≈øaid vii. yeare of a demi≈øe of the ≈øaid third part of the ≈øaid ≈øcite, lands, tenements, and hereditaments, with the appurtenances to the ≈øaid W. S. and M. his wife, to haue & to hold the ≈øame vnto the ≈øaid W. S. and M. from the decea≈øe of K. T. of S. for and during the terme of xxi. yeares then next en≈øuing, as by the ≈øaid Indenture appeareth. And deliuered the ≈øaid Indenture to be deliuered as his deed, when the ≈øaid W. S. had performed certaine conditions & agreements betweene them made, vpon which Indentures made by them, it was neuer intended nor agreed that the ≈øaid W. S. and M. his wife, or their executors or a≈ø≈øignes, or any of them, ≈øhould take any benefit to them: but that the ≈øame lea≈øe ≈øhould be ≈øurrendred, and at all times di≈øpo≈øed at the plea≈øure of the ≈øaid Lord M. by force whereof the ≈øaid W. S. and M. were po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the intere≈øt of the ≈øaid terme accordingly, and being thereof ≈øo po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, And the ≈øaid L. M. being ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid R. of the third part of the≈øe tenements & premi≈ø≈øes of an e≈øtate of inheritance, afterwards, that is to ≈øay, the xviii. day of May, in the xii. yeare of the Raigne of our ≈øaid Soueraigne Lady, the ≈øaid Lord. M. by Indenture bearing date the ≈øaid day and yeare, did bargaine and ≈øell the ≈øaid third part of the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes among other things to one I. C. of C. in the county of S. E≈øquire, and F. S. of S. in the ≈øaid County Gentleman, and their heires for euer, by which la≈øt recited Indenture, the ≈øaid Lord M. for him and his heires did couenant and grant, to and with the ≈øaid I. C. and F. S. and either of them, that a≈øwell the ≈øaid I. C. and F. S. their heires and a≈ø≈øignes, as all the ≈øaid manors, and tenements, by the ≈øaid Indenture to them bargained and ≈øold, at the en≈øealing and deliuery of the ≈øame Indentures, were di≈øcharged, exonerated or ≈øaued harmele≈ø≈øe, and from thencefoorth at all times, and from time to time hereafter for euer, ≈øhould be di≈øcharged, exonerated, acquited, or ≈øaued harmele≈ø≈øe by the ≈øaid W. Lord M. his heires, executors or admini≈øtrators, of, and from all and ≈øinguler giftes, grants, lea≈øes, charges, and incumbrances, had, made, granted or ≈øuffered in, or to the premi≈ø≈øes,
or any part or parcell thereof, by the ≈øaid Lord M. or by any other per≈øon or per≈øons what≈øoeuer, other then the ≈øaid e≈øtate of the ≈øaid K. S. late Dutche≈ø≈øe of S. and certaine other things, in, and by the ≈øaid Indenture excepted, as by the ≈øaid Indenture appeareth. For performance of which couenant of the ≈øaid Indenture, the ≈øaid Lord M. Eagle, the ≈øecond day of Iune in the ≈øaid xii. yeare, became vounden vnto the ≈øaid I. C. and vnto one M. S. of I. L. in the County of B. E≈øquire, by recogni≈øance knowledged in this high court of Chancery in the ≈øumme of two thou≈øand pounds, as thereby appeareth. And ≈øhortly afterwards, that is to ≈øay, about ≈øixe yeares now la≈øt pa≈øt, the ≈øaide K. late D. of S. died and the ≈øaid I. C. and F. S. entred into the manors, tenements, and premi≈ø≈øes with the appurtenances, and were, and yet be thereof ≈øei≈øed in their deme≈ønes, as of fee, by force of the ≈øaid conueyance, and the profits thereof ari≈øing and comming to their owne v≈øe tooke, and yet doe quietly ≈øo take the ≈øame without any interruption, let, or trouble of the ≈øaid W. S. and M. his wife, and their a≈ø≈øignes, and euerie other per≈øon or per≈øons according to the couenant, true intent, and meaning of the ≈øaid Indenture of bargaine & ≈øale, And afterwards, that is to ≈øay, about fiue yeares now la≈øt pa≈øt, the ≈øaid Lord M. for the ≈øumme of ≈øixe thou≈øand pounds, or thereabouts, did bargaine and ≈øell to the ≈øaid Earle and his heires, the manor of B. in the County of Yorke, and diuers other lands and tenements in B. and other places in the ≈øaid County, by force whereof the ≈øaid Earle was thereof lawfully ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne, as of fee, and the i≈ø≈øues and profits thereof ari≈øing and growing, did quietly take and conuert to his owne v≈øe, from the time of the bargaine, during all the life time of the ≈øaid Lord M. & W.
