S. which was by the ≈øpace of three yeares, after the death of the ≈øaid Dutche≈ø≈øe or thereabouts. And afterwards, that is to ≈øay, about fiue yeares la≈øt pa≈øt, the ≈øaid M. died, ≈øince who≈øe death the ≈øaid I. C. M. S. F. S. T. H. D. W. M. and I. T. And the ≈øaid M. late wife of the ≈øaid W. S. and executrix or admini≈øtratrix of the ≈øaid Will, as the ≈øaide Earle is informed, by the agreement and priuitie of Ed. Lord Morley, and the Lady Elizabeth his wife, daughter and heire of the ≈øaide Lord Mount Eagle, hauing gotten into their hands the ≈øaid Indenture of demi≈øe, albeit that the ≈øaid T. performed not the conditions and couenants betweene him the ≈øaid Lord M. among≈øt them≈øelues, did conceale and fru≈øtrate the ≈øaide tru≈øt repo≈øed by the ≈øaide Lord. M. in the ≈øaide W. S. and M. or the one of them to the intent to extend the ≈øaide Recogni≈øance of two thou≈øand pounds, vpon the ≈øaide manor of B, And ≈øuch other lands and tenementes as the ≈øaide Earle hath purcha≈øed of the ≈øaid Lord M. contrarie to the good meaning of the ≈øaid Lord M. contrarie to the great tru≈øt and confidence by him repo≈øed
in the ≈øaid W. S. and M. his wife, and the true meaning of the ≈øaid Indenture of lea≈øe. And for that purpo≈øe haue procured the ≈øaid e≈øtate and intere≈øt of the ≈øaid W. S. and M. of the ≈øaid third part to be conueied to the ≈øaid M. to the intent that the ≈øaid W. M. ≈øhould enter into the ≈øaid third part ≈øo lea≈øed, as is afore≈øaid, to di≈øturbe the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid C. and F. S. which he hath done accordingly, to the intent that therby, the ≈øaid I. C. & M. S. might haue ≈øome colour to extend the ≈øaid Recogni≈øance of two thou≈øand pounds agin≈øt y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid Earle, notwith≈øtanding that the ≈øaid I. C. & F. S. euer ≈øince the entrie of the ≈øaid M. haue quietly occupied the ≈øaid demi≈øed third part, & yet do quietly occupy the ≈øame, not hauing had any damage thereby to the value of xii. d . by rea≈øon of the ≈øaid lea≈øe, All which notwith≈øtanding, if it may plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, the ≈øaid M. S. F. S. and I. C. haue procured execution of the Recogni≈øance of two thou≈øand pounds, to be ≈øued again≈øt the ≈øaid Earle by proces out of this honorable Court, according to the forme and effect of the ≈øaid recogni≈øance, for that as they ≈øuppo≈øe the ≈øaid third part is charged with the ≈øaid lea≈øe thereof made to the ≈øaid S. and his wife, and a≈ø≈øigned by the ≈øaid S. to the ≈øaid W. M. who by force thereof hath entred into the ≈øaid third part, and di≈øturbed the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid I. C. and F. S. and their a≈ø≈øignes, And for that by meanes therof the ≈øaid manors, lands, and tenements to them bargained and ≈øold by the ≈øaid Lord M. in forme afore≈øaid, were not ≈øaued harmele≈ø≈øe by the ≈øaid Lord M. or his heires of, and from all and ≈øinguler lea≈øes had, made, or granted of the ≈øaid manor and other the premi≈ø≈øes mentioned in the ≈øaid Indenture of Bargaine and ≈øale, according to the forme and effect thereof, which ≈øaid practi≈øe and compact is much again≈øt the ≈øaid tru≈øt and meaning of the ≈øaid Lord M. repo≈øed in the ≈øaid W. S. and M. ‚Ä¢ is wife, and again≈øt the true meaning of the ≈øaid Indenture of lea≈øe & Recogni≈øance, tending to the great lo≈ø≈øe and damage of the ≈øaid Earle, and again≈øt all right, equity, and good con≈øcience, if the ≈øaid purpo≈øe ≈øhould not be equity and con≈øideration of this honorable Court be preuented and mette withall: In con≈øideration wherof, and for ≈øo much as, a≈øwell the ≈øaid tru≈øt touching the ≈øaid lea≈øe as the ≈øaid compact and agreement among≈øt the ≈øaid parties to extend the ≈øaid Earle his ≈øaid lands by rea≈øon of the ≈øaid Recogni≈øance by matters ≈øecretly agreed vppon among≈øt them≈øelues, the ≈øaid Earle not knowing any witne≈ø≈øes which were pre≈øent at the making thereof, ≈øo that the ≈øaid Earle can very hardly make ≈øuch proofe in this honorable Court thereof, or of the ≈øaid conditionall deliuerie of the ≈øaid Indenture, as is nece≈ø≈øary in the behalfe, vnle≈ø≈øe the ≈øaid parties or ≈øome of them will confe≈ø≈øe the ≈øame in their an≈øweres vpon their Oathes in this honorable Court, as the ≈øaid Earle verely thinketh they will. And for a≈ømuch al≈øo as it is very
likely, that the ≈øaid Lord M. would neuer haue entred into the ≈øaid recogni≈øance of two thou≈øand pounds for the performance of the ≈øaid couenants of the ≈øaid Indenture of bargaine and ≈øale, without making exception therein of the ≈øaide lea≈øe, if the ≈øaid lea≈øe of the ≈øaid third part before the making of the ≈øaide Indenture of bargaine and conueyance, had not beene ≈øo deliuered of credit and of tru≈øt fru≈øtrated or granted ouer to the ≈øaid W. M. or ≈øome other by the con≈øent and agreement of the ≈øaid I. C. and F. S. for their benefit, for the auoiding of new charges growing betwene the making of the ≈øaid lea≈øe & the ≈øaid bargaine. And albeit a≈øwell the other two parts of the ≈øaid lands, as all other lands & tenements, with thappurtenances, bargained & ≈øold by the ≈øaid Indenture, were & be clearly di≈øcharged of al incumbrances, according to the true meaning of the ≈øaid Indenture, it may therefore plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, the premi≈øes coÃÑ≈øidered, to grant vnto the ≈øaid Earle the Queenes Maie≈øties mo≈øt gracious writ of Subpena to be directed vnto the ≈øaid I. C. M. S. E. L. M. and E. his wife C. D. W. M. I. T. & M. commaunding them and euery of them, at a certaine day and place, and vnder a certaine paine therein to be limitted, to be, and per≈øonally to appeare before your good Lord≈øhip in the Queenes Maie≈øties high Court of Chancery, then and there to an≈øwere vnto the premi≈ø≈øes, and to abide ≈øuch further order and direction therein, as to your honour ≈øhall ≈øeeme to ≈øtand with right, equitie, and good con≈øcience. And the ≈øaid Earle, &c.

div.head: A Bill for the defendant by meanes of en ‚Ä¢ ermariage, with the wife and executrix of one, who by ca≈øuall meanes got the po≈ø≈øe≈øsion of one deede of demi≈øe indented made vnto the plaintife, detaineth the ≈øaid demi≈øe, and by colour thereof doth occupie the tenements demi≈øed, and taketh the profits to his owne v≈øe.
div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe complaining ≈øheweth vnto your good Lo. your Sect' 121. daily Orator I. M. of B. in the County of N. That whereas one T. C. of D. within the County of Y. did by his deed Indented of demi≈øe, about the fiueteenth yeare of the Raigne of our Soueraigne Ladie the Queenes Maie≈øtie that nowis, demi≈øe and grant to your ≈øaid Orator, ten acres of land, fiue acres of meadow, and fiue acres of pa≈øture with thapppurtenances, lying and being in B. afore≈øaid: To haue and to hold to your ≈øaid Orator and his a≈ø≈øignes, for the terme of xxi. yeares, from and after a certaine day therein expre≈ø≈øed, if the ≈øaid T. C. ≈øhould ≈øo long liue, for the yearely rent of xx. ≈øhillings, payable at the fea≈øt of P. and Saint M. the Bi≈øhop in winter, by euen portions. But now ≈øo it is, if it may plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, that the ≈øaid Indenture, the certaine dates or contentes whereof, your ≈øaide Lord≈øhippes
Orator knoweth not, before the day when the ≈øaid lea≈øe ≈øhould begin and take effect, did by ca≈øuall meanes come to the hands, cu≈øtodie, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of one I. W. who made his la≈øt Will and Te≈øtament, and therein appointed one E. then his wife, his ≈øole executrix and died, by and after who≈øe death the ≈øaid Indenture came into his hands and cu≈øtodie of the ≈øaid E. ≈øince which time the ≈øaid E. did marie, and tooke to hu≈øband one R. I. of B. by rea≈øon of which intermariage the ≈øaid Indenture is now come to, and remaineth in the hands, cu≈øtodie, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid R. I. and E. his wife, or of the one of them, who by rea≈øon of hauing of the ≈øaid Indenture, without any iu≈øt title or intere≈øt therein, haue entred into the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes with thappurtenances, and will not in any wi≈øe quietly permit and ≈øuffer your Lord≈øhips ≈øaid Orator to haue, and inioy his ≈øaid terme, of, and in the premi≈ø≈øes, according to his lawfull right and intere≈øt therein, but contrarie to all equitie, and good con≈øcience, haue euer ≈øithence taken and conuerted, and as yet doe daily take and conuert the i≈ø≈øues to their own proper v≈øe and behoofe, and will neither deliuer vnto your Lord≈øhips ≈øaid Orator the ≈øaid Indenture, nor permit and ≈øuffer him to haue and peaceably enioy the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes, as afore≈øaid, or any part thereof, although your ≈øaid Orator hath at diuers & ≈øundrie times required them ≈øo to doe. In con≈øideration whereof, and for as much as your Lord≈øhips ≈øaid Orator is without all helpe and remedie at the common law, for that he knoweth not, nor remembreth the dates or contents, or any other certainty of the ≈øaid Indenture, May it plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip to grant her Maie≈øties gracious writ of Subpena to be directed to the ≈øaid R. I. and E. his wife, and to either of them, commaunding them and eyther of them thereby, per≈øonally to appeare before your honor in her Maie≈øties high Court of Chancery at W. at a certaine day, and vnder a certaine paine by your honor therein to be limited there, &c.

div.head: A Bill again≈øt an Infant for bourding, and apparrell deliuered to him by the plaintife, and for not performing of a lea≈øe.
div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe complaining ≈øheweth vnto your Honorable Sect. 122. Lord≈øhip, your daily Orator T. T. of B. in the Countie of D. hu≈øbandman: That whereas about foure yeares now la≈øt pa≈øt, one G. B. of B. afore≈øaid yeoman, being ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne as of ‚Ä¢ ee, of, and in diuer≈øe landes, tenements, and hereditaments with their appurtenances in B. afore≈øaid, holden in Socage of I. S. as of the Manor of D. which ≈øaid tenements and premi≈ø≈øes the ≈øaid G. B. had by di≈øcent, by and after the death of B. his late father, and the ≈øaid G. B. being thereof ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, and being of the age of xx. yeares or thereabuuts, and vnder the age of xxi. yeares, about the xxv. day of Iuly which was in
the thirtie yeare of the Raigne of the Queenes mo≈øt excellent Maie≈øty that now is, by means, coun≈øaile, procurement, and per≈øwa≈øion of diuers euill di≈øpo≈øed per≈øons (that is to ≈øay) one A. E. I. M. W. M. T. C. H. M. N. H. W. H. and D. D. intending by their vngodly compact & practi≈øe to make a pray of the ≈øimplicity of your ≈øaid Orator, being an ignorant vnlearned man, the ≈øaid G. B. came vnto your ≈øaid Orator, pretending that he did then beare great good will and fauour to your ≈øaid Orator, and therefore entreated your ≈øaid Orator that he might boord & remaine with your ≈øaid Orator in his hou≈øe at B. afore≈øaid, and not onley haue meat, drinke, & lodging, but al≈øo ≈øuch apparrell & rayment as your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhould thinke meet & conuenient for his degree & calling, at the co≈øts & charges of your ≈øaid Orator, promi≈øing faithfully and fully to ≈øati≈øfie your ≈øaid Orator for all ≈øuch charges & expences as he by rea≈øon of the premi≈ø≈øes ≈øhould in any wi≈øe ≈øu≈øtaine. Wherefore your ≈øaid Orator giuing credit vnto the ≈øaid G. B. in the premi≈ø≈øes, & thinking that, that he had faithfully promi≈øed, he would fully and effectually haue performed, did then fully con≈øent and agree, to, and with the ≈øaid G. B. to find him meat, drinke, lodging, & apparrell, as is afore≈øaid, for the con≈øideration promi≈øed as is afore≈øaid: By pretence wherof the ≈øaid G. B. about the ≈øame time came to the ≈øaid hou≈øe of your ≈øaid Orator, and remained there with your ≈øaid Orator, vntill about the ≈øecond day of February then next following, during all which time your ≈øaid Orator at his owne proper co≈øtes and charges, did prouide and finde for, and vnto the ≈øaid G. B. all manner of nece≈ø≈øary meat, drinke, lodging, apparrell, and all other things nece≈ø≈øary for him. About which ≈øecond of Februarie the ≈øaid G. B. pretending to continue his ≈øaid fauour and good will towards your ≈øaid Orator, by the like coun≈øell, meanes, and per≈øwa≈øion of the ≈øaid euill di≈øpo≈øed per≈øons, and by their compact and agreement, did demi≈øe and lea≈øe vnto your ≈øaid Orator, all, or the mo≈øt part of all the ≈øaid me≈ø≈øuage, tenements, and premi≈ø≈øes, that he the ≈øaid G. B. ≈øo had, as is afore≈øaid, by di≈øcent from his ≈øaid father, to haue and to holdeth ≈øaid tenements and premi≈ø≈øes, with the appurtenances to him, his executors and a≈ø≈øignes, from the fea≈øt of the Annunciation of the ble≈ø≈øed virgin Mary then next en≈øuing, vnto the end and terme of three yeares thence next en≈øuing, your ≈øaid Orator & his a≈ø≈øignes, yeelding & paying therefore at the ende and expiration of the ≈øaid terme of three yeares xx. pounds of lawfull Engli≈øh money. And al≈øo finding vnto the ≈øaid G. B. during the ≈øaid time of three yeares conuenient lodging, meat, drink and apparrell, and al≈øo keeping for the ≈øaid G. B. twenty ≈øheepe, by rea≈øon of which demi≈øe, your ≈øaid Orator about the ≈øaid fea≈øt of the Annunciation of the ble≈ø≈øed virgin Marie, did enter into the ≈øaide demi≈øed me≈ø≈øuages, tenements, and premi≈ø≈øes, and occupied the ≈øame me≈ø≈øuages, tenements,
and premi≈ø≈øes, by the ≈øpace of two yeares, or thereabouts, and during the ≈øame time, did at his owne co≈øtes and charges prouide & find vnto the ≈øaid G. B. conuenient meat, drink, lodging, and apparrell, and al≈øo his xx. ≈øheepe, according to the ≈øaid agreement, and be≈øides tho≈øe xx. fortie ≈øheepe more at the lea≈øt, to the charges of your ≈øaid Orator of one hundred Markes at the lea≈øt. But now ≈øo it is, if it may plea≈øe your honorable Lord≈øhip to vnder≈øtand, that about the fir≈øt day of March, which was into the two and thirtie yeare of our Soueraigne Lady the Queenes Maie≈øties raigne that now is, your ≈øaid Orator hauing then inned into the Barnes of the ≈øaid tenements and premi≈ø≈øes forty loads of Hay, or thereabouts, part thereof did grow vpon the ≈øaid tenements and premi≈ø≈øes, but the mo≈øt part thereof was brought from other places and hauing al≈øo man ‚Ä¢ red the ≈øaid grounds to his exceeding great co≈øts and charges, the ≈øaid G. B. being then of full age, by the like per≈øwa≈øion and procurement of the per≈øons aboue≈øaid, did enter into the ≈øaid demi≈øed tenements and premi≈ø≈øes, whereof your ≈øaid Orator was then quietly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, as he then found the ≈øame, And he together with the ≈øaid A. E. I. M. W. N. C. H. M. N. H, W. H. & H. G. did take away and conuert to their owne v≈øes, the mo≈øt part of the ≈øaid forty loades of Hay or thereabouts to the value of twenty markes at the lea≈øt. By meanes whereof your ≈øaid Orator hauing again≈øt the Winter before, prouided greate ≈øtore of bea≈øtes and cattell for to haue eaten the ≈øaid Hay for the ≈øu≈øtenance of them, he was inforced to buy, and did buy a great quantitie of Hay at an exce≈ø≈øiue price, or el≈øe to haue fami≈øhed the mo≈øt of his ≈øaid bea≈øts for want of fodder, which was to the great lo≈ø≈øe and damage of your ≈øaid Orator: Neuertheles the ≈øaid G. B. by the like coun≈øel and per≈øwa≈øion of the ≈øaid euill di≈øpo≈øed per≈øons, albeit he hath beene ≈øundry times gently required by your ≈øaid Orator to make vnto him ≈øome rea≈øonable recompence and ≈øati≈øfaction for the lo≈ø≈øe of his ≈øaid terme and his other damages, and for ≈øuch co≈øtes and charges, as he had be≈øtowed for the manuring and bettering of the ≈øaid grounds ≈øo to him demi≈øed, and for ≈øuch co≈øtes and charges as he your ≈øaid Orator did ≈øu≈øtaine and beare, for, and by rea≈øon of the keeping, and maintaining of him the ≈øaid G. B. as is afore≈øaid, with apparrell, meat, drink, and lodging, he vtterly denieth, and refu≈øeth to yeeld vnto him any manner of ≈øati≈øfaction or recompence for the ≈øame, or part thereof, alleaging, that at the time of the making of the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall contractes, he was within the age of xxi. yeares, and therefore and for the incertainty ≈øome of the ≈øame contracts be meerely void in law. And not ≈øo contented, doth yet by the like coun≈øell & per≈øwa≈øion of the ≈øaid euill di≈øpo≈øed per≈øons, ≈øue your poore Orator, for the occupation and v≈øe of the ≈øaid grounds, and for the profits and commodities thereof during the fore≈øaid terme. Notwith≈øtanding
that he him≈øelfe, and his ≈øaid confederates did ≈øo as is afore≈øaid, vniu≈øtly take away your Orators ≈øaid Hay, being of farre more value then the profites which he euer receiued, for, or by the grounds ≈øo to him demi≈øed, did amount vnto, again≈øt all right, equitie, or good con≈øcience. In tender con≈øideration whereof, and for ≈øo much as your ≈øaid Orator is a verie poore man, and hath no ordinarie remedie by the ≈øtrict cour≈øe of the common lawes of this realme and dominion of England, either to defend him≈øelfe in the ≈øaid ≈øuit or to recouer any thing at all again≈øt the fore≈øaid G. B. as well by rea≈øon that the ≈øayd ≈øeuerall contracts and agreements were ≈øo vncertainly made, as is afore≈øaid with him, being at the making hereof an infant, as for that the ≈øame contracts & agreements were made priuately betweene your fore≈øaid Orator and him the ≈øaid G. B. few or none being pre≈øent thereat, which can te≈øtifie the ≈øame, neither can your ≈øaid Orator ≈øet downe in certain, how much of his ≈øaid Hay they did ≈øo take and carie away, and yet is there great cau≈øe in equity why your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhould be relieued for the ≈øame in this honorable court. It may therefore plea≈øe your honorable Lord≈øhip, the premi≈ø≈øes gratiou≈øly coÃÑ≈øidered, to grant vnto your ≈øaid Orator the Q. maie≈øties mo≈øt gracious ≈øeuerall writs of Subpena to be directed vnto the ≈øaid G. B. A. E. I. M. W. M. T. C. H. M. N. H. W. H. & H. G. & euery of them, thereby commanding them, and euery of them vnder a certaine paine, and at a certaine day therein to be limitted and appointed, to be, and per≈øonally to appeare before your Honorable Lord≈øhip in her Maie≈øties mo≈øt high Court of Chancerie, then & there to an≈øwere vnto the premi≈ø≈øes, and to abide ≈øuch further order & direction therein, as to your honorable Lord≈øhip ≈øhall ≈øeeme to ≈øtand with right, equitie, and good con≈øcience. And your ≈øayd Orator ≈øhall dayly pray vnto almighty God for the pre≈øeruation of your Honorable Lord≈øhip in good health long to continue with much encrea≈øe of honor &c.

div.head: A Bill of debt vppon a contract again≈øt the ≈øuruiuing partner, or ioynt chapman, and thadministrator of thother.
div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe complaining ≈øheweth vnto your Honorable Sect. 123. Lord≈øhip your dayly Orator R. P. of L. in the countie of Yorke chapman, that whereas the third day of May now la≈øt pa≈øt, which was in the fiue and thirtie yeere of the mo≈øt pro≈øperous raigne of our mo≈øt gratious Soueraigne Ladie Elizabeth the Queenes mo≈øt excellent Maie≈øtie that now is, and before and after the ≈øaid third day of May, one W. T. of W. in y‚Ä¢ countie of M. gra≈øier, now lately decea≈øed, were chapmen, partners, copercioners, or parting fellowes, did then as partners and parting fellowes iointly occupie together in all maner a≈øwell of buying, and ≈øelling, bartering, or bargaining of bea≈øts and cattell,
with their ≈øeuerall ≈øtockes, and of, and with diuers other goods, bea≈øts, and catttell taken vpon their credit, and of, and with all encrea≈øe and gaines from time to time ari≈øing and growing by rea≈øon of their ≈øayd occupying, as by factor≈øhip, alienation, exchaunge, or otherwi≈øe, for a certaine time betweene them the ≈øaid W. T. & R. W. priuately agreed vpon, and it was al≈øo then agreed betweene them, that during the time of their ≈øaid ioint occupying together or partner≈øhip, either of the ≈øaid parties ≈øhould be faithfull and true to other in buying, ≈øelling, and otherwi≈øe, as is afore≈øaid. And all ≈øuch lucre, profite and gaine, aduantage, benefite, and winning, as ≈øhould come, grow, or ari≈øe in buying and ≈øelling any bea≈øts or cattell, during their ioynt occupying or partner≈øhip, ≈øhould be equally parted and deuided betweene the ≈øaid parties, ≈øo as either of them ≈øhould haue his iu≈øt and true moitie and portion of the ≈øame. And that at ≈øuch times as it was betweene them agreed vpoÃÑ, either of them ≈øhould make a iu≈øt and true reckoning and accompt with other of buying and ≈øelling, of all ≈øuch bea≈øts and cattell, and otherwi≈øe as afore≈øaid. And it was then al≈øo agreed betweene them the ≈øayd W. T. and R. W. that if any lo≈ø≈øe or charge ≈øhal happen to either of the ≈øaid parties at any time or times during their ≈øaid ioint occupying together, & partner≈øhip by death of a cattell, euill debts, ca≈øualties, or otherwi≈øe concerning their ioint occupying to any part of the ≈øaid ≈øtocke in buying and ≈øelling of bea≈øts or cattell, or otherwi≈øe, as is afore≈øaid, to be impaired, that the ≈øame lo≈ø≈øe and charge ≈øhould be equally borne by both the ≈øaid parties. And if it ≈øhould happeÃÑ either of the ≈øaid parties of die during the ≈øaid ioint occupying or partner≈øhips, then the executors or admini≈øtrators of the goods and chattels of the party ≈øo dead ≈øhould make a iu≈øt & true accompt, paiment, & deliuery of ≈øuch part of all encrea≈øe, gaines, bea≈øts, cattell, & debts, as ≈øhould be due to the partie ≈øuruiuing. And in like maner that the party ≈øuruiuing ≈øhould make & declare to the executors of the goods & chattels of the party ≈øo dead, a iu≈øt, true & perfect accompt & reckoning of all the ≈øtate and qualitie of their ≈øaid ioint occupying or partner≈øhip, and al≈øo pay, deliuer & a≈ø≈øigne vnto ye ≈øaid executors or admini≈øtrators of the party ≈øo dead, ≈øuch moity, halfe part & portion of the ≈øaid increa≈øe, gaines, bea≈øts, cattell, & debts, as vpoÃÑ the ≈øame accompts ≈øhould then haue bin due vnto the party ≈øo dead, in ≈øo large and ample maner, as if he had bin then liuing, and the ≈øaid ioint occupying then ended, at ≈øuch times, & in ≈øuch maner, as it was betweene the ≈øaid parties agreed vpon, by force of which agreement, they the ≈øaid W. T. & R. W. iointly, as coparteners, ioint Chapmen, partners, or parting fellowes, occupied together their ≈øaid ≈øtocks, and other things afore≈øaid, & according to their mutuall agreement, by buying, ≈øelling, & exchanging of bea≈øts & cattell, and otherwi≈øe, in ≈øundray faires
and markets of this Realme of E. and with diuers and ≈øundrie of her Maie≈øties faithfull, and louing ≈øubiects vntill the day of &c. nowe la≈øt pa≈øt, at which time the ≈øaid R. W. died & the ≈øaid W. T. him ≈øuruiued, during which ≈øaid ioint occupying together, partner≈øhip, or ≈øociety, that is to ≈øay, the third day of May now la≈øt pa≈øt, the ≈øaid R. for, and to the v≈øe of him≈øelfe, and of the ≈øaid W. T. his partner, and ioint chapman, as is afore≈øaid, at M. in the county of N. did buy of your honors ≈øuppliant in the open ma ‚Ä¢ ket then there holden, three Oxen for ≈øixe pound fiue ≈øhillings, of which ≈øumme, part was then in hand paid, and the re≈øidue was then agreed to be paide vnto your Orator vppon the Tue≈øday in Whit≈øon weeke then next following in N. afore≈øaid, and al≈øo vpon the Wedne≈øday en≈øuing the day, commonly called or knowen by the name of Holie-thur≈øday, the ≈øaid R. W. did al≈øo buy to the v≈øe of him, & the ≈øaid T. of your ≈øaid Orator other two Oxen for 8. pounds, to haue been paid to your Orator vpon the ≈øaid Tue≈øday in Whit≈øon weeke, at N. afore≈øaid, which ≈øaid Oxen were then accordingly deliuered to the ≈øaide R. W. at N. afore≈øaid, and ≈øhortly after the ≈øaid R. W. deliuered the ≈øame Oxen to the hands of the ≈øaid W. T. and died, not hauing paied or ≈øati≈øfied this your Orator, of and for the ≈øaid fourteene pounds, nor of any part thereof, according to the ≈øaid bargaine, the ≈øaid Oxen remaining in the hands and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid W. T. and after the time of the death of the ≈øaid R. W. and were ≈øithence by him the ≈øaid W. T. conuerted to his owne onely v≈øe, by meanes whereof, action accrewed vnto your ≈øaid Orator, to demaund, and haue of the ≈øaid W. T. and of one E. W. of S. in the county of E. widow, late wife of the ≈øaid R. W. or of one of them, the ≈øaid 14 l . ≈øo to him due for the ≈øaid Oxen, which the ≈øaid E. W. by the compact and con≈øent of the ≈øaid W. T. and R. W. became executor to the ≈øaid R. W. and wrongfully admini≈øtred & conuerted to his owne v≈øe diuers goos and chattels which were belonging to the ≈øaid R. W. at the time of his death. And albeit your ≈øaid Orator hath diuers and ≈øundry times come and ≈øent to the ≈øaid W. T. and E. ≈øince the death of the ≈øaid R. W. gently requiring payment of the ≈øaid ≈øumme of 14. l . ≈øo as afore≈øaid, being behinde and vnpaid of the price of the ≈øaid Oxen, notwith≈øtanding that diuers goods & chattels, which were the ≈øaid R. W. at the time of his death ≈øufficient for the contentation of your ≈øaid Orator, of, and for his ≈øaid debt of 14. l . And al≈øo to performe the funerals of his ≈øaid R. W. and to ≈øati≈øfie all debts which the ≈øaid R. W. ought to any per≈øon or per≈øons at the time of his death, came to y‚Ä¢ hands & po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈ø. of the ≈øaid W. T. or E. W. or to the hands & po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈ø. of ≈øuch per≈øon or per≈øons, to whoÃÑ they ye ≈øaid W. T. & E. W. or the one of theÃÑ, haue left, yelded, or deliuered ye ≈øame, & in their or ≈øome of their haÃÑds doth ≈øtil remain. Notwith≈øtaÃÑding they & either of theÃÑ haue diuers
and ≈øundrie times ≈øince the death of the ≈øaid R. W. beene by your ≈øaid Orator & others in his behalfe gently required to pay the ≈øame, yet that to do they and either of them haue euer hitherto denied and refu≈øed, and yet do denie and refu≈øe to pay the ≈øame vnto your ≈øaid Orator, fraudulen ‚Ä¢ ly intending thereof and euerie part thereof craftily and ≈øubtilly to defraud, and deceiue your ≈øaid Orator. And for that purpo≈øe haue ≈øecretly conueyed, concealed, and hid a great part of the goods and chattels, which the ≈øaid K. W. had at the ≈øaid time of his death being of good value to diuer≈øe per≈øons, and in diuers places to your Orator vtterly vnknowen, ≈øo that the ≈øame being by that meanes left out of the Inuentory of the goods of the ≈øaid R. W. to the intent to da≈ø ‚Ä¢ e & blind the eies of your Orator, and of ≈øundry of the ≈øaid R. W. creditors to whom he was in like manner indebted, not knowing the trueth of their dealing, and vngodly practi≈øes and deui≈øes, intending by ≈øuch colourable meanes, either vtterly to defraud his ≈øaid creditors or ≈øo to inforce them to re≈øt contented with ≈øome ≈ømall part of their true and lawfull debt. And whereas afterwards that is to ≈øay, vpon Tue≈øday next after Mid≈øomer day now la≈øt pa≈øt, your Orator and one T. T. of L. in the County of L. hu≈øbandman by a priuate agreement betwene them made, did ioyntly buy of diuers per≈øons to the v≈øe of them both, eight Oxen, and ≈øeuen Bullocks, or Steeres for diuers ≈øeuerall ≈øums of money, and afterwards the ≈øaid bea≈øts that is ≈øeuen of the ≈øaid Oxen, and the ≈øaid ≈øeuen Bullocks or Steeres for the price of which 14. bea≈øts, and of the ≈øaid odde Oxe, your Orator and the ≈øaid T. T. afterwards priuatly accompted, and he thereupon ≈øati≈øfied your orator all that to him was due for the ≈øame but 3. l . 13. sÃÑ. 4. d . or thereabouts, and being per≈øwaded by the ≈øaid W. T. and E. W. and by their pernitious example, not ≈øati≈øfied with their former wrong as is ≈øaid, offered to your ≈øaid Orator, haue al≈øo per≈øwaded the ≈øaid T. T. not to pay to your ≈øaid Orator, the ≈øaid ≈øumme of 3. l . 13. sÃÑ. 4. d . or thereabouts ≈øo to him due, for the price of the ≈øaid Oxen, ≈øo that albeit the ≈øaid T. T. hath oftentimes ≈øince the making of the ≈øaid bargaine and accompt, been gently required by your ≈øaid Orator and others on his behalfe, yet ‚Ä¢ e hath euer hitherto denied and refu≈øed to make paiment thereof, and ≈øtill doth denie, and refu≈øe to do the ≈øame, again≈øt all right, equity, and good con≈øcience, which vnlawfull practi≈øes of the ≈øaid W. T. and E. W. and T. T. are likely to be to the great lo≈ø≈øe, and hinderance of your ≈øaid Orator, if ≈øpeedie remedie be not by your good Lord≈øhip prouided to meete with, and preuent their couetous and mo≈øt vncon≈øcionable dealings and purpo≈øes in the premi≈ø≈øes: wherefore, and for as much as the ≈øaid agreement of partner≈øhip, and otherwi≈øe, made betwene the ≈øaid W. T. and R. W. & al≈øo all the compacts and practi≈øes made, by, and betweene the ≈øaid W. T.
and the ≈øaid E. W. ≈øince the death of the ≈øaid R. W. And al≈øo the ≈øaid agreement of the ioint buying of the ≈øaid fifteene bea≈øtes by your Orator, and the ≈øaid T. and al≈øo the ≈øaid bargaine betweene your Orator and the ≈øaid R. W. for the ≈øaid fiue Oxen, as al≈øo the ≈øaid ioint buying of the ≈øaid fifteen bea≈øts by your orator, & the ≈øaid T. T. were ≈øecretly and priuately made betweene them≈øelues, ≈øo that there is no per≈øon liuing knowen to your ≈øaid Orator, but the ≈øaid W. T. E. W. and T. T. priuie thereunto, that can te≈øtifie the ≈øaid ≈øeueral contracts, made betwene your ≈øaid Orator, and the ≈øaid R. W. of, and for the ≈øaid fiue Oxen, as is afore≈øaid, and the ≈øaid ioint buying of the ≈øaid fifteene bea≈øts by your ≈øaid Orator & the ≈øaid T. T. & their ≈øaid accompts touching the ≈øame, or the ≈øaid ioint occupying or partner≈øhip betweene the ≈øaid W. and T. or the ≈øaid concealement, cunning, clo≈øe, and vnlawfull dealings of the ≈øaid E. W. and T. in the premi≈ø≈øes, ≈øo that your ≈øaid Orator, through the want of ≈øuch preci≈øe proofe thereof (as the ≈øtrict cour≈øe of the common lawes of this Realme doth in that behalfe require) is altogether remedile≈ø≈øe, by the order of this honorable Court, wherein your Orator verely hopeth, that the ≈øaid W. T. E. W. and T. T. in their ≈øeuerall an≈øweres to the premi≈ø≈øes, will ≈øeuerally vpon their corporall Oathes confe≈ø≈øe the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes, to be in effect, as they haue beene herein di≈øclo≈øed and ≈øet forth: It may therefore plea≈øe your Honorable good Lord≈øhip, the premi≈ø≈øes gratiou≈øly con≈øidered, to grant vnto your ≈øaid Orator, her Maie≈øties mo≈øt gracious ≈øeuerall writs of Subpena, to be directed to the ≈øaid W. T. EW. T. T. and to euery of them, thereby commaunding them, and euery of them, at a certaine day, and vnder a certaiue paine therein limitted, to be, and per≈øonally to appeare before your honorable Lord≈øhip in her Maie≈øties mo≈øt high Court of Chancery, then, and there to an≈øwere vnto the premi≈ø≈øes, and abide ≈øuch further order and direction therein, as to your honorable Lord≈øhip ≈øhall ≈øeeme to be agreeable with right, equitie, and good con≈øcience. And your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhall daily pray &c.

div.head: A Bill vpon a promi≈øe to forbeare debt due by Obligation vntil an other day, and yet ≈øuing the band.
div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe ≈øheweth and complaineth vnto your honorable Sect' 124. Lord≈øhip &c. That whereas one R. F. of &c. in the County afore≈øaid Gentleman, was indebted to one W. P. of D. afore≈øaid, in the ≈øumme of &c. And whereas your ≈øaid Orator, at the ≈øpeciall and earne≈øt intreatie and reque≈øt of the ≈øaid R. F. about two yeares la≈øt pa≈øt, became bounden for the ≈øaid F. vnto the ≈øaid W. P. by his deede or writing Obligatorie, in the ≈øumme of &c. with Condition therein cantained or indorced, for the payment of the ≈øumme of &c. vnto the ≈øaid W. P. at the fea≈øt of &c. which was in the yeare &c. at, or in the
Church porch of &c. afore≈øaid, as by the ≈øaid deede or writing Obligatorie doth and may appeare: Which ≈øaid ≈øumme of &c. your ≈øaid Orator had appointed in a readine≈ø≈øe, and purpo≈øed to pay the ≈øame at the time and place afore≈øaid, according to the Condition of the ≈øaid writing Obligatorie: Whereupon the ≈øaid W. P. the very day appointed for the paiment of the ≈øaid &c. or the day before, the certainty whereof your ≈øaid Orator, nowe remembreth not, came vnto your ≈øaide Orator, and vpon ≈øpeech had betweene your ≈øaid Orator, and the ≈øaid P. touching the paiment of the ≈øaid money: The ≈øaid P. was contented, and did agree to forbeare the paiment thereof, vntill the fea≈øt of P. then next following, and did faithfully a≈ø≈øume and promi≈øe, to, and with your ≈øaid Orator, both then, and at diuers times after, to forbeare the paiment thereof vntill the ≈øaid fea≈øt, and that he would not take any aduantage of the forfeiture of the ≈øaid bonde again≈øt your ≈øaid Orator, but would cancell the ≈øaid bonde, and take a newe bonde for the payment thereof at the ≈øaid fea≈øt of P. afore≈øaid, but neuer required any new bonde from your ≈øaid Orator: And your ≈øaide Orator giuing credite to his promi≈øe and a≈ø≈øumption afore≈øaid, did not pay the ≈øaide ≈øumme of &c. according to the Condition of the ≈øaide writing Obligatorie. After which time, the ≈øaide W. P. did oftentimes promi≈øe your ≈øaide Orator, to deliuer the ≈øaide bonde of &c. to your ≈øaide Orator to be cancelled, and to take new bonde for the payment of the fore≈øaide ≈øumme of &c. at the ≈øaid fea≈øt of Pentico≈øt according to his promi≈øe and agreement afore≈øaid: And your ≈øaide Orator doubting that the ≈øaide P. meante to delay him, and driue him off from time to time, and not fearing lea≈øt the ≈øaide P. ≈øhould take anie aduantage of the forfeiture of the ≈øaide bonde again≈øt him, in Michaelmas Terme la≈øt pa≈øt, your ≈øaide Orator demaunded the ≈øaide bonde againe of the ≈øaide P. in L. who tolde your ≈øaide Orator, that he had deliuered ouer the ≈øaide bonde vnto one W. W. being his brother in Lawe, to whom he had a≈ø≈øigned ouer the ≈øaide bonde, and could not relea≈øe or di≈øcharge the ≈øaide bonde without the a≈ø≈øent of the ≈øaide W. W. but would make meanes to the ≈øaide W. W. for the deliuerie of the ≈øame, and ≈øeemed to make diuers iourneyes to the ≈øaide W. W. to fetch the ≈øame: And ≈øo from time to time delayed your ≈øaide Orator, and droue him out with fayre wordes, vntill ≈øuch time as your ≈øaide Orator was vppon occa≈øion of bu≈øines, inforced to ride out of L. into the Countrey: And ≈øhortely after, your ≈øaide Orator purpo≈øing to get the ≈øame bonde out of the ≈øaide P. and W. handes, did in the ≈øaid Michaelmas Terme, ≈øend one G. V. his ≈øeruant to L. with the ≈øaid money, to make payment thereof vnto the ≈øaide W. and P. and to receiue
the ≈øaid bond, who comming to L. accordingly to the ≈øaid W. and P. and declaring vnto them, that he was come to make paiment of the fore≈øaid ≈øumme of &c. and to receiue the ≈øaid bond, the ≈øaid W. then told the ≈øaid N. that the ≈øaid bond was not then in his cu≈øtody or keeping: But the ≈øaid W. did then and there promi≈øe, that if the ≈øaid V. would deliuer ouer a bond which he had in his keeping of tru≈øt, to the v≈øe of the ≈øa ‚Ä¢ d P. that then the ≈øaid W. and P. would the next day following, come to the ≈øaid V. his lodging, and receiue the ≈øaid &c. and deliuer ouer the fore≈øaid bond of, &c. vnto him, vpon who≈øe promi≈øe the ≈øaid V. did then pre≈øently (tru≈øting to his faire ≈øpeeches) deliuer the ≈øaid bond which he had, to the v≈øe of the ≈øaid P. to the ≈øaid P. or W. accordingly. But ≈øo it is (may it plea≈øe your good Lo.) that the ≈øaid P. & W. nothing at all regarding their fore≈øaid ≈øeuerall promi≈ø≈øes, agreements, and a≈ø≈øumptions made, to, and with your ≈øaid Orator, and the ≈øaid V. as afore≈øaid, haue not onely hitherto refu≈øed and denied to deliuer ouer the ≈øaid bond of &c. vnto your ≈øaid Orator, according to the promi≈øes and agreements made, as afore≈øaid, but yet do vtterly refu≈øe and deny to do the ≈øame: albeit your ≈øaid Orator did oftentimes, both before the ≈øaid fea≈øt of &c. as afore≈øaid, and diuers times ≈øince, offer to make paiment of the ≈øaid ≈øumme of &c. vnto the ≈øaid P. and W. according to the fore≈øaid agreement, and yet is readie and willing to pay the ≈øame: But al≈øo the ≈øaid P. and W. purpo≈øing to bring vpon your ≈øaid Orator the whole penalty and forfeiture of the ≈øaid bond of &c. haue, or one of them hath of late, contrarie to the fore≈øaid a≈ø≈øumptions & agreements made, as afore≈øaid, & contrary to all hone≈øty, equity, and good con≈øcience, commenced ≈øuit at the common law again≈øt your ≈øaid Orator vpon the ≈øaid bond, to his great lo≈ø≈øe and hinderance. And the ≈øaid W. P. hath of late vtterly denied, that euer he promi≈øed to forbeare the paiment of &c. vntill the fore≈øaid fea≈øt of &c. contrary to the trueth, and contrary to all equity and good con≈øcience: In tender con≈øideration whereof, and for as much as your ≈øaid Oratar cannot pleade the promi≈øe and agreement of the ≈øaid P. made to your ≈øaide Orator, for forbearing of the money (as afore≈øaid) in barre of the ≈øaid bond at the common law, and thereby is void of all remedie, at, and by che ≈øtrict order and cour≈øe of the common law of this Realme, nor can v≈øe nor bring any action of the ca≈øe again≈øt the ≈øaid P. or W. upon their ≈øaid promi≈øes and a≈ø≈øumptions, for that your ≈øaid Orator cannot make any ≈øuch ≈øufficient proofe thereof, as by the common law is in ≈øuch ca≈øe required, for that the ≈øame were made priuatly betweene them≈øelues, and no witne≈ø≈øes called thereunto. And for as much as your ≈øaid Orator verely thinketh that the ≈øaid W. P. and W. W. being called into this mo≈øt honorable court to an≈øwere to the premi≈ø≈øes, will in their an≈øwere vpon their corporall oathes confe≈ø≈øe the fore≈øaid conclu≈øions, promi≈øes, and agreements
made, as a fore≈øaid, and di≈øclo≈øe the trueth of the premi≈ø≈øes: May it therefore plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhippe, the premi≈ø≈øes con≈øidered, to grant vnto your ≈øaid Orator, the Queenes mo≈øt gracious writ of Subpena to be directed vnto them the ≈øaid W. P. and W. W. commanding them, and either of them, at a certaine day, and vpon a certaine paine by your good Lord≈øhip to be appointed, per≈øonally to appeare before your good Lord≈øhip, in the Queenes Maie≈øties mo≈øt high Court of Chauncery, then, and there to an≈øwere to the premi≈ø≈øes: And further to ≈øtand to, and abide ≈øuch further order and direction therein, as to your good Lord≈øhip ≈øhall be thought mo≈øt meete and conuenient in that behalfe. And your ≈øaid Orator, according to his bounden duty, ≈øhall daily pray vnto God for the good and pro≈øperous e≈øtate of your Lord≈øhip, in honor long to continue.

div.head: The An≈øwere of W. P. and W. W. defendants, to the bill of complaint of E. L. complainant.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid defendants, and either of them ≈øaith, that for the mo≈øt part Sect. 125. the ≈øaid bil is vntrue, ≈ølaunderous and in≈øufficient in the law to be an≈øwered vnto, and the matters therein contained, deui≈øed of malice, to put the≈øe defendants to needle≈ø≈øe charges and expences in law, without any ≈øufficient cau≈øe ≈øo to do: The aduantage of exception to which in≈øufficient bill to the≈øe defendants at all times ≈øaued, For an≈øwere they ≈øay, and fir≈øt the ≈øaid W. P. for him≈øelfe ≈øaith, that true it is, that the ≈øaid complainant did become bound to the≈øe defendants, by his obligation in the ≈øumme of &c. with condition indorced for the true paiment of the ≈øaid ≈øumme &c. at a day long ≈øince pa≈øt, The which ≈øumme this defendant did verely thinke to haue receiued accordingly, and thereof did make reckoning, as of a debt then to be paid to him, and for that cau≈øe did at the very day appointed for the paiment of the ≈øame, repaire vnto the place ≈øpecified in the condition of the ≈øaid obligation, where the ≈øaid money ≈øhould be paid, and there did attend for the ≈øame, in hope to haue receiued it accordingly: But the ≈øaid complainant, meaning nothing le≈ø≈øe then the ≈øati≈øfying of the ≈øaid debt, left the ≈øame vnpaide, to the great hinderance, lo≈ø≈øe, and di≈øcredite of the≈øe defendants. And this defendant further ≈øaith, that he hath often and ≈øundry times ≈øithence the ≈øaid money was due, made meanes to the complainant for payment of the ≈øame, who from time to time with faire promi≈øes (now almo≈øt the≈øe three yeares) hath delaied this defendant to his greater hinderance, then the valew of the ≈øaid ≈øumme: By rea≈øon whereof, and for as much as the complainant hath ≈øought diuers indirect waies and meanes to get the ≈øaid Obligation of &c. out of the hands of this defendant with intent neuer to pay penny of the debt afore≈øaid: This defendant hath
cau≈øed the ≈øaid Obligation to be put in ≈øuite, as he thinketh it is lawfull for him to doe, without that, that the complainant to the knowledge of the defendant did prepare in a readine≈ø≈øe to haue paid the ≈øaid &c. at the time and place, according to the condition of the Obligation afore≈øaid: Or that this defendant vpon the very day appointed for the paiment of the ≈øame &c. or the day before, (or in trueth at any time el≈øe) did come to the complainant, and had ≈øpeech with him, that he was contented and did agree to forbeare the puni≈øhment thereof, vntill the fea≈øt of &c. then next following, or did a≈ø≈øume and promi≈øe, to, and with the complainant, both then, & at diuers times after to for beare the payment thereof, vntill the ≈øaid fea≈øt, and would not take any aduantage of the forfeiture of the ≈øaid bond, but would cancell the ≈øaid bond, and would take new bond for the paiment thereof, at the ≈øaid fea≈øt of P. as in the ≈øaid bill is mo≈øt fal≈øely declared. And without that, that the ≈øaid complainant to the knowledge of the defendant did ≈øend one G. V. his ≈øeruant to L. with the ≈øaid money to make payment thereof to one of the≈øe defendants, as al≈øo in the ≈øaid bill of complaint is vntruely alleaged. For this defendant ≈øaith, that he ≈øought often to the complainant, and made means vnto him, to haue the ≈øaid defendant eyther to be paide in noney, or that he might be ≈øati≈øfied thereof ≈øome other way, who made him many promi≈øes to do the ≈øame with ≈øpeed, but neuer ment or intended it, for any thing that this defendant could get to the contrary. And the ≈øaid W. W. the other of the≈øe defendaÃÑts for him≈øelf ≈øaith: That whereas he is charged to haue made promi≈øe to the ≈øaid V. that if he would deliuer a bonde which he had in his keeping of tru≈øt, to the v≈øe of the ≈øaid P. that then he this defendant and the ≈øaid P. would the next day following, come to the ≈øaid V. his lodging, and receiue the ≈øaid ≈øumme of &c. and deliuer ouer the ≈øaid bonde of &c. He this defendant ≈øaith, that he neuer made any ≈øuch promi≈øe to the ≈øaid V. to his remembrance, neither was there any cau≈øe at all that he ≈øhould ≈øo doe a≈øwell becau≈øe in trueth, and in hone≈øtie the ≈øaid V. ought to make deliuerie of the ≈øaid bonde, ≈øo committed vnto him, but of tru≈øt, as appeareth by the plantifes owne ≈øhewing, as al≈øo for that this defendant was informed, that the ≈øaid V. had deliuered the ≈øaid bonde before that they two mette together to talke of the ≈øaide debt. And this defendant further ≈øaith, that although it were true, that he had made ≈øuch promi≈øe (as afore≈øaid) yet were it nothing at all materiall for the reliefe of the complainant, a≈øwell for the cau≈øe afore≈øaid, as al≈øo for that this defendant had no power of him≈øelfe to doe, eyther good or hurt in the matter. And without that, that any other matter or thing what≈øoeuer materiall in the ≈øaid vntrue bill to b an≈øwered vnto, and not in this an≈øwere ≈øufficiently an≈øwered, confe≈ø≈øed, and auoided, trauer≈øed, or
denied, is true. All which matters the≈øe defendantes are readie to auerre and proue, as this mo≈øt honorable Court ≈øhall awarde, and prayen to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed with their rea≈øonable co≈øtes in this behalfe wrongfully ≈øu≈øtained.

div.head: The Replication of E. L. E≈øq. Complainant, to the An≈øwere of W. P, and W. W. Defendant.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid Complainant replieth and ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid bill of complaint Sect. 126. by him exhibited into this mo≈øt honorable court, is very true, certaine, and ≈øufficient, the law to be an≈øwered vnto, And that the matters therein contained, are neither deui≈øed, imagined, practi≈øed, or ≈øet forth by him the ≈øaid complainant, for any ≈øuch cau≈øe or purpo≈øe, as the defendants in their an≈øweres haue vntruely imagined, but the ≈øame is grounded vpon good and iu≈øt cau≈øe, as by the contents thereof doth and may appeare. And further ≈øaith, that the an≈øwere of the ≈øaid defendant is verie vntrue, vncertaine, and in≈øufficient in the lawe to be replied vnto, The aduantage of exception to the incertainety and in≈øufficiencie thereof to the ≈øaid complainant, nowe, and at all times hereafter ≈øaued. The ≈øaide complainant for further replication ≈øaith, that he doth, and will auerre, iu≈øtifie, maintaine, and proue, all, and eueuerie matter, article, ≈øentence, and thing, in the ≈øaid bill of complaint contained, to be good, iu≈øt, and true, in ≈øuch ≈øort, manner, and forme, as in the ≈øaid bill of complaint they be truely ≈øet forth, ≈øhewed, and declared. And further the ≈øaid complainant ≈øaith, that he doth, and will auerre and proue, as this mo≈øt honorable Court ≈øhall and will awarde, that the ≈øaid compainant did prepare in a readines, and purpo≈øed to pay the fore≈øaid ≈øumme &c. in the ≈øaid bill & an≈øwere mentioned, at the time and place in the condition of the ≈øaid obligation mentioned, according to the true intent and meaning of the condition of the ≈øaid obligation in ≈øuch ≈øort, maner, & forme, as in the ≈øaid bill of complaint is mo≈øt truly ≈øet forth & alleaged. And that the very day appointed for the paiment thereof, or the day before, the ≈øaid W. P. one of the ≈øaid defendants did come to the ≈øaid complainant, and vpon ≈øpeech had betweene them touching the paiment of the ≈øaid money, the ≈øaid defendaut was contented, & did agree to forbeare the paiment thereof, vntill the fea≈øt of &c the ‚Ä¢ next following, in ≈øuch ≈øort, maner, and forme, as in the ≈øaid bill of complaint is mo≈øt truely alleaged. With that al≈øo, that the ≈øaid W. P. did faithfully a≈ø≈øure and promi≈øe, to and with the ≈øaid complainant, both then, and at ≈øundry times after, to forbeare the paiment thereof, vntill the ≈øaid fea≈øt of &c. afore≈øaid, and would not take any aduantage of the forfeiture of the ≈øaid bond again≈øt the ≈øaid coÃÑplainant, but would cancel the ≈øaid bond and take new bond for the paimeÃÑt therof, at the fea≈øt afore≈øaid. And that
the ≈øaid complainant, relying vpon the fore≈øaid agreement, promi≈øe, and a≈ø≈øumption of the ≈øaid P. for the forbearing of the ≈øaid &c. vntil the ≈øaid fea≈øt of &c. afore≈øaid, and for the taking of a newe bond for the payment thereof, at the fea≈øt afore≈øaid, did not pay the ≈øame, according to the condition of the fore≈øaid Obligation, which otherwi≈øe he would haue done, in ≈øuch ≈øort, manner, and forme, as in the ≈øaid bill of complaint is al≈øo mo≈øt truely ≈øet forth and declared. And with that al≈øo, that the ≈øaid complainant in Mich. Terme la≈øt pa≈øt, ≈øent the ≈øaid G. V. his ≈øeruant to L. with the ≈øaid money to make payment thereof. And that the ≈øaid W. W. the other defendant vpon offer of tender of the fore≈øaid ≈øumme of money by the ≈øaid V. The ≈øaid W. W. did promi≈øe to deliuer the ≈øaide bond vnto the ≈øaid V. within ≈øhort time after, ≈øo as the ≈øaid V. would deliuer ouer a bond which he had in his keeping, to the v≈øe of the ≈øaid P. and would al≈øo at a time betwene them agreed on, make paiment of the ≈øaid ≈øumme of &c. which bond was deliuered ouer accordingly, to the ≈øaid P. or W. by the ≈øaid V. And the ≈øaid V. was readie to tender and pay the ≈øaid money, according to the ≈øaid appointment, in ≈øuch ≈øort, manner, and forme, as in the ≈øaid bill of complaint is al≈øo truely alleaged. Without that, that the ≈øaid W. P. one of the ≈øaid defendants, ≈øought often to the ≈øaid complainant, and made meanes to him to haue the ≈øaide debt, either to be paid in mony, or that he might be ≈øati≈øfied therof, ≈øome other way, who made him many faire promi≈øes to do the ≈øame, but neuer ment, or intended it, in ≈øuch ≈øort, manner, and forme, as in the ≈øaide an≈øwere is mo≈øt vntruly alleaged: For the ≈øaid complainant ≈øaith, that he did often and ≈øundrie times, both before the ≈øaid fea≈øts &c. and diuers times ≈øithence, offer to make paiment of the ≈øaid ≈øumme &c. vnto the ≈øaid W. P. and. W. and alwaies was, and yet is readie and willing, vppon the redeliuerie of the fore≈øaid bond, to pay the ≈øame, in ≈øuch ≈øort, as in the ≈øaid bill of complaint is mo≈øt truely ≈øhewed and alleaged. And without that al≈øo, that any other thing, matter, or circum≈øtance in the ≈øaid aun≈øwere mentioned, materiall or effectuall to be replied vnto, and in this Replication not ≈øufficiently confe≈ø≈øed, auoyded, denied, trauer≈øed or otherwi≈øe replied vnto, is true. All which matters the ≈øaid complainant is readie to auerre and prooue, as this mo≈øt Honorable Court ≈øhall and will awarde. And prateth, as before in his ≈øaid bill of complaint he praied.

div.head: The Ioint and ≈øeuerall Reioinder of W. P. and W. W. defendants to the Replication of E. L. complainant.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid defendants ≈øay, and either of them for him≈øelfe ≈øeuerally Sect. 127. ≈øaith, that the Replication of the ≈øaid complainant is vniu≈øt and vntrue, and very in≈øufficient in the law by the≈øe defendantes, or either of
them to be reioined vnto. Notwith≈øtanding all aduantage of exception to the incertainty and in≈øufficiency thereof to the≈øe defendants, and to either of them at all times hereafter being ≈øaued, for reioinder vnto the ≈øaid in ≈øufficient replication: The≈øe defendants ≈øay, and either of them for him≈øelfe ≈øeuerally ≈øaith in all and euerie matter and thing, as they and either of them in their ≈øeueral an≈øweres haue ≈øaid, without that that any other matter, cau≈øe, or thing what≈øoeuer, materiall or effectuall contained in the ≈øaid replication, & by the≈øe defendants or either of them to be reioined vnto, and not herein ≈øufficiently confe≈ø≈øed and auoided, trauer≈øed or denied, is true. All and euerie which matters and things the≈øe defendants and either of them are readie to auerre and proue, &c.

div.head: A Bill for detaining lands with euidences.
div.p:
MO≈øt humblie complaining &c. your daily Orator I. S. of A. in Sect. 128‚ñ™ the County of H. Hu≈øbandman. That whereas R. S. of H. in the County of H. afore≈øaid Hu≈øbandman, and grandfather to your Orator was in his life time ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈ø ‚Ä¢ e as of fee, or in fee taile, of, and in certaine me≈ø≈øuages, lands and tenements, to the yearely valew of &c. or there abouts, lying in H. afore≈øaid, and of the ≈øame died ≈øei≈øed: By force whereof the ≈øaid tenements di≈øcended and came (as of right they ought) vnto one I. S. father to your ≈øaid Orator, ≈øonne and heire to the ≈øaid R. who afterwards entred into the ≈øame, and was for diuers yeares ≈øei≈øed of the tenements accordingly, vntil about the fir≈øt yeare of the Raigne of the late King Edward the ≈øixt. At which time one W. G. of H. afore≈øaid, happening by ca≈øuall meanes to get into his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion all the euidences, charters, and writings concerning the ≈øaid lands and tenements: And knowing that your ≈øaid Orators father could not for want of tho≈øe euidences, charters, & writings defend his right, title, and intere≈øt to the lands afore≈øaid, entred al≈øo into the ≈øaid tenementes, and the ≈øame wrongfully did withhold and detaine, during the terme of his naturall life: ≈øithence which time, one T. G. of H. afore≈øaid, and E. G. widow, mother to the ≈øaid T. hath al≈øo entered into the ≈øaid tenements, and the ≈øame to this day mo≈øt vniu≈øtly withholdeth, together with all the charters, euidences, and writings afore≈øaid, which in right and equitie belong and appertaine to your Orator, as ≈øonne and heire to the ≈øaid I. S. now decea≈øed: In tender con≈øideration whereof, and for ≈øo much as your Orator doth now know the certaine dates of the charters, euideneds, and writings afore≈øaid, nor of any of them, neyther doth know whether they are in bagges, or boxe ≈øealed, or in che≈øt locked, he is without all remedie at the common lawes of this Realme, and al≈øo without all other meanes how to finde reliefe in this behalfe,
except your honorable Lord≈øhips fauour extended. And that the ≈øaid T. G. and E. G. may by your Lord≈øhips order be compelled vpon their oathes, plainely, and truely to ≈øhew forth their e≈øtate, in, and to the tenements afore≈øaid, and al≈øo to ≈øhew what right, title, or intere≈øt they haue or claime, in, and to the ≈øame, & likewi≈øe to ≈øhew the effect and certaine dates of ≈øuch charters, euidences, and writings, afore≈øaid, as they, or eyther of them haue in their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion concerning the ≈øaid tenements afore≈øaid, or any part thereof. May it therefore, &c. as before.

div.head: The An≈øwere.
div.p:
THe≈øe defendants by prote≈øtation ≈øay, and euery of them ≈øaith that Sect. 129. the bill of complaint exhibited into this honorable Court, is for y‚Ä¢ mo≈øt part vncertaine, vntrue, and in≈øufficient in the law to be an≈øwered vnto. And that the matters therein contained are deui≈øed by the complainant onely, to mole≈øt and trouble the≈øe defendantes, being verie poore, rather then vpon any iu≈øt cau≈øe. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe the aduantage of exception to the vncertaintie and in≈øufficiencie of the ≈øaid bill to the≈øe defendantes at all times ≈øaued: For aun≈øwere and declaration of the trueth, they ≈øay, and euery of them ≈øaith, that true it is that one R. S. of F. in her Maie≈øties Countie of H. was in his life time ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne, as of fee, of, and in one me≈ø≈øuage, and certaine lands and tenements in H. in the ≈øaid County of H. and being ≈øo ≈øei≈øed by his deed of foffement vnder his hand and ≈øeale, about the xxxvi. yeare of King H. the viii. conueyed and a≈ø≈øured the ≈øame me≈ø≈øuage and lands vnto one I. S. his ≈øonne, and to his heires and a≈ø≈øignes for euer, as by the deed of the ≈øaid R. vnder his hand and ≈øeale redy to be ≈øhewed vnto this honorable Court doth and may appeare: By force whereof the ≈øaid I. S. was thereof ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne as of fee, And being ≈øo thereof ≈øei≈øed, for a certaine ≈øumme of money to him paid by W. G. father of one of the defendants, did conuey and a≈ø≈øure the ≈øaid me≈ø≈øuage and lands vnto the ≈øaid W. G. and his heires with warrantie, as by the deed and relea≈øe of the fore≈øaid I. S. doth and may appeare: After which the fore≈øaid W. G. the father vnto the ≈øaid defendant died of the ≈øaid me≈ø≈øuage and lands ≈øei≈øed, After who≈øe death the≈øe defendants entred into the ≈øaid tenements, and the ≈øame enioyed the their own profits and commodities, as lawfull was for them to die: without that, that R. S. of H. in the ≈øaid bill mentioned, was ≈øei≈øed of the me≈ø≈øuage and lands in the bill mentioned in fee taile, or that the ≈øaid I. S. father of the complainant was ≈øei≈øed of the premi≈ø≈øes in the fir≈øt yeare of King Edward the ≈øixt, or that the ≈øaid W. G. father of one of the defendants got the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the me≈ø≈øuage, & the euidences concerning the ≈øame, other wi≈øe then was lawfull for him to doe: Or that the defendantes,
or any of them do vniu≈øtly withhold the ≈øaid me≈ø≈øuage or lands in the bill mencioned, or the euidences concerning the ≈øame, otherwi≈øe then is lawfull for them to do in re≈øpect of their right. And without that, that the ≈øaid me≈ø≈øuage and lands with the euidences concerning the ≈øame do in right or equitie appertaine to the Complainant, as ≈øonne and heire to I. S. the father. And without that, that any other matter or thing in the ≈øaid bill contained concerning the≈øe defendants, and not in this an≈øwere ≈øufficiently confe≈ø≈øed, and auoyded, trauer≈øed, or denyed, is true. All which matters the≈øe fore≈øaid defendants are &c. vt ≈øupra.

div.head: The Replication.
div.p: THe Complainant auerreth and maintaineth his ≈øaid bill of complaint, Sect. 130. and all and euery the matters and things therein contained to be verie good, iu≈øt, and true, in ≈øuch ≈øort, maner, and forme, as in the ≈øaid bill of complaint is declared. And ≈øaith, that the an≈øwere of the defendants for the mo≈øt part is vncertaine, vntrue, and in≈øufficient in the law to be an≈øwered vnto: Neuerthele≈ø≈øe all aduantages of erception to the in≈øufficiency thereof to this complainant, at all times hereafter ≈øaued: For replication ≈øaith in all and euery thing, as in the ≈øaid bill of complaint he hath ≈øaid. And further ≈øaith, that he doubteth not but that he can verie ≈øufficiently proue that the ≈øaid I. S. this complainants father, was about the fir≈øt yere of the raigne of King Eow. the ≈øixth, or not long before, ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne as of fee taile of the fore≈øaid me≈øuage, lands, and tenements in the ≈øaid bill mencioned. And he al≈øo hopeth to proue all the re≈øt of the ≈øaid bill to be true, in ≈øuch ≈øort as the ≈øame is truely declared and ≈øet downe: without that, that the fore≈øaid R. S. this complaynants graundfather being ≈øei≈øed of the premi≈ø≈øes in his deme≈øne as of fee, did lawfully by his deede of feoffement vnder his hand and ≈øeale, about the xxxvi. yere of king H. the eight, conuey and a≈ø≈øure the ≈øaid me≈øuage and lands vnto one I. S. his ≈øonne, and to his heires and a≈ø≈øignes for euer: Or that the ≈øaid I. S. being of the premi≈ø≈øes ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne as of fee, for a certaine ≈øumme of money to him paied by the ≈øaid W. G. father of one of the defendants, did lawfully conuey and a≈ø≈øure the ≈øaid me≈øuage and lands vnto W. G. one of the ≈øaid defendants, and his heires with warrantie, as in the ≈øaid an≈øwere is verie vntruely alleaged: And without that, that the ≈øaid W. G. father to one of the defendants, died of the ≈øaid me≈øuage and lands ≈øei≈øed in ≈øuch fort, as in the ≈øaid an≈øwere is likewi≈øe declared, or that it was lawfull for the ≈øaid defendants after the death of the ≈øaid W. G. to enter and occupie the fore≈øaid me≈øuage and lands, as al≈øo in the ≈øaid an≈øwere is in≈øerted. And without that, that any other matter &c. All which &c. vt ≈øupra.

div.head: A Bill for debt leuied by extent.
div.p:
COmplaining ≈øheweth &c. A. B. of &c. That whereas the ≈øaid A. B. Sect. 131. in the beginning of her Maie≈øties Raigne, liuing in her highnes Court, for his furniture of iewels, plate, money, and ≈øuch like, had credit with one C. D. Citizen and Gold≈ømith of London, for the which as he had occa≈øion to borrow any money, or take by any wares, ≈øo he deliuered his Bils or Obligations for the true paiment of any ≈øuch money ≈øo borrowed, or for the price of any ≈øuch wares ≈øo bought, at daies betwixt them agreed: which daies, he alwaies kept, or tooke order for the for bearing thereof by him≈øelfe, or his ≈øeruants, ≈øuch as he did imploy in tho≈øe affaires: Among≈øt which there was in D. in the fir≈øt yeare of &c. a certaine debt or reckoning (of how much certainely he now remembreth not) betwixt him the ≈øaid C. D. and the ≈øaid A. B. for the which he the ≈øaid A. B. was bound to the ≈øaid C. D. in the ≈øumme of &c. by his deed obligatory, bearing date &c. which Obligation (as he now remembreth) was ≈øingle with a defea≈øance for the debt, which was then agreed vpon to be an≈øwered at a certaine day following which ≈øaid debt he the ≈øaid A. B. paied accordingly by his then ≈øeruants and officers, who vnknowing vnto the ≈øaid A. B. did negligently (as is to be coniectured) leaue the bonds in the hands of the ≈øaid C. D. after the reckoning and debt paid or di≈øcharged. And ≈øo afterwards the ≈øaid A. B. did deale and continue in further credit with the ≈øaid C. D. for diuer≈øe other great ≈øummes of money, iewels, and plate, ≈øome vpon the ≈øaid Gold≈ømithes booke, and ≈øome vpon Bils, and Bonds, whereof the mo≈øt part were afterwards di≈øcharged, ≈øauing one debt by Recogni≈øa ‚Ä¢ ce about the foure and twentie day of, &c. in the &c. being to the value of 200. markes. In which ≈øaid latter debt, the ≈øaid A. B. pre≈øuming of friend≈øhip, and friendly dealing at the ≈øaid C. D. his hands, becau≈øe he had beene a very good cu≈øtomer vnto him, did not ≈øo preci≈øely keepe his day, thinking he would haue rea≈øonably dealt with him, being allowed for con≈øideration for forbearing thereof, as at other times he had done. Notwith≈øtanding, he the ≈øaid C. D. contrarie to the ≈øaid A. B. his expectation, did put the ≈øame Recogni≈øance in ≈øuit pre≈øently after the forfeiture thereof. And the ≈øaid A. B. being them bu≈øied in her Maie≈øties ≈øeruice, the ≈øaid C. D. had iudgement vpon the ≈øaid recogni≈øance again≈øt him before he could ≈øend vp to take any order for the ≈øaid latter debt by the ≈øaid recogni≈øance, and after tooke execution of the moitie of amanor of the ≈øaid A. B. called &c. in &c. which for the payment and performance of the ≈øaid debt was extended vnto twentie markes by the yeare, And ≈øo did leuie the ≈øaid whole forfeiture vpon the ≈øaid A. B. his manors and lands with great extremitie, vpon which extreme dealing
he the ≈øaid A. B. finding him≈øelfe mo≈øt cruelly and hardly dealt with, did refu≈øe to buy or ≈øell with him, and willed his Bailife of his ≈øaid manor to take acquittances of him at euery payment: who not onely did ≈øo, but vpon the la≈øt payment the fore≈øaid C. D. did acknowledge to him that paied the money, that your ≈øaid Orator was then cleere with him, and did owe nothing, or to ≈øuch effect, notwith≈øtanding the fore≈øaid A. B. accompted of him as of a verie extreame man: which the ≈øaid A. B. his di≈øplea≈øure towards him being notified & verie well knowen vnto him, both by letters from him≈øelfe and otherwi≈øe, yet the ≈øayd C. D. liuing nine or ten yeares after that, it can not be intended, that he who while≈øt they were in amitie, did ≈øue the ≈øaid A. B. vpon the ≈øaid recogni≈øance and debt therein conteined, being of ≈øo ≈ømall a value, would at the fir≈øt haue left the elder bond, and debt, being of a greater ≈øumme vn≈øued for, if it had bin vnan≈øwered for, or not paid, much le≈ø≈øe afterwards during all the ≈øpace of nine or ten yeres, when he the ≈øaid A. B. for his hard dealing had left to be his cu≈øtomer, or to deale with him, and thought but hardly of him, as he had no le≈ø≈øe cau≈øe: So though it be mo≈øt ≈øure and true, that the ≈øaid debt, for which the ≈øaid two hundred pounds bond was made in the ≈øaid fir≈øt yeare of the raigne of &c. was long ≈øince fully an≈øwered, yet it being ≈øo long ≈øince, the ≈øaid A. B. can not preci≈øely call to mind vpon the ≈øodaine who paid it (diuers of his officers which dealt for his reuenues, and e≈øpecially one I. P. whom principally he v≈øed in tho≈øe affaires, being now dead) whereby he can not vpon a ≈øpeedie triall at the common Law proue the payment thereof, by ≈øtrict and preci≈øe cour≈øe in that behalfe requi≈øite, and the rather, for that the Indentures for the defea≈øance of the ≈øaid recognizance, came by ≈øome ca≈øuall or negligeÃÑt meanes to the hands of the ≈øaid C. D. and of I. his wife, although it be manife≈øt by the pre≈øumptions afore≈øaid, that the ≈øaid C. D. would not haue let it lye ≈øo long vndemanded, if he had not bin ≈øati≈øfied, which the ≈øaid A. B. doubteth not to proue in this honorable court, for that al≈øo he thinketh there be yet ≈øome liuing that were pre≈øent at the la≈øt reckning, that the ≈øaid A. B. or his officers made with the ≈øaid C. D. either when he agreed for the ≈øaid extents, or about that time: at which time he the ≈øaid C. D. did acknowledge, that all matters, debtes, and reckonings what≈øoeuer, were then fully cleered and quit betwixt the ≈øaid A. B. and the ≈øaid C. D. And that the ≈øaid A. B. did not then owe him any thing. But ≈øo it is y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid C. D. now being dead, and I. his wife being his executrix, who finding the ≈øayd bond of CC. pounds remaining vncancelled, rather as it ≈øhould ≈øeeme by tho≈øe which haue conferred with her, vpon ≈øome words ≈øpoken, or conceit of offence, that ≈øhe hath conceaued of the ≈øaid A. B. his di≈øplea≈øure towards her late hu≈øband, then otherwi≈øe vpon any iu≈øt cau≈øe, ≈øhe
the ≈øaid I. hath publi≈øhed, that ≈øhe hath ≈øuch an ancient bond of the ≈øaid A. B. bearing date &c. of two hundred poundes, and inten ‚Ä¢ eth to put the ≈øame in ≈øuit again≈øt the ≈øaid A. B. In tender con≈øideration whereof, the apparant likelyhood of the ≈øaid debt before recited being mo≈øt true, and the ≈øame di≈øcharged, and yet the proofe of the di≈øcharge thereof in ≈øtrict cour≈øe of law being hard for the ≈øaid A. B. to make the ≈øaid I. P. and ≈øome others who dealt for him being now dead, and the ≈øaid defea≈øance being come to her hands (as afore≈øaid) but onely vpon oath of the ≈øaid I. D. who was priuy to that, and mo≈øt of her hu≈øbands reckonings and doings in his life time, and yet would not vniu≈øtly charge the ≈øaid A. B. with the ≈øaid debt, by meanes that ≈øhe hath both partes of the defea≈øans in her hands, whereby the ≈øaid A. B. can not pleade them, and not knowing the date of them, or wherein they are conteined, can not demaund them by the ordinarie cour≈øe of the Law. May it therefore plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip &c.

div.head: The An≈øwere.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid defendant ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid bill of complaint exhibited Sect. 132. again≈øt her in this Ho. court is vncertaine, and vn≈øufficient in the law to be an≈øwered vnto, and the matters therein conteined vntrue, and contriued more of purpo≈øe to put the ≈øaid def. to trouble and expences in law, then for any good or iu≈øt cau≈øe: Neuerthele≈ø≈øe if the ≈øame defendant ≈øhalbe compelled by this Ho. court to make any further an≈øwere to the ≈øame: then the aduantage of the in≈øufficiencie thereof to this defendant at all times hereafter ≈øaued. For further an≈øwere the ≈øaid defendant ≈øaith, that true it is, that the ≈øaid A. B. about the time mencioned in the ≈øaid bill of complaint, began to be a bargayner, and buyer of Plate and Iewels of the ≈øaide C. D. late hu≈øbandman to this defendant, and obtained credite at the hands of the ≈øaid C. D. for the ≈øumme of &c. For payment whereof the ≈øaid C. D. pre≈øuming vpon the promi≈øes of the ≈øaid A. B. was contented onely to accept of a bare ≈øingle obligation, which was ≈øealed and deliuered vnto him about the time mencioned in the ≈øaid bill, which ≈øumme of &c. the ≈øaid C. D. (after the day pa≈øt which was limitted for the payment thereof) often demaunded of the ≈øaid A. B. who notwith≈øtanding made no payment at all thereof, but with faire promi≈øes delayed time, and kept the ≈øaid C. D. in hope from yeare to yeare, that he ≈øhould be an≈øwered thereof to the vttermo≈øt peny. And at the la≈øt the ≈øaid A. B. hauing neede of certaine other Plate or Iewels, to the value of &c. intreated with the ≈øame C. D. to giue him credit for the ≈øame, and promi≈øed faithfully, that if the ≈øaide C. D. would tru≈øt him therewith, that then within ≈øhort ≈øpace after he would truely make payment a≈øwell of the hundred pounds, as al≈øo
of the ≈øaid two hundred poundes, vpon which earne≈øt intreatie the ≈øaid C. D. (being a man of a verie good nature, and ea≈øily led, by ≈øuch as he any way conceaued or thought well of) was contented to ≈øati≈øfie his reque≈øt: But yet fora≈ømuch as the ≈øaid A. B. had before that time taken but ≈ømall regard concerning the keeping of his dayes vpon the ≈øingle obligation afore≈øaid, the ≈øaid C. D. then thinking to deale more ≈øub≈øtancially with him then before, demaunded a recognizance for the ≈øaid ≈øumme of an hundred poundes, ≈øo then to be lent, without which he was vtterly vnwilling to tru≈øt him any further: Whereunto the ≈øaid A. B. a≈ø≈øented, and became bound accordingly in a Recognizance of two hundred markes, with condition for the true payment of an hundred pounds (which is the recognizance in the ≈øaide bill of complaint mencioned.) For di≈øcharge of which recognizance the ≈øaid A. B. tooke no greater regard then before he had done for payment of the ≈øaid ≈øingle Obligation, And therefore the ≈øaid C. D. at the la≈øt, three yeares at the lea≈øt being then pa≈øt after the forfaiture of the ≈øaid Recognizance, perceiuing the carele≈øne≈ø≈øe of the ≈øaid A. B. a≈øked adui≈øe of ≈øome of his friends, what cour≈øe he were be≈øt to take for the obtayning of the ≈øaide ≈øeuerall ≈øummes of money. By whom he was adui≈øed to put the ≈øaide Recognizance (rather then the Obligation afore≈øayd) in ≈øuit, a≈øwell for ≈øpeedy end of ≈øuit in the ≈øame, as al≈øo that thereby it was thought, the ≈øaide A. B. would the rather ≈øeeke meanes to make ≈øati≈øfaction a≈øwell of the one debt as of the other: But he meaning nothing le≈ø≈øe, nor regarding the ≈øaide ≈øuit, ≈øuffered the ≈øame to proceede till ≈øome parcell of his lande was extended, and ≈øo the ≈øaide C. D. was faine after three yeares forbearance of the ≈øaid ≈øumme of one hundred poundes, as afore≈øaid, and after he had ≈øpend more then twentie poundes in ≈øuites, and rewardes in obteyning the ≈øays extent, to accept onely twentie markes by the yeare, till the ≈øayd two hundred markes (being the principall) and penaltie were payed vnto hym: ≈øo that, the forbearance of the ≈øaide ≈øumme accompted together wyth the charges in ≈øuit, great lo≈ø≈øe of time in following the ≈øame, and rewardes gyuen to Shirifes and Baylifes, or euer any the ≈øaide landes might be extended: The ≈øaide C. D. ≈øu≈øtayned ≈øo great lo≈ø≈øe, as by the circum≈øtances of that which before hath been ≈øhewed, doth euidently approue, that he was vtterly di≈øcouraged to attempt any more ≈øuits again≈øt the ≈øaide A. B. but re≈øted ≈øtill in hope, that at one time or other he ≈øhould obtaine meanes in quiet ≈øort without ≈øuit in lawe to get ≈øati≈øfaction al≈øo of the ≈øaid ≈øumme of &c. which hath bin the rea≈øon onely why the ≈øayde E. D. did not put the ≈øayd Obligation in ≈øuit ≈øo long time, without that, that to the knowledge of this Defendant there was euer any defea≈øans
made vpon the ≈øaid Obligation, or that any ≈øuch defea≈øans by ca≈øuall meanes is come into the hands of this Defendant, as in the ≈øaid Bill is vntruely alleaged. And without that, that the ≈øaid A. B. by him≈øelfe or his officers as by the premi≈ø≈øes manife≈øtly appeareth, did make payment of the ≈øaid debt, or any part thereof: which the ≈øaid defendant is the rather throughly per≈øwaded of, as well becau≈øe ≈øhe was well acquainted with the dealings of her ≈øaid hu≈øband, as al≈øo becau≈øe at the time of the debts of her ≈øaid hu≈øband, he lying in extremity, called this defendant vnto him, and ≈øaid, that he had carefully gathered together ≈øundry bonds and Obligations, which at ≈øundry times had beene made vnto him for diuers ≈øummes of money, and yet in trueth they were paied and di≈øcharged, and tho≈øe bondes and Obligations he had put in a boxe by them≈øelues, and named them Billes, which Obligations he willed this defendant to cancell or deliuer to ≈øuch per≈øons as were the Obligors, and in any wi≈øe not to demaunde any debt vpon any of them. And further he al≈øo openly ≈øaid, that all the re≈øidue of the bonds and Obligations remaining in other boxes, which he then al≈øo named, were due and owing vnto him. In the which of the ≈øaid boxes the ≈øaid Obligation of 200. li. was found, neither is it to be thought that any officer of the ≈øaid A. B. would deale ≈øo lightly as to paye the money due vpon the ≈øaid Obligation beeing but ≈øingle and without penalty, without either acquittance, or the bond it ≈øelfe, redeliuered or cancelled. Or that the ≈øaid A. B. him≈øelfe would haue allowed of any ≈øuch payment vpon any his officers accompts. And without that, that the ≈øaid A. B. did at any time allow any maner of con≈øideration for the forbearaunce of any ≈øumme of money due by him to the ≈øaid C. D. (as al≈øo is vntruely alleaged.) And without that, that the ≈øaid C. D. did put the ≈øame Recogni≈øaunce in ≈øuite, pre≈øently after the forfeiture thereof: for the ≈øame was forborne three yeares after, as is before declared. And without that, that it is likely that the ≈øaide C. D. did acknowledge him≈øelfe ≈øati≈øfied of all tho≈øe ≈øeuerall ≈øummes of twenty markes, which ≈øhould make vp the two hundred markes vpon the extend afore≈øaid, when as he had recouered the whole debts due to him by the ≈øaid A. B. but onely without that, that the ≈øaid A. B. to the knowledge of this defendant, did ≈øignifie by his letters his di≈øplea≈øure towardes the ≈øayde C. D. as al≈øo is vntruely ≈øet downe. And without that, that any other thing materiall in the lawe &c. As in the other.

div.head: To cau≈øe one to ≈øhew his Lea≈øe, whereby he holdeth &c.
div.p:
MO≈øt humbly complayning &c. A. B. of &c. gentleman: That Sect. 133. whereas about fower yeares la≈øt pa≈øt, one C. D. of L. vpon a certaine
iudgement in a plea of debt amounting to the ≈øumme of &c. or there abouts, by him obteyned in her Maie≈øties court of common plees again≈øt one L. F. of &c. in the Countie of &c. ≈øued forth her Maie≈øties writ of Fieri facias, directed to the Shirife of the ≈øaid Countie, for the leuying of the ≈øaid debt of the goods and chattels of the ≈øaid E. F. By vertue of which writ the Shirife did among≈øt other things take into his hands one lea≈øe for diuers yeares yet induring made to the ≈øaid E. F. by one T. S. in the Countie of S. e≈øquier of three parcels of land, called and knowen by the name or names of &c. with all and ≈øinguler their appurtenances, lying and being in the pari≈øhes of &c. in the ≈øaid Countie of &c. together with all and ≈øinguler woods, vnderwoods, and trees, ≈øet, lying, being, and growing, in, or vpon the premi≈ø≈øes, or any part thereof: together al≈øo with the reuer≈øion and reuer≈øions of the premi≈ø≈øes afore≈øaid, and euery parcell thereof. And al≈øo all maner of common, a≈øwell of e≈øtouers and pa≈øtures, as all other commons, pa≈øtures, profites, and hereditaments what≈øoeuer, to the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes belonging or in any wi≈øe appertayning. And afterwards the ≈øaid Shirife (that is to ≈øay vpon the third day of May &c.) by his deede, bearing date vnder his hand and ≈øeale, did in con≈øideration of &c. to him paied towards the ≈øati≈øfaction of the debt and iudgement afore≈øaid, bargaine, ≈øell, a≈ø≈øigne, and ≈øet ouer the ≈øaid lea≈øe and terme of yeares yet to come, of all and ≈øinguler the premi≈ø≈øes vnto one G. H. of L. gen ‚Ä¢ , which G. H. not long after did in con≈øideration of &c. by your Orator to him paied, bargaine, ≈øell, a≈ø≈øigne, and ≈øet ouer vnto your ≈øaid Orator all and ≈øinguler the premi≈ø≈øes, and euery part thereof: Vpon which bargain and a≈ø≈øignement of the premi≈ø≈øes ≈øo made, as afore≈øaid, your ≈øaid Orator was in verie good hope to haue peaceably and quietly entred into the premi≈ø≈øes, and ≈øo to haue occupied and inioyed the ≈øame accordingly. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe ≈øo it is right Honorable, that one R. T. of &c. in the ≈øai ‚Ä¢ Countie of L. pretending to haue a lea≈øe for diuers yeres yet to come of ≈øome part of the ≈øaid lands, called &c. made vnto him by the afore≈øaid E. F. long time before any a≈ø≈øignements afore≈øaid, hath and yet doth keepe your ≈øaid Orator from the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid lands, vpon which lea≈øe or demi≈øe a certaine yerely rent is (as he ≈øaith) re≈øerued to the ≈øaid E. F. his executors or a≈ø≈øignes, which as your Orator verily thinketh is &c. by the yeare: and which rent, what≈øoeuer it be, your Orator by rea≈øon of the lawfull conueyance to him made as afore≈øaid, ought both in law and con≈øcience to haue and inioy during ≈øuch terme as the ≈øaid R. T. ≈øhall hold and occupie the land afore≈øaid, by rea≈øon of the ≈øaid lea≈øe, which he ≈øo pretendeth to haue: But becau≈øe your Orator doth not certainely knowe whether the ≈øaid R. T. haue any ≈øuch lea≈øe, neither if he haue, what date it beareth, what terme the ≈øaid R. hath therein vnexpired, what rent
thereby is re≈øerued, nor what couenants are therein conteined, as al≈øo your Orator can not, nor knoweth not how in due forme of law to enter or commence any action again≈øt the ≈øaid R. T. either for the recouerie of the ≈øaid land or rent afore≈øaid, which the ≈øaid R. T. right w ‚Ä¢ ll knowing being a man of little or no con≈øcience, but de≈øtitute of the feare of God, thinking all things well-gotten which he may get and hould without the puni≈øhment of the law, doth not onely v≈øe the ≈øaid land to his great profit and commoditie, without yelding or paying therefore any rent ot your Orator, or any other per≈øon lawfully clayming the ≈øame, but al≈øo doth vtterly refu≈øe to ≈øhewe his ≈øaid Lea≈øe, whereby he claymeth to hold the lands afore≈øaid, vnto your ≈øaid Orator, to the great lo≈ø≈øe and hinderance of your Lord≈øhips ≈øaid Orator: In tender con≈øideration whereof, and for a≈ømuch as your Orator hath no ordinarie way by the cour≈øe of the common Lawes of this Realme to enforce the ≈øaid R. T. to ≈øhew forth ≈øuch writings as he hath for the holding and inioying of the lands afore≈øaid, but is and ≈øhall be vtterly de≈øtitute of all maner of helpe or meanes to obtaine the ≈øame to his great hinderance and impoueri≈øhment, except your honorable Lord≈øhip of your accu≈øtomed clemencie towards all ≈øuch as are oppre≈ø≈øed, do extend your fauour in y‚Ä¢ behalfe, ≈øo that by the order of this honorable Court, the ≈øaid R. T. be inforced vpon his oath to ≈øhew what right he hath to the premi≈ø≈øes, or any part thereof, and likewi≈øe to ≈øet downe in his an≈øwere the true copie of the ≈øaid lea≈øe (verbatim) or other writings what≈øoeuer they he, whereby he claymeth the premi≈ø≈øes, or any part of the ≈øame. May it therefore plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip &c.

div.head: The An≈øwere.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid defendant not knowledging or confe≈ø≈øing the matters Sect. 134. ≈øugge≈øted in the ≈øaid bill of complaint to be true, for his an≈øwere touching the ≈øame ≈øaith, That the ≈øaid E. F. named in the ≈øaid bill of complaint was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed for diuers yeares yet to come and induring of the ≈øaid three parcels of land, called or knowen by the name of &c. mencioned in the ≈øaide bill of complaint by vertue of a lea≈øe thereof made by the ≈øaid T. S. al≈øo named in the ≈øaid bill of complaint, vnto the ≈øaid E. F. long before the ≈øuppo≈øed extent ≈øpecified in the ≈øaid bill of complaint. And the ≈øaid E. F. ≈øo being thereof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed long before the ≈øaid ≈øuppo≈øed extent, (if any ≈øuch were) had in ≈øuch manner, as in the ≈øaid bill of complaynt is ≈øuppo≈øed, made a lawfull demi≈øe and lea≈øe of part of the ≈øaid three parcels of land, conteyning fowerteene acres or thereabouts, vnto the ≈øaid defendant for diuers yeares yet to come, and remayning vnexpired, vpon which lea≈øe the ≈øaid E. F. re≈øerued a yerely rent to be paied during the continuance of the ≈øaid lea≈øe: By
force of which lea≈øe the ≈øaid defendant entered into the ≈øaid fowerteene acres of land, part of the ≈øaid three parcels called &c. and was and yet is lawfully po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed accordingly, And euer ≈øince, and yet doth inioy the ≈øaid fowerteene acres by vertue of the ≈øaid d ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ and lea≈øe made by the ≈øaid E. F. to the ≈øaid defendant, and is to haue and inioy the ≈øame during the continuance of the yeares, of which there are diuers yeares yet to come, and remayning vnexpired. And the ≈øaid defendant ≈øayeth, that y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid complaynant is a man to this defendant vtterly vnknowen, And therefore the ≈øaid defendant marueyleth much of the ≈øaid ≈øuit exhibited by the ≈øaid complaynant into this honorable court again≈øt the ≈øaid defendant touching the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes. And further ≈øaieth, that the ≈øaid E.
