F. after the ≈øaid demi≈øe and lea≈øe by him made vnto the ≈øaid defendant, of the ≈øaid fowerteene acres of land, and before the ≈øaid ≈øuppo≈øed extent if any ≈øuch be, made a graunt and a≈ø≈øignement of the intere≈øt and terme of the ≈øaid E. F. a≈øwell of the ≈øaid fowerteene acres, which the ≈øaid defendant hath and occupieth by vertue of his ≈øaid lea≈øe for diuers yeares yet thereof to come, and coutinuing vndetermined, as al≈øo of the re≈øidue of the ≈øaid three parcels of land mencioned in the ≈øaid bill of complaint vnto R. F. the ≈øonne of the ≈øaid E. F. vnto which graunt and a≈ø≈øignement the ≈øaid defendant was priuy. And therefore the ≈øaide defendant thinketh that he is for the payment of his rent chargeable, and ought by the Law to pay the ≈øame rent re≈øerued vnto the ≈øaide R. F. and not to the ≈øaide complaynant, which ≈øaide R. doth verily thinke that he is lawfull Landlord during the continuance of his yeres yet to come and induring, and not the ≈øaid complaynant, who is altogether a meere ≈øtranger vnto this defendant. And which complaynant neuer at any time heretofore demaunded any rent for the ≈øaid part of the lands that this defendant hath and occupieth by the lea≈øe for yeres yet continuing of the ≈øaid defendant. And the ≈øaid defendant al≈øo ≈øaieth, that he is ≈øued for the rent re≈øerued vpon his lea≈øe by the ≈øaid G. H. named in the ≈øaid bill of coÃÑplaint in the kings Bench in an action of debt brought by him again≈øt the ≈øaide defendant, And therefore the ≈øaid defendant much marueileth of this ≈øuit of the ≈øaide complaynant brought in this honorable court again≈øt the ≈øaid defendant touching the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes: By which ≈øuit of the ≈øaid complaynant, the ≈øaid defendant is wrongfully ≈øued and vexed without any iu≈øt cau≈øe of ≈øuit, without that, that there is any ≈øuch extent made of the ≈øaid three parcels of land called &c. or that after the ≈øame extent, there was any ≈øuch bargaine & ≈øale made by the ≈øaid Shirife named in y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid bill of complaint, of the ≈øaid terme & lea≈øe of yeres of the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes vnto the ≈øaid G. H. Or that the ≈øaid G. H. bargained or ≈øold the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes vnto the ≈øaid complaynant, or that the ≈øaid complaynant ought
to haue and inioy the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes to the knowledge of this defendant. And without that there is any other matter or thing &c. All which matters &c.

div.head: ‚Ä¢ ill for a title of land intailed.
div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øheweth and complayneth vnto your good Sect'. 135. Lord≈øhip, your daily Orator R. R. hu≈øbandman: That where one W. late of S. in the county of W. hu≈øbandman, grandfather of your ≈øaid Orator, was lawfully ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne as of fee, by due cour≈øe of inheritance vnto him lawfully di≈øcended from his aunce≈øtors, and other lawfull conueyances in the law, of, and in one me≈ø≈øuage &c. CC. acres of land, meadow, wood, and pa≈øture, with their appurtenances in S. afore≈øaid. And the ≈øaid W. R. ≈øo being of the premi≈ø≈øes ≈øei≈øed, about ten yeres now pa≈øt, It was condi≈øcended, granted, & agreed betweene the ≈øaid W. R. and one I. E. late of H. in the ≈øaid countie decea≈øed, that A. B. then ≈øonne and heire apparant of the ≈øaid W. R. before a certaine day ≈øhould marry and take to his wife one A. E. daughter of the ≈øaid I. E. and that the ≈øaid W. R. in con≈øideration thereof, and for that the ≈øaid A. ≈øhould be greatly aduanced and preferred in goods and ≈øub≈øtance by the mariage of the ≈øaid A. would immediatly after the ≈øaid mariage had and ≈øolemnized, conuey and make vnto the ≈øaid A. and A. a good, ≈øufficient, and lawfull e≈øtate in the Law, of, and in the ≈øaid me≈øuage, lands, tenements, and other the premi≈ø≈øes. To haue and to hold vnto the ≈øaid A. and A. and to their heires males of their bodies lawfully begotten. And afterward the ≈øaid A. according to the ≈øaid agreement, did marrie and take to his wife the ≈øaid A. E. immediatly after which mariage had and ≈øolempnized, the ≈øaid W. K. according to his ≈øaid promi≈øe and agreement, did lawfully enfeoffe of, and in the ≈øaid me≈øuage, lands, tenements, and other the premi≈ø≈øes, the ≈øaid A. R. and A. then his wife, To haue and to hold vnto the ≈øame A. and A. and to their heires males of their bodies lawfully begotten, by force whereof the ≈øaid A. and A. were ≈øei≈øed of, and in the premi≈ø≈øes, in their demeanes, as of fee taile ≈øpeciall, and they ≈øo being thereof ≈øei≈øed, the ≈øaid A. and A. had i≈ø≈øue male betweene them lawfully begotten, one I. R. and your ≈øaid Orator, and one W. R. and the ≈øaid W. R. the elder died, by and after who≈øe death the reuer≈øion in fee ≈øimple of the premi≈ø≈øes di≈øcended vnto the ≈øaid A. as ≈øonne and heire vnto him. And afterward the ≈øaid A. and Agnes dyed, after who≈øe death the ≈øaid me≈ø≈øuage, lands, tenements, and other the premi≈ø≈øes di≈øcended and came, and of right ought to di≈øcend and come vnto the ≈øaid I. R. as ≈øonne and heire male of the bodie of the ≈øaid A. and A. lawfully begotten, by force whereof the ≈øaid I. R. entred into the ≈øaid me≈ø≈øuage, lands, tenements, and other the premi≈ø≈øes,
and was thereof ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne as of fee taile. And he ≈øo being thereof ≈øei≈øed, the ≈øaid I. R. about foure yeres now pa≈øt, of the ≈øaid me≈ø≈øuage and other the premi≈ø≈øes dyed ≈øei≈øed, without i≈ø≈øue male of his bodie lawfully begotten, by force whereof the ≈øaid me≈ø≈øuage and other the premi≈ø≈øes di≈øcended and came, and of right ought to di≈øcend and come vnto your ≈øaid poore Orator, as brother and heire male to the ≈øaid I. R. by the vertue of the gift afore≈øaid. So it is my ≈øinguler good Lord, that a≈øwell the deede of intaile made, of, and for the premi≈ø≈øes by the ≈øaid W. R. the grandfather vnto the ≈øaid A. R. and A. and to the heires males of their bodies lawfully begotten, as is afore≈øaid, as diuers other charters, euidences, and deedes, writings and muniments concerning the premi≈ø≈øes, prouing the ≈øaid intere≈øt and title of your ≈øaid Orator, in, and to the premi≈ø≈øes: been di≈øceiptfully comen to the hands and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of I. W. and C. his wife, late wife of the ≈øaid I. R. G. W. gentleman, and T. S. the elder, and remaine there as they haue conueyed and put them: and by colour of hauing the ≈øaid euidences, deedes, writings, and mumments in their hands and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, the ≈øame I. W. and E. haue now of late wrongfully entred into the ≈øaid me≈ø≈øuage and other the premi≈ø≈øes, And the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof do ≈øo yet wrongfully deteine & keepe from your ≈øaid Orator, and al≈øo the rents, i≈ø≈øues, and profites thereof haue wrongfully receiued, perceiue ‚Ä¢ , and taken to their owne v≈øe by the ≈øpace of fower yeres pa≈øt, and ≈øo yet do, contrary to all right and good con≈øcience. And albeit that your ≈øayd Orator hath often and ≈øundry times required and in≈øtantly de≈øired the ≈øaid I. W. and E. G. W. and T. S. a≈øwell to deliuer vnto your ≈øaid Orator the ≈øaid euidences, deedes, writings, and muniments concerning the premi≈ø≈øes, as al≈øo to auoid the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the premi≈ø≈øes, and peaceably and quietly to permit and ≈øuffer your ≈øaid Orator and his a≈ø≈øignes, to haue and inioy the ≈øame, and to receiue and take the rents and profits thereof to his owne v≈øe, according to his ≈øaid intere≈øt and title therein, which to do, they at all times haue refu≈øed and denied, and yet do, contrarie to all right and good con≈øcience. And for a≈ømuch as your ≈øaid Orator knoweth not the certaine number, contents, ne other certainties of the ≈øaid euidences, deedes, writings, and muniments, nor wherein they be conteined. And al≈øo for that the ≈øaid I. W. E. G. W. and T. S. be of ≈øo great ≈øub≈øtance & riches, and al≈øo greatly frinded, and borne in the ≈øaid Countie of W. And your ≈øaid Orator being but a poore man and hauing but few friends in the ≈øaid Countie, the ≈øame your ≈øaid Orator is, and ≈øhall be therefore without remedy concerning the premi≈ø≈øes by due cour≈øe and order of the common Law, and otherwi≈øe, vnle≈ø≈øe your good Lord≈øhips ayde and fauour be vnto him ≈øhewed in this behalfe. In con≈øideration whereof it may plea≈øe your good
Lord≈øhip, (the premi≈ø≈øes tenderly con≈øidered) to graunt vnto your ≈øaid Orator the Queenes mo≈øt gratious ≈øeueral writs of Subpena to be directed vnto the ≈øaid I. Werewick, E. G. S. and T. S. commaunding them and euery of them by the ≈øame, per≈øonally to appeare in the mo≈øt honorable Court of Chauncery, at a certain day, & vpon a certain paine by your good Lord≈øhip to be limitted therein, then, and there to make an≈øwere to the premi≈ø≈øes: And further to be ordered therein, as ≈øhall accord with right and good con≈øcience. And your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhall daylie pray &c.

div.head: The An≈øwere of I. W. to the bill of complaint of R. K. husbandman.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid defendant ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid bill of complaint is vncertain Sect'. 136. and in≈øufficient in the law to be an≈øwered vnto, & the matter therein contained vntrue, & principally imagined, & pur≈øued by the vnlawfull procurement, bearing, & ≈øupportation of one W. C. E≈øq. to the intent to put the ≈øaid def. to trouble, co≈øtes, & expences, intending thereby the vnquiet & impoueri≈øh the ≈øaid def. as they ≈øhould be faine to leaue the right, title, and intere≈øt, of, and in the premi≈ø≈øes, ≈øo that the ≈øaid W. might purcha≈øe & buy the ≈øame of the ≈øaid Complainant: And of late the ≈øaid W. C. hath made meanes vnto the ≈øaid I. W. now def. to buy his title & intere≈øt, of, & in the premi≈ø≈øes, and threatned him to haue the ≈øame, and if he would not let him haue it with his good will, that then he would haue it again≈øt his will, who≈øoeuer tooke his part: and if the contents of the ≈øaid bill were true (as they are not) yet were the matter determinable at the common Law, and not in this honorable Court, whereunto the ≈øaid def. prayeth to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed: and yet neuerthele≈ø≈øe, the aduantage of the premi≈ø≈øes vnto this defendant at all times ≈øaued. For further an≈øwere vnto the ≈øaid bill for declaration of the truth of the contents of the ≈øaid bill, the ≈øaid def. ≈øaith, & euery one of them ≈øaith, that longtime before the ≈øaid A. R. mencioned in the ≈øaid bill of complaint, any thing had in the ≈øaid me≈ø≈øuage & other the premi≈ø≈øes, or that the ≈øaid W. R. was thereof enfeoffed, T. R. of P. T. S. of S. and W. of E. were thereof ≈øei≈øed in their deme≈ønes as of fee, & ≈øo being thereof ≈øei≈øed, by their writing indeÃÑted, ready to be ≈øhewed, (the ≈øaid me≈ø≈øuage & other the premi≈ø≈øes contained in y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid bill of coÃÑplaint, among≈øt other things) gaue, demi≈øed, deliuered, & by their ≈øaid writing indented, coÃÑfirmed, vnto the ≈øaid W. R. mencioned in the ≈øaid bill of complaint, and vnto A. his wife, To haue & to hold the ≈øaid me≈ø≈øuages & other the premi≈ø≈øes vnto the ≈øaid W. and A. for terme of their liues, and to the wife of the longer liuer of them. And the ≈øaid T. and T. willed & declared in the ≈øaid writing indented, that the ≈øaid me≈ø≈øuage & all other the premi≈ø≈øes ≈øhould remaine vnto the ≈øaid A. mentioned in the ≈øaid bil of complaint, & vnto A.
his wife, & vnto the heires & a≈ø≈øignes of y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid A. for euer: without y‚Ä¢ the ≈øaid W. R. did enfeoffe of, & in the ≈øaid me≈ø≈øuage lands, tenements, & other the premi≈ø≈øes, the ≈øaid A. & A. to haue to theÃÑ & to their heires males of their two bodies lawfully begotten, or that the ≈øaid A. & Agnes were ≈øei≈øed of, & in the premi≈ø≈øes in their deme≈ønes as of fee taile, as in the ≈øaid bill of coÃÑplaint is ≈øurmi≈øed, & without that, that after y‚Ä¢ death of the ≈øaid W. y‚Ä¢ the remainder of y‚Ä¢ premi≈ø≈øes in fee ≈øimple di≈øcended vnto the ≈øaid A. as ≈øonne & heire vnto him, or that after y‚Ä¢ death of the ≈øaid A. & A. the ≈øaid me≈ø≈øuage & other the premi≈ø≈øes di≈øcended, and of right ought to di≈øcend or come vnto the ≈øaid I. R. in the taile e≈øpeciall, as ≈øonne and heire male of the bodie of the ≈øaid A. and Agnes lawfully begotten, either any other di≈øcent of inheritance therein of a meere fee ≈øimple, or that the ≈øaid I. by his entrie into the ≈øaid me≈øuage & other the premi≈ø≈øes after the death of his father & mother, was then ≈øei≈øed of, and in his deme≈øne as of fee taile e≈øpeciall, or of any ≈øuch e≈øtate dyed ≈øei≈øed, or that after the death of the ≈øaid I. that the ≈øaid me≈øuage and other the premi≈ø≈øes, or any part or parcell thereof di≈øcended and came, or of right ought to di≈øcend and come to the ≈øaid complaynant as brother and heire male to the ≈øaid I. K. by vertue of any gift or otherwi≈øe, as in the bill of complaint is vntruly ≈øurmi≈øed: But the ≈øaid defendants do auerre, and are, & ≈øhall be at all times ready to proue, as this honorable Court ≈øhall award, that the ≈øaid me≈ø≈øuages and all other the premi≈ø≈øes, by, and immediatly after the death of the ≈øaid I. R. di≈øcended, and of right ought to di≈øcend and come to one A. daughter and heire of the ≈øaid I. lawfully begotten on the bodie of the ≈øaid E. one of the≈øe defendants, the which A. is yet in plaine life, and in the ward and cu≈øtodie of her ≈øaid mother: And without that, that any deede of taile was made, of, and by the ≈øaid W. R. the grandfather, or any other euidence, deeds, writings, or muniments, concerning the premi≈ø≈øes, proouing the ≈øaid intere≈øt and title of the ≈øaid complaynant of the premi≈ø≈øes, and euery part and parcell thereof, to be comen to the hands and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of the ≈øaid I. W. and E. his wife, or either of them, or to the cu≈øtodie or po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of any other by their deliuerie, conueyance, or appointment: but trueth it is, that the ≈øaid defendants haue in their cu≈øtodie, one writing indented readie to be ≈øhewed, whereby the remainder of the premi≈ø≈øes is conueyed vnto the ≈øaid A. and Agnes his wife, and to the heires and a≈ø≈øignes of the ≈øayd A. for euer, as is afore≈øaid, and diuers other euidences and writings, proouing and concerning the conueyance of the fee ≈øimple of the ≈øaid me≈øuage, and other the premi≈ø≈øes vnto the ≈øaid A. and other his aunce≈øtors, the which charters, euideÃÑces, & writings, the ≈øaid def. do ≈øtill with them detaine & keepe, as good & lawfull is for them to do, as wel for y‚Ä¢ proofe and pre≈øeruation of their right, title, and intere≈øt, vnto the third part of
the premi≈ø≈øes for the dowrie of the ≈øaid E. as for the pre≈øeruation of the right, title, and intere≈øt of the ≈øaid A. daughter and heire to the ≈øaid I. of, and in the ≈øaid me≈øuage, and other the premi≈ø≈øes: without that the ≈øaid def. haue at any time wrongfully entred into the ≈øaid me≈øuage, and other he premi≈ø≈øes, or into any part thereof, or the profites thereof do wrongfully detaine, and keepe froÃÑ the ≈øaid complainants, or the rents, i≈ø≈øues, and profites thereof, haue wrongfully de≈øtreyned, perceyued, and taken to their owne v≈øe, as in the ≈øame bill is al≈øo vntruely ≈øurmi≈øed.

div.head: A Supplication in the Chauncerie vpon deceipt by a Partner.
div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe complayning ≈øheweth &c. That whereas vpon Sect. 137. the imagination of hone≈øty and good opinion that R. C. father vnto your ≈øaide Orator decea≈øed, had in one T. T. &c. the ≈øaid R. about Ea≈øter la≈øt pa≈øt, did ioine in bargaine with the ≈øaid T. T. for the deliuerie of ≈øo much wares, whereof the moitie was the ≈øaid R. as amounted to the ≈øumme of &c. vnto one I. S. of the Queenes Maie≈øties hou≈øhold E≈øquire, for the which ≈øumme of &c. the ≈øaid S. ≈øtood bound by ≈øtatute of the Staple, vnto the ≈øaid R. C. and T. T. payable at the fea≈øt of &c. then next &c. which was in the yere of our ≈øoueraigne &c. And to the intent that the ≈øame R. being a man of ≈øuch hone≈øtie and ≈øimplicitie, as did neither ≈øu≈øpect, nor yet doubt the good con≈øcience of the ≈øaid T. who alwaies toward him, had counterfaited ≈øuch puritie of con≈øcience, and ≈øo hone≈øt behauior, might the better by the help of the ≈øame T. come by his debt, at the time to be due, if he ≈øo long liued, or els if he died, that the ≈øaid T. might be as a ≈øtay and ≈øure meanes to his executors, for the getting in of the ≈øame, he the ≈øame R. tru≈øted the ≈øaid T. with the cu≈øtodie of the ≈øaid Statute: Soone after the making of the which bargaine, and ≈øomewhat before the ≈øaid fea≈øt of &c. the ≈øaid R. decea≈øed, and made your Orator his executor, thereby charging him a≈øwell with the gathering in of all ≈øuch ≈øummes of money as were due to the ≈øaid Te≈øtator, as al≈øo with the payment of all ≈øuch debts, as the ≈øaid R. did owe. And ≈øo it is, mo≈øt gratious Lord, that although your ≈øaid Orator hath diuers and ≈øundrie times ≈øince the decea≈øe of his ≈øaid father, required the ≈øaid T. to haue the moitie of the ≈øaid &c. due to him by equitie and good con≈øcience, as executor vnto his ≈øaid te≈øtator &c. The ≈øaid T. (now declaring him≈øelfe what he is) hauing regard neither to con≈øcience, common hone≈øtie, nor yet to the tru≈øt he was put in, minding if he can (with what iniurie he careth not) vtterly to barre your ≈øaid Orator from the hauing thereof, and he him≈øelfe again≈øt all rea≈øon and con≈øcience to haue the ≈øaid &c. for nothing: hath not onely with many ≈øleight and ≈øubtill delayes, lingred and delaied your ≈øai ‚Ä¢ Orator long time from hauing the ≈øame: but al≈øo now lately hath
plainly an≈øwered and affirmed, that your ≈øaide Orator ≈øhall haue no part nor penie thereof, which if it ≈øhould thus pa≈ø≈øe, ≈øhould be both great incouraging to ≈øuch corrupt con≈øcioned per≈øons, ≈øtill to per≈øeuer in ≈øuch their lewd demeanour, and in the meane time, turne to the great impoueri≈øhing of your ≈øaide poore Orator: Wherefore may it plea≈øe your ho. Lord≈øhip, of your accu≈øtomed equitie, to inioyne the ≈øaid T. that he repay vnto your ≈øaid Orator the ≈øaid &c. moitie of the ≈øaid &c. if he haue receiued it of the ≈øaid S. or if he haue not, that he be nolet to your ≈øaid Orator, to do therein what he can, for the obteyning and getting in the ≈øame. And thus ≈øhall your ≈øaid Orator haue cau≈øe continually to pray for the pro≈øperous e≈øtate of your good Lord≈øhip long to indure.

div.head: A bill of Complaint for recouering of Euidences made by compul≈øion by a man in pri≈øon, without con≈øideration.
div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe complayning, ≈øheweth vnto your good Lord≈øhip, Sect. 138. your daily Oratrix I. B. That whereas in the yeare &c. it chaunced the hu≈øband of your ≈øaide Oratrix, together with one &c. iointly and ≈øeuerally to be bounden in a Recognizance of the ≈øumme of &c. knowledged before your good Lord≈øhip in the Queenes Maie≈øties Court of Chauncerie, for the payment of &c. payable at a certaine day now pa≈øt, vnto one &c. for which ≈øumme not being paied at the day due, the ≈øaid &c. hath ≈øued execution again≈øt your ≈øaid poore Oratrices hu≈øband, whereupon he was by y‚Ä¢ Shiriffe of &c. arre≈øted about &c. pa≈øt, and by all the ≈øaid ≈øpace hath remained in the Qu. Maie≈øties pri≈øon of Mar≈øhal≈øie, to his great paine of body, importable charges, and in maner vndoing, both of him, your poore Oratrix, and their ≈ømall children, which piteous e≈øtate of his, (with him≈øelfe lamenting) after he had well con≈øidered, he then con≈øulted with him≈øelfe, for his be≈øt remedy in that behalfe, and therewithall calling to his minde, that he had &c. a kin≈øman and co≈øin called &c. being of &c. vnto whom your ≈øaid oratrices hu≈øband, for the vicinitie of bloud, and abilitie of ≈øub≈øtance, was bolder to make his mone for helpe of this his aduer≈øitie, then vnto anie other. But (farre contrarie to his expectation, and again≈øt all humanitie) whence your ≈øaid Oratrices poore hu≈øband looked for mo≈øt ≈øuccour, thence he receiued, not onely lea≈øt help, but al≈øo mo≈øt hurt. For the ≈øaid &c. well perceiuing thaduer≈øe e≈øtate that your Oratrices poore hu≈øband was, and is in, which was the greedine≈ø≈øe of the Marchant for his money, therne≈øt thought and care of your poore Oratrix, and her poore children, and the great de≈øire that her ≈øaid poore hu≈øband had (as any man would) of liberty, and di≈øcharge of trouble, would by no meanes promi≈øe his helpe vnto her ≈øaid poore hu≈øband
herein, vnle≈ø≈øe he would be content to bargaine and ≈øell all his lands, amounting to the yearely rent of &c. vnto him the ≈øayd &c. for an Annuity of xx. li. ≈øterling to him, during his life, and for the ≈øumme &c. whereo ‚Ä¢ &c. to be paide in hand, whereunto your ≈øaid poore Oratrices hu≈øband, through the con≈øtraint of his ≈øaide ca≈øe, was compelled to agree, and to ≈øeale ≈øuch writings as the ≈øaide &c. not long after hee brought to him Indentures coÃÑcerning the bargaine, nothing doubting of &c. being his co≈øin, but that they would haue ≈øealed to none other, but onely ≈øuch as con≈øcience would ≈øtand with, at which time the ≈øame &c. neither paide nor profered any peny of the ≈øaid &c. according to his couenant, with delay of paiment, both again≈øt his promi≈øes and couenant: After her ≈øaid poore hu≈øband had ≈øtudied vpon, and therewithall read ouer the couenants compri≈øed in the ≈øaide Indentures of this bargaine, which indeede (mo≈øt honorable Lord) were ≈øo parcially deui≈øed for the behoofe of the ≈øaid &c. and againe, ≈øo ≈øore again≈øt your ≈øaide poore Oratrices hu≈øband, as (if the bargaine had taken effect) had bin to the vtter vndoing of him and her, with all their heires for euer, your ≈øaide poore Oratrices hu≈øbande, taking hold on the point that the ≈øaid &c. paied not the fore≈øaide &c. did at their next meeting, renounce and ≈øay, that he would not ≈øtand to the ≈øaide couenants and bargaine, whereunto the ≈øaid &c. partly acknowledging in that he had not paide nor profered this &c. ≈øaide before ≈øufficient witne≈ø≈øes here ready to be ≈øworne, he was contented, howbeit he ≈øaid, that your ≈øaide Oratrices poore hu≈øband ≈øhould pay for the making of the writings: For the payment whereof her ≈øaid hu≈øband, as then hauing no great ≈øtore of mony, was faine to giue him a gold Ring in pledge, to pay the ≈øcribe for writing of the ≈øame: All this notwith≈øtanding (mo≈øt honourable Lord) and that you ≈øaid poore Oratrices hu≈øbande, hath often and ≈øundry times ≈øince by many waies & meanes required the ≈øame writings, coÃÑcerning the ≈øaid bargaine of the ≈øaid &c. he again≈øt all naturall loue and humanity, nothing more coueting, then the extreame de≈øtruction of her, and her ≈øaide poore hu≈øband, and well perceiuing how farre he is now vnable to helpe him≈øelfe, hath vtterly denyed to render the ≈øame, and yet doth, contrary to all con≈øcience, equity, lawe or right: In con≈øideration whereof, may it like your honourable Lord≈øhip, of your accu≈øtomed pity, to call the ≈øaid &c. before you, together with the hu≈øband of your ≈øaide poore Oratrix, and there to will him to deliuer the ≈øaide writings againe to her hu≈øband, if it ≈øhall ≈øo ≈øeeme good vnto your honor, or els to ≈øhewe ≈øufficient matter why hee ≈øhoulde keepe the ≈øame. And your ≈øaid Oratrix, with her poore hu≈øband, and their poore children ≈øhall pray &c.

div.head: A bill of a title of Copyhold lands, praying an Iniunction.
div.p:
HVmbly complayning &c. your daily Orator W. S. otherwi≈øe Sect. 139. named W. T. of L. co≈øin and heire of I. S. otherwi≈øe called I. T. while he lyued &c. That whereas your ≈øaid Orator at your Lord≈øhips la≈øt being at &c. did exhibit vnto you a certaine bill of complaint, mencioning therein that the fore≈øaid I. S. otherwi≈øe called I. T. in his life time was ≈øei≈øed, of and in certaine Cu≈øtomarie lands & tenements, that is to ≈øay, of, and in &c. holden by Copie of court Roll of the manor of &c. at the wil of the Lord of the ≈øaid manor, according to the cu≈øtome of the ≈øame manor, of which one T. L. then was, and yet is Lord, And that the ≈øame I. S. ≈øo being ≈øei≈øed of the premi≈ø≈øes, afterwards of like e≈øtate died thereof by prote≈øtation ≈øei≈øed, after who≈øe death the ≈øaid &c. with the appurtenances, and the right, title, v≈øe, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and inheritance thereof di≈øcended and came, and of verie right ought to di≈øcend and come vnto your ≈øaid Orator as co≈øin & next heire of the ≈øaid I. S. that is to ≈øay, as yonge≈øt ≈øonne of I. yonge≈øt ≈øonne and heire of the ≈øame I. S. according to the auncient cu≈øtome of the ≈øaide manor. And that your ≈øaide Orator had often and ≈øundry times de≈øired and prayed the ≈øaid &c. that with lawfull warning vnto the tenants of the ≈øaid Lord≈øhip, a Court might be holden at the ≈øaide manor, by who≈øe inquirie, the title of your ≈øaid Orator might be pre≈øented and found in the premi≈ø≈øes, according as both iu≈øtice, right, and good con≈øcience do require: Hawbeit mo≈øt honorable Lord, that notwith≈øtanding, for a≈ømuch as the ≈øame &c. hath kept the premi≈ø≈øes in his owne handes the≈øe many yeares pa≈øt, and the profites and i≈ø≈øues thereof comming, hath by the ≈øame ≈øpace to his owne proper v≈øe receiued & taken, and yet doth, your ≈øaid poore Orator could neuer get the ≈øame &c. to hold a Court there, minding thereby vtter di≈øheriting vnto your ≈øaid poore Orator, of, and in the premi≈ø≈øes: Vntill ≈øuch time as your ≈øaide mu≈øt honorable Lord≈øhip, moued with your accu≈øtomed loue to Iu≈øtice, and pitie towards pouertie, vouch≈øafed to graunt your benigne letters directed to the ≈øaid &c. willing him thereby with lawfull warning giuen vnto the tenants of the ≈øaid Lord≈øhip, to ≈øummon and keepe a Court at the ≈øaide manor, for the triall of the right of your ≈øaide Orator in the premi≈ø≈øes, vpon the receipt of which letters, the ≈øaide &c. ≈øummoned and kept a Court at his ≈øaid Manor of &c. whereat vpon the open and plaine declaration of your ≈øaid Orators title, together with the examination of diuers witne≈ø≈øes, brought in by your ≈øaid Orator, for the due proofe of the ≈øaid title in the premi≈ø≈øes: And further, vpoÃÑ the ≈øhewing of ≈øuch ≈øub≈øtanciall and anncient euidences maintayning the ≈øame, the Homage therewith charged and ≈øworne did pre≈øent & ≈øind at the ≈øaid &c. (before
I. S. Steward of the ≈øame Court) that the fore≈øaid I. S. was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor, and held the premi≈ø≈øes by Copie of court Roll, according to the cu≈øtome of the ≈øaid manor: And that al≈øo your ≈øaid Orator was co≈øin and heire to the ≈øaid I. S. according to the cu≈øtome of the manor: that is to ≈øay, ≈øonne of I. yonger ≈øonne of &c. as by the Copie of the ≈øame court Rols ready to be ≈øhewed more plainly may appeare vnto your good Lord≈øhip. After which pre≈øentment at the ≈øame Court, it was agreed betwixt the ≈øaid Steward, in the name of the ≈øaid &c. and your ≈øaid Orator, that if the ≈øaid &c. would not declare and ≈øhow vnto your ≈øaid Orator, or to his learned Coun≈øell at London, within one Terme then next in≈øuing, a better title and intere≈øt to the fore≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes, then your ≈øaid Orator had then and there already proued, that then your ≈øaide Orator ≈øhould haue and inioy the premi≈ø≈øes to him, and to his heires, according to right, equitie, and good con≈øcience, and according to the cu≈øtome of the ≈øaid manor. But ≈øo it is (mo≈øt ho. Lord) that although the ≈øaid &c. as he cannot, ≈øo hath he not by the ≈øaid ≈øpace prooued any maner of title, or colour of title to the premi≈ø≈øes, but onely with ≈øuch and like fraudulent delayes, he intendeth to weary your ≈øaid Orator from the obtaining of the premi≈ø≈øes, and if he can, di≈øherite him from the ≈øame: Wherefore, may it &c. of your accu≈øtomable goodnes alwayes to pouertie extended, to graunt vnto your ≈øaid Orator, the Q. mo≈øt gracious writ of Subpena, to be directed to the ≈øaid &c. commaunding him by the ≈øame, not onely to appeare per≈øonally before your good Lord≈øhip in the high Court of Chauncery, at a certaine day, and vnder a certaine paine by your good Lord≈øhip therein to be limitted: but al≈øo to permit and ≈øuffer your ≈øaid Orator peaceably to haue, hold, occupie, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe, and inioy the premi≈ø≈øes afore≈øaid, and the profits and i≈ø≈øues of the ≈øame, vntill ≈øuch time as the ≈øame &c. hath duely approued better Title to the premi≈ø≈øes, then he hath heretofore done. And your ≈øaid poore Orator ≈øhall &c.

div.head: A bill of complaint for Debt without e≈øpecialtie.
div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe ≈øheweth and complayneth vnto your good Sect' 140. Lord≈øhip, your daily Orator and poore bedeman I. G. of H. in the countie of D. That where the ≈øaid I. G. by way of pre≈øt, at the fea≈øt of Penteco≈øt, in the xxxiiii. yeare of the raigne of our Soueraigne Ladie the Queenes Maie≈øtie that now is, did deliuer vnto one W. L. late of H. in the ≈øaid countie of D. the ≈øumme of xviii. pound, of lawfull money of England, to be paied vnto him at the fea≈øt of Saint A. then next in≈øuing, before which day the ≈øaid W. L. by his la≈øt will and Te≈øtament, con≈øtituted and made one E. then his wife, his executrix, and dyed, and left vnto the ≈øaid E. then his executrix, of his owne proper goods (all
his debts paied) the ≈øumme of one hundred pounds, of whom your ≈øaid Orator ≈øundrie and many times hath required payment of the ≈øaid xviii. pound, which to content and pay, the ≈øaid E. did neuer vtterly denye, but did require re≈øpite for the payment of the ≈øame, and before the ≈øaide E. did content and pay any penie of the ≈øaid xviii. pound the ≈øaid E. in her death ded, by her la≈øt will and te≈øtament, did con≈øtitute and make one I. S. her ≈øonne her executor, and dyed, and left to him ≈øufficient of the goods of the ≈øaide W. for the contentation and payment of the ≈øame xviii. pound, and after dyed, ≈øithence who≈øe death the ≈øaide complaynant, dayly, ≈øundrie, and many times required the ≈øaide I. S. to content and pay vnto him the ≈øaide ≈øumme of xviii. pound, which to do, he hath at all times refu≈øed, and yet doth, contrarie to right and good con≈øcience, to the vtter vndoing of your poore Orator foreuer. And for becau≈øe your Orator hath no ≈øpecialtie, whereby he ≈øhould charge the Executor or the Executrix of the ≈øaide W. L. he is therefore without remedie by the order of the common Law of this Realme, and is like vtterly to loo≈øe the ≈øaide xviii. pound vnle≈ø≈øe your gracious fauour be to him ≈øhewed in this behalfe: In tender con≈øideration whereof, it may therefore plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip (the premi≈ø≈øes con≈øidered) to graunt the Queenes writ of Subpena, to be directed to the ≈øaide I. S. commaunding him by the ≈øame per≈øonally to appeare before your good Lord≈øhip, in the Queenes mo≈øt gracious Court of Chauncerie &c.

div.head: The an≈øwere of the ≈øame Bill for xvii ‚Ä¢ . poundlent without ≈øpecialtie.
div.p:
THe ≈øaide I. S. by prote≈øtation not knowing that the ≈øaide Complainant Sect. 141. did deliuer the ≈øaide W. L. in the ≈øaide bill named, the ≈øumme of xviii. pound, or any part thereof by way of pre≈øt, as in the ≈øaid bill is ≈øurmi≈øed: He further ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid bill of complaint is vncertaine and in≈øufficient in the Law to be an≈øwered vnto, and much of the matter therein contained, is fained and imagined, for vexation and trouble of the ≈øaide I. S. notwith≈øtanding, the aduantage thereof to him at all times ≈øaued: The ≈øaid I. S. for further an≈øwere vnto the ≈øaide bill, ≈øayth, that long time before the ≈øaide E. L. was con≈øtituted and made Executrix vnto the ≈øaid W. L. the ≈øaid E. was maried vnto one R. S. father of this defendant, by the ≈øpace of twentie yeares and more, which ≈øaid R. S. by his la≈øt will and te≈øtament, con≈øtituted, ordeyned, and made the ≈øaid E. and the ≈øaid I. S. his Executors, and dyed, and left to the order and di≈øpo≈øition of the ≈øaid Executors, goods and cattles of his owne, to the value of two hundred pounds ≈øterling
and aboue. All which goods and cattels for the mo≈øt part of the ≈øame, being and remayning in the hands and cu≈øtodie of the ≈øaide E. ≈øhe the ≈øame E. married and tooke to hu≈øband the ≈øaid W. L. which ≈øaide W. after the marriage had betweene him and the ≈øaid E. did mi≈øpend, wa≈øt, and con≈øume of the ≈øaid goods and cattels late of the ≈øame R. S. to the value and ≈øumme of 140. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øterling and aboue. And after the ≈øaid W. L. by his la≈øt will and Te≈øtament ordeined and made the ≈øaide E. executrix thereof, & died a verie poore man, hauing no maner of goods nor cattels at the time of his death of his owne, to the value of twentie ≈øhillings ≈øterling. And afterward the ≈øaid E. by her la≈øt will, ordeined this defendant executor thereof, and died, ≈øithen who≈øe death there hath not come to the hands of this defendant of the goods late of the ≈øaid W. L. to the value of 20. ≈øhillings ≈øterling, without that, that the ≈øaid W. L. at his death left vnto the ≈øaide E. of his owne proper goods, to the ≈øumme of an hundred pounds, ouer his debts paid, or yet the ≈øumme of twentie ≈øhillings ≈øterling, or that the ≈øaid E. after the death of the ≈øaid W. L. did euer con≈øent or agree to pay the ≈øaide eighteene pound vnto the ≈øaid complainant, or did require him to re≈øpite the paiment thereof, or that the ≈øaid E. at the time of her death, left vnto the ≈øaid defendant ≈øufficient of the goods of the ≈øaide W. L. for the contentation and payment of the ≈øaide 18. ‚Ä¢ . as in the ≈øayde bill of complaynt vntruly is ≈øurmi≈øed. And without that, that any other thing compri≈øed in the ≈øaide fained bill of the afore≈øaid I. S. which is materiall to be an≈øwered vnto, and in this an≈øwere not confe≈ø≈øed, auoided, or trauer≈øed, is true. All which matters &c.

div.head: A bill of Complaint vpon certaine griefes, requiring a writ of Certiorari.
div.p:
IN mo≈øt lamentable wi≈øe ≈øheweth vnto your good Lord≈øhip, your Sect'. 142. dailie poore Orator I. W. of London, That where one A. H. of London afore≈øaide Marchant Taylor, borowed of your ≈øaide Orator twelue pounds ≈øterling, to be paied to the ≈øaid &c. at a certaine day betweene them agreed, which day was expired, and the ≈øaid ≈øumme of money not payed, wherfore the ≈øaid A. for that he had not ready money, de≈øired your ≈øuppliant, to take a certaine white broad cloth in pawne, containing fortie yards, cut in peeces, for the ≈øaide twelue pounds, which cloth was ≈øold and deliuered to your ≈øaide Orator by a Bill of ≈øale, wherein the ≈øaid A. H. ≈øtandeth bound, with Condicion in the ≈øame hill declared, That if the ≈øaid Cloth were not redeemed by a day certaine in the ≈øaid bill limitted, that then the ≈øame cloth to be to the only v≈øe of your ≈øaide Orator, for contentation and whole payment of the
≈øaid twelue pounds. Since the which time the ≈øaide A. coun≈øelled your ≈øaid Orator to put forth the ≈øaid cloth to one L. M. of London Shereman, to be died of ≈øeuerall colors for his mo≈øt profit, by the meanes whereof, the ≈øaid W. was contented to take the ≈øaide broad Cloth for the payment of the ≈øaide money, and afterward the ≈øaide cloth was deliuered to the ≈øaide L. M. and within ≈øixe dayes after the deliuery of the ≈øaide Cloth to the ≈øaide L. one R. M. Spaniard affirmed a plaint of debt again≈øt the ≈øaide A. and according to the cu≈øtome of the Citie of London, hath cau≈øed Attachment to be made of the ≈øaide broad Cloth, as debt due by the ≈øaide A. vnto the ≈øaide R. whereas the ≈øaide Cloth is your ≈øaide Orators: Notwith≈øtanding by rea≈øon of the ≈øaide Attachment, your ≈øaide Orator retayned Coun≈øaile in the Guildhall of London, where the matter was at an i≈ø≈øue, whereupon the Iurie was impanelled, ≈øince the which time for the ≈øpace of three Court dayes, your ≈øaide Orator did giue attendance there to haue the ≈øaide matter heard, and the ≈øaide Plaintife and Coun≈øaile would not ≈øuffer the ≈øaide Iurie to appeare, ≈øo long as your ≈øaide Suppliant did apply and pur≈øue his cau≈øe with effect herein. And for that the ≈øaid R. and his coun≈øaile would not proceede in his ≈øaid action, your ≈øaid Orator ≈øuppo≈øed, that it ≈øhould no more be called vpon, by occa≈øion whereof your Orator being about his bu≈øine≈ø≈øe in the countrey, in the meane time, the ≈øaid L. M. with his Coun≈øell (hauing knowledge that your ≈øaid Orator was out of the Citie, and in the Countrey) in≈øtantly laboured the Iurie to appeare in the ab≈øence of your ≈øaide Orator, and by their ≈øubtiltie and craft, the ≈øaide Iurie did appeare, and pa≈ø≈øed again≈øt your ≈øaide Orator, contrarie to all right, Lawe, and good con≈øcience, which ≈øhall be to the great impoueri≈øhment and vndoing of your ≈øayde Orator for euer, vnle≈ø≈øe your good Lord≈øhips lawfull fauour and ≈øuccour be to him ≈øhewed in this behalfe. In con≈øideration whereof, might it therefore plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip to graunt the Queenes writ of Cerciorari to be directed to the Maior and Sheriffes of the Citty of London, commanding them and euery of them by vertue of the ≈øame, to certifie before your good Lord≈øhip in the Queenes mo≈øt honorable Court of Chauncery, at a certaine day by your good Lord≈øhip to be limitted, the ≈øaide attachment, and all the matter concerning the ≈øame, and to examine the ≈øaid matter, and all the whole circum≈øtance thereof, and to ≈øtand to ≈øuch order and direction therein, as ≈øhall ≈øtande with right, equity, and good con≈øcience. And your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhall pray to God for the pre≈øeruation of your good Lord≈øhip long to continue.

div.head: A Bill where a Iurie hath pa≈ø≈øed in a matter wrongfully praying a Cerciorari.
div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe ≈øheweth and complaineth vnto your mo≈øt Honorable Sect'. 143. good Lord≈øhip, your poore ≈øuppliant and continuall Orator P. of W. of the Citty of L. Broker, that whereas one A. M. of the ≈øaid Citty Marchant ≈øtranger, within the ≈øaide City was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of, and in certaine linnen clothes, to the valew of xx. pound ≈øterling, and to your poore ≈øuppliants knowledge then, and as yet as of his owne meere proper goods and chattels, and ≈øo thereof being po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, the ≈øame within the ≈øaid Citty deliuered to your poore Orator being a Broker, ≈øafely to keepe and to ≈øell and marchandi≈øe by the di≈øcretion of your poore ≈øuppliant, to the v≈øe of the ≈øaid A. by force whereof your Orator made ≈øale thereof to certaine per≈øons within the ≈øame City, and the mony, goods, and marchandi≈øes thereof receiued and taken, deliuered vnto the ≈øaid A. And ≈øo it is right honorable Lord that after and ≈øince the ≈øale thereof made, one I. S. Marchant ≈øtranger, pretending a property in the fore≈øaid linnen clothes, hath commenced an action vpon his ca≈øe again≈øt your poore ≈øuppliant in the Guildhall, ≈øet and being within the fore≈øaid City before the Sherifes thereof, and thereupon hath declared that the ≈øaide I. ≈øhould haue lo≈øt tho≈øe goods, and that they came to the hands and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of your poore ≈øuppliant within the ≈øaid city by way of trouer. And furthermore that your poore Orator was ≈øundry times required to make deliuerance thereof to the ≈øaid I. and that refu≈øed, and the ≈øame afterward ≈øold, and the mony thereof receiued conuerted to your orators v≈øe, to which matter one I. D. your poore ≈øuppliants atturney, ra≈øhly without adui≈øement or coun≈øell therein taken, ≈øaid that your poore orator did not ≈øell the ≈øaid clothes, nor any part thereof, and vpon the ≈øame matter, whether any ≈øale thereof was made by your ≈øuppliant or not, an i≈ø≈øue was taken, and the Iurie tried, ≈øworne, and charged, found a ≈øale made by your poore orator of the ≈øaide clothes (as the truth was) nothing regarding to whom the property of the ≈øaide goods was at the time of the ≈øale thereof made, becau≈øe of the plee ≈øo vnadui≈øedly pleaded, it was confe≈ø≈øed in point of iudgement, the property thereof to be in the ≈øaid I. T. and ≈øo it is, right honorable Lord, that the ≈øaid atturney might haue taken an i≈ø≈øue that your ≈øaid orator ≈øold no clothes of the ≈øaide I. becau≈øe of trueth the clothes were the proper clothes of the ≈øaid A. and not the clothes of the ≈øaid I. and ≈øo the Iurie ≈øhould haue tried in whom the propertie was, and becau≈øe the property was not put in i≈ø≈øue, the Iurie had no warranty to enquire thereof, and in ca≈øe they had bin the clothes of the ≈øaid I. as they were not indeed, your poore orator ought not by the order of
the law to haue bin charged, becau≈øe they were deliuered to your Orator by the hands of the fore≈øaide A. to ≈øell, and your Orator did accordingly. And the money, goods, and March andizes thereof receiued, deliuered to the ≈øaid A. and ≈øo if any tre≈øpas or wrong was done to the ≈øaid I. it was done by the ≈øaide A. and not by your ≈øaide Orator, again≈øt whom the ≈øaide I. may take his action. For your poore Orator at the time of the ≈øaide action commenced, neither had the ≈øaide goods in his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, ne any other things in lieu or con≈øideration of the ≈øame goods. And al≈øo there is a cu≈øtome within the ≈øaide Citie, that if any Vphol≈øter or Broker ≈øell any goods within the ≈øame citie to any per≈øon or per≈øons of the ≈øame citie vpon the deliuery of any per≈øon, for, or at the reque≈øt of him hauing witne≈ø≈øe of y‚Ä¢ deliuerie thereof to him made, or bring out the partie who deliuered them vnto him, not being him≈øelfe particeps criminis, ≈øhould be di≈øcharged and not dampnefied, for that his offence doing in making ≈øale thereof. And al≈øo by the order of the common lawes of this Realme, a man comming immediatly to the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the goods, not being partie to the fir≈øt wrong, ≈øhall not be charged in an Action of tre≈øpas, which matters, or any of them, if they had bin pleaded, had bin a ≈øufficient matter of barre, and becau≈øe they were not pleaded, your poore ≈øuppliant could not be receiued to giue them in euidence to the Iury, and ≈øo your poore Orator is like to pay vnto the ≈øaid I. the value of the ≈øaide clothes, the ≈øaid I. hauing no property, right, nor title to the ≈øame, vnle≈ø≈øe your mo≈øt ho. Lord≈øhips fauour be ≈øhewed herein: In con≈øideration whereof, it may plea≈øe your mo≈øt ho. Lord≈øhip the premi≈ø≈øes tenderly con≈øidered, to graunt the Kings mo≈øt gracious writ of Cerciorare, to be directed to the Shirife of the ≈øaide City, commaunding them, and euery of them to certifie before your good Lord≈øhip the whole record of the premi≈ø≈øes depending before them, or either of them in the Kings mo≈øt gracious court of Chauncery, at a certaine day by your good Lord≈øhip to be limitted, and therein further to proceede, and further to graunt the Queenes mo≈øt gracious and ≈øpeedy writs of Subpena to be directed to the ≈øaid I. commanding him per≈øonally to appeare before your good Lord≈øhip in the ≈øaid court of Chauncery at a certaine day, and vnder a certaine paine by your good Lord≈øhip to be limitted therein, to ≈øtand to &c.

div.head: A bill contayning that the plaintife taking vp of a Mercer vpon his credit Silks and Veluets, put his hand to the debt booke of the parcels of the ≈øaid Silks and Veluets, witne≈ø≈øing his debt for the ≈øame: and afterwards the plaintife for the better ≈øecuritie of his ≈øaiddebt made him a bill of his hand for the ≈øame debt: and that the plaintife afterwards at the de≈øire of the Mercer procured his elde≈øt brother to become bound to the ≈øaide Mercer for the payment of the plaintifes ≈øaide debt vpon the Mercers promi≈øe to take no aduantage thereof vntill after the death of the plaintifes father. Afterwards the Mercer dyeth intestate, and the administration of his gods is committed to R. A. by a practi≈øe of the Mercers creditors. The administrator bringeth an accion of debt again≈øt the ≈øaidplaintife vpon his ≈øaid bill of debt: and al≈øo threatneth to ≈øue the plaintife and his brother vpon the ≈øaid booke of parcels, and the bond: and then ≈øheweth that he tendred the debt to the Admini≈øtrator, who refu≈øed the ≈øame, and ≈øo prayeth proces.

opener.salute: To the Right Ho. Sir Io P. Knight, Lord Keeper of the great Seale of England.

div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe complayning ≈øheweth vnto your Ho. Lord≈øhip Sect'. 144. your daily Orator T. D. Gentleman: That whereas your Orator being of late ≈øeruant in hou≈øhold to the right Ho. Sir C. H. Knight of the mo≈øt noble order of the Garter decea≈ø≈øed, late Chancellor of England, hauing then ≈ømall maintenance from I. D. of D. in the Countie of C. E≈øquier his father, did make his e≈øtate knowne to one N. B. of London Mercer now decea≈ø≈øed, being your ≈øaid Orators very neere kin≈øman, who was content to giue your ≈øaid Orator credit for diuers parcels of Silks and Veluets, at ≈øundrie times amounting in the whole to the ≈øomme of 22. l . or there abouts, for the which your Orator did ≈øub≈øcribe his hand to the debt booke of the ≈øaid N. B. wherein the ≈øaid parcels of Silks were ≈øet downe vnder the ≈øame parcels witne≈ø≈øing the ≈øaid debt. And at an other time after that, your ≈øaide Orator did ≈øeale and deliuer vnto him a bill of your Orators hand for his better ≈øecuritie of the payment of the ≈øaid debt. And afterwards becau≈øe your Orator was but a yonger brother, the ≈øaid N. B. de≈øired your Orator to procure his elde≈øt brother P. D. ≈øonne and heire apparant of the ≈øaide I. D. for the better ≈øecuritie of the ≈øaid debt to become bound to the ≈øaid N. B. by Obligation for the payment of the ≈øaid debt, promi≈øing neuerthele≈ø≈øe to take no aduantage of the ≈øaid Obligation, nor to put the ≈øame in ≈øuite during the life of the ≈øaid I. D. whereupon the ≈øaid P. D. at your Orators reque≈øt did become bound to the ≈øaid N. B. by Obligation accordingly, and your Orator did then ≈øeale and deliuer to the ≈øaid P. D. his brother a Counterbond to ≈øaue him harmele≈ø≈øe from
the ≈øaid Obligation. So as the ≈øaid N. B. by the ≈øeuerall meanes afore≈øaid had three ≈øeuerall kinds of a≈ø≈øurances or ≈øpecialties for one and the ≈øelfe≈øame debt, that is to ≈øay his debt booke ≈øub≈øcribed with your Orators hand, a bill of debt ≈øealed and deliuered vnto him by your Orator, and an Obligation ≈øealed and deliuered vnto him by the ≈øaide P. D. And now ≈øo it is if it may plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip that the ≈øaid N. B. is lately decea≈ø≈øed, after who≈øe decea≈ø≈øe the admini≈øtration of his goods and cattels is committed to one R. A. an vnknowne per≈øon that cannot be found who≈øe name is but v≈øed by others in all vncon≈øcionable ≈øuits. For if it may plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, R. S. Alderman of London, R. W. and F. S. pretending them≈øelues to be creditors of the ≈øaid N. B. hauing procured the ≈øaid bill of debt and obligation to be ≈øet ouer vnto them, haue thereupon not onely commenced ≈øuit in the Queenes Maie≈øties Court of Common Pleas at We≈øtmin≈øter, in the name of the ≈øaid R. A. as admini≈øtrator of the goods and cattels of the ≈øaid N. B. again≈øt your ≈øaid Orator vpon his ≈øaid bill of debt of 22. l . but al≈øo do threaten to commence one other ≈øuit again≈øt your ≈øaid Orator vpon the ≈øaid debt booke, and alike ≈øuit again≈øt the ≈øaid P. D. vpon the ≈øaid Obligation. And albeit your ≈øaid Orator haue diuers and ≈øundry times offered and tendered to pay the ≈øaid debt of 22. pound to the ≈øaid admini≈øtrator, with ≈øuch rea≈øonable co≈øts and expences as hath bin by him expended, and be≈øtowed in the ≈øaid ≈øuit at the Common lawe, and is ready to pay the ≈øame. Yet neuerthele≈ø≈øe the ≈øaid R. A. R. S. R. W. and F. S. do refu≈øe to accept thereof. And the ≈øaid R. S. &c. do very hotely pro≈øecute the ≈øaid ≈øuit at the commonlawe in the name of the ≈øaid R. A. contrarie to equitie and con≈øcience, and do procure and cau≈øe the ≈øaide R. A. to ab≈øent him≈øelfe ≈øo as your ≈øaide Orator cannot tell where to finde him to deliuer vnto him any proces to compell him to an≈øwere to his ≈øaid vncon≈øcionable dealing, and yet the ≈øaid ≈øuit at the Common lawe is ≈øtill pro≈øecuted in his name by the meanes and procurement and at the co≈øts and charges in lawe of the ≈øaid R. S. &c. or by ≈øome of them who haue procured the ≈øaid debts to be a≈ø≈øigned and ≈øet our vnto them as is afore≈øaid. In con≈øideration whereof, and for that it is again≈øt all con≈øcience to take aduantage of the ≈øaid treble a≈ø≈øurances made for one ≈øelfe≈øame debt: And for that your ≈øaid Orator is remedile≈ø≈øe therein by the due cour≈øe of the common lawes of this realme, and for that your ≈øaid Orator is readie to pay the principall debt being 22. pound, together with rea≈øonable co≈øts of ≈øuit. May it therefore plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip to graunt vnto your ≈øaid Orator the Queenes Maie≈øties mo≈øt gracious writs of Subpena to be directed to the ≈øaide R. A. R. S. &c. commaunding them and euery of them to appeare per≈øonally before your good Lord≈øhip in her Maie≈øties high
court of Chauncery, at a certaine day, and vnder a certaine paine therein to be by your good Lord≈øhip limitted, then and there to an≈øwere to the premi≈ø≈øes, and to ≈øtand vnto and abide ≈øuch further order and direction therein as to your good Lord≈øhip ≈øhall ≈øeeme to ≈øtand with iu≈øtice and equitie, and your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhall dayly pray &c.

div.head: A bill contayning that a Widow ≈øeazed in fee of three me≈ø≈øes &c. thereof enfeoffed diuers per≈øons in fee for the performance of her la≈øt will and testament, and by the ≈øame ≈øhe deui≈øed the ≈øaid mea≈ø≈øes &c. to her ≈øonne in taile generall with diuers remainders ouer and dyed, That the deui≈øee dyed, hauing i≈ø≈øue the plaintife. That the feoffment and will is come to the defendants hands. That by cullour thereof he hath entred and expul≈øed the plaintife, and hath made diuers ≈øecret estates to diuers vnknowne per≈øons to defraude the plaintife of his apt remedie by the common lawe, and ≈øo prayeth proces again≈øt the defendant.

opener.salute: To the Right Honorable Sir T. E. Knight, Lord Keeper of the great Seale of England.

div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe complayning ≈øheweth vnto your good Lord≈øhip Sect. 145. your dayly Orator I. B. labourer. That whereas R. G. Widowe was lawfully ≈øeazed in her deme≈øne as of fee of and in three me≈ø≈øes twentie acres of land, meadow, lea≈øowe and pa≈øture, with the appurtenances, ≈øet, lying, and being in M. in the Countie of B. And the ≈øaid R. G. being ≈øo ≈øeazed of all the premi≈ø≈øes, did of the ≈øame about fortie yeares la≈øt pa≈øt enfeoffe certaine per≈øons, To haue and hould to them and their heires to the v≈øe and performance of the la≈øt will and te≈øtament of the ≈øaide R. G. and by the ≈øame her will deui≈øed all the premi≈ø≈øes or the v≈øe thereof to her ≈øonne W. B. and to the heires of his body lawfully begotten, with diuers remainders ouer and dyed, by and after who≈øe death, the ≈øaid W. B. into the premi≈ø≈øes entred, and was thereof lawfully ≈øeazed in his demea≈øne as of fee tayle generall by force of the gift afore≈øaid. And the ≈øaid W. B. ≈øo being ≈øeazed of the premi≈ø≈øes died of ≈øuch an e≈øtate thereof ≈øea≈øed, by an after who≈øe death the ≈øame premi≈ø≈øes did di≈øcend and come to your ≈øaid Orator, as ≈øonne and heire of the body of the ≈øaid W. B. by force of the deui≈øe afore≈øaide, by rea≈øon whereof your ≈øaide Orator in the premi≈ø≈øes entred, and was thereof ≈øeazed in his deme≈øne as of fee by force of the ≈øaide gift in taking the i≈ø≈øues and profits accordingly, vntill of late, that is to ≈øay, about foure yeares la≈øt pa≈øt, that as well the ≈øaide deede of feoffment and la≈øt will and te≈øtament afore≈øaide, as al≈øo diuers other euidences, charters, e≈øcripts and miniments concerning the premi≈ø≈øes, are by ca≈øuall meanes come to the handes, cu≈øtodie, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of one R. W.
of S. afore≈øayde in the ≈øayde Countie yeoman, who by cullour of hauing of them, hath not onely entred into the premi≈ø≈øes, and thereof expul≈øed your ≈øayde Orator, but al≈øo hath contriued diuers ≈øecret e≈øtates to diuers and ≈øundry per≈øons to your Orator vnknowne in purpo≈øe to defraude and delay your ≈øayde Orator to his apt action and remedie by the cour≈øe of the common lawes of this realme, for recouerye of the pr ‚Ä¢ mi≈ø≈øes, to your Orators vtter vndoing, and di≈øinheritance for euer. And for as much as your ≈øayde Orator knoweth not the certayne number, nor the dates and contents of the ≈øayde Euidences, Charters, E≈øcripts, or Miniments, nor yet wherein the ≈øame be contayned, whether in bagge, or boxe, ≈øealed, or vn≈øealed, or in che≈øt locked or vnlocked, by rea≈øon whereof your ≈øayde Orator is clearely without all remedye for the recouerie thereof by the ordinarie cour≈øe of the common lawes of this Realme. In tender con≈øideration whereof, may it plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, the premi≈ø≈øes con≈øidered, to graunt vnto your ≈øayde Orator the Queenes Maie≈øties mo≈øt gracious writ of Subpena, to be directed vnto the ≈øayde R. W. commaunding „Äà‚óä„Äâ thereby per≈øo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ lly to appeare before your good Lord≈øhip in the Queenes Maie≈øties high court of Chauncerpe at a ≈øhort day, and ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ der a certayne payne therein to be limited, then and there to an≈øwere to the „Äà‚óä„Äâ , and to abide ≈øuch order and direction therein, as to „Äà‚óä„Äâ and iu≈øtice ≈øhall appertayne. And your ≈øaid poore Orator ≈øhall dayly pray as ‚Ä¢ e is bounden for the health and long life of your good Lord≈øhip, with all increa≈øe of honour to Gods will and good plea≈øure.

div.head: A bill again≈øt two for the deliuerie of he ‚Ä¢ reloomes or principalls to the plaintife being ≈øonne and heire, according to the custome of the Countie Pallantine of Chester.

opener.salute: To the Right Honorable Sir Nicholas Bacon Knight, Lord Keeper of the great ≈øeale of England.

div.p:
COmplayning, ≈øheweth vnto your good Lord≈øhip your dayly Orator Sect. 14 ‚Ä¢ . I. S. of Lincolnes I ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Ge ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , ≈øonne and heire of I. S. of D. within the Countie of ‚Ä¢ That where as the ≈øayde I. S. was in his life time lawfully po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of and in diuers goods and Chattels as of his owne proper goods, that is to ≈øay, Plate, Iewels, hou≈øhold ≈øtuffe, bea≈øts, cattaile, hor≈øes, and other manner of goods, amounting to the value of fiue hundred pound or neere thereabouts, and ≈øo being thereof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, made his te≈øtament and la≈øt will, ordeyning thereof Elizabeth then his Wife, and nowe Wife to B. P. his ≈øole executrix, and ≈øhortly after dyed, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the premi≈ø≈øes as afore≈øayde
within the ≈øaid Countie of C. Immediatly after who≈øe death, the ≈øaid E. did take vpon her the admini≈øtration of the ≈øaid goods and other the premi≈ø≈øes accordingly, by vertue whereof ≈øhe was thereof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed accordingly. But ≈øo it is and plea≈øe your Honor, that the cu≈øtome of all the countrie within the ≈øaid Countie of C. is and time out of minde of man to the contrarie hath beene, that if any per≈øon or per≈øons being po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of goods and cattels as of his owne proper goods and cattels and dye thereof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, that the next heire to him that ≈øo dyeth po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed ≈øhall haue the be≈øt and principall thing of euerie ≈øort and kinde of the ≈øaid goods and cattels for and in the name of the principals and heire Lomes, by force & vertue whereof your Orator being the ≈øonne and heire of the ≈øaid I. S. was after the death of the ≈øaide I. S. iu≈øtlie entituled to a great part of the ≈øaid goods and cattels amounting at the lea≈øt in value to 200. pound or neere thereabouts, by rea≈øon whereof, and for that your ≈øaid Orator was at the time of the death of his ≈øaide father vnder age of xxi. yeares, and yet is and in ward to the Queenes Maie≈øtie, and hauing the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of ≈øo much of all the ≈øaid goods and cattels as to your ≈øaid Orator did appertayne, and of right belong by vertue of the cu≈øtome afore≈øaid, being verie neere to the value of two hundred pound by deliuerie of the ≈øaide E. in her Widowhood immediatly after the death of the ≈øaide I. S. your ≈øaide Orator did incontinently thereupon deliuer the ≈øame to the ≈øaid E. to be ≈øafely by her kept to your ≈øaide Orators v≈øe, and to be in like maner ≈øafely redeliuered to your ≈øaide Orator at ≈øuch time or times as by your ≈øaide Orator or his a≈ø≈øignes ≈øhe ≈øhould be thereunto required ≈øithence which ≈øaid redeliuerie made by your ≈øaid Orator to the ≈øaid E. as afore≈øaid the ≈øaid E. hath taken to hu≈øband one B. P. Gen ‚Ä¢ , by rea≈øon whereof all the ≈øaid goods, cattels, and other the premi≈ø≈øes were and did come after the ≈øaid entermariage into the hands and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øame B. P. which ≈øaid E. ≈øithens the ≈øaid deliuerie made by your ≈øaid Orator vnto her as afore≈øaide before the day of entermariage, hath vtterly refu≈øed to make any redeliuerie of the ≈øaid goods and cattels ≈øo by your ≈øaid Orator to her deliuered as afore≈øaid, or yet to make any ≈øati≈øfaction thereof to your ≈øaid Orator, and the ≈øaid B. and E. alwaies ≈øithens the ≈øaide entermariage haue refu≈øed and yet do refu≈øe to redeliuer the ≈øame, or yet to make any ≈øati≈øfaction therefore to your ≈øaid Orator, notwith≈øtanding many lawfull and gentle reque≈øts to you and either of them made in that behalfe by your ≈øaid Orator contrarie to all right, equitie and con≈øcience. In tender con≈øideration whereof, and fora≈ømuch as your ≈øaid Orator doth not know or remember the certaine or preci≈øe perticulars or valew of the ≈øaid goods and cattels which of right do belong to your ≈øaid Orator, and deliuered by your ≈øaid Orator as afore≈øaid, by rea≈øon
of your ≈øaid Orators then tender age being not then of di≈øcretion to haue the cu≈øtodie and rule thereof, and ≈øo remedile≈ø≈øe by the order of the common lawe for the recouerie thereof, or of any part thereof, or to haue any ≈øati≈øfaction made to your ≈øaid Orator by the ≈øaid‚ñ™ B. and E. or by either of them. It may therefore plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip the premi≈ø≈øes con≈øidered, to graunt the Queenes Maie≈øties writs of Subpena to be directed to the ≈øaide B. P. and E. his wife, commaunding them and either of them to appeare before your good Lord≈øhip in the Queenes Maie≈øties mo≈øt honorable court of Chauncery at We≈øtmin≈øter, then and there to an≈øwere to the premi≈ø≈øes, and therein to ≈øtand to abide and performe ≈øuch order and direction as to your good Lord≈øhip ≈øhall be thought to ≈øtand and be con≈øonant to equitie and good con≈øcience, and your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhall dayly pray to God for your good Lord≈øhip in health and honor long to continue.

div.head: A bill (by a noble man) containing that the plaintife tooke vp vpon his credit Veluets and Silks of the defendant at a deere rate, and gaue his owne bond with ≈øuerties for the payment of the ≈øame: and that afterwards he tooke vpon his credit of him more Veluets and Silks as the like deere rate, and being within age knowledged a ≈øtatute ≈øtaple to the defendant for all his whole debt, vpon his promi≈øe to deliuer to the plaintife his obligation which he had made for his fir≈øt debt to be cancelled, the plaintife allowing intere≈øt to the defendant for the forbearance, notwithstanding the deere prices and rate he bought the ≈øtuffe at for which the ≈øaid debt grew, and then ≈øheweth that he paid not his debt at the day contained in the ≈øtatute ≈øtaple, and that the defendant threatneth not only to ≈øue the ≈øaid bond, but al≈øo to ≈øue execution of the ≈øaid ≈øtatute again≈øt him, and prayeth deliuerie or relea≈øe of his obligation and proces again≈øt the defendant to an≈øwere the bill.

opener.salute: To the Right honorable Sir Chri≈øtopher Hatton, of the mo≈øt noble order of the Garter, Knight, Lord Chauncellour of England.

div.p:
COmplayning ≈øheweth vnto your good Lord≈øhip E. S. Lord D. Sect. 147. That whereas he the ≈øaid Lord D. during ≈øuch time as he was vnder the age of 21. yeares at ≈øundrie times had and bought of one I. L. Citizen and Mercer of London diuers parcels or peeces of Veluet, Silke, and ≈øuch like at exce≈ø≈øiue prices, and not hauing then readie money to pay for the ≈øame, the ≈øaide Lord D. together with one R. S. Gen ‚Ä¢ and others did enter into ≈øundrie bonds to the ≈øaide I. L. for the payment thereof at ≈øeuerall dayes after, alwayes allowing vnto the ≈øaid I. L. ouer and be≈øides the exce≈ø≈øiue prices which he was to pay for
the ≈øame Veluets and Silks further con≈øideration, or rather as it may be ≈øaid v≈øurie for the forbearing thereof till the time of payment. And afterwards the ≈øaid Lord D. during the time of his minoritie afore≈øaid, had and did buy other parcels of Veluets, Silks, and ≈øuch like of the ≈øaid I. L. at like exce≈ø≈øiue prices, which likewi≈øe the ≈øaid Lord D. did not then pay for the prices or ≈øummes of money whereunto the ≈øaid parcels of Veluets, Silks, and ≈øuch like la≈øtlie had and bought after the like exce≈ø≈øiue prices and rates, together with the ≈øaide prices or ≈øummes of money before due for the other parcels formerly had and bought by the ≈øaid Lord D. together with coÃÑ≈øideration or rather v≈øurie for the forbearing of and for the payment thereof till a certaine time then agreed vpon betweene the ≈øaid Lord D. and him the ≈øaid I. L. did amount & come to the ≈øumme of 500. pound, for the payment of which ≈øaid ≈øumme of 500. pound at the time agreed vpon he the ≈øaid Lord D. at and vpon the motion, meanes and intreatie of the ≈øaid I. L. did during the time of the minoritie of him the ≈øaid Lord D. become bounden by one ≈øtatute ≈øtaple vnto the ≈øaid I. L. in the ≈øumme of one thou≈øand pounds of good and lawfull money of England, taking the word and promi≈øe only of the ≈øaid I. L. to deliuer vnto him the ≈øaid Lord D. or his ≈øaide ≈øureties the ≈øaide bonds which before he the ≈øaid Lord D. and his ≈øaid ≈øuerties had entred into to the ≈øaid I. L. or otherwi≈øe that he the ≈øaide Iohn ≈øhould and would cancell and make voyde the ≈øame, ≈øo as thereby or by rea≈øon of any of the ≈øaide bonds the ≈øaid Lord D. nor any of his ≈øaide ≈øuerties ≈øhould be in any wi≈øe ≈øued, vexed, troubled, or charged. But now ≈øo it is, and it may plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, that the ≈øaid I. L. although he hath beene thereunto in mo≈øt gentle and friendly manner earne≈øtly reque≈øted and de≈øired by the ≈øaide Lord D. the ≈øaide R. S. and other the ≈øaide ≈øureties of the ≈øaid Lord D. to deliuer vnto them the ≈øaid bonds to by them made, and entred into the ≈øaid I. L. as is afore≈øaid, or otherwi≈øe to cancell and make voyd the ≈øame, yet that to do the ≈øaid I. L. hath vtterly refu≈øed and denyed, and ≈øtill doth denye and refu≈øe to do the ≈øame. But contrary to his ≈øaide word and promi≈øe as afore≈øaid made and giuen vnto the ≈øaid Lord D. for the redeliuerie thereof, or otherwi≈øe to cancell and make voyd the ≈øame bonds, doth now dayly threaten to put the ≈øame in ≈øuit at the Common lawe, again≈øt the ≈øureties of him the ≈øaid Lord D. or el≈øe alreadye hath ≈øo done contrary to all right, equitie, and good con≈øcience. And be≈øides this, becau≈øe the ≈øayd Lord D. did not pay vnto hym the ≈øayd I. L. the ≈øayd ≈øumme of fiue hundred pound at the time limited for the paiment thereof, which in very trueth he the ≈øaid Lord D. could not well do vnle≈ø≈øe he ≈øhould haue made ≈øale of his lands to his great di≈øhonour and lo≈ø≈øe. And notwith≈øtanding that he the ≈øaide Lord D. hath
≈øought and made meanes to the ≈øaide I. L. to compound with him in ≈øome rea≈øonable ≈øort, and to accept his money at rea≈øonable dayes, ≈øuch as he the ≈øaid Lord D. could and might be well able to ≈øati≈øfye and pay the ≈øame, the rather con≈øidering his great intere≈øt allowed in recompence for the forbearing of time, and giuing day of payment and the exce≈ø≈øiue prices for which he ≈øould the ≈øame Silks, Veluets, and ≈øuch like to the ≈øaid Lord D. yet he the ≈øaid I. L. hath done and dayly doth ≈øeeke and go about to ≈øue execucion, and to take the benefit of the ≈øaid Statute of one thou≈øand pounds again≈øt the ≈øaid Lord D. contrarie to all equitie and good con≈øcience. The premi≈ø≈øes therefore tenderly con≈øidered, and for as much as the ≈øaid Lord D. the ≈øaid R. S. and others the ≈øaid ≈øuerties of him the ≈øaid Lord D. or any of them, cannot pleade any good or ≈øufficient plea in auoydance or di≈øcharge of the ≈øaid Bonds and Statutes, nor of any of them, whereof the ≈øaid I. L. mo≈øt vncon≈øcionably ≈øeeketh and goeth about to ≈øue, procure and take the penaltie, execucion and forfeiture again≈øt him the ≈øaid Lord D. and his ≈øureties by the ordinarie cour≈øe of the common lawes of this Realme, and the rather, for that al≈øo the ≈øaid Lord D. is and will be readie for the further di≈øcharge of the ≈øaid K. S. and others his ≈øaid ≈øureties, to ≈øati≈øfye and pay vnto him the ≈øaid I. L. the ≈øaid ≈øumme of 500. pound at ≈øuch dayes and times, and in ≈øuch maner and forme as to your good Lord≈øhip ≈øhall in equitie and right ≈øeeme meete and conuenient. It may therefore plea≈øe your good L. to graunt her Maie≈øties mo≈øt gracious writ of Subpena, to be directed to the ≈øaide I. L. commaunding him thereby at a certaine day, and vnder a certaine paine therein to be limited, per≈øonallie to appeare before your good Lord≈øhip in her Maie≈øties high court of Chauncerie, then and there to aun≈øwere to the premi≈ø≈øes, and to ≈øhew cau≈øe why he the ≈øaid I. L. ≈øhould not redeliuer the ≈øaide bonds to the ≈øaide Lord D. and his ≈øaide ≈øureties, or el≈øe to cancell and make voyd the ≈øame, or otherwi≈øe thereof to relea≈øe, di≈øcharge, and ≈øaue harmele≈ø≈øe the ≈øaide Lord D. his ≈øaid ≈øureties, as in right and equitie it behoueth: and further to ≈øtand to and abide ≈øuch order and direction therein, as to your good Lord≈øhip and the ≈øaid honorable Court ≈øhall ≈øeeme be≈øt to ≈øtand with equitie and good con≈øcience.

div.head: The Aun≈øwere of I. L. defendant to the Bill of complaint of Ed. Lo. D. complaynant.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid defendant by prote≈øtation not acknowledging or confe≈ø≈øing Sect. 148. any matter or thing in the ≈øaide bill of complaint conteyned materiall for the ≈øaid debt to be an≈øwered vnto to be true in ≈øuch maner and forme as in and by the ≈øaid bill of complaint is ≈øet forth & alledged. For aun≈øwere ≈øaith that the ≈øaid complaynant about foure yeares pa≈øt
at ≈øeuerall times had and bought of the ≈øaid defendant diuers parcels of Silks, Veluets, and Wares, amounting vnto the ≈øumme of 159. pound foure ≈øhillings fiue pence, or there abouts, all which parcels the ≈øaid defendant did ≈øell vnto the ≈øaid complaynant for and at rea≈øonable prices, con≈øidering the dayes of payment, and for the true payment of ≈øome part of the ≈øaid ≈øumme, he the ≈øaid Lord D. together with the ≈øaid R. S. in the ≈øaid bill of complaynt named, and one D. C. being then the ≈øaid complaynants ≈øeruants, did become bound to the ≈øaid defendant by two Obligations which they forfeited. And long afterwards that is to ≈øay in the month of May 1588. the ≈øaide Lord D. hauing occa≈øion to v≈øe other nece≈ø≈øaryes for him≈øelfe and his Wife, and hauing deteyned the afore≈øaid ≈øumme of 159. pound foure ≈øhillings fiue pence from the defendant a long time did in the ≈øaid month of May 1588. in re≈øpect of the ≈øaid time pa≈øt allow the ≈øayd defendant for con≈øideration but 26. pound 13. ≈øhillings. And in the ≈øaid moneth of May the ≈øaide complaynant at his earne≈øt reque≈øt had a new ≈øupplye of wares amounting to 73. pound fifteene ≈øhillings foure pence, and did then accept of and acknowledge certayne parcels had to his v≈øe by the ≈øayd Chri≈øtofer≈øon, to the value of 3. l . 17. sÃÑ. 9. d . which foure ≈øummes do amount to 255. pound, for all which ≈øaid debt the complaynant gaue his owne Obligation to the ≈øaid defendant endorced with condition for the payment thereof the 24. day of Iune 1588. After which bond for 255. l . taken & before the ≈øame was due, viz. about the la≈øt day of y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid month of May 1588. the ≈øaide complaynant ≈øtanding in neede both of money & other nece≈ø≈øary furniture for him≈øelfe, his wife, & hou≈øe, earne≈øtly did intreate the ≈øaid defendaÃÑt to lend vnto him the ≈øaid complaynant the ≈øumme of 50. l . in readie money, which he prote≈øted to be for pro≈øecuting an earne≈øt ≈øuit he had again≈øt one Sir I. L. Knight, as this defendant remembreth, which although y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid defendaÃÑt could then performe hardly, yet he the ≈øaid defendaÃÑt made meanes for ≈øo much money, & did lend the ≈øame 50. l to the ≈øaid complainant for 12. moneths, vpon allowance of 5. l . for the ≈øame for the ≈øaid time & no more. And al≈øo further did mo≈øt earne≈øtly de≈øire & intreat him the ≈øaid def. to ≈øell vnto him ≈øo much Silks, Veluets, & Wares to furni≈øh his then pre≈øent want, as ≈øhould make the fore≈øaid ≈øumme of 255. l . by his bond, & the 50. l . lent in ready money, with the 5. l . for intere≈øt therof as afore≈øaid, amounting to the ≈øumme of 503. l . and thereupon the ≈øaid def. deliuered, & cau≈øed to be deliuered to the ≈øaid p l or his a≈ø≈øignes about the ≈øaid la≈øt day of May & in Iune following the ≈øaid Silks, Veluets, & Wares at rea≈øonable pri≈øes, coÃÑ≈øidering the time he gaue for paymeÃÑt of his money due for the ≈øame to the value of Clxxxx. l . 17. sÃÑ. 4. d . which made vp all the former ≈øummes 500. l . 17. sÃÑ. 4. d . And for paiment of the ≈øaid ≈øumme of 500. l .
parcell of y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid debt of 500. l . 17. sÃÑ. 4. d . the ≈øaid compl did knowledge to the ≈øaid defend a recognizance or bond obligatorie of the nature of a ≈øtatute ≈øtaple of 1000. l . in the ≈øaid bill of compl mencioned, vpoÃÑ which ≈øtatute knowledged the ≈øaid defend . deliuered to the ≈øaide compl to be cancelled the fore≈øaid bond made by y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid compl to the ≈øaid defend for paiment of 255. l . And ≈øhortly after the knowledging of y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid ≈øtatute, that is to ≈øay about the ≈øpace of 4. or 5. weekes after, & long before the time limited for the paiment of y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid defend principall debt of 500 l . the ≈øaid compl purpo≈øing to defeate the ≈øaid defend of his ≈øaid iu≈øt & due debt, did pur≈øue a writ of Audita querela, ≈øuppo≈øing him≈øelf thereby to be within the age of 21. yeares, both then & at the time of the knowledging of the ≈øaid ≈øtatute, vpon which writ after the ≈øame was returned into the court of common pleas, & before the ≈øaid defend had notice or vnder≈øtanding of the ≈øame, the ≈øaid compl and others the ≈øolicitors of the cau≈øe after y‚Ä¢ he was in≈øpected & viewed by the Iu≈øtices of the ≈øame court, did produce or cau≈øe to be produced 2. per≈øons or witne≈ø≈øes before the ≈øaid Iu≈øtices to be depo≈øed that the allegacion & ≈øurmi≈øe of the ≈øaid Audita querela was true, viz. that the ≈øaid compl was then and at the knowledging of the ≈øaide ≈øtatute vnder the age of 21. yeares, which witne≈ø≈øes were examined and depo≈øed accordingly in the behalfe of the ≈øaid compl before the ≈øaid defend had any knowledge or vnder≈øtanding of the ≈øaid compl proceeding therein, and before any writ or Scirifacias was awarded and taken forth to warne the ≈øaid defendant of the ≈øaid ≈øuit, as by the ≈øaide depo≈øitions and proceedings therein remayning of Record in the ≈øaid court of Common pleas, whereunto the ≈øaid defendant for certaintie of the time doth referre him≈øelfe more certainely doth appeare, which ≈øaid ≈øuit of Audita querela for the auoyding of the ≈øaid ≈øtatute the ≈øaid complaynant by his ≈øolicitors & ≈øeruants did mo≈øt earne≈øtly follow vpon a bare pretence that the ≈øaid compl wanted ≈øome fewe moneths of the age of 21. yeares, for maintenance of which ≈øaid ≈øtatute the ≈øaid defend was called in by proces & did pleade thereunto, after which plea pleaded, and after the ≈øaid defend had bin drawne into great charges & expences for the defence of the ≈øaid ≈øtatute & cau≈øe, the ≈øaid compl and his Councell ≈øollicitors, Attorney, or ≈øome of them, ≈øeeing no likelyhood to preuaile in that cour≈øe, did become non≈øuit, & without any regard had of the penaltie thereof, did faile and neglect to pay to the ≈øaid defendant his ≈øaid principall debt of fiue hundred pound at the dayes & times wherein the ≈øame was limited & appointed to be paid by a writing of defeazance made between the ≈øaid compl & defend touching the penaltie of the ≈øaid ≈øtatute, the ≈øame daies of paiment or ≈øome of them being now expired 18. moneths pa≈øt and more, and yet the whole debt ≈øtill vnpaid vnto the ≈øaid defendant, for payment whereof,
the ≈øaid defendant hath and doth keepe the ≈øaid ≈øtatute and the fir≈øt two bonds wherein the ≈øaide complaynant with his men are bound as his ≈øureties as afore≈øaid for payment of part of the ≈øaid principall debt, being this defendants own proper goods as both by lawe and con≈øcience the ≈øaid defendant thinketh he may lawfullie do. And yet neuerthele≈ø≈øe the ≈øaid defendant further ≈øaith, that if y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid coÃÑplaynant will forthwith pay vnto him the ≈øaide defendant the ≈øaid ≈øumme of 500. pound being his principall and iu≈øt debt, together with the charges he hath bin put vnto, and con≈øideration after the v≈øuall rate of ten pound for the hundreth, like as the defendant him≈øelfe doth pay to others for the long time the ≈øaid defendant hath forborne his ≈øaid debt, he the ≈øaide defendant will forgoe the penaltie of the ≈øaide ≈øtatute, and will deliuer the ≈øame ≈øtatute and the ≈øaid bonds to the ≈øaid complaynant, without that that the ≈øaid defendant did ≈øell vnto the ≈øaid complaynant any peece or peeces of Veluet or Silke at the ≈øeuerall times in the bill mencioned, or any other time or any other thing at any exce≈ø≈øiue or vnrea≈øonable price the dayes of payment con≈øidered. Or that the ≈øaid complaynant did ouer and be≈øides the „Äà‚óä„Äâ price of any ≈øuch thing allow and pay to the ≈øaide defendant any further con≈øideration or v≈øurie for the forbearing thereof till the time of payment otherwi≈øe then is before truly layd downe in this aun≈øwere. Or that the ≈øaide complaynant and the ≈øaide R. S. or any other did enter into any more bounds for any the ≈øummes in the ≈øaid bill mencioned to the ≈øaide defendant then ≈øuch as before are confe≈ø≈øed to the knowledge of this defendant. And without that the ≈øaid complaynant did at the intreatie of the ≈øaid defendant during his the ≈øaid complaynants minoritie enter into the ≈øaid ≈øtatute in the bill mentioned to the knowledge of this defendant, but vpon the importunate reque≈øt and intreatie of the ≈øaide plaintife to ≈øupplie his wants as afore≈øaid, the ≈øaid defendant was content to accept of his ≈øaid ≈øtatute, not being able to giue better a≈ø≈øurance as the ≈øaide defendant required. Or that the ≈øaid defendant did then or at any other time promi≈øe to the ≈øaide complaynant or his ≈øaid ≈øureties in the bill mencioned any the bonds by them or any of them entred into to y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid defendaÃÑt for or touching the ≈øaide debt as he now remembreth or any part thereof, other then the ≈øaid obligacions which the ≈øaid defendant did redeliuer to the plaintife to be cancelled as afore≈øaid, or did promi≈øe to cancell or make void the ≈øame in manner and forme as in the ≈øaid bill of complaint is ≈øurmi≈øed to the remembrance of this defendant. And without that that the ≈øaid complaynant or any other for him did require the redeliuery of the ≈øaid bonds as this defendant remembreth, or that there is any cau≈øe or rea≈øon why the ≈øaid complaynant ≈øhould make any ≈øuch reque≈øt or the ≈øaid defendant to make any ≈øuch promi≈øe vntill his ≈øaid
debt be paid. And without that that the ≈øaid compl hath or doth ≈øeeke to make any rea≈øonable compo≈øition with the ≈øaid defend for or touching the ≈øaid debt, or any part thereof, but rather hath endeuoured to defeate the ≈øaid defend of his ≈øaid debt. And therefore he the ≈øaid defend hopeth that the ≈øaid compl ≈øhall not haue or receiue any fauour in this honorable Court again≈øt the ≈øaid defend , ≈øeeing that the ≈øaid defend de≈øireth nothing els but his principall, with rea≈øonable recoÃÑpence for the great wrong & iniurie the ≈øaid compl hath done, both in putting him to great charges & expences, & by the long withholding & deteining of the ≈øaid debt as afore≈øaid, without that that the ≈øaid defend hath hetherunto taken or recouered y‚Ä¢ penalties of y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid ≈øtatute or bonds, or any of theÃÑ, or that the ≈øaid compl' is or hath ≈øhewed him≈øelfe at any time readie to ≈øati≈ø ‚Ä¢ ye the ≈øaid debt vnto the ≈øaid defend , or any part thereof in manner & forme as in the ≈øaide bill of complaynt is alleaged. And without that that any other matter or thing &c.

div.head: A Bill exhibited again≈øt a noble man, & again≈øt diuers tenants & farmers, and officers of diuers mannors, contayning, that the noble man for his debt due to the plaintif became bouÃÑd in a ≈øtatute ≈øtaple of 1200 li. and for that the debt was not paid at the day it was due, the plaintife extended diuers manors & lands which the noble man had, and was ≈øea≈øed of at the time he knowledged the ≈øaid ≈øtatute, and had ≈øould the ≈øame before the time of the extent to diuers per≈øons, and vpon a Liberate to the Sherife, had the ≈øame mannors & laÃÑds deliuered vnto him to hold in extent till his debt were ≈øati≈øfied: Afterwards vpon the noble mans ≈øuit to the Lord Chaunce llor, and vpoÃÑ the Lord Chauncellors reque≈øt to the plaintife he was contented to forbeare the taking of the profits of the lands extended, & to referre the hearing & ending of the matter touching his debt to two thereunto appointed by the Lord Chauncellor, who heard and ended the matter, the which end afterwards the noble man refu≈øed to performe, whereupon the plaint if went about to take the benefit of his extent, & to keepe Courts, and vnder≈øtand what lands, and how the tenants held, and what rents & ≈øeruices they paid for the ≈øame, but could not performe his purpo≈øe therein, for the tenants & the noble man had the Courtrowles in their keeping, and the lea≈ø≈øes, rentals, &c. and would not let him ≈øee the ≈øame, and that the noble man refu≈øed to ≈øuffer the plaintife to enter into the manors & lands extended, or to keepe any Courts, and would not ≈øuffer the tenaÃÑts to pay the plaintife any of the rents or ≈øeruices due for the ≈øame manors, or to declare vnto him what the ≈øame rents and ≈øeruices were. And then the plaintife prayeth that the tenants, occupiers, and farmors of the ≈øaid manors may vpon their oathes bring forth their lea≈ø≈øes, & declare what lands they hold, and what rents & ≈øeruices euery of them pay. And that all the defendants may ≈øhewe to the plaintife the Courtro ‚Ä¢ les, rentals, books o ‚Ä¢ ≈øuruay, field books & terrars in their cu≈øtodie, and ≈øo prayeth proces again≈øt all the defendants.

opener.salute: To the Right Honorable Sir Chri≈øtopher Hatton of the mo≈øt noble order of the Garter Knight, Lord Chancellor of England.

div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe complayning ≈øheweth to your good Lord≈øhip Sect. 149. your dayly Orator I. L. Citizen and Clothworker of London. That whereas the Ho. Ed. Lord M. Baron of R. the la≈øt day of December in the 26. yeare of the raigne of our ≈øoueraigne Lady Queene Elizabeth, before Sir Chri≈øtopher Wray Knight, Lord chiefe Iu≈øtice of the pleas before her highnes to be holden, did acknowledge him≈øelfe to owe to your Orator the ≈øumme of MCC. of lawfull engli≈øh money by his recognizance in the nature of an e≈øtatute ≈øtaple, with a defeazance thereupon made for the true payment of diuers ≈øeuerall ≈øummes of money at ≈øundrie ≈øeuerall dayes now long ≈øithence pa≈øt. And whereas likewi≈øe the ≈øaide Ed.
