Lord M. was and ≈øtoode iu≈øtly indebted to your ≈øaide Orator in diuers other ≈øummes of money by ohter bonds, as al≈øo by your Orators booke, for diuers wares taken vp of your Orator for the v≈øe of the ≈øaide Lord Mo. And whereas al≈øo Tho. P. E≈øquier, brother of the ≈øaid Lord Mo. ≈øtood indebted & did owe to your ≈øaid Orator other certaine ≈øummes of money, for the paimeÃÑt wherof the ≈øaid Lord Mo. did vndertake, and did make to your ≈øaid Orator many ≈øeuerall & ≈øundrie promi≈øes, the which (as yet) he hath in no ≈øort performed. And whereas the ≈øaid Lord Mo. at the time of the knowledging of the fore≈øaid ≈øtatute ≈øtaple was lawfully ≈øeazed in his deme≈øne as of Fee, of & in the mannors of H. W. A. & B. with two faires twice in the yeare, with one market holden euery weeke at H. afore≈øaid, with the hundred of F. with euery of their appurtenances, ≈øcituate, lying & being in the Countie of Norffolke, and of and in the manor of H. with their appurtenances in the ≈øaid Countie of Norffolke: which ≈øaid mannors & other the premi≈ø≈øes afore≈øaid the ≈øaid Lord Mo. by lawfull a≈ø≈øurance & conueyance in the Lawe, did bargaine, ≈øell, conuey, & a≈ø≈øure the ≈øame, with all and euery their appurtenances what≈øoeuer to one Tho. Lord of H. in the ≈øaide Countie of Norffolke E≈øquier, and to his heires for euer, by vertue of which conueyance and a≈ø≈øurance the ≈øaid Tho. L. was and is yet ≈øeazed of the ≈øaide ≈øeuerall mannors, and other the afore≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes in his deme≈øne, as of Fee. And whereas the ≈øaid Edw. Lord Mo. was likewi≈øe ≈øeazed in his deme≈øne as of Fee at the time of the knowledging of the ≈øaide ≈øtatute ≈øtaple of and in the mannors of S. M. and W. with the aduou≈øons of Sw. Mo. and Wo. with their appurtenances in the Countie of Norffolke afore≈øaid, which ≈øaid ≈øeueral mannors, & thaduou≈øons afore≈øaid, the ≈øaid Lord Mo. by like conueyance and a≈ø≈øurance did conuey and a≈ø≈øure the ≈øame to one Ed. B. late of D. in the ≈øaid Countie of Norffolke E≈øquier decea≈øed, and to his heires for euer.
to the only v≈øe and behoofe of the ≈øaid Ed. B. his heires and a≈ø≈øignes for euer, by who≈øe death, T. B. ≈øonne and heire of the ≈øaid Ed. B. E≈øquier decea≈øed, was and yet is ≈øeazed of the ≈øaid mannors of S. Mo. and Wo. and of the aduow≈øons of S. Mo. and Wo. in his deme≈øne as of Fee. And whereas the ≈øaid Lord Mo. was at the time of the knowledging of the ≈øaide ≈øtatute ≈øtaple likewi≈øe ≈øeazed in his deme≈øne as of Fee, of and in the mannor of B. with the appurtenances, ≈øcituate and extending into the Townes of N. M. &c. in the afore≈øaid Countie of Norffolke, which ≈øaid mannor the ≈øaide Ed. Lord M. did likewi≈øe conuey vnto T. G. GentÃÑ, and to his heires for euer, to the only v≈øe and behoofe of the ≈øaid T. G. his heires and a≈ø≈øignes for euer. And whereas the ≈øaid Edw. Lord Mo. was at the time of the ≈øaide ≈øtatute knowledged, and yet is ≈øeazed of and in the mannor of A. with the appurtenances in the ≈øaid Countie of Norffolke in his deme≈øne as of fee, and being indebted to your ≈øaid Orator as afore≈øaid, your Orator made ≈øundrie and diuers earne≈øt reque≈øts for the getting of the ≈øaid debt and ≈øummes of money afore≈øaid, and your Orator being by the ≈øaide Lord Mo. promi≈øed to haue the ≈øaid debts at diuers ≈øeuerall dayes, yet none of them were performed or kept, whereby your Oratour ≈øeeing no performance, but was delayed from time to time, your ≈øaide Oratour about two yeares ≈øithence ≈øued forth his ≈øeuerall writs of Extendi facias directed to the Sheriffs of Norffolke, E≈ø≈øex, Hertford, Sommer≈øet≈øhire, and Yorke, and to the Chancellor of the Countie Pallantine of Lanca≈øter, for the extending of all the mannors, lands, tenements, and hereditaments, within the Counties afore≈øaid, whereof the ≈øaid Lord Mo. was ≈øeazed the time of the ≈øaide ≈øtatute knowledged, which writ directed to the Sheriffe of the ≈øaid Countie of Norffolke, was deliuered to one Clement Pa≈øtone E≈øquier then Sheriffe of the ≈øame Countie, to be by him executed and returned acordingly. By vertue whereof the ≈øaide Clement Pa≈øtone E≈øquier did by the Othes of a Iury ≈øworne & charged within the ≈øaid Countie of Norffolke, acording to the due cour≈øe of her Maie≈øties lawes, extend and apprai≈øe the ≈øaide ≈øeuerall maunors, faires, markets, lands, tenements, & all other the premi≈ø≈øes with the appurtenances lying within the ≈øaid Countie of Norffolke, as in and by the ≈øaide extents remayning of record in this ho. Court of Chauncery, and by the returne of the ≈øaid Sheriffe, with the ≈øei≈øure of the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall mannors into the Queenes Maie≈øties hands, to the intent they might be deliuered to your Orator in extent more at large it doth and may apeare. After which inqui≈øition, extent, and ≈øea≈øure ≈øo taken, had, & made, your Orator ≈øued forth her highnes writ of Liberate, bearing Te≈øte the 4. day of February, in the 30. yeare of her highnes raigne, directed tothe ≈øaid Sheriffe of Norffolke, commaunding him thereby to deliuer the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall mannours extended as afore≈øaid vnto your
Orator to hold them in extend, vntill your Oratour were of the ≈øaide ≈øumme of 1200. l . with his co≈øts and expences herein ≈øu≈øtayned, fully ≈øati≈øfied & paid. By vertue of which ≈øaid writ, the ≈øaid Clement Pa≈øton then Sherife did deliuer in extent to your ≈øaide Oratour the xii. day of March then next following the fore≈øaid ≈øeuerall mannors of H. W. A. and B. with the two faires holden twi≈øe by the yeare, and the market of H. there holden euery weeke, with the hundred of F. with their appurtenances. And the ≈øaid mannor of H. with the appurtenances. And al≈øo the ≈øaid mannor of S. Mo. and WO. with thaduow≈øons & patronage of Sw. M. and W. with their appurtenances together with the mannor of B. with thappurtenances, & the fore≈øaid mannor of A. with thappurtenances, to hold to your ≈øaid Orator & his a≈ø≈øignes according to the ≈øaid extent, vntill the ≈øaid debt of 1200. l . together with your Orators co≈øts and damages were taken and leuied of the premi≈ø≈øes. By vertue whereof your ≈øaid Orator was of the premi≈ø≈øes po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, and ≈øo being po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, the ≈øaid Lord Mo. before that your ≈øaid Orator had or could receiue any profit of the premi≈ø≈øes, or of any part or parcell thereof, by meanes or rea≈øon of the ≈øaid execution thereupon made & deliuered to your ≈øaide Orator, did make humble ≈øuit to your ho. Lord≈øhip, that it would plea≈øe the ≈øame to moue your ≈øayd Orator to forbeare ye taking of the i≈ø≈øues rents & profits of the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall manors, & other the premi≈ø≈øes, & from the mole≈øting of the farmors, tenants, & occupiers thereof for the ≈øame, vntill your ho. Lord≈øhip, or ≈øome others to be by your Lord≈øhip apointed, had heard & determined the cau≈øe and reckoning betweene the ≈øaid Lord M. & your ≈øaid Orator, whereupon your ≈øaid Orator was content at the motion & reque≈øt of your ho. Lord≈øhip to permit the tenants of the premi≈ø≈øes to continue in their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion quiet, and to forbeare the taking of the rents and profits thereof, and to referre the hearing and ending of all reckonings & demaunds betweene your ≈øaid Orator, and the ≈øaide Lord Mo. to the order and determination of mai≈øter Doctor S. one of the mai≈øters of this mo≈øt honorable Court of Chauncerie, & to S. B. GentÃÑ one of your Honors Secretaries, being thereunto a≈ø≈øigned and apointed by your Lord≈øhip in fauour of the ≈øaid Lord Mo. who entred into examination of the premi≈ø≈øes in controuer≈øie betweene the ≈øaid Lord Mo. and your ≈øaid Orator, and by their mediations and at their reque≈øts your ≈øaide Orator was content in forgo neere the ≈øumme of 100. pound of his iu≈øt demaund, ≈øo that the ≈øaid Lord Mo. would content and pay the re≈øidue to your ≈øaid Orator in ≈øuch ≈øort and at ≈øuch times as the ≈øaid mai≈øter S. and mai≈øter Br. did conclude and ≈øet downe, but the ≈øaid Lord Mo. meaning and intending ≈øtill to delay your ≈øaid Orator, and to keepe him both without his money, and the profits of the ≈øaid mannors and other the premi≈ø≈øes with the appurtenances, whcih were deliuered vnto your ≈øaid Oratour in
execucion towards the ≈øati≈øfying of the debt, co≈øts, and damages, did not only neglect to performe the ≈øaide agreement and order taken by the ≈øaide mai≈øter S. and mai≈øter Br. but hath and doth vtterly refu≈øe and denie to performe the ≈øame, by rea≈øon whereof your ≈øaid Orator for the leuying of his debt, co≈øts, and damages, did purpo≈øe and intend to take the benefit of his ≈øaid execucion, and for that end your ≈øaid Orator about the fea≈øt day of S. Michaell the Archangell la≈øt pa≈øt, trauayled into the ≈øaide Countie of Norffolke where the ≈øaide mannors and premi≈ø≈øes do lye, and there did offer to keepe Courts, and did likewi≈øe require the tenants, occupiers, and farmors of the ≈øaide mannors and premi≈ø≈øes to render and pay to your ≈øaid Orator the rents, i≈ø≈øues, and profits then due for the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes to your ≈øaid Orator, and therewithall your ≈øaide Orator did require the ≈øaide tenants and occupiers of the ≈øaide mannor and premi≈ø≈øes to di≈øcouer and make knowne to him how and in what ≈øort and by what title they and euery of them did hold, claime, and enioy the ≈øeuerall parcels of the ≈øaid premi≈ø≈øes which they the ≈øaid farmors and occupiers did ≈øeuerally occupie, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe, and enioy, to the end that your ≈øaide Orator might hereafter be a≈ø≈øertained and fully in≈øtructed how to demaund, recouer, and come by the rents re≈øerued vpon their ≈øeuerall e≈øtates and intere≈øts which be rightfully belonging and appertayning to your ≈øaide Oratour by rea≈øon of the ≈øaide extent, but ≈øo it is if it may plea≈øe your honourable Lord≈øhip that the ≈øaide L. Mo. T. L. Tho. B. Theodora Goodwin, Hen. Blage Steward, Thomas Louell, Thom. More, Henry Hynde, Rich. Handford, Edmond Coles, Tho. Baylie, Wil. Drake, Geo. Thur≈øtone, Rap. Story, being all Owners, Farmors, Tenants, Occupiers, and Officers of the ≈øayde Mannors and premi≈ø≈øes, in who≈øe hands and keeping all the Court Rolles, Rentalls, Lea≈øes, and counterparts thereof which touch or concerne the ≈øaide mannors and premi≈ø≈øes, or any part or parcel thereof be and remaine, Haue confederated together both to defeate your Orator of his lawfull execucion and e≈øtate in the premi≈ø≈øes, and al≈øo to defraude and vtterly to take away from your ≈øaid Orator the rents, i≈ø≈øues, and profits thereof, and therefore and for that end the ≈øaide Lord Mo. &c. did not only denye and refu≈øe to permit and ≈øuffer your ≈øaide Orator or any other per≈øon to his v≈øe to enter into the ≈øaide mannors and premi≈ø≈øes, or to keepe any Courts in and vpon the ≈øame, but al≈øo did and do denie and refu≈øe to pay to your ≈øaide Orator any free or farme rents for the ≈øaide mannors or premi≈ø≈øes, or to ≈øhew to your ≈øaid Orator how or by what lea≈øes or other titles they or any of them do po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe or enioy the premi≈ø≈øes, or any part or parcell thereof, or what rents or ≈øeruices ought to be paid for the ≈øame, by rea≈øon whereof your ≈øaide Orator is like to be kept
from the benefit of his ≈øaid execucion again≈øt all right, equitie, and con≈øcience, vnle≈ø≈øe your ho. & accu≈øtomed help be vnto him in this behalfe extended. In tender coÃÑ≈øideration whereof, & for that ye ≈øaid Lo. Mo. &c. being owners & occupiers of the mannors & premi≈ø≈øes afore≈øaid, and do conceale & keepe from the knowledge of your ≈øaid Orator a≈øwell your yearely rents, ≈øeruices & fermes, as al≈øo ye ≈øight of their ≈øeuerall Indentures of Lea≈øe, as al≈øo the Courtrowles, whereby your Orator is without remedy either to recouer any yearely ferme, or other the rents and ≈øeruices of the Freehold or Copyhold lands pertaining to the ≈øaid mannors, and for that your Orator hath not the counterpanes of your ≈øaid Indentures of Lea≈øe, neither knoweth the dates of them, nor the certeintie of your fermers re≈øerued, or of ye rents & ≈øeruices due & payable for your ≈øaid lands, hauing not ye Courtrowles to ≈øhew forth, ≈øo as your Orator cannot by ye cour≈øe of the common lawes of this realme, make any Auowrie for either the yearely farmes, nor yet for the rents & ≈øeruices due vpon & for the fore≈øaid freehold or copiehold lands holden of the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall mannors as afore≈øaid, nor yet for any other dutie or ≈øeruice due for the ≈øame, nor can ≈øhewe forth the certentie of the lands that the ≈øaid tenants do ≈øeuerally hold. May it therefore plea≈øe your ho. Lord≈øhip that ≈øome good order may be by your Lord≈øhip ≈øet downe, whereby the fore≈øaid ≈øeuerall Farmors, tenants & occupiers of the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall mannors, & all the other parties before mentioned, may be inforced to ≈øet downe vpoÃÑ their othes, as al≈øo bring forth their ≈øeueral Indentures of Lea≈øes, whereby your Orator may know the ≈øeuerall dates of theÃÑ, as al≈øo what lands they hold by the ≈øame, & by what yerely rents & fermes. And ye the tenants of the ≈øaid ≈øeueral mannors may likewi≈øe be inforced vpon their oathes to ≈øet downe what lands they hold of the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall mannors either freely, or by copy of courtrowle, & by what rents, fines, duties, & ≈øeruices. As al≈øo ye fore≈øaid Eo. Lord Mo. &c. hauing the cu≈øtodie of any the rentalls, Courtrowles, bookes of ≈øuruey, feild bookes or terrors concerning thafore≈øaid ≈øeuerall mannors or any of them, may likewi≈øe be inforced to ≈øhew them forth to your Oratour, to the intent your Orator may vnder≈øtand what lands, tenements, or hereditameÃÑts, are holden of ye ≈øaid ≈øeueral mannors or of any of them, & by what rents, duties or ≈øeruices the ≈øaid lands, tenements, or hereditaments are holden by, whereby your Orator may according to equitie & good con≈øcience reape, receiue, recouer, haue & take the yerely reuenews, i≈ø≈øues and profits of the fore≈øaid ≈øeuerall mannors & euery of them, as in lawe and right belongeth vnto him, & as he ought to do, vntill your ≈øaid Orator be ≈øati≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed of the ≈øumme conteined in his fore≈øaid ≈øtatute ≈øtaple knowledged vnto him as afore≈øaid, we his rea≈øonable co≈øts & damages herein ≈øu≈øteined, & to thend that al the≈øe points may be performed accordingly.
May it further plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip to get to your ≈øaid Oratour the Qu. Ma. mo≈øt gratious writs of Subpena to be directed to the fore≈øaid Ed. Lord Mo. Baron of R. &c. Commaunding them & euery of theÃÑ thereby at a certaine day, & vnder a certaine paine per≈øonally to apeare before your good Lord≈øhip in the ≈øaid ho. Court of Chancerie, then and there to an≈øwere to the premi≈ø≈øes, & to abide ≈øuch further order & direction herein, as to your Ho. ≈øhal ≈øeeme good to ≈øtand with right, equitie, and good con≈øcience. And your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhall according to his mo≈øt bounden dutie euer pray for the increa≈øe and continuance of your good Lord≈øhip in health and all honour long to endure.

div.head: The ioint and ≈øeuerall aun≈øweres of T. M. H. B. &c. Defendants, to the bill of complaint of I. L. Complaynant.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid defendants and euery of them ≈øauing to them and euery of Sect'. 150. them thaduantage of excepcion to the incertaintie & in≈øufficiencie of the ≈øaid bill of complaint, ≈øay. And fir≈øt the ≈øaid T. More for him≈øelfe ≈øaith, That he the ≈øaid T. Moore doth & hath by the ≈øpace of 2. yeares la≈øt pa≈øt or thereabouts exerci≈øed the Office of Baylife of the mannors of H. A. and B. in the ≈øaide Bill mentioned, whereof this defendant ≈øuppo≈øeth T. Lo. E≈øquier to be ≈øea≈øed of ≈øome e≈øtate of inheritance, and hath in his hands ≈øome rentalls of the ≈øaide mannors, which this defendant thinketh he ought not to impart to the ≈øaid complaynant, neyther ought the ≈øaid complaynant to haue the i≈ø≈øues, rents, and profits of the ≈øaid mannors as this defendant thinketh, for that as this defendaÃÑt hath credibly heard & verily beleeueth it to be true, the ≈øaid Ed. Lo. M. in the ≈øaid bill mentioned the day of the date of the ≈øaid recognizance in the ≈øaid bill mentioned, or at any time ≈øince, was neuer ≈øeazed in his demea≈øne as of fee ≈øimple, fee tayle, or freehold, of and in the ≈øaid mannors of H. A. and B. or any part or parcell thereof, as in the ≈øaid Bill is vntrulie alledged. But one T. H. was then ≈øeazed thereof, who ≈øince hath conueyed the ≈øame to the ≈øaid Th. Lo. as this defendant hath heard. By rea≈øon whereof ye ≈øaid Tho. Lo. ought in this defend opinion to haue the rents, i≈ø≈øues, & profits thereof notwith≈øtanding the ≈øaid execution, without that this defend is farmor, cu≈øtomarie, or free tenant of any part or parcell of the ≈øaid mannors or other the premi≈ø≈øes in the ≈øaid bill mentioned, other then of parcell of the deme≈ønes of the ≈øaid mannor of H. which this defend holdeth by lea≈øe for certain yeares yet to come, rendring yerely 5. l . and of the Faires of H. & the profits thereof, which he holdeth for diuers yeares yet to come, rendring yearely 26. sÃÑ. 8. d . and of the ≈øixth part of the Warren of H. which he houldeth for diuers yeares yet enduring, rendring 12. ≈øhillings by yeare or thereabouts. And of diuers Freeholds houlden of the mannor of H. by the rents
of 20. sÃÑ. or thereabouts. And without that that this defendant hath in his hands any Court Rolles, Rentalls, or Lea≈øes, concerning the premi≈ø≈øes in the ≈øaid Bill mencioned other then in this aun≈øwere before is mencioned, as in the ≈øaide Bill is vntrulie alledged. And without that that this defendant hath vnlawfully confederated with any the per≈øons in the ≈øaid Bill mencioned, to defeat the ≈øaide complaynant of his lawfull execucion and e≈øtate in the premi≈ø≈øes in the ≈øaid bill mencioned, as in the ≈øaid Bill of complaint is al≈øo vntrulie alledged. And the ≈øaide Henry Blake for him≈øelfe ≈øaith, that hee hath exerci≈øed the office of ≈øteward of the ≈øaid mannors of H. and B. in ye ≈øaid Bill mencioned, and of the mannors of H. in the ≈øaid Bill likewi≈øe mencioned lawfully con≈øtituted thereunto as this defendant thinketh by the ≈øaid T. Lo. being ≈øeazed of ≈øome e≈øtate of inheritance of the ≈øaid mannors as this defendant ≈øuppo≈øeth: and that the Court Rowles and euidences concerning the ≈øaide mannors are kept in the hou≈øe of the ≈øaide T. Lo. at E. in the Countie of Norffolke, and are not at this defendants di≈øpo≈øition, to yeeld vp or impart to the ≈øaid complaynant otherwi≈øe then as the ≈øaide T. Lo. ≈øhall appoint, whereof this defendant humblie prayeth this honorable Court to haue con≈øideration, without that that this defendant in Farmor or Cu≈øtomarie or free tenant of any part or parcell of ye ≈øaid mannors or other the premi≈ø≈øes in the ≈øaide Bill mencioned, or hath in his hands any Court rowles, Rentals, or Lea≈øes, concerning the premi≈ø≈øes in the ≈øaid Bill mencioned other then as in his aun≈øwere before is mencioned, as in the ≈øaide Bill of complaint is vntrulie ≈øurmi≈øed. And without that that this defendant hath vnlawfullie confederated with any per≈øon or per≈øons in the ≈øaid Bill mencioned to defeat the ≈øaid complainant of his lawfull execucion and e≈øtate in the premi≈ø≈øes in the ≈øaide Bill mencioned, as in the ≈øaide Bill of complaint is al≈øo vntrulie alledged. And the ≈øaide Thomas Ayn≈øworth for him≈øelfe ≈øaith, that he hath and doth exerci≈øe the Office of Baylife of the manor of S. in the ≈øaid BIll mencioned vnder and by the apointment of T. B. E≈øquier in the ≈øaid Bill mencioned, whome this defendant ≈øuppo≈øeth to be ≈øeazed thereof of ≈øome e≈øtate of inheritance, and hath in his hands certaine rentalls of the ≈øame mannor, which Rentalls this defendant thinketh he ought to dutie to keepe and v≈øe to the benefit and ≈øeruice of the ≈øaide Tho. B. and to employ the ≈øame according to his direction and not otherwi≈øe. And further this defendant ≈øaith, that this defendant is Farmor of parcell of the deme≈ønes of the mannor of S. afore≈øaid, which he holdeth for diuers yeares yet to come, yeelding and paying therefore yearely 14. l . 8. sÃÑ. 4. d . of lawfull money of England. And al≈øo holdeth by coppie of Court rowle at the will of the Lord of the ≈øaide mannor of Swanton Morley according to the cu≈øtome of the ≈øaid mannor, diuers
lands and tenements within the precincts of the ≈øaid mannor, and yeelding yearely for the ≈øame 40. sÃÑ. or thereabouts, which rents this defendant thinketh are not payable to the plaintife, for that the rents re≈øerued vpon Lea≈øes made of any parcell of the extended premi≈ø≈øes before the knowledging of the ≈øaide ≈øtatute, are not expre≈ø≈øely extended nor deliuered to the ≈øaid complainant in execucion. But the ≈øaide complainant hauing extended and receiued the premi≈ø≈øes into execucion as demeane in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion is to ≈øtay and expect till he may haue and enioy the ≈øame according to his extent, and to the liuerey thereof made vnto him. And further this defendant ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid mannor of Swanton Morley is and at the time of the awarding of execucion, was as this defendant thinketh the inheritance of the ≈øaide Th. B. which he then had by purcha≈øe from the ≈øaide Lord Mo. ≈øince the knowledging of the ≈øaid recognizance. And in a≈ømuch as the ≈øaide Lord Mo. at the time of the knowledging of the ≈øaid Recognizance had and was ≈øeazed in Fee ≈øimple, Fee taile, or for terme of life, as this defendant is crediblie enformed, and partly apeareth by the Schedule of the liuerie of the ≈øaide Lord Mo. of and in the mannors of H. in the Countie of E≈ø≈øex of the yearely value of 100. l . or there abouts, and of and in the mannors of F. and Todenhoberie in the Countie of Hertford of the yearely value of fortie pound or thereabouts, and of a certaine yearely rent of thirtie pound or thereabouts going out of the mannor of Shobington in the Countie of Buckingham, and of diuers other mannors, lands, tenements, and hereditameÃÑts, in diuers other Counties of England, which ought to be contributorie to the payment of the ≈øaide twelue hundred pound, and therefore the ≈øame is vndulie and contrarie to lawe charged vpoÃÑ the ≈øaid mannor of Swanton cum Worthinge, which the ≈øaid Th. B. houldeth as a Feoffee, for which cau≈øe the ≈øayde T. B. as this defendant ≈øuppo≈øeth hath pur≈øued his Sciri facias again≈øt the ≈øaide complainant in this honorable Court for the di≈øcharge of the ≈øaid mannor of Swanton cum Worthinge from the ≈øaide due execucion, and from the recouerie of the i≈ø≈øues and profits comming and growing of the ≈øame mannor from the time of the ≈øaid execucion. For which cau≈øe this defendant humblie prayeth this honorable Court that the ≈øaide complainant may be referred to the Common Lawe to bring his Accion again≈øt this defendant for the recouerie of the ≈øaide rents due vpon ≈øuch Lea≈øes and Coppie holds as this defendant houldeth of the ≈øaid mannor of Swanton cum Worthinge wherein the validitie of the ≈øayde E ‚Ä¢ tent may be tryed, ≈øo as this defendant may know to whom he may pay his ≈øaide rents without danger or further trouble. And his defendant is readie to ≈øtand to ≈øuch order as this honorable Court ≈øhall award concerning the ≈øhewing vnto the ≈øaid complainant of his e≈øtate
and terme which he hath of and in any part of ye ≈øaid mannor of Swanton cum Worthinge or holdeth of the ≈øame and other circum≈øtances thereof, without that this defend is Farmer or Cu≈øtomarie or free tenant of any other part or parcell of ye ≈øaid mannors, or other the premi≈ø≈øes in the ≈øaid Bill mentioned, or hath in his hands any Courtrowles, Rentalls, or Lea≈øes coÃÑcerning the premi≈ø≈øes in the ≈øaid bill mentioned, other then as in this aun≈øwere before is mentioned as in the ≈øaid bill of complaint is vntruly alledged. And without that that this defend hath vnlawfully confederated with any the per≈øons in the ≈øaid Bill mentioned, to defeate the ≈øaid compl of his lawfull execucion and e≈øtate in the premi≈ø≈øes in the ≈øaid BIll mentioned, as in the ≈øaid Bill is fal≈øely ≈øurmi≈øed. And the ≈øaid Henry S. Iohn for him≈øelfe ≈øayth, that he hath and doth exerci≈øe the office of Baylife of the mannors of Hockering &c. in the ≈øaide bill mentioned, whereof this defendant ≈øuppo≈øeth Th. Lo. E≈øquier to be ≈øeazed of ≈øome e≈øtate of inheritance, and hath in his hands certaine Rentalls of the ≈øaid mannors, which Rentalls this defendant thinketh he ought in dutie to keepe and v≈øe to the benefit and ≈øeruice of the ≈øaid mai≈øter Louell, and to employ the ≈øame according to his direction, & not otherwi≈øe. And further this defendant ≈øaith, ye he this defendant is Farmer of certaine deme≈ønes of the ≈øaid mannor of Hockering whereof he holdeth ≈øome part for yeares, & ≈øome for life by Lea≈øe made by the ≈øaid Lord Mo. who≈øe e≈øtate the ≈øaid mai≈øter Lo. now hath of and in the ≈øame, yeelding & paying therefore yearely 30. l . or thereabouts, which rent this defendant thinketh is not payable to the ≈øaid complaynant, for that the rents re≈øerued vpon Lea≈øes made of any parcell of the extended premi≈ø≈øes before the knowledging of the ≈øaide ≈øtatute are not expre≈ø≈øely extended nor deliuered to the ≈øaid complaynant in execution. But the ≈øaid complainant hauing extended & receiued the premi≈ø≈øes into execution as deme≈øne in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, is to ≈øtay and expect till he may haue and enioy the ≈øame according to his extent, and the liuerey thereof made vnto him. And further this defend ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid mannors of Hockering & Northtuddenham are and at the time of the awarding of the ≈øaide execution were as this defendant thinketh thenheritance of T. Lo. which he then had by purcha≈øe from the ≈øaid L. Mo. ≈øince the knowledging of the ≈øaid Recognizance. And in a≈ømuch as the ≈øaid Lo. Mo. at the time of the ≈øaid Recognizance had & was ≈øei≈øed in fee ≈øimple, fee taile, or for terme of life, as this defend is credibly enformed, and partly apeareth by the Schedule of the liuerey of the ≈øaid Lord Mo. of and in the mannors of Halingburie Morley, and Salcot Verley in the Countie of E≈ø≈øex of the yearely value of 100. l . or thereabouts, and of and in the mannors of Furnex and Tuddenhoberie in the Countie of Hertford of the yearely value of 40. l . or thereabouts, and a certaine
yerely rent of 30. l . or thereabouts going out of the manor of Shobington in the Countie of Buckingham, and diuers other mannors, lands, tenements, and hereditaments in diuers other Counties of England which ought to be contributorie to the payment of the ≈øayd 12. C. pound, and therefore the ≈øame is vndulie and contrarie to lawe charged vpon the ≈øaid mannors of Hockering, and Northtuddenham, which the ≈øaide mai≈øter Lo. holdeth as a Feoffee, for which rea≈øon the ≈øaid mai≈øter Lo. as this defendant ≈øuppo≈øeth, hath pur≈øued his Scire facias again≈øt the ≈øaide complaynant in this honorable Court for the di≈øcharge of the ≈øaid mannors of Ho. and N. from the ≈øaide vndue execution, and for the recouerye of the ≈øayd i≈ø≈øues and profits comming and growing of the ≈øame mannors from the time of the ≈øaid execution, for which cau≈øe this defendant humbly prayeth this honorable Court, that the ≈øaid complaynant may be referred to the Common lawe to bring his action again≈øt this defendant for the recouerie of the ≈øaid rents due vpon the ≈øaide lea≈ø≈øes and e≈øtates which this defendant holdeth of the ≈øaide mannors, wherein the validitie of the ≈øaid extent and execution may be tryed, ≈øo as the ≈øaid defendant may know to whom to pay his ≈øaide rent without danger or further trouble, and this defendant is readye to ≈øtand to ≈øuch order as this honorable Court ≈øhall award concerning the ≈øhewing to the ≈øaide complainants of his e≈øtates & tearmes which he hath of and in the ≈øaid parcell of the deme≈ønes of the ≈øaid mannor of Ho. or holdeth of the ≈øame and other circum≈øtances thereof without that, that this defendant is Farmer, Cu≈øtomarie, or free tenant of any other part or parcell of the ≈øaide manors or other the premi≈ø≈øes in the ≈øaide bill mentioned, or hath in his hands any Courtrowles, Rentalls, or Counterpanes of lea≈øes concerning the premi≈ø≈øes in the ≈øaide bill mentioned, other then in his An≈øwere before is declared, as in the ≈øaid bill of complaint is vntruly alledged. And without that, that the ≈øaid defendant hath vnlawfully confederated with any the per≈øons in the ≈øaid bill mentioned, to defeate the ≈øaide complaynant of his lawfull execution and e≈øtate in the premi≈ø≈øes in the ≈øaid bill mentioned, as in the ≈øaid bill of complaynt is al≈øo vntrulie alledged. And without that, that any other matter or thing in the ≈øaid bill of complaynt mentioned materiall or effectuall to be an≈øwered vnto, and not herein ≈øufficiently an≈øwered, confe≈ø≈øed, and auoyded, trauer≈øed, or denyed, is to the≈øe defendants or any of their knowledges true, All which matters the≈øe defendants are ready to auerre and prooue as this honorable Court ≈øhall award, and prayen to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed out of the ≈øame, with their rea≈øonable co≈øts and charges in this behalfe mo≈øt wrongfully ≈øu≈øtained.

div.head: A Bill into the Chauncery for detayning of euidences entering into a meadowe and a pasture and making to them≈øelues diuers estates.

opener.salute: To the Reuerend Father in God Thomas Bi≈øhop of Ely, Lord Chauncelor of England.

div.p: IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe ≈øheweth and complayneth vnto your good Sect'. 151. Lord≈øhip your dayly Orator G. I. That where W. I. father vnto your ≈øaid Orator was ≈øei≈øed in his demea≈øne as of fee of and in fifteene Acres of pa≈øture and meadowe with thappurtenances in Clare in the Countie of Suffolke, and ≈øo being thereof ≈øei≈øed dyed by prote≈øtacion ≈øei≈øed. After who≈øe death the ≈øaide fifteene Acres of pa≈øture and meadowe and all other the premi≈ø≈øes with the appurtenances de≈øcended and came and of right ought to de≈øcend and come vnto your ≈øaid Orator as ≈øonne and heire vnto the ≈øaide W. I. So it is if it may plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip that certaine euidences, deedes, charters, and other muniments concerning the premi≈ø≈øes, are come to the hands and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of M. G. Widow, and A. G. who by colour of hauing the ≈øaide euidences haue entered into the premi≈ø≈øes, and haue conueyed vnto them and to their heires diuers and ≈øundrie e≈øtates in the lawe for the di≈øheri≈øon of your ≈øaid Orator, and of his heires for euer: And becau≈øe your ≈øaid Orator knoweth not the certaintie of the ≈øaide euidence, nor whether it be contayned in bagge or bore ≈øealed, or in che≈øt locked, he is without remedie for the recouerie of the ≈øame by the order of the Common lawe, except your Lord≈øhips fauour be vnto him ≈øhewed in this behalfe: In con≈øideration whereof it may plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, the premi≈ø≈øes con≈øidered to graunt a writ of Subpena to be directed to the ≈øaide M. G. Widow, and A. G. commaunding them by the ≈øame per≈øonally to appeare before your good Lord≈øhip in the Kings high Court of Chauncerie at a certayne day, and vnder a certayne payne by your good Lord≈øhip to be limited there to aun≈øwere vnto the premi≈ø≈øes, and after to abide ≈øuch decree and order therein as to your good Lord≈øhip ≈øhall be thought to ≈øtand with right and con≈øcience. And your ≈øaide Orator ≈øhall dayly pray for the pre≈øeruation of your Lord≈øhips Honor long to endure.

div.head:
The Aun≈øwere of one of the defendants to the Bill next before, who pleadeth that the plaintifes father ≈øould the landes in the Bill mentioned to T. H. who ≈øould the ≈øame to the defendants husband, who conueyed the ≈øame to the defendant for her life: And ≈øheweth, that at the time of the ≈øaide purcha≈øe, and after the premi≈ø≈øes were in diuers Feoffes in
v≈øe, and ≈øheweth afterwards the making of the Statute of 27. Hen. 8. for transferring of v≈øes into po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.
The Aun≈øwere of M. G. Widow, to the Bill of complaynt of G. I.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid defendant ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid Bill of complaint is vntrue, Sect'. 152. vncertaine, and in≈øufficient in the lawe to be aun≈øwered vnto, and the matters therein contayned determinable at the Common lawe and not in this honorable Court, whereunto the ≈øaid defendant prayeth to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, and thaduantage thereof to the ≈øaid defendant alwayes ≈øaued, if ≈øhe ≈øhall be compelled to make any further aun≈øwere vnto the ≈øaide in≈øufficient Bill. Then for the declaration of the truth the ≈øaide defendant ≈øayth, That as to any pa≈øture or meadowe in Clare the ≈øaide defendant knoweth not that ≈øhe is Tenaunt of, or hath any that was belonging to the ≈øaide W. I. within the ≈øayde towne or pari≈øh of Clare, or detayneth any euidence concerning the ≈øame to her knowledge: But the ≈øaide defendant ≈øayth, the ≈øayde W. I. mentioned in the ≈øayde Bill of complaynt, together with I. W. alias Miller, I. F. &c. were ≈øei≈øed of and in ≈øeauen Acres of pa≈øture and moore, and three Acres and one Roode of meadowe in S. in their demea≈øne, as of fee to the v≈øe of the ≈øayde W. I. and of his heires, and ≈øo beeing thereof ≈øei≈øed, the ≈øayde W. I. bargained and ≈øoulde the pa≈øture, moore, and meadowe la≈øt before remembred vnto one T. H. and to hys heires for euer: By vertue of which bargaine the ≈øayde W. I. and hys ≈øayde other Coefeoffees were thereof ≈øei≈øed in their Demea≈øne as of Fee, to the v≈øe of the ≈øayde T. H. and of his heires, and after the ≈øayde W. I. dyed: After who≈øe death the ≈øayde I. W. &c. them held in by right of ≈øuruiuor≈øhip, and were thereof ≈øei≈øed in their demea≈øne as of Fee, to the ≈øayde v≈øe la≈øt remembred: and beeing ≈øo ≈øei≈øed to the ≈øayde v≈øe, the ≈øayde T. H. bargayned and ≈øold the ≈øayde Pa≈øture, Moore, and Meadowe to one W. G. Gentleman, hu≈øband of the ≈øayd defendant and to hys heyres: By vertue whereof the ≈øayde I. W. and other his ≈øayde Coefeoffes were ≈øea≈øed of and in the ≈øame to the v≈øe of the ≈øayde W. G. and of hys heyres: And after for the further a≈ø≈øurance thereof to the ≈øayde W. G. and hys heyres, the ≈øayde I. W. and the other hys Coefeoffees ≈øo beeyng ≈øea≈øed of and in all the premi≈ø≈øes, did enfeoffe W. B. E≈øquier, G. F. Gentleman, &c. of and in the ≈øayde Pa≈øture, Moore, and Meadowe: To haue and to hold the ≈øame to the ≈øayd W. B. &c. and their heires
and a≈ø≈øignes, to the only v≈øe and behoofe of the ≈øaide W. G. and of his heires and a≈ø≈øignes for euer: By vertue whereof the ≈øaide W. B. &C. were thereof ≈øei≈øed in their demea≈øne as of fee to the only v≈øe of the ≈øaid W. G. and of his heires and a≈ø≈øignes for euer, and ≈øo were thereof ≈øei≈øed vntill the fourth day of February in the 27. yeare of the raigne of our ≈øoueraigne Lord King Hen. 8. At which day the ≈øaide W. G. was ≈øei≈øed of and in the premi≈ø≈øes in his demea≈øne as of fee, and by vertue thereof the ≈øaide W. G. and his a≈ø≈øignes haue euer ≈øince enioyed the premi≈ø≈øes peaceablie and quietlie without interruption, vntill now of late within the≈øe twelue moneths that the ≈øaid complaynant pretended title vnto the ≈øame, The e≈øtate of which W. G. of and in the premi≈ø≈øes with their appurtenances the ≈øaide defendant for tearme of her life the reuercion ouer vnto A. G. GentÃÑ by lawfull conueyance in the Lawe now hath without that, that any thing materiall or trauer≈øeable, other then that in this pre≈øent aun≈øwere is confe≈ø≈øed and auoyded, is true. All which matters the ≈øaide defendant doth auerre, and is readie to prooue as this honorable Court ≈øhall award, and prayeth to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed out of the ≈øame with her rea≈øonable co≈øts for her wrongfull vexation ≈øu≈øtayned in this behalfe.

div.head: The Replication of the complaynant to the Aun≈øwere of one of the defendants (who≈øe Aun≈øwere is not here) wherein he confe≈ø≈øeth the ≈øale of the ≈øaid lands by his father, as before in the Aun≈øwere of one other of the defendants is alleaged, but ≈øaith it was made vpon condicion of redemption, the which condicion the vnder perfourmed &c.
The Replicacion of G. I. to the Aun≈øwere of A. G.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid complaynant ≈øaith, that his ≈øaid Bill is certaine and ≈øufficient Sect'. 153. in the lawe to be aun≈øwered vnto, and the matters therein contayned are true & not imagined of malice by the ≈øaid complaynant to the only intent and purpo≈øe to put the ≈øaid defendant to trouble, co≈øt, and vexation, in manner and forme as in the ≈øaid Aun≈øwere is vntrulie alleaged. And for Replication vnto the ≈øaide Aun≈øwere the ≈øaide complaynant ≈øayth as he in his ≈øaid Bill hath ≈øaid, that the ≈øaide W. I. father to the ≈øaide complaynant was ≈øei≈øed of the premi≈ø≈øes in his demea≈øne as of Fee, in v≈øe, or in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. And the ≈øaide W. I. ≈øo being thereof ≈øei≈øed by his deede indented bearing date the fourth day of Nouember, in the 22. yeare of the late King Hen. 8. bargained and ≈øould the premi≈ø≈øes vnto the ≈øaid T. H. his heires and a≈ø≈øignes for euer for the ≈øumme of fortie markes, whereof the ≈øaid T. H. paid vnto the ≈øayd W. H. twentie marks, and the other twentie marks to be payd vnto the ≈øaide W. I. at the fea≈øt of S. Nicholas, which was in the yeare of
our Lord God 1534. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe, the ≈øaid T. H. couenaunteth and graunteth by the ≈øaid Indenture, that if the ≈øaid W. I. his heires, executors or a≈ø≈øignes at the ≈øaid fea≈øt of S. Nicholas, or in the meane time before, did repay vnto the ≈øaid T. H. his heires executors and a≈ø≈øignes the ≈øaid twentie markes, that then the ≈øaid bargaine and ≈øale to be voyd, and of none effect, as by the ≈øaide Indenture readie to be ≈øhewed more plainely doth and may appeare, by force whereof the ≈øaide W. I. and the other his coefeoffees were ≈øei≈øed of the premi≈ø≈øes to the v≈øe of the ≈øaid T. H. and of his heires. And after the ≈øaid W. I. according to the ≈øaid Indenture, and before the ≈øaid fea≈øt of S. Nicholas, did well and truely content and pay vnto the ≈øaid T. H. the ≈øaid ≈øumme of twentie markes, by force whereof the ≈øaid W. I. and the other his Coefeoffees were ≈øei≈øed of the premi≈ø≈øes in their demea≈øne as of Fee to the v≈øe of the ≈øaid W. I. and of his heires: And the ≈øaid W. I. and the other his Coefeoffees ≈øo being thereof ≈øei≈øed, the ≈øaide W. I. dyed, after who≈øe death the re≈øidue of the ≈øaid feoffees were ≈øei≈øed of the premi≈ø≈øes to the v≈øe of the ≈øaide complaynant and of his heires vntill the fourth day of Februarie, in the 27. yeare of the late King Hen. 8. at which day the ≈øaid complaynant was ≈øolelie ≈øeized: And further auerreth all and euery thing contayned in his ≈øaide bill to be true in manner and forme as he in his ≈øaid Bill hath alleaged, without that that the ≈øaid W. I. bargained and ≈øould the premi≈ø≈øes vnto the ≈øaid T. H. and to his heires in ≈øuch manner and forme (without condicion) as in the ≈øaid Aun≈øwere is vntruely alleaged: And without that that the ≈øaid T. H. did lawfully bargaine and ≈øell the premi≈ø≈øes vnto the ≈øaide W. G. and to his heires: Or that the ≈øaide I. W. and his Coefeoffees were lawfully ≈øei≈øed of the premi≈ø≈øes to the v≈øe of the ≈øaid W. G. and of his heires: Or that the ≈øaide Feoffees did or might lawfully enfeoffe the ≈øaid W. B. and others named in the ≈øaid Aun≈øwere to the v≈øe of the ≈øaid W. G. and of his heires: Or that the ≈øaide W. B. and the other his Coefeooffees were lawfully ≈øei≈øed of the premi≈ø≈øes to the v≈øe of the ≈øaid W. G. and of his heires. Or that the ≈øaide W. G. at the ≈øaide fourth day of February, was lawfully and ≈øolelie ≈øei≈øed of the premi≈ø≈øes in fee: Or did lawfully and peaceably enioy the premi≈ø≈øes: Or that the ≈øaide M. G. mother of the ≈øaid defendant hath any lawfull e≈øtate from the ≈øaid W. in manner and forme as in the ≈øaid Aun≈øwere is vntruely alleaged: And without that that any other thing materiall in the ≈øaid Aun≈øwere, which by this Replicacion is not ≈øufficiently confe≈ø≈øed and auoyded or trauer≈øed is true: All which matters he is readie to aun≈øwere &c.

div.head: A Bill into the Chauncery for a Commi≈ø≈øion vpon the Statute of 13. Eliz. Cap. 7. entituled, An Act touching orders for Bankrupts, and all the whole proceedings therein.

opener.salute: To the Right Honorable Sir Nicholas Bacon Knight, Lord Keeper of the great Seale of England.

div.p:
HVmblie complayning, ≈øheweth vnto your good Lord≈øhip your Sect'. 154. dayly Orators T. B. of C. in the Countie of D. Clothier, W. M. of L. Grocer, M. G. Merchant, Subiects borne of this Realme of England as well for them≈øelues as for others, ≈øubiects borne of the ≈øaid Realme, and Denizens, Creditors of C. A. of L. Merchantaylor, al≈øo a ≈øubiect borne of the ≈øaide Realme. That whereas the ≈øaid C. A. v≈øing and exerci≈øing the trade of Merchandize, and ≈øeeking his trade of liuing by buying and ≈øelling, vpon good and iu≈øt cau≈øe for wares and merchandize to him ≈øold and deliuered, and al≈øo for ready money to him lent, being indebted to your ≈øaid Orators in ≈øeuerall ≈øummes of money amounting to the value of 300. pound. And now of late, that is to ≈øay, in this pre≈øent moneth of Nouember, in this xv. yeare of the raigne of our ≈øoueraigne Lady the Queenes Maie≈øtie, about the ≈øecond day of the ≈øaide moneth of Nouember, did begin to keepe his hou≈øe ≈øcituate in the ≈øaid Citie of London, and ≈øithence hath departed from his ≈øaid dwelling hou≈øe, and ab≈øented him≈øelfe, to thintent to defraude and hinder your ≈øaide Orators and other his Creditors of their iu≈øt debts and dueties to them due & owing, and ≈øo is become a Bankrupt: By rea≈øon whereof, and for that the ≈øaid Bankrupt and others his confederates haue deui≈øed and contriued diuers ≈øecret e≈øtates and ≈øini≈øter practi≈øes for the conueying and e ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ oyning of the bodie of the ≈øaide Bankrupt, and of all lands, goods, debts, and other things belonging to the ≈øaid Bankrupt, in ≈øuch wi≈øe, as your Orators are without helpe for recouering or obtayning of their ≈øaide iu≈øt debts and dueties, but onely by complaint to your Lord≈øhip, and thereupon to haue remedie according to the Statute, touching orders for Bankrupts in the Parliament begun and holden at We≈øtmin≈øter the ≈øecond day of Aprill, in the xiii. yeare of the Raigne of our ≈øaid ≈øoueraigne Lady the Queenes Maie≈øtie made and prouided. In con≈øideration thereof, may it plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip to graunt the Queenes Maie≈øties mo≈øt gratious Commi≈ø≈øion to be directed to ≈øuch and ≈øo many wi≈øe and hone≈øt di≈øcreet per≈øons as to your Lord≈øhip ≈øhall ≈øeeme good: Aucthorizing them not onely concerning the ≈øaid Bankrupts body, lands, freehold, and cu≈øtomarie goods, debts, and other things what≈øoeuer, but al≈øo concerning
all other per≈øons which by concealement clayme, or otherwi≈øe doe or ≈øhall offend touching the premi≈ø≈øes, or any part thereof, contrarie to the intent and true meaning of the ≈øaide Statute, to do and execute all and euery thing and things what≈øoeuer as well towards and for ≈øati≈øfaction and payment of your ≈øaid Orators, as towards and for all other intents and purpo≈øes, according to the ordinance and proui≈øion of the ≈øaid Statute: And your ≈øaid Orators ≈øhall dayly pray &c.

div.head: The Commi≈ø≈øion vpon the Statute of 13. Eliz. Cap. 7. made again≈øt Bankerupts, and graunted to the Creditors vpon the Bill next before.

opener.signed: ELizabeth by the grace of God Queene of England, Fraunce, and Sect'. 155. Ireland, defendor of the faith &c.
opener.salute: To our tru≈øtie and welbeloued Sir Rowland Heyward Knight, Iohn Langley Alderman of our Citie of London, Tho. Hatton, Tho. Alder≈øey, Thomas Egerton Mercers, and William Wignall Merchant Taylor of our ≈øaide Citie of London, greeting.

div.p:
Whereas we be enformed that C. A. of London Merchantaylor v≈øing and exerci≈øing the trade of Merchandize by way of bargayning, and ≈øeeking his trade of liuing by buying & ≈øelling, and being a Subiect borne of this our Realme of England, in this pre≈øent moneth of Nouember, in the xv. yeare of our Raigne, viz. about the ≈øecond day of the ≈øame moneth, did begin to keepe his hou≈øe ≈øcituate in London afore≈øaid, and ≈øithence hath departed from his ≈øaide dwelling hou≈øe and ab≈øented him≈øelfe, to the intent to defraude and hinder T. B. of C. in the Countie of Deuon≈øhire Clothier, W. M. of London Grocer, Mi. G. Merchant, and others his Creditors, being al≈øo Subiects borne of this our ≈øayde Realme, of their iu≈øt debts and dueties to them due and owing, and ≈øo is become a Bankerupt, We minding the due execution of the Statute touching orders for Bankerupts in our Parliament holden at We≈øtmin≈øter in the xiii. yeare of our Raigne made and prouided, vpon tru≈øt of your wi≈øedomes diligence and prudent circum≈øpections which we haue conceaued in you, doe by the≈øe pre≈øents name, a≈ø≈øigne, appoint, con≈øtitute, and ordayne you, our ≈øpeciall Commi≈ø≈øioners, geuing full power and aucthoritiye vnto you, fiue or foure of you, whereof they the ≈øayde Sir Row. H. I. L. or T. H. to be one, according to the ≈øayde Statute, not onely concerning the ≈øayde Bankerupt hys bodie, lands, freehold, and Cu≈øtomarie goods, debts, and other things what≈øoeuer, but al≈øo concerning all other per≈øons, which by concealement, clayme, or otherwi≈øe doe or ≈øhall offend touching the premi≈ø≈øes, or any part thereof, contrarye to the intent and true meaning
of the ≈øaide Statute, to do and execute according to the ≈øaide Statute all and euerie thing and things what≈øoeuer aswell for and towards ≈øati≈øfaction and payment of the ≈øaide Creditors, as towards and for all other intents and purpo≈øes, according to the ordinance and proui≈øion of the ≈øaide Statute: Willing and commaunding you, fiue or foure of you, whereof Sir Row. H. I. L. or T. H. to be one, to proceede to the execution and accompli≈øhment of this our Commi≈ø≈øioin according to the true intent and meaning of the ≈øaide Statute with all diligence and effect, as our ≈øpeciall tru≈øt is in you:

closer.dateline: Witne≈ø≈øe our ≈øelues at We≈øtmin≈øter the fifth day of Nouember, in the xv. yeare of our Raigne.

div.head: A precept from the ≈øayde Commi≈ø≈øioners to the Officers, to make proclamation according to the ≈øaide Statute again≈øt Bankrupts: that the ≈øaid Bankrupt before a day certaine come in and yeeld his bodie to the Commi≈ø≈øioners, or to one of them.
To the Bayliffes and head Officers of the Burrough of Southwarke.
div.p: WEe the Commi≈ø≈øioners hereafter named by vertue of theSect. 156. Queenes higne≈ø≈øe Commi≈ø≈øion to vs directed, require & charge you fiue ≈øundrie market dayes next en≈øuing the receipt hereof, to make fiue ≈øundry Proclamations in manner and forme hereunder ≈øpecified.

div.head: The Proclamation.
div.p: THe Queenes highne≈ø≈øe doth ≈øtrictly charge and commaund C. ‚Ä¢ .Sect. 157. Merchantaylor of the Citie of London, that he at or before the day of next comming in the Guildhall of London, or where you ≈øhall appoint, yeeld his bodie before Sir Row. Heyward Knight, or before ≈øome one of the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners appointed by her highne≈ø≈øe vnder her great ≈øeale of England, til the due execution of the Statute touching orders for Banckrupts lately made and prouided, vpon paine and perrill of the penaltie of the lawe in that ca≈øe limited and appointed.

div.head:
An Indenture vpon the ≈øaide Commi≈ø≈øion and Statute of Bankcrupts betwixt the Commi≈ø≈øioners of the one partie, and the Creditors of the other partie, whereby the Commi≈ø≈øioners after view, ≈øearch, and prai≈øement made, ≈øell certaine of the goods of the debtors vnto the creditors in part of ≈øatisfaction of their debts, with a Schedule annexed vnto the ≈øaid Indenture which is likewi≈øe indented, wherein are contayned the perticulers of the goods with their ≈øeuerall prices, as they be prized by the Commi≈ø≈øioners to the one part of which Indentures is put to the
hands and ≈øeales of the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners, and to the other of the ≈øaid Indentures the hands and ≈øeales of the creditors.
div.p:
THis Indenture made &c. betweene ≈øir R. H. Knight, A. B. C. D. Sect'. 158. E. F. of the one partie, and G. H. and I. K. creditors of C. A. Citizen and Merchantaylor of London on the other partie, witne≈ø≈øeth, That where our ≈øaid ≈øoueraigne Lady the Queenes Maie≈øtie that now is, by her highne≈ø≈øe letters of Commi≈ø≈øion bearing date at We≈øtmin≈øter the fifth day of Nouember la≈øt pa≈øt before the date hereof, minding the due execution of the Statute touching orders for Bankerupts in her Parliament holden at We≈øtmin≈øter in the xiii. yeare of her highne≈ø≈øe ≈øaid Reigne made and prouided, reciting, that whereas her Maie≈øtie was enfourmed that C. A. of London Merchantaylor v≈øing and exerci≈øing the trade of Merchandize by way of bargaining, and ≈øeekinig his trade of liuing by buying and ≈øelling (and being a ≈øubiect borne of this her Realme of England) in the ≈øaid moneth of Nouember, in the xv. yeare of her Maie≈øties Raigne, that is to ≈øay, about the ≈øecond day of the ≈øaide moneth, did begin to keepe his hou≈øe, ≈øcituate in London afore≈øaid, and ≈øithence hath departed froÃÑ his ≈øaide dwelling hou≈øe & ab≈øented him≈øelf, to thentent to defraude & hinder his creditors, being al≈øo ≈øubiects borne of this her ≈øaid Realme of England of their iu≈øt debts & duties to them due & owing, & ≈øo is become a Bankerupt, hath a≈ø≈øigned, appointed, con≈øtituted & ordained the ≈øaid R. H. &c. her e≈øpeciall Commi≈ø≈øioners, geuing full power & authoritie vnto them 5. or 4. of them, whereof the ≈øaid Sir R. H. to be one, according to the ≈øaid Statute, not only concerning the ≈øaid Bankerupt his bodie, lands, freehold, & cu≈øtomarie goods, debts, & all other things what≈øoeuer, but al≈øo concerning all other per≈øons which by concealemeÃÑt claime, or otherwi≈øe do or ≈øhall offend touching the premi≈ø≈øes or any part thereof, coÃÑtrary to thentent & true meaning of the ≈øaid Statute, to do & execute according to the ≈øaid Statute all & euery thing & things what≈øoeuer as well towards & for ≈øati≈øfaction and payment of the ≈øaide creditors, as towards and for all other intents & purpo≈øes, according to the order & proui≈øion of the ≈øaid Statute in that ca≈øe prouided, as by ye ≈øame Commi≈ø≈øion more plainely it doth and may appeare: By force and vertue of which ≈øaid Statute, and of the ≈øaide Commmi≈ø≈øion, the ≈øaide Commi≈ø≈øioners haue cau≈øed certaine goods, Cattels, wares, and Merchandizes of the ≈øaide C. A. contayned and mentioned in a Schedule indented to the≈øe pre≈øents annexed, to be ≈øearched, viewed & apprized: And al≈øo haue ≈øold & deliuered, and by the≈øe pre≈øents do ≈øell & deliuer to ye creditors aforenamed, all the ≈øaid goods, Cattalls, Wares, Merchandizes, contayned and mentioned in the ≈øaid Schedule indented to the≈øe pre≈øents annexed, To haue and
to hould the ≈øame & euery part thereof to the ≈øaid Creditors before named, their executors, admini≈øtrators, and a≈ø≈øignes, to their owne proper v≈øes for euer towards the ≈øati≈øfaction and payment of the ≈øaid Creditors, that is to ≈øay, to euery of the aforenamed creditors a portion, rate, and ratelike, according to the quantitie of the debts:

closer.dateline: In witne≈ø≈øe whereof the ≈øaid parties to the≈øe Indentures interchangeablie haue ≈øet to their Seales. Yeuen the day and yeare fir≈øt aboue written.

div.head: The intituling of the Schedule mentioned in the IndeÃÑture next before written, and annexed to the ≈øame Indenture.
div.p: IN this Schedule indented is contayned and mentioned certayne Sect. 159. goods, wares, Cattels, & Merchandize late of C. A. Merchantaylor, which be ≈øould by the Indentures, whereunto this Schedule indented is annexed, that is to ≈øay, in his hou≈øe in L. in the pari≈øh of G. in London. Imprimis &c.

div.head: A Bill into the Chauncery again≈øt one by a pri≈øoner in the Fleete, to compell the defendant to proceede in an agreament made betwixt the plaintife and the defendant for his enlargement, by the order of the Lord Chauncelor then dead.

opener.salute: To the right reuerend Father in God, Nicholas Archbi≈øhop of Yorke, and Lord Chauncelor of England.

div.p:
MO≈øt humblie complayning, ≈øheweth vnto your grace, your dayly Sect. 160. and poore Orator W. M. of M. in the Countie of Che≈øter GentÃÑ now being pri≈øoner in the Fleete at the ≈øuit of R. D. of the ≈øame Countie E≈øquier, committed thereunto by the late reuerend Father in God the Bi≈øhop of Ely being then Lord Chauncelor of England, of and vpon a Statute of 200. l . which ≈øuit of the ≈øaide R. D. hath thus remayned the ≈øpace of eight or nine yeares, to the great mi≈øerie and vtter vndoing of your graces ≈øaide Orator. And where diuers agreaments, with other diuers meanes haue bene taken and made betweene the ≈øaid R. D. and your ≈øaide Orator, and e≈øpecially the la≈øt day of May, in the la≈øt yeare of our late Soueraigne Lord King Edward, before Doctor Lyell, & Mai≈øter Dyer, appointed then by the ≈øaid late Lo. Chauncelor, where it was agreed betweene ye ≈øaid R. D. & your graces ≈øaid Orator, that your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhould be bound in 1000. l . that he ≈øhould not alienate nor ≈øell any parcell of his lands now being in his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, or to him in reuercion: And all ≈øuch lands that were ≈øold by your ≈øaide Orator, that your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhould endeuor we all diligence to recouer the ≈øame againe: And furthermore it was agreed & ordered betweene ye ≈øaid R. D. and your ≈øaid Orator, that your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhould put in≈øuerties
to pay vnto the ≈øaide R. D. 50. pound of lawfull money of England, that is to ≈øay, fiue pound yearely during tenne yeares next en≈øuing: All which orders and agreements your Graces ≈øaid Orator is contented to accompli≈øh and fulfill: Yet notwith≈øtanding the ≈øaide ‚Ä¢ . D. minding rather the continuance of your ≈øaid Graces Orator in pri≈øon to his vndoing, will neither obey the late ho. Lord Chauncelors order then made therein, nor yet the agreaments heretofore made, but onely doth finde delayes to prolong the time, to the vtter vndoing of your Graces Orator. In con≈øideration whereof the premi≈ø≈øes tenderly con≈øidered, it may plea≈øe your Grace to commaund the ≈øaide R. D. to appeare before your Grace, and to take ≈øuch order with him as ≈øhall ≈øeeme be≈øt to your Grace. And your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhall pray for your Grace long to continue.

div.head: A Bill into the Chauncerie by the Husband and Wife, for and on the behalfe of diuers to compell executors to pay legacies, wherein is ≈øhewed, that they to whom the legacies be giuen haue no remedie by the eccle≈øiasticall lawe to compell the then executors to pay the ≈øaid legacies.

opener.salute: To the right Honorable Sir Nicholas Bacon Knight, Lord Keeper of the great Seale of England.

div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe complayning ≈øheweth vnto your honors good Sect. 161. Lord≈øhip your daily Orators A. T. E≈øquier, and Katharine his wife, late wife vnto one R. K. decea≈øed, and one of the daughters of William W. of B. in the County of Warwike E≈øquier decea≈øed, for, and in the behalfe of William C. ≈øonne of the ≈øaid Katharine, and for and in the behalfe of Mary T. and K. T. daughters of the ≈øaid A. and Katharine, and of W. G. ≈øonne of Ed. G. Knight, of the body of Margaret G. one other of the daughters of the aforenamed W. W. lawfully begotten, Ed. M. and Anne his wife, one of the daughters of the aforenamed Ed. G. and Margaret, and Tho. M. and Elizabeth his wife, one other of the daughters of the ≈øaid Sir Ed. and Margaret. That whereas the afore≈øaid William W. in his life time had i≈ø≈øue ≈øeuen daughters, that is to ≈øay, Margerie late wife of Thomas H. E≈øquier, and after that wife to the ho. Sir A. C. Knight, one of the Queenes mo≈øt honorable priuie Councell, and now Chauncellor of her highne≈ø≈øe Duchie of Lanca≈øter, Godith, wife to B. F. E≈øquier, Elizabeth, late wife of Ed. B. E≈øquier decea≈øed, Mary, wife of William S. E≈øquier, Margaret, wife of the ≈øaid Sir Ed. G. Anne, wife of Frauncis Mo. E≈øquier, and Katharine, one of your ≈øaid Orators. And whereas al≈øo the ≈øaide W. W. in his life time was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of and in diuers goods and chattels, hou≈øhold ≈øtuffe,
plate, Iewels, and al≈øo entituled to certaine debts amounting to the value of tenne thou≈øand pounds or thereabouts, and ≈øo being thereof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed and entituled, did con≈øtitute and make his Te≈øtament and la≈øt Will, and by the ≈øame did bequeath, geue, and demi≈øe to diuers and ≈øundrie per≈øons diuers great legacies perticulerly and certainely ≈øet forth in the ≈øaid la≈øt Will, amounting in the whole to the ≈øumme and value of 3500. pound or thereabouts: And the re≈øidue of all his goods, Chattels and debts due vnto him after his funerall expences perfourmed, his debts paid, and all his legacies and beque≈øts perticulerlie contayned and mentioned in his ≈øaid Will, fulfilled, perfourmed, and payd, hee the ≈øayde W. W. by his ≈øayde Te≈øtament and la≈øt Will did geue and bequeath to the preferment of all the children comming of hys ≈øayde ≈øixe elde≈øt daughters, and to W. C. Mary T. and Katharine T. three of the Children of the ≈øayde Katherine, nowe Wife of the ≈øayde Anthonye T. younge≈øt Daughter of the ≈øayde W. W. to be equallie deuided among≈øt them by the di≈øcretion of hys executors: And by the ≈øame hys Te≈øtament and la≈øt Will, hee did ordayne, nominate, and make the ≈øayde honorable Sir A. C. Knight, Sir Ed. G. Knight, nowe decea≈øed, Ba≈øill F. and W. S. E≈øquiers, and one W. B. E≈øquiers decea≈øed, his Executors, as by the ≈øame his Te≈øtament and la≈øt Will more at large it doeth and may appeare: And afterwards in the moneth of May, in the ≈øecond and third yeares of King Phillip and the late Queene Mary, hee the ≈øayde W. W. dyed po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the ≈øayde goods, Chattels, and debts, amounting to about the ≈øumme or value of tenne thou≈øand pounds. After who≈øe decea≈øe, the ≈øayde Executors did take, admini≈øter, and agree to the ≈øayde Te≈øtament, which ≈øpeciall Legacies afore≈øayde eyther be or might haue beene by the ≈øayde Executors long ≈øithence fulfilled, ≈øati≈øfyed, and paide, ≈øo as the re≈øidue ≈øhould and ought to come to the ≈øayde Children according to the ≈øayde Will. And although your ≈øayde Oratours haue diuers and ≈øundry tymes required the ≈øayde Executors to make payment of ≈øo much of the re≈øidue of the ≈øayde goods, Cattalls, and debts, as to them appertayned, yet that to doe, they and euerie of them haue hitherto refu≈øed and denyed, contrarie to right, equitie, and good con≈øcience. In con≈øideration whereof, and for as much as your ≈øayde Orators cannot certainely tell and declare the ≈øeuerall parcels of the ≈øayde goods, Cattalls, and debts, nor what the ≈øayde Executors haue payd or receiued for any manner of debts owyng by or to the ≈øayde W. W. by rea≈øon whereof, they are vnable to pro≈øecute for their remedie in the premi≈ø≈øes at and by the order of the Eccle≈øia≈øticall lawes of this Realme. May it therefore
plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip to graunt the Queenes Maie≈øties writ of Subpena to be directed to the ≈øaid Executors, &c. commaunding &c.

div.head: A bill contayning that a lea≈øe of a rectorie, and the buildings, gleebe lands, and tythes was made by the Deane and Chapter of a Colledge in Oxford to the plaintifes father for terme of yeares re≈øeruing a rent: And that the ≈øame by force of the ≈øaid lea≈øe was long po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed. That the ≈øaid lea≈øe came to the plaintife by meane conueyance, and that continuing the tearme, the defendant ≈øuggesting to the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter that the ≈øaid Rectory and tythes were occupied by the plaintife without lea≈øe, or title, hauing a purpo≈øe to conceale and defraude the ≈øaid Colledge of the ≈øaid Rectorie and tythes, became a ≈øuitor to the now Deane and Chapter to haue a Lea≈øe of the ≈øaide Rectorie and tythes for 21. yeares, and thereupon obtained a lea≈øe thereof for 21. yeares, yeelding for it the accustomed rent, with an augmentation of rent corne. That the defendant hauing obteyned a lea≈øe of the ≈øaide rectorie and tythes for 21. yeares, ≈øued the plaintife for the ≈øame in the Excheker at We≈øtmin≈øter in a quo minus, and that he did interrupt the plaintifes po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion: And then the plaintife prayeth an iniunction for ≈øtay of the ≈øaide ≈øuite, and for the establi≈øhing of his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and proces again≈øt the defendant and the Deane and Chapter to aun≈øwere the bill.

opener.salute: To the Right Ho. Sir. Io. Puckering Knight, Lo. Keeper of the great Seale of England.

div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe complayning ≈øheweth vnto your good Lo. your Sect. 162. dayly Orator T. B. of N. in the Countie of C. E≈øquier, that whereas the Deane & Chapter of Chri≈øtes Church in the Vniuer≈øitie of Oxford, were ≈øea≈øed in their deme≈øne as of fee in the right of their ≈øayd Church of & in the Rectorie & Par≈øonage of R. with the appurtenaÃÑces in ye ≈øaid Countie of C. being a Par≈øonage impropriate, and being ≈øo thereof ≈øea≈øed by their deede indented ≈øealed with their common ≈øeale (the certain date wherof to your ≈øaid orator is vnknowne for waÃÑt of hauing ye ≈øame) did for the con≈øiderations in ye ≈øaid Indenture ≈øpecified, demi≈øe, graunt, & to farme let all the ≈øaid Rectorie & par≈øonage of R. with the appurtenances, & all maner of hou≈øes, barnes, glebe lands, tithes, fruits, profits, & aduaÃÑtages what≈øoeuer to ye ≈øame Rectorie & par≈øonage belonging or in any wi≈øe appertaining vnto one R. B. late of N. in ye ≈øaid Countie of C. E≈øquier decea≈ø≈øed, father vnto your ≈øaid Oratour for a number of yeares yet enduring, re≈øeruing thereby a great annuall rent (the tithes of ye vicarage of R. afore≈øaid, & the patronage & di≈øpo≈øition thereof, and all ye woods & timber trees of ye ≈øaid par≈øonage alwaies excepted & forepri≈øed out of the ≈øaid lea≈øe) which ≈øaid e≈øtate, intere≈øt, & terme of yeres of him ye ≈øaid R. B. of & in the ≈øaid Rectorie, your Lo. ≈øaid Orator by good
and ≈øufficient conueyance and a≈ø≈øurance in the lawe now hath, by vertue of which ≈øaide Lea≈øe as well the ≈øaide R. B. in his life time, as al≈øo your ≈øaid Oratour ≈øince the death of the ≈øaide R. haue by the ≈øpace of many yeares together beene lawfully po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the ≈øaid rectorie, and haue yearely from time to time ≈øince the making of the ≈øaid lea≈øe, quietly and peaceably receiued, leuied, taken, and enioyed in their ≈øeuerall times all the i≈ø≈øues, commodities, & profits thereof to their owne proper v≈øe and behoofs, without the di≈øturbance, let, or interruption of any per≈øon or per≈øons what≈øoeuer vntill now of late, So it is if it may plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, that one I. D. of D. in the ≈øaide Countie of C. E≈øquier, hauing by ≈øome ca≈øuall meanes gotten into his hands and cu≈øtodie the ≈øaid Indenture of lea≈øe made to the ≈øaide R. B. of the ≈øaide rectorie by the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter as afore≈øaid, and diuers other writings and meane conueyances concerning the ≈øame of right belonging to your ≈øaid Oratour, became an earne≈øt ≈øuitor vnto William I. Doctour of Diuinitie, Deane of Chri≈øts Church in Oxford afore≈øaid, R. P. T. T. &c. being the Chapter of the ≈øame Church, to procure a lea≈øe vnto him the ≈øaide I. D. from the ≈øaide Deane and Chapter of the tythes of the ≈øeuerall Towne≈øhips, Hamlets, & places of H. P. &c. which ≈øaid Towne≈øhips, Hamlets, and places are ≈øcituate, lying and being within the limits and precincts of the ≈øaide Rectorie formerlie demi≈øed to the ≈øaid R. B. as afore≈øaid, the ≈øaid I. D. vntrulie ≈øugge≈øting vnto the ≈øaide Deane and Chapter, that the Tithes of tho≈øe ≈øeuerall towne≈øhips were concealed from the ≈øaide Deane and Chapter, And that they had no rent or reuenue at all to them therefore an≈øwered or paid by your ≈øaide Orator, nor by any other per≈øon or per≈øons, vnto which ≈øaid ≈øuit and accompli≈øhment thereof the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter, as your Oratour hath bin credibly enformed, would not of long time con≈øent vpon ≈øu≈øpicion by them conceyued that the ≈øaid I. D. had ≈øome purpo≈øe or intent to procure from them a lea≈øe of ≈øome ≈øuch hamlets and towne≈øhips as were formerlie demi≈øed to the ≈øaide R. B. by the generall name of the rectorie of R. wherin the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall towne≈øhips were included, whereby the ≈øaide I. D. might impeach and call in que≈øtion the validitie of the ≈øaide lea≈øe made to the ≈øaide R. B. And thereupon the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter did affirme and declare to the ≈øaid I. D. that they would not demi≈øe or graunt vnto him the ≈øaid I. D. any thing that was compri≈øed in the ≈øaide lea≈øe made to the ≈øaid R. B. mentioned or intended to be demi≈øed vnto him the ≈øaide R. B. in or by the ≈øame, vnto whome the ≈øaid I. D. made aun≈øwere, that the ≈øaide Tithes of the ≈øaide ≈øeuerall Towne≈øhips and hamlets before mentioned, were not at all demi≈øed by the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter to the ≈øaid R. B. and that his purpo≈øe was not to challenge any thing by demi≈øe
from them which was formerlie letten to the ≈øaid R. B. but only ≈øuch things as were concealed from the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter, for which he would yearely an≈øwere and pay vnto the ≈øaide Deane and Chapter the old acu≈øtomed rent, with an augmentation of a yearely reuenue of Corne, acording to the forme of the Statute in ≈øuch ca≈øes prouided. Whereupon the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter giuing credit to the ≈øaid I. D. and willing to recontinue ≈øuch things as the ≈øaid I. D. affirmed to be wrongfully concealed and detayned from them, and thereby to increa≈øe their yearely reuenue, and hauing withall a great re≈øpect not to preiudice your ≈øaid Orator by any lea≈øe they ≈øhould make to the ≈øaide I. D. nor to lea≈øe any thing demi≈øed to the ≈øaid R. B. did at the importunate ≈øuite of the ≈øaid D. in July, in the xxxiii. yeare of the Raigne of our gratious ≈øoueraigne Lady the Queenes Maie≈øtie that now is by their Indenture ≈øealed with their common ≈øeale, demi≈øe, and to farm ‚Ä¢ let to the ≈øaid I. D. all their tithes, of what nature, kinde, or qualitie ≈øoeuer of the ≈øaide ≈øeuerall towne≈øhips and hamlets before mentioned, the ≈øame being within the ≈øaide precinct of the ≈øaide Rectorie of R. as afore≈øaid from the fea≈øt of S. Iohn the Bapti≈øt la≈øt pa≈øt before the date of the ≈øaid Indenture vnto thend and terme of one and twentie yeares. The ≈øaid Deane and Chapter then verily ≈øuppo≈øing that none of the tythes of the ≈øaide towne≈øhips were included or compri≈øed in the ≈øaide lea≈øe of the ≈øaid rectorie of R. made to the ≈øaid R. B. but that the ≈øame were other things exempted out of the ≈øaide lea≈øe, and concealed and wrongfully detained from the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter, and not within the limits and bounds of the ≈øaid rectorie. By coulour of which ≈øaid lea≈øe procured by the ≈øaide I. D. by ≈øuch practi≈øe and meanes as afore≈øaid, and by hauing in his hands the ≈øaid Indenture of lea≈øe made to the ≈øaid R. B. of right belonging to your ≈øaid Oratour the ≈øaid I. D. hath of late not only many wayes interrupted your ≈øaide Orators po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of and in the tythes of the ≈øaid towne≈øhips and hamlets, but hath al≈øo thereupon attempted ≈øuite in her Maie≈øties Court of Exchequer at We≈øtmin≈øter by writ of Quo minns again≈øt your ≈øaide Orator for the taking and carrying away of diuers parcels of the ≈øaid tythes growing and renuing within the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall Towne≈øhips and hamlets. And albeit your ≈øaid Orator hath diuers and ≈øundrie times in gentle manner required the ≈øaid I. D. not only to deliuer vnto your ≈øaide Orator the ≈øaid Indenture of lea≈øe ≈øo made to the ≈øaid R. B. together with the ≈øaid other writings and meane conueyances of right belonging to your ≈øaid Oratour, but al≈øo quietly to permit and ≈øuffer your ≈øaide Orator to haue and enioy the premi≈ø≈øes acording to right, equitie, and con≈øcience: Yet that do the ≈øaid I. D. hath alwayes denied and refu≈øed, and yet doth denie and refu≈øe, challenging the ≈øame by vertue of the
≈øaid ≈øuppo≈øed lea≈øe made to him by the ≈øayde Deane and Chapter, contrarie to all equitie and good con≈øcience. In tender con≈øideration whereof, and fora≈ømuch as your ≈øayde Oratour knoweth not the certaine date and contents of the ≈øayde Lea≈øe made to the ≈øayde R. B. and of the meane conueyances afore≈øayde, nor wherein the ≈øame be conteyned, whereby your ≈øayde Orator is remedile≈ø≈øe for the recouerie of the ≈øame by the order of the Common lawe. Neither is hee able to pleade the ≈øaid lea≈øe in certentie at the Common lawe, whereby he ≈øhall iu≈øtifie his right and title to the ≈øaide tithes by him lawfullie taken as afore≈øayd. And for that the ≈øayd Deane and Chapter were ≈øo abu≈øed by the in≈øinuations and vntrue pretences of the ≈øaid I. D. and had no purpo≈øe at all to impeach the ≈øayde Lea≈øe made to the ≈øayde R. B. nor your ≈øayde Orator his title to the ≈øayd Tithes and other the premi≈ø≈øes claymed by vertue of the ≈øame, nor yet to demi≈øe or graunt any thing to the ≈øaide I. D. that was compri≈øed, or intended to be demi≈øed in and by the ≈øame Indenture of lea≈øe made to the ≈øayde R. B. May it therefore plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, the premi≈ø≈øes tenderly con≈øidered, to graunt vnto your ≈øayde Oratour her Maie≈øties mo≈øt gratious writ of Subpena to be directed to the ≈øayd William I. Deane of Chri≈øt Church afore≈øayd, and to the ≈øayde R. P. T. T. &c. and to the ≈øayd I. D. who is v≈øuallie re≈øident within the Citie of London, commaunding them and euerie of them thereby vnder a payne therein to be limited, to appeare before your Lord≈øhip in her Maie≈øties high Court of Chauncerie, immediately then and there to aun≈øwere the premi≈ø≈øes: And al≈øo to graunt vnto your ≈øayde Oratour her Maie≈øties mo≈øt gratious writ of Iniunction for the e≈øtabli≈øhing of your ≈øayde Oratours po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, of and in the ≈øaide rectorie, and other the premi≈ø≈øes, and for the ≈øtay of all Accions commenced, or to be commenced again≈øt your ≈øaide Oratour at the Common lawe vpon or by coulour or pretence of the ≈øayde Lea≈øe ≈øo vndulie procured by the ≈øayd I. D. from the ≈øayde Deane and Chapter, and further to ≈øtand to and abide ≈øuch other order herein as to your Lord≈øhip ≈øhall ≈øeeme to ≈øtand with Iu≈øtice and equitie. And your ≈øaide Oratour ≈øhall dayly pray for your Lord≈øhip in all honour and happines long to continue.

list.item: T. E.
E. C.

div.head: The Aun≈øwere of I. D. E≈øquier one of the defendants, to the vntrue bill of complaynt of T. B. E≈øquier complaynant.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid defendant ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid Bill of complaynt is very Sect. 163. vntrue, vncertaine, and in≈øufficient in the Lawe to be aun≈øwered vnto, not contayning any ≈øufficient matter or iu≈øt cau≈øe of ≈øuit again≈øt this defendant, but only deui≈øed & contriued by the complainant, to put him as it ≈øeemeth to wrongfull vexation, co≈øts, charges, & expences in the law without any iu≈øt cau≈øe of ≈øuit, whereof this defendant doth demaund iudgement of this ho. Court, & prayeth to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed out of the ≈øame. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe, if this defend ≈øhal be coÃÑpelled to make any further aun≈øwer to the ≈øaid bill of complaint, ≈øaith, that he vnder≈øtanding y‚Ä¢ the ≈øaid lea≈øe for yeares mentioned in the ≈øaid bill of complaint made to the ≈øaid R. B. father of the ≈øaid complaynant, to be a meere void lea≈øe, and of no force & validitie in lawe, for that the ≈øame lea≈øe was not demi≈øed by the Deane & Chapter, but by the Deane, with the a≈ø≈øent & con≈øent of the Chapter procured diuers letter s of ≈øundrie honorable per≈øons to the ≈øaid Deane & Chapter of Chri≈øt Church of Oxenford named in the ≈øaid bill of complaint in this defend behalfe and fauour for the obtaining of a lea≈øe for yeares of the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter, the which ≈øaid Deane & Chapter at the reque≈øt & contemplation of tho≈øe letters by their Indenture vnder their Chapter ≈øeale, did among≈øt other things demi≈øe, & to farme let vnto this defendant all that their tythe Corne & graine, comming, renuing, & yearely growing in the Towne≈øhips or townes and fields mentioned in the ≈øaid bill of complaint for the terme of xxi. yeares, by vertue of which demi≈øe to him made, this defendant taketh him≈øelfe lawfullie interce≈ø≈øed and intituled in and to the ≈øaid tithes demi≈øed vnto him, and becau≈øe this defend meant to proceede in a plaine, vpright, and lawfull cour≈øe in lawe again≈øt the ≈øaide complaynant for the triall of the validitie of his ≈øaid pretended lea≈øe, brought his Accion in the Court of Exchequer by way of Quo minus again≈øt the ≈øaide complaynant & others, and as it ≈øeemeth now to this defend the ≈øaid complaynant perceiuing the weakenes & inualiditie of his owne title vpon fained & vntrue ≈øurmi≈øes, hath exhibited the ≈øaid bill of complaint into this ho. Court, to vexe & trouble this defend & the other defendants named in the ≈øaid bill of complaint, to maintaine & continue his wrongful po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion by a void lea≈øe, & of no validitie in law, as to your Lo. for the cau≈øe afore≈øaid may apeare, which ≈øaid lea≈øe the ≈øaid compl to the great preiudice & hinderance of the ≈øaid Colledge & Students thereof, laboureth and ≈øeeketh to enioy, being void in lawe, and which lea≈øe if it were a good lea≈øe ≈øhould indure and continue for many moe yeares
then the lea≈øe made to this defendant, and would be le≈ø≈øe in yearely rent and benefit to the ≈øaide Colledge then this defendants lea≈øe will be, re≈øpect being had to the things demi≈øed: And therefore as this defendant thinketh the ≈øaide complaynant is not to be releeued by any equitie, or maintayned in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion vpon a meere void lea≈øe in lawe, ≈øince that by coulour of the ≈øaid void lea≈øe the ≈øaid complaynant and his father haue receiued ≈øo great a profit for many yeares pa≈øt: without that that the defendant hath by any ca≈øuall meanes gotten into his hands and cu≈øtodie the ≈øaid Indenture of lea≈øe made to the ≈øaid R. B. of the ≈øaid rectorie by the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter, and diuers other writings and meane conueyances concerning the ≈øame of right belonging to the ≈øaide complaynant, as mo≈øt vntruly by the ≈øaid Bill of complaynt is alledged, for that he ≈øaith, that he neuer had the ≈øaid ≈øuppo≈øed lea≈øe, nor any meane conueyance thereof, or that the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter euer at any time made any ≈øuch lea≈øe to the ≈øaide R. B. father of the ≈øaid complaynant as the ≈øaid complaynant ≈øurmi≈øeth, but ≈øuch a lea≈øe as in this defendants aun≈øwere is before alledged, or that the defendant vntrulie ≈øugge≈øting vnto the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter the other defendants in the ≈øaid bill of complaynt that the tithes in the ≈øaid ≈øeuerall towne≈øhips mentioned in the ≈øame bill of complaynt were concealed from the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter, and that they had no rent or reuenue at all to them therefore aun≈øwered or paid by the ≈øaid complaynant, nor by any other per≈øon or per≈øons, as mo≈øt vntrulie is alledged and ≈øurmi≈øed by the ≈øaid bill of complaynt: or that the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter did affirme and declare to this defendant, that they would not demi≈øe or graunt vnto him this defend any thing that was compri≈øed in the ≈øaid lea≈øe made to the ≈øaid R. B. or that was mentioned or intended to be demi≈øed to him the ≈øaid R. in or by the ≈øame lea≈øe. Or that vpon any ≈øuch affirmation this defendant made aun≈øwere, that the tythes of the ≈øaide ≈øeuerall towne≈øhips mentioned in the ≈øaide bill of complaynt, were not demi≈øed by the ≈øaide Deane and Chapter to the ≈øaid R. B. And without that this defendant alledged that his purpo≈øe was not to challenge any thing by demi≈øe from them, which was formerlie letten to the ≈øaid R. B. but only ≈øuch things as were concealed from the ≈øaide Deane and Chapter as mo≈øt vntrulie is alledged by the ≈øaide bill of complaynt, but he ≈øayth that he affirmed if he might haue a lea≈øe made to him he would yeeld an increa≈øe of rent of corne acording to the forme of the ≈øtatutes in ≈øuch ca≈øes prouided. And further this defendant ≈øayth, as before he hath ≈øaid, that he being enformed that the lea≈øe made to the ≈øaid R. B. to be a void lea≈øe, became an earne≈øt ≈øuitor by the meanes afore≈øaid for a lea≈øe of the ≈øame things that were pretended to be demi≈øed to the ≈øaide R. B. and enformed the ≈øaide Deane and
Chapter, that they might and that they had power in them to demi≈øe the ≈øame. And this defendant further ≈øaith, that there was included in the ≈øaid ≈øuppo≈øed lea≈øe made to the ≈øaid R. B. all the things that be demi≈øed to this defendant, and if this defendant ≈øhould not haue meant to haue had in lea≈øe from the Deane and Chapter the things ≈øuppo≈øed to be demi≈øed to the ≈øaid R. B. and to enioy the ≈øame, then ≈øhould he haue had by his lea≈øe no benefite, and ≈øhould vainely haue procured ≈øuch honorable friend≈øhip: And therefore he ≈øayth, that the ≈øame allegation ≈øugge≈øted in the ≈øaid Bill of complaint, that this defendant meant not, or that his purpo≈øe was not to challenge any thing by demi≈øe from the ≈øaid Deane & Chapter, that was in ≈øhew formerlie demi≈øed to the ≈øaid R. B. is mo≈øt vntruly alledged again≈øt all probabilitie of rea≈øon, when as he wel did know, and the Deane and Chapter al≈øo might vnder≈øtand that the whole rectorie except the vicarage was in ≈øhewe demi≈øed, and the tithes of the ≈øaid towne≈øhips included in the ≈øaid ≈øuppo≈øed demi≈øe, and therefore ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter at the contemplation and reque≈øt of the ≈øaid letters made a lea≈øe of the ≈øaid tithes to this defendant, and to manife≈øt their good intention and meaning towards this defendant for the enioying thereof, the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter gaue this defendant a Tran≈øcript of the Counterpane of the ≈øaide ≈øuppo≈øed lea≈øe vnder their Chapter ≈øeale, and be≈øides this defendant had a rentall deliuered in writing to him, expre≈ø≈øing or conteyning the rents of the towne≈øhips mentioned in the ≈øaide bill of complaint. And this defendant ≈øaith, that his meaning was euer to haue and enioy the benefit of the ≈øaid demi≈øe, and of the thinges therein contayned, and ≈øo he taketh it, the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter ≈øo ment and vnder≈øtood the ≈øame, being per≈øons of ≈øo great learning, iudgement, and di≈øcretion, that they would not graunt the ≈øame things and meane contrarie to their owne demi≈øe: And without that the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter then verely ≈øuppo≈øing that none of the tithes of the ≈øaid towne≈øhips were included or compri≈øed in the ≈øaid lea≈øe of the ≈øaid Rectorie of R. made to the ≈øaide R. B. but the ≈øame were other things excepted out of the ≈øaide lea≈øe, and concealed, and wrongfully detained from the ≈øaid Deane & Chapter, and not within the bounds and limits of the ≈øaid Rectorie, as mo≈øt vntrulie and vainely it is alledged by the ≈øaid bill of complaint, without either rea≈øon, or probabilitie of rea≈øon, or that the ≈øame demi≈øe made to this defendant was mde vpon any ≈øuch fained and vntrue allegation: For he ≈øaith that ≈øuch an ouer≈øight may not be without any rea≈øon imputed to the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter, being men of learning and iudgement, that they ≈øhould ≈øuppo≈øe none of the tithes of the ≈øaide towne≈øhips were included in the ≈øaid lea≈øe of the rectorie of R. made to the ≈øaid R. B. but other things excepted and concealed, and not within
the limits and bounds of the ≈øaid rectorie, when as to the ≈øaid Deane & Chapter by the ≈øaid rentall may apeare, that the townes mentioned in the ≈øaid bill are parcell of the rectorie of R. and the tithes in the ≈øame towne demi≈øed to this defend .
