And the ≈øaid defend further ≈øaith, that he hath not had or euer had in his hands the ≈øaid Indenture of lea≈øe made to the ≈øaid R. B. nor by coulor of hauing thereof hath attempted any ≈øuit, but began his ≈øuit by rea≈øon of his owne lea≈øe made to him, which he taketh is lawfull for him to do. And without that, that there is any other matter or thing touching this defendant materiallie, or effectuallie to be an≈øwered vnto, and not herein confe≈ø≈øed and auoided, trauer≈øed or denied, is true: All which matters this defendant is readie to auerre and proue as this honorable Court ≈øhall award: and prayeth to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed out of this honorable Court, with allowance of his co≈øts and charges &c.

div.head: The ioint and ≈øeuerall Aun≈øweres of W. I. Doctor of Diuinitie, Deane of the cathedrall Church of Chri≈øt in Oxford, of King Henry the 8. foundation, R. P. A. W. T. T. &c. Prebendaries of the cathedrall Church defendants to the Bill of complaynt of T. B. E≈øquier complaynant.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid defendants all aduantages of exception to the incertaintie Sect'. 164. & in≈øufficiency of the ≈øaid bill of complaint being to them the≈øe defendants now & at all times hereafter ≈øaued for direct aun≈øwere thereunto ≈øo farforth as concerneth the knowledge of them the≈øe defend materiall for them to an≈øwere vnto ≈øaith as followeth, that is to ≈øay, that heretofore I. D. in y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid bill of complaint named was an earne≈øt ≈øuitor to the ≈øaid defend W. I. & to the Chapter of the ≈øaid cathedrall Church for the obteining and getting of a lea≈øe of all their the ≈øaid Deane and Chapters tithe barne in P. in the Countie of C. and of all their tithe, corne, and graine, comming, renuing, and yearely growing in the townes and fields of P. afore≈øaid H. &c. in the ≈øaid Countie of Che≈øter, and of the tithe corne, gra≈ø≈øe, Pigge, and Goo≈øe of T. in the ≈øaid Countie of Che≈øter, and of the tithe Haie and gra≈ø≈øe of M. S. and K. afore≈øaid. And for the better obteyning of his ≈øaid ≈øuit, he the ≈øaide I. D. obtained & procured ≈øeuerall letters froÃÑ diuers great and honorable per≈øons of this realme directed to the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter of the ≈øaide Cathedrall Church, whereby the ≈øaid Deane & Chapter were earne≈øtlie moued to grant & yeeld to the ≈øaid reque≈øt of the ≈øaid I. D. At the which time the ≈øaid I. D. did affirme & ≈øay to the≈øe defendants, or to the greater part of theÃÑ that in the premi≈ø≈øes ≈øo by him the ≈øaid I. D. required to be to him demi≈øed, there was then no lawful e≈øtate continuing, but v≈øurped by ≈øuch occupiers as had no right vnto them, and who vouch≈øafed
not to ≈øeeke vnto the Church for them, nor to offer any good offers to them, and y‚Ä¢ contrariwi≈øe him≈øelfe would reduce tho≈øe things to a more profitable reuenue to their Church, or v≈øed other words & ≈øpeeches to the like effect, by rea≈øon whereof, the≈øe defendants or the greater part of them the beter to ≈øati≈øfie their duties towards the ≈øaid ho. per≈øons in a ≈øuit ≈øo rea≈øonable, & tending to the benefit of their Church, did by Indenture vnder their Chapter ≈øeale bearing date the xxii. day of December, in the 35. yeare of the raigne of our ≈øoueraigne Lady the Qu. Maie≈øtie that now is, demi≈øe, graunt, & to farme let the ≈øaid tithe barne & other the premi≈ø≈øes to the ≈øaid I. D. to haue and to hold to him his executors admini≈øtrators & a≈ø≈øignes from the fea≈øt of S. Tho. the Apo≈øtle la≈øt pa≈øt before the date of the ≈øaid Indenture vnto the end and terme of xxi. yeares thence next following fully to be complet & ended as they thinke they might lawfully do, they then not knowing any lawfull lea≈øe to be in being of the premi≈ø≈øes, and yet to the end & intent that no per≈øon hauing any lawfull intere≈øt in y‚Ä¢ premi≈ø≈øes, or in any part thereof for terme of three yeares or more (if any ≈øuch were) might be by the ≈øaid demi≈øe or grant of the≈øe defend preiudiced or hindered, the defendants cau≈øed the ≈øaid I. D. by his ≈øufficient deed in writing as the defendants take it for the better ≈øecuritie, ≈øafetie, & quietnes of their lawfull tenants, whome they meant not ≈øhould be impeached to couenaunt with the≈øe defend that the ≈øaid demi≈øe, nor any couenant, graunt or article in the ≈øaid Indenture of demi≈øe conteined, ≈øhould in any wi≈øe extend to bind or charge any of them the ≈øaid Deane & Chapters tenants, holding or clayming by good & lawfull graunt any lawfull e≈øtate for the terme of 3. yeares at the lea≈øt or more then to coÃÑtinue, any matter or thing in the ≈øaid Indenture of demi≈øe mentioned to the contrary notwith≈øtanding, whereby it doth and may appeare to this honorable Court, that the≈øe defendants haue not done any thing concerning the ≈øaide demi≈øe of the premi≈ø≈øes to the ≈øaide I. D. then as they thinke they and euery of them might lawfully do, making ≈øuch proui≈øion as afore≈øaid that no tenants which held by any lawfull intere≈øt ≈øhould be impeached by this their lea≈øe, without that that to the knowlege of the≈øe defendants or of any of them, the Deane and Chapter of Chri≈øts Church in the Vniuer≈øitie of Oxford, predece≈ø≈øors of the≈øe defendants, did lawfully demi≈øe, grant, and to farme let the rectorie or par≈øonage of R. in the ≈øaide bill of complaint mentioned, with the appurtenances, to R. B. in the ≈øaide bill of complaint named in manner and forme, as in and by the ≈øaide bill of complaint is ≈øurmi≈øed. And without that that to the knowledge of the≈øe defendants or of any of them, the tythes demi≈øed by the≈øe defendants to the ≈øaid I. D. as is afore≈øaid, were lawfully demi≈øed by the Deane and Chapter of the ≈øaide Cathedrall Church, predece≈ø≈øors of the≈øe defendants to the ≈øaide R. B. in manner and forme as is in and
by the ≈øaid bill of complaint ≈øurmi≈øed: And without that that any other matter, clau≈øe, or ≈øentence in the ≈øaid bill of complaint compri≈øed, being materiall in the opinion of them to be by the≈øe defendants aun≈øwered vnto, and not herein ≈øufficiently confe≈ø≈øed and auoided or trauer≈øed and denied is true. All which matters they the≈øe defendants and euerie of them are readie to auerre and prooue as this ho. Court ≈øhall award, and prayen to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed out of the ≈øame, with their co≈øtes by them ≈øu≈øtayned.

div.head: The Replication of T. B. E≈øquier complaynant, to the Aun≈øwere of I. D. E≈øquier one of the defendants.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid complaynant by prote≈øtation not confe≈ø≈øing or acknowledging Sect'. 165. any matter or thing materiall or effectuall in the ≈øaide Aun≈øwere alledged to be true in ≈øuch ≈øort, manner and forme, as the ≈øame are thereby expre≈ø≈øed and ≈øet forth, and by prote≈øtation al≈øo that the ≈øaid aun≈øwere is vncertaine, and in≈øufficient in the lawe to be replied vnto, for diuers great & aparant faults therein manife≈øtly appearing, the benefit and aduantage whereof at all times hereafter to the complaynant ≈øaued and re≈øerued, the ≈øaide complaynant for replication replieth and ≈øaith in all things as before in his ≈øaide bill of complaynt he hath ≈øaid. And further ≈øaith, that all and euerie the matters in the ≈øaid bill of complaint conteined are and be good, iu≈øt, true, certaine and ≈øufficient in the lawe to be aun≈øwered vnto in ≈øuch ≈øort, manner and forme as they and euery of them in and by the ≈øaide bill of complaint by him beene mo≈øt iu≈øtly, plainely, and trulie alledged and ≈øet foorth, and the ≈øame he is readie to auerre and prooue, as it ≈øhall plea≈øe this ho. Court to award. And the ≈øaid complaynant further replieth and ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter the other defendants, named in the ≈øaid bill of complaint, had no meaning or intention to demi≈øe vnto the ≈øaid I. D. any thing that was by them or their predece≈ø≈øors formerlie demi≈øed to this complainants father, and in this complainants po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion by vertue of the ≈øaid lea≈øe, and to giue full ≈øati≈øfaction thereof to this ho. Court. This complainant further ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid I. requiring of the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter to haue a lea≈øe of the towne≈øhip of R. together with the ≈øaid other towne≈øhips in the ≈øaid bill of complaint mentioned by him, procured a lea≈øe from the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter by ≈øuch practize and ≈øugge≈øtion as in the ≈øaid bill of complaint is alleaged, the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter then made an≈øwere to the ≈øaid I. D. that this complainant was the Farmer of R. and held the ≈øame by lea≈øe from the ≈øaide Deane and Chapter: And that they would not in any wi≈øe demi≈øe any thing to the ≈øaid Daniell that was compri≈øed in the ≈øaid lea≈øe made to the complainants father. To which aun≈øwere
the ≈øaide I. D. replyed and ≈øayde that he could do well inough with that Lea≈øe if the ≈øayde Deane and Chapter would be plea≈øed to demi≈øe the ≈øayde Towne≈øhip of R. with the re≈øt of the ≈øayde Towne≈øhips to him the ≈øayde I. D. whereunto the ≈øayde Deane and Chapter then aun≈øwered to this or the like effect, viz. that they woulde not goe about to impeach the ≈øayde Lea≈øe made to the ≈øayde complaynants father: and that it was not fitting for men of theyr cote and qualitie to ≈øtand vpon quirks and quillets in Lawe. By which wordes it euidentlie appeares that the ≈øayde Deane and Chapter were circumuented and mi≈ø≈øed by the vntrue informations of the ≈øayde I. D. to them made in manner and forme as in the ≈øayde bill of complaynt is alledged and ≈øet foorth: and that they knewe not at the time of the making of the ≈øayde I. D. Lea≈øe, that the ≈øayde Towne≈øhips thereby letten were formerlie demi≈øed to the ≈øayde complaynants father in and by the generall wordes of the Rectorie of R. which did include the ≈øayde Towne≈øhips, ≈øo as if there be any ≈øuch defect in the ≈øayde Lea≈øe made to the ≈øayde complaynants father as the ≈øayde I. D. pretendeth by his ≈øayde aun≈øwere, as thys complaynant hopeth there is not, yet for as much as this complaynants father and this complaynant haue euer ≈øince the making of the ≈øayde Lea≈øe, which was many yeares ≈øince, quietly enioyed the ≈øame, and by all the ≈øayde time paid the rent to the ≈øayde Deane and Chapter re≈øerued thereupon: And that the ≈øayd I. D. procured his ≈øayde Lea≈øe by ≈øuch ≈øleights and ≈øubtilties as is afore≈øayde. And that the ≈øayde Deane meant not to demi≈øe any thing to the ≈øayde I. D. that was formerlie demi≈øed to the ≈øayde complaynants father, nor to impeach the ≈øayde Lea≈øe made to the ≈øayde complaynants father vpon any defect what≈øoeuer. Wherefore this complaynant hopeth this honorable Court will compell the ≈øayde I. D. to bring in the ≈øayde Lea≈øe ≈øo procured as afore≈øayde into this honorable Court to be cancelled, or otherwi≈øe di≈øpo≈øed of, as to the ≈øame ≈øhall be thought meete: and will order that this complaynant ≈øhall haue and enioy the benefit of the ≈øayde Lea≈øe made to this complaynants father as afore≈øaide, notwith≈øtanding any ≈øuch defect therein as is pretended by the ≈øaide I. D. And whereas the ≈øayde defendant alledgeth in his ≈øayde Aun≈øwere that the ≈øayde Deane and Chapter to manife≈øt their good intention and meaning towards the ≈øayde defendant, and to the intent he might enioy ≈øuch things as they had to him demi≈øed, did deliuer vnto him a copie or tran≈øcript of the ≈øayde Lea≈øe made to this complaynants father, and a rentall of the ≈øaide ≈øeuerall towne≈øhips in the ≈øayde bill of complaynt mentioned. To that Allegation this repliant ≈øayth, that the purpo≈øe of the ≈øayde Deane and Chapter in
the deliuerie of the ≈øaide copie or tran≈øcript was, that the ≈øaide I. D. might thereby knowe what was demi≈øed or intended to be demi≈øed to the ≈øaide complaynants father. And to the end that he the ≈øayde I. D. might not meddle with any thing compri≈øed in the ≈øaide Lea≈øe, and to no other intent or purpo≈øe, without that that the ≈øaide Deane and Chapter did knowe by the ≈øaide Rentall that the townes mentioned in the ≈øaide bill demi≈øed to the ≈øaide I. D. were parcell of the ≈øaide rectorie of R. and were formerlie demi≈øed to the ≈øaide complaynants father, and without that that any other matter or thing in the ≈øaide aun≈øwere alledged materiall or effectuall for this complaynant to replie vnto, and herein not ≈øufficientlie confe≈ø≈øed and auoided, denied or trauer≈øed is true: All which matters this complaynant is readie to auerre and prooue as it ≈øhall plea≈øe this honorable Court to award: And prayeth as before in his ≈øaide bill of complaynt hee hath prayed.

div.head: The Replication of T. B. E≈øquier complaynant to the ioint and ≈øeuerall aun≈øweres of W. I. Doctor of Diuinitie, Deane of the cathedrall church of Chri≈øt in Oxford of King Henry the eights foundation, R. P. A. W. T. T. &c. Prebendaries of the ≈øaid cathedrall Church defendants.
div.p:
THe ≈øaide complaynant all aduantage of exception to the incertaintie Sect'. 166. and in≈øufficiencie of the ≈øaide aun≈øwere being to him this complainant nowe and at all times hereafter ≈øaued, for Replication thereunto ≈øo farre forth as doth concerne the ≈øaid defendants, and the matter in the ≈øaid aun≈øwere conteined and ≈øet downe replieth and ≈øayth as followeth, that is to ≈øay, that this complainant doth and will auerre and prooue that the Deane and Chapter of Chri≈øtes Church afore≈øaide in the Vniuer≈øitie of Oxford, did demi≈øe the ≈øaid Rectorie and Par≈øonage of R. whereof the premi≈ø≈øes now in que≈øtion are, and ≈øo time out of minde of man haue beene parcell vnto the ≈øaide R. B. by their deede Indented vnder their common or Chapter ≈øeale for diuers yeares yet enduring in manner and forme as this Repliant in and by his ≈øaide bill of complaint hath the ≈øame alledged and ≈øet forth, and did thereupon re≈øerue a great annuall rent which doth continue due and payable vnto the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter of Chri≈øtes Church the ≈øaide defendants, and is and ≈øo hath beene by this Repliant continuallie paid from fea≈øt to fea≈øt, as the ≈øame fea≈øts on which the ≈øaide rent is re≈øerued and appointed by the ≈øaid Lea≈øe to be paid haue yearely happened euen vntill this time, euer ≈øithence this Repliant was intere≈ø≈øed in the ≈øaid Lea≈øe: And that the e≈øtate, intere≈øt, and title of the
≈øaid R. B. for the yeares yet enduring of and in the ≈øaid Lea≈øe and premi≈ø≈øes, is lawfullie come to this Repliant. And further replieth and ≈øaith, that the premi≈ø≈øes in the ≈øaide aun≈øwere mentioned required by the ≈øaide I. D. to be to him by the ≈øaide Deane and Chapter demi≈øed, were not v≈øurped or concealed from the ≈øaide Deane and Chapter, but continuallie ≈øithence their foundations in charge and reuenewe and ≈øo at this time are to the ≈øayde Deane and Chapter, and a rent vnto them by this Repliant aun≈øwered for the ≈øame, without any intention of this Repliant to conceale the ≈øame from the ≈øaide Deane and Chapter, or anie their right vnto the ≈øame, or vnto any other their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions: But contrarywi≈øe this complaynant is, and alwayes will be readie to further them in their right and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions to the be≈øt of his endeuour. And this Repliant moreouer replieth and ≈øaith, without that that the ≈øaide I. D. his information to the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter, or to the greater part of them was grounded vpon anie matter of truth, but vpon a malitious couetous affection and greedie de≈øire which he hath and carrieth to prie and ≈øearch into his neighbors e≈øtates and intere≈øts in their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, not conuerting ≈øuch po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions as he hath of his owne to any ≈øo good v≈øe, or good of his countrey, as that he ≈øhould de≈øerue to haue them augmented with his neighbors, without that that it is true which the ≈øaide I. D. did affirme that the premi≈ø≈øes by him required to be graunted in Lea≈øe by the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter vnto him were v≈øurped by ≈øuch as had no right, and would not vouch≈øafe to ≈øeeke vnto the ≈øaid Church for them, or offer any good offers vnto them as the ≈øaide I. D. for to ≈øerue his owne turne vntrulie ≈øugge≈øteth, for this repliant ≈øaith, that his meaning was and is to ≈øeeke vnto the Church for them at ≈øuch time as in lawe, rea≈øon and con≈øcience it ≈øhall be thought meete, rea≈øonable, or requi≈øite for him ≈øo to do: And hath and will offer vnto them all good offers meete and appertayning for him. In regard of all which, and in re≈øpect the ≈øaide I. D. obteyned the ≈øaide Lea≈øe at the ≈øaide Deane and Chapter their hands vpon vntrue ≈øugge≈øtions and informations which this repliant well hopeth they will at all times a≈øwell in their reioinders as otherwi≈øe at large declare and acknowledge, and in deceipt and abu≈øe of the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter, who woulde not in their graue wi≈ødomes and good con≈øiderations haue ≈øought by and quirks and quillets in lawe in nicitie of penning the formalitie of wordes, to haue ripped and rifled into a long ≈øetled continuing po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of their auncient Farmor, but woulde grauelie, di≈øcretely and adui≈øedlie haue giuen faith, credite and allowance of the doings of their predece≈ø≈øors, as they mo≈øt rea≈øonably and
de≈øeruedly may expect the like allowance of their owne doings by them that ≈øhall ≈øucceede them, that therefore the ≈øayde fraudulent, ≈øubtill, and guilefull lea≈øe by ≈øuch deceipt, abu≈øe, and vntruth obteyned, may by this honorable Court be decreed to be void again≈øt the ≈øaide Deane and Chapter and this repliant: and that the ≈øame may be ordred to be redeliuered vnto the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter, or into this Court to be cancelled, to the end they may thereupon take ≈øuch good cour≈øe therein, as this complaynant doubteth not that if this complaynant had knowne of this vntrue information made by the ≈øaide I. D. vnto them, and had made knowne the truth thereof vnto the ≈øaide Deane and Chapter, before the graunting of the ≈øaide Lea≈øe vnto the ≈øayde I. D. the ≈øayde Deane and Chapter no doubt would haue done, without that that any other matter or thing in the ≈øaide aun≈øwere materiall or effectuall to be replied vnto, and not hereby ≈øufficiently replied vnto, confe≈ø≈øed, and auoided, trauer≈øed, or denied, is true: All which matters this repliant is readie to auerre and proue, as this honorable Court ≈øhall award. And vpon all the ≈øaide matters in the ≈øaid Aun≈øwere conteyned, this repliant prayeth as he before in his ≈øaid bill hath prayed.

div.head: The Reioinder of I. D. E≈øquier to the Bill of complaint of T. B. E≈øquier complaynant.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid defendant ≈øauing vnto him the aduantage of exception Sect. 167. to the incertaintie and in≈øufficiencie of the ≈øaid Replication, and by prote≈øtation not confe≈ø≈øing any thing in the ≈øame to be true, in ≈øuch ≈øort, manner and forme, as in the ≈øame is ≈øet forth and declared, for reioinder thereunto ≈øaith in all and euerie thing and things, as he before in his ≈øaid Aun≈øwere hath ≈øaid. And further doth and will auerre, verifie, maintayne, and prooue all and euery thing, matter, and cau≈øe therein conteyned to be good, iu≈øt, and true, in ≈øuch ≈øort, manner, and forme, as by the ≈øaide defendant in his ≈øaide Aun≈øwere the ≈øame be very trulie expre≈ø≈øed, declared, and ≈øet foorth. And whereas the ≈øayde complaynant by hys replication alledgeth, that the Deane and Chapter ≈øhoulde ≈øaye, that they meant not to impeach the lea≈øe made to the complaynants father: And that it was not fitting for men of theyr cote and qualitie to ≈øtand vpon quirks and quillets in Lawe. This defendant thereunto ≈øayth, that there was no ≈øpeech of quirks or quillets betweene them, but a true and playne meaning, that if the Lea≈øe whereby the complaynant claymed were not good in Lawe, that then this defendant ≈øhoulde haue a Lea≈øe of tho≈øe things hee de≈øired, which with his great co≈øts and trauaile hee obteyned,
accordingly. And for further reioinder thereunto this defendant ≈øaith, that ≈øithence the making of the ≈øaide Lea≈øe to him in the ≈øaide bill of complaint mentioned, hee this defendant brought letters to the Deane and Chapter from one of her Maie≈øties mo≈øt honorable priuie Coun≈øell, to intreate the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter not onely to renew the ≈øaid Lea≈øe mentioned in the ≈øaid bill of complaint, and made to the ≈øaid defendant, but al≈øo mo≈øt hartely de≈øiring them by the ≈øame letters to graunt vnto this defendant other tithes parcell of the ≈øame po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions formerlie demi≈øed to the ≈øaid defendant, at which time the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter, renewed the ≈øaid Lea≈øe, and al≈øo graunted the ≈øaid defendant certaine other tithes parcell of the ≈øame po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions according to the ≈øaid letters, and al≈øo at the ≈øame time the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter promi≈øed vnto the ≈øaide defendant a Lea≈øe of the re≈øt of the ≈øaid par≈øonage, ≈øo that as the ≈øaide defendant taketh it the ≈øaide complaynant greatly abu≈øeth this honorable court with mo≈øt vaine and vntrue ≈øurmi≈øes both in his ≈øaid bill and Replication. And if this honorable court vpon the≈øe ≈øurmi≈øes or ≈øuch like ≈øhould grow to the vpholding of lea≈øes made from corporations which are void in lawe, a thing which heretofore hath not bene graunted vnto others in ≈øuch like ca≈øes it would reuiue or at lea≈øt might be a pre≈øident to reuiue many que≈øtions about ≈øuch lea≈øes which by the common lawes of this Realme long time haue beene determined, whereunto this defendant mo≈øt humblie prayes to be remitted. And whereas al≈øo the ≈øaide complainant alledged that the purpo≈øe of the Deane and Chapter in deliuering of the ≈øaid Tran≈øcript to the ≈øaid defendant was, that he might thereby knowe what was demi≈øed or intended to be demi≈øed to the ≈øaid complaynants father, and to that end that the ≈øaide complaynant might not meddle with any thing compri≈øed in the ≈øaid lea≈øe made to the complaynants father, to which allegation this defendant for reioinder ≈øaith, that he tooke it to the end that he might con≈øider of the validitie or inualiditie of the ≈øaide lea≈øe, vpon the view whereof being a≈ø≈øertained by his learned Coun≈øell that the ≈øaide lea≈øe was void in lawe, he was the rather incouraged to be≈øtow his charge vpon it. And this defendant ≈øaith, that he had a copie of the ≈øaid lea≈øe vnder the handwriting of a GentÃÑ of good calling before the deliuerie of the ≈øaide tran≈øcript to this defend , by which copie the imperfections of the ≈øaid lea≈øe did apeare to this defendant, and al≈øo the perticular names of the tithes of ≈øome townes were mentioned in the ≈øaid copie to be demi≈øed to the ≈øaide complaynants father, the tythes of which townes were afterwards demi≈øed to the ≈øaide defendant by the ≈øaid Deane and Chapter, whereby it may plainely appeare, that the Deane and Chapter meant that the ≈øame lea≈øe made to the ≈øaide complaynants father, if the ≈øame were not good in lawe, might be impeached,
fora≈ømuch as they graunted to the ≈øaide defendants the tithes of ≈øuch townes as were mentioned to be demi≈øed by the ≈øaide lea≈øe to the complainants father, ≈øo that the Deane and Chapter were not mi≈ø≈øed nor circumuented by the ≈øaid defend , nor that the ≈øaid defend obteined his lea≈øe by fleights & ≈øubtilties, nor the ≈øaid Deane & Chapter mi≈øadui≈øed in that they did as in the ≈øaide Replication is mo≈øt vntruly alledged: but this defend verely thinketh that this compl goeth about not only to defraud the ≈øaid defend of his Accion, & to hinder the ≈øaid Deane & Chapter in taking the benefite of the ≈øaid Tithes, but al≈øo it appeareth mo≈øt manife≈øtly, that the plaintife practizeth to trice the ≈øaid defendant in a triall by a Iurie by vntrue witne≈ø≈øes in concealing the ture Lea≈øe made to the plaintifes father: for the plaintife entituleth him≈øelfe vntrulie to the par≈øonage afore≈øaide by a Lea≈øe made by the ≈øaide Deane & Chapter to the plaintifes father, as by an order taken in this Court the 6. of Nouember la≈øt pa≈øt apeareth, and al≈øo by his plea in the Exchequer it apeareth that the plaintife pleaded a lea≈øe made by ye ≈øaid Deane & Chapter to the plaintifes father of the ≈øaid par≈øonage, & proffered by his plea in that court to ≈øhew forth the ≈øaid lea≈øe in Ea≈øter terme la≈øt pa≈øt. And after all the≈øe delatorie delayes the ≈øayd compl pleaded not guiltie in the Exchequer afore≈øaid, & neuer ≈øhewed any ≈øuch lea≈øe, but exhibited his bill of complaint in this honorable Court, ≈øurmi≈øing the ≈øaid lea≈øe to be come to the hands of the defendant, where in troth there is not nor euer was any ≈øuch Lea≈øe made to the ≈øaid plaintife, nor to R. B. the plaintifes father, but ≈øuch a Lea≈øe as in the defendants aun≈øwere is declared, which Lea≈øe being void, & of no validitie in lawe, is the cau≈øe of the plaintifes ≈øuite in this honorable Court, and al≈øo the cau≈øe of his long delay in the Exchequer afore≈øaid: for if the plaintifes father had euer any ≈øuch Lea≈øe as the plaintife pretendeth, he needeth not to v≈øe ≈øuch vaine & vntrue ≈øurmi≈øes in this Court again≈øt the ≈øaide defend in his bill & replication, nor craue an Iniunction in this Court to ≈øtay the defend proceedings at the Common lawe, nor make ≈øecret conueyances to ≈øeuerall per≈øons of the tithes in que≈øtion, nor cau≈øe the ≈øaid tithes to be gathered & carried away by ≈øtrong and by vnknowne per≈øons, nor prote≈øt and auow that the defendant, nor any other for him, ≈øhall euer quietly enioy the tithes in que≈øtion, though he recouered them by all the Lawes in England, nor threaten this defendant and his ≈øeruants to wound or kill them before the defend ≈øhould enioy any part of the ≈øaid tithes, ≈øo that the ≈øaid defend ≈øhal hardly maintaine any Accion again≈øt the true ownere or taker of the ≈øaide tithes for the cau≈øes afore≈øaid, nor quietly enioy the ≈øame being recouered by order of lawe, con≈øidering that the plaintife is a Gentleman of great wor≈øhip, friends and calling in that Countrie where the ≈øaide Tithes do ari≈øe and growe,
wherefore and for that the plaintifes Lea≈øe is a meere void Lea≈øe for the cau≈øes in the Aun≈øwere alledged, and the defendants Lea≈øe a good Lea≈øe, and more beneficiall for the poore Schollers of Chri≈øts Church then the plaintifes Lea≈øe, and no rea≈øon in lawe or equitie if there be no lawfull Lea≈øe in being thereof why the ≈øame ≈øhould not be graunted vnto the defendant. For all which cau≈øes this defend humblie craueth that ye plaintife may ≈øhew forth vnto this court vnder the chapter ≈øeale ≈øuch a Lea≈øe as by his ≈øaide bill and order in this Court he pretendeth: And if the plaintife faile therein then vpoÃÑ the now defendants ≈øhewing to this Court a tran≈øcript of the Counterpane of a Lea≈øe for yeares vnder the ≈øeale of the Deane & Chapter. Whereby it may apeare to this honorable Court, that the Deane and Chapter did not demi≈øe the ≈øaide par≈øonage to the plaintifes father as he affirmeth, but that the Deane with the full a≈ø≈øent & con≈øent of the whole Chapter did demi≈øe the ≈øame to the plaintifes father in the time of King Edward the 6. which is no Lea≈øe of any force in lawe, neither is there any equitie to make it better, but being obteined at the fir≈øt for ≈ømall or no con≈øideration, and long enioyed ≈øince, and now demi≈øed to the defendant for chargeable great and iu≈øt con≈øiderations, that then vpon ≈øight thereof it would plea≈øe this honorable Court to order that the ≈øaid tithes may be ≈øeque≈øtred into the hands of indifferent per≈øons to receyne and keepe them vntill further order ≈øhalbe taken in this Court: And that in the meane time a Commi≈ø≈øion may be graunted out of this Court to examine the true valew of the ≈øaide tithes the≈øe three yeares pa≈øt, to the end further order may be taken in this Court for the hauing thereof, and quiet enioying of the ≈øaid tithes to him that ≈øhall recouer the ≈øame or damages for any part thereof by Accion of Tre≈øpas or otherwi≈øe: And that your Lord≈øhip would al≈øo be plea≈øed to take order for reformation in the premi≈ø≈øes, for that now in this time of contention many tithes are ≈øubtracted and not ≈øet forth at all. And without that that any other matter or thing &c. All which matters &c.

div.head: The reioinder of W. I. Doctor of Diuinitie Deane of the cathedrall Church of Chri≈øt in Oxford of King Henry the 8. foundation, R. P. A. W. T. T. to the replication of T. B. E≈øquier complainant.
div.p:
THe aduantage of exception in and to the incertaintie and in≈øufficiencie Sect. 168. of the ≈øaide replication to the≈øe defendants and euery of them at all times hereafter ≈øaued, the ≈øaid defendants & euery of them for reioinder in all things ≈øay as they before in their ≈øaid an≈øwere haue ≈øaide and do, and will auerre, maintaine and proue their ≈øaide an≈øwere and euery thing therein conteyned to be iu≈øt and true in manner
and forme as they be there declared and ≈øet foorth, and that the ≈øaide Deane and Chapter do not know of any ≈øuch lawfull demi≈øe made to the ≈øaide T. B. as in the ≈øaide Bill and Replication is ≈øet foorth, and that if any ≈øuch lawfull demi≈øe or graunt hath beene made, they haue made ≈øuch proui≈øion as in their Aun≈øwere is declared, that no tenants which hold by any lawfull intere≈øt ≈øhould be impeached by their lea≈øe made to the ≈øaid I. D. whereof the≈øe defendants had ≈øpeciall care, and therefore the complaynant if it ≈øtand ≈øo with him that he haue a lawfull lea≈øe can receiue no preiudice by any thing done by the≈øe defendants. And for further reioinder the≈øe defendants ≈øay, that vpon the ≈øuit of the ≈øaid I. D. greatly pre≈ø≈øed by ≈øundrie honorable per≈øonages in his behalfe and aduerti≈øement, that no lawfull ≈øtate was in being of the premi≈ø≈øes, nor ≈øuch profits aun≈øwered to the Church therefore as appertained with offer on the behalfe of the ≈øaide I. D. to performe many things profitable to their Church, & the defendants not hearing any ≈øuit or motion made therefore by the ≈øaid T. B. and e≈øteeming the premi≈ø≈øes to be out of any lawfull lea≈øe and ≈øo enformed (which if it prooue not true, their graunt is not auaileable) condi≈øcended to the ≈øuit, and entreatie made on the behalfe of the ≈øaid I. D. as in lawe, con≈øcience, equitie, and good hu≈øbandrie towards their Church, which by all good, due, and con≈øcionable meanes they are bound to aduance, they were per≈øwaded it was fit for them to do: And the rather, for that the complainant did not make any meanes, nor ≈øeeke vnto them for it, who if he haue any lawfull lea≈øe of the things demi≈øed to the ≈øaid I. D. from their Church, then cannot the graunt made to the ≈øAid I. D. be of any force or auaile, and if he haue not a lawfull lea≈øe, then cannot the plaintife defend him≈øelfe of ouer great ≈ølacknes to hold it ≈øo long without a lawfull lea≈øe, and in all that time not to di≈øcouer the ≈øame to their church, intending by likelyhood either ≈øo to haue retayned it ≈øtill, or di≈øtru≈øting of their well meaning towards him, as to other their tenants whome their manner is not to di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe or otherwi≈øe to intreate then their demeanors do occa≈øion. And if the things demi≈øed be in charge, or aun≈øwered in reuenue to the Colledge as the plaintife doth alledge, whether it be perticularlie for tho≈øe things demi≈øed to the ≈øaid I. D. or confu≈øedly included with other things, or held as an e≈øtate at will, the≈øe defendants are not a≈ø≈øertained, and if the plaintife did hold them without any lawfull e≈øtate made vnto him, or lawfull e≈øtate continuing, it had beene meete that the defendants or their predece≈ø≈øors had beene made acquainted of this manner of holding of them, and that the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions and reuenews ≈øhould not be caried away vnderhand, or enioyed by coulour of a lea≈øe, when there was no lawfull lea≈øe to warrant it: And had the complaynants then bre ‚Ä¢ e ≈øo readie to further the defendants
in their right and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion to the be≈øt of his indeuour as now he pretendeth to be, this que≈øtion had not hapned, but now ≈øtanding as it doth, if the information of the ≈øaide I. D. made to the ≈øaide Deane and Chapter be not grounded vpon any matter of truth, the ≈øaid complaynant ≈øhall receiue no impeachment by it, the≈øe defendants intending to hold the ≈øaid I. D. to his Couent, that by coulour of his graunt he ≈øhall not call in que≈øtion any tenant of theirs which hold by any lawfull intere≈øt. And if it be grounded vpon matter of truth, the≈øe defendants hope that this honorable court will not giue further allowance to the complaynants pretended lea≈øe then the validitie thereof requireth: Humblie praying further that if vpon this interpleading betweene the ≈øaid T. B. and the ≈øaid I. D. it ≈øhall appeare that the ≈øaid T. B. holdeth that which he ≈øhould not hold, or the ≈øad I. D. vpon any vndue ≈øurmi≈øe or ≈øugge≈øtion to haue obtayned any thing not fit or not meant to be pa≈ø≈øed to him, which the≈øe defendants carrying them≈øelues in a plaine and euen cour≈øe, haue not ≈øo farre looked into, neither do or can charge him ≈øo to haue dealt: That the≈øe defendants might not be preiudiced again≈øt either of them, but left at libertie to do that for the iu≈øt and rea≈øonable benefit and auaile of their Church, which in lawe, iu≈øtice, and equitie, ≈øhall be ≈øeeming for them to do. And further, or more then this the defendants de≈øire nothing, without that that the complaynant hath to their knowledge any lawfull e≈øtate or intere≈øt in the premi≈ø≈øes, or hath ≈øought or offred him≈øelfe vnto their church in ≈øuch ≈øort as hee alledgeth. And without that that the defendants by any quicks, quillets, or nicities in lawe haue ≈øought to rifle into the e≈øtates of their Farmers: And yet humblie de≈øire, that if the complaynants enioy any thing without good lea≈øe which is vnknowne to the≈øe defendants, that he may not be ≈øet in better ≈øtate again≈øt their church then his e≈øtate requireth, but may be referred to their church, of who≈øe dealings he ≈øheweth, neither can ≈øhewe any cau≈øe to complayne, without that that any other matter or thing &c. All which matters &c.

div.head: A bill by one tenant in common of a mannor in the North parts, to haue a commi≈ø≈øion to examine witne≈ø≈øes which be aged and impotent, that their testimonies may remayne of record in perpetuam rei memoriam, for proofe of the plaintifes title to the ≈øaid mannor, for that the Lord Pre≈øident and Coun≈øell of the North parts haue not power to graunt any ≈øuch commi≈ø≈øion.

opener.salute: To the Right Honorable Sir Tho. Bromley Knight, Lord Chauncellor of England.

div.p:
HVmbly complayning, ≈øheweth vnto your good Lord≈øhip your Sect. 169. dayly Orator C. P. of T. in the Countie of C. E≈øquier: That
whereas your ≈øaide Orator and one L. P. of C. in the County of C. be and ≈øtand, or ought to be and ≈øtand ≈øeazed in common in their deme≈øne as of fee among≈øt other things of and in the Mannor of L. with the appurtenances in the ≈øaide County of C. concerning the partition of which ≈øaid mannor, variance, and contention in lawe is like to ari≈øe betweene your Orator and the ≈øaide L. at the common lawe. And for as much as there be yet liuing diuers aged per≈øons inhabiting about the ≈øaide Mannor which do very well knowe the intere≈øt and title of your ≈øaide Orator in and to the ≈øaid mannor in forme afore≈øaid. And for that if the ≈øaide witne≈ø≈øes being very aged and impotent and not likely long to liue ≈øhould fortune to dye before tryall of your ≈øaide Orators e≈øtate and title of, in, & vnto the premi≈ø≈øes, it might thereby be greatly blemi≈øhed, and your ≈øaid Orator in time to come di≈øinherited of his ≈øaid nioytie of the ≈øaide mannor. And for that the ≈øaide witne≈ø≈øes dwelling in the North parts of this Realme be ≈øo aged that they be not able to trauaile neyther before your Honor to be examined in her Maie≈øties high Court of Chauncerie, nor to any other ordinarie place of Iu≈øtice, where the title of your ≈øaide Orator might, or may conueniently come in que≈øtion and tryall by the due cour≈øe of the common lawes of this Realme. And for that the Lord Pre≈øident and Coun≈øell e≈øtabli≈øhed in the North parts (within the precinct of who≈øe Commi≈ø≈øion not onely the ≈øaid Mannor but al≈øo your ≈øaid Orator, and the ≈øaid L. P. do inhabit and dwell) do not v≈øually, nor cannot graunt any Commi≈ø≈øion for the examination of witne≈ø≈øes in perpetuam rei memoriam, although there be great cau≈øe in equitie to graunt the ≈øame. It may therefore plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, the premi≈ø≈øes con≈øidered, to graunt vnto your ≈øaid Orator the Queenes Maie≈øties mo≈øt gratious Commi≈ø≈øion vnder the ≈øeale of this mo≈øt honorable Court, to be directed vnto ≈øome Gentlemen of credit dwelling in tho≈øe partes, as to your good Lord≈øhip ≈øhall be thought conuenient for the examination of ≈øuch witne≈ø≈øes, as by your ≈øaide Orator ≈øhall be produced before them, and to certifie and returne the examinations of the ≈øaide witne≈ø≈øes, together with the ≈øame Commi≈ø≈øion before your good Lord≈øhip into her Maie≈øties high Court of Chauncerie, there to remayne of record ad perpetuam rei memoriam, and to be publi≈øhed at ≈øuch time as to your good Lord≈øhip ≈øhall be thought meete and conuenient. And further to graunt vnto your ≈øaide Orator the Queenes Maie≈øties mo≈øt gratious writ of Subpena, to be directed to the ≈øaide L. P. commaunding him thereby at a certaine day, and vnder a certaine paine therein by your Lord≈øhip to be limited, either to ioyne in Commi≈ø≈øion with your ≈øaide Orator for the examination of the ≈øaide witne≈ø≈øes, or el≈øe to ≈øhewe cau≈øe before your good Lord≈øhip why your ≈øaide Orator ≈øhould
not haue a Commi≈ø≈øion alone for that purpo≈øe, and your ≈øaide Orator ≈øhall accordingly to his bounden dutie dayly pray to Almightie God for the long pre≈øeruation of your Lord≈øhips good health, with increa≈øe of honor.

div.head: A bill of Complaint for detayning of the plaintifes Euidences, for entring into Mannors and Lands, and contriuing of ≈øecret estates.

opener.salute: To the Right Reuerend Father in God Stephen Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, Lord Chauncellor of England.

div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe complayning, ≈øheweth vnto your honorable Sect'. 170. good Lord≈øhip your daylie Orator T. M. Gentleman. That whereas one P. M. elder brother to your ≈øaid Orator was lawfully ≈øea≈øed in his deme≈øne as of fee, of, and in the Mannors of M. & W. with diuers me≈ø≈øuages, lands, tenements, & hereditaments to the ≈øaid Mannors belonging in the County of C. to the yearely value of 50. l . and aboue, and he being of the ≈øaid Mannors and other the premi≈ø≈øes ≈øei≈øed died of ≈øuch an e≈øtate thereof ≈øei≈øed, without i≈ø≈øue of his body lawfully begotten. After who≈øe decea≈øe the premi≈ø≈øes de≈øcended and of right ought to di≈øcend vnto your ≈øaide Orator as brother and next heire of the ≈øaide Peter your ≈øaide Orator, then being but of tender age, that is to ≈øay, of the age of twelue yeares or there abouts. But ≈øo it is right honorable Lord, that all the Euidences, Deedes, Charters, writings, and miniments concerning the ≈øaid mannors and premi≈ø≈øes during the minoritie of your ≈øaid Orator, came ca≈øually to the hands & po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of R. D. E≈øquier, who by cullor of hauing of the ≈øaid Euidences, Deedes, Charters, writings and miniments hath wrongfully entred into the ≈øaide manors, lands, tenements, and other the premi≈ø≈øes, and of the ≈øame hath made and contriued diuers and ≈øundrie ≈øecret and fal≈øe e≈øtates and conueyances to diuers per≈øons to your ≈øaide Orator vnknowne, to his owne v≈øe, to the vtter di≈øheri≈øon of your ≈øaide Orator. And albeit your ≈øaide Orator hath diuers and ≈øundrie times required the ≈øaide R. D. as well to deliuer vnto him the ≈øaid Euidences, Deedes, Charters, writings, and miniments, as al≈øo peaceablie and quietly to ≈øuffer and permit him to enioy ye ≈øaid manors, lands, & tenements, with their appurtenances, yet y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid R. D. hath alwaies hitherto denied & refu≈øed, & yet denieth & refu≈øeth ≈øo to do, coÃÑtrary to all right, equitie, & good con≈øcience: And fora≈ømuch as your Orator knoweth not the certaintie of the ≈øaid euidences, deeds, charters, writings, & miniments, nor whether they be contained in bag or box en≈øealed, or che≈øt locked yea or no, he is like to be without all remedy for y‚Ä¢ recouery of y‚Ä¢ ≈øame by the order & due cour≈øe of y‚Ä¢ coÃÑmon lawe, except your Lo. goodnes be vnto him ≈øhewed in this behalf. In coÃÑ≈øideration wherof it may plea≈øe your good L. to grant
vnto your Orator the King and Queenes Maie≈øties writ of Subpena to be directed to the ≈øaide R. D. Commaunding him by the ≈øame at a certaine day, and vnder a certaine paine by your Lord≈øhip to be limited, per≈øonally to appeare before your good Lord≈øhip in the King and Qu. high Court of Chauncery at We≈øtmin≈øter, then and there to make aun≈øwere to the premi≈ø≈øes &c.

div.head: The Aun≈øwere of the defendant to the ≈øaid Bill, wherein is confe≈ø≈øed the hauing of diuers euidences concerning the lands mentioned in the ≈øaid Bill, and that he is readie to deliuer them to whom the Court ≈øhall order them to belong: And for that the plaintifes father is yet liuing, the defendant prayeth that he may be called into the Court to ≈øhew what title he hath to the ≈øaid euidences, and di≈øclaymeth to haue any intere≈øt in any of the mannors &c. mentioned in the Bill, but an Intere≈øt he may be entituled to haue by rea≈øon of a Statute merchant he hath which was acknowledged by the complaynants father.

opener.salute: The Aun≈øwere of R. D. E≈øquier to the Bill of complaynt of T. M. Gentleman.

div.p:
THe ≈øaid defendant by prote≈øtation not confe≈ø≈øing or acknowledging Sect'. 171. any ≈øuch ≈øei≈øin, dying ≈øei≈øed, or di≈øcent as in the ≈øaid Bill is alleaged for aun≈øwere, ≈øayth, that he is not, nor at the time of the exhibiting of the ≈øaid Bill was not Tenant of the ≈øaid mannors, and other the premi≈ø≈øes, ≈øauing only ≈øuch benefit, intere≈øt, and title as the ≈øaid R. is or may be entituled to haue in or to the premi≈ø≈øes, by rea≈øon of a certaine Statute merchant, or Recognizance knowledged by W. M. E≈øquier, father of the ≈øaid complaynant to Sir P. D. Knight, decea≈øed. Thaduantage of exception thereof, and all other benefits and intere≈øts that the ≈øaid defendant hath or may haue by rea≈øon of the ≈øaid Statute merchant or Recognizance knowledged by the ≈øaide W. M. E≈øquier, father of the ≈øaid complaynant as afore≈øaid, and the execution to be ≈øued of the ≈øame to the ≈øaid defendant alwayes ≈øaued and re≈øerued, the ≈øaide defendant for all other Intere≈øts or Titles di≈øclaimeth in the ≈øaid manors, lands, or tenements. And as to any euidences concerning the ≈øaid manors, lands, and tenements mentioned in the ≈øaid Bill, except one Indenture, and one other writing made by the ≈øaide W. M. and one writing made by the ≈øaid complaynant: The ≈øaid defendant by prote≈øtation not knowing the certaintie what euidences he hath in his cu≈øtodie concerning the ≈øaid mannors and other the premi≈ø≈øes, for that they be in the County of Che≈øter, now farre from the ≈øaid defendant, for aun≈øwere
≈øaith, that the ≈øaide W. M. father to the ≈øaid complaynant long time pa≈øt was ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øaid Mannors, lands, and Tenements of an e≈øtate of inheritance in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion or in v≈øe by di≈øcent from his Aunce≈øtors, and the ≈øaid Euidences came to the hands of the ≈øaid Sir P. D. Knight long time pa≈øt, and by and after the death of the ≈øaid Sir P. D. the ≈øame euidences came to the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid defendant, which ≈øaid defendant de≈øireth that the ≈øaide W. M. which is yet in full life may be called into this honorable Court to ≈øhewe what title he hath or claymeth to the ≈øaide euidences, and the ≈øaide defendant is and ≈øhall be readie to deliuer ≈øuch euidences as he hath concerning the premi≈ø≈øes, except the ≈øaid Statute merchant, and other writings and defea≈øances of the ≈øaid Statute as appertaineth to the ≈øaid defendant to ≈øuch per≈øon or per≈øons to whome this honorable Court ≈øhall award the ≈øame to appertayne: And as to three writings before excepted, the ≈øaid defendant hath them here readie in this honorable Court, to be deliuered to whome this honorable Court ≈øhall adiudge the ≈øame to appertayne, Without that that the ≈øaide defendant hath wrongfully entered into the ≈øaid Mannors, lands, and Tenements, and of the ≈øame hath made or contriued any e≈øtates and conueyances to diuers per≈øons in ≈øuch ≈øort as in the ≈øaid Bill is vntruly alleaged: And without that that any other thing materiall to be aun≈øwered vnto, other then that in this pre≈øent Aun≈øwere is confe≈ø≈øed and auoyded is true: All which matters the ≈øaid defendant is ready to auerre and prooue as this honorable Court ≈øhall award, and prayeth as before he hath de≈øired: And al≈øo that he may be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed out of this honorable Court with his rea≈øonable co≈øts and charges for his wrongfull vexations ≈øu≈øtained in this behalfe.

div.head: A bill of complaint by I. W. and the Lady lane his Wife, daughter and heire of the Lady Iane decea≈øed again≈øt the husband and his wife, for entring into a hou≈øe, and lands, and keeping of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof, for detayning of Euidences, and contriuing of ≈øecret estates in the premi≈ø≈øes.

opener.salute: To the right reuerend Father in God Stephen Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, Lo. Chauncellor of England.

div.p:
IN right humble wi≈øe complayning, ≈øheweth vnto your good Lord≈øhip Sect. 172. your Suppliants I. W. and the Lady Iane his Wife, daughter and heire to the Lady Iane P. decea≈øed. That whereas the ≈øaid Lady Iane P. in her life time was lawfully ≈øea≈øed in her deme≈øne as of fee, of and in one me≈øuage or hou≈øe, with a gardeine thereunto belonging, ≈øet, lying, and being in B. in the Countie of D. and of and in 12. acres of errable land, medow, and pa≈øture, with their appurtenances thereunto
belonging in B. afore≈øaid, and ≈øo being of ≈øuch an e≈øtate thereof ≈øei≈øed about foure yeares pa≈øt died thereof ≈øei≈øed. After and by who≈øe death the premi≈ø≈øes di≈øcended and came as of right they ought to di≈øcend and come vnto your ≈øayde Oratrix, as daughter and heire of the ≈øaide Lady Ia. P. her mother. So it is if it may plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip, that diuers Deeds, Euidences, Charters, Miniments, and writings concerning onlie the premi≈ø≈øes and of right belonging to your ≈øaid Oratrix as in the right of the ≈øaid Lady I ‚Ä¢ . P. by ca≈øuall meanes are come to the hands, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and cu≈øtodie of I. C. Gentleman, and E. his Wife, who by cullor of hauing the ≈øayde Euidences and writings, haue entred into the premi≈ø≈øes, and by cullour thereof haue contriued, conueyed, and made to them≈øelues diuers ≈øecret e≈øtates of the premi≈ø≈øes, and thereby do likewi≈øe detaine and keepe the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øame premi≈ø≈øes from your ≈øaid Orators, albeit they haue beene diuers and ≈øundrie times thereunto by your ≈øuppliants required for the deliuerie of the ≈øame, yet that to do they haue alwayes hitherunto denyed, and yet to denye to the manife≈øt di≈øinheriting of the ≈øaide A. and the great wrong and lo≈ø≈øe of both your ≈øaide Orators, for that your ≈øaide Orators do not knowe the certeine number, or certaine dates of the deedes and conueyances, nor whether they be contayned in bagge or boxe ≈øealed, or che≈øt locked, whereby they be for the recouerie of the ≈øame premi≈ø≈øes cleane without remedie by the ≈øtrict cour≈øe of the common lawes of this Realme. In con≈øideration whereof the premi≈ø≈øes by your good Lord≈øhip tenderly con≈øidered, it may plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip to graunt vnto your ≈øaid Orators the Qu. Maie≈øties mo≈øt gratious writ of Subpena to be directed to the ≈øaid I. C. and E. his wife, commaunding them and eyther of them thereby per≈øonallie to appeare before your good Lord≈øhip in the Queenes Maie≈øties high Court of Chauncerie at a certaine day, and vnder a certaine paine therein by your good Lord≈øhip to be limitted and appointed, then and there to an≈øwere to the premi≈ø≈øes, and further, to ≈øtand to and abide ≈øuch finall order and direction therein as to you Ho. good Lo. with right and equitie ≈øhall ≈øeeme mo≈øt meete and conuenient. And your ≈øaid Orators ≈øhall pray for &c.

div.head:
A bill by the lea≈ø≈øee for yeares of the Scite of a Man ‚Ä¢ or &c. contayning the detayning of the plaintifes lea≈øe of the premi≈ø≈øes, the breaking of the ≈øeales thereof, and that the defendandts by a practi≈øe amongst them, to the intent to impoueri≈øh the plaintife, and vniustlie to get from him the premi≈ø≈øes, haue brought an A≈ø≈øi≈øe in the towne of Salop again≈øt him for the ≈øame, in which ≈øuit there is a partial Iurie returned by the Bayliffes of the ≈øaid towne. And one other ≈øuit comenced again≈øt him for part of
the premi≈ø≈øes by one of the defendaÃÑts before the Coun≈øell in the marches of Wales, and therefore prayeth an Iniunction for ≈øtay of the ≈øaid ≈øuits: and al≈øo a Subpena again≈øt the defendants to appeare and aun≈øwere the bill.

opener.salute: To the Right Ho. Sir Nicholas Bacon Knight, Lord Keeper of the great ≈øeale of England.

div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe complayning, ≈øheweth vnto your Ho. good Lo. Sect. 174. your poore & dayly Orator H. D. of A. in y‚Ä¢ Countie of Salop GentÃÑ. That whereas one Io. late Duke of Northumberland in his life time among≈øt diuers other lands, tenements, & hereditaments was lawfully ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne as of fee, of & in ye manor of A. lying & being within the ≈øaid County of S. and ≈øo being thereof ≈øei≈øed by his deede indented about the 27. yeare of the Raigne of the late King of famous memorie King Henry the 8. by the name of Sir Io. D. Knight, did demi≈øe, graunt, ≈øet, and to farnie let vnto P. C. the Scite of the Manor of A. afore≈øaid, together with the man≈øion or hall place of the ≈øame: And all and ≈øingular lands, meadowes, lea≈øowes, pa≈øtures, feedings, woods, waters, and commons, with all other commodities, duties, ≈øeruices, and cu≈øtomes to the ≈øaid Scyte of the ≈øaid Mannor belonging or in any wi≈øe appertayning: To haue and to hould the afore≈øaid Scyte of the ≈øaide Mannor, and all other the premi≈ø≈øes, and all and ≈øinguler the appurtenaunces to the ≈øaid P. C. his executors and a≈ø≈øignes from the fea≈øt of Saint Michaell the Archangell then next comming after the date of the afore≈øaide Indentures vnto the end and tearme of three≈øcore yeares then next en≈øuing, and fullie to be compleated and ended, yeelding and paying therefore yearely vnto the ≈øaide Sir Iohn Dudley his heires and a≈ø≈øignes foure pound ≈øterling at the fea≈øt of the Annunciation of our Lady, and Saint Michaell the Archangell by euen portions, with diuers other couenaunts, graunts, and agreaments contayned and ≈øpecified in the ≈øaide Indentures, as by the ≈øame more at large it doth and may appeare: By force whereof the ≈øaid P. C. into the premi≈ø≈øes entered, and was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed accordinglie: The ≈øtate and intere≈øt of which ≈øaide P. C. to and in the premi≈ø≈øes, and euery part and parcell thereof, your poore Orator by iu≈øt and lawfull conueyance and a≈ø≈øurance in lawe of long time hath had and now hath, and the ≈øame hath quietlie and continuallie po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed and enioyed for and by the ≈øpace of fourteene yeares nowe la≈øt pa≈ø≈øed by force of the ≈øayd Lea≈øe made to the ≈øayde P. C. by the afore≈øayde Duke, without lette or interruption of anye per≈øon or per≈øons, vntill now of late that the afore≈øayde Lea≈øe is ca≈øuallie come to the hands & po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Ed. Le. of P. in the County of S. E≈øquier, which per≈øons
malitiou≈øly intending your poore Orators impoueri≈øhment and vtter vndoing, haue not only wilfully broken in pieces and di≈ø≈øeuered from the ≈øaid Lea≈øe the ≈øeales of Armes of the ≈øaide late Duke annexed by him to the afore≈øaid lea≈øe, and otherwi≈øe defaced the ≈øame, to the intent your ≈øaid Orator although he ≈øhould recouer again≈øt them by due order and cour≈øe of the lawes of this Realme the afore≈øaid lea≈øe, yet he might be the le≈ø≈øe able to prooue the ≈øaide Lea≈øe to be made by the afore≈øaid Duke, for that they well perceiue the time now ≈øo farre ≈øpent, that very fewe or none of the witne≈ø≈øes that were pre≈øent at then≈øealing and deliuerie of the ≈øaid Lea≈øe be now liuing as they ≈øuppo≈øe: But al≈øo they haue further con≈øpired and agreed among≈øt them≈øelues, together with one R. W. of A. in the Countie of Salop, and R. S. of the towne of Salop and Countie afore≈øaid. That he the ≈øaid R. W. in the name of the ≈øaid Ed. Le. at the only co≈øts and charges of the ≈øaid R. W. ≈øhould arraigne an A≈ø≈øi≈øe of Nouel Di≈ø≈øe≈øine again≈øt your ≈øaid Orator in the Towne court of Salop, for that the afore≈øaid Scyte of the mannor of Acton Renard and other the premi≈ø≈øes are ≈øcituate and lying within the iuri≈ødiction of the ≈øaid Towne court of Salop, ≈øuppo≈øing thereby your ≈øaide Orator to haue di≈ø≈øei≈øed the ≈øaide Ed. Le. of his Freehold in Acton Renard afore≈øaid, intending thereby through his ≈øini≈øter dealing and practi≈øing by indirect meanes with the Bayliffes of the ≈øaide Towne, which haue returned a pannell of ≈øuch Iurors as he the ≈øaide Ed. Le. and other of his friends, kinred, and allyance, might rather through friend≈øhip and fauour then by rea≈øon of any good matter, win and allure to find and giue verdict for the ≈øaid Ed. Le. rather then for your ≈øaid Orator, although his intere≈øt and right to and in the premi≈ø≈øes be very good & rightfull as in very deede it is: But al≈øo the afore≈øaid Ed. L. together with others the per≈øons aboue named, haue, for your poore Orators further trouble, vexation, and expences, con≈øpired and agreed among≈øt them≈øelues together with the aforenamed R. D. that he the ≈øaid R. D. ≈øhould exhibit his Bill of complaint again≈øt your ≈øaid Orator before the Queenes Maie≈øties Councell in the marches of Wales, pretending thereby title and intere≈øt to part of the ≈øaide land, by vertue of a ≈øuppo≈øed lea≈øe for yeares made to one R. D. Clerke, by one A. N. E≈øquier, where in very deede there was neuer any ≈øuch lea≈øe thereof to him made by the ≈øaid A. N. ≈øo that the ≈øaid R. S. hath not by rea≈øon of any ≈øuch lea≈øe, or otherwi≈øe any iu≈øt cau≈øe of ≈øuit again≈øt your ≈øaide Orator: which vngodly inuention and diueli≈øh deui≈øes of theirs they of late put in vre, and practi≈øed again≈øt your ≈øaide Orator, intending thereby through the ≈øuit had and pro≈øecuted by the ≈øaide R. W. in the name of the ≈øaide Ed. Le. afore≈øaid again≈øt your ≈øaide Orator in the Towne court of Salop afore≈øaid, where the ≈øaide Ed. Le. is greatly
friended of kinne and allyaunce, And al≈øo through the afore≈øayde ≈øuite commenced before the Queenes Maie≈øties Councell by the ≈øayde R. D. again≈øt your ≈øayde Orator, where the ≈øayde Ed. Le. is al≈øo greatlie friended and acquainted, and readie at all a≈ø≈øayes as much as in him lyeth, to ≈øuccour and further the ≈øayde R. D. in his ≈øayde ≈øuite again≈øt your ≈øayde Orator in the Courtes afore≈øaide, where the ≈øaide Ed. Le. and R. D. are verie well friended and allyed as afore≈øayde, and your ≈øayde Orator a meere ≈øtraunger and of the Countie of Che≈øter borne a poore ≈øeruingman there altogether vnfriended, and not acquainted, intending by their ≈øayde ≈øuites ≈øo to trouble and vexe your ≈øayde Orator, and to put him to ≈øuch intollerable charges and expences in defending his right again≈øt them, that your poore Orator either for lacke of ≈øub≈øtance and wealth ≈øhould not be able to heare the charge of the ≈øayde ≈øuits in lawe again≈øt them, but eyther be compelled of meere nece≈ø≈øitie to yeeld and giue vp his intere≈øt in the premi≈ø≈øes vnto them, or el≈øe to trouble and mole≈øt your ≈øayde Orator in the ≈øayde Courts, that eyther for want of wealth, or ley≈øure, your ≈øayde Orator ≈øhould not be able to complaine again≈øt them before your Honor, or el≈øewhere to ≈øeeke for redre≈ø≈øe to be had therein by due meanes, and order of the lawes of this Realme. In tender con≈øideration whereof, and for as much as your ≈øayde Orator knoweth not the certayne date of the afore≈øayde Lea≈øe, nor yet the number of yeares therein contayned, by rea≈øon whereof your ≈øayde Orator by meanes thereof is without all remedye by the due cour≈øe and order of the Common lawes of this Realme. May it therefore plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip the premi≈ø≈øes con≈øidered, not onelie to graunt the Queenes Maie≈øties writ of Iniunction to be directed to the ≈øayde Ed. L. R. W. and R. D. and to euery of them, and to all theyr Coun≈øellors, Attourneys, and Solicitors, and to the Coun≈øellor, Attourneys, and Sollicitors of euery of them, commaunding them and euery of them thereby no further to pro≈øecute, or proceede in the ≈øaide ≈øuits or eyther of them, again≈øt your ≈øayd Orator before the Queenes Maie≈øties Coun≈øell in the Marches of Wales, nor before the Bayliffes of the ≈øaid towne of S. vntill ≈øuch further order therein be taken by your good Lord≈øhip as ≈øhall ≈øeeme to ≈øtand with con≈øcience and equitie, but al≈øo to graunt the Queenes Maie≈øties mo≈øt gratious writ of Subpena to be directed vnto the ≈øaid Ed. L. R. D. &c. and to euery of them, commaunding them and euery of them thereby vnder a certayne payne therein to be limited per≈øonallie to appeare before your good Lord≈øhip in the Qu. Maie≈øties high Court of Chauncerie at a certaine day therein to be contained, then and there to aun≈øwere to the premi≈ø≈øes &c. And your
poore Orator ≈øhall dayly pray vnto God for the pre≈øeruation of your honorable e≈øtate long to continue.

div.head: A bill contayning that one being ≈øeazedin fee of an Inne in London, lea≈øed the ≈øame to one for yeares re≈øeruing a rent, the which lea≈øe came by diuers meane conueyances to the plaintife, with couenaunt to make further a≈ø≈øurances: and then they ≈øhewe that the originall Lea≈øe and the meane conueyances, with a deede of guift, are come to the hands of the defendants, by cullor whereof they haue entred into the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Inne, and thereof haue di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the plaintifes, and that they refu≈øe to deliuer the lea≈øe, meane conueyances, and deede of guift, or to make any further conueyances to the plaintifes of the ≈øaid Inne according to the ≈øaid couenant, whereupon the plaintifes pray a Subpena, with a duces tecum again≈øt the defendants.

opener.salute: To the Right Ho. Sir Chri≈øtopher Hatton of the mo≈øt noble order of the garter, Knight, L. Chancellor of England.

div.p:
IN mo≈øt humble wi≈øe complaining, ≈øhewen vnto your good Lo. your Sect. 174. dayly Orators I. L. & N. Mo. Citizens & Clothworkers of the Citie of London, that whereas one A. B. Citizen and Fi≈øhmonger of London was lawfully ≈øeazed in his deme≈øne as of fee, of and in one hou≈øe or tenement, called the ≈øigne of the Lambe, with the ≈øhops, ≈øellers, ≈øollers, together with all & ≈øinguler the appurtenances, ≈øet, lying, & being in the pari≈øh of S. Michaell in Cornehill London, ≈øometimes in the occupation of one I. S. Grocer, and the ≈øaid A. B. ≈øo being of the ≈øaid hou≈øe or tenement & other the premi≈ø≈øes of ≈øuch an e≈øtate ≈øei≈øed, about the month of September in the 36. yeare of the raigne of the late king of famous memory King Henry the 8. did by his deede in writing ≈øufficient in the lawe, demi≈øe, graunt, & to farme let to one W. Lo. citizen & black ≈ømith of London the ≈øaid hou≈øe or tenement, & other the premi≈ø≈øes, To haue & to hold to the ≈øaid W. Lo. his executors & A≈ø≈øignes for the terme of diuers yeares yet enduring at & for a certeine yearely rent thereupon re≈øerued. By force whereof the ≈øaid W. Lo. into the ≈øaid hou≈øe or tenemeÃÑt & other the premi≈ø≈øes entred, & was therof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed acordingly. And the ≈øaid W. Lo. ≈øo being thereof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by his deed indented ≈øufficient in the lawe in or about the month of December in the ≈øaid 36. yeare of the raigne of the ≈øaid late King H. the 8. bargained, ≈øold, & conueyed the ≈øaid Indenture of lea≈øe ≈øo made vnto the ≈øaid W. Lo. & all his title & terme of yeares then to come in the premi≈ø≈øes to one T. H. Citizen & Draper of London his executors & a≈ø≈øignes. By force wherof the ≈øaid T. H. into the ≈øaid hou≈øe or tenement & other the premi≈ø≈øes entred, & was thereof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, & the i≈ø≈øues & profits therof receiued & tooke acordingly, and ≈øo being therof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed died inte≈øtate, after who≈øe decea≈øe, the admini≈øtration of the ≈øaid lea≈øe, & of all other the goods, cattels, & debts of the ≈øaid T. H. were lawfully coÃÑmitted to the hands, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, & di≈øtribution of
Ioane the wife of the ≈øaid Thom. by force whereof the ≈øaid Ioane into the premi≈ø≈øes entred, & was thereof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, & ≈øo being thereof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed maried & tooke to hu≈øband one W. P. Citizen & Vphol≈øter of London. By force of which intermariage, the ≈øaid W. P. into the premi≈ø≈øes entered, & was thereof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, and receiued and tooke the i≈ø≈øues & profits thereof acordingly, and ≈øo being thereof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, in or about the month of Iune, in the yeare of the raigne of our ≈øoueraigne Lady Queene Elizabeth that now is, by one writing or Pole deede ≈øufficient in the lawe, conueyed & a≈ø≈øured the premi≈ø≈øes and all his e≈øtate, right, title, intere≈øt, terme of yeares, claime & demaund, of, in, and to the ≈øame, to one W. M. Citizen & Draper of London, by force whereof the ≈øaid W. M. into the premi≈ø≈øes entred, and was thereof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, and ≈øo being thereof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by his deede of gift ≈øufficient in the law, or by ≈øome other good & ≈øufficient conueyance & a≈ø≈øurance in the lawe, the certaintie whereof for want of the ≈øame your Orators are not able to ≈øhew, did giue, grant, conuey, or a≈ø≈øure the ≈øaid hou≈øe & tenement, & other the premi≈ø≈øes, & all other his goods & chattels what≈øoeuer to one W. B. late of Stoke Albanye in the County of Northampton GentÃÑ decea≈øed, & Bar≈øaba alias Barbara his wife, by force whereof the ≈øaid W. B. and Bar≈øaba alias Barbara into the premi≈ø≈øes entred, & were thereof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, and ≈øo being thereof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, the ≈øaid W. B. in or about the month of Ianuarie, in the 17. yeare of the raigne of our ≈øoueraigne Lady Elizabeth the Qu. Maie≈øtie that now is, made & declared his la≈øt will & te≈øtament in writing, and thereof con≈øtituted & apointed the ≈øaid Bar≈øaba alias Barbara his wife his executrir, and died of the premi≈ø≈øes po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed. By and after who≈øe decea≈øe y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid Bar≈øaba alias Barbara, by right of ≈øuruiuor, & by vertue of the ≈øaid executor≈øhip, held her ≈øelfe in y‚Ä¢ premi≈ø≈øes, & was thereof ≈øolie po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, & receiued & tooke the i≈ø≈øues & profits thereof accordingly, & ≈øo being thereof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, maryed & tooke to hu≈øband one Rob. Williams of Stoke Albanie in the ≈øaid County of Northampton GentÃÑ. By force whereof y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid Rob. Williams & the ≈øaid Ber≈øaba alias Barbara his wife or one of them were of the premi≈ø≈øes lawfully po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, and ≈øo being therof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, they the ≈øaid R. Williams & Ber≈øaba alias Barbara or one of theÃÑ by their or one of their writing of a≈ø≈øignemeÃÑt ≈øufficient in the lawe in or about the month of February, in the 28. yeare of the raigne of our ≈øoueraigne Lady Elizabeth the Queenes Maie≈øtie that now is for and in con≈øideration of a certaine competent ≈øumme of lawfull money of England to them or one of them in hand paid by one George Smith Citizen and Merchantaylor of London, did bargaine, ≈øell, a≈ø≈øigne, and ≈øet ouer vnto the ≈øaid George Smith a≈øwell the afore≈øaid hou≈øe or tenement, the ≈øaid originall Indenture of lea≈øe, the ≈øaide deede of guift, and all other the meane conueyances afore≈øaide, as all the e≈øtate, right, title, Intere≈øt, terme of yeares, v≈øe,
po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, reuercion, claime and demaund of the ≈øaid Robert Williams and Ber≈øaba alias Barbara, and either of them, or of any other per≈øon or per≈øons to the v≈øe and behoofe of them or either of them. And did couenant, promi≈øe, conclude, & agree to & with the ≈øaid George Smith his executors & a≈ø≈øignes, that they the ≈øaid Robert Williams, & Ber≈øaba alias Barbara, & Elizabeth Mo≈øier, wife of the ≈øaid W. M. & euery of them, and the executors and admini≈øtrators of them & euery of them ≈øhould and would at all times after the making of the ≈øaid writing of A≈ø≈øignement to the ≈øaid George Smith as afore≈øaid, and from time to time during the ≈øpace of diuers yeares make ≈øuch further conueyance of the ≈øaid hou≈øe, and all other the premi≈ø≈øes to the ≈øaid George Smith his executors or a≈ø≈øignes as by them or any of them or their or any of their Coun≈øell learned ≈øhould be deui≈øed. By vertue whereof the ≈øaid George Smith into the ≈øaid hou≈øe and tenement and other the premi≈ø≈øes entred, and was thereof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, and ≈øo being thereof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed in or about the moneth of March in the 28. yeare of the raigne of our ≈øaide ≈øoueraigne Lady Elizabeth the Queenes Maie≈øtie that now is by his writing of A≈ø≈øignement vnder his hand and ≈øeale did well and ≈øufficiently giue, graunt, bargaine, ≈øell, a≈ø≈øigne, and ≈øet ouer the ≈øaide hou≈øe or tenement and all other the premi≈ø≈øes, and all his e≈øtate, right, title, intere≈øt, & demaund, of, in, and to the ≈øame, together with the ≈øaid originall Indenture of Lea≈øe, & all other the meane a≈ø≈øignemeÃÑts thereof, & all other writings & euidences concerning the ≈øame vnto your Lo. ≈øaid orators. By vertue whereof your orators into y‚Ä¢ premi≈ø≈øes entred, & were thereof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed & the i≈ø≈øues & proffits thereof receiued & tooke without interuption of any per≈øon or per≈øons. But ≈øo it is if it may plea≈øe your good Lo. that the ≈øaid deede of gift made by the ≈øaid W. M. together with y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid originall Indenture of Lea≈øe & the meane a≈ø≈øignements thereof are ca≈øuallie come to the hands, cu≈øtodie & po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid Robert Williams, & Ber≈øaba alias Barbara his wife, or one of theÃÑ, who by coulour of hauing thereof haue wrongfully entred into the premi≈ø≈øes, & thereof di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed your ≈øaid orators, & the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øioÃÑ thereof together with y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid euidences & writings detaine & keepe froÃÑ your ≈øaid orators, & by meanes of hauing the writing of A≈ø≈øignemeÃÑt made by the ≈øaid R. W. and Ber≈øaba alias Barbara his wife vnto the ≈øaid George Smith in their owne hands & cu≈øtodie, whereby they haue couenanted to make further a≈ø≈øurance vnto the ≈øaid George Smith his executors & a≈ø≈øignes vtterly refu≈øe to deliuer vnto your ≈øaid orators the ≈øaid euidences & writings, or to make them any further a≈ø≈øuraÃÑce of the premi≈ø≈øes, notwith≈øtanding they haue beene ≈øundry times thereunto gently required, but by practize and confederacie with other their complices, aduer≈øaries of your ≈øayde Orators, goe about to impeach, hinder,
and ouerthrow your Orators good and lawfull e≈øtate in and to the premi≈ø≈øes contrarie to all right, equitie, and good con≈øcience, and to the manife≈øt and expre≈ø≈øe wrong and iniurie of your ≈øaid Orators. In con≈øideration whereof, and for that your Orators knowe not the certeine dates, number, nor contents of the ≈øaid Euidences and writings, nor wherein the ≈øame are conteyned, whether in bag or boxe ≈øealed or vn≈øealed, che≈øt or cofer locked or vnlocked, and ≈øo con≈øequently without apt remedie at the common lawe for the recouerie thereof, or to compell the ≈øaide Robert Williams, Barbara his wife, and the Executors or Admini≈øtrators of the ≈øaid Eliz. Mo≈øier or any of them to make vnto your Orators further a≈ø≈øurance of the premi≈ø≈øes, or to keepe or defend their lawfull title thereunto. May it therefore plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip to graunt vnto your Orators her Maie≈øties mo≈øt gratious writ of Subpena, with a Duces tecum to be directed to the ≈øaid Robert Williams and Ber≈øaba alias Barbara his wife, commaunding them and either of them thereby at a certeine day and vnder a certeine paine by your Lord≈øhip to be limited to be, and per≈øonallie to appeare before your Lord≈øhip in her Maie≈øties mo≈øt high Court of Chauncerie, and to bring with them the ≈øaid originall Indenture of lea≈øe, & the ≈øaid deede of gift, and all other the meane a≈ø≈øignements thereof, Then and there a≈øwell to auN≈øwere to the premi≈ø≈øes, as al≈øo to ≈øtand to and abide ≈øuch further order and direction therein as to your Lord≈øhip ≈øhalbe thought to ≈øtand with equitie and good con≈øcience, And your ≈øaide Orators according to their bounden dutie ≈øhall pray to God for your Lord≈øhips long life, with increa≈øe of much honour.

div.head: The ioint and ≈øeuerall aun≈øweres of R. W. and Ber≈øaba his wife defendants to the bill of complaint of I. L. and N. M. complaynants.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid defendants by prote≈øtation not confe≈ø≈øing the ≈øaid B. to be Sect. 175. lawfully ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne as of fee, of and in the ≈øaid hou≈øe or tenement called the ≈øigne of the Lambe, with the ≈øhops, ≈øellers, ≈øollars, and other their appurtenances: Neither that the ≈øaide Brincton did graunt it to the ≈øaide W. L. for certeine yeares vpon a ceerteine rent in maner as the ≈øaid plaintifes haue alledged: neither that the ≈øaid L. was thereof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed accordinglie, and ≈øo being po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, did bargaine, ≈øell, and conuey the ≈øaid Indenture and all his title and terme vnto the ≈øaid T. H. and his A≈ø≈øignees, or that the ≈øaid H. was thereof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed accordinglie, or that after his decea≈øe the admini≈øtration of all the goods and chattels were committed to Ioane his wife, or that ≈øhe was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed thereof by vertue of the ≈øaid admini≈øtration, or after tooke to hu≈øband the ≈øaide Pinchbecke. But the ≈øaide defendants for aun≈øwere ≈øay, that they haue heard that the ≈øaide Pinchbecke was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the ≈øaide
hou≈øe called the Lambe, but whether the ≈øaide Pinchbecke conueyed his e≈øtate to the ≈øaid Mo≈øier, or that the ≈øaid Mo≈øier was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed thereof, or by his deede of gift did a≈ø≈øure the premi≈ø≈øes vnto the ≈øaide B. ≈øhe knoweth not, but ≈øaith, that about 26. yeares ≈øithence the ≈øaid Mo≈øier did giue all his goods and Chattels to the ≈øaid B. and the ≈øaid Ber≈øaba one of the ≈øaid defendaÃÑts, but ≈øhe knoweth not whether the ≈øaid B. was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the ≈øaid hou≈øe, or died thereof po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed. And the ≈øaid Ber≈øaba ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid B. apointed her his Executrix of his la≈øt will, but knoweth not whether the premi≈ø≈øes came to her by ≈øuruiuor≈øhip or executor≈øhip or any other wayes, or whether ≈øhe was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed thereof by tho≈øe or any other meanes. And the ≈øaide defendants further ≈øay, that it is more then they do certainelie knowe whether they or either of them were thereof in right po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed. and the ≈øaide Robert Williams ≈øaith that whether he a≈ø≈øigned or ≈øet our his Intere≈øt or the Lea≈øe thereof in the ≈øaid hou≈øe and premi≈ø≈øes vnto the ≈øaid Smith he knoweth not, but to his remembrance he ≈øealed and deliuered an obligation as he taketh it to the ≈øaide Smith, but vpon what condition he knoweth not, being three yeares pa≈øt, and he altogether vnlearned, without that that the ≈øaid Smith gaue the ≈øaid Robert Williams for his intere≈øt of the ≈øaide hou≈øe any money to his remembrance, neither do the ≈øaide defendants know whether the ≈øaid Smith did bargaine & ≈øell a≈ø≈øigne or ≈øet ouer all his e≈øtate in & to the premi≈ø≈øes, and the Indenture with other writings vnto the ≈øaid complainants. Or that the ≈øaid coÃÑplainants did enter accordingly, or were po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed thereof, or tooke the profits thereof as it is alledged, without that that the originall Indenture of lea≈øe, or y‚Ä¢ meane conueyances or a≈ø≈øignements thereof are come to the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid defendants. But the ≈øaid Ber≈øaba ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid deede of gift made by the ≈øaid William Moy≈øier was in her po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion about 3. yeres now pa≈øt, but what is become of it ≈øince ≈øhe knoweth not: And without that that the ≈øaide defendants haue by coulour thereof vnlawfully entred into the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the premi≈ø≈øes, or di≈øpo≈øe≈ø≈øed the ≈øaid complainants in ≈øuch maner and forme as in and by their ≈øaid bill of complaint is alledged. And without that &c.

div.head: A bill containing that the plaintife is ≈øeazed in fee of the mannor of O. and that one of the defendants is al≈øo ≈øea≈øed of the mannor of C. in fee holden of the plaintifes manor by homage, fealtie, e≈øcuage, and rent, and that the ≈øame defendant hath a≈ø≈øured parcell of his ≈øaid mannor to the other of the ≈øaid defendants in fee, and that the ≈øame is holden of his ≈øaid mannor by the ≈øame ≈øeruices and part of the rent: and that diuers Euidences &c. are come to the hands of the defendants, and that the defendants intend to di≈øherit the plaintife of the rent and ≈øeruices, and that they refu≈øe to pay the plaintife the rent, or to do him the ≈øeruices, and ≈øo prayeth a Subpena again≈øt the two defendants.

opener.salute: To the right honourable and reuerend Father in God Stephen Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, and L. Chauncellor of England.

div.p:
SHeweth & complaineth vnto your good Lo. your dayly Orator Sir Sect. 176. T. H. Knight, that where your ≈øaid Orator is lawfully ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne as of fee of & in the manor of D. in the County of C. of which manor diuers per≈øons being tenants and freeholders do hold by ≈øuit of Court and other ≈øeruices. And where al≈øo one Io. W. of C. in the ≈øaid County of C. E≈øquier is al≈øo ≈øeazed in his deme≈øne as of fee of & in the Manor & Lord≈øhip of C. in y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid County of C. and of & in diuers lands & tenements in C. in the ≈øaid County of C. and ≈øo being thereof ≈øeazed the ≈øame doth hold of your ≈øaid Orator as of his ≈øaid manor of D. by homage, fealty, e≈øcuage, vi. sÃÑ. of rent & ≈øuit of Court from three weekes to three weekes holden within the ≈øaid manor of D. And the ≈øaid I. W. ≈øo being ≈øeazed of the premi≈ø≈øes hath now lately conueyed & a≈ø≈øured part of the ≈øaid manor, lands & tenements in C. afore≈øaid vnto one H. S. E≈øquier his heires & a≈ø≈øignes, by rea≈øon wherof y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid H. S. doth now hold the ≈øaid parcell of land of your ≈øaid Orator as of his ≈øaid manor of D. by the ≈øeruice afore≈øaid, & by part of the ≈øaid rent of vi. sÃÑ. acording to y‚Ä¢ quaÃÑ titie of the ≈øaid lands ≈øo by him purcha≈øed of the ≈øaid I. W. And ≈øo it is right ho. Lo. that diuers deeds, euidences, writings, & courtrolls, a≈øwell toÃÑcerning the ≈øaid manor of D. as al≈øo coÃÑcerning the ≈øaid ren ‚Ä¢ & ≈øeruice before rehear≈øed, be now of late ca≈øually come to the hands, cu≈øtodie, & po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid I. W. and H. S. who by coulour thereof do intend now vtterly to di≈øinherit your ≈øaid Orator of his ≈øaid rent and ≈øeruices, and do deny & refu≈øe either to pay vnto your ≈øaid Orator his ≈øaid rent, or el≈øe to do vnto him his ≈øaid ≈øeruices: And although your ≈øaid Orator hath diuers & ≈øundry times required y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid I. W. & H. S. a≈øwell to deliuer vnto him the ≈øaid Euidences, deeds, writings, & courtrolls, as al≈øo to pay & do vnto him the ≈øaid rent & ≈øeruices according as of right they ought to do, yet neuertheles the ≈øaid I. W. & H. S. haue vtterly denied & refu≈øed alwaies the ≈øame to do coÃÑtrary to all equitie & coÃÑ≈øcience. And fora≈ømuch as your ≈øaid Orator knoweth not the certaintie of the ≈øaide deedes, euidences, & writings, nor wherein y‚Ä¢ ≈øame be conteined, nor al≈øo knoweth not the certaintie of the ≈øaid lands & tenements that the ≈øaide H. S. hath purcha≈øed of the ≈øaid I. W. therefore he is not only clearely without remedie for the recouerie of the ≈øaid deeds and euidences, but al≈øo by the order of the common lawe is not able to make any auowrie vpon the ≈øaid H. S. for his ≈øaid rent. In con≈øideration whereof may it plea≈øe your good Lo. to graunt the King and Queenes mo≈øt gratious writ of Subpena to be directed vnto the ≈øaide I. W. and H. S. commaunding them and either of them by vertue thereof per≈øonallie
to apeare before your good Lord≈øhip in the King and Queenes mo≈øt honorable Court of Chauncerie at We≈øtmin≈øter, there to make aun≈øwere to all the premi≈ø≈øes, and therein to abide ≈øuch order and direction as to your good Lord≈øhip ≈øhall be thought con≈øonant to equitie and good con≈øcience, and your ≈øaid Orator ≈øhall dayly pray to God for your good Lord≈øhip in health and honour long to continue.

div.head: An An≈øwere to the bill next before. The Aun≈øwere of H. S. E≈øquier to the bill of complaynt of Sir T. H. Knight.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid defendant ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid bill of complaynt is vntrue, Sect. 177. vncerteine & in≈øufficient in the lawe to be aun≈øwered vnto, and the matters therein conteined are determinable and ought to be determined at the Common lawe within the Countie Palantine of C. within which Countie a≈øwell the ≈øaide complaynant as the ≈øaide defendant do dwell. And al≈øo the ≈øaid mannor and other the premi≈ø≈øes mentioned in the ≈øaid bill of complaint, and ≈øuppo≈øed to be holden of the ≈øaid complainant do lie and be: and further ≈øaith, that it apeareth by the ≈øaide bill of complaint, that although it were true as it is not indeede that the ≈øaid mannor of Capi≈øthorne were holden of the ≈øaide complainant in ≈øuch manner and forme as in his ≈øaid bill is ≈øurmi≈øed, yet the ≈øaid defendant doth not nor can or ought by the lawe of the realme hold ≈øuch parcell of the ≈øame mannor of C. as he hath purcha≈øed by the ≈øeruices mentioned in the ≈øaide bill. And al≈øo that the ≈øaide complainant is compellable by the lawes and ≈øtatutes of this realme to auow at his perill vpon ≈øuch parcell of the ≈øaid mannor of C. as is ≈øeuered froÃÑ the ≈øame in fee ≈øimple for ≈øuch portion of the ≈øaid rent as the value of the ≈øame parcell ≈øo ≈øeuered doth amount vnto, and hath his ordinarie remedie for the ≈øame by the order of the common lawes and of the ≈øtatutes of this realme in that ca≈øe prouided, if the allegations of his bill be true, and the ≈øaid rent can not by the order of the common lawe of this realme be aportioned in this honorable Court. For which matters and other cau≈øes aparant in the ≈øaid bill the ≈øaid defendant ≈øaith, that the ≈øame bill and the matters conteyned in the ≈øame be in≈øufficient in the lawe to be aun≈øwered vnto: And that he is not compellable, nor ought by the lawe to be compelled to make any further aun≈øwere to the ≈øame, and demurreth in lawe vpon the ≈øame, and prayeth to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed out of this honorable Court without any further aun≈øwere to be made thereunto. And if this Court will not nor do admit this demurrer, but the ≈øame notwith≈øtanding will compell the ≈øaid defendant to make further aun≈øwere to the ≈øaid bill as otherwi≈øe then by compul≈øatorie order of this Court the
≈øaid defendant clayming the aduantage of the lawes of this realme whereby he ought to be tryed, doth not nor will make any further or other aun≈øwere to the ≈øame, then the ≈øaide defendant after ≈øuch order made by this Court to make further an≈øwere ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid I. W. named in the ≈øaid bill of complaint was ≈øeazed in his deme≈øne as of fee, of and in one Me≈øe and certeine lands and tenements conteyning by e≈øtimation 60. acres or thereabouts, which me≈øe and lands is called W. and are within the Countie of C. afore≈øaid, and are of the yearely rent and value of 51. sÃÑ. 4. d . and the ≈øaid I.
