W. ≈øo being thereof ≈øei≈øed for certeine ≈øummes of money to him paid, did bargaine and ≈øell the ≈øaid Me≈øe, lands, and tenements called W. vnto the ≈øaid defendant and his heires, and thereupon did by ≈øufficient and lawfull conueyance in the lawe conuey and a≈ø≈øure the ≈øaid Me≈øe, lands, and tenements called W. vnto t ‚Ä¢ e ≈øaid defendant and his heires, to the proper v≈øe of the ≈øaid defendant and of his heires, by force whereof the ≈øaid defendant entred into the premi≈ø≈øes, and was thereof ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne as of fee, and the ≈øame e≈øtate continued vntill about the fifth yeare of the raigne of the late King Eow, the ≈øixt, that one R. B. by the commaundement of the ≈øaid complainant did enter into the ≈øaid Me≈øe, and into one pa≈øture or croft, coÃÑ
‚Ä¢ eyning by e≈øtimation 2. Acres of land, lying on y‚Ä¢ Southea≈øt part of the ≈øaid Me≈øe and adioyning to the ≈øame, and into one Orchard and one garden lying to the ≈øaid me≈øe, being parcell of the ≈øaide lands and tenements called W. and in W. afore≈øaid, and thereof did di≈ø≈øea≈øe the ≈øaid defendant to the v≈øe of the ≈øaid complainant, to which entrie and di≈ø≈øei≈øin the ≈øaid complainant did agree, by force whereof the ≈øaid complainant was and yet is ≈øea≈øed in his deme≈ø ‚Ä¢ e as of fee by di≈ø≈øei≈øin as is afore≈øaid of the ≈øaid me≈øe, orchard, garden and croft, without that that the ≈øaid defendant I. W. did hold the ≈øaid mannor of Capi≈øhorne of the ≈øaide complainant in manner and forme and by ≈øuch ≈øeruices as by the ≈øaid bill of complaint is alledged. Or that there is any ≈øuch mannor of C. to the knowledge of this defendant, or that the ≈øaid I. W. did or doth hold the ≈øaid mannor of C. of the ≈øaid complainant to the knowledge of the ≈øaide defendant, or that the ≈øaide defendant had any other me≈øes, lands, or tenements which at any time were the me≈øes, lands, or tenements of the ≈øaide I. W. other then the ≈øaid me≈øe, lands, and tenements called W. or that the ≈øaid me≈øe, lands, and tenements called W. are or at any time were parcell of the ≈øaid mannor of T. and if the ≈øaid me≈øe, lands, and tenements called W. had beene parcell of the ≈øaid mannor of C. as they were not, or if the ≈øaide defendant did hold the ≈øaide me≈øe, lands, and tenements called W. of the ≈øaid complainant acording to the quantitie of the ≈øaid rent and ≈øeruice, as the ≈øaid complainant by his ≈øaide bill of complaint hath ≈øuppo≈øed as he doth not indeede, yet
for≈øomuch as the ≈øaid complainant is ≈øei≈øed of parcell of the ≈øaid lands and tenements called W. by di≈ø≈øei≈øin as is afore≈øaide, and the ≈øame me≈øe, lands & tenements called Woodford are holden all by one entire tenure, the whole rent and ≈øeruices are ≈øu≈øpended during the time of the ≈øaide de≈øei≈øin, and the ≈øaid defendant is and ought by the lawe to be di≈øcharged during the time of the ≈øaide di≈ø≈øei≈øin, without that that any Euidences, deedes, writings or Courtrowles concerning the ≈øaid mannor of Ouer, or the ≈øaid rent and ≈øeruice at any time came to the hands, cu≈øtodie, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid defendant, or that the ≈øaid defendant doth intend vtterly to di≈øinherit the ≈øaide complainant of the ≈øaid rent and ≈øeruices, or doth wrongfullie denie to do the the ≈øaid complaynant any ≈øeruices which he ought to do or pay, or that any other thing &c. All which matters &c.

div.head: A Replication to the An≈øwere next before. The Replication of Sir T. H. Knight, to the Aun≈øwere of H. S. E≈øquier.
div.p: THe ≈øaid complainant ≈øaith in all and euery thing as he before in his Sect'. 178. bill hath ≈øaide, and auerreth all and euery thing therein conteined to be good and true in ≈øuch manner and forme as in his ≈øaid bill is alledged, without that that the ≈øaide R. B. named in the ≈øaide aun≈øwere did wrongfullie enter by the commaundement of this complaynant into the ≈øaid me≈øe & other the lands named in the ≈øaid an≈øwere, being parcell of the ≈øaid lands & tenements called Woodford, or thereof di≈ø≈øei≈øed the ≈øaid defend to the v≈øe of the ≈øaid compl as by the ≈øaide an≈øwere it is vntrulie alledged, or that the ≈øaid compl did agree to any ≈øuch entrie & di≈ø≈øei≈øin, as by the ≈øaid aun≈øwere is ≈øuppo≈øed, or that this compl was or is by force thereof ≈øei≈øed by di≈ø≈øe≈øin of the ≈øaide me≈øuage, orchard, and garden named in the ≈øaid an≈øwere, as by the ≈øaid an≈øwere is vntruly alledged, or that any other matter or thing alledged in the ≈øaide an≈øwere materiall to be replied vnto, which heere in this replication is not confe≈ø≈øed and auoided, denied or trauer≈øed, is true. All which matters &c.

div.head: A bill containing that the plaintife by bargaine and ≈øale, by feoffement and fine bought one me≈øe &c. in fee, and that diuers euidences concerning the premi≈ø≈øes are ca≈øually come to the plaintifes hands, and that by cullour thereof the plaintife hath entred into parcell of the premi≈ø≈øes and expul≈øed the plaintife from the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof, and wrongfully keepeth the ≈øame.

opener.salute: To the Right Ho. and the reuerend Father in God Stephen Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter.

div.p:
COmplayning ≈øheweth vnto your ho. Lo. your Orator H. S. E≈øquier, Sect. 179. that where one I. W. of C. in the County of C. was ≈øei≈øed in
his deme≈øne as of fee, of & in one me≈øe, one gardeÃÑ, one orchard, 60. acres of land, meadow, wood, and pa≈øture, with the appurtenances in W. called W. in the Countie of C. and the ≈øaid I. W. and his ance≈øtors, who≈øe heire he is, did coÃÑtinue peaceable po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the premi≈ø≈øes by the ≈øpace of 100. yeares and aboue, and the ≈øaid I. W. ≈øo being thereof ≈øei≈øed for certeine great ≈øummes of money to the ≈øaid I. W. by your ≈øaid Orator coÃÑtented & paid, did bargaine & ≈øell the premi≈ø≈øes vnto your ≈øaid Orator & his heires to the proper v≈øe of your ≈øaid Orator & of his ≈øaid heires for euer, and thereupon did by his deede ≈øufficient in the lawe, giue, grant, & confirme y‚Ä¢ premi≈ø≈øes vnto your ≈øaid Orator & his heires for euer. And for a further a≈ø≈øurance thereof to be had vnto your ≈øaid Orator and his heires, the ≈øaid I. W. before the Iu≈øtice of y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid County of C. did leuie a fine ≈øur conu≈øance de droit of the ≈øaid me≈øe, lands, and tenements vnto your ≈øaid Orator, and by by the ≈øame fine the ≈øaid I. W. did knowledge all the right which he had in the ≈øame me≈øe, lands, & tenements to be the right of your ≈øaide Orator, as tho≈øe which your ≈øaide Orator had of his gift, as by the ≈øaid deede & fine more at large it doth & may appeare, by force whereof your ≈øaid Orator entred into the premi≈ø≈øes, & was thereof ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne as of fee. But ≈øo it is if it may plea≈øe your hon. Lo. that diuers euidences, deeds, e≈øcripts & miniments concerning the premi≈ø≈øes are ca≈øually come to the haÃÑds, cu≈øtodie & po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of one Sir T. H. Knight, who by coulour of hauing thereof hath wrongfully entred into the ≈øaid me≈øe, orchard, gardeine, and into one croft conteining by e≈øtimation 2. acres of land lying & adioyning vnto the ≈øaid me≈øe on the Southea≈øt part of the ≈øaid me≈øe parcell of the premi≈ø≈øes, and expul≈øed your ≈øaid orator from the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof: And the ≈øaid Sir T. H. doth ≈øtill wrongfully keepe your ≈øaid Orator from the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øaid me≈øe, orchard, garden, & croft. And although your ≈øaid Orator haue diuers times required the ≈øaid Sir T. H. not only to permit and ≈øuffer your ≈øaid orator to haue & inioy the ≈øaid me≈øe, lands, and tenements, but al≈øo to make deliuerie thereof vnto your ≈øaid orator, which to do the ≈øaid Sir Tho. at all times hath refu≈øed & yet doth refu≈øe, contrary to right, equitie, and con≈øcience. In con≈øideration whereof, and for ≈øo much as your ≈øaide Orator knoweth not the certaintie of the ≈øaide Euidences, deedes and writings, nor wherein they be conteyned, therefore he is without remedie by the order of the common lawe. It may therefore plea≈øe your honorable Lord≈øhip to graunt &c.

div.head: The Aun≈øwere of Sir T. H. Knight to the Bill of complaint of H. S.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid defend ≈øaith y‚Ä¢ the ≈øaid bill of compl is vncerteine & in≈øufficient Sect'. 180. in y‚Ä¢ law to be an≈øwered vnto, & the matters therein coÃÑteined
beene very vntruly deui≈øed, imagined, and ≈øet forth, without any good matter or iu≈øt cau≈øe, only to the intent to put this defendant to wrongfull vexation, trouble, and expences. And for aun≈øwere vnto the ≈øaide in≈øufficient bill, the ≈øaid defendant ≈øaith, that our late ≈øoueraigne Lord King Henry the eight late King of England, father to our mo≈øt ≈øoueraigne Ladie that now is, was ≈øei≈øed among other lands in his deme≈øne as of fee, as in the right of his ≈øaid Crowne of and in the Mannor and Lord≈øhip of D. with the appurtenances and hamlets to the ≈øame appertaining, ≈øet, lying, and being in the Countie of C. whereof the ≈øaid me≈ø≈øuage, garden, orchard, and croft, conteining by e≈øtimation the ≈øaid two Acres of land lying in D. parcell of the premi≈ø≈øes in the ≈øaid bill of complaint mentioned be parcell: And our ≈øaid late ≈øoueraigne Lord King Henry the eight being ≈øo thereof lawfullie ≈øei≈øed a≈øwell for and in con≈øideration of the faithfull ≈øeruice that the ≈øaide defendant had done to the ≈øaid late King Henry the 8. as al≈øo for diuers ≈øummes of money paid by y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid defendant to the ≈øaid late King Hen. the 8. the ≈øaid late King Henry the 8. by his letters patents in this honorable Court readie to be ≈øhewed, the date whereof the ≈øaid defendant doth not perfectly remember, did giue and graunt of his pre≈øcience and meere motion vnto the ≈øaid defendant the ≈øaid mannor and other the premi≈ø≈øes in the ≈øaide Aun≈øwere mentioned, to haue and to hold vnto the ≈øaid defendant and his heires for euer, by force whereof this defendant vnto the premi≈ø≈øes entred, and thereof was ≈øei≈øed acordingly, and tooke the profits thereof acordingly, and yet doth as well and lawfull it was and is for him to do. And further the ≈øaid defendant ≈øaith, that ≈øuch euidences, deedes, e≈øcripts, and writings concerning the premi≈ø≈øes mentioned in this aun≈øwere as the ≈øaid defendant hath concerning the ≈øame, he the ≈øaid defendant doth detaine and keepe them for the pre≈øeruation of the right, title and intere≈øt that he hath to the ≈øame as well and lawfull is for him to do. And furthermore the ≈øaide defendant ≈øaith, that as to any other deedes, euidences, writings and miniments concerning the re≈øidue of the ≈øaid lands and tenements ≈øpecified in the ≈øaide bill of complaint, or any parcell thereof in W. afore≈øaid, which do concerne the Intere≈øt, inheritance, and title of the ≈øaid complaynant, the ≈øaid defendant aun≈øwereth and ≈øaith, that he doth not withhold any, nor yet at any time hath withholden from the ≈øaide complaynant any ≈øuch as by the ≈øaide bill is vntruly depo≈øed, without that that the ≈øaid Io. W. of C. named in the ≈øaid bill was ≈øei≈øed in his dem ‚Ä¢ ≈øne as of fee of or in y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid me≈øe, orchard, garden, or croft mentioned in the ≈øaid bill or any parcell thereof, ≈øet, lying, and being in D. afore≈øaid. Or that the ≈øaid I. W. or his aunce ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ors who≈øe heire he is did continue peaceable po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the premi≈ø≈øes by the ≈øpace of 100. yeares and aboue as by the ≈øaide bill of complaint is
vntrulie ≈øurmi≈øed, or that the ≈øaid Io. ≈øo being thereof ≈øei≈øed for certeine ≈øummes of money, did bargaine or ≈øell, or might lawfully bargaine and ≈øell the premi≈ø≈øes conteyned in the ≈øaid Aun≈øwere or any part thereof ≈øet, lying, and being in D. or the Lord≈øhip of the ≈øame, to the ≈øaid complaynant and his heires as by the ≈øaid bill it is in like manner vntrulie alledged and ≈øuppo≈øed. Or that the ≈øaid Io. before the Iu≈øtice of A≈ø≈øi≈øe of the ≈øaid Countie of C. did leuie a fine ≈øur conu≈øance de droit of the ≈øaid me≈øe and other the premi≈ø≈øes mentioned in the ≈øaid aun≈øwere, or of any parcell thereof vnto the ≈øaid complainant, as by the ≈øaid bill is al≈øo vntrulie ≈øurmi≈øed: or that by the ≈øaid ≈øuppo≈øed fine the ≈øaid Io. did knowledge, or might lawfullie knowledge the ≈øaid me≈øe and other the premi≈ø≈øes conteined in the ≈øaid bill to be the right of the ≈øaid complainant, as tho≈øe which the ≈øaid complainant had of his gift as it is in like manner vntrulie ≈øuppo≈øed, or that by force thereof the ≈øaid complainant entred or might lawfullie enter into the ≈øaid me≈øe and other the premi≈ø≈øes in this aun≈øwere mentioned, or that he was thereof lawfullie ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne as of fee, as by the ≈øaid bill it is al≈øo vntrulie ≈øurmi≈øed, and without that that any other matter or thing alledged in the ≈øaide bill materiall to be aun≈øwered vnto, which heere in this aun≈øwere is not confe≈ø≈øed and auoided, denied or trauer≈øed, is true. All which matters this defendant is readie to auerre 7 prooue as this Court ≈øhall award, and prayeth to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed out of this Court with his co≈øts and expences in this wrongfull vexation ≈øu≈øtained.

div.head: The Replication of H. S. to the Aun≈øwere of Sir T. H. Knight.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid complainant ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid bill of complaint is true, Sect. 181. certeine, and ≈øufficient in the lawe to be aun≈øwered vnto, and not imagined and ≈øet forth by the ≈øaid complainant of malice, or wrongfullie to put the ≈øaid defendant to co≈øts, labour, or expences, for the ≈øaide complainant auerreth his ≈øaid bill of complaint and euery thing therein conteined to be good and true in manner and forme as in the ≈øaid bill of complaint is alledged, without that that the late King Henry the 8. named in the ≈øaide aun≈øwere was ≈øeazed in his deme≈øne as of fee as in the right of his Crowne of and in the ≈øaide me≈øe, garden, orchard, and croft, conteining by e≈øtimation two acres of land lying in D. parcell of the lands and tenements mentioned in the ≈øaide bill of complaint, as parcell of the mannor and Lord≈øhip of D. in the ≈øaid Countie of C. or that the ≈øaide me≈øe, garden, orchard, and croft, or any part or parcell thereof is or at any time was parcell of the ≈øame mannor, or that the ≈øaid late King by his letters patents gaue and graunted vnto the ≈øaide defendant and his heires for euer the ≈øaide me≈øe, garden, orchard, and
croft, or that the ≈øaide late King Henry the 8. did or might lawfullie giue the ≈øaid me≈øe, garden, orchard, and croft vnto the ≈øaid defendant, or that the ≈øaide me≈øe, garden, orchard and croft, did or might lawfullie pa≈ø≈øe or come vnto the ≈øaid defend by the ≈øaid graunt, if any ≈øuch graunt had beene as there was not indeede, or that the ≈øaid defend by force of any ≈øuch graunt or letters patents entred into the premi≈ø≈øes la≈øt before mentioned, and was thereof ≈øeazed acordinglie, or did or might lawfullie take the i≈ø≈øues and profits thereof by force of the ≈øame letters patents, or that any other thing &c. All which matters the ≈øaide defendant &c. And prayeth that it may be ordred by this ho. Court, that the ≈øaid complainant may quietly enioy the lands and tenements mentioned in the ≈øaid bill of complaint, without let, ≈øuit, vexation, or impediment of the ≈øaide defendant, or of his heires, or any other per≈øon or per≈øons by his or their con≈øent, ayde, title, or procurement.

div.head: A Supplication exhibited by a Scot to the priuie Coun≈øell (his ≈øuit being commended to the Queene by letters from the King of Scots) robbed by Pirats vpon the Sea, who de≈øireth a Commi≈ø≈øion to examine witne≈ø≈øes to prooue the Piraci ‚Ä¢ .

opener.salute: To the Right Ho. the Lords and others of her Maie≈øties honorable priuie Coun≈øell.

div.p: MO≈øt humbly be≈øeecheth your good Lo. your di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Suppliant Sect. 182. G. P. of the towne of Leth in Scotland, being lately robbed and ≈øpoiled by certaine engli≈øh pirats vpon the ≈øeas of all his goods to the value of 400. l . or there abouts, as by certaine proceedings in the court of y‚Ä¢ Admiraltie plainly appeareth, and for that this cau≈øe hath bin commended to her Maie≈øtie by the king of Scots his letters, your Lo. poore ≈øuppliant therefore hopeth the rather to be relieued in any of his rea≈øonable & con≈øcionable ≈øuits & reque≈øts at your ho. hands. It may therefore plea≈øe your good Lo. to tender & pitie the ca≈øe of your ≈øaid Suppliant, & to graunt vnto him your ho. letters of Commi≈ø≈øion to be directed to the Maior of the towne of H. in the Countie of P. & others Iu≈øtices of peace & Aldermen of the ≈øaid towne, geuing them Aucthoritie thereby to call before them the per≈øons who≈øe names be ≈øub≈øcribed, & vpon their corporall oathes to examine theÃÑ vpon ≈øuch que≈øtions or interrogatories as vpon your ≈øaid ≈øuppliants behalfe ≈øhalbe mini≈øtred vnto them, and to certifie their ≈øayings & depo≈øitions touching the premi≈ø≈øes vnto your good Lo. vnder their hands & ≈øeales, with all coÃÑuenient ≈øpeede they may. And your good Lo. poore ≈øuppliant ≈øhal dayly pray to God for the pre≈øeruation of your good Lo. in all health & honour long to continue.

list.head: the witne≈ø≈øes.

C. D.
E. F.

postscript.head: The indor≈øement of the Supplication.

p.q: The humble petition of G. P. of Leth in Scotland.

postscript.p: And then endor≈øe the contents of the petition.

div.head: A Supplication by two maymed ≈øouldiers, to haue the Coun≈øels licence to begge, or to haue ≈øome maintenance allowed them for the ‚Ä¢ pre≈øent ≈øtay and reliefe, vntill two Almes roumes which the Queene gaue in reuercion do become voide.

opener.salute: To the Right Ho. the Lords &c.

div.p: HUmblie ≈øhewe and be≈øeech your good Lo. your very poore and Sect. 183. humble Suppliants A. G. and B. C. That whereas in con≈øideration of the ≈øundrie maymes and hurts of your ho. Suppliants in her Maie≈øties ≈øeruice, it plea≈øed her highne≈ø≈øe of her mo≈øt gratious di≈øpo≈øition and pitifull con≈øideration of vs, to giue and be≈øtowe vpon vs the reuercion of two ≈øeuerall Almes roomes in the Ho≈øpitall of D. in the Citie of London during our liues when the ≈øame ≈øhall become voide, the which be yet full, and after their deathes which now be in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øame diuers reuercions are graunted to ≈øeuerall per≈øons of the ≈øame, by rea≈øon whereof your Lo. poore Suppliants are neuer likely to enioy the ≈øame roumes for their reliefe and ≈øu≈øtenance. In con≈øideration whereof, and for that your ho. ≈øaid ≈øuppliants be in very poore and weake e≈øtate by rea≈øon of their ≈øaide maymes and hurts, and greatly indebted to diuers per≈øons, being charged with wiues and many children, not hauing any thing now left them to maintaine, helpe, or relieue them≈øelues withall in this their great pouertie and extremities, but are readie to peri≈øh for lacke of ≈øu≈øtenaunce and other meanes, It may therefore plea≈øe your good Lo. the premi≈ø≈øes being by your ho. tenderly con≈øidered, to graunt vnto your Lo. poore Suppliants for their pre≈øent ≈øtay, reliefe and comfort, your Honours licence for the taking and receiuing of the Almes, and charitable beneuolence of the well di≈øpo≈øed per≈øons throughout the whole Realme, vntill the ≈øaide Almes roumes ≈øhall become voide, or ≈øome other proui≈øion or maintenaunce for the reliefe of their pre≈øent nece≈ø≈øitie, ≈øuch as to your Honours ≈øhall ≈øeeme meete and conueuient may be had & made, and your ≈øaid poore Suppliants according to their bounden duties will pray to God for your good Lord≈øhips in all health & honour long to continue.

div.head: A Supplication by a Merchant ≈øtraunger, who hauing beene before called into question for co≈øening of one in a barter of Pearle for Cloth, who de≈øireth the ≈øame may be examined and ended by Aldermen of London, and other a≈ø≈øistants of skill and iudgement: And that if they cannot agree, then the Lord Maior of London to be vmpier betwixt them, or el≈øe that the ≈øame may receiue a triall in any Court of Iustice within the realme, and that in the meane time his libertie may not be impeached.

opener.salute: To the Right Honorable the Lords &c.

div.p:
IN all humblenes be≈øeecheth your honorable good Lord≈øhip I. C. of Sect'. 184. the Citie of London Merchaunt ≈øtraunger. That whereas R. S. of the ≈øame Citie Merchant taylour hath ≈øundrie times complained vnto your Honor that the ≈øaide Suppliant had co≈øened him in deliuering pearles for 185. pound, which were not worth 20. pound, in con≈øideration of a barter of cloth deliuered to your Lord≈øhips Suppliant, whereupon it plea≈øed your Lord≈øhip to graunt your warrant for the bringing of the ≈øaide Suppliant and his aged father before your good Lord≈øhip to an≈øwere to the ≈øaid ≈øuppo≈øed co≈øenage obiected again≈øt them, which they haue alreadie in ≈øome ≈øort an≈øwered, according to the ≈øhortnes of the time. But for as much as for the full and plaine di≈øcouerie of the ≈øaid pretended co≈øenage, wherewith your Lord≈øhips ≈øaid Suppliant is charged by the ≈øaide R. S. it ≈øeemeth requi≈øite that the whole proceedings in the ≈øaid barter or contract were throughly examined by ≈øome Aldermen of the Citie of London, calling vnto them for their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance therein two of the Dutch Church, of ≈øufficient iudgement and ≈økill in ≈øuch ca≈øes to be indifferently nominated by your ≈øaide Suppliant and the ≈øaid R. S. It may therefore plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip to giue full power and aucthoritie by your Honors letters to Alderman S. and E. D. one of the Dutch Church cho≈øen by your ≈øaid Suppliant (if ≈øo it may ≈øtand with the liking of your good Lord≈øhip) being of iudgement and ≈økill, and very wi≈øe and di≈øcreete men, and to an other Alderman of the ≈øaide Citie, and any other of the ≈øaid Dutch Church to be likewi≈øe nominated and appointed by the ≈øaid R. S. who may examine and try out the truth of the ≈øaide ≈øuppo≈øed co≈øenage: And that it may al≈øo plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip that the Lord Maior of the ≈øaid Citie of London may be by your Honor nominated and appointed to be vmpier in the ≈øaid cau≈øe for the finall ending thereof, if it ≈øhould ≈øo happen and fall out that the ≈øaid foure per≈øons ≈øhould not fully end the ≈øame cau≈øe betwixt the ≈øaide parties touching the ≈øaid ≈øuppo≈øed co≈øenage, to the which arbitrement & vmpiradge your ≈øaide Suppliant will willingly ≈øubmit him≈øelfe to ≈øtand vnto and performe. And if the ≈øaide cau≈øe can not by the ≈øaide arbitrators or vmpiers receiue a full and finall ende through the wilfulnes or frowardnes of the ≈øaide R. S. according to the charitable and hone≈øt intent and purpo≈øe of your Lord≈øhips ≈øaide Suppliant. Then your ≈øaid Suppliant humblie be≈øeecheth your Honor that it may be ordered by your good Lord≈øhip that the ≈øaide cau≈øe may receiue a ≈øhort, ≈øpeedie, vpright, and indifferent tryall at the Common lawe in what Court in ≈øhall plea≈øe your good Lord≈øhip to appoint. And for that your ≈øaid Suppliant doubteth lea≈øt by the practi≈øe of the
≈øaid R. S. his libertie may be impeached before the ≈øaide ≈øuppo≈øed co≈øenage may be fully tryed & ended, the petitioner therefore humblie be≈øeecheth your good Lo. that by your Lo. order his poore aged father may be protected and defended from arre≈øts or other trouble or mole≈øtation, vntill the ≈øaid cau≈øe ≈øhall receiue a full and finall end, and your ≈øaid Suppliant ≈øhall dayly pray to God for &c.

div.head: A Supplication by an Inkeeper impri≈øoned for trea≈øon vpon counterfaite letters from the priuie Coun≈øell, who being thereof afterwards di≈øcharged by letters from the Coun≈øell, had ≈øeuerall accions of det laid vpon him before his inlargement. And afterwards was from thence remoued to the Fleete, and there remayning for his det, prayeth that he may complaine of abu≈øes offered to him, and to detect others of offences and mi≈ødemeanours by them committed. And al≈øo to write letters to the Commi≈ø≈øioners for pri≈øoners for det in the Fleete, to compound all cau≈øes betwixt him and his creditors.

opener.salute: To the Right Ho. the Lords &c.

div.p:
HUmbly ≈øheweth and complaineth vnto your good Lo. your poore Sect. 185. ≈øuppliant & dayly Orator I. W. of N. now pri≈øoner in y‚Ä¢ Fleete. That where about the month of September la≈øt pa≈øt in the 32. yeare of her Maie≈øties raigne, one W. P. brought to the ≈øaid towne of N. certaine counterfait letters vnder the names of the Lo. Chancellor, Lord Trea≈øuror, and others of her Ma. mo≈øt honorable priuie Coun≈øell, with commandement to I. B. then Maior of the ≈øaid towne of N. by vertue of the ≈øaid letters, to apprehend & take your ≈øaid ≈øuppliant vpoÃÑ ≈øu≈øpition of trea≈øon, & to commit him to clo≈øe pri≈øon, with beauy irons to be laide vpoÃÑ him, the which the ≈øaid Maior executed acordingly, where your ≈øaid ≈øuppliant ≈øo continued by the ≈øpace of 5. weekes. And your ≈øuppliant being ≈øo impri≈øoned, required the ≈øaid Maior that the ≈øaid W. P. might be ≈øtayed, for that he in the ≈øame yeare had counterfaited certeine other letters vnder diuers of your Lo. hands, but the ≈øaide Maior refu≈øed to ≈øtay him becau≈øe he came with your Lo. letters to him (as he ≈øuppo≈øed) ≈øo the ≈øaid W. P. departed, leauing your ≈øaid ≈øuppliant in clo≈øe pri≈øon. Whereupon your ≈øaid poore ≈øuppliant ≈øent one to aquaint your ho. with his poore di≈øtre≈ø≈øed ca≈øe, for redre≈ø≈øe & reliefe froÃÑ your good Lo. therein, who thereupon receiued your honorable letters in your ≈øuppliants behalfe, directed vnto the ≈øaid now Maior of the ≈øaid towne of N. for his enlargement of his ≈øaid impri≈øonment. But your Lo. ≈øaid letters notwith≈øtanding, your poore ≈øuppliant was not ≈øet at libertie, but detained in pri≈øon by the ≈øpace of 8. dayes after your Lo. letters were deliuered vnto the ≈øaid Maior, by meanes whereof there was one execution for det, and diuers other Accions of debt laid vpon him to the vtter vndoing of him, his wife, & 8. poore children, your ≈øuppliant being a poore Inholder in the ≈øa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ towne of N. & hauing no other trade of liuing or meanes
to maintaine him≈øelfe & his poore family, by rea≈øon of which ≈øaid vntrue ≈ølaunder of ≈øu≈øpition of Trea≈øon, & of his long impri≈øonment of ≈øeuen months or more, he hath lo≈øt all his accu≈øtomes gue≈øts being many, which v≈øed to come to his ≈øaid hou≈øe. May it therefore plea≈øe your good Lo. the premi≈ø≈øes being by your Honors tenderly con≈øidered, & for that your ≈øaid poore ≈øuppliant vpoÃÑ his remoue to the pri≈øon of the Fleete, entered into bond to appeare before your good Lo. at what time ≈øoeuer it ≈øhould plea≈øe your Ho. to appoint im ≈øo to do, to admit your ≈øaid ≈øuppliant to complaine before your Ho. of diuers wrongs & abu≈øes offered & done vnto your poore ≈øuppliant, as al≈øo to di≈øcouer & detect y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid W. & ≈øome others his confederates of very lewd parts & offences coÃÑmitted by theÃÑ: And al≈øo y‚Ä¢ it wil plea≈øe your Ho. to graunt your letters to ye CoÃÑ mi≈ø≈øioners for poore pri≈øoners for debt in the Fleete, for y‚Ä¢ ≈øpeedy compounding & ending of all cau≈øes betwixt your ≈øaid ≈øuppliant & his creditors, and your ≈øaid ≈øuppliant as he is mo≈øt bounden ≈øhal dayly pray for your Ho. good Lord≈øhip in health and in honour long to continue.

div.head: A Supplication containing that vpon a former ≈øupplication the Coun≈øels letters were directed to a knight and others of the cuntrey where both the parties dwelled to heare and end a cau≈øe being a matter of account, whereupon the knight and the others fir≈øt wrote their letters to the parties and they not comming before them, vpon their letters they did thereupon by vertue of the Coun≈øels ≈øaid letters ≈øend their precept vnto them commaunding them to appeare before them for ending of the ≈øaid cau≈øe, who refu≈øed to come before theÃÑ, the which his contempt was by the ≈øaid knight &c. certified to the Coun≈øell again≈øt them. And now the petitioner prayeth the Coun≈øels warrant to bring the parties before the ≈øaid knight &c. for the ending of the ≈øaid cau≈øe, and if the ≈øaid parties wilfully refu≈øe to ≈øtand to and obey their order, then to commit them to the Gaole, there to remayne vntill they will be contented to obay and performe the ≈øame.

opener.salute: To the Right Honorable the Lords &c.

div.p:
HUmbly ≈øheweth vnto your good Lo. your humble ≈øuppliant N. Sect. 186. C. Clothier, that whereas vpon a former petition exhibited vnto your good Lo. declaring the iniurious, vncon≈øcionable, & ≈øini≈øter dealings of one T. N. & I. his ≈øonne, touching a matter of debt & account, which was by your ≈øaid ≈øuppliant fullie ≈øati≈øfyed: Yet continued they ≈øuite again≈øt your ≈øaid ≈øuppliant for the ≈øpace of ≈øeuen yeares together only of purpo≈øe & malice to the end to mole≈øt, trouble, & impoueri≈øh your ≈øaid ≈øuppliant, as by diuers certificates then to your Ho. by your ≈øaide ≈øuppliant ≈øhewed did fully & at large appeare, as al≈øo the lewde & euill conuer≈øation & demeanor of ye ≈øaid I. N. dulie certified vnto your good Lo. by the towne of C. in the County of S. vnder the common Seale of
the ≈øame towne: whereupon it plea≈øed your good L. to direct your honorable letters vnto Sir G. T. of A. in the ≈øaid County of S. knight, & others, to call before them the ≈øaid T. N. and all other per≈øons whom that matter did in any wi≈øe concerne, and that vpon due hearing & examination of witne≈ø≈øes vpoÃÑ both parts to be produced to proceede to the finall ending & determining thereof according to equitie & con≈øcience, and thereupon the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners according to your Lo. ≈øaid letters of Commi≈ø≈øion ≈øent fir≈øt their letters, requiring them to come before them for the ending of the ≈øaid cau≈øe: and for that they did not appeare before them vpon their ≈øaid letters, they then addre≈ø≈øed vnto theÃÑ their precept, requiring and commanding them and euery of them by vertue of your Honours ≈øaid letters of Commi≈ø≈øion to them directed, to come & appeare before them for the ending of the ≈øaid cau≈øe, both which letters & precept were deliuered by one A. B. vnto the ≈øaid T. N. who was the principall mole≈øtor & troubler of your ≈øuppliant in the≈øe cau≈øes, who albeit he had receiued the ≈øaid letters & precept, yet that notwith≈øtanding he would not appeare before the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners, but contemptuou≈øly by his letters to the CoÃÑmi≈ø≈øioners refu≈øed to appeare before them either vpoÃÑ the ≈øaid letters or the precept froÃÑ the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners, as by a Certificate froÃÑ the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners ready to be ≈øhewed vnto your good Lo. may appeare, to the great derogation & contempt of your good Lord≈øhips. May in therefore plea≈øe your Ho. for the bridling & checking of ≈øuch di≈ø≈øolute, froward, & wilfull ob≈øtinacie, to the terrifying of ≈øuch like di≈øobedient per≈øons, to graunt vnto your ≈øaid ≈øuppliant your Lo. warrant to be directed vnto the Sherife of the ≈øaid County of S. to bring the ≈øaid T. N. before the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners at ≈øuch day, houre, & place, as by letters froÃÑ the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners to the ≈øaid Sherife ≈øhalbe a≈ø≈øigned or appointed: And that if the ≈øaide T. N. being ≈øo brought before the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners ≈øhall wilfully refu≈øe to o bay & performe ≈øuch order, end, & determination, as the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners ≈øhall thinke good to ≈øet downe therein: That the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners may haue full power & Aucthority to commit the ≈øaid T. N. to the Gaole within the ≈øaid County, there to remaine vntill he will yeeld to performe and obay the order and determination of the ≈øaid Comm≈ø≈øioners, or that your good Lo. ≈øhall geue order and direction for his deliuery out of pri≈øon. And your ≈øaid Suppliant ≈øhall dayly pray for the pre≈øeruation of your good Lord≈øhips in all felicitie and happines long to continue.

div.head:
A Supplication by one for him≈øelfe and for eight other pri≈øoners endicted of murder in Wales (wrongfullie as they pretend) contayning a former Supplication, whereupon the Coun≈øell ordered that they ≈øhoulde receiue their tryals vpon the ≈øayd Indictmens of life and death in the
Countie of Salop, and not in the Countie of M. where they were indicted, praying that they might be bayled, for that he was a freeholder of good woorth, and able to put in good ≈øuertie, that the Coun≈øell would be plea≈øed to giue order by their letters to the Lo. Pre≈øident and Coun≈øell in the marches of Wales for the bayling of them.

opener.salute: To the Right Ho. the Lords &c.

div.p:
MO≈øt humbly enformeth your good Lo. your humble ≈øuppliant and Sect. 187. dayly Orator E. D. of the County of C. for him≈øelfe & 8. others, now pri≈øoners in the Gaole of M. for a ≈øuppo≈øed murthering of one M. G. who died about Penteco≈øt la≈øt pa≈øt: That whereas vpoÃÑ ≈øome ≈øodaine heate of words bariance hapning to growe betweene the ≈øame M. G. & your ≈øaid ≈øuppliant L. in the ≈øaid County of C. vpon the 28. day of May la≈øt pa≈øt, about the hauing vp of a writ of Capias, with a fee formerlie giuen for the executing of the ≈øame writ, at which time by hard hap a ≈øtander by geuing a light blowe to the ≈øaid M. G. with a ≈øtone vpon the head, whereof he neuer langui≈øhed ≈øo much as one houre in outward apparance, neither did his Chirurgion conceiue any danger to be therein, but the ≈øaid M. G. trauelled afterwards without ≈øhewe of griefe from place to place about his affaires into forraine countreys, v≈øing all exerci≈øes & di≈øports of plea≈øure, and afterwards vpon the 10. day of Iune through ≈øicknes died in the ≈øaid County of M. In which County of M. by fauour of the kinred & allies of the ≈øaid M. G. your ≈øuppliant and 11. others were uniu≈øtly endicted for y‚Ä¢ death of the ≈øaid M. G. as for murther although there were no maner of malice betwixt your Lo. ≈øaid ≈øuppliant & the ≈øaid M. G. before the ≈øaid hurt of him y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid M. G. but great good will & liking betwixt theÃÑ. For the ≈øame night that the ≈øaid M. G. was hurt as is afore≈øaid, he had appointed to lye at your Lo. ≈øaid ≈øuppliants hou≈øe, whereupon your good Lo. ≈øaid ≈øuppliant being an humble ≈øuitor to your Ho. for redre≈ø≈øe of the ≈øaid hard mea≈øure, it plea≈øed your good Lo. in your very honorable con≈øideration by order froÃÑ your Lo. to appoint the triall of your ≈øaid ≈øuppliant, & the other 8. endicted per≈øons at the A≈ø≈øi≈øes to be holden for the ≈øaid County of Salop, as a place more indiffereÃÑt & fit for the ≈øame, and yet neuertheles your ≈øaid poore ≈øuppliand & the re≈øt remaine in pri≈øon & cannot be bayled, and albeit very good & ≈øufficient bayle haue bin by your Lo. ≈øupplliant diuers times offered not only for him≈øelfe, but al≈øo for the re≈øt of the people, being endicted & impri≈øoned. And for that your ho. ≈øaid ≈øuppliant is a freeholder, of credit & worth well able to find very good & ≈øufficient ≈øuretie for his owne bayle & his ≈øaid people to appeare and an≈øwere to the ≈øaid indictment again≈øt them before the Qu. Maie≈øties Iu≈øtices of A≈ø≈øi≈øe for the ≈øaide County of Salop, at y‚Ä¢ next a≈ø≈øi≈øes to be holden within the ≈øaid County of S ‚Ä¢ lop for the ≈øaid County. It may therefore plea≈øe your good Lo. of your accu≈øtomed care and commi≈øeration of poore afflicted per≈øons
for their reliefes, to giue ≈øuch order and direction by your honours letters to be directed to the Lo. Pre≈øident and Coun≈øell of the Marches of Wales, that your Lo. ≈øaid Suppliant and his poore people may not only receiue their ≈øaid triall vpoÃÑ the ≈øaid indictment in the ≈øaid County of Salop according to your good Lo. former order & directions therein, but al≈øo that they may be pre≈øently bayled vpon good and ≈øufficient ≈øureties to be of them taken by the ≈øaid Lo. Pre≈øident and Coun≈øell for their per≈øonall appearance before the ≈øaid Iu≈øtices of A≈ø≈øi≈øe for the ≈øaid Countie of Salop at the ≈øaid next A≈ø≈øi≈øes to be holden before them for the ≈øame Countie, then and there to an≈øwere to the ≈øaid endictment, and to receiue therein according to lawe and iu≈øtice: And your ≈øaid poore Suppliant ≈øhall pray vnto God for the long pre≈øeruation of your good Lord≈øhip in health and much honour long to continue.

div.head: A Supplication to haue the Coun≈øels letters to two Bayliffes of a Towne, to take vpon them the hearing of a controuer≈øie of an Account, or el≈øe to appoint other two to do the ≈øame, and that they two to appoint an vmpier to end the matter. And if the ≈øaid vmpier cannot end it, then to certifie the Coun≈øell of the ≈øtate of the matter, and their opinions thereof, and in whom they conceiue the fault to be.

opener.salute: To the Right Honorable the Lords &c.

div.p: IN mo≈øt humble and lamentable maner ≈øheweth vnto your honorable Sect'. 188. Lord≈øhips your poore Suppliant A. B. of C. in the Countie of N. Merchant. That whereas there are diuers matters of Account in que≈øtion and controuer≈øie betweene your ≈øaid poore ≈øuppliant, & one H. B. of N. which will a≈øke & require ≈øome long time & great charges to be pro≈øecuted & determined by the due cour≈øe of the common lawes of the realme, the which would turne to the vtter vndoing of your ≈øaid ≈øuppliand, becau≈øe he is now readie with his Ship to depart towards the Straights, and therefore very vncertaine of his returne. It may therefore plea≈øe your good Lo. to graunt your Ho. letters to be directed vnto the two Bayliffes of great Yarmouth, either to heare the ≈øaid Account betwixt them, or el≈øe to appoint two other indifferent per≈øons to heare the ≈øame and that tho≈øe two may of them≈øelues appoint an vmpier to end and determine the ≈øaid controuer≈øies, vnto the which if the ≈øaid H. B. or your Ho. ≈øaid Suppliant will not yeeld vnto, that then they may certifie vnto your good Lo. the ≈øtate of the ≈øaide controuer≈øies betwixt them, with their opinions therein, and in whom they conceiue the fault to be. And your ≈øaide poore Suppliant ≈øhall be bound during his life to pray for your good Lo. increa≈øe of honour, and perpetuall felicitie.

div.head: A Supplication of H. K. and E. M. beeing pri≈øoners in the Fleete for mi≈ødemeanors ≈øenten≈øed in the Star chamber to be enlarged of their impri≈øonment.

opener.salute: To the Right Ho. the L. Keeper of the great ≈øeale of England.

div.p: THe Suppliants in Michaelmas Tearme la≈øt were ≈øenten≈øed for aSect'. 189. Riot, & other mi≈ødemeanours, and A. B. the principall defend was then al≈øo committed to the Fleete, and adiudged to pay to the Queene 100. l . for a fine, and al≈øo to di≈øcharge the fines impo≈øed vpoÃÑ ≈øuch other of the ≈øaid defendants then likewi≈øe ≈øentenced & fined as are not able to ≈øati≈øfie the ≈øame. Your Lo. ≈øaide poore Suppliants dwelling in the County of C. were brought vp by the Warden of the Fleets ≈øeruants, & are now likewi≈øe pri≈øoners in the ≈øaid pri≈øon of the Fleete for the ≈øaid offences, where they haue already remained by the ≈øpace of a fortnight & more in great mi≈øerie & want, being very poore men & very aged, and hauing nothing at all wherewith to relieue their great wants & nece≈ø≈øities more then the bare allowance of the pri≈øon, being ≈øo ≈ømall, as your poore ≈øuppliants are readie to ≈øtarue for want of meate, drinke, & other nece≈ø≈øaries, to the vtter ouerthrowing of them and their poore wiues & children, without it may plea≈øe your good Lo. ≈øpeedily to extend your commi≈øeration and pitie vpon them in ≈øetting them at libertie.

div.head: A Supplication of a pri≈øoner in the Fleete for mi≈ødemeanours cen≈øured in the Star chamber to be enlarged of his impri≈øonment, and to haue the benefit of a generall pardon, and to be di≈øcharged of one of his fines impo≈øed vpon him.

opener.salute: To the Right Ho. Sir T. E. Knight, Lord keeper of the great ≈øeale of England.

div.p:
IN all humblenes H. A. a very poore aged man of 70. yeares old andSect. 190. more now pri≈øoner in the Fleete, humbly be≈øeecheth your good Lo. That where your ≈øuppliant in the cau≈øe betweene A. B. and C. D. had in the Starrechamber two ≈øeuerall fines impo≈øed vpon him for two ≈øeuerall mi≈ødemeanours, the one a fine of 10. l . & the other a fine of 20. l . and brought out of the Countie of C. by the ≈øeruant of the deputie warden of the Fleete to the pri≈øon of the Fleete, the 10. day of this in≈øtant Iune, being as he is informed di≈øcharged and freed from the ≈øaid fir≈øt fine of 10. l . and from impri≈øonment of his bodie by her Maie≈øties mo≈øt gratious generall pardon at the la≈øt Parliament, that it would plea≈øe your good Lo. for Gods ≈øake to yeeld and allow vnto your Lo. ≈øaid ≈øuppliant the benefit of the ≈øaid generall pardon for his ≈øaid fir≈øt time, and al≈øo in your ho. and mercifull regard of his great pouertie & mi≈øerie he now lieth in to enlarge him of his ≈øaid impri≈øonment, and to di≈øcharge him of the ≈øaid fine of 20. l . and to ≈øet it ouer vpon the head of the ≈øaid
C. D. according to an order therein taken: And al≈øo to order & appoint the ≈øaid C. D. to pay your ≈øaid ≈øuppliants pri≈øon charges, hauing been drawen into that action by the ≈øaide C. D. otherwi≈øe your Lo. poore ≈øuppliant is vtterly vndone for euer, and ≈øhall neuer be able to procure his libertie, but of force mu≈øt peri≈øh in pri≈øon: And your ≈øaid poore ≈øuppliant & his poore wife and children ≈øhall dayly pray for your Lo. good and honorable e≈øtate in all health and happines long to continue.

div.head: A Supplication of a pri≈øoner in the Fleete for a mi≈ødemeanour cen≈øured in the Starre chamber to haue the benefite of a generall pardon, and to be di≈øcharged of his impri≈øonment and fine, and that in re≈øpect of his very poore estate his pri≈øon charges may be paid and di≈øcharged by one A. B. by who≈øe meanes the Suppliant was drawen into the action.

opener.salute: To the Right Ho. Sir T. E. Knight, Lord keeper of the great ≈øeale of England.

div.p: YOur Ho. very poore Suppliant H. M. being a very poore olde manSect'. 191. of aboue 80. yeares old, and weake and ≈øicklie, now pri≈øoner in the Fleete, humbly be≈øeecheth your Lo. That where your poore ≈øuppliant in a cau≈øe betweene A. M. and C. K. was fined in the Starre chamber at the ≈øumme of 5. l . and brought out of C. by the warden of the Fleets ≈øeruants to the pri≈øon of the Fleete, the 20. day of this Iuly, that he may not only be freed & di≈øcharged of the ≈øaid fine impo≈øed vpon him, but al≈øo of his ≈øaid impri≈øonment by force and vertue of a generall pardon at the la≈øt Parliament. And that your good Lo. will be plea≈øed for Gods cau≈øe to yeeld & allow vnto your poore ≈øuppliant the benefit of y‚Ä¢ ≈øaid pardon for his enlargement. And further, that it will plea≈øe your good Lo. in regard of his great pouertie being not able to relieue him≈øelfe with ≈øufficient meate and drinke, but is ready to ≈øtarue for hunger for want thereof, to take ≈øuch order that the ≈øaid C. K. by whome your ≈øaid poore ≈øuppliant hath been drawen to commit the ≈øaid mi≈ødemeanour, may pay for your ≈øaid ≈øuppliant all his fees and charges of impri≈øonment, the which if he be not compelled by your good Lo. to do, your ≈øaide poore ≈øuppliant is very likely to remayne langui≈øhing in pri≈øon all the dayes of his life, without any hope euer to be deliuered thence. And your poore ≈øuppliant will dayly pray for your good Lo. &c.

div.head: The end of Bils and An≈øweres &c.
div.p: HItherto of Bils, An≈øweres, Replications, Reioinders, &c. and ≈øuch other things as concerne the maner of proceeding in Chancery ≈øuites, with ≈øome newe additions vnto them added. Now of certaine writs and commi≈ø≈øions i≈ø≈øuing thence, and there al≈øo re ‚Ä¢ ournable.

div.head: The maner of proceeding vpon a ≈øpeciall Certiorari.
div.p: THe party grieued exhibiteth his bill, and by the ≈øame prayeth notSect. 192. only a ≈øpeciall Certiorari, but al≈øo a Subp. again≈øt the def. to an≈øwere to his bill, as appeareth by the la≈øt two bils. And if the Lord Chauncelor, Lord Keeper, or Mai≈øter of the Rols ≈øhall ≈øee good and probable matter in the bill, they v≈øually graunt the ≈øame, taking bond of the plaintife for the proofe of the ≈øurmi≈øes of his bill, within foureteene daies after the retourne of his ≈øpeciall Certiorari, which writ of Certiorari followeth in haec verba.

opener.signed: Elizabeth Dei gratia Angliae, Franciae, & Hyberniae, Regina, fidei defen≈øor &c.
opener.salute: Maiori & Vicecomitibus London ≈øalutem,

body.p: volentes certis de cau≈øis certiorari ≈øuper cau≈øa captionis & detentionis R. S. in pri≈øona ≈øub cu≈øtodia ve≈øtra, vos praefati vicecomites detenti vt dicitur, vobis mandamus, quod cau≈øam praedictam cum omnibus eam tangentibus quocunque nomine idem R. in cau≈øa illa cen≈øeatur nobis in Cancellariam no≈øtram in quindena pa≈øche prox. futurÃÑ, vbicunque tunc fuerit, ≈øub ≈øigillis ve≈øtris di≈øtincte & aperte mittatis, & hoc breue

closer.dateline: te≈øte &c.

div.p: And if the pl . do not make proofe of the ≈øurmi≈øe of his bill as afore≈øaid, then vpon certificat made vnder the hands of the examiners of this Court, and notice from the plaintifes Attourney that he hath not examined any witne≈ø≈øes either in this Court, or by Commi≈ø≈øion, then a Procedendo is graunted of cour≈øe. But if there be witne≈ø≈øes examined, then to haue their examinations referred to a Ma≈øter of the Chancery.

And if he finde and ≈øo certifie, that the plaintife hath proued the ≈øub≈øtance of his bill, then the cau≈øe to be reteined & ordered in this Court, if not, then a Procedendo to proceede for the remuanding of the ≈øaid cau≈øe.

div.head: A Corpus cum cau≈øa to remoue a Pri≈øoner.

p.hi: REgina &c. Maiori & Vicecomitibus Lond' ≈øalutem. Mandamus

vobis, quod R. S. quocunque nomine cen≈øeatÃÑ captum & in pri≈øona ≈øub cu≈øtodia ve≈øtra vos praefatÃÑ VicecomitÃÑ detentÃÑ, vt dicitur, habeatis coram nobis in CancellarÃÑ no≈øtra tali die proximÃÑ futurÃÑ, vbicunque tunc fuerit, vna cum cau≈øa captionis & detentionis ip≈øius R. in pri≈øona praedict'. Et hoc nullatenus omittatÃÑ. Et habeatis ibi hoc breue. Te≈øte &c.

div.p:
This writ is graunted by the L. Chauncelor, L. Keeper, or Ma≈øter of the Rolles, for the mo≈øt part vpon a Bill exhibited, and good baile put into the Court for the parties apparance and foorth comming, de die in diem, or further time, as the Court ≈øhall thinke fit, whereby many of her Maie≈øties ≈øubiects are verie much relieued in hard and extreame cau≈øes, lying often times in pri≈øon vpon great actions ≈øurmi≈øed
again≈øt them, without iu≈øt cau≈øe, and thereby not able to put in ≈øuch bayle, as the common Lawe doth require in ≈øuch ca≈øes.

div.head: Of a writ of Diem clau≈øit extremum.
div.p: THis writ is to be ≈øued foorth by the heire of the kings Tenant inSect'. 194. chiefe, within a yeare after the death of his aunce≈øter, or a Commi≈ø≈øion of the ≈øame effect. And an Office or Inqui≈øition being thereupon taken and retorned, ≈øuch heire may haue liuerie of his lands out of the kings hands, for if the lands of ≈øuch tenant exceede the yearely value of v. li. no Liuerie thereof can be ≈øued, before ≈øuch Inqui≈øition or office found and retorned by vertue of ≈øuch writ or Commi≈ø≈øion. And ≈øuch writ or Commi≈ø≈øion may not pa≈ø≈øe, but by warrant or bill, fir≈øt ≈øigned and ≈øub≈øcribed with the hands and names of the Ma≈øter of the Wardes and Liueries, the Surueior of the Liueries, and the Attorney of the Court of Wardes & Liueries, or ≈øome of them, 33. H. 8. cap. 22. The forme of which writ in≈øueth.

p.hi: Rex E≈øchaetori in comitÃÑ Eb. ≈øalutem. Quia I. qui de nobis tenuit in capite Diem clau≈øit extremum, vt accepimus. Tibi praecipimus, qd' oiÃÑa terras & tenÃÑta de quibus idem I. fuit ≈ø ‚Ä¢ i≈øitus in dnÃÑico ≈øuo vt de feod', in balliua tua die quo obijt, ≈øine dilatione capÃÑ in manuÃÑ nrÃÑaÃÑ, & ea ≈øaluo cu≈øtodiri facias, donec aliud inde praeciperimus: Et per ≈øacramentum proborum & legalium hominuÃÑ de eadem balliua tua, per quos rei veritas melius ≈øciri poterit diligenter inquiras, quantum terrÃÑ & tenÃÑtorum praedictus I. tenuit de nobis in capite, tam in dominico quaÃÑ in ≈øeruitio, in dict' balliua tua dict' die quo obijt, & quantum de alijs, & per quod ≈øeruitium, & quantum terrÃÑ & tenÃÑta illa valeant per annum in omnibus exitibus, & quo die idem I. obijt, & quis propinquior haeres eius ≈øit, & cuius aetatis. Et inqui≈øitionem inde di≈øtincte & aperte factam nobis in Cancellar' no≈øtram ≈øub ≈øigillo tuo, & ≈øigillis eorum, per quos facta fuerit, ≈øine dilatione mittas &c. Et hoc breue. T. &c.

div.p: But if one that holdeth of the Queenes ward by knights ≈øeruice die, the Diem clau≈øit &c. mu≈øt be thus:

p.hi: Regina dilecto &c. Quia I. de S. qui de haered' W. de O. defunct', qui de nobis tenuit in capite, infra aetatem, & in cu≈øtodia no≈øtra exi≈øtentÃÑ tenuit per ≈øeruic' MilitarÃÑ Diem clau≈øit extremum, vt accepimus. Tibi praecipimus, quod omnia terrÃÑ & tenÃÑtÃÑ &c. per ≈øacramentum &c. quantum terrarum & tenementorum idem I. tenuit de haered' praedictÃÑ. Et quis propinquior haeres eius ≈øit &c. vt ≈øupra.

div.head: And if the Queenes warde, Thus:
div.p:
Regina &c. Quia R. de H. filius & haeres I. de H. defuncti, qui de nobis tenuit in capite, nuper dum infra aetatem & in cu≈øtod' no≈øtra fuit, Diem clau≈øit extremum, vt accepimus. Tibi praecipimus, quod per ≈øacramentum
&c. inquiras, quae terrae & quae tenÃÑta per mortem praedic ‚Ä¢ I. & ratione minoris aetatis haered' praedictÃÑ I. ad manus nrÃÑas deuenerÃÑ, & ≈øic in manu no≈øtrÃÑ exi≈øtunt, & quantum inde de nobistenetur in capite, & quantum de alijs, & per quod ≈øeruitium, & quantum &c.
But if the wife of the Queenes tenant which holdeth in Dower dye, his Heire being the Queenes warde, then the Diem clau≈øit extremum mu≈øt be made thus:

Rex dilecto ≈øibi N. de B. Maiori ciuitatis ≈øuae London, & E≈øchaetori ≈øuo in eadem Ciuitate ≈øalutem. Quia E. quae fuit vxor I. de B. nuper defunct', quae qua≈ødam terras & quaedam tenementa de nobis tenuit in dotem de haereditate pÃÑdict' I. quondam viri≈øui, Diem clau≈øit extremum, vt accepimus. Tibi praecipimus, quod omnia terras & tenÃÑta, quae ‚Ä¢ adem E. ≈øic tenuit in dotem de haereditate pÃÑdicta in balliua tua &c. per ≈øacramentum &c. diligenter inquiras, quas terras & quae tenementa eadem E. ≈øic tenuit in dotem de haereditate pÃÑdictÃÑ in balliua tua, die quo obijt, & quantum inde de nobis tenetur in capite, & quantum de alijs, & per quod ≈øeruitium &c.
If the Queene haue the ward≈øhip of a reuer≈øion, and the tenant for life die, then thus.

Quia A. qua≈ødam terras & quaedam tenementa de haered' E. con≈øanguinei & haered' H. de P. defuncti, qui de rege tenuit in capite, infra aetatem & in cu≈øtod' regis exi≈øtentÃÑ tenuit ad terminum vitae ≈øuae, Diem clau≈øit extremÃÑ &c. tibi praecipimus &c.
After the death of the tenant by the Curte≈øie, thus.
Quia A. qui qua≈ødam terras & quedam tenÃÑta de nobis tenuit per legem Angliae de haered' M. vxoris ≈øuae dudum defunctae, Diem clau≈øit extremum, tibi praecipimus &c.
But if the Queene haue a remainder, and her tenaunt for life dieth, then mu≈øt the Writ be thus.

Quia A. quae fuit vxor &c. qui qua≈ødam terras & quaedam tenementa tenuit ad vitam ≈øuam & quae po≈øt mortem ip≈øius A. nobis & haered' nrÃÑis remanerÃÑ debent, Diem clau≈øit extremum &c. tibi praecipimus &c. qui eadem ≈øic tenuit & quae po≈øt mortem &c. remanerÃÑ debent &c. vel ≈øic po≈øt mortÃÑ praedict' B. ad manus no≈øtras ratione minoris etatis praefatÃÑ haered' deuenerÃÑ &c.
But if the temporalties of a Bi≈øh. be in the Queenes hands, and one that holdeth of the Bi≈øhopricke by knights ≈øeruice dieth, the Diem clau≈øit extremum mu≈øt be thus.

Regina &c. Quia A. de Archiepi≈øcopatu CantuarÃÑ vacantÃÑ & in manu no≈øtra exi≈øtentÃÑ tenuit per ≈øeruic' militare, Diem clau≈øit extremum &c. tibi praecipimus &c. de quibus idem A. fuit ≈øei≈øitus in dominico ≈øuo vt de feodo &c. & tenuit de Archiepi≈øcopatu praed' ≈øine dilatione &c.

div.head: But if the Queenes Idiot die, the writ mu≈øt be ≈øuch.
div.p:
Quia B. de C. nuper fatuus & Idiota, cuius terrae & tenÃÑta ratione fatuitatis eiu≈ødeÃÑ B. in manu nrÃÑa exi≈øtunt, diem &c. vt accepimus, tibi pÃÑcipimus
quam Íùë ≈øacramentÃÑ &c. diligenter inqui ‚Ä¢ as, quae terrae & quae tenÃÑta ratione fatuitatis pÃÑd' B. in manuÃÑ nrÃÑam capta fuerunt, & adhuc in manu nrÃÑa exi≈øtunt, & de quo vel de quibus teneantur, & Íùë quod ≈øeruitiuÃÑ, & quantuÃÑ terrae illae valeant &c. & quis propinquior &c. & inqui≈øitÃÑ &c.

div.head: Datur nobis intelligi.
div.p:
ANd if the E≈øchea ‚Ä¢ or receiue a Diem ciau≈øit extremum, and die,
Sect. 195. or be otherwi≈øe remoued from his office before execution thereof, then i≈ø≈øueth a writ of Datur nobis intelligi in this forme.

Regina &c. Cum nuper datur nobis intelligi quod I. de B. qui de nobis tenuit in capite, Diem clau≈øit extremum, praeceperimus dilect' nobis W. de O. nuper E≈øchaetori nrÃÑo in comitatu praedict' quod omnia terras & tenements &c. vt ≈øupra, Mutatis mutandis. Ac idem W. ab offic' praedictÃÑ iam ≈øit amotus, per quod executio breuis no≈øtri praedictÃÑ fieri non pote≈øt: Nos ≈øuper praemi≈ø≈øis volentÃÑ cerciorari: Tibi praecipimus, quod per≈øacramentum &c. diligenter ≈øuper praemi≈ø≈ø‚ñ™ facias inqui≈øitionem, & etiam di≈øtincte &c. T. &c.

div.head: Or thus.
div.p: Regina dilecto &c. Cum nuper datur nobis intelligi, quod I. de B. qui de nobis tenuit in capite, Diem clau≈øit extremum, praeceperimus dilecto & fideli no≈øtro H. de B. nuper E≈øchaetori no≈øtro in eodem ComÃÑ, quod omnes terras &c. ≈øine dilatione caperet in manum no≈øtram &c. donec aliud inde praecepi≈ø≈øemus, & per ≈øacramentum &c. inquiret, quantum terrae &c. vt in primo breui. Ac idem H. antequam praedictÃÑ breue fuerat executum, ab officio praedictÃÑ fuerat amotus: Nos volentes ≈øuper praemi≈ø≈øis plenius cerciorari, ‚Ä¢ ibi praecipimus, quod ≈øuper articulis praedict' & eorum ≈øingulis diligenter facias inqui≈øic', & eam di≈øtincte & aperte fact' &c. vt ≈øupra &c.

p.hi:
But if the fir≈øt E≈øcheator execute the writ, and die before the inqui≈øition
‚Ä¢ e returned into the Chauncery, then a Certiorare ≈øhall be awarded to his Executors, or Admini≈øtrators, to certi≈ø ‚Ä¢ e the ≈øame inqui≈øition, for it is a matter of Record ≈øo ≈øoone as the Iurors haue found and ≈øealed it.

div.head: Of a Mandamus.

p.hi: IF the Kings tenant by Knights ≈øeruice die, his heire within age, and
no writ of Diem clau≈øit extremum be awarded within a yeare after his death, then ≈øhall i≈ø≈øue a Mandamus in this forme.

div.p:
Rex dilecto ≈øibi W. de B. E≈øchaetori ≈øuo in comÃÑ B. Salutem. Praecipimus tibi quod per ≈øacramentum proborum & legalium hominum de balliua tua, per quos &c. diligenter inquiras, quas terras & quae tenÃÑta I. de B. tenuit de nobis in capite, tam in dominico quam in ≈øeruitio in balliua tua die quo obijt, & quaÃÑtum de alijs, & per
quam ≈øeruitium, & quantum terrae & tenÃÑta illa valeant per annum in omnibus exitibus, & quo tempore idem I. obijt, & quis propinquior &c. & cuius aetatis, & quis vel qui terras & tenÃÑta illa a tempore mortis praed' occupauit vel occupÃÑ, & exitus & proficua inde praecepit vel praeceperunt, quo titulo & qualitÃÑ, & quo modo &c. Et inqui≈øitionem &c.

THe heire ≈øhall haue but one writ of Diem clau≈øit extremum only Sect. 197. within a yere after his aunce≈øters death: But where thance≈øter died ward to the Queene and within age, for then a new Diem clau≈øit extremum ≈øhall be a warded a yeare after the Infants death, and not a Mandamus, per Regi≈øt. fol.

div.head: Of Commi≈ø≈øions after the death of the Queenes tenant.
div.p: AL≈øo the heire of the Kings tenant by Knights ≈øeruice in chiefe, Sect'. 198. may ≈øue forth a ≈øpeciall Commi≈ø≈øion, directed to certaine per≈øons, to inquire what lands &c. (as aboue in a Diem clau≈øit extremum,) which Commi≈ø≈øion will he as beneficiall for the heire, as a Diem clau≈øit extremum: For vpon Inqui≈øition taken by ≈øuch a Commi≈ø≈øion, retornable into the Chauncerie, ‚Ä¢ e may haue Liuerie at his full age. But he ≈øhall neuer haue Liuerie vpon a generall Commi≈ø≈øion to inquire of all Wardes &c.

div.head: Quae plura.
div.p: THis writ lyeth when any of the Heires lands be omitted in a former Sect. 199. office or inqui≈øition, to finde the lands ≈øo omitted, and is ≈øuch.

Rex E≈øchaetori ≈øuo &c. ≈øalutem. Quia datum e≈øt nobis intelligi quod A. defunctus qui de nobis tenuit in capite, tenuit die quo obijt plura terras & tenÃÑta in comitatÃÑ praedict', quam tu in inqui≈øitione inde po≈øt mortem pÃÑdictÃÑ A. de mandato no≈øtrÃÑ capta, & in Cancell' no≈øtrÃÑ retornata ≈øpecificantur. Tibi praecipimus, quod per≈øacramentum proborum &c. inquiras quae plura terras & tenÃÑta idem A. tenuit in comÃÑ pÃÑdict', die quo obijt, & de quo, vel de quibus illa plura terrae & tenÃÑta teneantur, & per
quam ≈øeruitium, & quantum valeant per annum in omnibus exitibus. Et inqui≈øitionem &c.

div.head: Melius inquirendum.
div.p:
THis writ lyeth where an office found by vertue of a Diem clau≈øit
Sect. 200. extremum or Commi≈ø≈øion is vncertaine in the tenure, value, or
tenants e≈øtate of the lands, or otherwi≈øe. But if ≈øuch incertaine office be found before the E≈øcheator ratione officij only, then it is void, and no Melius inquirendum ≈øhall thereupon be awarded. And the Melius inquirendum is ≈øuch.

p.hi: Rex E≈øcheatori ≈øuo &c. Salutem. Cum per quandam inqui≈øitionem coram A. E≈øchaetore no≈øtro in comÃÑ praedicto de mandato no≈øtro captam, & in Cancellaria no≈øtra retornatÃÑ ≈øit compertum, quod N. defunctus tenuit diuer≈øa terras & tenÃÑta cum pertinentijs in comitatu predicto, & quis propinquior haeres eiu≈ødem N. ≈øit ex parte patris ≈øui, iuratores inqui≈øitionis predicti ignorant: Tamen ex parte R. matris praedicti N. filiae W. B. e≈øt eius haeres propinquior, & aetatis viginti & vnius annorum & amplius. Et quia in inqui≈øitione praedict' quis propinquior haeres ip≈øius N. exi≈øtat minime ≈øpecificatur: tibi praecipimus quod per ≈øacramentum &c. inquiras, quis propinquior haeres praedicti N. exi≈øtat, qualiter & quo modo. Et inqui≈øitionem &c. T. &c.

div.p: And this writ is grauntable vpon ≈øurmi≈øe made in the court, that ≈øuch former Office is ≈øo incerteine, as is aboue≈øaid.

div.head: Another Melius inquirend' po≈øt inqui≈øitionem imperfectam.
div.p: Rex e≈øchaetori ≈øuo &c. Cum per inqui≈øitionem coram te de mandato no≈øtro &c. compertum ≈øit, quod A. tenuit die quo obijt vnum me≈ø≈øuag' in N. in comÃÑ praedicto de B. per ≈øeruitiuÃÑ militare, quodque idem A. tenuit die quo obijt vnum toftum cum pertinentijs in N. in comitatu praedicto, de haerede F. L. per ≈øeruitium militare, & quia in inqui≈øitione praedicta qualem ≈øtatum & quale ius idem A. habuit in me≈ø≈øuagio & tofto praedictis, ≈øeu de quo vel de quibus eadeÃÑ me≈ø≈øuagium & toftum teneantur minime ≈øpecificatur: nos volentes inde per te plenius Cerciorari, tibi praecipimus &c. inquiras, qualem ≈øtatum, & quale ius idem A. habuit in me≈ø≈øuagio & tofto praed die quo obijt, & de quo vel de quibus me≈ø≈øuagium & toftum praedict' teneantur, & per quod ≈øeruitium, qualiter & quomodo. Et inqui≈øitionem &c. T. &c.

div.head: A Writ de aetate probanda.

p.hi: IT behoueth the heire of the Queenes tenant in chief being in ward,

at his full age, and before liuery, to haue a writ to the E≈øcheator of the Countie where he was borne, to prooue his age. And it ≈øeemeth, that ≈øuch writ may as well be made to the E≈øcheator of the Countie where his land lyeth, for it may be he was borne where the Kings writ runneth not: as in Ireland, Calice. Berwike, &c.

div.p:
Rex dilecto ≈øibi I. de B. E≈øchaetori ≈øuo in comÃÑ B. ≈øalutem. Quia A. de B. qui M. ≈øororem‚ñ™ & vnam haer' R. defuncti, qui de dnÃÑo Edw. nuper Rege Angliae auo no≈øtro tenuit in capite duxit in vxorem, dicit praefatÃÑ M. plenae aetatÃÑ e≈ø≈øe, & petit a nobis terras & tenementa, que ≈øunt de haereditate
ip≈øius M. & quorum vna pars in manu no≈øtra, & alia pars i ‚Ä¢ cu≈øtodia I. de H. ex commi≈ø≈øione dicti aui no≈øtri v≈øque ad legitimam aetatem haered' eiu≈ødem exi≈øtunt ≈øibi reddend', per quod volumus, quod eadem M. quae apud G. in comitÃÑ M. nata e≈øt, & in Eccle≈øia eiu≈ødem villae, baptizatÃÑ fuit vt dicitur, aetatem ≈øuam probet coram te. Tibi praecipimus, quod ad certum diem & locum, quos ad hoc prouideris, probationem illam per ≈øacramentÃÑ, tam militÃÑ quam proborÃÑ & legalium hominum de balliua tua, per quos probatio illa capi, & veritas aetatis pÃÑd‚ñ™ melius ≈øciri poterit & inquiri, capias, & ≈øc. fa. praef. I. quod tunc ≈øit ibi ad o≈øtendend' ≈øi quid pro ≈øe habeat vel dicere ≈øciat quare praed' H. & pÃÑd' M. vt illi qui plenae aetatis e≈øt, ≈øi plene aetatis ≈øit, terras & tenementa praed' reddere non debeamus, & probationem illam ≈øic captam nobis ≈øub ≈øigillo tuo, & ≈øigillis eorum per quos capta fuerit, ≈øine dilatione mittas, & hoc breue. Te≈øte &c.

div.head: Another forme of the writ De Aetate probanda.

p.hi: REx &c. Quia M. de F. filius & haeres I. defuncti, qui de nobis tenuit in capite, dicit ≈øe plenae aetatis e≈ø≈øe, & petit a nobis terras & tenÃÑta quae ≈øunt de haereditatÃÑ ≈øua & in cu≈øtodia no≈øtra, v≈øque ad legitimam aetatem hered' praed' ≈øibi reddi, per quod volumus quod &c. v≈øque ibi melius ≈øciri poterit & inquiri capias, & tunc ≈øic. Et probationem illam &c. vt ≈øupra.

div.p: But if the King commit the Ward≈øhip, the Aetate probanda mu≈øt mention the ≈øame.
And if the Ward≈øhip by rea≈øon of the temporalities of a Bi≈øhopricke be in the Queenes hands, the writ de Aetate probanda mu≈øt mention the ≈øame: And yet that is no Court in capite.

div.head: Commi≈ø≈øion pro aetate probanda.
div.p: Regina dilectis &c. Sciatis quod a≈ø≈øignauimus vos ad inquirend' per ≈øacramentum tam Militum quam aliorum proborum & legalium hominum de vi≈øinetÃÑ de N. in comÃÑ L. ≈øi I. filius & h ‚Ä¢ res B. apud N. natus, & in eccle≈øia eiu≈ødem villae baptizatus fuit, & quod ratione minoris aetatis ≈øuae in cu≈øtodia nrÃÑa exi≈øtit, plenae aetatis ≈øit, vt dicit, necne. Et ideo vobis mandauimus, quod ad certos diem & locum, quos ad hoc prouideritis, inqui≈øitionem illam faciatis, & illam di≈øtincte & aperte factam nobis in CancellarÃÑ &c. ≈øine dilatione mittatis, & hoc breue. Mandauimus enim Vicec' no≈øtro LincolnÃÑ, quod ad diem & locum, quos ei ≈øcire facietÃÑ venire faciat &c. In cuius rei te≈øtimonium &c.

p.hi: And vpon this Commi≈ø≈øion a writ ≈øhall be ≈øent to the Shirife to returne a panel before the Commi≈ø≈øioners at a certaine day before them limitted vnto him by their Precept. Thus:

div.head: A Venire facias to the Shirife vpon the ≈øame Commi≈ø≈øion.
div.p:
REgina VicecomitÃÑ &c. Praecipimus tibi, quod ≈øummonÃÑ per bonosSect. 202 ≈øummonitÃÑ xij. tam Milites, quam alios probos & legales homines de vi≈øinetÃÑ de N. quod ≈øint coram dilectis & fidelibus no≈øtris A. B. & C. & hijs quos ≈øibi a≈ø≈øociauerimus, ad certos diem & locum, quos ijdem A. B. & C. tibi ≈øcire facient, parati ≈øacramÃÑto recogno≈øcere, ≈øi F. filius & haeres C. apud N. natus, & in eccle≈øia eiu≈ødem villae baptiz. fuit, qui ratione minoris aetatis ≈øuae in cu≈øtodia no≈øtra exi≈øtit, plenae aetatis ≈øit, vt dicit necne, & interim ad pÃÑd' eccle≈øiam & villam accedant, vt veritatem aetatis pÃÑd', diligenter inquirant, & nomina eorum imbreuiari faciant. Et ≈øci. fac. E. & S. cu≈øtodibus terrÃÑ praed' herÃÑ,
quam tunc ≈øint ibi ad audiend' illam recognÃÑ, & ad o≈øtend' ≈øi quid ob≈øtare debeat, quare praed' I. terras & tenementa ≈øua habere non debeat, & habeas ibi nomina illorum duodecim & hoc breue, Te≈øte &c.

Whereby appeareth that the committee of the King ≈øhall be warned to be there. But if the King haue the Ward in his owne hands, then this clau≈øe Et ≈øcire facias E. & S. cu≈øtodibus &c. ≈øhall be omitted in the writ.

div.head: Of Homage done or re≈øpited.

p.hi: WHen a writ de Aetate probanda is executed and returned, and

that the heire hath proued his age, then he mu≈øt do homage, or agree with the Queene to re≈øpect the ≈øame, and pay reliefe before liuery ≈øued: and a writ te≈øtifying homage to be done, when the heire is at full age at the death of his aunce≈øtors.

div.p: Regina E≈øchaetorÃÑ &c. Sciatis quod cepimus homagium I. de H. filij & hered' B. de H. defuncti, de omnibus terris & tenemÃÑtis que idem B. pater ≈øuus tenuit de nobis in capite die quo obijt, & ei terras & tenÃÑta illa reddidimus: Et ideo tibi praecipimus, quod accepta ≈øecuritatÃÑ a praef. I. de rationabili releuio ≈øuo nobis ≈øoluend', ad Scaccarium nrÃÑum, eid' I. de omnibus terris & tenemÃÑtis praed', & de quibus praef. B. pater ≈øuus fuit ≈øei≈øitus in dnÃÑico ≈øuo vt de feodo in balliua tua, die quo obijt, queque occa≈øione mortis eiu≈ød' B. captÃÑ ≈øunt in manum nrÃÑam, plenam ≈øei≈øinam habere facias: Saluo iure cuiu≈ølibet, & ≈øalua Matildae que fuit vxor B. rationabili dote ≈øua, ip≈øam de terris & tenementis praed', ≈øecundum legem & con≈øuetudinem regni no≈øtri Angliae contingentÃÑ, ei per nos a≈ø≈øignand'. Te≈øte meip≈øa. &c.

p.hi: But if the heire were in ward, and hath proued his age, the writ of the homage receiued mu≈øt be thus.

div.p:
Regina &c. Quia N. de E. fil' & haeres R. de C. defuncti, qui de domino Ed. nuper Rege Angl. auo no≈øtro tenuit in capite, aetatem ≈øuaÃÑ coraÃÑ
te ≈øufficienter probauit, ≈øicut per probationem de mandato no≈øtro captam, & in CancellarÃÑ no≈øtram retornatÃÑ, e≈øt compertum, ceperimus homagium ip≈øius N. de omnibus terris & tenemÃÑtis quae idem R. pater ≈øuus tenuit de dicto auo no≈øtro in capite, die quo obijt, & ei terras & tenementa illa reddidimus. Ideo tibi pÃÑcipimus, quod eidem N. de omnibus terris & tenementis praedict' de quibus praedict' R. pater ≈øuus fuit ≈øei≈øitus in dominico ≈øuo vt de feodo in balliua tua die quo obijt, & per mortem eiu≈ødem R. in manum dicti aui no≈øtri capta fuerÃÑ, & in manu no≈øtrÃÑ ≈øic capta exi≈øtunt, plenam ≈øei≈øinam habere facias, ≈øaluo iure cuiu≈ølibet. Te≈øte &c.

div.head: Diem claufit extremum po≈øt mortem felonis.

p.hi: WHen the King hath the lands of the Wife, by rea≈øon that her
Hu≈øband was outlawed for felonie, then after the Hu≈øbands death the Diem clau≈øit extremum is ≈øuch.

div.p: Quia A. cuius terrae & tenemÃÑta, que ip≈øe tenuit de iure & haereditate N. nuper vxoris ≈øuae, ad huc ≈øuper≈øtitit, ad manus domini E. nuper Regis Angl' 4. po≈øt conque≈øtum‚ñ™ occa≈øione cuiu≈ødam vtlagariae in ip≈øum A. pro quadam felonia, vnde indictatus fuit, vt dicitÃÑ, promulg', deuenerÃÑ in manu domini H. &c. patris no≈øtri extiterunt, & ≈øic in manu no≈øtra exi≈øtunt, diem clau≈øit extremum &c. Tibi praecipimus quod per ≈øacrameÃÑ tum &c. inquiras que tenÃÑta, ratione feloniae praed', ad manus ip≈øorum nuper regis deuenerÃÑ, & ad huc in manu no≈øtra ≈øic exi≈øtunt, & de quo vel de quibus teneantur, & per quod ≈øeruitium, & qualiter, & quo modo, & quantum terrae & tenemÃÑta illa valeant per annum in omnibus exitibus iuxta verum valorem ‚Ä¢ orundem, & quis vel quiterras & tenementa illa a tempore perpetrationis feloniae praed' occupauit, vel occupauerunt, & exitus & proficua inde percepit vel perceperunt, quo titulo, qualiter, & quomodo, & inqui≈øitÃÑ &c.
